title: Micronutrient Information Center
author: Cognitive function
cleaned_text: The Linus Pauling Institute's Micronutrient Information Center is a source for scientifically accurate information regarding the roles of vitamins, minerals, phytochemicals (plant chemicals that may affect health), and other dietary factors, including some food and beverages, in preventing disease and promoting health. All of the nutrients and dietary factors included in the Micronutrient Information Center may be obtained from the diet, and many are also available as dietary supplements. The Linus Pauling Institute's Micronutrient Information Center (MIC) is a source for scientifically accurate information on the functions and health effects of all micronutrients (vitamins and nutritionally essential minerals); other nutrients like choline and essential fatty acids; dietary factors, including many phytochemicals (non-nutritive plant chemicals that may affect health); and some food and beverages, including tea, coffee, and alcohol. All of the nutrients and dietary factors included in the MIC may be obtained from the diet, and many are also available as dietary supplements; dietary and supplemental sources are discussed in each article. Human research is emphasized in the MIC, although cell culture or animal studies may be mentioned when human studies are lacking. Most MIC articles have summaries at the beginning and include the following subsections: Function or Biological Activities, Metabolism and Bioavailability, Deficiency, The RDA or AI (for males and females of various age groups), Disease Prevention, Disease Treatment, Sources (food and supplements), and Safety (toxicity and drug or nutrient interactions). For the micronutrients (vitamins and essential minerals), the Linus Pauling Institute provides a daily intake recommendation. For each article, Ph.D. nutrition scientists critically review and synthesize basic, clinical, and epidemiological studies in the peer-reviewed literature and provide references throughout. Each article is then additionally reviewed by an expert in the field; the names of the authors and reviewers are listed at the bottom of each article. This multiple review process minimizes bias and presents objective information. In order to keep this website freely available (and free from ads), we rely on outside funding. This comes in part from corporate sponsorships. We provide information about corporate funders, if applicable, at the bottom of each article. We thank DSM Nutritional Products, LLC for providing general funding to develop content on health and disease topics. The [Micronutrient Information Center staff](staff) can be contacted directly though The term vitamin is derived from the words vital and amine, because vitamins are required for life and were originally thought to be amines. Although not all vitamins are amines, they are organic compounds required by humans in small amounts from the diet. An organic compound is considered a vitamin if a lack of that compound in the diet results in overt symptoms of deficiency. The information from the Linus Pauling Institute's Micronutrient Information Center on vitamins and minerals is now available in a book titled, An Evidence-based Approach to Vitamins and Minerals: Health Benefits and Intake Recommendations. The book can be purchased from the [Linus Pauling Institute](../../publications/books) or [Thieme Medical Publishers](http://www.thieme.com/books-main/complementary-medicine/product/1040-an-evidence-based-approach-to-vitamins-and-minerals). Select a vitamin from the list for more information. Contents Biotin is a water-soluble [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin) that is generally classified as a B-complex vitamin. After its initial discovery in 1927, 40 years of additional research was required to unequivocally establish biotin as a vitamin [(1)](#references). Biotin is required by all organisms but can be [synthesized](../glossary#synthesis) by some strains of [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria), yeast, mold, algae, and some plant species [(2)](#reference2). Biotin functions as a [covalently](../glossary#covalent) bound [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) required for the biological activity of the five known mammalian biotin-dependent [carboxylases](../glossary#carboxylase) (see [below](#enzyme-cofactor)). The covalent attachment of biotin to the apocarboxylase (i.e., the carboxylase protein without the biotin prosthetic group and is is [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme), "biotinylation" refers to the covalent addition of biotin to any molecule, including the apocarboxylases [histones](../glossary#histone). HCS catalyzes the post-translational biotinylation of the epsilon amino group of a lysine residue at the active site of each apocarboxylase, converting the inactive apocarboxylase into a fully active holocarboxylase (Figure 1a). ACC1 is located in the cytosol, and the malonyl CoA generated by ACC1 is a rate-limiting substrate for the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of [fatty acids](../glossary#fatty-acid) (Figure 2). ACC1 is found in all tissues and is particularly active in [lipogenic](../glossary#lipogenesis) tissues (i.e., liver, white adipose tissue, and mammary gland), heart, and [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) islets. ACC2 is located on the outer mitochondrial membrane, and the malonyl CoA generated via ACC2 inhibits CPT1, an [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) that regulates malonyl-CoA entry into the inner mitochondria, thereby regulating fatty acid [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) (Figure 3). ACC2 is especially abundant in skeletal muscle and heart [(4)](#reference4). Pyruvate carboxylase is a critical enzyme in [gluconeogenesis](../glossary#gluconeogenesis) (the formation of [glucose](../glossary#glucose) from sources other than [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate), the [citric acid cycle](../glossary#citric-acid-cycle) (Figure 3). Oxaloacetate can then be converted to phosphoenolpyruvate and eventually to glucose. Methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase catalyzes an essential step in the [catabolism](../glossary#catabolism) an essential [branched-chain amino acid](../glossary#branched-chain-amino-acids). This -oxidation of fatty acids with an odd number of carbon atoms (Figure 4a). The conversion of propionyl-CoA to D-malonylmalonyl-CoA is also required in the catabolic pathways of two branched-chain amino acids (isoleucine and valine) and the side chain of [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) (Figure 4a) and of the amino acids [methionine](../glossary#methionine) and threonine (Figure 4b). In eukaryotic [nuclei](../glossary#nucleus), [DNA](../glossary#DNA) is packaged into compact structures to form [nucleosomes](../glossary#nucleosome) — fundamental units of [chromatin](../glossary#chromatin). Each nucleosome is composed of 147 base pairs of DNA wrapped around eight [histones](../glossary#histone) (paired located at the outer surface of each nucleosome and serves as an anchor to fix the DNA around the histone core. The compact packaging of chromatin must be relaxed for DNA replication and [transcription](../glossary#transcription). Chemical modifications of DNA and histones affect the folding of chromatin, increasing or reducing DNA accessibility to factors involved in replication and transcription. DNA [methylation](../glossary#methylation) and a number of chemical modifications within the N-terminal tail of core histones modify their electric charge and structure, thereby changing chromatin conformation and transcriptional activity of [genes](../glossary#gene). regulatory functions. Several sites of biotinylation have been identified in histones lysine (K) 12 (noted H4K12bio) appears to be enriched in heterochromatin, a tightly condensed chromatin associated with repeat regions in (peri)centromeres and [telomeres](../glossary#telomere). H4 biotinylation appears to be enriched in transposable elements known as long terminal repeats [(3)](#reference3). These biotinylation marks also co-localize with well-known gene For example, H4K12bio can be found at the [promoter](../glossary#promoter) of the gene SLC5A6 that codes for the transporter mediating biotin uptake into cells, the human sodium-dependent multivitamin biotin H4 in the SLC5A6 promoter, which down regulates hSMVT synthesis and reduces biotin uptake. Conversely, in biotin-deficient cells, biotinylation marks in the SLC5A6 promoter are removed increasing [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression) and enabling the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of hSMVT and uptake of biotin [(7)](#reference7). Although clinically overt biotin deficiency is very rare, the human requirement for dietary biotin has been demonstrated in three different situations: prolonged [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) feeding ( [parenteral](../glossary#parenteral-nutrition)) without biotin [supplementation](../glossary#supplement), infants fed an elemental formula devoid of biotin, and consumption of raw egg white for a prolonged period (many weeks to years) [(8)](#reference8). Raw egg white contains avidin; this [antimicrobial](../glossary#antimicrobial) protein binds biotin with an affinity and specificity that is almost unique as a reversible binding. Because native avidin is resistant to mammalian and microbial digestion, avidin prevents biotin absorption. Cooking egg white denatures avidin, rendering it susceptible to digestion and therefore unable to block the absorption of dietary biotin [(5)](#reference5). Signs of overt biotin deficiency include hair loss ( [alopecia](../glossary#alopecia)) and a scaly red rash around the eyes, nose, mouth, and genital area. [Neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) symptoms in adults have included depression, lethargy, hallucinations, numbness and tingling of the extremities, [ataxia](../glossary#ataxia), and [seizures](../glossary#seizure). The characteristic facial rash, together with unusual facial fat distribution, has been termed the "biotin deficient facies" by some investigators [(1)](#references). Individuals with hereditary disorders of biotin [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) (see [Inborn metabolic disorders](#inborn-metabolic-disorders)) that result in functional biotin deficiency often have similar physical findings, impaired immune system function, and increased susceptibility to [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) and fungal infections [(9, 10)](#reference9). Aside from prolonged consumption of raw egg white or total [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) nutritional support lacking biotin, other conditions may increase the risk of biotin depletion. Smoking has been associated with increased biotin [catabolism](../glossary#catabolism) [(11)](#reference11). The rapidly dividing cells of the developing fetus require biotin for [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of essential [carboxylases](../glossary#carboxylase) and for [histone](../glossary#histone) biotinylation; hence, the maternal biotin requirement is likely increased during pregnancy. Research suggests that a substantial number of women develop marginal or [subclinical](../glossary#subclinical) biotin deficiency during normal pregnancy (see also [Disease Prevention](#disease-prevention)) [(8](#reference8), [12, 13)](#reference12). Moreover, certain types of liver disease may decrease biotinidase activity and theoretically increase the requirement for biotin. For example, a study of 62 children with chronic liver disease and 27 healthy controls found [serum](../glossary#serum) biotinidase activity to be abnormally low in those with severely impaired liver function due to [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis) [(14)](#reference14). However, this study did not provide evidence of biotin deficiency. Additionally, [anticonvulsant](../glossary#anticonvulsant) medications used to prevent [seizures](../glossary#seizure) in individuals with [epilepsy](../glossary#epilepsy) increase the risk of biotin depletion (for more information on biotin and anticonvulsants, see [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions)). Biotinidase deficiency is an [autosomal](../glossary#autosomal) [recessive](../glossary#recessive-trait) inherited disorder that is often detected upon newborn screening for metabolic disorders, although late-onset forms have been recently described [(15-17)](#reference15). Biotinidase deficiency leads to secondary biotin deficiency in several ways. Intestinal absorption is decreased because deficient biotinidase impairs release of biotin from dietary [protein](../glossary#protein) [(18)](#reference18). of intracellular biotin bound to [carboxylases](../glossary#carboxylase) and [histones](../glossary#histone) is also impaired, and urinary loss of biocytin (N-biotinyl-lysine) biotin is increased deficiency responds to [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) biotin. Oral supplementation with as much as 5 to 20 milligrams (mg) of biotin daily is sometimes required [(19, 20)](#reference19), although smaller doses may be sufficient, especially later in childhood (reviewed in [20, 21](#reference20)). [Prognosis](../glossary#prognosis) is characteristically good when biotin therapy is introduced in infancy or early childhood and reliably continued for life [(10)](#reference10). Holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency results in decreased formation of blood responds to supplementation with [pharmacologic doses](../glossary#pharmacological-dose) of biotin in some cases but not others. The [prognosis](../glossary#prognosis) of holocarboxylase synthetase is usually, but not always, good if biotin therapy is introduced early (even [antenatally](../glossary#antenatal)) and continued for life [(10](#reference10), [22)](#reference22). There has been one [case report](../glossary#case-report) of a child with biotin transport deficiency who responded to high-dose biotin supplementation [(23)](#reference23). Of note, the presence of a defective human sodium-dependent multivitamin transporter (hSMVT) was ruled out as a cause of biotin transport deficiency. Four measures of marginal biotin deficiency have been validated as indicators of biotin [status](../glossary#status): and (1) reduced levels of holo-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase and holo-propionyl-CoA carboxylase in lymphocytes, the most of biotin status [(24)](#reference24); (2) reduced propionyl-CoA carboxylase activity in peripheral blood [lymphocytes](../glossary#lymphocyte) [(5)](#reference5); (3) high urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of an organic acid, 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid, and its derivative, 3-hydroxyisovaleryl carnitine, both of which reflect decreased activity of biotin-dependent methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase; (4) reduced urinary excretion of biotin and some of its catabolites. These markers have been only validated in men and nonpregnant women, and they may not accurately reflect biotin status in pregnant or breast-feeding women [(12](#reference12), [25)](#reference25). Sufficient scientific evidence is lacking to estimate the dietary requirement for biotin; thus, no Recommended Dietary Allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) for biotin has been established. Instead, the Food and Nutrition Board of the National Academy of Medicine set recommendations for an Adequate Intake ( [AI](../glossary#AI); Table 1). The AI for adults (30 g/day) was extrapolated from the AI for infants exclusively fed human milk and probably overestimates the dietary requirement for biotin for most adults. Dietary intakes of generally healthy adults have been estimated to be 40 to 60 micrograms (g) of biotin daily [(1)](#references). The requirement for biotin Current research indicates that at least one-third of women develop marginal biotin deficiency during pregnancy [(8)](#reference8). Small [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) in pregnant women have reported an abnormally high urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid in both early and late pregnancy, suggesting decreased activity of biotin-dependent women, supplementation with 300 g/day of biotin for two weeks limited the excretion of 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo), confirming that increased 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid excretion indeed reflected marginal biotin deficiency in pregnancy [(29)](#reference29). A small [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) in 22 pregnant women reported an incidence of low [lymphocyte](../glossary#lymphocyte) propionyl-CoA carboxylase activity greater than 80% [(13)](#reference13). Although these levels of biotin deficiency are not associated with overt signs of deficiency in pregnant women, such observations are sources of concern because [subclinical](../glossary#subclinical) biotin deficiency has been shown to cause cleft palate and limb hypoplasia in several animal species (reviewed in [13](#reference13)). In addition, biotin depletion has been found to suppress the expression of biotin-dependent carboxylases, remove biotin marks from [histones](../glossary#histone), and decrease the in human embryonic palatal mesenchymal cells in culture [(30)](#reference30). Impaired carboxylase activity may result in alterations in [lipid](../glossary#lipid) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), which have been linked to cleft palate and skeletal abnormalities in animals. Further, biotin deficiency leading to reduced histone biotinylation at specific genomic loci may increase genomic instability and result in [chromosome](../glossary#chromosome) anomalies and fetal malformations [(13)](#reference13). Analogous to pregnant women who are advised to consume [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) folic acid prior to and during pregnancy to prevent [neural tube defects](../glossary#neural-tube-defect) (see [Folate](folate#adverse-pregnancy-outcomes)), it would also be prudent to ensure adequate biotin intake throughout pregnancy. The current AI for pregnant women is 30 g/day of biotin, and no toxicity has ever been reported at this level of intake (see [Safety](#safety)). Biotin-thiamin-responsive basal deficiency, and an [autosomal](../glossary#autosomal) [recessive](../glossary#recessive-trait) [gene](../glossary#gene) that codes for thiamin transporter-2 (THTR-2). The disease usually presents around 3 to 10 years of age [(31)](#reference31), but an early infantile form of the disease exists with onset as early as one month of age [(32)](#reference32). Clinical features include subacute [encephalopathy](../glossary#encephalopathy) (confusion, drowsiness, altered level of consciousness), [ataxia](../glossary#ataxia), and [seizures](../glossary#seizure). A [retrospective study](../glossary#retrospective-study) of 18 affected individuals from the same family or the same tribe in Saudi Arabia showed that biotin [monotherapy](../glossary#monotherapy) (5-10 mg/kg/day) efficiently abolished the clinical manifestations of the disease, although one-third of the patients suffered from recurrent acute crises. Often associated with poor outcomes, acute crises were not observed after thiamin supplementation started (300-400 mg/day) and during a five-year follow-up period, early diagnosis and immediate treatment with biotin and thiamin led to positive outcomes [(33)](#reference33). Although the specific mechanism for therapeutic effects of biotin in biotin-thiamin-responsive basal ganglia disease remains unknown, lifelong high-dose supplementation with a combination of biotin and thiamin is the recommended treatment [(31)](#reference31). Early diagnosis and treatment is important to ensure a better [prognosis](../glossary#prognosis) [(32, 34)](#reference32). [Multiple sclerosis](../glossary#multiple-sclerosis) (MS) is an [autoimmune disease](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) characterized by progressive damage to the [myelin](../glossary#myelin) sheath surrounding nerve fibers ( [axons](../glossary#axon)) and [neuronal](../glossary#neuron) loss in the brain and spinal cord of affected individuals in anatomic locations that vary widely among affected individuals producing variable signs and symptoms. The progression of [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) disabilities in MS patients is often assessed by the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) with scores from 1 to 10, from minimal signs of motor dysfunction (score of 1) to death by MS (score of 10). [ATP](../glossary#ATP) deficiency due to [mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) dysfunction and increased [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) may be partly responsible for the progressive degeneration of [neurons](../glossary#neuron) in MS [(35)](#reference35). Given its role in energy production by intermediary metabolism and [fatty acid](../glossary#fatty-acid) [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) and in fatty (see [Function](#function)), high-dose biotin supplementation it has been hypothesized that to exert beneficial effects that would limit or reverse MS-associated functional impairments [(35)](#reference35). The mechanism of action of high-dose biotin has been investigated in a genetic mouse model of chronic axon injury caused by [oxidative [axonal](../glossary#axon) death and locomotor impairment. Dysregulation of the transcriptional program for [lipid](../glossary#lipid) synthesis and degradation in the spinal cord was also normalized, possibly as the result of hyperactivation of a nutrient/energy/ [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction) sensor that controls protein synthesis restoring lipid homeostasis. A nonrandomized, uncontrolled [pilot study](../glossary#pilot-study) in 23 patients with progressive MS found high doses of biotin (100-600 mg/day) to be associated with sustained clinical improvements in five (out of five) patients with progressive visual loss and 16 (out of 18) patients with partial paralysis of the limbs after a mean three months following treatment onset [(36)](#reference36). Additionally, a multicenter, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 154 subjects with progressive MS reported that 13 out of 103 patients supplemented with high-dose, pharmaceutical-grade biotin (300 mg/day) for 12 months achieved MS-related disability reversal — assessed by improved EDSS or 25-foot walk time [(37)](#reference37). In comparison, none of the 51 patients randomized to the placebo group showed significant clinical improvements [(37)](#reference37). However, when this regimen of high-dose biotin supplementation was examined in a larger, international cohort of patients with progressive MS (326 patients receiving biotin and 316 patients receiving placebo), no benefits on EDSS or walk time were seen after 12 months [(38)](#reference38). Moreover, a randomized, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), placebo-controlled trial in 93 MS patients with chronic visual loss found that 300 mg/day of pharmaceutical-grade biotin for six months did not improve visual acuity, but an interesting trend favoring the biotin group was observed in the subgroup of patients with progressive optic neuritis [(39)](#reference39). Moreover, a meta-analysis of three randomized controlled trials (2 on disability; 3 on adverse effects), involving 889 individuals diagnosed with MS (the preponderance of participants [830] had progressive MS while only 59 had remitting relapsing MS) was conducted [(40)](#reference40). Pooling results of two trials found no benefit of high-dose biotin on MS-related disability, but there was significant heterogeneity between the trials. When the subgroup progressive MS was analyzed separately, a moderate certainty of evidence suggested a potential benefit in favor of high-dose biotin for the 25-foot minute walk time [(40)](#reference40). On balance, studies remain inconclusive but promising. Overt biotin deficiency has been shown to impair [glucose](../glossary#glucose) utilization in mice [(41)](#reference41) and cause fatal [hypoglycemia](../glossary#hypoglycemia) in chickens. Overt biotin deficiency likely also causes abnormalities in glucose regulation in humans (see [Function](#function)). One early human study reported lower [serum](../glossary#serum) biotin concentrations in 43 patients with type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) compared to 64 control subjects without the disease; an [inverse relationship](../glossary#inverse-association) between fasting blood glucose and biotin concentrations was observed as well [(42)](#reference42). In a small, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled [intervention study](../glossary#intervention-trial) in 28 patients with type 2 diabetes, daily supplementation with 9 milligrams (mg) of biotin for one month resulted in a 45% decrease in mean fasting blood glucose concentrations [(42)](#reference42). Yet, another small study in 10 patients with type 2 diabetes and 7 controls without diabetes found no effect of biotin supplementation (15 mg/day) for 28 days on fasting blood glucose concentrations in either group [(43)](#reference43). A more recent [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), placebo-controlled study by the same research group showed that the same biotin regimen lowered [plasma](../glossary#plasma) [triglyceride](../glossary#triglyceride) concentrations in patients with hypertriglyceridemia — independent of whether they had type 2 diabetes [(44)](#reference44). In this study, biotin administration did not affect blood glucose concentrations in either patient group. Additionally, a few studies have shown that co-supplementation with biotin and chromium picolinate may be a beneficial [adjunct therapy](../glossary#adjunct) in patients with type 2 diabetes [(45-48)](#reference45). For information on chromium supplementation as a [monotherapy](../glossary#monotherapy) for type 2 diabetes, see the article on [Chromium](../minerals/chromium#type-2-diabetes-treatment). Potential mechanisms for the glucose and [lipid](../glossary#lipid) effects have been suggested. As a [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) of [carboxylases](../glossary#carboxylase) required for [fatty acid](../glossary#fatty-acid) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis), biotin may increase the utilization of glucose for fat synthesis. Also, biotin stimulates glucokinase, a liver [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) that increases synthesis of [glycogen](../glossary#glycogen), the storage form of glucose. Biotin also triggers the secretion of [insulin](../glossary#insulin) in the pancreas of rats and improves glucose [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) [(50)](#reference50). Yet, reduced activity of ACC1 and ACC2 would be expected to reduce fatty acid synthesis and increase fatty acid [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation), respectively. Hence, whether [pharmacologic doses](../glossary#pharmacological-dose) of biotin benefits the management of [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia) in patients with [impaired glucose tolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance) remains unclear. Moreover, whether supplemental biotin lowers the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) complications in patients with diabetes by reducing serum triglycerides and [LDL](../glossary#LDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) remains to be proven [(44-46)](#reference44). The finding that biotin [supplements](../glossary#supplement) were effective in treating hoof abnormalities in hoofed animals suggested that biotin might also be helpful in strengthening brittle fingernails in humans [(50-52)](#reference50). Three uncontrolled trials examining the effects of biotin supplementation (2.5 mg/day for several months) in women with brittle fingernails have been published [(53-55)](#reference53). In two of the trials, subjective evidence of clinical improvement was reported in 67%-91% of the participants available for follow-up at the end of the treatment period [(53, 54)](#reference53). One trial that used scanning electron microscopy to assess fingernail brittleness reported less fingernail splitting and a 25% increase in the thickness of the nail plate in patients supplemented with biotin for 6 to 15 months [(55)](#reference55). Biotin supplementation (5 mg/day) was also found to be effective in controlling unruly hair and splitting nails in two toddlers with inherited uncombable hair syndrome [(56)](#reference56). Although preliminary evidence suggests that supplemental biotin may help strengthen fragile nails (reviewed in [57](#reference57)), larger [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials are needed to assess the efficacy of high-dose biotin supplementation for the treatment of brittle fingernails. Biotin administration has been associated with [alopecia](../glossary#alopecia) reversal in children treated with the [anticonvulsant](../glossary#anticonvulsant) valproic acid (see [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions)), as well as with hair regrowth or normal hair growth in some children with inborn errors of biotin metabolism or other genetic disorders (i.e., uncombable hair syndrome) (reviewed in [58](#reference58)). Yet, while hair loss is a symptom of severe biotin deficiency (see [Deficiency](#deficiency)), there are no published scientific studies that support the claim that high-dose biotin [supplements](../glossary#supplement) are effective in preventing or treating hair loss in men or women [(59, 60)](#reference59). [Randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials in healthy individuals would be needed to evaluate this claim. Biotin is found in many foods, either as the free (i.e., unbound) form that is directly taken up by [enterocytes](../glossary#enterocyte) or as biotin bound to dietary proteins. Egg yolk, liver, and yeast are rich sources of biotin. Estimates of average daily intakes of biotin from small studies ranged between 40 and 60 micrograms (g) per day in adults [(1)](#references). However, US national nutritional surveys have not yet been able to estimate biotin intake due to the scarcity and unreliability of data regarding biotin content of food. Food composition tables for biotin are incomplete such that dietary intakes cannot be reliably estimated in humans. A study by Staggs et al. [(61)](#reference61) employed a high-performance liquid chromatography method rather than bioassays [(62)](#reference62) and reported relatively different biotin content for some selected foods. Table 2 lists some food sources of biotin, along with their content in g. is about the size of a deck of cards.| A majority of [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria) that normally colonize the small and large intestine ( [colon](../glossary#colon)) [synthesize](../glossary#synthesis) biotin [(63)](#reference63). Whether the biotin is released and absorbed by humans in meaningful amounts remains unknown. The uptake of free biotin into intestinal cells via the human sodium-dependent multivitamin transporter (hSMVT) has been identified in cultured cells derived from the lining of the [small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine) and colon [(64)](#reference64), suggesting that humans may be able to absorb biotin produced by enteric bacteria — a phenomenon documented in swine. Biotin is available as a single-nutrient [supplement](../glossary#supplement) in various doses (many containing 5,000 g [5 mg] of biotin) and is often included in B-complex and multivitamin-mineral supplements. Several multivitamin supplements contain 30 g of biotin, although the amount varies by product [(65)](#reference65). Biotin is not known to be toxic. In people without disorders of biotin [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), doses of up to 5 mg/day (5,000 g) for two years were not associated with adverse effects [(66)](#reference66). Oral biotin supplementation has been well tolerated in doses up to 200 mg/day (nearly 7,000 times the [AI](../glossary#AI)) in people with hereditary disorders of biotin metabolism [(1)](#references). Daily supplementation with a highly concentrated formulation of biotin (100-600 mg) for several months was also found to be well tolerated in individuals with progressive [multiple sclerosis](../glossary#multiple-sclerosis) [(36](#reference36), [67)](#reference67). However, there is one case report of life-threatening eosinophilic pleuropericardial effusion in an elderly woman who took a combination of 10 mg/day of biotin and 300 mg/day of [pantothenic acid](pantothenic-acid) (vitamin B5) for two months [(68)](#reference68). Because reports of adverse events were lacking when the Dietary Reference Intakes ( [DRIs](../glossary#DRI)) for biotin were established in 1998, the Food and Nutrition Board did not establish a tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for biotin [(1)](#references). Large doses of [pantothenic acid](pantothenic-acid) (vitamin B5) have the potential to compete with biotin for intestinal and cellular uptake by the human sodium-dependent multivitamin transporter (hSMVT) [Pharmacologic](../glossary#pharmacological-dose) (very high) doses of lipoic acid have been found to decrease the activity of biotin-dependent [carboxylases](../glossary#carboxylase) in rats, but such an effect has not been demonstrated in humans [(72)](#reference72). Individuals on long-term [anticonvulsant](../glossary#anticonvulsant) (anti- [seizure](../glossary#seizure)) therapy reportedly have reduced blood biotin concentrations, as well as an increased urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of organic acids (e.g., 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid) that indicate decreased [carboxylase](../glossary#carboxylase) activity (see [Markers of biotin status](#biomarkers-status)) [(5)](#reference5). as well increased biotin [catabolism](../glossary#catabolism) [(73)](#reference73). Use of the anticonvulsant valproic acid in children has resulted in hair loss reversed by biotin [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) [(74-77)](#reference74). Long-term treatment with antibacterial sulfonamide (sulfa) drugs or other antibiotics may decrease [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) synthesis of biotin. Yet, given that the extent to which bacterial synthesis contributes to biotin intake in humans is not known, effects of antimicrobial drugs on biotin nutritional [status](../glossary#status) remain uncertain [(73)](#reference73). In 2017, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) released a safety communication regarding high-dose biotin supplementation and its potential interference with streptavidin (avidin)-biotin immunoassays, including assays of thyroid hormones, reproductive hormones, and the cardiac protein, troponin. Such interference can cause aberrant results — either falsely high or falsely low depending on the method of the particular assay — and potential misdiagnosis of disease [(78-81)](#reference78). An updated FDA communication in 2019 focused on biotin interference in certain lab assays of troponin that have not addressed the concern of falsely low blood concentrations [(82)](#reference82). Troponin in blood is a marker of cardiac damage and often used in the clinical diagnosis of a myocardial infarction (heart attack). When blood work is planned, patients should routinely inform their health care provider concerning supplementation of biotin at doses substantially greater than those in usual diets or in routine daily multivitamins. Little is known regarding the amount of dietary biotin required to promote optimal health or prevent [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease). The Linus Pauling Institute supports the recommendation made by the National Academy of Medicine, which is 30 micrograms (g) of biotin per day for adults. A varied diet should provide enough biotin for most people. However, following the Linus Pauling Institute recommendation to take a daily multivitamin-mineral supplement will generally provide an intake of at least 30 g/day of biotin. Presently, there is no indication that older adults have an increased requirement for biotin. If dietary biotin intake is not sufficient, a daily multivitamin-mineral supplement will generally provide an intake of at least 30 g of biotin per day. Accessed 7/5/2022. Contents [Folate is a water-soluble B-vitamin, which is also known as vitamin B9 or folacin. Naturally occurring folates exist in many chemical forms; folates are found in food, as well as in metabolically active forms in the human body. Folic acid is the major synthetic form found in fortified foods and vitamin supplements. Other synthetic forms include folinic acid (Figure 1) and levomefolic acid. Folic acid has no biological activity unless converted into folates ] [(1)](#references). In the following discussion, forms found in food or the body are referred to as "folates," while the form found in supplements or fortified food is referred to as "folic acid." The only function of folate [coenzymes](../glossary#coenzyme) in the body appears to be in mediating the transfer of [one-carbon units](../glossary#one-carbon-unit) [(2)](#reference2). Folate coenzymes act as acceptors and donors of one-carbon units in a variety of reactions critical to the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of [nucleic acids](../glossary#nucleic-acid) and [amino acids](../glossary#amino-acid) (Figure vital role in [DNA](../glossary#DNA) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) through two different pathways. (1) The [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of DNA from its [precursors](../glossary#precursor) (thymidine and purines) is dependent on folate coenzymes. (2) A folate coenzyme is required for the synthesis of [methionine](../glossary#methionine) from [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine), and methionine is required for the synthesis of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM). SAM is a methyl group (one-carbon unit) donor used in most biological [methylation](../glossary#methylation) reactions, including the methylation of a number of sites within DNA, [RNA](../glossary#RNA), [proteins](../glossary#protein), and [phospholipids](../glossary#phospholipid). The methylation of DNA plays a role in controlling [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression) and is critical during cell [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation). Aberrations in DNA methylation have been linked to the development of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) (see [Cancer](#cancer-prevention)). Folate [coenzymes](../glossary#coenzyme) are required for enzyme (as but also [vitamin B12](../vitamins/vitamin-B12). Thus, folate (and/or vitamin B12) deficiency can result in decreased synthesis of methionine and an accumulation of homocysteine. Elevated blood concentrations of homocysteine have been considered for many years to be a [risk](../glossary#risk) factor for some chronic diseases, including [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) and [dementia](../glossary#dementia) (see [Disease Prevention](#disease-prevention)). The [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) intermediate in the metabolism of sulfur-containing [amino acids](../glossary#amino-acid), provides an example of the interrelationships among nutrients necessary for optimal physiological function and health. Healthy individuals utilize two different pathways to metabolize homocysteine (Figure 3). One pathway (methionine synthase) [methionine](../glossary#methionine) and folate and [vitamin B12](../vitamins/vitamin-B12) as [cofactors](../glossary#cofactor). The other pathway converts homocysteine to another amino acid, cysteine, and requires two [vitamin B6](../vitamins/vitamin-B6)-dependent [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme). Thus, the concentration of homocysteine in the blood is regulated by three B-vitamins: folate, vitamin B12, and vitamin B6 [(4)](#reference4). In some individuals, riboflavin (vitamin B2) is also involved in the regulation of homocysteine concentrations (see the article on [Riboflavin](../vitamins/riboflavin)). Although less well recognized, folate has an important metabolic interaction with [riboflavin](../vitamins/riboflavin). Riboflavin [precursor](../glossary#precursor) of flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), (MTHFR). generates 5-methyltetrahydrofolate (see [Figure 2](#figure-2) above). This active form of folate is required to form [methionine](../glossary#methionine) from [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine). Along with other B-vitamins, higher riboflavin intakes have been associated with decreased [plasma](../glossary#plasma) concentrations [(5)](#reference5). The effects of riboflavin on folate [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) appear to be greatest in individuals [homozygous](../glossary#homozygous) for the common c.677C>T [polymorphism](../glossary#polymorphism) (i.e., TT genotype) in folate requirements](#genetic-variation-requirements)) [(6)](#reference6). These individuals (about 10% of adults worldwide) typically present with low folate status, along with elevated homocysteine concentrations, particularly when folate and/or riboflavin intake is suboptimal. The elevated homocysteine concentration in these individuals, however, is highly responsive to lowering with riboflavin supplementation, confirming the importance of the riboflavin-MTHFR interaction [(7)](#reference7). [Vitamin C](../vitamins/vitamin-C) may limit degradation of natural folate [coenzymes](../glossary#coenzyme) and [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) folic acid in the stomach and thus improve folate [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability). A [cross-over trial](../glossary#cross-over-trial) in nine healthy men found that oral co-administration of 5-methyltetrahydrofolic acid (343 g) and vitamin C (289 mg or 974 mg) was associated with higher concentrations of serum folate compared to 5-methyltetrahydrofolic acid alone [(8)](#reference8). Moreover, a recent study suggested that several genetic variations of folate [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) might influence the effect of vitamin C on folate metabolism [(9)](#reference9). Dietary folates exist predominantly in the polyglutamyl form (containing several [glutamate](../glossary#glutamate) residues), whereas folic acid—the synthetic vitamin form—is a monoglutamate, containing just one glutamate moiety. In addition, natural folates are reduced molecules, whereas folic acid is fully oxidized. These chemical differences have major implications for the [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of the [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin) such that folic acid is considerably more bioavailable than naturally occurring food folates at equivalent intake levels. The [intestinal](../glossary#small-intestine) absorption of dietary folates is a two-step process that involves the [hydrolysis](../glossary#hydrolysis) of folate polyglutamates to the corresponding monoglutamyl derivatives, followed by their transport into intestinal cells. There, folic acid is converted into a naturally occurring folate, namely 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, which is the major circulating form of folate in the human body (see [Figure 1](#figure-1) above). The bioavailability of naturally occurring folates is inherently limited and variable. There is much variability in the ease with which folates are released from different food matrices, and the polyglutamyl "tail" is removed (de-conjugation) before uptake by intestinal cells. Also, other dietary constituents can contribute to instability of labile folates during the processes of digestion. As a result, naturally occurring folates show incomplete bioavailability compared with folic acid. The bioavailability of folic acid, in contrast, is assumed to be 100% when ingested as a [supplement](../glossary#supplement), while folic acid in [fortified](../glossary#fortification) food is estimated to have about 85% the bioavailability of supplemental folic acid. Of note, folate recommendations in the US and certain other countries are now expressed as Dietary Folate Equivalents (DFEs), a calculation that was devised to take into account the greater bioavailability of folic acid compared to naturally occurring dietary folates (see [The Recommended Dietary Allowance](#RDA)). Folate and its [coenzymes](../glossary#coenzyme) require transporters to cross [cell membranes](../glossary#cell-membrane). Folate transporters include reduced folate folate transporter FR and FR. Folate [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) is supported by the ubiquitous distribution of folate transporters, although abundance and importance vary among tissues [(10)](#reference10). PCFT plays a major role in folate intestinal transport since [mutations](../glossary#mutation) affecting the [gene](../glossary#gene) encoding PCFT cause hereditary folate [malabsorption](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome). Defective PCFT also leads to impaired folate transport into the brain (see [Disease Treatment](#disease-treatment)). FR and RFC are also critical for folate transport across the blood-brain barrier when extracellular folate is either low or high, respectively. Folate is essential for the proper development of the embryo and the fetus. The [placenta](../glossary#placenta) is known to concentrate folate to the fetal circulation, leading to higher folate concentrations in the fetus compared to those found in the pregnant woman. All three types of [receptors](../glossary#receptor) have been associated with folate transport across the placenta during pregnancy [(11)](#reference11). Folate deficiency is most often caused by a dietary insufficiency; however, folate deficiency can also occur in a number of other situations. For example, chronic and heavy alcohol consumption is associated with diminished absorption of folate (in addition to low dietary intake), which can lead to folate deficiency [(12)](#reference12). Smoking is also associated with low folate status. In one study, folate concentrations in blood were about 15% lower in smokers compared to nonsmokers [(13)](#reference13). Additionally, impaired folate transport to the fetus has been described in pregnant women who either smoked or abused alcohol during their pregnancy [(14, 15)](#reference14). Pregnancy is a time when the folate requirement is greatly increased to sustain the demand for rapid cell replication and growth of fetal, [placental](../glossary#placenta), and maternal tissue. Conditions such as cancer or inflammation can also result in increased rates of cell division and [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), causing an increase in the body's demand for folate [(16)](#reference16). Moreover, folate deficiency can result also to folate deficiency (see [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions)). Finally, a number of genetic diseases affecting folate absorption, transport, or metabolism can cause folate deficiency or impede its metabolic functions (see [Disease Treatment](#disease-treatment)). Clinical folate deficiency leads to [megaloblastic anemia](../glossary#megaloblastic-anemia), which is reversible with folic acid treatment. Rapidly dividing cells like those derived from bone marrow are most vulnerable to the effects of folate deficiency since [DNA](../glossary#DNA) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) and cell division are dependent on folate [coenzymes](../glossary#coenzyme). When folate supply to the rapidly dividing cells of the bone marrow is inadequate, blood cell division is reduced, resulting in fewer but larger red blood cells. This type of [anemia](../glossary#anemia) is called [megaloblastic](../glossary#megaloblastic-anemia) or [macrocytic anemia](../glossary#macrocytic-anemia), referring to the enlarged, immature red blood cells. [Neutrophils](../glossary#neutrophil), a type of white blood cell, become hypersegmented, a change that can be found by examining a blood sample microscopically. Because normal red blood cells have a lifetime in the circulation of approximately four months, it can take months for folate-deficient individuals to develop the characteristic megaloblastic anemia. Progression of such an anemia leads to a decreased oxygen carrying capacity of the blood and may ultimately result in symptoms of fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath [(1)](#references). It is important to point out that megaloblastic anemia resulting from folate deficiency is identical to the megaloblastic anemia resulting from [vitamin B12](../vitamins/vitamin-B12) deficiency, and further clinical testing is required to diagnose the true cause of megaloblastic anemia (see [Toxicity](#safety)). Individuals in the early stages of folate deficiency may not show obvious symptoms, but blood concentrations of [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) may increase (see [Disease Prevention](#cardiovascular-disease-prevention)). Yet, the concentration of circulating homocysteine is not a specific indicator of folate status, as elevated homocysteine can be the result of vitamin B12 and other B-vitamin deficiencies, lifestyle factors, and [renal](../glossary#renal) insufficiency. Subclinical deficiency is typically detected by measurement of folate concentrations in [serum](../glossary#serum)/ [plasma](../glossary#plasma) or in red blood cells. Traditionally, the dietary folate requirement was defined as the amount needed to prevent a deficiency severe enough to cause symptoms like [anemia](../glossary#anemia). The most recent [RDA](../glossary#RDA) (1998; Table 1) was based primarily on the adequacy of red blood cell folate concentrations at different levels of folate intake, as judged by the absence of abnormal [hematological](../glossary#hematology) indicators. Red cell folate has been shown to correlate with liver folate stores and is used as an indicator of long-term folate status. [Plasma](../glossary#plasma) folate reflects recent folate intake and is not a reliable [biomarker](../glossary#biomarker) for folate status. Maintenance of normal blood [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) concentrations, an indicator of [one-carbon](../glossary#one-carbon-unit) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), was considered only as an ancillary indicator of adequate folate intake. Because pregnancy is associated with a significant increase in cell division and other metabolic processes that require folate [coenzymes](../glossary#coenzyme), the RDA for pregnant women is considerably higher than for women who are not pregnant [(3)](#reference3). However, the prevention of [neural tube defects](../glossary#neural-tube-defect) (NTDs) was not considered when setting the RDA for pregnant women. Rather, reducing the [risk](../glossary#risk) of NTDs was considered in a separate recommendation for women capable of becoming pregnant (see [Disease Prevention](#disease-prevention)), because the crucial events in the development of the neural tube occur before many women are aware that they are pregnant [(18)](#reference18). When the Food and Nutrition Board of the US Institute of Medicine set the new dietary recommendation for folate, they introduced a new unit, the Dietary Folate Equivalent (DFE) [(1)](#references). Use of the DFE reflects the higher [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of synthetic folic acid found in [supplements](../glossary#supplement) and [fortified](../glossary#fortification) food compared to that of naturally occurring food folates [(18)](#reference18). For example, a serving of food containing 60 g of folate would provide 60 g of DFEs, while a serving of pasta fortified with 60 g of folic acid would provide 1.7 x 60 = 102 g of DFEs due to the higher bioavailability of folic acid. A folic acid supplement of 400 g taken on an empty stomach would provide 800 g of DFEs. It should be noted that DFEs were determined in studies with adults and whether folic acid in infant formula is more bioavailable than folates in mother's milk has not been studied. (NTDs) arise from failure of embryonic neural tube closure between the 21st and 27th days after conception, a time when many women may not even realize they are pregnant [(26)](#reference26). NTDs include various malformations, such as lesions of the brain (e.g., [anencephaly](../glossary#anencephaly), encephalocele) or lesions of the spine ( [spina bifida](../glossary#spina-bifida)), which are devastating and life-threatening [(27)](#reference27). The prevalence of NTDs in the United States prior to [fortification](../glossary#fortification) of food with folic acid was estimated to be 1 per 1,000 pregnancies [(1)](#references). Results of [randomized trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have demonstrated 60% to 100% reductions in NTD cases when women consumed folic acid [supplements](../glossary#supplement) in addition to a varied diet during the periconceptional period (about one month before and at least one month after conception) [(28, 29)](#reference28). The results of these and other studies prompted the US Public Health Service to recommend that all women capable of becoming pregnant consume 400 g of folic acid daily to prevent NTDs. Women with a previously affected pregnancy were also advised to receive 4,000 g (4 mg) of folic acid daily in order to reduce NTD recurrence [(30)](#reference30). These recommendations were made to all women of childbearing age because adequate folate must be available very early in pregnancy, and because many pregnancies in the US are unplanned [(31)](#reference31). Despite the effectiveness of folic acid supplementation in improving folate status, it appears that globally only 30% of women who become pregnant correctly follow the recommendation, and there is some concern that young women from minority ethnic groups and lower socioeconomic backgrounds are the least likely to follow the recommendation [(32-34)](#reference32). To decrease the incidence of NTDs, the US FDA implemented legislation in 1998 requiring the fortification of all enriched grain products with 1.4 mg of folic acid per kg of grain (see [Sources](#sources)). The required level of folic acid fortification in the US was initially estimated to provide 100 g of additional folic acid in the average person's diet, though it probably provides even more due to overuse of folic acid by food manufacturers [(25](#reference25), [35)](#reference35). The National Birth Defects Prevention Network reported about a 30% decrease in the prevalence of NTDs in the US compared to the pre-fortification period, and the post-fortification prevalence of NTDs is 0.69 cases per 1,000 live births and fetal deaths [(36)](#reference36). Also, a genetic component in NTD [etiology](../glossary#etiology) is evidenced by the increased [risk](../glossary#risk) in women with a family history of an NTD and also by variations in risk among ethnicities [(37)](#reference37). Moreover, NTD occurrence can be attributed to specific folate- [gene](../glossary#gene) interactions. The MTHFR c.677C>T [polymorphism](../glossary#polymorphism) and other genetic variations can increase the folate requirement and susceptibility for an NTD-affected pregnancy. [Congenital anomalies](../glossary#congenital-anomaly) of the heart are a major cause of infant mortality but also cause deaths in adulthood [(48)](#reference48). Using data from the European Registration of Congenital Anomalies and Twins (EUROCAT) database, a [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study), involving 596 cases and 2,359 controls, found that consumption of at least 400 g/day of folic acid during the periconceptual period (one month before conception through eight weeks' post-conception, covering the period of embryonic heart development) was associated with an 18% reduced [risk](../glossary#risk) of congenital heart defects [(49)](#reference49). Recent meta-analyses of 20 to 25 case-control and family-based studies observed positive associations between maternal, fetal, or paternal MTHFR c.677C>T variant and incidence of congenital heart defects [(50, 51)](#reference50). Additional studies are needed to elucidate the effects of [gene](../glossary#gene)-nutrient interactions on the risk of congenital heart defects; however, the currently available research indicates that adequate folate intake may play an important role. Maternal folate status during pregnancy may influence the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [congenital anomalies](../glossary#congenital-anomaly) called orofacial clefts, [(52)](#reference52). A population-based [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) in Norway investigated the impact of folic acid [supplements](../glossary#supplement) in mothers of 377 newborns with CL/P, 196 with cleft palate only (CPO) and 763 controls [(53)](#reference53). Although dietary intakes or supplements (during the first three months of pregnancy) on their own did not significantly modify the risk of CL/P, the study reported a 64% lower risk among women taking multivitamin and folic acid (400 g daily) supplements in addition to dietary folates. In the same population, [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) in the cystathionine [gene](../glossary#gene) (c.699C>T) or (c.677C>T; when folate intake was below 400 g/day) appeared protective, while other gene variants in the folate/ [one-carbon](../glossary#one-carbon-unit) metabolism could not be linked to CL/P [(54, 55)](#reference54). However, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 18 studies showed an elevation of CL/P risk with the maternal 677T/T [homozygosity](../glossary#homozygous) [(56)](#reference56). Additional studies are needed to evaluate the risk of CL/P while integrating both genetic polymorphism and folate intake parameters. [Epidemiological](../glossary#epidemiological-study) evidence supporting a role for folate in the risk of CPO is lacking. Low birth weight has been associated with increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of mortality during the first year of life and may also influence health outcomes during adulthood [(57)](#reference57). A recent [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of eight [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found a positive association between folic acid [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) and birth weight; no association with length of [gestation](../glossary#gestation) was observed [(58)](#reference58). Additionally, a [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) of 306 pregnant adolescents associated low folate intakes and maternal folate status during the third trimester of pregnancy with higher incidence of small for gestational age births (birth weight <10th percentile) [(59)](#reference59). Moreover, the maternal c.677C>T MTHFR genotype and increased [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) concentrations, considered an indicator of functional folate deficiency, have been linked to lower birth weights [(60)](#reference60). Elevated blood homocysteine concentrations have also been associated with increased incidence of miscarriage and other pregnancy complications, including [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia) and [placental abruption](../glossary#placental-abruption) [(61)](#reference61). A large [retrospective study](../glossary#retrospective-study) showed that [plasma](../glossary#plasma) homocysteine in Norwegian women was strongly related to adverse outcomes and complications, including preeclampsia, premature delivery, and very low birth weight, in previous pregnancies [(62)](#reference62). A recent meta-analysis of 51 prospective cohort studies linked the c.677C>T MTHFR variant with increased risk of preeclampsia in Caucasian and East Asian populations, reinforcing the notion that folate [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) may play a role in the condition [(63)](#reference63). A large multicenter, randomized, controlled trial, the Folic Acid Clinical Trial (FACT), has been initiated to evaluate whether the daily supplementation of up to 5.1 mg of folic acid throughout pregnancy could prevent preeclampsia and other adverse outcomes (e.g., maternal death, placental abruption, preterm delivery) in high-risk women [(64)](#reference64). Adequate folate intake during pregnancy protects against [megaloblastic anemia](../glossary#megaloblastic-anemia) [(65)](#reference65). A recent [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) found a reduction in risk of autism spectrum disorders with daily folic acid consumption of 600 g or more before and during pregnancy when mother and child carried the c.677C>T MTHFR genotype [(66)](#reference66). Thus, it is reasonable to maintain folic acid supplementation throughout pregnancy, even after closure of the neural tube, in order to decrease the risk of other problems during pregnancy. Moreover, recent systematic reviews of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) found no evidence of an association between folate exposure during pregnancy and adverse health outcomes in offspring, in particular childhood [asthma](../glossary#asthma) and allergies [(67, 68)](#reference67). The results of more than 80 studies indicate that even moderately elevated concentrations of [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) in the blood increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) (CVD) [(4)](#reference4). Possible predispositions to vascular accidents have also been linked to genetic deficiencies in homocysteine [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) in certain populations [(69)](#reference69). The mechanism by which homocysteine may increase the risk of vascular disease has been the subject of a great deal of research, but it may involve adverse effects of homocysteine on blood clotting, arterial [vasodilation](../glossary#vasodilation), and thickening of arterial walls [(70)](#reference70). Although increased homocysteine concentrations in the blood have been consistently associated with increased risk of CVD, it is unclear whether lowering circulating homocysteine will reduce CVD risk (see [Folate and homocysteine](#folate-homocysteine)). Research had initially predicted that a prolonged decrease in [serum](../glossary#serum) homocysteine level of 3 micromoles/liter would lower the risk of CVD by up to 25% and be a reasonable treatment goal for individuals at high risk [(71, 72)](#reference71). However, the analysis of recent [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) of B-vitamin supplementation has shown that lowering homocysteine concentrations did not prevent the occurrence of a second [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) event in patients with existing CVD [(73, 74)](#reference73). Consequently, the American Heart Association recommends screening for elevated total homocysteine concentrations only in "high risk" individuals, for example, in those with personal or family history of premature cardiovascular disease, malnutrition or [malabsorption syndromes](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome), [hypothyroidism](../glossary#hypothyroidism), kidney failure, [lupus](../glossary#systemic-lupus-erythematosus), or individuals resins, methotrexate, [coronary artery disease](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease), [myocardial infarction](../glossary#myocardial-infarction) (heart attack), and [stroke](../glossary#stroke). A study that followed 1,980 Finnish men for 10 years found that those who consumed the most dietary folate had a 55% lower risk of an acute coronary event when compared to those who consumed the least dietary folate [(75)](#reference75). Of the three B-vitamins that regulate [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) concentrations, folic acid has been shown to have the greatest effect in lowering basal concentrations of homocysteine in the blood when there is no coexisting deficiency [vitamin through food or [supplements](../glossary#supplement) has been found to reduce homocysteine concentrations [(77)](#reference77). Besides, blood homocysteine concentrations have declined since the FDA mandated folic acid [fortification](../glossary#fortification) of the grain supply in the US [(25)](#reference25). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 25 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), including almost 3,000 subjects, found that folic acid supplementation with 800 g/day or more could achieve a maximal 25% reduction in [plasma](../glossary#plasma) homocysteine concentrations. In this meta-analysis, daily doses of 200 g and 400 g of folic acid were associated with a 13% and 20% reduction in plasma homocysteine, respectively [(78)](#reference78). A supplement regimen of 400 g of folic acid, 2 mg of vitamin B6, and 6 g of vitamin B12 has been advocated by the American Heart Association if an initial trial of a folate-rich diet (see [Sources](#sources)) is not successful in adequately lowering homocysteine concentrations [(79)](#reference79). Several [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) in folate/ [one-carbon](../glossary#one-carbon-unit) metabolism modify homocysteine concentrations in blood [(80)](#reference80). In particular, the effect of the c.677C>T MTHFR variant has been examined in relation to folic acid fortification policies worldwide. The analysis of [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) trials, including 59,995 subjects without a history of CVD, revealed that the difference in homocysteine concentrations between T/T and C/C genotypes was greater in low-folate regions compared to regions with food fortification policy (3.12 vs. 0.13 micromoles/liter) [(81)](#reference81). Although folic acid supplementation effectively decreases homocysteine concentrations, it is not yet clear whether it also decreases risk for CVD. A recent meta-analysis of 19 randomized [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial), including 47,921 subjects with preexisting cardiovascular or [renal](../glossary#renal) disease, found that homocysteine lowering through folic acid and other B-vitamin supplementation failed to reduce the incidence of CVD despite significant reductions in plasma homocysteine concentrations [(74)](#reference74). Other meta-analyses have confirmed the lack of causality between the lowering of homocysteine and the risk of CVD [(80-82)](#reference80), including the risk of stroke [(83, 84)](#reference83). Consequently, the American Heart Association removed its recommendation for using folic acid to prevent cardiovascular disease in high-risk women [(85)](#reference85). It should be noted that the majority of prevention trials to date have been performed in CVD patients with advanced disease. The evidence supporting a beneficial role for folate and related B-vitamins appears to be strongest for the primary prevention of stroke [(86)](#reference86). The introduction of mandatory folic acid fortification has been associated with a decline in stroke-related mortality in North America, adding further support to the potential benefit of enhancing folate status and/or lowering homocysteine in the prevention of stroke [(87)](#reference87). Despite the controversy regarding the role of homocysteine lowering in CVD prevention, some studies have investigated the effect of folic acid supplementation on the development of [atherosclerosis](../glossary#atherosclerosis), a known risk factor for vascular accidents. The measurement of the [carotid](../glossary#carotid-arteries) intima-media thickness (CIMT) is a surrogate endpoint for early atherosclerosis and a predictor for [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events [(88)](#reference88). The meta-analysis of 10 randomized trials testing the effect of folic acid supplementation showed a significant reduction in CIMT in subjects with chronic kidney diseases and in those at risk for CVD, but not in healthy participants [(89)](#reference89). [Endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) dysfunction is a common feature in atherosclerosis and vascular disease. High doses of folic acid (400-10,000 g/day) have been associated with improvements in vascular health in both healthy and CVD subjects [(90)](#reference90). Although recent trials failed to demonstrate any cardiovascular protection from folic acid supplementation, low folate intake is a known risk factor for vascular disease, and more research is needed to explore the role of folate in maintaining vascular health [(91)](#reference91). [Cancer](../glossary#cancer) is thought to arise from [DNA](../glossary#DNA) damage in excess of ongoing DNA repair and/or the inappropriate expression of critical [genes](../glossary#gene). Because of the important roles played by folate in DNA and [RNA](../glossary#RNA) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) and [methylation](../glossary#methylation), it is possible that inadequate folate intake contributes to genome instability and [chromosome](../glossary#chromosome) breakage that often characterize cancer development. In particular, DNA replication and repair are critical for genome maintenance, and the shortage in [nucleotides](../glossary#nucleotide) caused by folate deficiency might lead to genome instability and DNA [mutations](../glossary#mutation). A decrease in 5,10-methylene THF can compromise the conversion of deoxyuridine thymine depletion. This could then lead to uracil misincorporation into DNA during replication or repair, and cause DNA damage, including point mutations and strand breaks [(92)](#reference92). Since 5,10-methylene THF is also the MTHFR enzyme substrate, it is plausible that a reduction of MTHFR activity with the c.677C>T polymorphism may increase the use of 5,10-methylene THF for thymidylate synthesis and prevent DNA damage. However, this hypothesis might only be valid in a situation of folate deficiency [(93)](#reference93). Conversely, it was argued that folic acid supplementation could fuel DNA synthesis, therefore promoting tumor growth. This is supported by the observation that TS can function like a tumor promoter (oncogene), while a reduction in TS activity is linked to a lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of cancer [(94, 95)](#reference94). Additionally, antifolate molecules that block the thymidylate synthesis pathway are successfully used in cancer therapy [(96)](#reference96). Folate also controls the homocysteine/ [methionine](../glossary#methionine) cycle and the pool of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), the methyl donor for methylation reactions. Thus, folate deficiency may impair DNA and [protein](../glossary#protein) methylation and alter the [expression](../glossary#gene-expression) of genes involved in DNA repair, [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) and cell death. Global DNA hypomethylation, a typical hallmark of cancer, causes genome instability and chromosome breaks (reviewed in [97](#reference97)). The consumption of at least five servings of fruit and vegetables daily has been consistently associated with a decreased incidence of cancer [(98)](#reference98). Fruit and vegetables are excellent sources of folate, which may play a role in their anti-carcinogenic effect. [Observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have found diminished folate [status](../glossary#status) to be associated with site-specific cancers. While food [fortification](../glossary#fortification) is mandatory in the US (since 1998; see [Sources](#sources)), concerns about the impact of high folic acid intakes on health have delayed the practice in several other countries [(99)](#reference99). However, the most recent [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of folic acid [intervention trials](../glossary#intervention-trial) (supplemental doses ranging from 500 to 5,000 g/day for at least one year) did not show any specific benefit or harm regarding total and site-specific cancer incidence [(100, 101)](#reference100). A pooled analysis of 13 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), which followed a total of 725,134 individuals for a 7 to 20-year period, revealed a modest, inverse association between dietary and total (from food and [supplements](../glossary#supplement)) folate intake and [colon](../glossary#colon) [cancer](../glossary#cancer) risk. Specifically, a 2% decrease in colon cancer risk was estimated for every 100 g/day increase in total folate intake [(102)](#reference102). A large US [prospective study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), which followed 525,488 subjects, ages 50 to 71 years between 1995 and 2006, correlated dietary folate, supplemental folic acid, and total folate intakes with a decreased colorectal cancer (CRC) risk [(103)](#reference103). However, when stratified by gender, there was no association between dietary folate intake and CRC risk in women [(103, 104)](#reference103). A lack of association between CRC risk and dietary, supplemental, and total folate intakes was also reported in another prospective study that followed more than 90,000 US postmenopausal women during an 11-year period encompassing pre- and post- [fortification](../glossary#fortification) periods [(105)](#reference105). These data suggest the possible influence of gender over CRC risk modification by folate. In the latter study, a significant but transient risk elevation was also observed during the post-fortification era; however, some have asserted that this is unlikely to be caused by increased folate intake due to mandatory fortification [(106)](#reference106). Finally, a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 18 [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) found a slight reduction in CRC risk with folate from food [(107)](#reference107). However, it is important to note that the case-control studies were highly [heterogeneous](../glossary#heterogeneity), and that the authors stated that dietary fiber, vitamins, and alcohol intake could have confounded their results. Moreover, the lower limit of the highest quantile of folate intake was highly variable, ranging from 270 to 1,367 g/day [(107)](#reference107). While most [epidemiological](../glossary#epidemiological-study) research shows a protective effect of folate against colorectal cancer development, it has been suggested that high doses of supplemental folic acid may actually accelerate tumor growth in cancer patients [(108)](#reference108). Whereas higher folate status within the normal dietary range is widely considered to be protective against cancer, some investigators remain concerned that exposure to excessively high folic acid intakes may increase the growth of pre-existing neoplasms [(108)](#reference108). Several [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) addressed the effect of folic acid supplementation in patients with a history of [colorectal adenoma](../glossary#colorectal-adenoma), with trials finding a risk reduction or no effect of supplemental folic acid [(109-112)](#reference109). A recent meta-analysis of three large [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in high-risk subjects did not demonstrate any increase in colorectal adenoma recurrence in subjects supplemented with 500 or 1,000 g/day of folic acid for 24 to 42 months when compared with [placebo](../glossary#placebo) treatment [(113)](#reference113). The incidence of Wilms' tumors (kidney [cancer](../glossary#cancer)) and certain types of brain cancers (neuroblastoma, ganglioneuroblastoma, and ependymoma) in children has decreased since the mandatory [fortification](../glossary#fortification) of the US grain supply in 1998 [(129)](#reference129). However, incidence rates were unchanged between the pre- and post-fortification periods for leukemia—a predominant childhood malignancy. Despite earlier studies linking maternal folic acid supplementation during pregnancy with the reduced [risk](../glossary#risk) of childhood leukemia, more recent investigations have found little evidence to support a preventive effect of folic acid [(130)](#reference130).
