[Alzheimer's disease](../glossary#alzheimer-disease) (AD) is the most common form of [dementia](../glossary#dementia), affecting more than 5 million individuals over 65 years old in the US [(132)](#reference132). [-amyloid plaque](../glossary#amyloid-plaque) deposition, Tau protein-forming tangles, and increased cell death in the brain of AD patients have been associated with [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) decline and memory loss. One study associated increased consumption of fruit and vegetables, which are abundant sources of folate, with a reduced [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing dementia and AD in women [(133)](#reference133). Through its role in [nucleic acid](../glossary#nucleic-acid) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) and methyl donor provision for [methylation](../glossary#methylation) reactions, folate is critical for normal brain development and function, not only during pregnancy and after birth, but also later in life [(134)](#reference134). In one [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) of elderly women, AD patients had significantly higher [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) and lower red blood cell folate concentrations compared to healthy individuals. However, there was no difference in the level of [serum](../glossary#serum) folate between groups, suggesting that long-term folate status, rather than recent folate intake, may be associated with the risk of AD [(135)](#reference135). Several investigators have described associations between increased homocysteine concentrations and cognitive impairment in the elderly [(136)](#reference136), but [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have not found higher folate intakes to be associated with improved [cognition](../glossary#cognition) [(137, 138)](#reference137). Higher homocysteine concentrations were found in individuals suffering from dementia, including AD and [vascular dementia](../glossary#vascular-dementia), compared to healthy subjects [(139, 140)](#reference139). Although deficiencies in folate, vitamin B12, and vitamin B6 could increase homocysteine concentrations, a reduction in [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin) concentrations in the serum of AD patients compared to healthy individuals could not be attributed to decreased vitamin intakes [(141)](#reference141). It is not presently clear whether serum homocysteine is a risk factor for developing dementia or simply associated with the cognitive decline. In the last decade, a number of [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have tested the use of B-vitamins to lower homocysteine and prevent or delay cognitive decline. A meta-analysis of nine randomized, placebo-controlled trials of folic acid supplementation (0.2 to 15 mg/day for a median duration of six months) in healthy individuals over 45 years of age failed to find a short-term effect on cognitive functions, including memory, speed, language, and [executive functions](../glossary#executive-function) [(142)](#reference142). More recently, a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 19 [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials of B-vitamin supplementation found no difference in cognitive parameters between the treatment and placebo groups, despite the treatment effectively lowering homocysteine concentrations [(143)](#reference143). Inconsistent findings across trials may be due to differences in design and methodology (reviewed in [144](#reference144)). Nevertheless, a two-year randomized, placebo-controlled trial in 168 elderly subjects with mild cognitive impairment recently described the benefits of a daily regimen of 800 g of folic acid, 500 g of vitamin B12, and 20 mg of vitamin B6 [(145, 146)](#reference145). [Atrophy](../glossary#atrophy) of specific brain regions affected by AD was observed in individuals of both groups, and this atrophy correlated with cognitive decline; however, the B-vitamin treatment group experienced a smaller loss of [gray matter](../glossary#gray-matter) compared to the placebo group (0.5% vs. 3.7%). A greater benefit was seen in subjects with higher baseline homocysteine concentrations, suggesting the importance of lowering circulating homocysteine in prevention of cognitive decline and dementia. Although encouraging, the effect of B-vitamin supplementation needs to be further studied in larger trials that evaluate long-term outcomes, such as the incidence of AD. Folinic acid (see [Figure 1](#figure-1) above), a tetrahydrofolic acid derivative, is used in the clinical management of rare inborn errors that affect folate transport or [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) (reviewed in [147](#reference147)). Such conditions are of [autosomal](../glossary#autosomal) [recessive](../glossary#recessive-trait) inheritance, meaning only individuals receiving two copies of the mutated [gene](../glossary#gene) (one from each parent) develop the disease. Hereditary folate [malabsorption](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome) is caused by [mutations](../glossary#mutation) in the SLC46A1 [gene](../glossary#gene) coding for the folate transporter PCFT and typically affects [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) folate absorption and folate transport into the brain [(148)](#reference148). Patients present with low to undetectable concentrations of folate in [serum](../glossary#serum) and [cerebrospinal fluid](../glossary#cerebrospinal-fluid), pancytopenia (low number of all blood cells), impaired immune responses that increase susceptibility to infections, and a general failure to thrive [(149)](#reference149). [Neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) symptoms, including [seizures](../glossary#seizure), have also been observed [(150)](#reference150). Clinical improvements have been recorded following [parenteral](../glossary#total-parenteral-nutrition) provision of folinic acid [(151)](#reference151). CFD is characterized by low levels of folate [coenzymes](../glossary#coenzyme) in [cerebrospinal fluid](../glossary#cerebrospinal-fluid) despite normal concentrations of folate in blood. Folate transport across the blood-brain barrier is compromised in CFD and has been linked either to the presence of [antibodies](../glossary#antibody) blocking the folate receptor FR or FR 153)](#reference152). [Neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) abnormalities, along with visual and hearing impairments, have been described in children with CFD; autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is present in some cases. Folinic acid (also known as leucovorin) can enter the brain and normalize the level of folate coenzymes and has been shown to normalize folate concentrations and improve various social interactions in CFD, including mood, behavior, and verbal communication in children with ASD [(152, 154, 155)](#reference152). DHFR is the NADPH-dependent [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) acid (DHF) to tetrahydrofolic acid (THF). DHFR is also required to convert folic acid to DHF. DHFR deficiency is characterized by [megaloblastic anemia](../glossary#megaloblastic-anemia) and [cerebral](../glossary#cerebral) folate deficiency causing intractable [seizures](../glossary#seizure) and mental deficits. Although folinic acid treatment can alleviate the symptoms of DHFR deficiency, early diagnosis is essential to prevent irreversible brain damage and improve clinical outcomes [(156, 157)](#reference156). Green leafy vegetables (foliage) are rich sources of folate and provide the basis for its name. Citrus fruit juices, [legumes](../glossary#legumes), and [fortified](../glossary#fortification) foods are also excellent sources of folate [(1)](#references); the folate content of fortified cereal varies greatly. A number of folate-rich foods are listed in Table 2, along with their folate content in micrograms (g). The addition of nutrients to food in order to prevent a nutritional deficiency or restore nutrients lost in processing is known as | The principal form of [supplementary](../glossary#supplement) folate is folic acid. It is available in single-ingredient and combination products, such as B-complex vitamins and multivitamins. Doses of 1 mg or greater require a prescription [(159)](#reference159). Additionally, folinic acid, a tetrahydrofolic acid derivative, is used to manage certain metabolic diseases (see [Disease Treatment](#disease-treatment)). Further, the US FDA has approved the supplementation of folate in oral contraceptives. The addition of levomefolate calcium (the calcium salt of MeTHF; 451 g/tablet) to oral contraceptives is intended to raise folate status in women of childbearing age [(160)](#reference160). According to a US national survey, only 24% of non-pregnant women aged 15-44 years are meeting the current recommendation of 400 g/day of folic acid [(161)](#reference161). No adverse effects have been associated with the consumption of excess folate from food. Concerns regarding safety are limited to synthetic folic acid intake. Deficiency of vitamin B12, though often undiagnosed, may affect a significant number of people, especially older adults (see the article on [Vitamin B12](../vitamins/vitamin-B12#deficiency)). One symptom of vitamin B12 deficiency is [megaloblastic anemia](../glossary#megaloblastic-anemia), which is indistinguishable from that associated with folate deficiency (see [Deficiency](#deficiency)). Large doses of folic acid given to an individual with an undiagnosed vitamin B12 deficiency could correct megaloblastic anemia without correcting the underlying vitamin B12 deficiency, leaving the individual at [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing irreversible [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) damage. Such cases of neurologic progression in vitamin B12 deficiency have been mostly seen at folic acid doses of 5,000 g (5 mg) and above. In order to be very sure of preventing irreversible neurological damage in vitamin B12-deficient individuals, the Food and Nutrition Board of the US Institute of Medicine advises that all adults limit their intake of folic acid ( [supplements](../glossary#supplement) and [fortification](../glossary#fortification)) to 1,000 g (1 mg) daily (Table 3). The Board also noted that vitamin B12 deficiency is very rare in women in their childbearing years, making the consumption of folic acid at or above 1,000 g/day unlikely to cause problems [(1)](#references); however, there are limited data on the effects of large doses. |Age of intake should be from food and formula only.| The saturation of DHFR metabolic capacity by oral doses of folic acid has been associated with the appearance of unmetabolized folic acid in blood [(162)](#reference162). [Hematologic](../glossary#hematology) abnormalities and poorer [cognition](../glossary#cognition) have been associated with the presence of unmetabolized folic acid in vitamin B12-deficient older adults (60 years) [(163, 164)](#reference163). A small study conducted in postmenopausal women also raised concerns about the effect of exposure to unmetabolized folic acid on immune function [(165)](#reference165). In a small, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [open-label trial](../glossary#open-label-trial) in 38 women of reproductive age receiving 30 weeks of daily multivitamin supplements, daily supplementation with either 1.1 mg or 5 mg of folic acid resulted in the transient appearance of unmetabolized folic acid in blood over the first 12 weeks of supplementation [(166)](#reference166). However, unmetabolized folic acid concentrations returned to baseline levels at the end of the study, suggesting that adaptive mechanisms eventually converted folic acid to reduced forms of folate. Nonetheless, the use of supplemental levomefolate (5-methyl THF) may provide an alternative to prevent the potential negative effects of unconverted folic acid in older adults. When nonsteroidal anti- [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) drugs (NSAIDs), such as aspirin or ibuprofen, are taken in very large therapeutic dosages (i.e., to treat severe arthritis), they may interfere with folate [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism). In contrast, routine use of NSAIDs has not been found to adversely affect folate [status](../glossary#status). The [anticonvulsant](../glossary#anticonvulsant), phenytoin, has been shown to inhibit the [intestinal](../glossary#small-intestine) absorption of folate, and several studies have associated decreased folate status with long-term use of the anticonvulsants, phenytoin, phenobarbital, and primidone [(167)](#reference167). However, few studies controlled for differences in dietary folate intake between anticonvulsant users and nonusers. Also, taking folic acid at the same time as the [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol)-lowering agents, cholestyramine and colestipol, may decrease the absorption of folic acid [(159)](#reference159). Methotrexate is a folate [antagonist](../glossary#antagonist) used of diseases, including [cancer](../glossary#cancer), [rheumatoid arthritis](../glossary#rheumatoid-arthritis), and [psoriasis](../glossary#psoriasis). Some of the side effects of methotrexate are similar to those of severe folate deficiency, and supplementation with folic or folinic acid is used to reduce antifolate toxicity. Other antifolate molecules currently used in cancer therapy include aminopterin, pemetrexed, pralatrexate, and raltitrexed [(96)](#reference96). Further, a number of other medications have been shown to have antifolate activity, including trimethoprim (an antibiotic), pyrimethamine (an antimalarial), triamterene (a blood pressure medication), and sulfasalazine (a treatment for [ulcerative colitis](../glossary#ulcerative-colitis)). Early studies of oral contraceptives (birth control pills) containing high doses of [estrogen](../glossary#estrogen) indicated adverse effects on folate status; however, this finding has not been supported in more recent studies that used low-dose oral contraceptives and controlled for dietary folate [(168)](#reference168). The available scientific evidence shows that adequate folate intake prevents [neural tube defects](../glossary#neural-tube-defect) and other poor outcomes of pregnancy; is helpful in lowering the [risk](../glossary#risk) of some forms of [cancer](../glossary#cancer), especially in genetically susceptible individuals; and may lower the risk of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease). The Linus Pauling Institute recommends that adults take a daily multivitamin/mineral supplement, which typically contains 400 g of folic acid, the Daily Value ( [DV](../glossary#DV)). Even with a larger than average intake of folic acid from [fortified](../glossary#fortification) food, it is unlikely that an individual's daily folic acid intake would regularly exceed the tolerable upper intake level of 1,000 g/day established by the Institute of Medicine (see [Safety](#safety)). The recommendation for 400 g/day of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) folic acid as part of a daily multivitamin/mineral supplement, in addition to a folate-rich diet, is especially important for older adults because blood [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) concentrations tend to increase with age (see [Disease Prevention](#disease-prevention)). Rev. 2011;69(10):572-583. Niacin or vitamin B3 is a water-soluble [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin) used by the body to form the nicotinamide [coenzyme](../glossary#coenzyme), NAD+. The term 'niacin' is often used to refer to nicotinic acid (pyridine-3-carboxylic acid) only, although other vitamers with a pyridine ring, including nicotinamide (pyridine-3-carboxamide) and nicotinamide riboside, also contribute to NAD+ formation [(1)](#references). None of the vitamers are related to the nicotine found in tobacco, although their names are similar. Likewise, nicotine — but not nicotinic acid — is an [agonist](../glossary#agonist) of the nicotinic [receptors](../glossary#receptor) that respond to the [neurotransmitter](../glossary#neurotransmitter), acetylcholine. Essential to all forms of life, the nicotinamide [coenzyme](../glossary#coenzyme) NAD+ is [synthesized](../glossary#synthesis) in the body from four [precursors](../glossary#precursor) that are provided in the diet: nicotinic acid, nicotinamide, nicotinamide riboside, and tryptophan (Figure 1). Figure 2 illustrates the separate biosynthetic pathways that lead to NAD+ production from the various dietary precursors. NAD+ is synthesized from nicotinamide and nicotinamide riboside via two enzymatic reactions, while the pathway that yields NAD+ from nicotinic acid - known as the Preiss-Handler pathway — includes three steps. The kynurenine pathway is the longest NAD+ biosynthetic pathway: the [catabolism](../glossary#catabolism) of tryptophan through kynurenine produces acid, which is then converted to nicotinic acid mononucleotide, an intermediate in NAD+ [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism). Living organisms derive most of their energy from [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction) reactions, which are processes involving the transfer of [electrons](../glossary#electron). Over 400 [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) require the niacin [coenzymes](../glossary#coenzyme), NAD and NADP, mainly to accept or donate electrons for redox reactions [(5)](#reference5). NAD and NADP appear to support distinct functions (Figure 4). NAD functions most often in energy-producing reactions involving the degradation ( [catabolism](../glossary#catabolism)) of [carbohydrates](http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/infocenter/glossary.html#carbohydrate), fats, [proteins](http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/infocenter/glossary.html#protein), and alcohol. NADP is also essential for the regeneration of components of detoxification and [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) systems [(4)](#reference4). The late stage of severe niacin deficiency is known as pellagra. Early records of pellagra followed the widespread cultivation of corn in Europe in the 1700s [(23)](#reference23). The disease is generally associated with poorer social classes whose chief dietary staple consisted of cereal like corn or sorghum. Pellagra was also common in the southern United States during the early 1900s where income was low and corn products were a major dietary staple [(24)](#reference24). Interestingly, pellagra was not known in Mexico, where corn was also an important dietary staple and much of the population was also poor. In fact, if corn contains appreciable amounts of niacin, it is present in a bound form that is not nutritionally available to humans. The traditional preparation of corn tortillas in Mexico involves soaking the corn in a lime (calcium oxide) solution, prior to cooking. Heating the corn in an [alkaline](../glossary#alkaline) solution results in the release of bound niacin, increasing its [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) [(25)](#reference25). Pellagra epidemics were also unknown to Native Americans who consumed immature corn that contains predominantly unbound (bioavailable) niacin [(24)](#reference24). Niacin deficiency or pellagra may result from inadequate dietary intake of NAD precursors, including tryptophan. Niacin deficiency — often associated with malnutrition — is observed in the homeless population, in individuals suffering from anorexia nervosa or [obesity](../glossary#obesity), and in consumers of diets high in maize and poor in animal protein [(26-29)](#reference26). Deficiencies of other B [vitamins](../glossary#vitamin) and some trace [minerals](../glossary#mineral) may aggravate niacin deficiency [(30, 31)](#reference30). Malabsorptive disorders megaduodenum [(32, 33)](#reference32). Patients disease](../glossary#hartnup-disease), a hereditary disorder resulting in defective tryptophan absorption, have developed pellagra (see [Niacin-responsive genetic disorders](#niacin-responsive-genetic-disorders-treatment)). [Carcinoid syndrome](../glossary#carcinoid-syndrome), a condition secretion of [serotonin](../glossary#serotonin) and other [catecholamines](../glossary#catecholamine) by carcinoid tumors, may also result in pellagra due to increased utilization of dietary tryptophan for serotonin rather than niacin [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis). Further, prolonged treatment with the anti- [tuberculosis](../glossary#tuberculosis) drug isoniazid has resulted in niacin deficiency [(34)](#reference34). Other pharmaceutical agents, including the immunosuppressive given to people with [Parkinson's disease)](../glossary#parkinson-disease), are known to increase the reliance on dietary niacin by interfering with the tryptophan-kynurenine-niacin pathway [(35)](#reference35). Finally, other populations at risk for niacin deficiency include [dialysis](../glossary#dialysis) patients, cancer patients [(36, 37)](#reference36), individuals suffering from chronic alcoholism [(38)](#reference38), and people with [HIV](../glossary#HIV) (see [HIV/AIDS](#HIV-AIDS-treatment) below). Further, chronic alcohol intake can lead to severe niacin deficiency through reducing dietary niacin intake and interfering with the tryptophan-to-NAD conversion [(30)](#reference30). The most common symptoms of niacin deficiency involve the skin, the digestive system, and the nervous system. The symptoms of pellagra are commonly referred to as the three "Ds": sun-sensitive [dermatitis](../glossary#dermatitis), diarrhea, and [dementia](../glossary#dementia). A fourth "D," death, occurs if pellagra is left untreated [(5)](#reference5). In the skin, a thick, scaly, darkly pigmented rash develops symmetrically in areas exposed to sunlight. In fact, the word "pellagra" comes from "pelle agra," the Italian phrase for rough skin. Symptoms related to the digestive system include [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) of the mouth and tongue ("bright red tongue"), vomiting, constipation, abdominal pain, and ultimately, diarrhea. [Gastrointestinal ](../glossary#gastrointestinal)disorders and diarrhea contribute to the ongoing malnourishment of the patients. [Neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) symptoms include headache, apathy, fatigue, depression, disorientation, and memory loss and are more consistent with delirium than with the historically described dementia [(38)](#reference38). Disease presentations vary in appearance since the classic triad rarely presents in its entirety. The absence of dermatitis, for example, is known as pellagra sine pellagra. To treat pellagra, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends administering nicotinamide to avoid the flushing commonly caused by nicotinic acid (see [Safety](#safety)). Treatment guidelines suggest using 300 mg/day of oral nicotinamide in divided doses, or 100 mg/day administered parenterally in divided doses, for three to four weeks [(37, 39)](#reference37). Because patients with pellagra often display additional [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin) deficiencies, administration of a vitamin B-complex preparation is advised [(39)](#reference39). The term "niacin equivalent" (NE) is used to describe the contribution to dietary intake of all the forms of niacin that are available to the body. In healthy individuals, less than 2% of dietary tryptophan is converted to NAD in the kynurenine pathway [(40)](#reference40). The synthesis of NAD from tryptophan is fairly inefficient and depends on [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) requiring [vitamin B6](vitamin-B6) and riboflavin, Nonetheless, tryptophan is essential as a for NAD+. Inherited defects in tryptophan transport and [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) result in severe clinical disorders attributed to NAD+ depletion (see [Niacin-responsive genetic disorders](#niacin-responsive-genetic-disorders-treatment)). On average, 60 milligrams (mg) of tryptophan are considered to correspond to 1 mg of niacin or 1 mg of NE. The recommended dietary allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) for niacin is based on the prevention of deficiency. Pellagra can be prevented by about 11 mg NE/day, but 12 mg to 16 mg NE/day has been found to normalize the urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of niacin [metabolites](../glossary#metabolism) (breakdown products) in healthy young adults. Because pellagra represents severe deficiency, the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the US Institute of Medicine chose to use the excretion of niacin metabolites as an indicator of niacin nutritional status rather than symptoms of pellagra [(41)](#reference41). However, it has been argued that cellular NAD and NADP content may be more relevant indicators of niacin nutritional [(24)](#reference24). of cultured cells ( [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro)) provide evidence that NAD content influences mechanisms that maintain [genomic](../glossary#genome) stability. Loss of genomic stability, characterized by a high rate of damage to [DNA](../glossary#DNA) and [chromosomes](../glossary#chromosome), is a hallmark of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [(42)](#reference42). The current understanding is that the pool of NAD is decreased during niacin deficiency and that it affects the activity of NAD-consuming [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) rather than [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction) and metabolic poly ADP-ribosylations catalyzed by PARP enzymes (ARTDs) are critical for the cellular response to DNA injury. After DNA damage, PARPs are activated; the subsequent poly ADP-ribosylations of a number of signaling and structural molecules by PARPs were shown to facilitate DNA repair at DNA strand breaks [(44)](#reference44). Cellular depletion of NAD has been found to decrease levels of the tumor suppressor protein p53, a target for poly ADP-ribosylation, in human breast, skin, and lung cells [(45)](#reference45). The expression of p53 was also altered by niacin deficiency in rat bone marrow cells [(46)](#reference46). Impairment of DNA repair caused by niacin deficiency could lead to genomic instability and drive tumor development in rat models [(47, 48)](#reference47). Both PARPs and sirtuins have been recently involved in the maintenance of heterochromatin, a chromosomal domain associated with genome stability, as well as in [transcriptional](../glossary#transcription) [gene](../glossary#gene) silencing, [telomere](../glossary#telomere) integrity, and chromosome segregation during cell division [(49, 50)](#reference49). Neither the cellular NAD content nor the dietary intake of NAD precursors necessary for optimizing protective responses following DNA damage has been determined, but both are likely to be higher than that required for the prevention of pellagra. [Cancer](../glossary#cancer) patients often suffer from bone marrow suppression following [chemotherapy](../glossary#chemotherapy), given that bone marrow is one of the most [proliferative](../glossary#proliferation) tissues in the body and thus a primary target for chemotherapeutic agents. Niacin deficiency was found to decrease bone marrow NAD and poly-ADP-ribose levels and increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of chemically induced [leukemia](http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/infocenter/glossary.html#leukemia) in rats [(51)](#reference51). Conversely, a [pharmacologic dose](../glossary#pharmacological-dose) of either nicotinic acid or nicotinamide was able to increase NAD and poly ADP-ribose in bone marrow and decrease the development of leukemia in rats [(52)](#reference52). It has been suggested that niacin deficiency often observed in cancer patients could sensitize bone marrow tissue to the suppressive effect of chemotherapy. However, little is known regarding cellular NAD levels and the prevention of [DNA](../glossary#DNA) damage or cancer in humans. One study in two healthy individuals involved elevating NAD levels in blood [lymphocytes](http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/infocenter/glossary.html#lymphocyte) by supplementation with 100 mg/day of nicotinic acid for eight weeks. Compared to non-supplemented individuals, the supplemented individuals had reduced DNA strand breaks in lymphocytes exposed to [free radicals](../glossary#free-radical) in a test tube assay [(53)](#reference53). However, nicotinic acid supplementation of up to 100 mg/day for 14 weeks in 21 healthy smokers failed to provide any evidence of a decrease in cigarette smoke-induced genetic damage in blood lymphocytes compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(54)](#reference54). More recently, the frequency of [chromosome](../glossary#chromosome) translocation was used to evaluate DNA damage in peripheral blood lymphocytes of 82 pilots chronically exposed to ionizing radiation, a known human [carcinogen](../glossary#carcinogen). In this [observational study](../glossary#observational-study), the rate of chromosome aberrations was significantly lower in subjects with higher (28.4 mg/day) compared to lower (20.5 mg/day) dietary niacin intake [(55)](#reference55). Higher availability of NAD+ in X-irradiated peripheral blood lymphocytes was found to favor DNA repair by enhancing survival, particularly through SIRT-mediated p53 deacetylation [(56)](#reference56). Generally, relationships between dietary factors and [cancer](../glossary#cancer) are established first in [epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study) and followed up by basic cancer research at the cellular level. In the case of niacin, research on biochemical and cellular aspects of [DNA](../glossary#DNA) repair has stimulated an interest in the relationship between niacin intake and cancer risk in human populations [(57)](#reference57). A large [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) found increased consumption of niacin, along with [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) nutrients, to be associated with decreased incidence of oral (mouth), pharyngeal (throat), and [esophageal](../glossary#esophagus) cancers in northern Italy and Switzerland. An increase in daily niacin intake of 6.2 mg was associated with about a 40% decrease in cases of cancers of the mouth and throat, while a 5.2 mg increase in daily niacin intake was associated with a similar decrease in cases of [esophageal](http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/infocenter/glossary.html#esophagus) cancer [(58, 59)](#reference58). Niacin deficiency can lead to severe sunlight sensitivity in exposed skin. Given the implication of NAD-dependent [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) in [DNA](../glossary#DNA) repair, there has been some interest in the effect of niacin on skin health. [In vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) and animal experiments have helped gather information, but human data on niacin/NAD status and skin [cancer](../glossary#cancer) are very limited. One study reported that niacin supplementation decreased the [risk](../glossary#risk) of ultraviolet light (UV)-induced skin cancers in mice, despite the fact that mice convert tryptophan to NAD more efficiently than rats and humans and thus do not get severely deficient [(60)](#reference60). Hyper- [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) and impaired [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation) of skin cells can alter the integrity of the skin barrier and increase the occurrence of pre- [malignant](../glossary#malignant) and malignant skin conditions. A protective effect of niacin was suggested by [topical](../glossary#topical) application of myristyl nicotinate, a niacin derivative, which successfully increased the expression of [epidermal](../glossary#epidermis) [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation) markers in subjects with [photodamaged](../glossary#photodamage) skin [(61)](#reference61). Conversely, differentiation defects in skin cancer cells were linked to the abnormal cellular localization of defective nicotinic acid receptors [(62)](#reference62). Nicotinamide restriction with subsequent depletion of cellular NAD was shown to increase [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress)-induced DNA damage in a precancerous skin cell model, implying a protective role of NAD-dependent pathways in cancer [(63)](#reference63). Altered NAD availability also affects sirtuin expression and activity in UV-exposed human skin cells. Along with PARPs, NAD-consuming sirtuins could play an important role in the cellular response to photodamage and skin [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) [(64)](#reference64). A pooled analysis of two large US [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) that followed 41,808 men and 72,308 women for up to 26 years suggested that higher versus lower intake of niacin (from diet and supplements) might be protective against squamous-cell carcinoma but not against basal-cell [phase III](../glossary#phase-III-clinical-trial), [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), trial in 386 subjects with a history of nonmelanoma skin cancer recently examined the effect of daily nicotinamide supplementation (1 g) for 12 months on skin cancer recurrence at three-month intervals over an 18-month period [(66)](#reference66). Larger trials are needed to assess whether nicotinamide could reduce the risk of melanomas, which are not as common as other skin cancer but are more deadly [(67)](#reference67). Type 1 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) in children is caused by the [autoimmune](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) destruction of [insulin](../glossary#insulin)-secreting -cells in the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas). Prior to the onset of symptomatic diabetes, specific [antibodies](../glossary#antibody), including islet cell autoantibodies (ICA), can be detected in the blood of high-risk individuals [(68)](#reference68). In an experimental animal model of diabetes, high levels of nicotinamide are administered to protect -cells from damage caused by streptozotocin [(69)](#reference69). Yet, [pharmacologic doses](../glossary#pharmacologic-dose) of nicotinamide (up to 3 g/day) have not been found to be effective in delaying or preventing the onset of type 1 diabetes in at-risk subjects. An analysis of 10 trials, of which five were [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled, found evidence of improved -cell function after one year of treatment with nicotinamide, but the analysis failed to find any clinical evidence of improved glycemic control [(70)](#reference70). A large, multicenter [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) of nicotinamide in ICA-positive siblings (ages, 3-12 years) of type 1 diabetic patients also failed to find a difference in the incidence of type 1 diabetes after three years [(70)](#reference70). A [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), placebo-controlled multicenter trial of 3 g/day) was conducted in 552 ICA-positive relatives of patients with type 1 diabetes. The proportion of relatives who developed type 1 diabetes within five years was comparable whether they were treated with nicotinamide or placebo [(71)](#reference71). Nicotinamide could reduce [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation)-related parameters in these high-risk subjects yet was ineffective to prevent disease onset [(72)](#reference72). More recently, [case reports](../glossary#case-report) of the combined use of nicotinamide (25 mg/kg/day) and acetyl-L- [carnitine](../dietary-factors/L-carnitine) (50 mg/kg/day) in children at risk for type 1 diabetes showed promising results, warranting further investigation [(73)](#reference73). Niacin [supplements](../glossary#supplement) at [pharmacologic doses](../glossary#pharmacologic-dose) (i.e., doses much larger than those needed to prevent deficiency) have been used in an attempt to treat a range of conditions, some of which are discussed below. Congenital NAD deficiency-related disorders can result from [mutations](../glossary#mutation) in [genes](../glossary#gene) involved in the uptake and transport of the various dietary NAD+ [precursors](../glossary#precursor) or in the distinct metabolic pathways leading to NAD+ production (see [Metabolism](#metabolism)). Some of these disorders might respond to niacin supplementation. For example, defective transport of tryptophan into cells results in [Hartnup disease](../glossary#hartnup-disease), which features signs of severe niacin deficiency [(74)](#reference74). Hartnup disease is due to mutations in the SLCA19 gene, which codes for a sodium-dependent neutral [amino acid](../glossary#amino-acid) transporter expressed primarily in the kidneys and intestine. Disease management involves supplementation with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide [(75)](#reference75). [Recessive mutations](../glossary#recessive-trait) in genes coding for [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) kynurenine pathway — namely kynureninase and 3-hydroxyanthranilic-acid — lead to combined Depletion of NAD+, rather than accumulation of intermediate [metabolites](../glossary#metabolite) in the kynurenine pathway, was found to be responsible for these malformations. Niacin supplementation throughout pregnancy ensured adequate levels of NAD+ and prevented [congenital anomalies](../glossary#congenital-anomaly) in mice with kynurenine pathway mutations [(76)](#reference76). In humans, the dose of NAD+ precursors necessary to avert NAD deficiency-induced congenital VACTERL malformations has yet to be defined [(77)](#reference77). Nicotinamide may also rescue NAD+ depletion secondary to an ultra-rare inborn error of glutamine metabolism [(78)](#reference78). Glutamine is required for the conversion dinucleotide to NAD+ 2). Thus, inherited glutamine synthetase deficiency specifically affects the synthesis of NAD+ from the NAD+ precursors, tryptophan and nicotinic acid. If the combined deficiencies of glutamine and NAD+ are responsible for the severe clinical phenotype of subjects with inherited glutamine synthetase deficiency, it is likely that supplementation with both glutamine and nicotinamide would provide some relief [(78)](#reference78). Finally, many inborn errors of metabolism result from genetic mutations decreasing [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) binding affinity and, subsequently, enzyme efficiency [(79)](#reference79). In many cases, the administration of high doses of the [vitamins](../glossary#vitamin) serving as precursors of cofactors can restore enzymatic activity — at least partially — and lessen signs of the genetic diseases [(79)](#reference79). Given the large number of enzymes requiring NAD, it is speculated that many of the conditions due to defective enzymes might be rescued by niacin supplementation [(5)](#reference5). Nicotinic acid is dense low-density lipoprotein ( [LDL](../glossary#LDL)) particles to large, buoyant LDL particles. All of these changes in the blood [lipid](../glossary#lipid) profile are considered cardioprotective. Low concentrations of HDL-cholesterol are one major [risk](../glossary#risk) factor for [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) (CHD), and an increase in HDL concentrations is associated with a reduction of that risk [(80)](#reference80). Because of the adverse side effects associated with high doses of nicotinic acid (see [Safety](#safety)), nicotinic acid has most often been used in combination with other lipid-lowering medications at slightly lower doses [(17)](#reference17). In particular, low-dose nicotinic acid is often co-administered with 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A reductase inhibitors (statins), the cornerstone of treatment of [hyperlipidemia](../glossary#hyperlipidemia), a major risk factor for CHD. A [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in 39 patients taking statins (cerivastatin, atorvastatin, or simvastatin) found that a very low dose of nicotinic acid (100 mg/day) increased HDL-cholesterol by only 2.1 mg/dL, and the combination had no effect on LDL-cholesterol, total cholesterol, or [triglyceride](../glossary#triglyceride) concentrations [(81)](#reference81). The Arterial Biology for the Investigation of the Treatment Effects of Reducing Cholesterol (ARBITER) 2 study — a [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), placebo-controlled trial — investigated the incremental effect of adding nicotinic acid (1 g/day) to statin therapy in 167 patients with known CHD and low HDL concentrations on carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT) [(82)](#reference82), a surrogate endpoint for the development of [atherosclerosis](../glossary#atherosclerosis). The addition of extended-release nicotinic acid to simvastatin prevented the increase in CIMT compared to simvastatin [monotherapy](../glossary#monotherapy). A post-hoc analysis of data from ARBITER2 showed that the blockade of atherosclerotic progression was related to the increase in HDL concentrations in patients with normal glycemic status. However, in the presence of additional risk factors, such as impaired fasting [glucose](../glossary#glucose) or [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), the increase in HDL concentrations was not predictive of CIMT reduction and atherosclerotic retardation [(83)](#reference83). A comparative efficacy trial (ARBITER6) also showed a significant reduction of baseline CIMT with extended-release nicotinic acid (2 g/day for 14 months), as opposed to ezetimibe (a cholesterol-lowering drug), in patients taking statins [(84)](#reference84). Additional studies have examined the impact of nicotinic acid on endothelium-dependent brachial flow-mediated dilation (FMD) in patients at risk of CHD or with established CHD. The measurement of FMD is often used as a surrogate marker of endothelial function; FMD values are [inversely correlated](../glossary#inverse-association) with the risk of future cardiovascular events [(85)](#reference85). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of seven [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), including 441 participants, showed a significant, 2% increase with nicotinic acid (1-2 g/day) administered for 12 weeks to one year [(86)](#reference86). Several [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled, multicenter trials have investigated the efficacy and safety of nicotinic acid therapy, alone or in combination with other lipid-lowering agents, on outcomes of [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) (CVD). Specifically, the Coronary Drug Project (CDP) followed over 8,000 men with a previous [myocardial infarction](../health-disease/heart-attack) for six years [(87)](#reference87). Compared to the placebo group, patients who took 3 g of immediate-release nicotinic acid daily experienced an average 10% reduction in total blood cholesterol, a 26% decrease in [triglycerides](../glossary#triglyceride), a 27% reduction in recurrent nonfatal myocardial infarction, and a 10% reduction in total deaths with nicotinic acid treatment. The HDL-Atherosclerosis Treatment Study (HATS), a three-year [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 160 patients with documented CHD and low HDL concentrations, found that a combination of simvastatin and nicotinic acid (2-3 g/day) increased HDL concentrations, inhibited the progression of coronary artery [stenosis](../glossary#stenosis) (narrowing), and decreased the frequency of [cardiovascular ](../glossary#cardiovascular)events, including myocardial infarction and stroke, compared to placebo [(88)](#reference88). A subgroup analysis of the HATS patients with [metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome) showed a reduction in rate of primary clinical events even though [glucose](../glossary#glucose) and [insulin](../glossary#insulin) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) were moderately impaired by nicotinic acid [(89)](#reference89). Moreover, a review of nicotinic acid safety and tolerability among the HATS subjects showed glycemic control in diabetic patients returned to pretreatment values following eight months of disease management with medication and diet [(90)](#reference90). Similarly, the cardiovascular benefit of long-term nicotinic acid therapy outweighed the modest increase in risk of newly onset type 2 diabetes in patients from the CDP study [(91)](#reference91). In contrast, the AIM-HIGH (Atherothrombosis intervention in metabolic syndrome with low HDL/high triglycerides: impact on global health outcomes) trial, which examined the incremental effect of extended-release nicotinic acid (1.5-2 g/day) on 3,414 patients who had [dyslipidemia](../glossary#dyslipidemia) and were treated with simvastatin (+/- ezetimibe), provided disappointing results. Indeed, in these patients who had achieved target concentrations of LDL-cholesterol (<70 mg/dL) before randomization, the HDL-raising effect of nicotinic acid treatment failed to reduce the number of cardiovascular events after a mean follow-up of three years [(92, 93)](#reference92). While some limitations, like a greater use of simvastatin and ezetimibe in the control group, may have [confounded](../glossary#confounder) the results, it was also suggested that low HDL-cholesterol might be a marker of risk rather than a causal risk factor for predicting CVD [(93)](#reference93). In addition, a post-hoc analysis of 505 participants with stage 3 chronic kidney disease found an increase in all-cause mortality in those randomized to nicotinic acid compared to those in the placebo group [(94)](#reference94). Although nicotinic acid failed to reduce the number of cardiovascular events in simvastatin-treated patients with low LDL-cholesterol, these results cannot be extrapolated to patients with higher LDL-cholesterol at baseline. A much larger multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial — the HPS2-THRIVE (Heart protection study 2: treatment of HDL to reduce the incidence of vascular events) trial — in 25,673 participants with vascular disease examined the incremental effect of extended-release nicotinic acid (2 g/day) and laropiprant (a prostaglandin D2 receptor-1 antagonist; 40 mg/day) on the incidence of vascular events. Compared to placebo, nicotinic acid/laropiprant reduced LDL-cholesterol by an average of 10 mg/dL, decreased triglycerides by 33 mg/dL, and increased HDL-cholesterol by 6 mg/dL after a median 3.9-year follow-up period. Nonetheless, nicotinic acid/laropiprant showed no effect on the incidence of major vascular events and death of any cause [(95)](#reference95). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 23 randomized controlled trials — including the CDP, AIM-HIGH, and HPS2-THRIVE trials — in 39,195 subjects with a history of vascular disease compared the effect of nicotinic acid alone or as an add-on to other lipid-lowering agents. No cardiovascular benefits were associated with nicotinic acid therapy: the number of fatal and non-fatal myocardial infarctions and strokes was not decreased with nicotinic acid supplementation (median dose of 2 g/day for a median period of 11.5 months) [(96)](#reference96). Despite the lack of evidence for a role of nicotinic acid in CVD prevention [(96, 97)](#reference96), the use of nicotinic acid therapy has rapidly increased over the years in the US [(98)](#reference98). Friedreich's ataxia, a common form of inherited [ataxia](../glossary#ataxia), is an early onset [recessive](../glossary#recessive-trait) disorder with clinical features that includes progressive ataxia, scoliosis, dysarthria, [cardiomyopathy](../glossary#cardiomyopathy), guanine-adenine-adenine (GAA) expansions in the first intron of the [gene](../glossary#gene) FXN coding for the [protein](../glossary#protein) frataxin. These abnormal and unstable GAA repeats trigger gene silencing through heterochromatin formation, leading to significantly reduced frataxin expression [(100)](#reference100). Frataxin is a [mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) protein needed for the making of iron-sulfur clusters (ISC). ISC-containing subunits are especially important for the mitochondrial [respiratory chain](../glossary#electron-transport-chain) and for the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of [heme](../glossary#heme)-containing proteins localized in the [nucleus](../glossary#nucleus), SIRT1 is a NAD+-dependent deacetylase that promotes gene silencing through heterochromatin formation. Nicotinamide has been shown to [antagonize](../glossary#antagonist) heterochromatization FXN locus and lymphoblastoid cells derived Friedreich's ataxia-affected patients, possibly through inhibiting SIRT1 activity [(100)](#reference100). In an open-label, dose escalating [pilot trial](../glossary#pilot-study) in 10 adult patients with Friedreich's ataxia, single and repeated doses of nicotinamide (2-8 g) for up to eight weeks were found to be well tolerated [(101)](#reference101). Repeated daily doses of 3.5 to 6 g of nicotinamide led to significant increases in frataxin concentration in peripheral white blood cells [(101)](#reference101). Yet, no [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) improvements were reported, suggesting that the duration of the treatment was too short and/or the nervous system of the participants was unresponsive to increases in frataxin [(102)](#reference102). To our knowledge, there is currently no ongoing trial designed to further investigate the effect of nicotinamide in Friedreich's ataxia-affected patients. The first step in the pathway is [catalyzed](../glossary#catalyst) by the extrahepatic [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme), indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase which is responsible for the cleavage of tryptophan. The chronic stimulation of tryptophan oxidation, mediated by an increased activity of IDO and/or inadequate dietary niacin intakes, is observed with the infection of human immunodeficiency virus ( [HIV](../glossary#HIV)), the virus that causes ( [AIDS](../glossary#AIDS)). Interferon-gamma (IFN-) is a [cytokine](../glossary#cytokine) produced by cells of the immune system in response to infection. Through stimulating the enzyme IDO, IFN- increases the breakdown of tryptophan, thus supporting the finding that the average tryptophan concentration in blood is significantly lower in HIV patients compared to uninfected subjects [(40)](#reference40). An increased degradation of tryptophan via the kynurenine pathway appears to coexist with intracellular niacin/NAD deficiency in HIV infection [(103)](#reference103). An explanatory model for these paradoxical observations incriminates the [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) induced by multiple nutrient deficiencies in HIV patients [(103)](#reference103). In particular, the activation of PARP enzymes (ARTDs) by [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) to [DNA](../glossary#DNA) could be responsible for inducing niacin/NAD depletion (see [Function](#function)). The breakdown of tryptophan would then be a compensatory response to inadequate niacin/NAD levels. However, [metabolites](../glossary#metabolite) derived from the oxidation of tryptophan in the kynurenine pathway regulate specific T- [lymphocyte](../glossary#lymphocyte) subgroups. As mentioned above, circulating IFN-, but also [viral](../glossary#virus) and [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) products, can activate IDO during HIV infection. The overstimulation of the tryptophan pathway has been involved in the loss of normal T-lymphocyte function, which characterizes HIV infection [(104, 105)](#reference104). The increased IDO activity has been linked to the altered immune response that contributes to the persistence of HIV [(104)](#reference104). Antiretroviral therapy (ART) only partially restores normal IDO activity, without normalizing it, yet induces viral suppression and CD4 T-cell recovery [(106)](#reference106). In a monkey model for HIV infection, a partial and transient blockade of IDO with IDO inhibitor 1-methyl tryptophan proved ineffective to reduce the viral load in [plasma](../glossary#plasma) and intestinal tissues beyond the level achieved by ART [(107)](#reference107). At present, a better understanding of the role of kynurenine pathway and other NAD biosynthetic pathways during HIV infection is needed before the relevance and clinical implications of niacin supplementation in HIV treatment could be considered. Nonetheless, [pharmacologic doses](../glossary#pharmacologic-dose) of nicotinic acid have been shown to be well tolerated in HIV patients with [hyperlipidemia](../glossary#hyperlipidemia) [(108)](#reference108). Abnormal [lipid](../glossary#lipid) profiles observed in patients have been attributed to the HIV infection and to the highly active antiretroviral treatment (HAART) [(109)](#reference109). Moreover, [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance) has been ART-treated patients [(110)](#reference110). [Cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) (CVD) is the second most frequent cause of deaths in the HIV population, and the rate of CVD is predicted to increase further as patients are living longer due to successful antiretroviral therapies. As for the general population, statin-based therapy appears to benefit HIV patients in terms of [atherogenic](../glossary#atherogenic) protection and CVD risk reduction, although contraindications exist due to drug interactions with ART. Other first-line treatments include lipid-lowering fibrates, which are preferred to nicotinic acid due to the increased risk of glucose intolerance and insulin resistance [(111)](#reference111). Nevertheless, an unblinded, controlled [pilot study](../glossary#pilot-study) showed that extended-release nicotinic acid (0.5-1.5 g/day for 12 weeks) could effectively improve endothelial function of the brachial artery in ART-treated HIV subjects with low [HDL](../glossary#HDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) and no history of CVD [(112)](#reference112). In addition, combined treatment of fibrates, extended-release nicotinic acid (0.5-2 g/day), and lifestyle changes (low-fat diet and exercise) for 24 weeks was effective in normalizing lipid parameters in a cohort of 191 ART-treated patients. Increased risk of liver dysfunction was detected in subjects receiving both fibrates and niacin, but [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) was not affected by nicotinic acid treatment given alone or when combined with fibrates [(113)](#reference113). Another 24-week, [open-label](../glossary#open-label-trial), uncontrolled trial in 99 to extended-release nicotinic acid (0.5-2 g/day) or fenofibrates increased blood HDL-cholesterol but did not reduce inflammatory markers or improve endothelial function when compared to baseline [(114)](#reference114). [Schizophrenia](../glossary#schizophrenia) is a [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) disorder with unclear [etiology](../glossary#etiology) that is diagnosed purely from its clinical presentation. Because neurologic disorders associated with pellagra resemble acute schizophrenia, niacin-based therapy for the condition was investigated during the 1950s-70s (reviewed in [115](#reference115)). The [adjunctive](../glossary#adjunct-therapy) use of nutrients like niacin to correct deficiencies associated with neurologic symptoms is called orthomolecular psychiatry [(116)](#reference116). Such an approach has not been included in psychiatric practice; practitioners have instead relied solely on antipsychotic drugs to eliminate the clinical symptoms of schizophrenia. Nevertheless, recent scientific advances and new [hypotheses](../glossary#hypothesis) on the benefit of nutrient supplementation in the treatment of psychiatric disorders have suggested the re-assessment of orthomolecular medicine by the medical community [(117, 118)](#reference117). Skin flushing is one major side effect of the therapeutic use of nicotinic acid and the primary reason for non-adherence to treatment (see [Toxicity](#toxicity)). Flushing is caused by the activation of phospholipase A2, an [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) that stimulates the production of a specific [lipid](../glossary#lipid) from the prostanoid family called [prostaglandin](../glossary#prostaglandin) D2. Prostaglandin D2, [synthesized](../glossary#synthesis) by [antigen](../glossary#antigen)-presenting cells of the skin and mucosa (i.e., the Langerhans cells), can induce the dilation of blood vessels and trigger a flushing response. Interestingly, patients with schizophrenia tend not to flush following treatment with nicotinic acid. This blunted skin flushing response suggests abnormal prostanoid signaling in schizophrenic patients [(119, 120)](#reference119). An association has been found between the altered niacin sensitivity and greater functional impairment in schizophrenic subjects [(121)](#reference121), which supports other findings suggesting that altered lipid [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) could critically impair brain development and contribute to the disease [(122)](#reference122). Interestingly, blunted skin flushing responses are more [prevalent](../glossary#prevalent) in first-degree relatives of people with schizophrenia than in the general population, suggesting that reduced niacin sensitivity is a heritable trait within affected families [(123)](#reference123). Good sources of niacin include yeast, meat, poultry, red fish (e.g., tuna, salmon), cereal (especially [fortified](../glossary#fortification) cereal), [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes), and seeds. Milk, green leafy vegetables, [coffee](../food-beverages/coffee), and [tea](../food-beverages/tea) also provide some niacin [(124)](#reference124). In plants, especially mature cereal grains like corn and wheat, niacin may be bound to sugar molecules in the form of [glycosides](../glossary#glycoside), which significantly decrease its [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) [(25)](#reference25). In the United States, the average dietary intake of niacin is about 30 mg/day for young adult men and 20 mg/day for young adult women. In a sample of adults over the age of 60, men and women were found to have an average dietary intake of 21 mg/day and 17 mg/day, respectively [(41)](#reference41). Food composition tables generally list niacin content without including niacin equivalents (NE) from tryptophan or any adjustment for niacin bioavailability. For more information on the nutrient content of specific foods, search [USDA's FoodData Central database](https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/); data included in Table 2 are from this database [(125)](#reference125). |Food||Serving||Niacin (mg)| |Chicken (light meat, cooked canned, packed in the size of a deck of cards.| Niacin [supplements](../glossary#supplement) are available as nicotinamide or nicotinic acid. Nicotinamide is the form of niacin typically used in nutritional supplements and in food [fortification](../glossary#fortification). Nicotinic acid is available over the counter and with a prescription as a [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol)-lowering agent [(126)](#reference126). Nicotinic acid for anti- three formulations: immediate-release (crystalline) nicotinic acid (absorption time, 1-2 hrs), acid (absorption time, 8-12 hrs), and sustained-release nicotinic (absorption time, >12 hrs) [(127)](#reference127). At the [pharmacologic dose](../glossary#pharmacologic-dose) required for cholesterol-lowering effects, the use of nicotinic acid should be approached as if it were a drug (see [Safety](#safety)). Individuals should only undertake cholesterol-lowering therapy with nicotinic acid under the supervision of a qualified health care provider in order to minimize potentially adverse effects and maximize therapeutic benefits. Common side effects of nicotinic acid include flushing, [pruritus](../glossary#pruritus) (severe itching of the skin), skin rashes, and [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) disturbances, such as nausea and vomiting [(97)](#reference97). Transient episodes of low blood pressure (hypotension) and headache have also been reported. Hepatotoxicity (liver cell damage), including elevated liver [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) and [jaundice](../glossary#jaundice), has been observed at intakes as low as 750 mg/day of nicotinic acid [(128)](#reference128). Although [hepatitis](../glossary#hepatitis) has been observed with extended-release nicotinic acid at dosages as little as 500 mg/day for two months, almost all reports of severe hepatitis have been associated with doses of 3 to 9 g/day used to treat high [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) for months or years [(41)](#reference41). It is unclear whether immediate-release (crystalline) nicotinic acid is less toxic to the liver than extended-release forms [(41)](#reference41). Yet, immediate-release nicotinic acid is often used at higher doses than extended-release forms, and severe liver toxicity has occurred in individuals who substituted extended-release nicotinic acid for immediate-release nicotinic acid at equivalent doses [(126)](#reference126). Large doses of nicotinic acid have been observed to [impair glucose tolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance), likely because of a decrease in [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive). Impaired glucose tolerance in susceptible (pre-diabetic) individuals could result in elevated blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentrations and clinical type 2 diabetes mellitus. An analysis of the HPS2-THRIVE trial (see [Cardiovascular disease](#cardiovascular-disease-treatment)), using data from 17,374 participants without type 2 diabetes at baseline, found a significantly higher proportion of newly diagnosed cases among those [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) to nicotinic acid/laropiprant than to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) to nicotinic acid/laropiprant significantly increased the [risk](../glossary#risk) of serious disturbances in diabetes control (leading to hospitalization) compared to placebo among 8,299 participants with diabetes at baseline [(95)](#reference95). Elevated blood concentrations of [uric acid](../glossary#uric-acid), occasionally resulting in attacks of [gout](../glossary#gout) in susceptible individuals, have also been observed with high-dose nicotinic acid therapy [(126)](#reference126). Niacin at doses of 1.5 to 5 g/day has resulted in a few [case reports](../glossary#case-report) of blurred vision and other eye problems, which have generally been reversible upon discontinuation [(41)](#reference41). People with abnormal liver function or a history of liver disease, diabetes, active [peptic ulcer disease](../glossary#peptic-ulcer-disease), gout, cardiac [arrhythmias](../health-disease/arrhythmia), [inflammatory bowel disease](../glossary#inflammatory-bowel-disease), [migraine headaches](../glossary#migraine-headache), or alcoholism may be more susceptible to the adverse effects of excess niacin intake than the general population [(41)](#reference41). Nicotinamide is generally better tolerated than nicotinic acid; it does not generally cause flushing [(126)](#reference126). However, nausea, vomiting, and signs of liver toxicity (elevated liver [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme), [jaundice](../glossary#jaundice)) have been observed at very high doses (10 g/day) [(126)](#reference126). A study in 12 healthy subjects found that nicotinamide riboside at three single doses (100 mg, 300 mg, and 1,000 mg) safely increased blood NAD+. Two of the participants self-reported skin flushing after taking the 300-mg dose, and two others reported feeling hot following intake of 1,000 mg of nicotinamide riboside [(1)](#references). In a recent [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 120 healthy adults (ages, 60-80 years), daily supplementation with nicotinamide riboside (250 mg or 500 mg) and pterostilbene (a SIRT activator; 50 mg or 100 mg) for eight weeks showed a favorable side effect profile, with no evidence of higher incidence of adverse effects compared to placebo [(129)](#reference129). Most recently, a randomized, placebo-controlled trial in 40 obese men (ages, 40-70 years) found that daily supplementation with nicotinamide riboside (2,000 mg/day divided into two daily dosages) for 12 weeks was associated with reports of only minor side effects, including excessive sweating, [pruritus](../glossary#pruritus), and mild [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) symptoms like bloating [(139)](#reference139). Flushing of the skin primarily on the face, arms, and chest is a common side effect of nicotinic acid and may occur initially at doses as low as 30 mg/day. Although flushing from nicotinamide is rare, the Food and Nutrition Board set the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for niacin (nicotinic acid and nicotinamide) at 35 mg/day in adults to avoid the adverse effect of flushing [(41)](#reference41). Analysis of data from the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 2003-2006 found that 15.8% of children and adolescents (ages 2-18 years) and 8.5% of adults (19 years) had total usual niacin intakes exceeding the UL [(130)](#reference130). The UL applies to the general population and is not meant to apply to individuals who are being treated with a nutrient under medical supervision (e.g., high-dose nicotinic acid for cholesterol of intake should be from food and formula only.| The occurrence of rhabdomyolysis is increased in patients treated with statins (HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors). Rhabdomyolysis is a relatively uncommon condition in which muscle cells are broken down, releasing [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) and [electrolytes](../glossary#electrolyte) into the blood, and sometimes resulting in kidney failure [(131)](#reference131). Co-administration of nicotinic acid with a statin seems to enhance the [risk](../glossary#risk) of rhabdomyolosis [(132)](#reference132). A new drug, laropiprant, blocks nicotinic acid-induced flushing [(133)](#reference133). A [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial was designed to identify possible adverse effects of the niacin/laropiprant combination in over 25,000 simvastatin-treated subjects [(134)](#reference134). When added to the statin therapy, niacin/laropiprant increased the risk of [myopathy](../glossary#myopathy) and rhabdomyolosis, particularly in Asian subjects. It is possible that the niacin/laropiprant combination further reduces the poor tolerability to statin treatment observed in certain populations [(135)](#reference135). In the three-year, randomized controlled HATS study, concurrent therapy with [antioxidants](../glossary#antioxidant) (1,000 mg/day of vitamin C, 800 IU/day of RRR--tocopherol, 100 µg/day of selenium, and 25 mg/day of -carotene) diminished the protective effects of the simvastatin-nicotinic acid combination [(136)](#reference136). Although the mechanism for these effects is not known, the benefit of concurrent antioxidant therapy in patients on lipid-lowering agents has been questioned [(137)](#reference137). Adverse effects of large doses of nicotinic acid may be exacerbated by the concomitant use of certain medications. The risk of [myopathy](../glossary#myopathy) may be further increased in those taking nicotinic acid and [bile acid](../glossary#bile-acids) and the risk of hepatotoxicity observed with nicotinic acid might be enhanced by drugs like paracetamol, amiodarone (Cordarone), or carbamazepine (Tegretol) [(35)](#reference35). In nicotinic acid may reduce [uric acid](../glossary#uric-acid) [excretion](../glossary#excretion), thereby opposing the action of uricosuric agents like probenecid (Probalan) [(35)](#reference35). Several other medications may interact with niacin therapy or with absorption and [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of the [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin) [(126)](#reference126). [Estrogen](../glossary#estrogen) and estrogen-containing oral contraceptives increase the efficiency of niacin [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) from tryptophan, resulting in a decreased dietary requirement for niacin [(138)](#reference138). Long-term administration of [chemotherapy](../glossary#chemotherapy) agents has been reported to cause symptoms of pellagra; therefore, niacin supplementation may be needed (see [Pellagra causes](#pellagra)). The optimum intake of niacin for health promotion and [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease) prevention is not yet known. The [RDA](../glossary#RDA) (16 mg NE/day for men and 14 mg NE/day for women) is easily obtainable by consuming a varied diet and should prevent deficiency in most people. Following the Linus Pauling Institute recommendation to take a daily multivitamin/mineral supplement, containing 100% of the Daily Value ( [DV](../glossary#DV)) for niacin, will provide at least 20 mg of niacin daily.
