Pantothenic acid is found throughout all branches of life in the form of [coenzyme](../glossary#coenzyme) A, a vital coenzyme in numerous chemical reactions [(2)](#reference2). Pantothenic acid is a [precursor](../glossary#precursor) in the [biosynthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of coenzyme A (CoA) (Figure 1), an essential coenzyme in a variety of biochemical reactions that sustain life (see below). Pantothenic acid kinase II (PANKII) catalyzes the initial step of [phosphorylation](../glossary#phosphorylation) of pantothenic acid to 4'-phosphopantothenic acid. Coenzyme A and its derivatives inhibit the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of 4'-phosphopantothenic acid, but the inhibition can be reversed by [carnitine](../glossary#carnitine), required for the transport of [fatty acids](../glossary#fatty-acid) into the [mitochondria](../glossary#mitochondria) [(3)](#reference3). The subsequent reactions in this biosynthetic pathway include the synthesis of the intermediate 4'-phosphopantetheine, as well as the recycling of coenzyme A to 4'-phosphopantetheine (Figure 1). The 4'-phosphopantetheinyl moiety of coenzyme A can be transferred to [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) in which 4'-phosphopantetheine is an essential [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) for their biological activities (see [4'-phosphopantetheinylation](#phosphopantetheinylation)). Coenzyme A reacts with acyl groups, giving rise acetyl-CoA, malonyl-CoA, and 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl (HMG)-CoA. Coenzyme A and its acyl derivatives are required for reactions that generate energy from the degradation of dietary fat, [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate), and [proteins](../glossary#protein). In addition, coenzyme A in the form of acetyl-CoA and succinyl-CoA is involved in the [citric acid cycle](../glossary#citric-acid-cycle), in the synthesis of essential fats, [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol), [steroid](../glossary#steroid) [hormones](../glossary#hormone), vitamins A and D, the [neurotransmitter](../glossary#neurotransmitter) in the [fatty acid](../glossary#fatty-acid) - [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) pathway. Coenzyme A derivatives are also required for the synthesis of the hormone, melatonin, and for a component of [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) called [heme](../glossary#heme). Further, [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of a number of drugs and toxins by the liver requires coenzyme A [(4)](#reference4). Coenzyme A was named for its role in [acetylation](../glossary#acetylation) reactions. Most acetylated proteins in the body have been modified by the addition of an acetate group that was donated by the coenzyme A thioester derivative, acetyl-CoA. Protein acetylation alters the overall charge of proteins, modifying their three-dimensional structure and, potentially, their function. For example, acetylation is a mechanism that regulates the activity of [peptide hormones](../glossary#peptide-hormone), including those produced by the [pituitary gland](../glossary#pituitary-gland) [(5)](#reference5). Also, protein acetylation, like other posttranslational modifications, has been shown to regulate the subcellular localization, the function, and the half-life of many [signaling](../glossary#cell-signaling) molecules, [transcription factors](../glossary#transcription-factor), and [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme). Notably, the acetylation of [histones](../glossary#histone) plays a role in the regulation of [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression) by facilitating [transcription](../glossary#translation) (i.e., [mRNA](../glossary#mRNA) synthesis), while deacetylated histones are usually associated with [chromatin](../glossary#chromatin) compaction and [gene](../glossary#gene) silencing. The acetylation of histones was found to result in structural changes of the chromatin, which affect both [DNA](../glossary#DNA)-protein and protein-protein interactions. Crosstalk between acetylation marks and other posttranscriptional modifications of the histones also facilitate the recruitment of transcriptional regulators to the [promoter](../glossary#promoter) of genes that are subsequently transcribed (reviewed in [6](#reference6)). Finally, a number of signaling molecules are modified by the attachment of long-chain fatty acids donated by coenzyme A. These modifications are known as protein acylation and have central roles in [cell-signaling](../glossary#cell-signaling) pathways [(4)](#reference4). Specific multi- [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) complexes, which need to carry out several reactions in an orderly manner, may require the [covalent](../glossary#covalent-bond) attachment of a 4'-phosphopantetheine arm to a "carrier" domain (or [protein](../glossary#protein)). This carrier domain holds substrates or reaction intermediates during the progression through the various enzymatic reactions. In mammals, the transfer of the 4'-phosphopantetheinyl moiety from coenzyme A to a conserved serine residue of a specific carrier domain is [catalyzed](../glossary#catalyze) by one unique phosphopantetheinyl transferase [(7)](#reference7). The 4'-phosphopantetheinylation is necessary for the conversion of apo-enzymes into fully active holo-enzymes (see below). [Lipids](../glossary#lipid) are fat molecules essential for normal physiological function and, among other types, include sphingolipids (essential components of the [myelin](../glossary#myelin) sheath that enhances nerve transmission), [phospholipids](../glossary#phospholipid) (important structural components of [cell membranes)](../glossary#cell-membrane), and that [catalyzes](../glossary#catalyze) the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of fatty acids. Within the FAS complex, the acyl-carrier protein (ACP) requires pantothenic acid in the form of 4'-phosphopantetheine for its activity as a carrier protein [(3)](#reference3). A group, such as the 4'-phosphopantetheinyl moiety for ACP, is called a prosthetic group; the prosthetic group is not composed of [amino acids](../glossary#amino-acid) and is a tightly bound [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) required for the biological activity of some [proteins](../glossary#protein) (Figure 2). Acetyl-CoA, malonyl-CoA, and ACP are all required for the synthesis of fatty acids in the [cytosol](../glossary#cytosol). During fatty acid synthesis, the acyl groups of acetyl-CoA and malonyl-CoA are transferred to the sulfhydryl group (-SH) of the 4'-phosphopantetheinyl moiety of ACP. The prosthetic group is used as a flexible arm to transfer the growing fatty acid chain to each of the enzymatic centers of the type I FAS complex. In the [mitochondria](../glossary#mitochondria), 4'-phosphopantetheine also serves as a prosthetic group for an ACP homolog present in mitochondrial type II FAS complex [(8)](#reference8). the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of [nucleic acids](../glossary#nucleic-acid) and [amino acids](../glossary#amino-acid) (Figure 3). Similar to ACP, FDH requires a 4'-phosphopantetheine prosthetic group for its biological activity. The prosthetic group acts as a swinging arm to couple the activities of the two catalytic domains of FDH [(9, 10)](#reference9). A homolog of FDH to be biologically active [(11)](#reference11). 4'-phosphopantetheinylation is required for -aminoadipate semialdehyde synthase (AASS). AASS [catalyzes](../glossary#catalyze) the initial the [mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) pathway for the degradation of lysine — an essential [amino acid](../glossary#amino-acid) for humans. AASS is made of two catalytic domains. The lysine-ketoglutarate reductase domain first catalyzes the conversion of lysine to saccharopine. Saccharopine is further converted to -aminoadipate semialdehyde in a reaction catalyzed by the saccharopine dehydrogenase domain (Figure 4). Naturally occurring pantothenic acid deficiency in humans is very rare and has been observed only in cases of severe malnutrition. World War II prisoners in the Philippines, Burma, and Japan experienced numbness and painful burning and tingling in their feet; these symptoms were relieved specifically by pantothenic acid supplementation [(4)](#reference4). Pantothenic acid deficiency in humans has been induced experimentally by co-administering a pantothenic acid kinase and a pantothenic acid-deficient diet. Participants in this experiment complained of headache, fatigue, insomnia, intestinal disturbances, and numbness and tingling of their hands and feet [(12)](#reference12). In another study, participants fed only a pantothenic acid-free diet did not develop clinical signs of deficiency, although some appeared listless and complained of fatigue [(13)](#reference13). Calcium homopantothenate (or hopantenate) is a pantothenic acid [antagonist](../glossary#antagonist) with [cholinergic](../glossary#cholinergic) effects (i.e., similar to those of the [neurotransmitter](../glossary#neurotransmitter), acetylcholine). This compound is used in Japan to enhance mental function, especially in [Alzheimer's disease](../glossary#alzheimer-disease). A rare side effect was the development of hepatic encephalopathy, a condition of abnormal brain function resulting from the failure of the liver to eliminate toxins. The encephalopathy was reversed by pantothenic acid supplementation, suggesting that it was due to homopantothenate-induced pantothenic acid deficiency [(14)](#reference14). Of note, genetic [mutations](../glossary#mutation) in the human [gene](../glossary#gene) PANKII, which codes for pantothenic acid kinase II (see [Figure 1](#figure-1) above), result in impaired [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of 4'-phosphopantetheine and A (see [Function](#function)). The disorder, called pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration, is characterized by visual and intellectual impairments, dystonia, speech abnormalities, behavioral difficulties, and personality disorders [(15)](#reference15). Yet, because pantothenic acid is widely distributed in nature and deficiency is extremely rare in humans, most information regarding the consequences of deficiency has been gathered from experimental research in animals (reviewed in [3](#reference3)). Pantothenic acid-deficient rats developed damage to the [adrenal glands](../glossary#adrenal-glands), while monkeys developed [anemia](../glossary#anemia) due to decreased synthesis of [heme](../glossary#heme), a component of [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin). Dogs with pantothenic acid deficiency developed low blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose), rapid breathing and heart rates, and convulsions. Chickens developed skin irritation, feather abnormalities, and spinal nerve damage associated with the degeneration of the [myelin](../glossary#myelin) sheath. Pantothenic acid-deficient mice showed decreased exercise tolerance and diminished storage of glucose (in the form of [glycogen](../glossary#glycogen)) in muscle and liver. Mice also developed skin irritation and graying of the fur, which is reversed by pantothenic acid administration. The diversity of symptoms emphasizes the numerous functions of pantothenic acid in its [coenzyme](../glossary#coenzyme) forms. Because there was little information on the requirements of pantothenic acid in humans, the Food and Nutrition Board of the Institute of Medicine set an adequate intake ( [AI](../glossary#AI)) based on observed dietary intakes in healthy of calcium D-pantothenate and/or pantothenol (Figure 5) to the medium of cultured skin [fibroblasts](../glossary#fibroblast) given an artificial wound was found to increase cell [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) and migration, thus accelerating wound healing [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) [(17, 18)](#reference17). Likewise, in vitro deficiency in pantothenic acid induced the expression of [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation) markers in proliferating skin fibroblasts and inhibited proliferation in human [keratinocytes](../glossary#keratinocyte) [(19)](#reference19). The application of ointments containing either calcium D-pantothenate or pantothenol — also known as D-panthenol or dexpanthenol — to the skin has been shown to accelerate the closure of skin wounds and increase the strength of scar tissue in animals [(3)](#reference3). The effects of dexpanthenol on wound healing are unclear. In a [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study that included 12 healthy volunteers, the application of dexpanthenol-containing ointment (every 12 hours for 1 to 6 days) in a model of skin wound healing was associated with an enhanced expression of markers of proliferation, [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), and tissue repair [(20)](#reference20). However, the study failed to report whether these changes in response to [topical](../glossary#topical) dexpanthenol improved the wound-repair process compared to placebo [(20)](#reference20). Some studies have shown no effects. Early [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in patients undergoing surgery for tattoo removal found that daily co-supplementation with 1 gram or 3 grams of vitamin C and 200 mg or 900 mg of pantothenic acid for 21 days did not significantly improve the wound-healing process [(21, 22)](#reference21). Yet, in a recent [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), study, the use of dexpanthenol pastilles (300 mg/day for up to 14 days post surgery) was found to accelerate mucosal healing after tonsillectomy in children [(23)](#reference23). Early studies suggested that [pharmacologic doses](../glossary#pharmacologic-dose) of pantethine, a pantothenic acid derivative, might have a [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol)-lowering effect [(24, 25)](#reference24). Pantethine is made of two molecules of pantetheine joined by a disulfide bond (chemical bond between two molecules of sulfur) (Figure 5). Pantethine is structurally related to coenzyme A and is found in the prosthetic group that is required for the biological function of acyl-carrier protein, formyltetrahydrofolate dehydrogenase, pantethine (600 mg/day for 8 weeks, followed by 900 mg/day for another 8 weeks) significantly improved the profile of [lipid](../glossary#lipid) parameters in 120 individuals at low-to-moderate risk of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) (CVD). After adjusting to baseline, pantethine was found to be significantly more effective than placebo in lowering the concentrations of [low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol](../glossary#LDL) (LDL-C) and apolipoprotein B (apoB), as well ratio of [triglycerides](../glossary#triglycerides) to [high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol](../glossary#HDL) (TG:HDL-C) [(26)](#reference26). Although it appears to be well tolerated and potentially beneficial in improving cholesterol [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), pantethine is not a [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin), and the decision to use pharmacologic doses of pantethine to treat elevated blood cholesterol or triglycerides should only be made in collaboration with a qualified health care provider who provides appropriate follow up. Mice that are deficient in pantothenic acid developed skin irritation and graying of the fur, which is reversed by pantothenic acid administration. In humans, there is no evidence that taking pantothenic acid as [supplements](../glossary#supplement) or using shampoos containing pantothenic acid can prevent or restore hair color. Pantothenic acid is available in a variety of foods, usually as a component of coenzyme A (CoA) and 4'-phosphopantetheine (see [Figure 1](#figure-1) above). Upon ingestion, dietary coenzyme A and phosphopantetheine are [hydrolyzed](../glossary#hydrolysis) to pantothenic acid prior to intestinal absorption [(3)](#reference3). Animal liver and kidney, fish, shellfish, pork, chicken, egg yolk, milk, yogurt, [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes), mushrooms, avocados, broccoli, and sweet potatoes are good sources of pantothenic acid. [Whole grains](../food-beverages/whole-grains) are also good sources of pantothenic acid, but processing and refining grains may result in a 35 to 75% loss. Freezing and canning of foods result in similar losses [(16)](#reference16). Large national, nutritional surveys failed to estimate pantothenic acid intake, mainly because of the scarcity of data on the pantothenic acid content of food [(16)](#reference16). Smaller studies estimated average daily intakes of pantothenic acid to be between 4 and 7 mg/day in adults. A specialized transporter for the uptake of [biotin](biotin) and pantothenic acid was identified in cultured cells derived from the lining of the colon, suggesting that humans may be able to absorb pantothenic acid and biotin produced by intestinal bacteria [(27)](#reference27). However, the extent to which bacterial synthesis contributes to pantothenic acid intake in humans is not known [(28)](#reference28). [Supplements](../glossary#supplement) commonly contain pantothenol (panthenol), a stable alcohol [analog](../glossary#analog) of pantothenic acid, which can be rapidly converted to pantothenic acid by humans. Calcium and sodium D-pantothenate, the [calcium](../minerals/calcium) and [sodium](../minerals/sodium) salts of pantothenic acid, are also available as supplements. Pantethine is used as a [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol)-lowering agent in Japan and is available in the US as a dietary supplement [(29)](#reference29). Pantothenic acid is not known to be toxic in humans. The only adverse effect noted was diarrhea resulting from very high intakes of 10 to 20 g/day of calcium D-pantothenate [(30)](#reference30). of life-threatening eosinophilic pleuropericardial effusion in an elderly woman who took a combination of 10 mg/day of [biotin](biotin) and 300 mg/day of pantothenic acid for two months [(31)](#reference31). Due to the lack of reports of adverse effects when the Dietary Reference Intakes ( [DRI](../glossary#DRI)) for pantothenic acid were established in 1998, the Food and Nutrition Board of the Institute of Medicine did not establish a tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for pantothenic acid [(16)](#reference16). Pantethine is generally well tolerated in doses up to 1,200 mg/day. However, [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) side effects, such as nausea and heartburn, have been reported [(29)](#reference29). Also, [topical](../glossary#topical) formulations containing up to 5% of dexpanthenol (D-panthenol) have been safely used for up to one month. Yet, a few cases of skin irritation, contact [dermatitis](../glossary#dermatitis), and eczema have been reported with the use of dexpanthenol-containing ointments [(32, 33)](#reference32). Large doses of pantothenic acid have the potential to compete with [biotin](biotin) for intestinal and cellular uptake by the human sodium-dependent multivitamin transporter (hSMVT) [(27](#reference27), [34)](#reference34). Oral contraceptives (birth control pills) containing [estrogen](../glossary#estrogen) and progestin may increase the requirement for pantothenic acid [(30)](#reference30). Use of pantethine in combination with cholesterol-lowering drugs called statins (HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors) or with nicotinic acid (see the article on [Niacin](niacin)) may produce additive effects on blood [lipids](../glossary#lipid) [(29)](#reference29). More data are needed to define the amount of dietary pantothenic acid required to promote optimal health or prevent [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease). The Linus Pauling Institute supports the recommendation by the Food and Nutrition Board of 5 mg/day of pantothenic acid for adults. A varied diet should provide enough pantothenic acid for most people. Following the Linus Pauling Institute recommendation to take a daily [multivitamin/mineral supplement](../micronutrients-health/multivitamin-mineral-supplements) that contains 100% of the Daily Value ( [DV](../glossary#DV)) for pantothenic acid will ensure an intake of at least 5 mg/day. There is currently little evidence that older adults differ in their intake of or their requirement for pantothenic acid. Most [multivitamin/mineral supplements](../micronutrients-health/multivitamin-mineral-supplements) provide at least 5 mg/day of pantothenic acid. Riboflavin is primarily found as an integral component of the that use a flavocoenzyme are called flavoproteins [(2)](#reference2). Living organisms derive most of their energy from [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction) reactions, which are processes that involve the transfer of [electrons](../glossary#electron). Flavocoenzymes participate in redox reactions in numerous metabolic pathways They are critical for the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate), [lipids](../glossary#lipid), and [proteins](../glossary#protein). FAD is part of the [electron transport (respiratory) chain](../glossary#electron-transport-chain), which is central to energy production. In conjunction with [cytochrome P-450](../glossary#cytochrome-P450), flavocoenzymes also participate in the metabolism of toxins [(4)](#reference4). Glutathione reductase is a FAD-dependent [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction) cycle of [glutathione](../glossary#glutathione). The glutathione redox cycle plays a major role in protecting organisms from [reactive oxygen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species), such as hydroperoxides. Glutathione reductase requires FAD to regenerate two molecules of reduced glutathione from oxidized glutathione. Uric acid is one of the most effective water-soluble [ antioxidants](../glossary#antioxidant) in the blood. Riboflavin deficiency can result in decreased xanthine oxidase activity, reducing blood uric acid levels [(6)](#reference6). Riboflavin (as FAD or FMN) is required for the synthesis of [niacin](niacin) from tryptophan, and in the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of [vitamin B6](vitamin-B6) and [iron](../minerals/iron). It is also essential for folate and related [one-carbon](../glossary#one-carbon-unit) metabolism, where FAD is required as a [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) for methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR), a key folate-metabolizing enzyme. Along with other B vitamins vitamin B12, and vitamin B6), higher dietary riboflavin intakes have been associated with lower [plasma](../glossary#plasma) concentrations of homocysteine [(12)](#reference12). In individuals [homozygous](../glossary#homozygous) [polymorphism](../glossary#polymorphism) in the MTHFR [gene](../glossary#gene), low riboflavin status is associated with elevated plasma homocysteine, and in turn linked with a higher risk of cardiovascular disease and other [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease) [(13, 14)](#reference13). Furthermore, supplementation with riboflavin results in marked lowering of homocysteine concentrations specifically in individuals with the variant MTHFR 677TT genotype [(15)](#reference15). Such results illustrate that chronic disease risk may be influenced by complex interactions between genetic and dietary factors. Riboflavin deficiency alters [iron](../minerals/iron) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism). Although the mechanism is not clear, research in animals suggests that riboflavin deficiency may impair iron absorption, increase intestinal loss of iron, and/or impair iron utilization for the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) [(16)](#reference16). In humans, low dietary intake of riboflavin has been associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for [anemia](../glossary#anemia) [(17)](#reference17), and improving riboflavin nutritional [status](../glossary#status) has been found to increase circulating hemoglobin levels [(18)](#reference18). Correction of riboflavin deficiency in individuals who are both riboflavin and iron deficient improves the response of iron-deficiency anemia to iron therapy [(19)](#reference19). Anemia during pregnancy, a worldwide public health problem, is responsible for considerable perinatal morbidity and mortality [(20, 21)](#reference20). The management of maternal anemia typically involves [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with iron alone or iron in combination with folic acid [(22)](#reference22). It is possible that the inclusion of riboflavin could enhance the effects of iron-folic acid supplementation in treating maternal anemia, but the evidence is limited. There are, however, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind) [intervention trials](../glossary#intervention-trial) conducted in pregnant women with anemia in Southeast Asia showing that a combination of folic acid, iron, [vitamin A](vitamin-A), and riboflavin improved hemoglobin levels and decreased anemia compared to iron-folic acid supplementation alone [(23, 24)](#reference23). Ariboflavinosis is the medical name for clinical riboflavin deficiency, which occurs commonly in low- and middle-income countries. Riboflavin deficiency is rarely found in isolation; it typically occurs in combination with deficiencies of other water-soluble [vitamins](../glossary#vitamin). Clinical signs of riboflavin deficiency include sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, cracks or sores on the outsides of the lips (cheliosis) and at the corners of the mouth (angular stomatitis), [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) and redness of the tongue (magenta tongue), and a moist, scaly skin inflammation (seborrheic dermatitis). Other signs may involve the formation of blood vessels in the clear covering of the eye ( [vascularization](../glossary#vascularization) of the [cornea](../glossary#cornea)) and decreased red blood cell count in which the existing red blood cells contain normal levels of hemoglobin and are of normal size (normochromic normocytic [anemia](../glossary#anemia)) [(1, 3)](#references). Subclinical deficiency (low [status](../glossary#status)) of without clinical signs may be widespread, including in high-income countries, but usually goes undetected because riboflavin [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) are very rarely measured in human studies. Low or deficient riboflavin status may result in decreased conversion of vitamin B6 to its active [coenzyme](../glossary#coenzyme) form (PLP) and decreased conversion of tryptophan to [niacin](niacin) (see [Nutrient interactions](#nutrient-interactions)). [Preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia) is defined as the presence of elevated blood pressure, protein in the urine, and [edema](../glossary#edema) (significant swelling) during pregnancy. About 5% of women with preeclampsia progress to [eclampsia](../glossary#eclampsia), a significant cause of maternal and fetal death. Eclampsia is characterized by seizures, in addition to high blood pressure and increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [hemorrhage](../glossary#hemorrhage) (severe bleeding) [(25)](#reference25). A study in 154 pregnant women at increased risk of preeclampsia found that those who were riboflavin deficient were 4.7 times more likely to develop preeclampsia than those who had adequate riboflavin nutritional status [(26)](#reference26). The cause of preeclampsia-eclampsia is not known. Decreased intracellular levels of flavocoenzymes could cause [mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) dysfunction, increase [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress), and interfere with [nitric oxide](../glossary#nitric-oxide) release and thus blood vessel dilation - all of these changes have been associated with preeclampsia [(26)](#reference26). A 2015 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 54 [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) found that the MTHFR C677T [polymorphism](../glossary#polymorphism) was associated with an increased risk of preeclampsia, especially in Caucasian and Asian populations [(27)](#reference27). The reduction in the flavoprotein MTHFR activity observed in individuals with the variant MTHFR 677TT [genotype](../glossary#genotype) leads to an increase in [plasma](../glossary#plasma) [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) higher homocysteine concentrations [(28)](#reference28). One [small randomized controlled](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) trial in 450 pregnant women in West Africa, without specified MTHFR genotype but at high risk for preeclampsia, found that [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with 15 mg of riboflavin daily was not effective in preventing the condition [(29)](#reference29), but the study was likely underpowered to detect a significant effect. Further studies are needed to assess the potential benefit of riboflavin supplementation in reducing [perinatal](../glossary#perinatal) complications generally and specifically in preeclamptic women with the MTHFR 677TT genotype. Alcoholics are at an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of riboflavin deficiency, likely due to decreased dietary intake, decreased absorption, and/or impaired utilization of riboflavin. Interestingly, the elevated blood [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) concentrations associated with riboflavin deficiency rapidly decline during alcohol withdrawal [(30)](#reference30). Additionally, people with anorexia rarely consume adequate dietary riboflavin, and those who are lactose intolerant are unlikely to meet requirements due to the avoidance of dairy products, the major dietary sources of riboflavin. The conversion of riboflavin into the active [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) forms FAD and FMN is impaired in [hypothyroidism](../glossary#hypothyroidism) and [adrenal](../glossary#adrenal-glands) insufficiency [(3, 4)](#reference3). Further, people who are very active physically (athletes, laborers) may have slightly increased riboflavin requirements. However, riboflavin [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) has not generally been found to increase exercise tolerance or performance [(31)](#reference31) unless the individuals are riboflavin deficient [(32)](#reference32). The [ RDA](../glossary#RDA) for riboflavin, revised in 1998, is based on the prevention of deficiency (Table 1). Clinical signs of deficiency in humans appear at intakes of less than 0.5 to 0.6 milligrams (mg)/day, and urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of riboflavin is seen are the leading cause of visual disability in the US and other developed countries. Research has focused on the role of nutritional [antioxidants](../glossary#antioxidant) because of evidence that light-induced [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) of [lens](../glossary#lens) proteins may lead to the development of age-related cataracts. A [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) found significantly decreased [risk](../glossary#risk) of age-related cataracts (33% to 51%) in men and women in the highest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of dietary riboflavin intake (median of 1.6 to 2.2 mg/day) compared to those in the lowest quintile (median of 0.08 mg/day in both men and women) [(33)](#reference33). Another case-control study reported that individuals in the highest quintile of riboflavin [status](../glossary#status), as measured by red blood cell glutathione reductase activity, had approximately one-half the occurrence of age-related cataract as those in the lowest quintile of riboflavin status, though the results were not statistically significant [(34)](#reference34). A [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) of 2,900 Australian men and women, 49 years of age and older, found that those in the highest quintile of riboflavin intake were 50% less likely to have cataracts than those in the lowest quintile [(35)](#reference35). A [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) of more than 50,000 women did not observe a difference between rates of cataract extraction between women in the highest quintile of riboflavin intake (median of 1.5 mg/day) and women in the lowest quintile (median of 1.2 mg/day) [(36)](#reference36). However, the range between the highest and lowest quintiles was small, and median intake levels for both quintiles were above the [RDA](#RDA) for riboflavin. A study in 408 women found that higher dietary intakes of riboflavin were [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with a lens [(37)](#reference37). A [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) using a fractional factorial design showed that compared with [placebo](../glossary#placebo), the combined supplementation with riboflavin (3 mg/day) and niacin (40 mg/day) for five to six years reduced the [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of nuclear cataract but increased the progression of posterior subcapsular cataracts in population affected by multiple nutrient deficiency living in rural China [(38)](#reference38). Of note is that the results of this trial are somewhat conflicting, and the study design does not allow the effects of riboflavin and niacin to be differentiated. In summary, there is some evidence predominantly from [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study), that suggests higher riboflavin status might be beneficial; however, more evidence from well-designed, randomized controlled trials is needed to confirm a role for riboflavin in the prevention of cataracts. The flavoprotein, methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase plays converts 5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate to re-methylation of [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) to [methionine](../glossary#methionine) (see [Figure 2](#figure-2) above). The conversion of homocysteine to methionine is of importance for homocysteine detoxification and for the production of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), the methyl donor for the [methylation](../glossary#methylation) of [DNA](../glossary#DNA) and [histones](../glossary#histone). Folate deficiency and elevated homocysteine concentrations may [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [risk](../glossary#risk) (see the article on [Folate](folate#cancer-prevention)). Aberrant methylation changes are also known to alter the structure and function of DNA and histones during cancer development [(39)](#reference39). Since MTHFR controls the detoxification of homocysteine and the supply of methyl groups for SAM synthesis, a reduction in its activity can affect homocysteine metabolism and disturb cellular methylation processes. The substitution of a cytosine by a thymine in position 677 (c.677C>T) in the MTHFR [gene](../glossary#gene) is a [polymorphism](../glossary#polymorphism) that affects the binding of FAD and leads to an increased propensity for MTHFR to lose its flavin exhibit reduced MTHFR activity and increased risk for a wide variety of cancers [(41-43)](#reference41), but the evidence of an association between this polymorphism and cancer is inconsistent, with some reports suggesting a reduction in [colorectal cancer](../glossary#colorectal-cancer) risk with the T [allele](../glossary#allele) [(44)](#reference44). As mentioned above (see [B-complex vitamins](#B-complex-vitamins)), riboflavin intake is a determinant of homocysteine concentration. This suggests that riboflavin [status](../glossary#status) can influence MTHFR activity and the metabolism of folate, thereby affecting cancer risk [(43)](#reference43). In a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study, 93 subjects with colorectal [polyps](../glossary#polyp) and 86 healthy subjects were given a placebo, folic acid (400 or 1,200 g/day), or folic acid (400 g/day) plus riboflavin (5 mg/day) for 45 days. These interventions significantly improved folate and riboflavin status in [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin)- [supplemented](../glossary#supplement) individuals compared to those taking the placebo. Interestingly, riboflavin enhanced the effect of 400 g folic acid on circulating 5-methyltetrahydrofolate (5-MTHF) specifically in the polyp patients with the C677T genetic variant [(45)](#reference45). This suggests that riboflavin may improve the response to folic acid supplementation in individuals with a reduced MTHFR activity. Additionally, a [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) of 88,045 postmenopausal women found total (dietary plus supplemental) intake of riboflavin to be [inversely correlated](../glossary#inverse-association) with colorectal cancer risk when comparing the highest (>3.97 mg) and lowest (<1.80 mg) [quartiles](../glossary#quartile) of daily intake [(46)](#reference46); intake in the reference group was well above the [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for riboflavin of 1.1 mg/day. The subjects in this study were not prescreened to identify those with the variant MTHFR 677TT genotype, and the association between this polymorphism and colorectal cancer remains unclear, with some reports suggesting a reduction in cancer risk with the T allele [(44)](#reference44). Two [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) have found inverse associations between riboflavin intake and risk of colorectal cancer [(47, 48)](#reference47). The most recent of these was a dose-response meta-analysis that pooled results from five prospective cohort studies, nine [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study), and two studies reporting blood concentrations of riboflavin. This analysis found that higher intakes of riboflavin were associated with a significantly lower risk of colorectal cancer ( [RR](../glossary#relative-risk)=0.87; 95% [CI](../glossary#confidence-interval), 0.81-0.93); inverse associations were observed for both dietary riboflavin intake and total daily intake from the diet and supplements [(48)](#reference48). Associations between riboflavin intake and cancer risk have also been evaluated in other types of cancer. A seven-year [intervention study](../glossary#intervention-trial) evaluated the use of riboflavin-fortified salt in 22,093 individuals at high risk for [esophageal](../glossary#esophagus) cancer in China. Riboflavin status and esophageal [pathology](../glossary#pathology) (percent normal, dysplastic, and cancerous tissues) improved in the intervention group compared to the control group, but the lower incidence of esophageal cancer found in the intervention group was not statistically significant [(49)](#reference49). Additionally, a 25-year follow up of an intervention trial in patients at high risk for gastric cancer found that dietary supplementation with riboflavin (3.2 mg/day) and niacin (40 mg/day) for five years decreased the risk of mortality from esophageal cancer by 8% but had no effect on mortality from [gastric cancer](../health-disease/stomach-cancer) [(50)](#reference50). In the Melbourne Collaborative Cohort Study, which followed 41,514 men and women over a 15-year period, weak inverse associations were found between riboflavin intake and lung cancer [(51)](#reference51) and breast cancer [(52)](#reference52); no association of riboflavin intake with [prostate](../glossary#prostate) cancer was observed in this cohort [(53)](#reference53). A 2017 meta-analysis of 10 observational studies found an overall inverse association of riboflavin intake and breast cancer incidence and reported a 6% lower risk with each 1 mg/day increment of riboflavin intake [(54)](#reference54). Further, studies to date have not found riboflavin intake or measures of riboflavin status to be associated with renal cell carcinoma, as reviewed in a recent meta-analysis [(55)](#reference55). Some evidence indicates that impaired [mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) oxygen [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) in the brain may play a role in the [pathology](../glossary#pathology) of [migraine headaches](../glossary#migraine-headache). Since riboflavin is the [precursor](../glossary#precursor) of the two flavocoenzymes (FAD and FMN) required by flavoproteins of the mitochondrial [electron transport chain](../glossary#electron-transport-chain), [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) riboflavin has been investigated as a treatment for migraine. A [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) examined the effect of very high dose riboflavin (400 mg/day) for three months on migraine prevention in 54 men and women with a history of recurrent migraine headaches [(56)](#reference56). Riboflavin compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) reduced attack frequency and the number of headache days, though the beneficial effect was most pronounced during the third month of treatment [(56)](#reference56). Another study by the same investigators found that treatment with either a -blocker drug or high-dose riboflavin (400 mg/day) for four months resulted in clinical improvement, but each therapy appeared to act on a distinct pathological mechanism: -blockers on abnormal cortical information processing and riboflavin on decreased brain mitochondrial energy reserve [(57)](#reference57). A small study in 23 patients reported a reduction in median migraine attack frequency after supplementation with 400 mg of riboflavin daily for three months [(58)](#reference58). A single-blinded, randomized, parallel group trial in 85 patients with migraine headaches (ages 15-55 years), high-dose riboflavin supplementation (400 mg/day) for 12 weeks decreased migraine frequency, duration, and severity compared to baseline and was as effective as sodium valproate (500 mg/day) [(59)](#reference59), a medication with established efficacy in migraine preventative therapy [(60)](#reference60). Riboflavin elicited significantly fewer adverse effects compared to the drug [(59)](#reference59). Thus, although the available trials have been small and short term, most studies to date suggest that high-dose riboflavin supplementation might be a useful [adjunct therapy](../glossary#adjunct-therapy) in adults with migraine headaches. A few randomized controlled trials have investigated the effect of riboflavin supplementation on the frequency and severity of headache attacks in children with migraines. An initial study evaluated riboflavin at 200 mg/day for 12 weeks in 48 children of ages 5 to 15 years old [(61)](#reference61). A second study was a [cross-over trial](../glossary#cross-over-trial) with half of the 42 children, ages 6 to 13, receiving 50 mg/day riboflavin for 16 weeks then placebo (100 mg/day carotene) for 16 weeks (with a four-week washout period in between each), while the other half were first given the placebo then riboflavin [(62)](#reference62). Neither study showed differences in the frequency, duration, or intensity of migraines between treatments. However, a more recent trial found a benefit of intervention with higher dose riboflavin: children with migraine treated with 400 mg/day of riboflavin for 12 weeks (n=30) had reductions in migraine frequency and duration, but not intensity, compared to placebo (n=30), yet no benefit was seen in children taking 200 mg/day for 12 weeks in this study [(63)](#reference63). Additionally, a randomized controlled trial in 98 adolescents, ages 12 to 19 years, found that 400 mg/day of riboflavin for three months decreased both headache frequency and duration and improved migraine-related disability compared to placebo [(64)](#reference64). [Retrospective studies](../glossary#retrospective-study) of children and adolescents suffering from migraine have also suggested some benefit associated with supplemental riboflavin [(65-67)](#reference65). Thus, studies to date are somewhat conflicting, and more research is needed to understand whether riboflavin supplementation might have utility in the treatment of childhood migraine and the most effective dose required for any beneficial effects. Increasing evidence from [case reports](../glossary#case-report) indicates that patients with [autosomal](../glossary#autosomal) [recessive](../glossary#recessive-trait) disorders caused defective FAD-dependent [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) could benefit from riboflavin [supplementation](../glossary#supplement). MADD, also known acidemia), is a [fatty acid](../glossary#fatty-acid) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) disorder characterized by the accumulation of short-, medium-, and long-chain acyl- [carnitines](../glossary#carnitine) in various tissues. MADD is classified into three separate types based on age of onset and clinical symptoms: type I MADD is evident in the neonatal period and is characterized by the presence of [congenital anomalies](../glossary#congenital-anomaly); type II MADD is present in the neonatal period but lacks congenital defects; and type III is characterized by late onset, from infancy through adulthood [(68)](#reference68), and even as late as the seventh decade of life [(69)](#reference69). Clinical symptoms of type I and II MADD present shortly after birth and include hypoglycemia, hyperammonemia, metabolic acidosis, hepatomegaly, and respiratory distress [(68](#reference68), [70)](#reference70); these forms of MADD are often fatal in infancy, even if treated. Type III MADD usually presents later in life and includes milder symptoms, varying from periodic vomiting, rhabdomyolysis, muscle pain and weakness, and exercise intolerance [(68](#reference68), [70)](#reference70). [Peripheral neuropathy](../glossary#peripheral-neuropathy) has also recently been reported as a symptom of adult-onset MADD [(71)](#reference71). MADD is caused by [autosomal](../glossary#autosomal) [genes](../glossary#gene) that impair the activity of [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) involved in the transfer of [electrons](../glossary#electron) from acyl-coenzyme A (acyl-CoA) to [coenzyme (Figure ETFA, ETFB, and ETFDH code for the two subunits of the electron transfer flavoprotein (ETF-A and -B) and for ETF dehydrogenase/ubiquinone oxidoreductase (ETFDH/ETFQO), respectively. Deficiencies in these enzymes (ETF or ETFDH) lead to a decrease in oxidized FAD, which becomes unavailable for FAD-dependent dehydrogenation reactions, including the first step in -oxidation - a major fatty acid [catabolic](../glossary#catabolism) process that takes place in the mitochondria. A defect in fatty acid -oxidation causes [lipid](../glossary#lipid) accumulation in skeletal muscles, leading to lipid storage [myopathy](../glossary#myopathy) characterized by muscle pain and weakness and exercise intolerance. Together with a low-fat, high-carbohydrate diet, riboflavin [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) has led to significant clinical improvements in patients with ETFDH mutations. The specific type of the mutation in ETF/ETFDH contributes to age of onset, severity, and responsiveness to riboflavin treatment [(70](#reference70), [72)](#reference72). Additionally, the report of a 20-year-old man with riboflavin-responsive MADD failed to find mutations in ETF and ETFDH genes, suggesting that other sites of mutation should not be excluded [(73)](#reference73). Primary [trimethylaminuria](../glossary#trimethylaminuria) is caused by defective [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) of trimethylamine by a liver flavoprotein called flavin containing mono-oxygenase 3 (FMO3). Individuals with FMO3 deficiency have increased levels of trimethylamine in urine, sweat, and breath [(85)](#reference85). This socially distressing condition is known as "fish odor syndrome" due to the fishy odor and volatile nature of trimethylamine. FMO3 [gene](../glossary#gene) [mutations](../glossary#mutation) are usually associated with mild or intermittent trimethylaminuria; the condition is sometimes limited to peri-menstrual periods in female subjects or to the consumption of trimethylamine-rich food. The clinical management of the condition includes dietary restriction of trimethylamine and its [precursors](../glossary#precursor), such as foods rich in [choline](../other-nutrients/choline) and seafood, as well as [cruciferous vegetables](../food-beverages/cruciferous-vegetables) that contain both trimethylamine precursors and FMO3 [antagonists](../glossary#antagonist) [(86)](#reference86). The use of riboflavin [supplements](../glossary#supplement) was reported 17-year-old female patient affected by pyridoxine non-responsive homocystinuria [(87)](#reference87). The disease was initially treated with betaine (a choline derivative), which caused body odor secondary to FMO3 deficiency. Riboflavin supplementation (200 mg/day) reduced trimethylamine [excretion](../glossary#excretion) and the betaine body odor. Similar effects were seen with riboflavin supplementation in two pediatric patients [(88)](#reference88). The data suggest that riboflavin might help maximize residual FMO3 [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) activity in patients with primary trimethylaminuria. Moreover, a recent [case report](../glossary#case-report) in a 35-year-old male with [HIV](../glossary#HIV) described supplemental riboflavin as an effective treatment for secondary trimethylaminuria caused by antiretroviral therapy [(89)](#reference89). [Hypertension](../glossary#hypertension) in adulthood is recognized as the leading risk factor contributing to mortality worldwide primarily from [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease), while hypertension in pregnancy leads to serious adverse fetal and maternal outcomes. A number of risk factors are recognized to contribute to the development of hypertension. In recent years, evidence has emerged from genetic and clinical studies pointing to the role of [one-carbon](../glossary#one-carbon-unit) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) in blood pressure [(90)](#reference90). The common MTHFR C677T [polymorphism](../glossary#polymorphism), affecting 1 in 10 adults globally, is associated with higher blood pressure, although this is much less well recognized compared with the phenotype of elevated [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) concentrations that was established at the time of discovery of this polymorphism and its link with cardiovascular disease [(91)](#reference91). [Meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) show that this polymorphism is associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of hypertension by up to 87% and of heart disease and [stroke](../health-disease/stroke) by up to 40% [(92)](#reference92). The MTHFR C677T polymorphism is also associated with a significantly higher risk of hypertension in pregnancy [(93)](#reference93) and with [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia) [(27)](#reference27). Since FAD is required as a [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) for the MTHFR [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) and the MTHFR C677T polymorphism results in decreased MTHFR activity, studies have investigated whether affected individuals may benefit from riboflavin [supplementation](../glossary#supplement). In an initial [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 77 healthy young adults stratified by MTHFR [genotype](../glossary#genotype), riboflavin supplementation at dietary levels (1.6 mg/day for 12 weeks) resulted in marked lowering of homocysteine concentrations in the MTHFR 677TT genotype group, but not in the 677CC or 677CT genotype groups who exhibited normal [plasma](../glossary#plasma) homocysteine at baseline [(15)](#reference15). Three randomized controlled trials subsequently investigated the effect of riboflavin on blood pressure in patients with hypertension with or without overt cardiovascular disease [(91](#reference91), [94, 95)](#reference94). The results of these trials showed that supplementation with low-dose riboflavin (1.6 mg/day for 16 weeks) resulted in significant lowering of blood pressure and reduction in incidence of hypertension specifically in those patients with the variant MTHFR 677TT genotype. Riboflavin intervention reduced mean systolic/diastolic blood pressure in those with the TT genotype from 144/87 to 131/80 [mm Hg](../glossary#mm-Hg), with no response observed in those without the genetic variant (i.e., the CT or CC genotypes) [(89)](#reference89). Notably, the 13 mm Hg decrease in systolic blood pressure occurred even though over 80% of the patients were taking one or more antihypertensive drugs at recruitment, and the addition of supplemental riboflavin was shown to greatly enhance the achievement of goal blood pressure with routine antihypertensive drugs [(89, 91)](#reference89). Furthermore, the magnitude of blood pressure response achieved with riboflavin in these trials compares very favorably with typical decreases from other interventions, such as dietary salt reductions of 3 g/day (3.6/1.9 mm Hg) and 6 g/day (7.1/3.9 mm Hg). The trial findings therefore suggest that the excess risk of hypertension linked to this genetic polymorphism can be overcome by low-dose riboflavin supplementation. Also, analysis of plasma samples from individuals participating in these trials showed lower concentrations of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), an important methyl group donor for [methylation](../glossary#methylation) reactions, in those with the MTHFR (1.6 mg/day) for 12 weeks was shown to increase plasma concentrations of SAM and another one-carbon metabolite, cystathionine [(96)](#reference96), and thus may have potential in correcting the altered one-carbon metabolism arising with the variant TT genotype. Thus, studies to date indicate that riboflavin supplementation may have benefits in lowering blood pressure and reducing hypertension in individuals (and sub-populations) affected by the common MTHFR C677T polymorphism. However, the mechanisms explaining the blood pressure phenotype and its responsiveness to riboflavin remain unclear. Future studies examining the effects of riboflavin supplementation on one-carbon metabolism may help to elucidate the biological mechanisms involved. Interestingly, a recent randomized controlled trial found that riboflavin supplementation in those with the variant MTHFR 677TT genotype resulted in altered [DNA](../glossary#DNA) methylation of certain [genes](../glossary#gene) known to be involved in blood pressure regulation [(97)](#reference97). Corneal ectasia is an eye condition characterized by irregularities of the [cornea](../glossary#cornea) that affect vision. [Multiple sclerosis](../glossary#multiple-sclerosis) (MS) is an [autoimmune disease](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) of unknown [etiology](../glossary#etiology) that is characterized by the progressive destruction of [myelin](../glossary#myelin) and nerve fibers in the [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system), causing [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) symptoms in affected individuals [(102)](#reference102). Riboflavin appears to have a role in the formation of myelin [(103)](#reference103), and [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) has been implicated in the [pathogenesis](../glossary#pathogenesis) of MS; thus, riboflavin may be helpful in treatment of the disease. A strong [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between dietary riboflavin intake and [risk](../glossary#risk) for MS was initially observed in a [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) [(104)](#reference104). In a mouse model of MS (i.e., experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis), riboflavin supplementation improved clinical measures of a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled [pilot study](../glossary#pilot-study) in 29 patients with MS found that [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with 10 mg/day of riboflavin for six months had no effect on MS-related disability, assessed by the Expanded Disability Status Scale [(106)](#reference106). Large-scale randomized, placebo-controlled trials are needed to determine whether riboflavin supplementation has a beneficial effect in the treatment of MS. Most plant- and animal-derived foods contain at least small quantities of riboflavin. In the US, wheat flour and bread have been enriched with riboflavin (as well as [thiamin](thiamin), [niacin](niacin), and [iron](../minerals/iron)) since 1943. Data from a US national survey indicate that the average dietary intake of riboflavin is 2.5 mg/day for men and 1.8 mg/day for women [(107)](#reference107); these intakes are well above the [RDA](../glossary#RDA) values of 1.3 mg/day for men and 1.1 mg/day for women. Surveys of adults of ages 70 years or older showed similar intakes: 2.2 mg/day for older men and 1.8 mg day for older women [(107)](#reference107). Riboflavin is heat-stable, but it is easily destroyed upon exposure to light. For instance, up to 50% of the riboflavin in milk contained in a clear glass bottle can be destroyed after two hours of exposure to bright sunlight [(6)](#reference6). Nationally representative surveys from the US, Ireland, and the UK showed that milk and other dairy products were the main dietary contributors to riboflavin intake, followed by meat and ready-to-eat breakfast cereals [(108-110)](#reference108). The [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for riboflavin (1.3 mg/day for men and 1.1 mg/day for women), which should prevent deficiency in most individuals, is easily met by eating a varied diet. Consuming a varied diet should supply 1.5 mg to 2 mg of riboflavin a day. Following the Linus Pauling Institute recommendation to take a multivitamin/mineral supplement containing 100% of the Daily Values ( [DV](../glossary#DV)) will ensure an intake of at least 1.3 mg/day of riboflavin. Isolated and characterized in the 1930s, thiamin was one of the first organic compounds to be recognized as a vitamin [(2)](#reference2).
