Beriberi, the disease resulting from severe thiamin deficiency, was described in Chinese literature as early as 2600 B.C. Thiamin deficiency affects the [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular), muscular, [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal), and central and peripheral nervous systems [(2)](#reference2). Beriberi has been subdivided into dry, wet, cerebral, or gastrointestinal, depending on the systems affected by severe thiamin deficiency [(1](#references), [8)](#reference8). The main feature of dry (paralytic or nervous) beriberi is [peripheral neuropathy](../glossary#peripheral-neuropathy). Early in the course of the neuropathy, "burning feet syndrome" may occur. Other symptoms include abnormal (exaggerated) reflexes, as well as diminished sensation and weakness in the legs and arms. Muscle pain and tenderness and difficulty rising from a squatting position have also been observed [(9)](#reference9). In addition to [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) symptoms, wet (cardiac) beriberi is characterized by [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) manifestations of thiamin deficiency, which include rapid heart rate, enlargement of the heart, severe swelling ( [edema](../glossary#edema)), difficulty breathing, and ultimately, [congestive heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure). The Japanese literature describes the acute fulminant form of wet beriberi as "shoshin" [(10)](#reference10). Cerebral beriberi may lead to Wernicke's encephalopathy and Korsakoff's psychosis, especially in people who abuse alcohol. The diagnosis of Wernicke's encephalopathy is based on a "triad" of signs, which include abnormal eye movements, stance and gait [ataxia](../glossary#ataxia), and [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) impairment. Due in part to an overlap of symptoms with alcoholic delirium, Wernicke's encephalopathy is thought to be underdiagnosed [(11)](#reference11). If left untreated, the irreversible [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) damage can cause additional clinical manifestations known as Korsakoff's psychosis. This syndrome - also called Korsakoff's [dementia](../glossary#dementia), Korsakoff's amnesia, or amnestic confabulatory syndrome - involves a confused, apathetic state and a profound memory disorder, with severe amnesia and loss of recent and working memory. Thiamin deficiency affecting the [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system) is referred to as Wernicke's disease when the amnesic state is not present and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (WKS) when the amnesic symptoms are present along with the eye-movement and gait disorders. Rarer neurologic manifestations can include [seizures](../glossary#seizure) [(12)](#reference12). Most WKS sufferers are alcoholics, although it has been observed in other disorders of gross malnutrition, including stomach [cancer](../glossary#cancer) and [AIDS](../glossary#AIDS). Administration of [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) thiamin to WKS patients generally results in prompt improvement of the eye symptoms, but improvements in motor coordination and memory may be less, depending on how long the symptoms have been present. Evidence of increased immune cell activation and increased [free radical](../glossary#free-radical) production in the areas of the brain that are selectively damaged suggests that [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) plays an important role in the neurologic pathology of thiamin deficiency [(13)](#reference13). TPP is critical for metabolic reactions that utilize [glucose](../glossary#glucose) [glycolysis](../glossary#glycoloysis) and the [citric acid cycle](../glossary#citric-acid-cycle) (see [Figure 1](#figure-1)). A decrease in the activity of thiamin-dependent [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) limits the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA and the utilization of the citric acid cycle, leading to accumulation of pyruvate and lactate. Lactic acidosis, a condition resulting from the accumulation of lactate, is often associated with nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain in a syndrome described as gastrointestinal beriberi [(8)](#reference8). Thiamin deficiency may result from inadequate thiamin intake, increased requirement for thiamin, excessive loss of thiamin from the body, consumption of anti-thiamin factors in food, or a combination of these factors. Inadequate consumption of thiamin is the main cause of thiamin deficiency in developing countries [(2)](#reference2). Thiamin deficiency is common in low-income populations whose diets are high in [carbohydrate](../glossary#carbohydrate) and low in thiamin (e.g., milled or polished rice). Breast-fed infants whose mothers are thiamin deficient are vulnerable to developing infantile beriberi. Alcoholism, which is associated with low intake of thiamin among other nutrients, is the primary cause of thiamin deficiency in industrialized countries. Some of the non-alcoholic conditions associated with WKS include anorexia nervosa, [bariatric](../glossary#bariatrics) heightened thiamin deficiency [(18, 19)](#reference18). Moreover, cases of Wernicke's encephalopathy have been linked with hyperemesis gravidarum (severe nausea and vomiting during pregnancy) [parenteral nutrition](../glossary#parenteral-nutrition) lacking [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin) supplementation Conditions resulting in an increased requirement for thiamin include strenuous physical exertion, fever, pregnancy, breast-feeding, and adolescent growth. Such conditions place individuals with marginal thiamin intake at [risk](../glossary#risk) for developing symptomatic thiamin deficiency. [Malaria](../glossary#malaria) patients in Southeast Asia were found to be thiamin deficient more frequently than non-infected individuals [(24, 25)](#reference24). Malarial infection leads to a large increase in the metabolic demand for [glucose](../glossary#glucose). Because thiamin is required for [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) involved in glucose [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), the stresses induced by malarial infection could exacerbate thiamin deficiency in predisposed individuals. [HIV](../glossary#HIV)-infected individuals, whether or not they had developed [AIDS](../glossary#AIDS), were also found to be at increased risk for thiamin deficiency [(26)](#reference26). Further, chronic alcohol abuse impairs intestinal absorption and utilization of thiamin [(1)](#references); thus, alcoholics have increased requirements for thiamin. Thiamin deficiency is also observed as a complication of the refeeding syndrome: the introduction of [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) in severely starved individuals leads to an increased demand for thiamin in [glycolysis](../glossary#glycoloysis) and the [citric acid cycle](../glossary#citric-acid-cycle) that Excessive precipitate deficiency. By increasing urinary flow, [diuretics](../glossary#diuretic) may prevent reabsorption of thiamin by the kidneys and increase its excretion in the urine [(28, 29)](#reference28). The [risk](../glossary#risk) of thiamin deficiency is increased in diuretic-treated patients with marginal thiamin intake [(30)](#reference30) and in individuals receiving long-term, diuretic therapy [(31)](#reference31). Individuals with kidney failure requiring [hemodialysis](../glossary#hemodialysis) lose thiamin at an increased rate and are at risk for thiamin deficiency [(32)](#reference32). Alcoholics who maintain a high fluid intake and high urine flow rate may also experience increased loss of thiamin, exacerbating the effects of low thiamin intake [(33)](#reference33). The presence of anti-thiamin factors (ATF) in foods contributes to the [risk](../glossary#risk) of thiamin deficiency. Certain plants contain ATF, which react with thiamin to form an oxidized, inactive product. Consuming very large amounts of tea or coffee (including decaffeinated), as well as chewing tea leaves and betel nuts, might lower thiamin status due to the presence of ATF [(34, 35)](#reference34). ATF include mycotoxins (molds) and thiaminases that break down thiamin in food. Individuals who habitually eat certain raw fresh-water fish, raw shellfish, or ferns are at higher risk of thiamin deficiency because these foods contain thiaminase that normally is inactivated by heat in cooking [(1](#references), [6)](#reference6). In Nigeria, an acute, [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) syndrome (seasonal [ataxia](../glossary#ataxia)) has been associated with thiamin deficiency precipitated by a thiaminase in African silkworms, a traditional, high-protein food for some Nigerians [(36)](#reference36). The [ RDA](../glossary#RDA) for thiamin, revised in 1998 by the Food and Nutrition Board of the Institute of Medicine, was based on the prevention of deficiency in generally healthy individuals [(37](#reference37); Table 1). |Life of 2,900 Australian men and women, 49 years of age and older, found that those in the highest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of thiamin intake were 40% less likely to have nuclear [cataracts](../glossary#cataract) than those in the lowest quintile [(38)](#reference38). In addition, a study in 408 US women found that higher dietary intakes of thiamin were [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with five-year change in lens opacification [(39)](#reference39). However, these cross-sectional associations have yet to be elucidated by studies of causation. Patients with [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) have been reported to have low [plasma](../glossary#plasma) concentrations and high [renal](../glossary#renal) clearance of thiamin [(40, 41)](#reference40), suggesting that individuals with type 1 or type 2 diabetes are at increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for thiamin deficiency. Two thiamin transporters, thiamin transporter-1 THTR-2, are involved in thiamin uptake by [enterocytes](../glossary#enterocyte) in the small intestine and re-uptake in the proximal tubules of the kidneys. One study suggested that [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia) in patients with diabetes could affect thiamin re-uptake by decreasing the expression of thiamin transporters in the kidneys [(42)](#reference42). Conversely, thiamin deficiency appears to impair the normal [endocrine](../glossary#endocrine-system) function of the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas) and exacerbate hyperglycemia. Early studies showed that [insulin](../glossary#insulin) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) and secretion were altered in the endocrine of thiamin-deficient rats [(43, 44)](#reference43). In caused by [recessive](../glossary#recessive-trait) [mutations](../glossary#mutation) in the [gene](../glossary#gene) encoding leads to the thiamin-responsive six weeks to hyperglycemic individuals (either [glucose](../glossary#glucose) intolerant or newly diagnosed with type 2 diabetes). Thiamin supplementation prevented any further increase in fasting glucose and insulin concentrations compared with [placebo](../glossary#placebo) treatment but did not reduce the hyperglycemia [(45)](#reference45). However, one study suggested that thiamin supplementation might improve fasting glucose concentrations in in early stages of type 2 diabetes (i.e., pre-diabetes) [(46)](#reference46). Some older adults are at increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for developing [subclinical](../glossary#subclinical) thiamin deficiency secondary to poor dietary intake, reduced [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) absorption, and multiple medical conditions [(47, 48)](#reference47). Since thiamin deficiency can result in a form of [dementia](../glossary#dementia) (Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome), its relationship to [Alzheimer's disease](../health-disease/alzheimer-disease) (AD) and other forms of dementia have been investigated. AD is characterized by a decline in [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) function in elderly people, accompanied by [pathologic](../glossary#pathology) features that include [-amyloid plaque](../glossary#amyloid-plaque) deposition and tomography (PET) scanning](../glossary#PET-scan), reduced [glucose](../glossary#glucose) metabolism has been observed in brains of AD patients [(50)](#reference50). A large, multicenter PET study using a radiolabeled glucose [analog](../glossary#analog), 18F-Fluoro-deoxyglucose (FDG), correlated a reduction in FDG uptake (a surrogate marker for glucose metabolism) with the extent of cognitive impairment in AD patients. This study, which included 822 subjects over 55 years of age that were cognitively normal (n=229), displayed mild cognitive impairment (n=405), or had mild AD (n=188), demonstrated that brain glucose utilization could predict the progression from mild cognitive impairment to AD [(51)](#reference51). A nine-year longitudinal study associated the presence of [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) in older people (above 55 years old) with an increased risk for developing AD [(52)](#reference52). Emerging evidence links type 2 diabetes and AD, conditions that may involve [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance) in the brain (reviewed in [53](#reference53)). A reduction in thiamin-dependent processes in the brain appears to be related to the altered glucose metabolism in patients with AD [(54-56)](#reference54). [Case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) have found blood levels of thiamin, TPP, and TMP to be lower in those with dementia of Alzheimer's type (DAT) compared to control subjects [(57, 58)](#reference57). Moreover, several investigators have found evidence of decreased activity of TPP-dependent [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme), -ketoglutarate dehydrogenase and transketolase, in the brains of patients who died of AD [(59)](#reference59). The finding of decreased brain levels of TPP in the presence of normal levels of free thiamin and TMP suggests altered TPP synthesis rather than poor thiamin [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability). However, it is not clear whether the activities of TPP-metabolizing enzymes (including thiamin pyrophosphokinase) are altered in AD patients [(60, 61)](#reference60). Chronic administration of the thiamin derivative benfotiamine alleviated cognitive alterations and decreased the number of -amyloid plaques in a mouse model of AD without increasing TMP and TPP levels in the brain. This suggested that the beneficial effects of benfotiamine in the brain were likely mediated by the stimulation of TPP-independent pathways [(62)](#reference62). Chronic benfotiamine administration was also shown to decrease the number of neurofibrillary tangles in certain brain regions and improve survival in a mouse model [(63)](#reference63). In a rat model of neurodegeneration, long-term oral benfotiamine [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) increased thiamin pyrophosphate concentrations and led to improvements in insulin signaling and cognitive deficits [(64)](#reference64). Thiamin deficiency has been linked to increased -amyloid production in cultured [neuronal](../glossary#neuron) cells and to plaque formation in animal models [(65, 66)](#reference65). These pathological hallmarks of AD could be reversed by thiamin supplementation, suggesting that thiamin could be protective in AD. Other disorders, including [mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) dysfunction and chronic [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress), have been linked to both thiamin deficiency and AD pathogenesis and progression [(13](#reference13), [55](#reference55), [67)](#reference67). Presently, there is only slight and inconsistent evidence that thiamin supplements are of benefit in AD. A [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study of 15 patients (10 completed the study) reported no beneficial effect of 3 grams/day of thiamin on cognitive decline over a 12-month period [(68)](#reference68). A preliminary report from another study claimed a mild benefit of 3 to 8 grams of thiamin per day in DAT, but no additional data from that study are available [(69)](#reference69). A mild beneficial effect in patients with AD was reported after 12 weeks of treatment with 100 mg/day of a thiamin derivative (thiamin tetrahydrofurfuryl disulfide), but review](../glossary#systematic-review) of [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), double-blind, placebo-controlled trials of thiamin in patients with DAT found no evidence that thiamin was a useful treatment for the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease [(71)](#reference71). More recently, a small uncontrolled study in five patients with mild-to-moderate AD reported cognitive improvement, measured by the Mini-Mental Status Examination, following supplementation with 300 mg/day of benfotiamine for 18 months [(72)](#reference72). In a placebo-controlled study of 70 -amyloid positive patients with either amnestic mild cognitive impairment (a [precursor](../glossary#precursor) to AD) or mild AD, those receiving 600 mg/day of benfotiamine for 12 months experienced less cognitive decline compared to placebo, but the differences did not reach statistical significance (p=0.125; [73)](#reference73). Large-scale, [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) are needed to determine whether supplemental thiamin or benfotiamine might help slow progression of cognitive decline in those with Alzheimer's disease. [Huntington's disease](../glossary#huntington-disease) is an inherited [neurodegenerative disorder](../glossary#neurodegenerative-disease) characterized by selective degeneration of nerve cells known as striatal spiny neurons. Symptoms, such as movement disorders and impaired [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) function, typically develop in the fourth decade of life and progressively deteriorate over time. A recent study found decreased levels of the thiamin transporter-2 (THTR-2) protein in the striatum and frontal cortex of patients with Huntington's disease compared to age-and sex-matched healthy controls [(74)](#reference74). Compared to control subjects, this study also found lower concentrations of TPP in the striatum and lower concentrations of TMP in the [cerebrospinal fluid](../glossary#cerebrospinal-fluid) of patients with thiamin for life (see [Biotin-thiamin-responsive ganglia disease](#biotin-thiamin-responsive-basal-ganglia-disease) In a mouse model of Huntington's disease, high-dose supplementation with both of these vitamins improved neuropathological and motor deficits but had no effect on lifespan (p=0.15) [(74)](#reference74). A [phase II](../glossary#phase-II-clinical-trial), at moderate (600 mg/day of thiamin and 150 mg/day of biotin) and high (1,200 mg/day of thiamin and 300 mg/day of biotin) dosages, in Huntington's disease is currently underway [(75)](#reference75). Severe thiamin deficiency (wet beriberi) can lead to impaired cardiac function and ultimately [congestive heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure) (CHF). Although cardiac manifestations of beriberi are rarely encountered in industrialized countries, CHF due to other causes is common, especially in the elderly. Loop [diuretics](../glossary#diuretic) used in the treatment of CHF, notably furosemide, increase thiamin [excretion](../glossary#excretion), potentially leading to thiamin deficiency [(76, Patients with CHF might also have altered thiamin [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), including reduced absorption of thiamin in the [(78)](#reference78). A 2015 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) found a 2.5 times higher [risk](../glossary#risk) of thiamin deficiency in patients with heart failure compared to control subjects [(78)](#reference78). As in the general population, older CHF patients were found to be at higher risk of thiamin deficiency than younger ones [(79)](#reference79). An important measure of cardiac function in CHF is the left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), which can be assessed by [echocardiography](../glossary#echocardiography). One study in 25 patients found that furosemide use at doses of 80 mg/day or greater was associated with a 98% [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of thiamin deficiency [(31)](#reference31). In a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind) study of 30 CHF patients, all of whom had been taking furosemide (80 mg/day) for at least three months, [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) (IV) thiamin therapy (200 mg/day) for seven days resulted in an improved LVEF compared to IV [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(80)](#reference80). When all 30 of the CHF patients in that study subsequently received six weeks of oral thiamin therapy (200 mg/day), the average LVEF improved by 22%. This finding may be relevant because improvements in LVEF have been associated with improved survival in CHF patients [(81)](#reference81). However, [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) of oral thiamin supplementation in heart failure patients have not found any benefit. In a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in 52 patients with systolic heart failure, 300 mg/day of supplemental thiamin for one month did not improve LVEF compared to placebo [(82)](#reference82). A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in 64 patients with heart failure reported that 200 mg/day or supplemental thiamin for six months did not improve LVEF [(83)](#reference83). Although little evidence supports the routine use of supplemental thiamin in CHF patients, trials specifically in CHF patients with marginal thiamin [status](../glossary#status) have not been done, and some suggest that it may be prudent to screen patients on long-term diuretic therapy for thiamin deficiency and treat accordingly [(84)](#reference84). Chronic [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia) in individuals with [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) contributes to the [pathogenesis](../glossary#pathogenesis) of microvascular diseases. Diabetes-related [retina](../glossary#retina) (retinopathy), and [neuropathy](../glossary#neuropathy)). In subjects with diabetes, hyperglycemia alters the function of bone marrow-derived endothelial progenitor cells (EPC) that are critical for the growth of blood vessels [(85)](#reference85). Interestingly, a higher daily intake of thiamin from the diet was correlated with more circulating EPC and with better vascular endothelial health in 88 individuals with type 2 diabetes [(86)](#reference86). An [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) has also been found between [plasma](../glossary#plasma) concentrations of thiamin and the presence of soluble vascular adhesion molecule-1 (sVCAM-1), a marker of vascular dysfunction, in patients with diabetes [(40](#reference40), [87)](#reference87). Early markers of diabetic nephropathy include the presence of [serum](../glossary#serum) albumin in the urine, known as microalbuminuria. Administration of thiamin or benfotiamine (a thiamin derivative) prevented the development of [renal](../glossary#renal) complications in chemically-induced diabetic rats [(88)](#reference88). A [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study conducted in 40 patients with type 2 diabetes with microalbuminuria found that high-dose thiamin [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) three-month period [(87)](#reference87). Since thiamin treatment has shown promising results in cultured cells and animal models [(89-91)](#reference89), the effects of thiamin and its derivatives on vascular complications should be examined in patients with diabetes. Thiamin deficiency and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome have been observed in some [cancer](../glossary#cancer) patients with rapidly growing tumors [(92, 93)](#reference92). Research in cell culture and animal models indicates that rapidly dividing cancer cells have a high requirement for thiamin [(94)](#reference94). All rapidly dividing cells require [nucleic acids](../glossary#nucleic-acid) at an increased rate, and some cancer cells appear to rely heavily on the TPP-dependent [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme), transketolase, to provide the ribose-5-phosphate necessary for nucleic acid [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis). One study found that the levels of THTR-1, transketolase, and TPP [mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) transporters were increased in samples of human breast cancer tissue compared to normal tissue, suggesting an adaptation in thiamin [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) in support of cancer metabolism [(95)](#reference95). Other studies have found that the [gene](../glossary#gene) encoding THTR-2 is downregulated in certain cancers [(96)](#reference96). Moreover, use of the chemotherapeutic drug, 5-fluorouracil, inhibits [phosphorylation](../glossary#phosphorylation) of thiamin to thiamin thiamin deficiency [(97, 98)](#reference97). Thiamin [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) in cancer patients is common to prevent thiamin deficiency, but Boros et al. caution that too much thiamin may actually fuel the growth of some [malignant](../glossary#malignant) tumors [(99)](#reference99), suggesting that thiamin supplementation be reserved for those cancer patients who are actually deficient in thiamin. Presently, there is no evidence available from studies in humans to support or refute this theory. However, it would be prudent for individuals with cancer who are considering thiamin supplementation to discuss it with the clinician managing their cancer therapy. [Intravenous](../glossary#intravenous), high-dose thiamin has been suggested as a treatment for cancer patients with confirmed Wernicke-Korsakoff [(93)](#reference93). Sepsis is a life-threatening critical illness caused by a dysregulated host response to an infection. The widespread [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) can lead to tissue and organ damage and to death [(100)](#reference100). Because thiamin deficiency is common among septic patients [(101)](#reference101), several studies have investigated the treatment effect of [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) thiamin - alone or in combination with other agents like vitamin C and hydrocortisone. [Observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) examining the association of intravenous thiamin as a [monotherapy](../glossary#monotherapy) have mainly looked at its association with lactic acidosis, which commonly occurs in both thiamin deficiency and sepsis, and with mortality. One [retrospective study](../glossary#retrospective-study) in 123 septic patients and 246 matched controls found that intravenous thiamin administration within 24 hours of hospital admission was linked to improvements in both lactate clearance and 28-day mortality [(102)](#reference102). In a small retrospective study of 53 alcohol-use disorder patients presenting with septic shock, lower mortality was observed in the 34 patients who received intravenous thiamin compared to the 19 patients who did not [(103)](#reference103). A few [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have evaluated the effect of intravenous thiamin in the treatment of sepsis. A [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 88 patients with sepsis and elevated blood concentrations of lactate reported that intravenous thiamin (200 mg twice daily for seven days or until discharge from the hospital) did not decrease lactate concentrations at 24 hours post initiation of treatment - the primary endpoint of the trial [(104)](#reference104). No differences between the treatment and placebo groups were found for the secondary endpoints, which included survival [(104)](#reference104). In a subsequent analysis of data from this trial, the septic patients that were given parenteral thiamin (n=31) had lower creatinine concentrations throughout the treatment and were less likely to need [renal](../glossary#renal) replacement therapy compared to placebo (n=39; [105)](#reference105). A 2020 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of four studies - one observational and three randomized controlled trials - found no benefit of intravenous thiamin for improving lactate concentrations, length of hospital stay in intensive care, or overall survival [(106)](#reference106). Large-scale [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) are needed to determine whether parenteral administration of thiamin is beneficial in the treatment of sepsis. Administering thiamin in combination with vitamin C and corticosteroids may be more efficacious to treat sepsis [(107)](#reference107); some clinical trials of such treatments are currently underway (see clinicaltrials.gov/). Thiamin [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) is included in the clinical management of genetic diseases that affect the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) and [branched-chain amino acids](../glossary#branched-chain-amino-acids) efficient [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) of [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) in affected individuals. PDHC deficiency is commonly characterized by lactic acidosis, [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) and neuromuscular degeneration, and death during childhood. The patients who respond to thiamin treatment (from a few mg/day to doses above 1,000 mg/day) exhibit PDHC deficiency due to the decreased affinity of PDHC for TPP [(108, 109)](#reference108). Although thiamin supplementation can reduce lactate accumulation and improve the clinical features in thiamin-responsive patients, it does not constitute a cure [(110)](#reference110). Inborn errors of [BCAA](../glossary#branched-chain-amino-acids) metabolism lead to thiamin-responsive branched-chain ketoaciduria, also known as maple syrup urine disease. Alterations in the BCAA [catabolic](../glossary#catabolism) pathway result in [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) dysfunction caused by the accumulation of BCAAs and their derivatives, branched-chain ketoacids (BCKA). The therapeutic approach includes a synthetic diet with reduced BCAA content, and thiamin (10-1,000 mg/day) is supplemented to subunit of the BCKDH complex [(111)](#reference111). In thiamin-responsive individuals, the supplementation has been proven effective to correct the phenotype without recourse to the BCAA restriction diet. [Mutations](../glossary#mutation) SLC19A2 [gene](../glossary#gene) impairs to thiamin-responsive [megaloblastic anemia](../glossary#megaloblastic-anemia) [(112)](#reference112). This syndrome, which is also called thiamin metabolism dysfunction syndrome-1, is characterized by megaloblastic anemia, [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), and deafness. A review of 30 cases reported additional [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic), visual, and cardiac impairments [(113)](#reference113). High-dose oral supplementation with thiamin (up to 300 mg/day) helps to maintain health and correct [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia) in prepubescent children. A recent study in 32 individuals with found no additional benefit of oral doses above 150 mg/day [(114)](#reference114). After puberty, a decline in [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) function results in the requirement of [insulin](../glossary#insulin) together with thiamin to control the hyperglycemia. One study also reported that the treatment of a four-month-old girl with 100 mg/day of thiamin did not prevent hearing loss at 20 months of age [(115)](#reference115). Early diagnosis of the syndrome and early treatment with thiamin is important for a better [prognosis](../glossary#prognosis) deficiency, and an [autosomal](../glossary#autosomal) [recessive](../glossary#recessive-trait) [mutation](../glossary#mutation) in the SLC19A3 [gene](../glossary#gene) that codes for THTR-2. The disease usually presents around 3 to 10 years of age [(116)](#reference116), but an early infantile form of the disease exists with onset as early as one month of age [(117)](#reference117). Clinical features include subacute [encephalopathy](../glossary#encephalopathy) (confusion, drowsiness, altered level of consciousness), [ataxia](../glossary#ataxia), and [seizures](../glossary#seizure). A [retrospective study](../glossary#retrospective-study) of 18 affected individuals from the same family or the same tribe in Saudi Arabia showed that biotin [monotherapy](../glossary#monotherapy) (5-10 mg/kg/day) efficiently abolished the clinical manifestations of the disease, although one-third of the patients suffered from recurrent acute crises. Often associated with poor outcomes, acute crises were not observed for a five-year follow-up period following thiamin supplementation (300-400 mg/day) - early diagnosis and immediate treatment with biotin and thiamin led to positive outcomes [(118)](#reference118). Recent studies have found supplemental thiamin to be important in treating the condition. In an [open-label study](../glossary#open-label-trial) of 20 pediatric patients with the disease, supplemental thiamin alone was as effective as combined biotin-thiamin supplementation when given for 30 months [(119)](#reference119). Lifelong high-dose supplementation with a combination of biotin and thiamin is generally the treatment for biotin-thiamin-responsive basal ganglia disease [(116)](#reference116). Early diagnosis and treatment is to ensure a better [prognosis](../glossary#prognosis) [(117](#reference117), [120)](#reference120). [Supplemental](../glossary#supplement) thiamin has limited utility in treating other inborn errors of thiamin metabolism. [Mutations](../glossary#mutation) in the SLC25A19 [gene](../glossary#gene) that codes for the [mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) TPP transporter can result in either thiamin metabolism dysfunction syndrome-3 (THMD3) or thiamin metabolism dysfunction called Amish-type or Amish lethal microcephaly) the more severe phenotype, resulting in a congenital microcephaly, elevated concentrations of -ketoglutarate in urine, and usually death in infancy [(121)](#reference121). THMD4 is characterized by episodic encephalopathy and weakness, which often presents following a viral infection or febrile illness in childhood. Some patients affected with THMD4 may respond to high-dose thiamin supplementation [(122)](#reference122). Mutations in the TPK1 gene result pyrophosphokinase 1 deficiency and thiamin metabolism dysfunction syndrome-5 (THMD5), which usually manifests in early childhood. While the clinical presentation of THMD5 varies, affected individuals often experience episodic ataxia, dystonia, and lactic acidosis [(123)](#reference123). Only a few cases of THMD5 have been reported to date; two of these patients experienced limited improvement of symptoms upon supplementation with thiamin, in conjunction with adherence to a high-fat diet [(124)](#reference124). Humans obtain thiamin from dietary sources and from the normal [microflora](../glossary#intestinal-microbiota) of the [colon](../glossary#colon), although the contribution of the latter towards the body's requirement for thiamin is not clear [(125)](#reference125). A varied diet should provide most individuals with adequate thiamin to prevent deficiency. In the US the average dietary thiamin intake for young adult men is about 2 mg/day and 1.2 mg/day for young adult women. A survey of people over the age of 60 found an average dietary thiamin intake of 1.4 mg/day for men and 1.1 mg/day for women [(37)](#reference37). However, institutionalization and poverty both increase the likelihood of inadequate thiamin intake in the elderly [(126)](#reference126). Whole-grain cereals, [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes) (e.g., beans and lentils), [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts), lean pork, and yeast are rich sources of thiamin [(1)](#references). Because most of the thiamin is lost during the production of white flour and polished (milled) rice, white rice and foods made from white flour (e.g., bread and pasta) are [fortified](../glossary#fortification) with thiamin in many Western countries. For more information on the nutrient content of of meat is a serving about the size of a deck of cards| Thiamin is available in dietary [supplements](../glossary#supplement) and in [fortified](../glossary#fortification) foods, most commonly as thiamin hydrochloride or thiamin mononitrate [(127)](#reference127). Multivitamin supplements typically contain at least 1.2 mg of thiamin, the Daily Value ( [DV](../glossary#DV)) for adults and children 4 years and older [(128)](#reference128). Benfotiamine is a synthetic, lipid-soluble [precursor](../glossary#precursor) of thiamin that is available as a dietary supplement. It has higher [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) compared to thiamin [(129)](#reference129). The Food and Nutrition Board did not set a tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for thiamin because there are no well-established toxic effects from consumption of excess thiamin in food or through long-term, oral [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) (up to 200 mg/day). A small number of life-threatening [anaphylactic](../glossary#anaphylaxis) reactions have been observed with large [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) doses of thiamin [(37)](#reference37). Reduced blood concentrations of thiamin have been reported in individuals with [seizure](../glossary#seizure) disorders ( [epilepsy](../glossary#epilepsy)) taking the [anticonvulsant](../glossary#anticonvulsant) medication, phenytoin, for long periods of time [(130)](#reference130). 5-Fluorouracil, a drug used in [cancer](../glossary#cancer) therapy, inhibits of thiamin to TPP especially furosemide, may increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of thiamin deficiency in individuals with marginal thiamin intake due to increased urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of thiamin [(29)](#reference29). Moreover, chronic alcohol abuse is associated with thiamin deficiency due to low dietary intake, impaired absorption and utilization, and increased excretion of the [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin) [(1)](#references). Chronic alcohol feeding to rats showed a decrease in the active absorption of thiamin linked to the inhibition of thiamin membrane transporter THTR-1 in the intestinal epithelium [(132)](#reference132). Alcohol consumption in rats also decreases the levels of THTR-1 and THTR-2 in [renal](../glossary#renal) [epithelial](../glossary#epithelium) cells, thus limiting thiamin re-uptake by the kidneys [(133)](#reference133). The Linus Pauling Institute supports the recommendation by the Food and Nutrition Board of 1.2 mg/day of thiamin for men and 1.1 mg/day for women. A varied diet should provide enough thiamin for most people. Following the Linus Pauling Institute recommendation to take a daily multivitamin/mineral supplement, containing 100% of the Daily Values (DV), will ensure an intake of at least 1.5 mg/day of thiamin. Presently, there is no evidence that the requirement for thiamin is increased in older adults, but some studies have found inadequate dietary intake and thiamin insufficiency to be more common in elderly populations [(126)](#reference126). Thus, it would be prudent for older adults to take a multivitamin/mineral supplement, which will generally provide at least 1.5 mg/day of thiamin. Retinol and retinyl esters are often referred to as preformed vitamin A. Retinol can be converted by the body to retinal, which can be in turn be ] [oxidized](../glossary#oxidation) to retinoic acid, the form of vitamin A known to regulate [gene](../glossary#gene) [transcription](../glossary#transcription). Retinol, retinal, retinoic acid, and related compounds are known as retinoids. -Carotene and other food carotenoids that can be converted by the body into retinol are referred to as provitamin A carotenoids (see the article on [Carotenoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/carotenoids)). Hundreds of different carotenoids are [synthesized](../glossary#synthesis) by plants, but only about 10% of them are capable of being converted to retinol [(1)](#references). The following discussion will focus mainly on preformed vitamin A compounds and retinoic acid. Vitamin A compounds are essential fat-soluble molecules predominantly stored in the liver in the form of retinyl esters (e.g., retinyl palmitate). When appropriate, retinyl which binds to retinol binding [protein](../glossary#protein) (RBP) before being released in the bloodstream. The all-trans-retinol/RBP complex circulates bound to the protein, transthyretin, which delivers all-trans-retinol to peripheral tissues (reviewed in [2](#reference2)). Vitamin A as retinyl esters in chylomicrons was also found to have an appreciable role in delivering vitamin A to extrahepatic tissues, especially in early life [(3, 4)](#reference3). Located at the back of the eye, the [retina](../glossary#retina) contains two main types of light-sensitive [receptor](../glossary#receptor) cells known as rod and cone photoreceptor cells. Photons (particles of light) that pass through the [lens](../glossary#lens) are sensed by the photoreceptor cells of the retina and converted to [nerve impulses](../glossary#nerve-impulse) (electric signals) for interpretation by the brain. All-trans-retinol is transported to the retina via the circulation and accumulates in retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells (Figure 2) [(5)](#reference5). Here, all-trans-retinol is esterified to form a retinyl ester, which can be stored. When needed, retinyl esters are broken apart ( [hydrolyzed](../glossary#hydrolysis)) and isomerized to 11-cis-retinol, which can be [oxidized](../glossary#oxidation) to form 11-cis-retinal. 11-cis-retinal can be shuttled across the interphotoreceptor space to the rod photoreceptor cell that is specialized for vision in low-light conditions and for detection of motion. In rod cells, 11-cis-retinal binds to a [protein](../glossary#protein) called opsin to form the visual pigment rhodopsin (also known as visual purple). Absorption of a photon of light [catalyzes](../glossary#catalyze) the isomerization of 11-cis-retinal to all-trans-retinal that is released from the opsin molecule. This photoisomerization triggers a cascade of events, leading to the generation of a nerve impulse conveyed by the optic nerve to the brain's visual cortex. All-trans-retinal is converted to all-trans-retinol and transported across the interstitial space to the RPE cells, thereby completing the visual cycle. A similar cycle occurs in cone cells that contain red, green, or blue opsin proteins required for the absorption of photons from the visible light spectrum [(2)](#reference2). Vitamin A is also essential for mammalian eye development [(6)](#reference6). Thus, because vitamin A is required for the normal functioning of the retina, dim-light vision, and color vision, inadequate retinol and retinal available to the retina result in impaired dark adaptation. In the severest cases of vitamin A deficiency, thinning and ulceration of the cornea leads to blindness (see [Deficiency](#deficiency)). In cells, all-trans-retinol can be either stored (in the form of retinyl ester) or [oxidized](../glossary#oxidation) to all-trans-retinal by alcohol dehydrogenases. retinaldehyde dehydrogenases can [catalyze](../glossary#catalyze) the conversion of retinoic as to [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression) and thereby influence numerous physiological processes. All-trans-RA and 9-cis-RA are transported to the [nucleus](../glossary#nucleus) of the cell bound to cellular retinoic acid-binding [proteins](../glossary#protein) (CRABP). Within the nucleus, RA isomers bind specific nuclear [receptor](../glossary#receptor) proteins that are [ligand](../glossary#ligand)-dependent [transcription factors](../glossary#transcription-factor) (Figure 3). Both all-trans-RA and 9-cis-RA can bind to retinoic acid receptors (RAR, RAR, and RAR), whereas only 9-cis-RA binds to retinoid X receptors (RXR, RXR, and RXR) [(7)](#reference7). RAR and RXR subtypes form either complexes of two of the same protein (RAR/RAR and RXR/RXR [homodimers](../glossary#homodimer)) or complexes of two different proteins (RAR/RXR [heterodimers](../glossary#heterodimer)). RAR/RXR heterodimers can bind to a regulatory [DNA](../glossary#DNA) sequence called retinoic acid response element (RARE) located within the [promoter](../glossary#promoter) of retinoid-responsive [genes](../glossary#gene). The [transcriptional](../glossary#transcription) activity of RAR/RXR heterodimers appears to be mainly driven by the binding of all-trans-RA to RAR. The activation of RAR by RA binding triggers the recruitment of transcriptional coregulators to target promoters, thereby inhibiting or allowing the transcription of genes [(8)](#reference8). RXR also forms heterodimers with several other nuclear receptors, including thyroid hormone receptor (TR), [vitamin D](vitamin-D) receptor (VDR), [steroid](../glossary#steroid) receptors, and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR) [(9)](#reference9). In this way, vitamin A may interact with thyroid hormone, vitamin D, steroids (e.g., estrogen), or PPAR ligands [signaling](../glossary#cell-signaling) pathways and influence the transcription of a broad range of genes. There is also evidence that RA/RAR can affect gene expression in a RARE-independent manner. For example, it was reported that RAR could interfere with TGF/Smad signaling pathway through direct interaction of RAR with the heterodimeric transcription factor, Smad3/Smad4. In the absence of RA, RAR was found to act as a coactivator of Smad3/Smad4-mediated transcription, while RAR agonists repressed the transcriptional activity of Smad3/Smad4 [(10)](#reference10). In retinoblastoma cells, RAR was also involved in RA-induced activation of signaling cascades mediated by tyrosine kinases known as phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) and leading to [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation) [(11, 12)](#reference11). RA also appeared to induce [neuronal](../glossary#neuron) differentiation by activating ERK1/2 MAP kinase signaling pathway that [phosphorylated](../glossary#phosphorylation) transcription factor, CREB (cyclic AMP response element binding protein). Phosphorylated CREB can subsequently bind to the CREB response element in the promoter of genes involved in cell differentiation [(13)](#reference13). Also, independently of RAR, RA was found to inhibit ERK1/2 phosphorylation/activation and subsequent AP1-mediated expression of interleukin-6 in synovial cells [(14)](#reference14). Hence, RA can influence the expression of genes whose promoters do not contain RARE. By regulating the expression of over 500 retinoid-responsive genes (including several genes involved in vitamin A [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) itself), retinoic acid isomers play major roles in cellular [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) and differentiation (i.e., cell commitment to highly specialized functions). In the eye and tissues like white [adipose](../glossary#adipose) and muscle, [catalyzes](../glossary#catalyze) retinol esterification and to maintain an inward concentration gradient of retinol [(15)](#reference15). Interestingly, retinol uptake by STRA6 was found to trigger the activation of a [signaling](../glossary#cell-signaling) cascade mediated by tyrosine kinases known as Janus kinases (JAK) and associated [transcription factors](../glossary#transcription-factor) (STAT). JAK/STAT signaling pathway regulates the expression of a wide range of [cytokines](../glossary#cytokine), [hormones](../glossary#hormone), and growth factors [(16)](#reference16). Animal studies have reported that an increased [expression](../glossary#gene-expression) of [genes](../glossary#gene), such as SOCS3 by the JAK/STAT pathway, could result in the inhibition of [insulin](../glossary#insulin) signaling. Hence, obese mice lacking LRAT or be protected from retinol/STRA6-induced [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance) [(17, 18)](#reference17). Apart from its role as a [ligand](../glossary#ligand) for opsin in the visual cascade (see [Visual system and eyesight](#visual-system)), retinal has been specifically implicated in the regulation of [genes](../glossary#gene) important for [lipid](../glossary#lipid) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism). In humans, two types of [adipose tissue](../glossary#adipose) have been distinguished based on their respective functions: white adipose tissue (WAT) stores [fatty acids](../glossary#fatty-acid) as [triglycerides](../glossary#triglycerides), and brown adipose tissue (BAT) [oxidizes](../glossary#oxidation) to generate heat (thermogenesis). In the [mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) [respiratory chain](../glossary#electron-transport-chain) of brown adipose cells, the processes of electron transport and [ATP](../glossary#ATP) production are uncoupled (dissociated) to permit the rapid production of heat from fatty acid oxidation [(19)](#reference19). Retinaldehyde dehydrogenase 1 (RALDH1), which converts retinal to retinoic acid, is highly expressed in WAT but not in BAT. The suppression of RALDH1 expression in WAT can induce a thermogenic phenotype resembling that of BAT [(20)](#reference20). During adipocyte differentiation, the stimulation of cells with all-trans retinal has been found to activate the UCP1 gene required for thermogenesis while inhibiting genes promoting adipogenesis, such as PPAR [(20)](#reference20). Retinal also appeared to regulate lipid metabolism and adiposity in bone marrow by inhibiting PPAR/RXR [heterodimer](../glossary#heterodimer)-mediated [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression) [(21)](#reference21). In addition, retinal was found to inhibit [gluconeogenic](../glossary#gluconeogenesis) gene expression and [glucose](../glossary#glucose) production in the liver of mice deficient in RALDH1 [(22)](#reference22). Vitamin A was initially coined "the anti-infective [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin)" because of its importance in the normal functioning of the immune system [(23)](#reference23). The skin and mucosal cells, lining the airways, digestive tract, and urinary tract function as a barrier and form the body's first line of defense against infection. Retinoic acid (RA) is produced by [antigen](../glossary#antigen)-presenting cells (APCs), including [macrophages](../glossary#macrophage) and [dendritic cells](../glossary#dendritic-cell), found in these mucosal interfaces and associated lymph nodes. RA appears to act on dendritic cells themselves to regulate their [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation), migration, and antigen-presenting capacity. In addition, the production of RA by APCs is required for the differentiation of naïve CD4 T- [lymphocytes](../glossary#lymphocyte) into induced regulatory T- lymphocytes (Tregs). Critical to the maintenance of mucosal integrity, the differentiation of Tregs is driven by all-trans-RA through RAR-mediated regulation of [gene (see [Regulation of gene expression](#gene-expression-regulation)). Also, during [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), signaling pathway the conversion of naïve into effector T-lymphocytes type 1 helper T-cells (Th1) (rather than into Tregs) and induces the production of proinflammatory [cytokines](../glossary#cytokine) by effector T-lymphocytes in response to infection. There is also substantial evidence to suggest that RA may help prevent the development of autoimmunity (reviewed in [24](#reference24)). Both vitamin A excess and deficiency are known to cause birth defects. Retinoid signaling begins soon after the early phase of embryonic development known as gastrulation. During fetal development, RA is critical for the development of organs, including the heart, eyes, ears, lungs, as well as other limbs and visceral organs. Vitamin A has been implicated in fetal lung maturation [(2)](#reference2). Vitamin A status is lower in preterm newborns than in full-term infants [(25)](#reference25). There is some evidence to suggest that vitamin A [supplementation](../glossary#supplmentation) may help reduce the incidence of chronic lung disease and mortality in preterm newborns (see [Disease Prevention](#disease-prevention)). Retinoid signaling is also involved in the expression of many [proteins](../glossary#protein) of the extracellular matrix (ECM; material surrounding cells), including [collagen](../glossary#collagen), laminin, and [proteoglycans](../glossary#proteoglycan) [(26)](#reference26). Vitamin A deficiency may then result in alterations of the ECM composition, thus disrupting organ morphology and function (reviewed in [26](#reference26)). Red blood cells ( [erythrocytes](../glossary#erythrocyte)), like all blood cells, are derived from pluripotent stem cells in the bone marrow. Studies involving [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) culture systems have suggested a role for retinoids in stem cell commitment and [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation) to the red blood cell lineage. Retinoids might also regulate [apoptosis](../glossary#apoptosis) (programmed cell death) of red blood cell [precursors](../glossary#precursor) (erythropoietic cells) [(27)](#reference27). However, whether retinoids regulate erythropoiesis vivo](../glossary#in-vivo) has not been established. Yet, vitamin A [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) in vitamin A deficient-individuals has been shown to increase [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) concentrations. Additionally, vitamin A appears to facilitate the mobilization of [iron](../minerals/iron) from storage sites to the developing red blood cell for incorporation into hemoglobin, the oxygen carrier in red blood cells [(27, 28)](#reference27). [Zinc](../minerals/zinc) deficiency is thought to interfere with vitamin A [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) in several ways [(29)](#reference29): (1) zinc deficiency results in decreased [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of retinol-binding protein (RBP), which transports retinol through the circulation to peripheral tissues and protects the organism against potential toxicity of retinol; (2) zinc deficiency results in decreased activity of the [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) that releases retinol from its storage form, retinyl palmitate, in the liver; and (3) zinc is required for the enzyme that converts retinol into retinal [(30)](#reference30). The health consequences of zinc deficiency on vitamin A nutritional status in humans are yet to be defined [(29)](#reference29). Vitamin A deficiency often coexists with [iron](../minerals/iron) deficiency and may exacerbate iron deficiency [anemia](../glossary#anemia) by altering iron [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [(27)](#reference27). Vitamin A [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) has beneficial effects on iron deficiency anemia and improves iron nutritional status among children and pregnant women [(27, 28)](#reference27). The combination of supplemental vitamin A and iron seems to reduce anemia more effectively than either supplemental iron or vitamin A alone [(31)](#reference31). Moreover, studies in rats have shown that iron deficiency alters [plasma](../glossary#plasma) and liver levels of vitamin A [(32, 33)](#reference32). Vitamin A deficiency usually results from inadequate intakes of vitamin A from animal products (as preformed vitamin A) and fruit and vegetables (as provitamin A carotenoids). In developing countries, vitamin A deficiency and associated disorders predominantly affect children and women of reproductive age. Other individuals at [risk](../glossary#risk) of vitamin A deficiency are those with poor absorption of [lipids](../glossary#lipid) due to impaired [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) or [biliary](../glossary#bile) secretion and those and [celiac disease](../glossary#celiac-disease) A deficiency is often defined by serum retinol concentrations lower than 0.70 mol/L (20 g/dL). In severe vitamin A deficiency, vitamin A body stores are depleted and serum retinol concentrations fall below 0.35 mol/L (10 g/dL). Other [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) have been calibrated to assess vitamin A nutritional status (reviewed in [34](#reference34)). Of note, the World Health Organization considers vitamin A deficiency a public health problem when the prevalence of low serum retinol (<0.70 mol/L) reaches 15% or more of a defined population. With an estimated 250,000 to 500,000 children becoming blind annually, vitamin A deficiency constitutes the leading preventable cause of blindness in low- and middle-income nations [(35)](#reference35). The earliest symptom of vitamin A deficiency is impaired dark adaptation known as night blindness or nyctalopia. The next clinical stage is the occurrence of abnormal changes in the conjunctiva (corner of the eye), manifested by the presence of Bitot's spots. Severe or prolonged vitamin A deficiency eventually results in a condition called xerophthalmia (Greek for dry eye), characterized by changes in the cells of the cornea (clear covering of the eye) that ultimately result in corneal ulcers, scarring, and blindness [(36)](#reference36). Immediate administration of 200,000 international units (IU) of vitamin A for two consecutive days is required to prevent blinding xerophthalmia [(36)](#reference36). There is an estimated 19.1 million pregnant women worldwide (especially in Sub-Saharan Africa, Southeast Asia, and Central America) with vitamin A deficiency and over half of them are affected by night blindness [(37)](#reference37). The prevalence of vitamin A deficiency and night blindness is especially high during the third trimester of pregnancy due to accelerated fetal growth. Also, approximately 190 million preschool-age children have low [serum](../glossary#serum) retinol concentrations (<0.70 mol/L), with 5.2 million suffering from night blindness. Moreover, half of the children affected by severe vitamin A deficiency-induced blinding xerophthalmia are estimated to die within a year of becoming blind [(37)](#reference37). The World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) promote vitamin A supplementation as a public health intervention to reduce child mortality in areas and populations where vitamin A deficiency is [prevalent](../glossary#prevalence) [(38-40)](#reference38). Infectious diseases have been associated with depletion of vitamin A [hepatic](../glossary#hepatic) reserves (already limited in vitamin A-deficient subjects), reduced [serum](../glossary#serum) retinol concentrations, and increased loss of vitamin A in the urine [(37)](#reference37). Infection with the measles virus was found to precipitate conjunctival and [corneal](../glossary#cornea) damage, leading to blindness in children with poor vitamin A status [(41)](#reference41). Conversely, vitamin A deficiency can be considered a nutritionally acquired immunodeficiency disease [(42)](#reference42). Even children who are only mildly deficient in vitamin A have a higher incidence of respiratory complications and diarrhea, as well as a higher rate of mortality from measles infection compared to children consuming sufficient vitamin A [(43)](#reference43). A recent [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), conducted in 2,774 Colombian children (ages, 5-12 years old) followed for a median 128 days, also reported an inverse relationship between [plasma](../glossary#plasma) retinol concentrations and rates of diarrhea with vomiting and cough with fever, the latter being a strong predictor of influenza infection (flu) [(45)](#reference45). Phrynoderma or follicular hyperkeratosis is a skin condition characterized by an excessive production of keratin in hair follicles. The lesions first appear on the extremities, shoulders, and buttocks and may spread over the entire body in the severest cases [(53)](#reference53). While vitamin A deficiency may contribute to the occurrence of phrynoderma, the condition has been strongly associated with multiple nutritional deficiencies and is considered a sign of general malnutrition. A rare case of esophagitis ( [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) of the [esophagus](../glossary#esophagus)) has recently been attributed to hyperkeratosis secondary to vitamin A deficiency [(54)](#reference54). Also, vitamin A deficiency affects [iron](../minerals/iron) mobilization, impairs [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis), and precipitates iron deficiency anemia that is only alleviated with [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) of both vitamin A and iron (see [Nutrient interactions](#nutrient-interactions)) [(27)](#reference27). Vitamin A can be obtained from food as preformed vitamin A in animal products or as provitamin A carotenoids in fruit and vegetables (see [Food sources](#food-sources)). The efficiency of conversion of provitamin A carotenes into retinol is highly variable, depending on factors such as food matrix, food preparation, and one's digestive and absorptive capacities [(55)](#reference55). The most recent international standard of measure for vitamin A is retinol activity equivalents (RAE), which represent vitamin A activity as retinol. It has been determined that 2 micrograms (g) of -carotene in oil provided as a [supplement](../glossary#supplement) could be converted by the body to 1 g of retinol giving it an RAE ratio of 2:1. The condition caused by vitamin A toxicity is called hypervitaminosis A. It is caused by overconsumption of preformed vitamin A, not [carotenoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/carotenoids). Preformed vitamin A is rapidly absorbed and slowly cleared from the body. Therefore, toxicity from preformed vitamin A may result acutely from high-dose exposure over a short period of time or chronically from a much lower intake [(2)](#reference2). Acute vitamin A toxicity is relatively rare, and symptoms include nausea, headache, fatigue, loss of appetite, dizziness, dry skin, desquamation, and [cerebral](../glossary#cerebral) [edema](../glossary#edema). Signs of chronic toxicity include dry itchy skin, desquamation, anorexia, weight loss, headache, cerebral edema, enlarged liver, enlarged spleen, [anemia](../glossary#anemia), and bone and joint pain. Also, symptoms of vitamin A toxicity in infants include bulging fontanels. Severe cases of hypervitaminosis A may result in liver damage, [hemorrhage](../glossary#hemorrhage), and coma. Generally, signs of toxicity are associated with long-term consumption of vitamin A in excess of 10 times the RDA (8,000-10,000 g RAE/day or 25,000-33,000 IU/day). However, more research is necessary to determine if [subclinical](../glossary#subclinical) vitamin A toxicity is a concern in certain populations [(89)](#reference89). There is evidence that some populations may be more susceptible to toxicity at lower doses, including the elderly, chronic alcohol users, and some people with a genetic predisposition to high [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) [(90)](#reference90). Whether this increases the dietary requirement of vitamin A is not known. Also, the use of [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol)-lowering medications (like cholestyramine and colestipol), as well as orlistat, mineral oil, and the fat substitute, olestra, which interfere with fat absorption, may affect the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamin A [(88)](#reference88). Further, intake of large doses of vitamin A may decrease the absorption of [vitamin K](vitamin-K). isotretinoin, should not be used in combination with single-nutrient vitamin A [supplements](../glossary#supplement), because they may increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of vitamin A toxicity [(88)](#reference88). The [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for vitamin A (700 g RAE/day for women and 900 g RAE/day for men) is sufficient to support normal [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression), immune function, and vision. However, following the Linus Pauling Institute's recommendation to take a multivitamin/mineral supplement daily could supply as much as 5,000 IU (1,500 g RAE)/day of vitamin A as retinol, the amount that has been associated with adverse effects on bone health in older adults. For this reason, we recommend taking a [multivitamin/mineral supplement](../micronutrients-health/multivitamin-mineral-supplements) that provides no more than 2,500 IU (750 g) of preformed vitamin A (usually labeled vitamin A acetate or vitamin A palmitate) and no more than 2,500 IU of additional vitamin A as -carotene. High potency vitamin A supplements should not be used without medical supervision due to the [risk](../glossary#risk) of toxicity. Presently, there is little evidence that the requirement for vitamin A in older adults differs from that of younger adults. Additionally, vitamin A toxicity may occur at lower doses in older adults than in younger adults. Further, data from observational studies suggested an association between intakes of preformed vitamin A in excess of 1,500 g RAE (5,000 IU)/day and increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of hip [fracture](../glossary#fracture) in older people (see [Safety](#safety)). Yet, following the Linus Pauling Institute's recommendation to take a multivitamin/mineral supplement daily could supply as much as 5,000 IU/day of retinol, the amount that has been associated with adverse effects on bone health in older adults. For this reason, we recommend taking a multivitamin/mineral supplement that provides (750 g) of preformed vitamin A (usually labeled vitamin A acetate or vitamin A palmitate) and no more than 2,500 IU of additional vitamin A as -carotene. As for all age groups, high potency vitamin A supplements should not be used without medical supervision due to the risk of toxicity. Alcohol Res Health. 2003;27(3):220-231. ] [(PubMed)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15535450) Contents Vitamin B6 is a water-soluble [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin) that was first isolated in the 1930s. The term vitamin B6 refers to six common forms, namely pyridoxal, pyridoxine (pyridoxol), pyridoxamine, and 5'-phosphate (PLP) is the bioactive [coenzyme](../glossary#coenzyme) form involved in over 4% of all [enzymatic](../glossary#enzyme) reactions (Figure 1) [(1-3)](#references). Vitamin B6 must be obtained from the diet because humans cannot synthesize it. PLP plays a vital role in the function of over 100 enzymes that catalyze essential chemical reactions in the human body [(4)](#reference4). PLP-dependent enzymes have been classified into five structural classes known as Fold Type I-V [(5)](#reference5): The many biochemical reactions catalyzed by PLP-dependent enzymes are involved in essential biological processes, such as [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) and [amino acid](../glossary#amino-acid) biosynthesis, as well as [fatty functions for [glycogen](../glossary#glycogen) phosphorylase, an enzyme that catalyzes the release of [glucose](../glossary#glucose) from stored glycogen. Much of the PLP in the human body is found in muscle bound to glycogen phosphorylase. PLP is also a coenzyme for reactions that generate glucose from amino acids, a process known as [gluconeogenesis](../glossary#gluconeogenesis) [(6)](#reference6). In the brain, the PLP-dependent [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) aromatic [catalyzes](../glossary#catalyze) reactions catalyzed by PLP-dependent enzymes [(7)](#reference7). PLP functions as a [coenzyme](../glossary#coenzyme) of 5-aminolevulinic acid synthase, which is involved in the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of [heme](../glossary#heme), an [iron](../minerals/iron)-containing component of [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin). Hemoglobin is found in red blood cells and is critical to their ability to transport oxygen throughout the body. Both pyridoxal and PLP are able to bind to the hemoglobin molecule and affect its ability to pick up and release oxygen. However, the impact of this on normal oxygen delivery to tissues is not known [(6, 8)](#reference6). Vitamin B6 deficiency may impair hemoglobin synthesis and lead to microcytic [anemia](../glossary#anemia) [(3)](#reference3). Deficiency in another B vitamin, [niacin](../vitamins/niacin), is easily prevented by adequate dietary intakes. The dietary requirement for niacin and the niacin [coenzyme](../glossary#coenzyme), nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), can be also met, though to a fairly limited extent, by the [catabolism](../glossary#catabolism) of the essential [amino acid](../glossary#amino-acid) tryptophan in the tryptophan-kynurenine pathway (Figure 2). Key reactions in this pathway are PLP-dependent; in particular, PLP is the [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) for the [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) kynureninase, which [catalyzes](../glossary#catalyze) the conversion of 3-hydroxykynurenine to 3-hydroxyanthranilic acid. A reduction in PLP availability appears to primarily affect kynureninase activity, limiting NAD production and leading to higher concentrations of kynurenine, 3-hydroxykynurenine, and xanthurenic acid in blood and urine (Figure 2) [(9)](#reference9). Thus, while dietary vitamin B6 restriction impairs NAD [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) from tryptophan, adequate PLP levels help maintain NAD formation from tryptophan [(10)](#reference10). The effect of vitamin B6 inadequacy on immune activation and [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) may be partly related to the role of PLP in the tryptophan-kynurenine [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) as [estrogen](../glossary#estrogen) and testosterone, exert their effects in the body by binding to [steroid hormone receptors](../glossary#steroid-hormone-receptor) in the [nucleus](../glossary#nucleus) of target cells. The nuclear receptors themselves bind to specific regulatory sequences in [DNA](../glossary#DNA) and alter the [transcription](../glossary#transcription) of target [genes](../glossary#gene). Experimental studies have uncovered a mechanism by which PLP may affect the activity of steroid receptors and decrease their effects on [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression). It was found that PLP could interact with RIP140/NRIP1, a repressor of nuclear receptors known for its role in reproductive biology [(11)](#reference11). Yet, additional research is needed to confirm that this interaction can enhance RIP140/NRIP1 repressive activity on steroid receptor-mediated gene expression. If the activity of steroid receptors for estrogen, progesterone, testosterone, or other steroid hormones can be inhibited by PLP, it is possible that vitamin B6 status may influence one's risk of developing diseases driven by steroid hormones, such as breast and [prostate](../glossary#prostate) [cancers](../glossary#cancer) [(6)](#reference6). a coenzyme for SHMT, which [catalyzes](../glossary#catalyze) the simultaneous conversions glycine and tetrahydrofolate (THF) to 5,10-methylene THF. The latter molecule is the donor](../glossary#one-carbon-unit) for the generation of dTMP from deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) by TYMS. Severe deficiency of vitamin B6 is uncommon. Alcoholics are thought to be most at risk of vitamin B6 deficiency due to low dietary intakes and impaired [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of the [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin). In the early 1950s, [seizures](../glossary#seizure) were observed in infants as a result of severe vitamin B6 deficiency caused by an error in the manufacture of infant formula [(7)](#reference7). Abnormal [electroencephalogram](../glossary#electroencephalogram) (EEG) patterns have also been reported in vitamin B6-deficient adults. Other [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) symptoms observed in severe vitamin B6 deficiency include irritability, depression, and confusion; additional symptoms include [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) of the tongue, sores or ulcers of the mouth, and ulcers of the skin at the corners of the mouth [(12)](#reference12). Specifically, the [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 19 [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials of B-vitamin supplementation failed to report any difference in several measures of cognitive function between treatment and placebo groups, despite the treatment effectively lowering homocysteine levels [(52)](#reference52). Nausea and vomiting in pregnancy (NVP), often referred to as morning sickness, can affect up to 85% of women during early pregnancy and usually lasts between 12 and 16 weeks [(73)](#reference73). Vitamin B6 has been used since the 1940s to treat nausea during pregnancy. Vitamin B6 was originally included in the medication Bendectin, which was prescribed for NVP treatment and later withdrawn from the market due to unproven concerns that it increased the risk for birth defects. Vitamin B6 itself is considered safe during pregnancy and has been used in pregnant women without any evidence of fetal harm [(74)](#reference74). The results of two [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials, including 401 pregnant women that used 25 mg of pyridoxine every eight hours for three days [(75)](#reference75) or 10 mg of pyridoxine every eight hours for five days [(76)](#reference76), suggested that vitamin B6 may be beneficial in reducing nausea. Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) causes numbness, pain, and weakness of the hand and fingers due to compression of the median nerve at the wrist. To prevent sensory neuropathy in virtually all individuals, the Food and Nutrition Board of the Institute of Medicine set the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for pyridoxine at 100 mg/day for adults (Table 3) [(14)](#reference14). In the NHANES 2003-2004 analysis, significantly more current and past users of oral contraceptives (OCs) among [menstruating](../glossary#menstruation) women had low [plasma](../glossary#plasma) PLP levels compared to women who have never used OCs, suggesting that the [estrogen](../glossary#estrogen) content of OCs may interfere with vitamin B6 metabolism (see [Side effects of oral contraceptives](#side-effects-oral-contraceptives)) [(88)](#reference88). and anti- [parkinsonian](../glossary#parkinson-disease) drugs like L-Dopa can all form complexes with vitamin B6 and limit its [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability), thus creating a functional deficiency. PLP bioavailability may also be reduced by methylxanthines, such as theophylline used to treat certain respiratory conditions [(7)](#reference7). The long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs; e.g. celecoxib and naproxen) may also impair vitamin B6 metabolism [(91)](#reference91). Conversely, high doses of vitamin B6 have been found to decrease the efficacy of two [anticonvulsants](../glossary#anticonvulsant), phenobarbital and phenytoin, and of L-Dopa [(6](#reference6), [90)](#reference90). Because of the [amino acid](../glossary#amino-acid) the tryptophan load test (an assay of tryptophan metabolites after an oral dose of tryptophan) has been used as a functional assessment of vitamin B6 status. Abnormal tryptophan load tests in women taking high-dose oral contraceptives (OCs) in the 1960s and 1970s suggested that these women were vitamin B6 deficient, which led to the prescription of high doses of vitamin B6 (100-150 mg/day) to women taking OCs. However, most other indices of vitamin B6 status were normal in women on high-dose OCs, and the [estrogen](../glossary#estrogen) content of OCs appeared to be more likely responsible for the abnormality in tryptophan metabolism [(88)](#reference88). Yet, more recently, the use of lower dose formulations has also been associated with vitamin B6 inadequacy [(88](#reference88), [92)](#reference92). Although it is not known whether OCs actually impair vitamin B6 metabolism or merely affect the tissue distribution of PLP, the use of OCs may place women at higher risk of vitamin B6 deficiency when they discontinue OCs and become pregnant [(93)](#reference93). Whether OC users are at higher risk of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) despite normal [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) levels also needs to be determined. Finally, although high doses of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) have demonstrated no benefit in preventing the risk of side effects from OCs [(94)](#reference94), the use of vitamin B6 supplements may be warranted in current and past OC users. The Linus Pauling Institute supports the [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for vitamin B6. LPI recommends that all adults take a daily [multivitamin/mineral supplement](../micronutrients-health/multivitamin-mineral-supplements), which usually contains at least 2 mg of vitamin B6. This amount is slightly above the RDA but still 50 times lower than the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) set by the Food and Nutrition Board (see [Safety](#safety)). Early metabolic studies have indicated that the requirement for vitamin B6 in older adults is approximately 2 mg daily [(95)](#reference95). Yet, the analysis of the US population survey (NHANES) 2003-2004 showed that adequate vitamin B6 status and low [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) levels were associated with total vitamin B6 intakes equal to and above 3 mg/day in people aged 65 years and older [(88)](#reference88). The Linus Pauling Institute recommends that older adults take a [multivitamin/mineral supplement](../micronutrients-health/multivitamin-mineral-supplements), which provides at least 2.0 mg of vitamin B6 daily.
