J Nutr. 1991;121(7):1062-1074. ] [(PubMed)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2051226) Contents Vitamin B12 has the largest and most complex chemical structure of all the [vitamins](../glossary#vitamin). It is unique among vitamins in that it contains a metal [ion](../glossary#ion), cobalt. For this reason cobalamin is the term used to refer to compounds having vitamin B12 activity. Methylcobalamin and 5-deoxyadenosylcobalamin are the forms of vitamin B12 used in the human body [(1)](#references). The form of cobalamin used in most nutritional supplements and fortified foods, cyanocobalamin, is readily converted to 5-deoxyadenosylcobalamin and methylcobalamin in the body. In mammals, cobalamin is a [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) for only L-methylmalonyl-coenzyme A mutase [(2)](#reference2). the folate-dependent [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme), methionine synthase. This enzyme [amino acid](../glossary#amino-acid), [methionine](../glossary#methionine), from [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine). Methionine in turn is required for the synthesis of S-adenosylmethionine, a methyl group donor used in many biological [methylation](../glossary#methylation) reactions, including the methylation of a number [DNA](../glossary#DNA), [RNA](../glossary#RNA), and [proteins](../glossary#protein) [(3)](#reference3). Aberrant methylation of DNA and which causes alterations in [chromatin](../glossary#chromatin) structure and [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression), are a common feature of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) cells. Inadequate function of methionine synthase can lead to an accumulation of homocysteine, which has been associated with increased risk of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) (Figure 1). 5-Deoxyadenosylcobalamin is required by the [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) that [catalyzes](../glossary#catalyze) the conversion of L-methylmalonyl-coenzyme A to succinyl-coenzyme A (succinyl-CoA), which then enters the [citric acid cycle](../glossary#citric-acid-cycle) (Figure 2). Succinyl-CoA plays an important role in the production of energy from [lipids](../glossary#lipid) and [proteins](../glossary#protein) and is also required for the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin), the oxygen-carrying pigment in red blood cells [(3)](#reference3). In healthy adults, vitamin B12 deficiency is uncommon, mainly because total body stores can exceed 2,500 g, daily turnover is slow, and dietary intake of only 2.4 g/day is sufficient to maintain adequate vitamin B12 status (see [RDA](#RDA)) [(4)](#reference4). In elderly individuals, vitamin B12 deficiency is more common mainly because of impaired intestinal absorption that can result in marginal to severe vitamin B12 deficiency in this population. Intestinal [malabsorption](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome), rather than inadequate dietary intake, can explain most cases of vitamin B12 deficiency [(5)](#reference5). Absorption of vitamin B12 from food requires normal function of the stomach, [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas), and [small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine). Stomach acid and [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) free vitamin B12 from food, allowing it to bind to R-protein (also known as transcobalamin-1 or haptocorrin), found in saliva and [gastric](../glossary#gastric) fluids. In the [alkaline](../glossary#alkaline) environment of the small intestine, R-proteins are degraded by pancreatic enzymes, freeing vitamin B12 to bind to intrinsic factor (IF), a protein secreted by specialized cells in the stomach. [Receptors](../glossary#receptor) on the surface of the ileum (final part of the small intestine) take up the IF-B12 complex only in the presence of calcium, which is supplied by the pancreas [(5)](#reference5). Vitamin B12 can also be absorbed by passive diffusion, but this process is very inefficient—only about 1% absorption of the vitamin B12 dose is absorbed passively [(2)](#reference2). The prevalent causes of vitamin B12 deficiency are (1) an [autoimmune](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) condition known as [pernicious anemia](../glossary#pernicious-anemia), and (2) a disorder called food-bound vitamin B12 malabsorption. Both conditions have been associated with a chronic [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) disease of the stomach known as [atrophic gastritis](../glossary#atrophic-gastritis). [Atrophic gastritis](../glossary#atrophic-gastritis) is thought to affect 10%-30% of people over 60 years of age [(6)](#reference6). The condition is frequently associated with the presence of autoantibodies directed toward stomach cells (see [Pernicious anemia](#pernicious-anemia)) and/or infection the [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria), Helicobacter [(7)](#reference7). H. pylori infection induces chronic [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) of the which may to [peptic ulcer disease](../glossary#peptic-ulcer-disease), atrophic gastritis, and/or [gastric](../glossary#gastric) [cancer](../glossary#cancer) in Diminished gastric function in individuals with atrophic gastritis can result in bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine and cause food-bound vitamin B12 malabsorption. Vitamin B12 levels in [serum](../glossary#serum), [plasma](../glossary#plasma), and gastric fluids are significantly decreased in individuals with H. pylori infection, and eradication of the bacteria has been shown to significantly improve vitamin B12 serum concentrations [(8)](#reference8). [Pernicious anemia](../glossary#pernicious-anemia) has been estimated to be present in approximately 2% of individuals over 60 years of age [(9)](#reference9). Although [anemia](../glossary#anemia) is often a symptom, the condition is actually the end stage of an [autoimmune](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) of the stomach known as autoimmune [atrophic gastritis](../glossary#atrophic-gastritis), resulting in destruction of stomach cells by one's own [antibodies](../glossary#antibody) (autoantibodies). Progressive destruction of the cells that line the stomach causes decreased secretion of acid and [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) required to release food-bound vitamin B12. Antibodies to intrinsic factor (IF) bind to IF preventing formation of the IF-B12 complex, further inhibiting vitamin B12 absorption. About 20% of the relatives of pernicious anemia patients also have the condition, suggesting a genetic predisposition. It is also thought that H. pylori infection could be involved in initiating the autoimmune response in a subset of individuals [(10)](#reference10). Further, co-occurrence of autoimmune atrophic gastritis with other autoimmune conditions, especially autoimmune thyroiditis and type 1 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), has been reported [(11, 12)](#reference11). Treatment of pernicious anemia generally requires injections of vitamin B12 to bypass intestinal absorption. High-dose oral supplementation is another treatment option, because consuming 1,000 g (1 mg)/day of vitamin B12 orally should result in the absorption of about 10 g/day (1% of dose) by passive diffusion. In fact, high-dose oral therapy is considered to be as effective as intramuscular injection [(4)](#reference4). Food-bound vitamin B12 [malabsorption](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome) is defined as an impaired ability to absorb food- or [protein](../glossary#protein)-bound vitamin B12; individuals with this condition can fully absorb the free form [(13)](#reference13). While the condition is the major cause of poor vitamin B12 status in the elderly population, it is usually associated with [atrophic gastritis](../glossary#atrophic-gastritis), a chronic [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) of the lining of the stomach that ultimately results in the loss of glands in the stomach ( [atrophy](../glossary#atrophy)) and decreased stomach acid production (see [Atrophic gastritis](#atrophic-gastritis)). Because stomach acid is required for the release of vitamin B12 from the proteins in food, vitamin B12 absorption is diminished. Decreased stomach acid production also provides an environment conducive to the overgrowth of [anaerobic](../glossary#anaerobic) [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria) in the stomach, which further interferes with vitamin B12 absorption [(3)](#reference3). Because vitamin B12 in [supplements](../glossary#supplement) is not bound to protein, and because intrinsic factor (IF) is still available, the absorption of supplemental vitamin B12 is not reduced as it is in [pernicious anemia](../glossary#pernicious-anemia). Thus, individuals with food-bound vitamin B12 malabsorption do not have an increased requirement for vitamin B12; they simply need it in the crystalline form found in [fortified](../glossary#fortification) foods and dietary supplements. Other causes of vitamin B12 deficiency include surgical resection of the stomach or portions of the [small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine) where [receptors](../glossary#receptor) for the IF-B12 complex are located. Conditions affecting the small intestine, such as [malabsorption syndromes](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome) ( [celiac disease](../glossary#celiac-disease) and tropical sprue), may also result in vitamin B12 deficiency. Because the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas) provides critical [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme), as well as calcium required for vitamin B12 absorption, pancreatic insufficiency may contribute to vitamin B12 deficiency. Since vitamin B12 is found only in foods of animal origin, a strict vegetarian (vegan) diet has resulted in cases of vitamin B12 deficiency. Moreover, alcoholics may experience reduced intestinal absorption of vitamin B12 [(2)](#reference2), and individuals with [acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)](../glossary#AIDS) appear to be at increased risk of deficiency, possibly related to a failure of the IF-B12 receptor to take up the IF-B12 complex [(3)](#reference3). Further, long-term use of acid-reducing drugs has also been implicated in vitamin B12 deficiency (see [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions)). Rare cases of inborn errors of vitamin B12 [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) have been reported in the literature (reviewed in [5](#reference5)). Imerslund-Gräsbeck syndrome is an inherited vitamin B12 [malabsorption syndrome](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome) that causes [megaloblastic anemia](../glossary#megaloblastic-anemia) and [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) disorders of variable severity in affected subjects. Similar clinical symptoms are found in individuals with hereditary IF deficiency (also called congenital pernicious anemia) in whom the lack of IF results in the defective absorption of vitamin B12. Additionally, [mutations](../glossary#mutation) affecting vitamin B12 transport in the body have been identified [(14)](#reference14). Vitamin B12 deficiency results in impairment of the activities of vitamin B12-requiring [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme). Impaired activity of methionine synthase results in elevated [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) levels, while impaired activity of L-methylmalonyl-CoA mutase results in increased levels of a [metabolite](../glossary#metabolite) of methylmalonyl-CoA called methylmalonic acid (MMA). While individuals with mild vitamin B12 deficiency may not experience symptoms, blood levels of homocysteine and/or MMA may be elevated [(15)](#reference15). Diminished activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency inhibits the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate (THF) and traps [folate](../vitamins/folate) in a form that is not usable by the body (Figure 3), resulting in symptoms of folate deficiency even in the presence of adequate folate levels. Thus, in both folate and vitamin B12 deficiencies, folate is unavailable to participate in [DNA](../glossary#DNA) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis). This impairment of DNA synthesis affects the rapidly dividing cells of the bone marrow earlier than other cells, resulting in the production of large, immature, [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin)-poor red blood cells. The resulting [anemia](../glossary#anemia) is known as [megaloblastic anemia](../glossary#megaloblastic-anemia) and is the symptom for which the disease, [pernicious anemia](../glossary#pernicious-anemia), was named [(3)](#reference3). Supplementation with folic acid will provide enough usable folate to restore normal red blood cell formation. However, if vitamin B12 deficiency is the cause, it will persist despite the resolution of the anemia. Thus, megaloblastic anemia should not be treated with folic acid until the underlying cause has been determined [(16)](#reference16). The [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency include numbness and tingling of the hands and, more commonly, the feet; difficulty walking; memory loss; disorientation; and [dementia](../glossary#dementia) with or without mood changes. Although the progression of neurologic complications is generally gradual, such symptoms may not be reversed with treatment of vitamin B12 deficiency, especially if they have been present for a long time. Neurologic complications are not always associated with [megaloblastic anemia](../glossary#megaloblastic-anemia) and are the only clinical symptom of vitamin B12 deficiency in about 25% of cases [(17)](#reference17). Although vitamin B12 deficiency is known to damage the [myelin](../glossary#myelin) sheath covering cranial, spinal, and peripheral nerves, the biochemical processes leading to neurological damage in vitamin B12 deficiency are not yet fully understood [(18)](#reference18). Tongue soreness, appetite loss, and constipation have also been associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. The origins of these symptoms are unclear, but they may be related to the stomach [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) underlying some cases of vitamin B12 deficiency and to the progressive destruction of the lining of the stomach [(17)](#reference17). The [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for vitamin B12 was revised by the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the US Institute of Medicine in 1998 (Table 1). Because of the increased risk of food-bound vitamin B12 [malabsorption](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome) in older adults, the FNB recommended that adults over 50 years of age get most of the RDA from [fortified](../glossary#fortification) food or chronic [atrophic gastritis](../glossary#atrophic-gastritis) and infection by H. pylori can cause deficiency in vitamin B12 secondary to [malabsorption](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome) disorders (see [Causes of vitamin B12 deficiency](#deficiency-causes)). However, the occurrence of H. pylori infection and chronic atrophic gastritis did not modify the incidence of [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) accidents ( [stroke](../glossary#stroke) and [heart attack](../glossary#myocardial-infarction)) or mortality in a large cohort study of nearly 10,000 men and women over 50 years old [(19)](#reference19). Yet, vitamin B12 status was not assessed in this study, despite the high prevalence of vitamin B12 deficiency in older individuals. [Epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study) indicate that even moderately elevated levels of [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) in the blood raise the risk of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) (CVD) [(20)](#reference20), though the mechanism by which homocysteine may increase the CVD risk remains the subject of a great deal of research [(21)](#reference21). The amount of homocysteine in the blood is regulated by at least three vitamins: [folate](../vitamins/folate), [vitamin B6](../vitamins/vitamin-B6), and vitamin B12 (see [Figure 1](#figure-1) above). An early analysis of the results of 12 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) showed that folic acid supplementation (0.5-5 mg/day) had the lowering blood homocysteine levels (25% decrease); co-supplementation with folic acid and (500 g/day) provided an additional 7% reduction (32% decrease) in blood homocysteine concentrations [(22)](#reference22). The results of a sequential supplementation trial in 53 men and women indicated that after folic acid supplementation, vitamin B12 became the major determinant of [plasma](../glossary#plasma) homocysteine levels [(23)](#reference23). It is thought that the elevation of homocysteine levels might be partly due to vitamin B12 deficiency in individuals over 60 years of age. Two studies found blood methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels to be elevated in more than 60% of elderly individuals with elevated homocysteine levels. In the absence of impaired kidney function, an elevated MMA level in conjunction with elevated homocysteine suggests either a vitamin B12 deficiency or a combined vitamin B12 and folate deficiency [(24)](#reference24). Thus, it appears important to evaluate vitamin B12 status, as well as kidney function, in older individuals with elevated homocysteine levels prior to initiating homocysteine-lowering therapy. For more information regarding homocysteine and CVD, see the article on [Folate](folate#homocysteine). Although increased intake of folic acid and vitamin B12 is effective in decreasing [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) levels, the combined intervention of these B vitamins did not lower risk for [CVD](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease). Indeed, several [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials have been conducted to determine whether homocysteine-lowering through folic acid, vitamin B12, and vitamin B6 supplementation reduces the incidence of CVD. A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of data from 11 trials, including nearly 45,000 participants at risk of CVD, showed that B-vitamin supplementation had no significant effect on risk of [myocardial infarction](../glossary#myocardial-infarction) (heart attack) or [stroke](../glossary#stroke), nor did it modify the risk of all-cause mortality [(25)](#reference25). Other meta-analyses that included patients with chronic kidney disease have confirmed the lack of effect of homocysteine-lowering on risk of myocardial infarction and death. However, stroke risk was significantly reduced by 7%-12% with the B-vitamin supplementation (FMD; a surrogate marker of vascular health) in response to homocysteine reduction revealed that B-vitamin supplementation was accompanied by an improved FMD in short-term <8 weeks) but not in long-term studies conducted in subjects with preexisting vascular diseases [(28)](#reference28). Yet, some of the studies included in these meta-analyses did not use vitamin B12, and folate administration on its own has shown a protective role on vascular function and stroke risk [(29)](#reference29). Besides, the high prevalence of [malabsorption disorders](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome) and vitamin B12 deficiency in elderly individuals might warrant the use of higher doses of vitamin B12 than those used in these trials [(30)](#reference30); in cases of malabsorption, only high-dose oral therapy or intramuscular injections can overcome vitamin B12 deficiency [(4)](#reference4). [Folate](../vitamins/folate) is required for [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of [DNA](../glossary#DNA), and there is evidence that decreased availability of folate results in strands of DNA that are more susceptible to damage. Deficiency of vitamin B12 traps folate in a form that is unusable by the body for DNA synthesis. Both vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies result in a diminished capacity for [methylation](../glossary#methylation) reactions (see [Figure 3](#figure-3) above). Thus, vitamin B12 deficiency may lead to an elevated rate of DNA damage and altered methylation of DNA, both of which are important risk factors for [cancer](../glossary#cancer). A series of studies in young adults and older men indicated that increased levels of [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) and decreased levels of vitamin B12 in the blood were associated with a [biomarker](../glossary#biomarker) of [chromosome](../glossary#chromosome) breakage in white blood cells (reviewed in [31](#reference31)). In a [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study, the same biomarker of chromosome breakage was minimized in young adults who were supplemented with 700 g of folic acid and 7 g of vitamin B12 daily in cereal for two months [(32)](#reference32). A compared B6](../vitamins/vitamin-B6), and vitamin B12 in 195 women later diagnosed with breast [cancer](../glossary#cancer) and 195 age-matched, cancer-free women. Among postmenopausal women, the association between blood levels of vitamin B12 and breast cancer suggested a [threshold](../glossary#threshold) effect. The risk of breast cancer was more than doubled in women with [serum](../glossary#serum) vitamin B12 levels in the lowest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) compared to women in the four highest quintiles [(33)](#reference33). However, the [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of this study with three additional case-control studies found no protection associated with high compared to low vitamin B12 serum levels [(34)](#reference34). A case-control study in Mexican women (475 cases and 1,391 controls) reported that breast cancer risk for women in the highest quartile of vitamin B12 intake (7.3-7.7 g/day) was 68% lower than those in the lowest quartile (2.6 g/day). Stratification of the data revealed that the inverse association between dietary vitamin B12 intake and breast cancer risk was stronger in postmenopausal women compared to premenopausal women, though both associations were statistically significant. Moreover, among postmenopausal women, the apparent protection conferred by folate was only observed in women with the highest vitamin B12 quartiles of intake [(35)](#reference35). However, more recent case-control and [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have reported weak to no risk reduction with vitamin B12 intakes in different populations, including Hispanic, African American and European American women [(36, 37)](#reference36). A meta-analysis of seven case-control and seven prospective cohort studies concluded that the risk of breast cancer was not modified by high versus low vitamin B12 intakes [(34)](#reference34). There was no joint association between folate and vitamin B12 intakes and breast cancer risk. Presently, there is little evidence to suggest a relationship between vitamin B12 [status](../glossary#status) and breast cancer. In addition, results from [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) are not consistently in support of an association between high dietary folate intakes and reduced risk for breast cancer (see the article on [Folate](folate#breast-cancer-prevention)). There is a need to evaluate the effect of folate and vitamin B12 supplementation in well-controlled, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial), while considering various factors that modify breast cancer risk, such as menopausal status, ethnicity, and alcohol intake. [Neural tube defects](../glossary#neural-tube-defect) (NTD) may result in [anencephaly](../glossary#anencephaly) or [spina bifida](../glossary#spina-bifida), which are mostly fatal [congenital malformations](../glossary#congenital-malformation) of the [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system). The defects arise from failure of embryonic neural tube to close, which occurs between the 21st and 28th days after conception, a time when many women are unaware of their pregnancy [(38)](#reference38). [Randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have demonstrated 60% to 100% reductions in NTD cases when women consumed folic acid supplements in addition to a varied diet during the month before and the month after conception. Increasing evidence indicates that the [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine)-lowering effect of folic acid plays a critical role in reducing the risk of NTD [(39)](#reference39). Homocysteine may accumulate in the blood when there is inadequate folate and/or vitamin B12 for effective functioning of the methionine synthase [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme). Decreased vitamin B12 levels and elevated homocysteine concentrations have been found in the blood and amniotic fluid of pregnant women at high risk of NTD [(40)](#reference40). The recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 12 [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study), including 567 mothers with current or prior NTD-affected pregnancy and 1,566 unaffected mothers, showed that low maternal vitamin B12 status was associated with an increased risk of NTD [(41)](#reference41). Yet, whether vitamin B12 supplementation may be beneficial in the prevention of NTD has not been evaluated [(42)](#reference42). The occurrence of vitamin B12 deficiency prevails in the elderly population and has been frequently associated with [Alzheimer's disease](../glossary#alzheimer-disease) (reviewed in [43](#reference43)). One study found lower vitamin B12 levels in the [cerebrospinal fluid](../glossary#cerebrospinal-fluid) of patients with Alzheimer's disease than in patients with other types of [dementia](../glossary#dementia), though blood levels of vitamin B12 did not differ [(44)](#reference44). The reason for the association of low vitamin B12 status with Alzheimer's disease is not clear. Vitamin B12 deficiency, like [folate](../vitamins/folate) deficiency, may lead to decreased [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of [methionine](../glossary#methionine) and S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), thereby adversely affecting [methylation](../glossary#methylation) reactions. Methylation reactions are essential for the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of components of the [myelin](../glossary#myelin) sheath of nerve cells as well as for synthesis of [neurotransmitters](../glossary#neurotransmitter) [(18)](#reference18). Other metabolic implications of vitamin B12 deficiency include the accumulation of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid, which might contribute to the neuropathologic features of dementia [(43)](#reference43). A large majority of [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) and [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have associated elevated [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) concentrations with measures of poor [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) scores and increased risk of [dementia](../glossary#dementia), including [Alzheimer's disease](../glossary#alzheimer-disease) (reviewed in [45](#reference45)). A [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) of 164 patients with dementia of Alzheimer's type included 76 cases in which the diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease was confirmed by examination of brain cells after death. Compared to 108 control subjects without evidence of dementia, subjects with dementia of Alzheimer's type and confirmed Alzheimer's disease had higher blood homocysteine levels and lower blood levels of folate and vitamin B12. Measures of general nutritional status indicated that the association of increased homocysteine levels and diminished vitamin B12 status with Alzheimer's disease was not due to dementia-related malnutrition [(46)](#reference46). In a sample of 1,092 men and women without dementia followed for an average of 10 years, those with higher [plasma](../glossary#plasma) homocysteine levels at baseline had a significantly higher risk of developing Alzheimer's disease and other types of dementia. Specifically, those with plasma homocysteine levels greater than 14 mol/L had nearly double the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease [(47)](#reference47). A study in 650 elderly men and women reported that the risk of elevated plasma homocysteine levels was significantly higher in those with lower cognitive function scores [(48)](#reference48). A prospective study in 816 elderly men and women reported that those with [hyperhomocysteinemia](../glossary#hyperhomocysteinemia) (homocysteine levels >15 mol/L) had a significantly higher risk of developing Alzheimer's disease or dementia. Although raised homocysteine levels might be partly due to a poor vitamin B12 status, the latter was not related to risk of Alzheimer's disease or dementia in this study [(49)](#reference49). A recent [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) of 35 prospective cohort studies assessing the association between vitamin B12 status and cognitive deterioration in older individuals with or without dementia at baseline did not support a relationship between vitamin B12 serum concentrations and cognitive decline, dementia, or Alzheimer's disease [(50)](#reference50). Nevertheless, studies utilizing more sensitive [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) of vitamin B12 [status](../glossary#status), including measures of holo-transcobalamin (holo-TC; a vitamin B12 carrier) and methylmalonic acid, showed more consistent results and a trend toward associations between poor vitamin B12 status and faster cognitive decline and risk of Alzheimer's disease [(51-55)](#reference51). Besides, it cannot be excluded that the co-occurrence of potential confounders like elevated homocysteine level and poor folate status might mitigate the true contribution of vitamin B12 status to cognitive functioning [(45)](#reference45). High-dose B-vitamin supplementation has been proven effective for treating [hyperhomocysteinemia](../glossary#hyperhomocysteinemia) in elderly individuals with or without [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) impairment. However, [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine)-lowering trials have produced equivocal results regarding the prevention of cognitive deterioration in this population. A [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 18 [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials examining the effect of B-vitamin supplementation did not find that the decrease in homocysteine level prevented or delayed cognitive decline among older subjects [(56)](#reference56). A more recent randomized, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), placebo-controlled clinical trial in 900 older individuals at high risk of cognitive impairment found that daily supplementation of 400 g of folic acid and 100 g of vitamin B12 for two years significantly improved measures of immediate and delayed memory and slowed the rise in [plasma](../glossary#plasma) homocysteine concentrations [(57)](#reference57). However, supplemented subjects had no reduction in homocysteine concentrations compared to baseline, nor did they perform better in processing speed tests compared to placebo. Another two-year, randomized, placebo-controlled study in elderly adults reported that a daily regimen of 800 g of folic acid, 500 g of vitamin B12, and 20 mg of vitamin B6 significantly reduced the rate of brain [atrophy](../glossary#atrophy) compared to placebo treatment (0.5% vs. 3.7%). Interestingly, a greater benefit was seen in those with high compared to low homocysteine concentrations at baseline, suggesting the importance of lowering homocysteine levels in prevention of brain atrophy and cognitive decline [(58, 59)](#reference58). The authors attributed the changes in homocysteine levels primarily to vitamin B12 [(59)](#reference59). Finally, the most recent randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled trial in over 2,500 individuals who suffered a [stroke](../glossary#stroke) showed that the normalization of homocysteine concentrations by B-vitamin supplementation (2 mg of folic acid, 500 g of vitamin B12, and 25 mg of vitamin B6) did not improve cognitive performance or decrease incidence of cognitive decline compared to placebo [(60)](#reference60). Currently, there is a need for larger trials to evaluate the effect of B-vitamin supplementation on long-term outcomes, such as the incidence of [Alzheimer's disease](../glossary#alzheimer-disease). [Observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have found as many as 30% of patients hospitalized for depression are deficient in vitamin B12 [(61)](#reference61). A [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) of 700 community-living, physically disabled women over the age of 65 found that vitamin B12-deficient women were twice as likely to be severely depressed as non-deficient women [(62)](#reference62). A population-based study in 3,884 elderly men and women with depressive disorders found that those with vitamin B12 deficiency were almost 70% more likely to experience depression than those with normal vitamin B12 [status](../glossary#status) [(63)](#reference63). The reasons for the relationship between vitamin B12 deficiency and depression are not clear but may involve a shortage in S-adenosylmethionine (SAM). SAM is a methyl group donor for numerous [methylation](../glossary#methylation) reactions in the brain, including those involved in the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of [neurotransmitters](../glossary#neurotransmitter) whose deficiency has been related to depression [(64)](#reference64). Severe vitamin B12 deficiency in a mouse model showed dramatic alterations in the level of [DNA](../glossary#DNA) methylation in the brain, which might lead to [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) impairments [(65)](#reference65). This hypothesis is supported by several studies that have shown supplementation with SAM improves depressive symptoms [(66-69)](#reference66). Increased [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) level is another nonspecific [biomarker](../glossary#biomarker) of vitamin B12 deficiency that has been linked to depressive symptoms in the elderly [(70)](#reference70). However, in a recent cross-sectional study conducted in 1,677 older individuals, higher vitamin B12 [plasma](../glossary#plasma) levels, but not changes in homocysteine concentrations, were correlated with a lower prevalence of depressive symptoms [(71)](#reference71). Few studies have examined the relationship of vitamin B12 status, homocysteine levels, and the development of depression over time. In a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled, [intervention study](../glossary#intervention-trial) with over 900 older participants experiencing psychological distress, daily supplementation with folic acid (400 g) and vitamin B12 (100 g) for two years did not reduce the occurrence of symptoms of depression despite significantly improving blood folate, vitamin B12, and homocysteine levels compared to placebo [(72)](#reference72). However, in a long-term randomized, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), placebo-controlled study among sufferers of cerebrovascular accidents at high risk of depression, daily supplementation with 2 mg of folic acid, 25 mg of vitamin B6, and 500 g vitamin B12 significantly lowered the risk of major depressive episodes during a seven-year follow-up period compared to placebo [(73)](#reference73). Although it cannot yet be determined whether vitamin B12 deficiency plays a causal role in depression, it may be beneficial to screen for vitamin B12 deficiency in older individuals as part of a medical evaluation for depression. High [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) levels may affect [bone remodeling](../glossary#bone-remodeling) by increasing bone [resorption](../glossary#resorption) (breakdown), decreasing bone formation, and reducing bone blood flow. Another proposed mechanism involves the binding of homocysteine to the [collagenous matrix](../glossary#collagenous-matrix) of bone, which may modify [collagen](../glossary#collagen) properties and reduce bone strength (reviewed in [74](#reference74)). Alterations of bone biomechanical properties can contribute to [osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis) and increase the risk of [fractures](../glossary#fracture) in the elderly. Since vitamin B12 is a determinant of homocysteine metabolism, it was suggested that the risk of osteoporotic fractures in older subjects might be enhanced by vitamin B12 deficiency. A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of four [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study), following a total of 7,475 older individuals for 3 to 16 years, found a weak association between an elevation in vitamin B12 of 50 picomoles/L in blood and a reduction in fracture risk [(75)](#reference75). A [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 559 elderly individuals with low [serum](../glossary#serum) levels of folate and vitamin B12 and at increased risk of fracture evaluated the combined supplementation of very high doses of folic acid (5 mg/day) and vitamin B12 (1.5 mg/day). The two-year study found that the supplementation improved B-vitamin status, decreased homocysteine concentrations, and reduced risk of total fractures compared to placebo [(76)](#reference76). However, a multicenter study in 5,485 subjects with [cardiovascular or [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) showed that daily supplementation with folic acid (2.5 mg), vitamin B12 (1 mg), and vitamin B6 (50 mg) lowered homocysteine concentrations but had no effect on fracture risk compared to placebo [(77)](#reference77). Another small, randomized, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind) trial in 93 individuals with low vitamin D status found no additional benefit of B-vitamin supplementation (50 mg/day of vitamin B6, 0.5 mg/day of folic acid, and 0.5 mg/day of vitamin B12) on markers of bone health over a one-year period beyond that associated with vitamin D and calcium supplementation. Yet, the short length of the study did not permit a conclusion on whether the lowering of homocysteine through B-vitamin supplementation could have long-term benefits on bone strength and fracture risk [(78)](#reference78). A large [intervention study](../glossary#intervention-trial) conducted in older people with no preexisting conditions is under way to evaluate the effect of B-vitamin supplementation on markers of bone health and incidence of fracture; this trial might clarify whether B vitamins could have a protective effect on bone health in the elderly population [(79)](#reference79). Only [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria) can [synthesize](../glossary#synthesis) vitamin B12 [(80)](#reference80). Vitamin B12 is present in animal products, such as meat, poultry, fish (including shellfish), and to a lesser extent dairy products and eggs [(1)](#references). Fresh pasteurized milk contains 0.9 g per cup and is an important source of vitamin B12 for some vegetarians [(17)](#reference17). Those strict vegetarians who eat no animal products (vegans) need [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) vitamin B12 to meet their requirements. Recent analyses revealed that some plant-source foods, such as certain fermented beans and vegetables and edible algae and mushrooms, contain substantial amounts of bioactive vitamin B12 [(81)](#reference81). Together with B-vitamin [fortified](../glossary#fortification) food and supplements, these foods may contribute, though modestly, to prevent vitamin B12 deficiency in individuals consuming vegetarian diets. Also, individuals over the age of 50 should obtain their vitamin B12 in supplements or fortified foods (e.g., fortified cereals) because of the increased likelihood of food-bound vitamin B12 malabsorption with increasing age. Most people do not have a problem obtaining the [RDA](../glossary#RDA) of 2.4 g/day of vitamin B12 in food. According to a US national survey, the average dietary intake of vitamin B12 is 5.4 g/day for adult men and 3.4 g/day for adult women. Adults over the age of 60 had an average dietary intake of 4.8 g/day [(42)](#reference42). However, consumption of any type of vegetarian diet dramatically increases the prevalence of vitamin B12 deficiency in individuals across all age groups [(82)](#reference82). For more information on the nutrient content of three-ounce serving of meat or fish is about the size of a deck of cards.| Cyanocobalamin is the principal form of vitamin B12 used in oral [supplements](../glossary#supplement), but methylcobalamin is also available as a supplement. Cyanocobalamin is available by prescription in an injectable form and as a nasal gel for the treatment of [pernicious anemia](../glossary#pernicious-anemia). Over-the-counter preparations containing cyanocobalamin include and single-nutrient, vitamin B12 supplements [(83)](#reference83). No toxic or adverse effects have been associated with large intakes of vitamin B12 from food or supplements in healthy people. Doses as high as 2 mg (2,000 g) daily by mouth or 1 mg monthly by intramuscular (IM) injection have been used to treat [pernicious anemia](../glossary#pernicious-anemia) without significant side effects [(84)](#reference84). When high doses of vitamin B12 are given orally, only a small percentage can be absorbed, which may explain the low toxicity [(4)](#reference4). Because of the low toxicity of vitamin B12, no tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) has been set by the US Food and Nutrition Board [(17)](#reference17). A number of drugs reduce the absorption of vitamin B12. Proton-pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole and lansoprazole), used for therapy of [Zollinger-Ellison syndrome](../glossary#Zollinger-Ellison-syndrome) and [gastroesophageal reflux disease](../glossary#gastroesophageal-reflux-disease) (GERD), markedly decrease stomach acid secretion required for the release of vitamin B12 from food but not from [supplements](../glossary#supplement). Long-term use of proton-pump inhibitors has been found to decrease blood vitamin B12 levels. However, vitamin B12 deficiency does not generally develop until after at least three years of continuous therapy [(85, 86)](#reference85). Another class of gastric acid inhibitors known as histamine2 (H2)-receptor antagonists (e.g., cimetidine, famotidine, and ranitidine), often used to treat [peptic ulcer disease](../glossary#peptic-ulcer-disease), has also been found to decrease the absorption of vitamin B12 from food. It is not clear whether the long-term use of H2-receptor antagonists could cause overt vitamin B12 deficiency [(87, 88)](#reference87). Individuals taking drugs that inhibit [gastric](../glossary#gastric) acid secretion should consider taking vitamin B12 in the form of a supplement because gastric acid is not required for its absorption. Other drugs found to inhibit vitamin B12 absorption from food include cholestyramine (a [bile acid](../glossary#bile-acids)-binding resin used in the treatment of high [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol)), chloramphenicol and neomycin (antibiotics), and colchicine (medicine for [gout](../glossary#gout) treatment). Metformin, a medication for individuals with type 2 [diabetes](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), was found to decrease vitamin B12 absorption by tying up free calcium required for absorption of the IF-B12 complex [(89)](#reference89). However, the clinical significance of this is unclear [(90)](#reference90). It is not known whether calcium supplementation can reverse vitamin B12 malabsorption; therefore, calcium supplementation is not currently prescribed for the prevention or treatment of metformin-induced vitamin B12 deficiency [(91)](#reference91). Previous reports that megadoses of vitamin C destroy vitamin B12 have not been supported [(92)](#reference92) and may have been an artifact of the assay used to measure vitamin B12 levels [(17)](#reference17). Nitrous oxide, a commonly used anesthetic, oxidizes and inactivates vitamin B12, thus inhibiting both of the vitamin B12-dependent [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme), and can produce many of the clinical features of vitamin B12 deficiency, such as [megaloblastic anemia](../glossary#megaloblastic-anemia) or [neuropathy](../glossary#neuropathy). Since nitrous oxide is commonly used for surgery in the elderly, some experts feel vitamin B12 deficiency should be ruled out prior to its use [(6](#reference6), [15)](#reference15). Large doses of folic acid given to an individual with an undiagnosed vitamin B12 deficiency could correct megaloblastic anemia without correcting the underlying vitamin B12 deficiency, leaving the individual at risk of developing irreversible [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) damage [(17)](#reference17). For this reason, the Food and Nutrition Board of the US Institute of Medicine advises that all adults limit their intake of folic acid (supplements and [fortification](../glossary#fortification)) to 1,000 g (1 mg) daily. A varied diet should provide enough vitamin B12 to prevent deficiency in most individuals 50 years of age and younger. Strict vegetarians and women planning to become pregnant should take a multivitamin [supplement](../glossary#supplement) daily or eat [fortified](../glossary#fortification) cereal, which would ensure a daily intake of 6 to 30 g of vitamin B12 in a form that is easily absorbed. Higher doses of vitamin B12 supplements are recommended for patients taking medications that interfere with its absorption (see [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions)). Because vitamin B12 malabsorption and vitamin B12 deficiency are more common in older adults, the Linus Pauling Institute recommends that adults older than 50 years take 100 to 400 g/day of supplemental vitamin B12. Arch Intern Med. 1999;159(6):619-624. ] [(PubMed)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10090119) Contents Vitamin C (L-ascorbic acid) is a potent [reducing](../glossary#reduction) agent, meaning that it readily donates [electrons](../glossary#electron) to recipient molecules (Figure 1). Related to this [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation)-reduction ( [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction)) potential, two major functions of vitamin C are as an [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) and as an [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) [(1)](#references). Vitamin C is the primary water-soluble, non-enzymatic antioxidant in [plasma](../glossary#plasma) and tissues. Even in small amounts, vitamin C can protect indispensable molecules in the body, such as [proteins](../glossary#protein), [lipids](../glossary#lipid) (fats), [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate), and and [reactive oxygen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species) (ROS) that are generated during normal [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), by active immune cells, and through exposure to toxins and pollutants (e.g., certain [chemotherapy](../glossary#chemotherapy) drugs and cigarette smoke). Vitamin C also participates in redox recycling of other important antioxidants; for example, vitamin C is known to regenerate [vitamin E](vitamin-E) from its [oxidized](../glossary#oxidation) form (see the article on [Vitamin E](vitamin-E#nutrient-interactions-vitamin-C)). The role of vitamin C as a cofactor is also related to its redox potential. By maintaining enzyme-bound metals in their reduced forms, vitamin C assists mixed-function oxidases in the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of several critical biomolecules [(1)](#references). enzymes are either monooxygenases or dioxygenases (see [Table 1](#table-1)). Symptoms of vitamin C deficiency, such as poor wound healing and lethargy, likely result from the impairment of these vitamin C-dependent enzymatic reactions leading to the insufficient synthesis of [collagen](../glossary#collagen), [carnitine](../glossary#carnitine), and [catecholamines](../glossary#catecholamine) (see [Deficiency](#deficiency)). Moreover, several dioxygenases involved in the regulation of gene expression and the maintenance of genome integrity require vitamin C as a cofactor. Indeed, research has recently uncovered the crucial role played by enzymes, such as the TET dioxygenases and Jumonji domain-containing [histone](../glossary#histone) demethylases, in the fate of cells and tissues (see [Table 1](#table-1)). These enzymes contribute to the epigenetic regulation of gene expression by catalyzing reactions involved in the demethylation whereas dioxygenases catalyze a reaction that couples the hydroxylation of a specific substrate with the conversion (decarboxylation) of -ketoglutarate into succinate.| The capacity of vitamin C to influence the [methylation](../glossary#methylation) status of DNA and histones in mammalian cells supports a role for the vitamin in health and disease beyond what was previously understood, in particular by safeguarding genome integrity [(3, 4)](#reference3). Vitamin C affects several components of the human immune system [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro); for example, vitamin C has been shown to stimulate both the production [(5-9)](#reference5) and function [(10, 11)](#reference10) of [leukocytes](../glossary#leukocyte) (white blood cells), especially [neutrophils](../glossary#neutrophil), [lymphocytes](../glossary#lymphocyte), and [phagocytes](../glossary#phagocyte). Specific measures of functions stimulated by vitamin C include accumulate vitamin C to high concentrations, which can protect these cell types from [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) [(12-14)](#reference12). In response to invading microorganisms, such these [reactive oxygen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species) kill [pathogens](../glossary#pathogen) and, in the process, can damage the leukocytes themselves [(15)](#reference15). Vitamin C, through its [antioxidant ](../glossary#antioxidant)functions, has been shown protect leukocytes from self-inflicted damage [(14)](#reference14). Phagocytic leukocytes also produce release [cytokines](../glossary#cytokine), including interferons, which have antiviral activity [(16)](#reference16). Vitamin C has been shown to increase interferon production in vitro [(17)](#reference17). Additional studies have reported that vitamin C enhances the chemotactic and microbial killing capacities of neutrophils and stimulates the [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) and [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation) of B- and T-lymphocytes (reviewed in [18](#reference18)). It is widely thought by the general public that vitamin C boosts immune function, yet human studies published to date are conflicting. Disparate results are likely due to study design issues, often linked to a lack of understanding of vitamin C [pharmacokinetics](../glossary#pharmacokinetics) and requirements [(19, 20)](#reference19). Finally, vitamin C increases the [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of iron from foods by enhancing intestinal absorption of non- [heme](../glossary#heme) iron (see the article on [Iron](../minerals/iron#food-sources)) [(21)](#reference21). [Depletion-repletion](../glossary#depletion-repletion-study) [pharmacokinetic](../glossary#pharmacokinetics) experiments demonstrated that [plasma](../glossary#plasma) vitamin C concentration is tightly controlled by three primary mechanisms: intestinal absorption, tissue transport, and [renal](../glossary#renal) reabsorption [(22)](#reference22). In response to increasing oral doses of vitamin C, plasma vitamin C concentration rises steeply at intakes between 30 and 100 mg/day. Plasma concentrations of ascorbate reach steady-state at concentrations between 60 and 80 micromoles/L (mol/L). This is typically observed at doses between 200 to 400 mg/day in healthy young adults, with some degree of individual variation [(23, 24)](#reference23). One hundred percent absorption efficiency is observed when ingesting vitamin C at doses up to 200 mg at a time. Higher doses (>500 mg) result in fractionally less vitamin C being absorbed as the dose increases. Once plasma vitamin C concentrations reach saturation, additional vitamin C is largely [excreted](../glossary#excretion) in the urine. Notably, [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) administration of vitamin C bypasses absorptive control in the intestine such that very high concentrations of vitamin C can be achieved in the plasma; within a few hours, renal excretion restores vitamin C to baseline plasma concentrations (see [Cancer Treatment](#cancer-treatment)) [(25)](#reference25). While plasma vitamin C concentration reflects recent dietary intake, [leukocyte](../glossary#leukocyte) (white blood cell) vitamin C is thought to be an indicator of body stores. However, leukocyte vitamin C concentration does not accurately reflect vitamin C in several tissues and may specifically underestimate vitamin C uptake into skeletal muscle [(26)](#reference26). Yet, plasma concentrations of vitamin C 50 mol/L are sufficient to saturate muscle tissue vitamin C. There is also some limited evidence suggesting that individuals who carry certain [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) in [genes](../glossary#gene) involved in vitamin C transport and detoxification mechanisms may have lower plasma vitamin C concentrations even with high vitamin C intakes (see also [Vascular complications of diabetes mellitus](#vascular-complications-diabetes-mellitus)) (reviewed in [27](#reference27)). Due to the pharmacokinetics and tight regulation of plasma vitamin C, supplementation with vitamin C will have variable effects in vitamin C- [replete](../glossary#replete) (plasma concentrations near saturation) versus sub-optimal (plasma concentrations <50 mol/L), marginally deficient (plasma concentrations <23 mol/L), or severely deficient (plasma concentrations <11 mol/L) individuals [(28)](#reference28). Scientific studies investigating vitamin C efficacy to prevent or treat disease need to assess baseline vitamin C [status](../glossary#status) before embarking on an intervention or statistical analysis [(22](#reference22), [29-31)](#reference29). For a more detailed discussion on the bioavailability of different forms of vitamin C, see the article, [The Bioavailability of Different Forms of Vitamin C](vitamin-C/supplemental-forms). Severe vitamin C deficiency has been known for many centuries as the potentially fatal disease, [scurvy](../glossary#scurvy). By the late 1700s, the British navy was aware that scurvy could be cured by eating oranges or lemons, even though vitamin C would not be isolated until the early 1930s. Symptoms of scurvy include [subcutaneous](../glossary#subcutaneous) bleeding, poor wound closure, and bruising easily, hair and tooth loss, and joint pain and swelling. Such symptoms appear to be related to the weakening of blood vessels, connective tissue, and bone, which all contain [collagen](../glossary#collagen). Early symptoms of scurvy like fatigue may result from diminished levels of [carnitine](../glossary#carnitine), which is needed to derive energy from fat, or from decreased [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of the [catecholamine](../glossary#catecholamine) norepinephrine (see [Function](#function)). Scurvy is rare in developed countries because it can be prevented by as little as 10 mg of vitamin C daily [(32)](#reference32). However, cases have occurred in children and the elderly on very restricted diets [(33, 34)](#reference33). The recommended dietary allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) for vitamin C is based on the amount of vitamin C intake necessary to maintain [neutrophil](../glossary#neutrophil) vitamin C concentration with minimal urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of vitamin C and is proposed to provide sufficient [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) protection (Table 2) [(35)](#reference35). The recommended intake for smokers is 35 mg/day higher than for nonsmokers, because smokers are under increased [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) from the toxins in cigarette smoke and generally have lower blood concentrations of vitamin C [(36)](#reference36). |Life Stage||Age||Males (mg/day)||Females (mg/day)| |Infants||0-6 months|| 40 ( | of vitamin C required to help prevent [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease) is higher than the amount required for prevention of [scurvy](../glossary#scurvy). Information regarding vitamin C and the prevention of chronic disease is based on both observational [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) and [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) [(29](#reference29), [37)](#reference37). Prospective cohort studies can examine the incidence of a specific disease in relation to vitamin C intake or body status in a cohort of participants who are followed over time. In contrast, trials are [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-study) that can establish a causal relationship between an exposure and an outcome, e.g., by evaluating the effect of vitamin C supplementation on the incidence of chronic disease in participants randomly assigned to receive either vitamin C or [placebo](../glossary#placebo) for a given length of time. [Endothelial](http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/glossary#vascular-endothelium) dysfunction is considered to be an early step in the development of [atherosclerosis](../health-disease/atherosclerosis). Alterations in the structure and function of the [vascular endothelium](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) that lines the inner surface of all blood vessels are associated with the loss of normal [nitric oxide](../glossary#nitric-oxide)-mediated endothelium-dependent [vasodilation](../glossary#vasodilation). Endothelial dysfunction results in widespread The measurement of brachial artery flow-mediated dilation (FMD) is often used as a marker of endothelial function; FMD values are [inversely correlated](../glossary#inverse-association) with [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events [(38)](#reference38). A 2014 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 44 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in subjects with or without [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease) summarized the effect of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) vitamin C on endothelial function by measuring FMD (19 studies), assessing forearm blood flow (20 studies), or by pulse wave analysis (5 trials) [(39)](#reference39). Short-term supplementation with vitamin C was found to reduce endothelial dysfunction in subjects with [heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure), atherosclerosis, or [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), but it had no effect in those with [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure). Vitamin C also limited endothelial dysfunction that was experimentally induced in healthy volunteers [(39)](#reference39). Improved endothelial function was observed with daily vitamin C doses above 500 mg [(39)](#reference39). [Hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure) is a major [risk](../glossary#risk) factor heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease), [stroke](../health-disease/stroke), and [atrial fibrillation](../glossary#atrial-fibrillation). An analysis that combined data from three, large, independent prospective cohorts, (1) Nurses' Health Study 1 (NHS1; 88,540 women, median age 49 years); (2) Nurses' Health Study 2 (NHS2; 97,315 women, median age 36 years); and (3) Health Professionals Follow-up Study (HPFS; 37,375 men, median age 52 years), found no association between the level of vitamin C intake and risk of developing hypertension [(40)](#reference40). On the other hand, when [plasma](../glossary#plasma) vitamin C concentration was measured, [cross-sectional studies](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) have consistently indicated an [inverse relationship](../glossary#inverse-association) between plasma vitamin C concentration and blood pressure in both men and women [(41-43)](#reference41). A 15-year follow-up of about 2,500 participants in the Coronary Artery Risk Development in Young Adults (CARDIA) study found that higher plasma vitamin C and a higher diet quality score were independently associated with a reduced risk of developing hypertension [(44)](#reference44). Interestingly, there was no relationship between diet score and risk of hypertension in those with the lowest plasma vitamin C, and plasma vitamin C was positively associated with risk of hypertension in those with low diet scores [(44)](#reference44). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 29 small [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) of short durations (median duration, 8 weeks) in 1,407 participants (10 to 120 subjects per trial; including both normotensive and hypertensive subjects) found that daily supplementation with 60 to 4,000 mg of vitamin C (median dose, 500 mg) reduced [systolic blood pressure](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) by 3.84 [mm Hg](../glossary#mm-Hg) and [diastolic blood pressure](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) by 1.48 mm Hg [(45)](#reference45). Good quality long-term trials are needed to examine whether the anti-hypertensive effect of vitamin C is sustained over time and eventually results in a reduced risk of cardiovascular events. It is important for individuals with significantly elevated blood pressure not to rely on vitamin C supplementation alone to reduce their hypertension. They should instead seek or continue treatment with anti-hypertensive medication and make dietary and lifestyle changes in consultation with their health care provider. [Coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) (CHD) is characterized by the buildup of plaque inside the arteries that supply blood to the heart ( [atherosclerosis](../health-disease/atherosclerosis)). Over years of buildup and accumulated damage to the [coronary arteries](../glossary#coronary-artery), CHD may culminate in a [myocardial infarction](../health-disease/heart-attack) or heart attack. Many [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have examined the relationship between vitamin C intake from diet and [supplements](../glossary#supplement) and CHD [risk](../glossary#risk), the results of which have been pooled and analyzed in two separate analyses [(46, 47)](#reference46). In 2004, a pooled analysis of nine prospective cohort studies found that supplemental vitamin C intake (400 mg/day for a mean of 10 years), but not dietary vitamin C intake, was [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with CHD risk [(46)](#reference46). Conversely, a 2008 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 14 cohort studies concluded that dietary, but not supplemental, vitamin C intake was inversely related to CHD risk [(47)](#reference47). The most recent large prospective cohort study found an inverse association between dietary vitamin C intake and CHD mortality in Japanese women, but not in men [(48)](#reference48). In spite of the variable association depending on source, these analyses indicate an overall inverse association between higher vitamin C intakes and CHD risk. Limitations inherent to dietary assessment methodology, such as [recall bias](../glossary#recall-bias), [measurement error](../glossary#measurement-error), and [residual confounding](../glossary#residual-confounding), may account for some of the inconsistent associations between vitamin C intake and CHD risk. In order to overcome such limitations, some prospective studies measured [plasma](../glossary#plasma) or [serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of vitamin C as a more reliable index of vitamin C intake and [biomarker](../glossary#biomarker) of body vitamin C [status](../glossary#status). The European Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC)-Norfolk prospective cohort study investigated the relationship between vitamin C status and incident [heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure) in healthy adults (9,187 men and 11,112 women, aged 58.1+/-9.2 years) [(49)](#reference49). After a mean follow-up of 12.8 years, plasma vitamin C was inversely associated with incident cases of heart failure. Specifically, plasma vitamin C ranged from approximately 23 to 70 mol/L in men and 33 to 82 mol/L in women; across this range, every 20 mol/L increase in plasma vitamin C was associated with a 9% reduction in risk of heart failure. Although a primary source of dietary vitamin C, consumption of fruit and vegetables — assessed by [food frequency questionnaire](../glossary#food-frequency-questionnaire) — was not found to be associated with a lower risk of congestive heart failure [(49)](#reference49). This highlights the fact that limitations associated with dietary assessment methods such as food frequency questionnaires may be overcome by using biomarkers of nutrient intake [(50, 51)](#reference50). A 2017 review of eight published [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found inconsistent results from seven trials reporting on the effect of vitamin C supplementation on serum [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) and [triglycerides](../glossary#triglycerides), established risk factors for [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) [(52)](#reference52). Only one large trial in more than 14,000 older men participating in the Physicians' Health Study II (PHS II) reported on cardiovascular outcomes. PHS II found that vitamin C supplementation (500 mg/day) for an average of eight years had no significant effect on major cardiovascular events, total myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular mortality [(53)](#reference53). Notably, this study had several limitations [(54)](#reference54), including no measurement of vitamin C status and the recruitment of a well-nourished study population. There is a need for better quality studies to examine the effect of vitamin C on cardiovascular endpoints in participants with elevated risk of cardiovascular disease. A cerebrovascular event, or [stroke](../health-disease/stroke), can be classified as [hemorrhagic](../glossary#hemorrhagic-stroke) or [ischemic](../glossary#ischemic-stroke). Hemorrhagic stroke occurs when a weakened blood vessel ruptures and bleeds into the surrounding brain tissue. Ischemic stroke occurs when an obstruction within a blood vessel blocks blood flow to the brain. Most (~80%) cerebrovascular events in high-income countries are ischemic in nature and associated with [atherosclerosis](../health-disease/atherosclerosis) as an underlying condition [(55, 56)](#reference55). With respect to vitamin C and [cerebrovascular disease](../glossary#cerebrovascular-disease), a [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) that followed more than 2,000 residents of a rural Japanese community for 20 years found that the [risk](../glossary#risk) of stroke in those with the highest [serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of vitamin C was 29% lower than in those with the lowest serum concentrations of vitamin C [(57)](#reference57). Similarly, the EPIC-Norfolk study, a 10-year prospective cohort study in 20,649 adults, found that individuals with [plasma](../glossary#plasma) vitamin C concentrations in the top [quartile](../glossary#quartile) (25%) had a 42% lower risk of stroke compared to those in the lowest quartile (66 mol/L vs. <41 mol/L) [(58)](#reference58). In both the Japanese [(57)](#reference57) and EPIC-Norfolk [(58)](#reference58) populations, blood vitamin C concentrations were highly correlated with fruit and vegetable intake. Therefore, as in many studies of vitamin C intake and [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease) risk, it is difficult to separate the effects of vitamin C from the effects of other components of fruit and vegetables. For example, [potassium](../minerals/potassium) — found at high levels in bananas, potatoes, and other fruit and vegetables — is known to be important in blood pressure regulation, and elevated blood pressure is a major risk factor for stroke (see the article on [Potassium](../minerals/potassium)). A 2013 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 17 prospective cohort studies reported a 19% lower risk of stroke with the highest versus lowest dietary vitamin C intakes and a 38% lower risk with the highest versus lowest circulating vitamin C concentrations [(59)](#reference59). A [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in more than 14,000 older men participating in the Physicians' Health Study II (PHS II) found that vitamin C supplementation (500 mg/day) for an average of eight years had no significant effect on the incidence of or mortality from any type of stroke [(53)](#reference53). Other trials also failed to show any evidence of an effect of vitamin C on the risk of stroke. A meta-analysis of 10 trials that examined [antioxidant ](../glossary#antioxidant)vitamins, of which five included vitamin C, found no association between any antioxidant vitamin (vitamin C, vitamin E, or -carotene), administered alone or in combination, and risk of stroke [(60)](#reference60). Overall, [observational](../glossary#observational-study) [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have reported no or modest [inverse associations](../glossary#inverse-association) between vitamin C intake and the [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing a given type of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [(37](#reference37), [61-63)](#reference61). Additional detail is provided below for those cancer subtypes with substantial scientific information obtained from prospective cohort studies. [Randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials that have tested the effect of vitamin C supplementation (alone or in combination with other [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) nutrients) on cancer incidence or mortality have shown no effect [(64)](#reference64). Two large [prospective studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) found dietary vitamin C intake to be [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with breast cancer incidence in certain subgroups. In the Nurses' Health Study, premenopausal women with a family history of breast cancer who consumed an average of 205 mg/day of vitamin C from food had a 63% lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of breast cancer than those who consumed an average of 70 mg/day [(65)](#reference65). In the Swedish Mammography Cohort, overweight women who consumed an average of 110 mg/day of vitamin C had a 39% lower risk of breast cancer compared to overweight women who consumed an average of 31 mg/day [(66)](#reference66). More recent prospective cohort studies have reported no association between dietary and/or [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) vitamin C intake and breast cancer [(67-69)](#reference67). A number of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have found increased dietary vitamin C intake to be associated with decreased [risk](../glossary#risk) of gastric (stomach) [cancer](../glossary#cancer), and laboratory experiments indicate that vitamin C inhibits the formation of [carcinogenic](../glossary#carcinogen) N-nitroso compounds in the stomach [(70-72)](#reference70). A [nested case-control study](../glossary#nested-case-control-study) in the EPIC study found a 45% lower risk of [gastric](../glossary#gastric) cancer incidence in individuals in the highest (51 mol/L) versus lowest (<29 mol/L) [quartile](../glossary#quartile) of plasma vitamin C concentration; no association was observed between dietary vitamin C intake and gastric cancer [(73)](#reference73). Infection with the [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria), Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori), is known to increase the risk of stomach cancer and is associated with lower vitamin C content of stomach secretions [(74, 75)](#reference74). Although two [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-study) failed to show a reduction in stomach cancer incidence with vitamin C [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) [(35)](#reference35), some research suggests that vitamin C supplementation may be a useful addition to standard H. pylori eradication therapy in reducing the risk of gastric cancer [(76)](#reference76). Because vitamin C can inactivate urease (an [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) that facilitates H. pylori survival and of the [gastric mucosa](../glossary#gastric-mucosa) at low [pH](../glossary#pH)) [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro), vitamin C may be most effective as a [prophylactic ](../glossary#prophylaxis)agent in those without [achlorhydria](../glossary#achlorhydria) [(77, 78)](#reference77). By pooling data from 13 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) comprising 676,141 participants, it was determined that dietary intake of vitamin C was not associated with [colon](../glossary#colon) [cancer](../glossary#cancer), while total intake of vitamin C (i.e., from food and [supplements](../glossary#supplement)) was associated with a 19% reduced [risk](../glossary#risk) of colon cancer [(79)](#reference79). Each of the cohort studies used self-administered [food frequency questionnaires](../glossary#food-frequency-questionnaire) at baseline to assess vitamin C intake. Although the analysis adjusted for several lifestyle and known risk factors, the authors noted that other healthy behaviors and/or folate intake may have [confounded](../glossary#confounder) the association. A population-based, [prospective study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), the Iowa Women's Health Study, collected baseline data on diet and [supplement](../glossary#supplement) use in 35,159 women (aged 55-69 years) and evaluated the [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) over 19 years of follow-up [(80)](#reference81). Overall, an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between fruit and vegetable intake and risk of NHL was observed. Additionally, dietary, but not supplemental, intake of vitamin C and other [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) nutrients ( [carotenoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/carotenoids), proanthocyanidins, and [manganese](../minerals/manganese)) was inversely associated with NHL risk. Another large, multi-center, prospective study — the Women's Health Initiative — that followed 154,363 postmenopausal women for 11 years found that dietary and supplemental vitamin C intake at baseline was inversely associated with diffuse B-cell lymphoma, a subtype of NHL [(81)](#reference81). The Physicians' Health Study II was a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial that examined the effect of [vitamin E](../vitamins/vitamin-E) (400 IU/day), vitamin C (500 mg/day), and on the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) in 14,641 middle-aged male physicians over 10.3 years (7.6 years of active treatment plus 2.8 years post-treatment follow-up) [(82)](#reference82). Supplementation with vitamin C had no effect on the overall risk of cancer or on the risk of [prostate](../glossary#prostate), bladder, or [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) cancer; there was a marginal reduction in [colorectal cancer](../glossary#colorectal-cancer) incidence with vitamin C compared to placebo [(82)](#reference82). In the National Institutes of Health (NIH)-American Association of Retired Persons (AARP) Diet and Health study that included 232,007 participants, the use of vitamin C [supplements](../glossary#supplement) for at least seven times a week was associated with a 9% lower risk of developing type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) compared to non-supplement use [(83)](#reference83). In a cohort of 21,831 adults followed for 12 years in the EPIC-Norfolk study, high [plasma](../glossary#plasma) vitamin C was found to be strongly associated with a reduced [risk](../glossary#risk) of diabetes [(84)](#reference84). Additionally, several [cross-sectional studies](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) reported [inverse associations](../glossary#inverse-association) between circulating vitamin C concentrations and markers of resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance) or have found no effect of vitamin C supplementation on fasting glucose, fasting insulin, and HbA1c concentrations in healthy individuals [(87)](#reference87). It is not known whether supplemental vitamin C could improve markers of glycemic control in subjects at risk of diabetes. A 2015 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 29 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found that administration of vitamin C during pregnancy, alone or in combination with a few other [supplements](../glossary#supplement), failed to reduce the risks of stillbirth, perinatal death, intrauterine growth restriction, preterm birth, premature rupture of membranes, and [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia) [(88)](#reference88). Nonetheless, vitamin C supplementation led to a 36% lower risk of [placental abruption](../glossary#placental-abruption) and to a significant increase in [gestational](../glossary#gestation) age at birth [(88)](#reference88). Another meta-analysis of 40 randomized controlled trials in 276,820 women found no effect of vitamin C, alone or combined with [vitamin E](vitamin-E) or multivitamins, when supplemented during pregnancy (starting prior to 20 weeks' gestation), on the risks of overall fetal loss, miscarriage, stillbirth, and [congenital malformation](../glossary#congenital-malformation) [(89)](#reference89). Cigarette smoking during pregnancy causes intrauterine growth restriction and preterm birth, among other pregnancy complications [(90, 91)](#reference90), and is the primary cause of childhood respiratory illness [(92)](#reference92). For some still unclear reasons, smoking has been associated with a lower risk of preeclampsia during pregnancy [(93)](#reference93). A secondary analysis of a multicenter, randomized, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in nearly 10,000 pregnant women found no reduction in the risk of preeclampsia with supplemental vitamin C (1,000 mg/day) and vitamin E (400 IU/day), regardless of women's smoking status during pregnancy. However, [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) supplementation resulted in reduced risks of placental abruption and preterm birth in women who smoked during pregnancy but not in non-smokers [(94)](#reference94). Another [pilot](../glossary#pilot-study) multicenter trial found better lung function during the first week of life and lower risk of wheezing through one year of age in infants whose smoking mothers were randomized to receive vitamin C (500 mg/day) rather than a placebo during pregnancy [(95)](#reference95). The Vitamin C to Decrease the Effects of Smoking in Pregnancy on Infant Lung Function [VCSIP] study is an ongoing trial designed to confirm these preliminary observations using more accurate measurements of pulmonary function in a larger sample of women randomized to receive supplemental vitamin C or placebo [(96)](#reference96). In the US, [Alzheimer's disease](../health-disease/alzheimer-disease) (AD) is the most common form of [dementia](../glossary#dementia), affecting 5.5 million individuals 65 years and over [(97)](#reference97). stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress), and [neuronal](../glossary#neuron) cell death in the brain of subjects affected by AD have been associated with [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) decline and memory loss. Lower vitamin C concentrations in the [cerebrospinal fluid](../glossary#cerebrospinal-fluid) (CSF) and brain extracellular matrix of a mouse model of AD were found to increase oxidative stress and accelerate amyloid deposition and disease progression [(98)](#reference98).
