In a [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) conducted among 3,173 men and women aged 50-79 years and free of PD at baseline, individuals in the highest [quartile](../glossary#quartile) of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (20 ng/mL for women and 22.8 ng/mL for men) had a 67% lower risk of PD compared to those in the lowest quartile (10 ng/mL for women and 11.2 ng/mL for men) [(239)](#reference239). [Meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) pooling data from [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) all showed that vitamin D inadequacy was more likely reported in subjects with PD than in healthy controls [(240-242)](#reference240). In a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study, 112 PD patients (mean age, 72 years) on standard PD treatment were [supplemented](../glossary#supplement) with 1,200 IU/day of vitamin D or a placebo for 12 months. Vitamin D supplementation nearly doubled serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration (from mean of 22.5 ng/mL to 41.7 ng/mL) in supplemented subjects and limited the progression of PD, as indicated by a greater proportion of patients who showed no worsening (as assessed by the Hoehn and Yahr stage and the United Parkinson Disease Rating Scale part II) in the supplemented group compared to the placebo group [(243)](#reference243). It is not known whether vitamin D insufficiency has a role in the [pathogenesis](../glossary#pathogenesis) of the disease, but the [repletion](../glossary#replete) of vitamin D may provide health benefits that go beyond the prevention and/or the treatment of PD. For example, vitamin D deficiency may contribute to the increased risk of [osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis) and bone [fracture](../glossary#fracture) in individuals with [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) disorders, including PD and [multiple sclerosis](../glossary#multiple-sclerosis) [(244-246)](#reference244). Interestingly, sunlight exposure was found to be associated with improved vitamin D status, higher [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) of the second metacarpal bone, and lower incidence of hip fracture in a prospective study conducted in 324 elderly people with PD [(247)](#reference247). A [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 31 [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) on maternal vitamin D status and pregnancy outcomes indicated that vitamin D insufficiency may be associated with [gestational](../glossary#gestation) [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia), and [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) vaginosis in pregnant women. Low maternal serum vitamin D during pregnancy was also linked to an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for small-for-gestational age infants and low-birth-weight infants, but not for Cesarean section [(248)](#reference248). However, the number of [intervention trials](../glossary#intervention-trial) is currently too limited to draw conclusions as to whether vitamin D [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) during pregnancy might reduce the incidence of the above-mentioned adverse outcomes [(249)](#reference249). Abnormal [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia) due to [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) characterizes the onset of [gestational](../glossary#gestation) [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) (GDM) in pregnant women without known type 2 diabetes mellitus. This condition is associated with serious adverse maternal outcomes, including [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia), high [risk](../glossary#risk) of Cesarean delivery, and life-long increased risk of developing [metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome) and type 2 diabetes mellitus. GDM may also contribute to increased risks of fetal macrosomia (excessive birth weight), neonatal [hypoglycemia](../glossary#hypoglycemia), infant respiratory distress, and increased life-long risk for [glucose intolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance), type 2 diabetes mellitus, and [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) the offspring (reviewed in [250](#reference250)). A recent [prospective study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) conducted in 655 pregnant women found that the mean [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration during the first trimester of pregnancy was significantly lower in 54 women who developed incident GDM compared to the rest of the cohort (23 ng/mL vs. 25.4 ng/mL). After multiple adjustments for [confounding](../glossary#confounder) factors of vitamin D status and GDM risk (including overweight/obesity and prior history of type 2 diabetes and GDM), the study found each 7.5 ng/mL decrease in serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration during early pregnancy was associated with a 48% higher risk of developing GDM [(251)](#reference251). Low serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations (<29.4 ng/mL) during the second trimester of pregnancy were also associated with GDM incidence in a [nested case-control study](../glossary#nested-case-control-study) of 118 women with GDM and 219 subjects [(252)](#reference252). Five [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) [(248](#reference248), [253-256)](#reference253), including [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) of moderate-to-high quality, also reported that maternal serum vitamin D concentrations during pregnancy were [inversely related](../glossary#inverse-association) to the risk of developing GDM despite evidence of [bias](../glossary#bias) amongst studies, such as the use of different methods for serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D measurement, measures done in different trimesters, and different criteria to assess GDM (reviewed in [257](#reference257)). Further, evidence for the role of vitamin D in [glucose](../glossary#glucose) regulation during pregnancy was reported in a small [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 54 pregnant women diagnosed with GDM. The [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with 50,000 IU of vitamin D3 twice during a six-week period (at day 1 and day 21) resulted in significantly lower fasting [plasma](../glossary#plasma) glucose and serum [insulin](../glossary#insulin) concentration, reduced [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance), and improved [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) compared to placebo [(258)](#reference258). This suggests that vitamin D deficiency may adversely affect glucose tolerance during pregnancy and contribute to the onset of GDM. Yet, the potential benefits of vitamin D supplementation in the prevention of glucose intolerance and GDM during pregnancy have not been assessed. A multicentered, [randomized controlled trial ](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial)(DALI) is ongoing in Europe to evaluate the effects of vitamin D and lifestyle interventions (healthy eating and physical activity) on the metabolic status of pregnant women at risk of GDM (inclusion criteria: pre-pregnancy BMI 29 kg/m2) [(259)](#reference259). Preliminary findings suggest that healthy eating and physical activity can help lower gestational weight gain, when compared to standard-of-care; however, these lifestyle changes are unlikely to reduce the risk of GDM among obese pregnant women [(260)](#reference260). The results regarding the effect of vitamin D supplementation in the DALI study are yet to be published. During pregnancy, increased [intestinal](../glossary#small-intestine) [calcium](../minerals/calcium) absorption and mobilization of calcium from the skeleton allows accretion of calcium within the fetal skeleton. Yet, [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) that examined the relationship between maternal vitamin D status and measures of fetal bone growth have not provided consistent results [(261, 262)](#reference261). In addition, recent data from the Maternal Vitamin D Osteoporosis Study (MAVIDOS) suggested no difference in whole-body bone mineral content (BMC) of newborns from mothers randomized to daily supplementation with either vitamin D3 (1,000 IU) or [placebo](../glossary#placebo) from <17 weeks' gestation until delivery [(263)](#reference263). Further, the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [fracture](../glossary#fracture) in Danish children ages 10 to 18 years was similar regardless of whether their mothers were exposed to extra vitamin D from [fortification](../glossary#fortification) during pregnancy [(264)](#reference264). While maternal vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy effectively prevents the neonate's risk of vitamin D deficiency at birth [(265)](#reference265), there is little evidence that neonatal vitamin D status influences the risk of fracture later during childhood [(266)](#reference266). A few observational studies have given rather weak evidence in support of a relationship between maternal vitamin D sufficiency during pregnancy and incidence of respiratory conditions and allergies in children [(267)](#reference267). A [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found that the supplementation of 108 pregnant women in the third trimester (at week 27 of gestation until delivery) with either 800 IU/day or a bolus dose of 200,000 IU of vitamin D3 did not decrease the risk of wheezing, allergic rhinitis, food allergy diagnosis, lower respiratory tract infections, or eczema in offspring at three years of age compared to placebo (N=50) [(268)](#reference268). A more recent [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), randomized controlled trial found that vitamin D3 supplementation of 295 Danish pregnant women, from weeks 22 to 26 of gestation until delivery, with 2,800 IU/day (70 g/day) — compared to 400 IU/day (10 g/day) of vitamin D3 (i.e., the current recommendation in Denmark) (N=286) — reduced the risk of troublesome episodes of lung symptoms by 17% in offspring during the first three years of life [(269)](#reference269). However, no differences were reported regarding the risk of persistent wheeze, [asthma](../glossary#asthma), allergic sensitization, respiratory tract infections, or eczema between treatment and control groups [(269)](#reference269). In a similar randomized, double-blind, controlled trial — the Vitamin D Antenatal Asthma Reduction Trial — conducted in 777 US pregnant women with a history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema (or whose partner had such an history), supplementation with 2,400 IU/day (60 g/day) or 400 IU/day (10 g/day) did not result in differences in the risk of developing asthma or recurrent wheezing in their children at age three years [(270)](#reference270). Despite the lack of significance reported in individual studies, the pooled analysis of the three trials found a 19% reduction in the risk of recurrent wheeze in children whose mothers received high-dose versus low-dose vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy [(271)](#reference271). In a cohort of 378 mother-child pairs, high [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations measured in the 34th week of pregnancy were associated with an increase in food allergy of the child during the first two years of life, warranting careful evaluation of the safety of vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy [(272)](#reference272). Since vitamin D insufficiency has been linked to [autoimmunity](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) (see [Autoimmune diseases](#autoimmune-diseases-prevention)), it has also been proposed that poor maternal vitamin D status during pregnancy may contribute to an increased risk of autoimmune diabetes ( [insulin](../glossary#insulin)-dependent type 1 diabetes mellitus) in the offspring. Yet, the results of a study of 3,723 children at high genetic risk for type 1 diabetes and followed for a mean 4.3 year-period found that maternal intake of vitamin D (from food and/or supplements) during the third trimester of pregnancy (assessed through [food frequency questionnaires](../glossary#food-frequency-questionnaire)) was not associated with advanced -cell autoimmunity or clinical diabetes [(142)](#reference142). In a [nested case-control study](../glossary#nested-case-control-study), there was no difference in mean serum concentration of 25-hydroxyvitamin D during the first trimester of pregnancy between 343 mothers of children with type 1 diabetes and 343 control mothers [(143)](#reference143). A follow-up study suggested that specific maternal VDR polymorphisms, rather than vitamin D status, may be linked to an increased susceptibility to developing type 1 diabetes in children [(273)](#reference273). Another nested case-control study (119 mothers of children with type 1 diabetes and 129 control mothers) found an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between maternal vitamin D-binding protein — but not 25-hydroxyvitamin D — concentration during the third trimester of pregnancy and the risk of type 1 diabetes in children [(274)](#reference274). At present, there is no established causality between maternal vitamin D status during pregnancy and risk of autoimmune disease in offspring. More than 200 [viruses](../glossary#virus) are responsible for causing familiar infections of the upper respiratory tract (URT), known as the [common cold](../health-disease/common-cold), resulting in symptoms of nasal congestion and discharge, cough, sore throat, and sneezing [(275)](#reference275). The analysis of [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) data from 18,883 participants (ages 12 years and older) of the Third US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES III) reported an [inverse relationship](../glossary#inverse-association) between [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations and recent (self-reported) URT infection (URTI). Compared to levels of circulating vitamin D of 30 ng/mL or above, the [risk](../glossary#risk) of URTI was 24% higher in individuals with concentrations between 10 and 29 ng/mL and 36% higher in those with levels below 10 ng/mL [(276)](#reference276). A subgroup analysis indicated that low concentrations of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D in subjects with [asthma](../glossary#asthma) and [chronic obstructive pulmonary disease](../glossary#chronic-obstructive-pulmonary-disease) (COPD) were linked to a greater susceptibility to URTI when compared to people without pulmonary disease. In a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial conducted in 322 healthy adults (ages 18 years), supplementation with monthly doses of vitamin D3 (200,000 IU for the first two months and 100,000 IU for the following 16 months) significantly raised the mean serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration (from 29 ng/mL to 48 ng/mL) in the intervention group but did not decrease the occurrence of URTI compared to placebo [(277)](#reference277). Moreover, in a larger, multicenter, four-arm [clinical trial](../glossary#clinical-trial) in 2,259 subjects (aged 45-75 history of [colorectal adenoma](../glossary#colorectal-adenoma), daily vitamin D3 supplementation of 1,000 IU did not reduce the number or the duration of URTI episodes during winter or the rest of the year, even among participants with the lowest serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations at baseline [(278)](#reference278). In addition, the post-hoc analysis of data from a randomized, placebo-controlled trial in 644 individuals (ages 60-84 years) found that monthly supplementation with 30,000 IU or 60,000 IU of vitamin D3 for a maximum period of one year did not significantly decrease the rate of antibiotic prescriptions for [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) airway infections. The stratified analysis, however, found that doses of 60,000 IU/month reduced the risk of using antibiotics in participants 70 years old by 47% [(279)](#reference279). In addition, compared to placebo, the supplementation of pregnant women with vitamin D3 (with 2,000 IU/day) for three months until birth followed by the supplementation of their infants (800 IU/day) from birth to six months of age significantly reduced the number of acute respiratory infections after the intervention period in children 6 to 18 months old [(280)](#reference280). Interestingly, despite significant [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) among trials, the pooled analysis of these data with that of 21 additional trials suggested an overall 12% reduction in incidence of URTI with vitamin D3 given as bolus doses (every week, month, or every three months), daily doses, or a combination of bolus and daily doses [(281)](#reference281). Subgroup analyses revealed a 42% reduction in URTI risk with vitamin D3 supplementation in subjects with baseline serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations <10 ng/mL, while there was no protective effect of vitamin D3 in those with concentrations 10 ng/mL. Moreover, large bolus doses (30,000 IU) were found to be ineffective compared to daily or weekly doses such that, in subgroup analyses that excluded bolus doses, daily and weekly vitamin D3 regimens appeared to be protective against URTI regardless of baseline vitamin D status. Finally, the effect of vitamin D3 supplementation on URTI did not appear to vary with age, [BMI](../glossary#body-mass-index), the presence of asthma or COPD, and flu vaccination status [(281)](#reference281). The findings of a large clinical trial in New Zealand, the Vitamin D Assessment (ViDA) Study, confirmed the ineffectiveness of large bolus doses of vitamin D in reducing the risk of acute respiratory infections [(282)](#reference282). In this double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in 5,110 older adults (ages 50-84 at baseline), supplementation with an initial dose of 200,000 IU of vitamin D3 followed by 100,000 IU/month of vitamin D3 for a median of 3.3 years had no effect on the incidence of (self-reported) acute respiratory infections (HR, 1.01; 95% [CI](../glossary#confidence-interval), 0.94-1.07). Upon data stratification by vitamin D status, a similar null result (HR, 1.08; 95% CI, 0.95-1.23) was seen in study participants with blood vitamin D concentrations 20 ng/mL (50 nmol/L; [282](#reference282)). The recently completed VITAL (Vitamin D and Omega-3 Trial) may provide additional evidence of an effect of daily dosing (2,000 IU/day of vitamin D) on risk of airway infections in older adults, although the prevention of infectious disease is a secondary outcome in the trial [(204](#reference204), [283, 284)](#reference283). In a trial in preschool-age children, vitamin D supplementation with 2,000 IU/day for at least four months did not decrease the incidence [(285)](#reference285) or severity [(286)](#reference286) of URTI in winter compared to supplementation with 400 IU/day for at least four months. Supplementation with 2,000 IU/day led to significantly higher mean serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations compared to the lower dose (48.7 ng/mL vs. 36.8 ng/mL), but the 400 IU dose may have been sufficient to prevent URTI in these young children [(285)](#reference285). In a placebo-controlled trial in 1,300 healthy children and adolescents in rural Vietnam (baseline 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations of 26 ng/mL for both the control and intervention group), supplementation with 14,000 IU/week of vitamin D for eight months significantly reduced the incidence of non-influenza viral respiratory infections by 24%, but not the incidence of influenza A or B infection [(287)](#reference287). The coronavirus disease, COVID-19, is caused by infection with the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2). This virus originated in Wuhan, China in late 2019 and rapidly spread throughout the world causing a global pandemic. Flu-like symptoms, including cough, fever, fatigue, and difficulty breathing, as well as several other diverse symptoms characterize COVID-19 (see the websites of the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/symptoms.html) and the [WHO](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public)). The effects of the disease vary widely, with the most severe resulting in pneumonia, respiratory distress, and death. Some individuals infected with SARS-CoV-2, however, are asymptomatic but can transmit virus to others [(288)](#reference288). Moreover, SARS-CoV-2 infected individuals can spread disease before they experience symptoms (i.e., presymptomatic transmission) [(289)](#reference289), placing importance on public health measures like hand washing, face mask wearing, social distancing, and testing and contact tracing to curtail the pandemic. A number of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have examined the correlation of vitamin D status and COVID-19 incidence, with most — but not all [(290-292)](#reference290) — finding vitamin D deficiency or insufficiency associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of SARS-CoV-2 infection. In a [retrospective](../glossary#retrospective-study) cohort study of more than 191,000 US residents administered a SARS-CoV-2 test during a three-month period in spring 2020, SARS-CoV-2 positivity was strongly associated with a lower [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration, measured at a single point in the 12 months prior to the viral test [(293)](#reference293). In this study, each 1 ng/mL increment of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D was linked to a 1.6% lower risk of SARS-CoV-2 positivity, with the risk being the lowest at serum concentrations of 55 ng/mL and above [(293)](#reference293). In a retrospective, population-based study among 7,807 people in Israel, including 782 SARS-CoV-2 positive cases, [plasma](../glossary#plasma) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations below 30 ng/mL were associated with a 50% higher risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection compared to higher vitamin D concentrations [(294)](#reference294). The vitamin D status assessment in this study was done prior to the viral testing, but details on the time frame are lacking. The temporal relationship of the vitamin D status measure and COVID diagnostic test is also a concern in an analysis of a large dataset from the UK Biobank, which found vitamin D status was not associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection: the study utilized vitamin D status assessments done 10 to 14 years prior to the COVID-19 diagnostic test [(291)](#reference291). Consistent with findings of most available studies, a small retrospective cohort study [(295)](#reference295) and five [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) [(296-300)](#reference296) reported an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) vitamin D status and SARS-CoV-2 infection. A 2021 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 10 observational studies, including 361,934 participants, reported an association between vitamin D insufficiency or deficiency and increased risk of COVID-19 ( [OR](../glossary#odds-ratio), 1.43; 95% [CI](../glossary#confidence-interval): 1.00-2.05), although [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) across studies was high [(301)](#reference301). Further, in an analysis of data from the UK Biobank, regular use of vitamin D supplements was found to be associated with a 34% lower risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection compared nonusers of vitamin D supplements [(292)](#reference292). Additionally, most of the available observational research suggests an association between low vitamin D status and COVID-19 severity, with studies finding vitamin D deficiency linked to an increased risk of disease severity, as measured by need for hospitalization, intensive care unit admission [(302)](#reference302), stage of pneumonia (in men but not in women; [303](#reference303)), need for non-invasive ventilation [(304)](#reference304), need for invasive mechanical ventilation [(305)](#reference305), or a combination of these and other indicators [(297)](#reference297). Another study found that insufficient vitamin D status, defined as plasma 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations below 30 ng/mL, was associated with an increased likelihood of COVID-related hospitalization, but the association failed to reach statistical significance (p=0.061) except in a subanalysis of individuals over 50 years of age (OR, 2.71; 95% CI: 1.55-4.78; p<0.001) [(294)](#reference294). In contrast to most of the evidence to date, one case-control study found vitamin D deficiency was not linked to COVID-19 severity [(298)](#reference298). Further, a few studies have looked at the relationship of vitamin D status and COVID-19 mortality, with three finding vitamin D deficiency to be associated with an increased risk of death [(303](#reference303), [305, 306)](#reference305) and two finding no association [(304](#reference304), [307)](#reference307), although one of the studies finding no association used vitamin D status measurements more than 10 years prior to the COVID-19 diagnostic testing [(307)](#reference307). Since there are several known risk factors for severe illness from COVID-19, including advanced age, obesity, and preexisting type 2 diabetes or cardiovascular disease [(308)](#reference308), it is important for observational studies to control for potential [confounders](../glossary#confounder). Two quasi-experimental studies reported that bolus supplementation with vitamin D3 (either 50,000 IU per month or 80,000-100,000 IU every two to three months) prior to or during SARS-CoV-2 infection was associated with a less severe illness and improved survival in frail elderly COVID-19 patients [(309, 310)](#reference309). A number of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) of vitamin D supplementation in COVID-19 prevention and treatment are currently underway; the results of these trials will inform on the causality of the association. Nevertheless, the currently available data indicate that improving vitamin D status through supplementation represents a modifiable risk factor for COVID-19. Atopic dermatitis or eczema is particularly [prevalent](../glossary#prevalence) in industrialized countries, affecting 10%-20% of children and 1%-3% of adults. Atopic dermatitis is a chronic [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) skin disorder characterized by dry and pruritus (itchy) areas of the skin in affected subjects. Local skin inflammation and immune dysfunction can damage the [epidermal](../glossary#epidermis) barrier and increase the susceptibility to skin infections and atopic reactions in affected individuals. The disease is often associated with other atopic diseases, including food allergies, [asthma](../glossary#asthma), and allergic rhinitis [(311)](#reference311). While the [etiology](../glossary#etiology) of the disease is not fully elucidated, it has been suggested that vitamin D deficiency might contribute to the onset and/or the severity of the disease [(312)](#reference312). Recently, using large-scale datasets from Caucasian people of European descent, including the UK Biobank resource [(313)](#reference313) and the SUNLIGHT [(35)](#reference35), the GABRIEL asthma and EAGLE eczema [(315)](#reference315) consortia, a [Mendelian randomization study](../glossary#Mendelian-randomization-study) found no association between genetically low serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations and [risks](../glossary#risk) of number of [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have examined whether vitamin D might be an effective [adjunct](../glossary#adjunct) tool in disease management, possibly through regulating local inflammatory reactions and stimulating [antimicrobial](../glossary#antimicrobial) activities in the skin. Moreover, the beneficial effect of phototherapy observed in specific cases of atopic dermatitis may be partly mediated by the action of vitamin D [(311)](#reference311). In a small [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in 45 patients with atopic dermatitis and low vitamin D status (70% of subjects had serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations <20 ng/mL), daily administration of 1,600 IU of oral vitamin D3, alone or together with 600 IU/day of [vitamin E](vitamin-E), for a period of 60 days significantly reduced the extent and intensity of eczema, as assessed by the SCORAD (SCORing Atopic Dermatitis) score [(317)](#reference317). Vitamin D3 (1,600 IU/day for 60 days) also improved vitamin D status and reduced disease severity in 53 patients with atopic dermatitis in another small randomized trial [(318)](#reference318). More recently, vitamin D3 (1,000 IU/day for one month) improved the severity of winter-related atopic dermatitis in Mongolian children, as shown by changes in Eczema Area and Severity Index (EASI) and Investigator's Global Assessment (IGA) scores [(319)](#reference319). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of four small trials (including those cited above) confirmed that supplemental vitamin D can lead to measurable clinical improvements in affected individuals [(320)](#reference320). Larger trials are needed to strengthen these preliminary findings and determine the most appropriate and effective supplementation regimen. Of note, [topical](../glossary#topical) treatment of [psoriasis](../glossary#psoriasis) with vitamin D [analogs](../glossary#analog) has been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and may be effective in the management of other skin disorders [(321)](#reference321). Several ill-defined environmental and genetic factors are thought to contribute to the development of the inappropriate immune response to the [intestinal microbiota](../glossary#intenstinal-microbiota) that causes [ulcerative colitis](../glossary#ulcerative-colitis) (UC) and [Crohn's disease](../glossary#crohn-disease) (CD). While specific VDR [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) may be linked to an increased susceptibility to developing UC and CD [(322)](#reference322), higher vitamin D intakes and predicted circulating levels were found to be associated with a reduced incidence of UC and CD in a large cohort of 72,719 women [(323)](#reference323). A meta-analysis of six [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) found an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between vitamin D status and severity of CD [(324)](#reference324). Three studies have investigated whether vitamin D3 could benefit patients with CD, possibly through reducing intestinal [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation). In one multicenter, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study, the relapse rate in CD patients in remission after one year of treatment was significantly lower in those supplemented daily with 1,200 IU of vitamin D3 and 1,200 mg of [calcium](../minerals/calcium) compared to those who received calcium alone (13% vs. 29%) [(325)](#reference325). In a second [pilot study](../glossary#pilot-study), incremental daily doses of vitamin D3, from 1,000 IU up to 5,000 IU, were administrated over a 24-week period to 18 CD patients in order to achieve circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations >40 ng/mL. Although half of the patients failed to achieve 40 ng/mL, the mean 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration was raised to 45 ng/mL (from a baseline mean of 16 ng/mL), and the overall improvement in vitamin D status was associated with a significant decrease in disease severity as assessed by Crohn's Disease Activity (CDAI) scores [(326)](#reference326). In a three-month, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in 27 CD patients in remission, daily supplementation with vitamin D3 (2,000 IU) improved vitamin D status but had no significant effect on intestinal permeability ('leaky gut') or measures of inflammation and disease activity [(327)](#reference327). Yet, the study suggested that achieving serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations 30 ng/mL might help reduce intestinal inflammation and improve patients' quality of life. Additional studies are needed to confirm the therapeutic efficacy of vitamin D in [inflammatory bowel diseases](../glossary#inflammatory-bowel-disease). The [prospective](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) analysis of 41,504 electronic medical records in the Intermountain Heart Collaborative study found that only one-third of patients had adequate [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations (>30 ng/mL); vitamin D insufficiency (serum D concentrations 30 ng/mL) was associated with increased [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) and incidence of many [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) conditions, [(328)](#reference328). D status also been linked to arterial stiffness and [vascular endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) dysfunction — strong determinants of incident hypertension and adverse cardiovascular outcomes [(329)](#reference329). Several [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) have evaluated the effect of vitamin D [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) on blood pressure. An early controlled [clinical trial](../glossary#clinical-trial) in 18 men and women with untreated mild [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension) living in the Netherlands found that exposure to UVB radiation three times weekly for six weeks during the winter increased serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations by 162%, lowered PTH concentrations by 15%, and decreased 24-hour ambulatory [systolic](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) and [diastolic blood pressure](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) measurements by an average of 6 mm Hg [(330)](#reference330). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 16 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) involving 1,879 participants, either healthy or with pre-existing cardiometabolic conditions (including hypertension), found no significant reduction in systolic and diastolic blood pressures with vitamin D supplementation (800-8,571 IU/day for five weeks to one year). However, a subgroup analysis of six trials found a significant reduction of 1.31 mm Hg in diastolic blood pressure in individuals with preexisting conditions. While improvements in blood pressure may be expected in cases of vitamin D insufficiency/deficiency, the authors noted that suboptimal vitamin D status in participants was not exclusively observed in those with cardiometabolic conditions [(331)](#reference331). In contrast, in two recent intervention studies — the Styrian vitamin D hypertension trial [(332)](#reference332) and the Vitamin D therapy in individuals at high risk of hypertension trial [DAYLIGHT] [(333)](#reference333) — subjects with (pre)hypertension supplemented with vitamin D3 (400 to 4,000 IU/day for two to six months) showed no evidence of blood pressure lowering, regardless of their baseline vitamin D status (insufficient or adequate, according to the IOM's current cutoffs). Conditions that decrease vitamin D [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) in the skin, such as having dark-colored skin, living in temperate latitudes, and aging, are associated with increased [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of hypertension [(334)](#reference334), suggesting that vitamin D may reduce blood pressure levels in selected groups of individuals. In the above-mentioned meta-analysis, one four-arm, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled clinical trial was conducted in 283 African Americans randomized to receive daily vitamin D3 supplements of 1,000 IU, 2,000 IU, or 4,000 IU for a period of three months. Systolic blood pressure was decreased by 0.66 mm Hg with 1,000 IU/day, 3.4 mm Hg with 2,000 IU/day, and by 4 mm Hg with 4,000 IU/day while it increased by 1.7 mm Hg in the placebo group when compared to baseline. A significant reduction of 0.2 [mm Hg](../glossary#mm-Hg) in systolic blood pressure was detected per 1 ng/mL incremental increase in 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration. However, there was no statistical difference on three-month change in blood pressure between vitamin D3 and placebo [(335)](#reference335). Another randomized, placebo-controlled study in 150 elderly participants (mean age, 77 years) showed that supplementation with 100,000 IU of vitamin D3 every three months for one year did not significantly lower blood pressure compared to placebo [(336)](#reference336). Further research is needed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation is helpful in the prevention or management of hypertension. [Congestive heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure) (also called cardiac insufficiency) is characterized by increased heart rate and subsequent [hypertrophy](../glossary#hypertrophy) of the left heart [ventricle](../glossary#ventricles). Cardiac insufficiency is associated with a reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), assessed by [echocardiography](../glossary#echocardiography). Inhibitors of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) (see [Blood pressure regulation](#blood-pressure-regulation)) are currently used as first-line therapy for patients with heart failure. In a [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) in healthy patients who underwent [coronary](../glossary#coronary-artery) angiography, [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations <30 ng/mL were associated with poorer coronary flow rates [(337)](#reference337). Suboptimal vitamin D status has also been linked to poorer [prognosis](../glossary#prognosis) in patients with heart failure [(338)](#reference338). Over the past several years, a number of [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) have examined the effect of vitamin D supplementation in those with cardiac insufficiency. In a 12-week [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study, daily supplementation with 1,200 IU of vitamin D3 in children with chronic congestive heart failure led to a significant increase in vitamin D status accompanied by an improved heart muscle performance (increased LVEF), as well as by lower levels of PTH and pro- [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) [cytokines](../glossary#cytokine) [(339)](#reference339). In another randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in 64 elderly patients with heart failure, participants receiving 800 mg/day of [calcium](../minerals/calcium) and 50,000 IU/week of vitamin D3 did not perform significantly better at physical performance tasks (used as proxy to assess aerobic capacity and skeletal muscle strength) compared to those supplemented with calcium only [(340)](#reference340). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of seven small randomized placebo-controlled trials in 573 subjects with heart failure showed that vitamin D supplementation (from 1,000 IU/day to 50,000 IU/week) for six weeks to nine months could reduce serum concentrations of PTH, tumor necrosis factor- (TNF-), and [C-reactive protein](../glossary#c-reactive-protein) (CRP). Yet, there were no differences in LVEF, circulating interleukin-10 (IL-10) concentration, and renin concentration between patients treated with vitamin D and those given a placebo [(341)](#reference341). Finally, in the EVITA (Effect of vitamin D on all-cause mortality) trial in patients with end-stage heart failure and inadequate vitamin D status (baseline serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D values, 8.6-19.7 ng/mL), supplementation with 4,000 IU/day for three years did not reduce the risk of mortality compared to placebo [(342)](#reference342). Solar ultraviolet-B radiation (UVB; wavelengths of 290 to 315 nanometers) stimulates the production of vitamin D3 in the [epidermis](../glossary#epidermis) of the skin [(343)](#reference343). Sunlight exposure can provide most people with their entire vitamin D requirement. Children and young adults who spend a short time outside two or three times a week will generally [synthesize](../glossary#synthesis) all the vitamin D they need to prevent deficiency. One study reported that [serum](../glossary#serum) vitamin D concentrations following exposure to one [minimal erythemal dose](../glossary#minimal-erythemal-dose) of simulated sunlight (the amount required to cause a slight pinkness of the skin) to the whole body was equivalent to ingesting approximately 10,000 to 25,000 IU of vitamin D [(344)](#reference344). People with dark-colored skin synthesize markedly less vitamin D on exposure to sunlight than those with lighter complexion [(34)](#reference34). Additionally, older adults have diminished capacity to synthesize vitamin D from sunlight exposure and frequently use sunscreen or protective clothing in order to prevent skin [cancer](../glossary#cancer) and sun damage. The application of sunscreen with an SPF factor of 10 reduces production of vitamin D by 90% [(30)](#reference30). In latitudes around 40 degrees north or 40 degrees south (Boston is 42 degrees north), there is insufficient UVB radiation available for vitamin D synthesis from November to early March. Ten degrees farther north or south (Edmonton, Canada), the "vitamin D winter" extends from mid-October to mid-March. It has been estimated that up to 15 minutes of daily sun exposure on the hands, arms, and face around 12 pm throughout the year at 25 degrees latitude (Miami, FL) and during the spring, summer, and fall at 42 degrees (Boston, MA) latitude may provide a light-skinned individual with 1,000 IU of vitamin D [(345)](#reference345). Vitamin D is found naturally in only a few foods, such as some fatty fish (mackerel, salmon, sardines), fish liver oils, eggs from hens that have been fed vitamin D, and mushrooms exposed to sunlight or UV light. In the US, milk and infant formula are [fortified](../glossary#fortification) with vitamin D so that they contain 400 IU (10 g) per quart. However, other dairy products, such as cheese and yogurt, are not always fortified with vitamin D. Some cereal, bread, and fruit juices may also be fortified with vitamin D. Accurate estimates of average dietary intakes of vitamin D are difficult because of the high variability of the vitamin D content of fortified foods [(346)](#reference346). Vitamin D toxicity (hypervitaminosis D) has not been observed to result from sun exposure. The reason is that excessive sunlight exposure generates a number of biologically inert photoproducts from 7-dehydrocholesterol and induces abnormally high [serum](../glossary#risk) [calcium](../minerals/calcium) concentration (hypercalcemia), which could result in bone loss, [kidney stones](../glossary#kidney-stones), and calcification of organs like the heart and kidneys if untreated over a long period of time. Most multivitamins contain 400 IU (10 g) of vitamin D, and single-ingredient vitamin D supplements are available for additional supplementation. Sun exposure, diet, skin color, and [body mass index](../glossary#body-mass-index) (BMI) have variable, substantial impact on body vitamin D levels. To adjust for individual differences and ensure adequate body vitamin D status, the Linus Pauling Institute recommends aiming for a serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration of at least 30 ng/mL (75 nmol/L). [Observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) suggest that serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations between 30 ng/mL and 60 ng/mL are associated with lower [risks](../glossary#risk) of adverse health outcomes, including [cancers](../glossary#cancer) and [autoimmune diseases](../glossary#autoimmune-disease). The American Academy of Pediatrics currently suggests that all infants, children, and adolescents receive 400 IU of supplemental vitamin D daily [(19)](#reference19). Consistent with the recommendations of the Endocrine Society [(40)](#reference40), the Linus Pauling Institute recommends daily intakes of 400 to 1,000 IU (10 to 25 g) of vitamin D in infants and 600 to 1,000 IU (15 to 25 g) of vitamin D in children and adolescents. Given the average vitamin D content of breast milk, infant formula, and the diets of children and adolescents, supplementation may be necessary to meet these recommendations. Daily supplementation with 2,000 IU (50 g) of vitamin D is especially important for older adults because aging is associated with a reduced capacity to [synthesize](../glossary#synthesis) vitamin D in the skin upon sun exposure. Traber, Ph.D. [The term vitamin E describes a family of eight fat-soluble molecules with ] [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) activities: four tocopherol isoforms (-, -, -, and -tocopherol) and four tocotrienol isoforms (-, -, -, and -tocotrienol) (Figure 1). Only one form, -tocopherol, meets human vitamin E requirements (see [The RDA](#RDA)). In the human liver, -tocopherol is the form of vitamin E that is preferentially bound to -tocopherol transfer protein (-TTP) and incorporated into [lipoproteins](../glossary#lipoprotein) that transport -tocopherol in the blood for delivery to extrahepatic tissues. Therefore, it is the predominant form of vitamin E found in the blood and tissues [(1)](#references). In addition, -tocopherol appears to be the form of vitamin E with the greatest nutritional significance, such that it will be the primary topic of the following discussion. Natural -tocopherol made by plants found in food has an RRR-configuration at the 2, 4', and 8'-position of the -tocopherol molecule (wrongly referred to as d--tocopherol) (see [Figure 1](#figure-1)). Chemically synthesized all-rac--tocopherol (all-racemic--tocopherol; incorrectly labeled dl--tocopherol) is a mixture of eight stereoisomers of -tocopherol, which arose from the three chiral equal [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) activity, only the forms in the R-conformation at position 2 (noted 2R) meet the vitamin E requirements in humans [(2)](#reference2). The main function of -tocopherol in humans is that of a fat-soluble [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant). Fats, which are an integral part of all [cell membranes](../glossary#cell-membrane), are vulnerable to damage through [lipid peroxidation](../glossary#lipid-peroxidation) by [free radicals](../glossary#free-radical). -Tocopherol is uniquely suited to intercept peroxyl radicals and thus prevent a chain reaction of [lipid](../glossary#lipid) [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) (Figure 2). When a molecule of -tocopherol neutralizes a free radical, it is oxidized and its antioxidant capacity is lost. Other antioxidants, such as [vitamin C](vitamin-C), are capable of regenerating the antioxidant capacity of -tocopherol (Figure 2) (reviewed in [1](#references)). Aside from maintaining the integrity of cell membranes throughout the body, -tocopherol protects the fats in low-density lipoproteins ( [LDLs](../glossary#LDL)) from oxidation. Lipoproteins are particles composed of lipids and [proteins](../glossary#protein) that transport fats through the bloodstream. LDLs specifically transport [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) from the liver to the tissues of the body. Oxidized LDLs have been implicated in the development of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) [(3)](#reference3). Other functions of -tocopherol are likely to be related to its [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) capacity [(1)](#references). For instance, -tocopherol can protect the physiological properties of [lipid](../glossary#lipid) bilayer membranes and may influence the activity of membrane [proteins](../glossary#protein) and [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) [(4)](#reference4). In cell culture studies, -tocopherol was found to improve the formation of an adhesive junction (known as immune synapse) between naïve T [lymphocytes](../glossary#lymphocyte) and [antigen](../glossary#antigen)-presenting cells (APC), which eventually prompted cell activation and [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) (see [Disease Prevention](#aging-immune-function)) [(5, 6)](#reference5). Vitamin E forms other than -tocopherol are also known to be potent [antioxidants](../glossary#antioxidant). Tocotrienols and -tocopherol are thought to be better scavengers of peroxyl radicals and [reactive nitrogen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species), respectively, than -tocopherol [(7)](#reference7). Yet, in the body, (1) -tocopherol is preferentially retained in the liver by the binding to -tocopherol transfer protein (-TTP), which incorporates -tocopherol into [lipoproteins](../glossary#lipoprotein) for delivery to extrahepatic tissues; and (2) forms of vitamin E other than -tocopherol are actively [metabolized](../glossary#metabolism) and [excreted](../glossary#excretion). Hence, while -tocopherol is the most common form of vitamin E in the American diet [(8)](#reference8), its [plasma](../glossary#plasma) and tissue concentrations are generally significantly lower than those of -tocopherol, and more -tocopherol is excreted in urine than -tocopherol, suggesting less -tocopherol is needed for use by the body [(1)](#references). Studies conducted [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) and in animals have indicated that -tocopherol and its major metabolite, -carboxyethyl hydroxychroman (-CEHC), may play a role in protecting the body from [free radical](../glossary#free-radical)-induced damage in various conditions of [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) and (reviewed in [7](#reference7)). Limited [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) (highlighted in [7](#reference7)) have not convincingly demonstrated a potential anti-inflammatory effect of -tocopherol in humans. Yet, in two recent [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled studies, the supplementation of smokers with -tocopherol potentiated short-term benefits of smoking cessation (with or without nicotine replacement therapy) on [vascular endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) function [(9, 10)](#reference9). Numerous preclinical studies have also suggested that tocotrienols might be beneficial in the prevention of [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease) [(11)](#reference11). For instance, tocotrienols (especially -tocotrienol) have [proliferative](../glossary#proliferation) and pro- [apoptotic](../glossary#apoptosis) effects than tocopherols in [malignant](../glossary#malignant) cell lines [(12)](#reference12). However, a number of factors, including dose, formulation, and type of study population, affect the [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of tocotrienols and may undermine their putative efficacy in humans [(13)](#reference13). There are currently no data available on the effectiveness of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) tocotrienols in humans [(11)](#reference11). The mechanism of vitamin E digestion and uptake into intestinal cells ( [enterocytes](../glossary#enterocyte)) is unclear but requires [bile acids](../glossary#bile-acids) and [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme), and the packaging along with dietary fat into [chylomicrons](../glossary#chylomicron). The efficiency of vitamin E absorption increases with the amount of fat in ingested food, such that vitamin E absorption from supplements is likely to be minimal with low-fat meals [(14, 15)](#reference14). In the circulation, all [lipoproteins](../glossary#lipoprotein) (i.e., VLDLs, [LDLs](../glossary#LDL), and [HDLs](../glossary#HDL)) are involved in the transport and tissue distribution of -tocopherol [(1)](#references). Increased concentrations of [lipids](../glossary#lipid) ( [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) and [triglycerides](../glossary#triglycerides)) the blood have been correlated to higher [serum](../glossary#serum) -tocopherol concentrations. However, if a high blood concentration of lipids is associated with a slower turnover of lipoproteins, then the distribution of -tocopherol to tissues may be substantially altered [(16)](#reference16). A few human studies using conditions of [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) have demonstrated the importance of [vitamin C](vitamin-C) (ascorbic acid) in the recycling of [oxidized](../glossary#oxidation) -tocopherol back to its reduced state (see [Figure 2](#figure-2)). Oxidative stress caused by cigarette smoking accelerates the depletion of [plasma](../glossary#plasma) -tocopherol in smokers compared to nonsmokers [(17)](#reference17). In a [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 11 smokers and 13 nonsmokers given -tocopherol and -tocopherol that was labeled with deuterium (hence traceable), supplementation with vitamin C reduced the rate of vitamin E loss in plasma, most probably by regenerating tocopheryl radicals back to nonoxidized forms [(18)](#reference18). One study in adults with normal coagulation (clotting) status found that daily supplementation with 1,000 IU (670 mg) of RRR--tocopherol for 12 weeks decreased -carboxylation of prothrombin, a [vitamin K](vitamin-K)-dependent factor in the [coagulation](../glossary#coagulation) cascade [(19)](#reference19). Individuals taking [anticoagulant](../glossary#anticoagulant) drugs like warfarin and those who are vitamin K deficient should not take vitamin E [supplements](../glossary#supplement) without medical supervision because of the increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of bleeding (see [Safety](#safety)) [(20)](#reference20). Severe vitamin E deficiency rarely occurs in humans but has been observed as a result of malnutrition [(21)](#reference21). Severe vitamin E deficiency has been associated with specific genetic defects affecting the transport of -tocopherol by -tocopherol transfer protein (-TTP) and [lipoproteins](../glossary#lipoprotein). Vitamin E deficiency has also been observed in individuals with fat [malabsorption syndromes](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome), which impair the absorption of dietary fats and therefore fat-soluble vitamins like vitamin E (see [Nutrient interactions](#nutrient-interactions)) [(21)](#reference21). Severe vitamin E deficiency results mainly in [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) symptoms, including impaired balance and coordination (spinocerebellar [ataxia](../glossary#ataxia)), injury to the sensory nerves ( [peripheral neuropathy](../glossary#peripheral-neuropathy)), muscle weakness ( [myopathy](../glossary#myopathy)), and damage to the [retina](../glossary#retina) of the eye (retinopathy). For this reason, people who develop peripheral neuropathy, ataxia, or retinitis pigmentosa (RP) of unknown causes should be screened for vitamin E deficiency [(21)](#reference21). The results of one [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 601 patients with common forms of RP indicated that daily [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with 400 IU of all-rac--tocopherol (180 mg of RRR--tocopherol) modestly but significantly increased the loss of retinal function [(22)](#reference22). In contrast, daily supplementation with 15,000 IU of vitamin A (4,500 g RAE) significantly slowed the loss of retinal function over a period of four to six years, suggesting that patients with common forms of RP may benefit from long-term vitamin A supplementation but should avoid high-dose supplemental vitamin E. Inherited defects in -TTP are associated with a characteristic syndrome called AVED (Ataxia with Vitamin E Deficiency). A recent case study reported that visual impairment in a middle-age patient with AVED was caused by both RP and early-onset macular degeneration [(23)](#reference23). Supplementation with high-dose vitamin E used to prevent neurologic deterioration in AVED subjects [(21)](#reference21). Moreover, the developing nervous system appears to be especially vulnerable to vitamin E deficiency. For instance, children with severe vitamin E deficiency at birth rapidly experience irreversible neurologic symptoms if not treated with vitamin E. In contrast, individuals who develop [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) disorders affecting vitamin E absorption in adulthood may not develop neurologic symptoms for 10-20 years [(21)](#reference21). It should also be noted that neurologic symptoms caused by vitamin E deficiency have not been reported in healthy individuals who consume diets low in vitamin E. Although frank vitamin E deficiency is rare, marginal intake of vitamin E is relatively common. Between 1988 and 1994, the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey III (NHANES III) examined the dietary intake and blood concentrations of -tocopherol in 16,295 adults. The study reported that about one-third of all participants had blood concentrations of -tocopherol below 20 micromoles/liter (mol/L) — a cutoff value chosen because of its initial association with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) [(24)](#reference24). More recent data from 18,063 participants in NHANES 2003-2006 indicated an average dietary intake of -tocopherol from food (including enriched and [fortified](../glossary#fortification) sources) among Americans adults of 7.2 mg/day [(25)](#reference25). This intake is well below the current recommended dietary allowance of 15 mg/day (see [the RDA](#RDA)). At this level of dietary intake, more than 93% of American adults do not meet the estimated average requirement ( [EAR](../glossary#EAR)) of 12 mg/day for vitamin E [(25)](#reference25). The RDA is based largely on the results of studies done in the 1950s in men fed vitamin E-deficient diets. In a test-tube analysis, vitamin E suppresses the breakdown of red blood cells (known as [hemolysis](../glossary#hemolysis)) induced by hydrogen peroxide. Because hemolysis has also been reported in children with severe vitamin E deficiency, the preventive effect of vitamin E against oxidative damage-induced hemolysis was considered to be a clinically relevant [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) analysis to assess vitamin E status. Importantly, this means that the latest RDA for vitamin E continues to be based on the prevention of deficiency symptoms rather than on health promotion and prevention of [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease). The results of several [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) that examined the association between vitamin E consumption and the incidence or severity of cataracts are also mixed. Some reported that increased vitamin E intake protected against cataract development, while others found no association [(65)](#reference65). Yet, a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of eight studies, including 15,021 participants, found a 17% reduction in the risk of age-related cataract in subjects in the highest versus lowest quantile of dietary vitamin E intake [(66)](#reference66). [(67)](#reference67) — found no association between supplemental vitamin E and risk of cataract [(66)](#reference66). In clinical settings, the supplementation of high-dose vitamin E — alone or in addition to other supplements — was found to be safe, yet the benefits regarding cataract risk or progression were limited. An early intervention trial found that a daily supplement of 50 mg of synthetic -tocopherol (equivalent to 25 mg of RRR--tocopherol) did not alter the incidence of cataract surgery in male smokers [(68)](#reference68). [Oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) contributes to the progression of type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) and causes damage to many organs and tissues, including the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas), brain, eyes, peripheral nerves, and kidneys. Evidence from animal studies suggests that vitamin E supplementation could mitigate the role of [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) in the occurrence of diabetes complications (reviewed in [77](#reference77)). In the Alpha-Tocopherol Beta-Carotene cancer prevention (ATBC) trial in male smokers, supplementation with 50 mg/day of synthetic -tocopherol (25 mg/day of RRR--tocopherol) had no effect on the risk of incident type 2 diabetes mellitus during the 19-year post-intervention follow-up. The increasing incidence of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in children and adults in industrialized countries is mainly attributed to the ongoing epidemic of [obesity](../glossary#obesity) and type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus). NAFLD results from the abnormal accumulation of fat (steatosis) in the liver in the absence of heavy alcohol consumption. Although the condition is considered to be largely benign, NAFLD can progress to a more severe disease called nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) with increased [risks](../glossary#risk) [Oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) is thought to be one of the possible mechanisms responsible for prompting [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) processes that can lead to the progression of NAFLD to NASH. There is currently no established treatment for NAFLD and NASH other than interventions that encourage lifestyle changes and the use of medicines to control or treat metabolic disorders [(82)](#reference82). In the multicenter PIVENS (PIoglitazone versus Vitamin E versus placebo for the treatment of Nonalcoholic Steatohepatitis) trial, 247 nondiabetic subjects with NASH were [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) to receive 30 mg/day of pioglitazone (an insulin-sensitizing IU/day (536 RRR--tocopherol, or a [placebo](../glossary#placebo) for 96 weeks [(83)](#reference83). Only vitamin E supplementation significantly increased the overall rate of improvement in [histological](../glossary#histology) abnormalities that characterize NASH on liver biopsies (i.e., hepatocellular ballooning, steatosis, and lobular [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation)) [(84)](#reference84). Both active treatments improved some markers of liver function (i.e., alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase) [(84)](#reference84). Yet, results from another two-year, [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) — called TONIC for Treatment Of Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease In Children — in 173 children (ages, 8-17 years) with NAFLD failed to observe any significant reduction in blood concentrations of alanine and aspartate aminotransferases either with supplemental vitamin E or with metformin (an anti-diabetic drug; mg/day) compared to placebo [(85)](#reference85). However, vitamin E supplementation significantly improved the overall disease activity score — used to quantify the severity of the disease. In addition, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of another six trials found that vitamin E significantly lowered circulating aminotransferase concentrations in NAFLD and NASH patients, suggesting liver function improvements [(86)](#reference86). Finally, in a small nonrandomized, unblinded, controlled study in 42 obese children (mean age, 8 years) with NAFLD, lifestyle recommendations combined with 600 mg/day of supplemental RRR--tocopheryl acetate for six months reduced markers of oxidative stress and liver dysfunction and improved [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) and the profile of lipid in the blood, when compared to baseline. No such changes in markers of oxidative stress, liver function, and glucose utilization were reported in the lifestyle intervention only group [(87)](#reference87). Further randomized and well-controlled studies are needed to confirm these preliminary findings. [Mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) dysfunction and [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) are thought to contribute to the onset and/or progression of several [neurodegenerative diseases](../glossary#neurodegenerative-disease), especially [Alzheimer's disease](../glossary#alzheimer-disease) (AD) [(88)](#reference88). The progressive degeneration of [neuronal](../glossary#neuron) cells that accompanies the decline of memory and other [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) functions in subjects with Alzheimer's disease is associated with an intracellular aggregation of Tau fibrils, an extraneuronal accumulation [reduction](../glossary#reduction) ( [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction)) imbalance of complex [etiology](../glossary#etiology). In the brain of patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and those with AD, the level of markers of oxidative damage to [DNA](../glossary#DNA), [proteins](../glossary#protein), and [lipids](../glossary#lipid) is increased, while the expression and activities of [glutathione](../glossary#glutathione) and [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) are reduced (reviewed in [88](#reference88)). In addition, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) reported that circulating concentrations of vitamins, including vitamin A, vitamin C, and vitamin E, were significantly lower in AD patients than in cognitively healthy individuals [(89)](#reference89). Other studies have documented low concentrations of vitamin E in [cerebrospinal fluid](../glossary#cerebrospinal-fluid) of cognitively impaired patients (reviewed in [90](#reference90)). Because a reduction in oxidative stress may help maintain cognitive status and/or prevent deterioration, the effects of vitamin E supplementation have been assessed in a few [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial). An early multicenter, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in individuals with AD of moderate severity found that supplementation with 2,000 IU/day of all-rac--tocopherol (equivalent to 900 mg/day of RRR--tocopherol) for two years significantly delayed cognitive decline, slowed disease progression, and increased median survival [(91)](#reference91). However, a placebo-controlled trial in 769 patients with MCI found that the same dosage of vitamin E did not affect the probability of progression from MCI to AD over a three-year period [(92)](#reference92). In another [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), placebo-controlled trial, an improvement in cognitive performance — measured by the Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) scoring system — was reported in AD patients randomized to receive 800 IU/day of all-rac--tocopherol (360 mg/day of RRR--tocopherol) for six months only when the treatment effectively reduced oxidative stress (as assessed by the measure of total glutathione and markers of [lipid peroxidation](../glossary#lipid-peroxidation) in the blood) [(93)](#reference93). Conversely, a failure to reduce oxidative stress resulted in supplemental vitamin E being more detrimental to the cognitive function of AD patients than placebo. In the most recent multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study, supplemental vitamin E (2,000 IU/day; form of vitamin E not mentioned in the publication) for over two years significantly delayed functional decline — determined by the (in)ability to perform basic activities of daily living — and reduced the annual mortality rate in mild and moderate AD patients [(94)](#reference94). Yet, vitamin E failed to affect cognitive performance measured with MMSE scores and other cognitive ability tests. While there is currently little evidence to suggest that long-term supplementation of vitamin E provides any cognitive benefits in healthy older adults [(95)](#reference95), additional research needs to confirm whether vitamin E supplementation could benefit the management of patients with mild-to-moderate cognitive impairments. Vitamin E supplements generally contain 100 IU to 1,000 IU of -tocopherol. Supplements made from entirely natural sources contain only RRR--tocopherol (wrongly labeled d--tocopherol). RRR--tocopherol is the most [bioavailable](../glossary#bioavailability) form of -tocopherol in the body. Synthetic -tocopherol, which is often found in [fortified](../glossary#fortification) food and nutritional supplements and usually labeled all-rac--tocopherol or dl--tocopherol, include all eight possible stereoisomers of -tocopherol (see [Function](#Function)). Because half of the [isomers](../glossary#isomer) present as a mixture in synthetic -tocopherol are not usable by the body, synthetic -tocopherol is less bioavailable than natural -tocopherol (see [Figure 1](#figure-1)).
