The most stable ] [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) state of chromium in biological systems is trivalent chromium (Cr3+), which forms relatively inert complexes with [proteins](../glossary#protein) and [nucleic acids](../glossary#nucleic-acid) [(1)](#references). The essentiality of trivalent chromium is questioned, and its proposed function in the body remains poorly understood. In fact, in 2014 the European Food Safety Authority concluded that a dietary requirement — or even an [Adequate Intake](../glossary#AI) — cannot be set for trivalent chromium as no conclusive evidence exists that chromium is essential at any dietary intake [(2)](#reference2). Trivalent chromium appears to have health effects only at [pharmacological doses](../glossary#pharmacological-dose) (reviewed in [3](#reference3)), and a dietary deficiency of the mineral has not been observed. Another common and stable form of chromium in the environment is hexavalent chromium (Cr6+). Hexavalent chromium is derived from trivalent chromium by heating at [alkaline](../glossary#alkaline) [pH](../glossary#pH) and is used as a source of chromium for industrial purposes. Hexavalent chromium is highly toxic and is classified as a human [carcinogen](../glossary#carcinogen) when inhaled [(4)](#reference4). In the [acidic](../glossary#acidic) environment of the stomach, hexavalent chromium can be readily reduced to trivalent chromium by reducing substances present in food, which limits the ingestion of hexavalent chromium [(5-7)](#reference5). Trivalent chromium has been proposed to be the [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) for a biologically active molecule that could enhance the effects of [insulin](../glossary#insulin) on target tissues. Insulin is secreted by specialized cells in the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas) in response to increased blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentration, such as after a meal. Insulin binds to insulin [receptors](../glossary#receptor) on the surface of cells, activating the receptors and stimulating glucose uptake by cells. Through its interaction with insulin receptors, insulin provides cells with glucose for energy and helps maintain blood glucose within a narrow range of concentrations. In addition to its effects on [carbohydrate](../glossary#carbohydrate) (glucose) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), insulin also influences the metabolism of fat and [protein](../glossary#protein) [(8)](#reference8). Together, a decreased response to insulin or decreased [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitivity) in peripheral tissues ( [adipose tissue](../glossary#adipose), muscle, and liver) and a progressive defect in insulin secretion may result in [impaired glucose tolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance), frequently leading to overt type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus). The body initially increases the secretion of insulin by specialized pancreatic cells to overcome the decrease in insulin sensitivity. However, the pancreas eventually fails to produce enough insulin to maintain normal blood glucose concentrations. Individuals with type 2 diabetes are at increased risk for [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) [(9)](#reference9). The precise composition and structure of the biologically active form of chromium is not known. One model postulates that trivalent chromium might be the [cofactor](#cofactor) of a low-molecular-weight chromium-binding substance known as LMWCr or chromodulin [(10)](#reference10). Chromodulin has been shown to play a role in the transport of chromium from the tissues to the bloodstream for ultimate elimination in the urine [(11)](#reference11). When chromium is consumed at high levels, such as from dietary supplements, levels of chromodulin in tissues rise. At these high levels, chromodulin is proposed to enhance the cascade of signaling events induced by the binding of [insulin](../glossary#insulin) to extracellular -subunit of the insulin receptor (IR) [(12)](#reference12). Upon insulin binding, the tyrosine kinase domain of the intracellular -subunit of the IR becomes activated and causes the [phosphorylation](../glossary#phosphorylation) of tyrosine residues in the -subunit itself. Subsequently, IR activation triggers a series of rapid phosphorylation reactions that activate many downstream effectors, eventually resulting in an increase in glucose uptake and storage [(10)](#reference10). While this model is supported by [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) studies, this mode of action for chromodulin has not been confirmed to date by [in vivo](../glossary#in-vivo) studies. Some, but not all, studies conducted in cell-based and animal models of [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance) and [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) have found that chromium inhibits the activity of protein tyrosine phosphatase-1B (PTP-1B) and other negative regulators of insulin signaling, suggesting that chromium might improve insulin sensitivity under insulin-resistant conditions (reviewed in [10](#reference10)). A study in diabetic mice also suggested that chromium may reduce insulin clearance and enhance insulin signaling by inhibiting the [proteolysis](../glossary#proteolysis) (degradation) of insulin and some downstream effectors [(13)](#reference13). Additional mechanisms that may underlie the effect of chromium on insulin sensitivity, such as the reduction of markers of [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) and [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) known to contribute to insulin resistance, are under investigation (reviewed in [10](#reference10), [14](#reference14)). Chromium competes for one of the binding sites on the iron transport [protein](../glossary#protein), transferrin. However, supplementation of older men with 925 g/day of chromium for 12 weeks did not significantly affect measures of iron nutritional [status](../glossary#status) [(15)](#reference15). A study of younger men found an insignificant decrease in transferrin saturation with iron after supplementation of 200 g/day of chromium for eight weeks, but no long-term studies have addressed this issue [(16)](#reference16). In a 12-week, [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), supplementation with chromium picolinate (200 g/day) did not affect iron nutritional status in premenopausal women when compared to picolinic acid or [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(17)](#reference17). Iron overload in [hereditary hemochromatosis](../glossary#hereditary-hemochromatosis) may interfere with chromium transport by competing for transferrin binding. It has been [hypothesized](../glossary#hypothesis) that decreased chromium transport might contribute to the [pathogenesis](../glossary#pathogenesis) of [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) in patients with hereditary hemochromatosis [(5)](#reference5). Chromium uptake is enhanced in animals when given at the same time as [vitamin C](../vitamins/vitamin-C) [(7)](#reference7). In a study of three women, administration of 100 mg of vitamin C together with 1 mg of chromium resulted in higher [plasma](../glossary#plasma) levels of chromium than 1 mg of chromium without vitamin C [(5)](#reference5). Compared to diets rich in complex [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) (e.g., whole grains), diets high in simple sugars (e.g., sucrose) result in increased urinary chromium [excretion](../glossary#excretion) in adults. This effect may be related to increased [insulin](../glossary#insulin) secretion in response to the consumption of simple sugars compared to complex carbohydrates [(5)](#reference5). Dietary chromium deficiency has not been observed in humans. Potential cases of chromium deficiency were thought to have been observed in a few patients on long-term [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) feeding ( [parenteral nutrition](../glossary#parenteral-nutrition)) who did not receive [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) chromium in their intravenous solutions. The subjects developed abnormal [glucose](../glossary#glucose) utilization and increased [insulin](../glossary#insulin) requirements that responded to chromium supplementation [(18)](#reference18). However, because intravenous solutions provide chromium at doses well above dietary levels, it has been suggested that chromium might produce biological effects only at [pharmacological doses](../glossary#pharmacological-dose) [(3](#reference3), [14)](#reference14). However, the differences in symptoms among subjects, the range of doses of chromium utilized over varying windows of time, and the different reported outcomes are now realized to make interpretation of these results difficult, even in terms of any potential pharmacological effects from the chromium supplementation. Because chromium appeared to enhance the action of insulin and chromium deficiency has been proposed to result in impaired glucose tolerance, chromium insufficiency has been [hypothesized](../glossary#hypothesis) to be a contributing factor to the development of type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) [(5](#reference5), [19)](#reference19). However, evidence for this is ambiguous at best. Urinary chromium loss was reportedly increased by endurance exercise in male runners, suggesting that chromium needs may be greater in individuals who exercise regularly [(20)](#reference20). In one study, weightlifting (resistive exercise) was found to increase urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of chromium in older men. However, chromium absorption also increased, leading to little or no net loss of chromium as a result of resistive exercise [(21)](#reference21). The absence of animal models for chromium deficiency makes it difficult to study possible biochemical, physiological, and functional abnormalities associated with inadequate intakes of chromium (if chromium is nutritionally essential) [(2)](#reference2). Because there was not enough information to set an estimated average requirement ( [EAR](../glossary#EAR)), the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the US Institute of Medicine (now the National Academy of Medicine) established an adequate intake ( [AI](../glossary#AI)) based on the chromium content younger||-||44| and older||-||45| The case of trivalent chromium essentiality has been questioned in both animals and humans in the last decades, and in 2014 the European Food Safety Authority's Panel on Dietetic Products, Nutrition, and Allergies — which provides dietary guidelines for the EU community — concluded that requirements for chromium could not be established [(2)](#reference2). The FNB, which sets dietary intake recommendations for the United States and Canada, is not currently reconsidering the AI level for chromium [(22)](#reference22). Early controlled studies in subjects with [impaired glucose tolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance) reported that chromium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) improved some measure of [glucose](../glossary#glucose) utilization or had beneficial effects on blood [lipid](../glossary#lipid) profiles [(23)](#reference23). Impaired glucose tolerance refers to a prediabetic state and is currently defined by the presence of impaired fasting glucose (fasting [plasma](../glossary#plasma) glucose concentration of 100-125 mg/dL) and impaired glucose tolerance status (plasma glucose concentration of 140-199 mg/dL during a two-hour challenge test with a 75-g oral glucose load) [(24)](#reference24). Impaired glucose tolerance is associated with modest increases in risk of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease), as well as other traditional microvascular complications of diabetes mellitus [(25)](#reference25). Current estimates suggest that up to 70% of individuals with impaired glucose tolerance eventually develop type 2 diabetes [(26)](#reference26). In a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in 56 subjects at risk of developing type 2 diabetes, six months of daily chromium picolinate supplementation (500 g or 1,000 g) had no effect on glucose and [insulin](../glossary#insulin) concentrations, [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitivity), and blood lipid profiles [(27)](#reference27). Another randomized, placebo-controlled trial in 31 individuals without diabetes reported a great variability in [serum](../glossary#serum) and urinary chromium concentrations in response to a daily supplementation with 1,000 g of chromium picolinate for 16 weeks. Also, in the chromium-supplemented group, participants with higher vs. lower serum chromium concentrations (>3.1 g/L vs. 3.1 g/L) exhibited a decline in insulin sensitivity that could not be explained by expression changes in the [genes](../glossary#gene) involved in insulin signaling [(28)](#reference28). Additionally, a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine randomized [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) published between 1992 and 2010 reported that chromium at doses of 200-1,000 g/day for 8-16 weeks had no effect on fasting glucose concentrations in 309 individuals without diabetes [(29)](#reference29). [Impaired glucose tolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance) and type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) are associated with adverse changes in [lipid](../glossary#lipid) profiles and increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease). Studies examining the effects of chromium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) on lipid profiles have given inconsistent results. While some studies have observed reductions in serum total [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol), [LDL](../glossary#LDL)-cholesterol, and [triglyceride](../glossary#triglyceride) levels or increases in [HDL](../glossary#HDL)-cholesterol levels, others have observed no effect. Such mixed responses of lipid and [lipoprotein](../glossary#lipoprotein) levels to chromium supplementation may reflect differences in chromium nutritional [status](../glossary#status). It is possible that only individuals with insufficient dietary intake of chromium will experience beneficial effects on lipid profiles after chromium supplementation [(6, 7](#reference6), [30)](#reference30). Moreover, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 10 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), mostly in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus or metabolic syndrome, found chromium supplementation had no effect on either systolic or diastolic blood pressure [(31)](#reference31). Yet, another meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials found chromium supplementation decreased circulating levels of two proinflammatory [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) associated with increased cardiovascular risk, hs-CRP and TNF-, but not blood levels of IL-6 [(32)](#reference32). Claims that chromium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) increases lean body mass and decreases body fat are based on the relationship between chromium and [insulin](../glossary#insulin) action (see [Function](#function)). In addition to regulating [glucose](../glossary#glucose) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), insulin is known to affect fat and [protein](../glossary#protein) metabolism [(8)](#reference8). At least 12 [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled studies have compared the effect of chromium supplementation (172-1,000 g/day of chromium as chromium picolinate) with or without an exercise program on lean body mass and measures of body fat (reviewed in [33](#reference33)). In general, the studies that used the most sensitive and accurate methods of measuring body fat and lean mass ( [dual energy x-ray absorbtiometry](../glossary#DEXA) or DEXA and hydrodensitometry or underwater weighing) did not find a beneficial effect of chromium supplementation on body composition [(6](#reference6), [30)](#reference30). In the US, the claim that chromium picolinate increases lean body mass is not allowed on supplement labels because it is not substantiated by the available research [(34, 35)](#reference34). Controlled studies of chromium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) have demonstrated little if any beneficial effect on weight or fat loss, and claims of weight loss in humans appear to be exaggerated. In 1996, the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) ruled that there was no scientific basis for claims that chromium picolinate could promote weight loss and fat loss in humans [(36)](#reference36). A 2013 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 11 [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials in 866 overweight or obese subjects found a significant 0.50-kilogram (1.10-pound) reduction in body weight with supplemental chromium (most exclusively in the form of chromium picolinate) at doses between 137 g/day and 1,000 g/day for 8 to 24 weeks [(37)](#reference37). However, such a small change did not reach a clinically significant weight loss of 5% of the initial body weight [(38)](#reference38). A 2019 meta-analysis of 19 clinical trials found similar results: chromium supplementation at doses between 20 g/day and 1,000 g/day for 4 to 24 weeks decreased body weight in overweight or obese subjects by only 0.75 kg, a clinically insignificant amount [(39)](#reference39). Some reports have suggested that supplemental chromium may reduce food craving and intake in overweight or obese women [(40, 41)](#reference40). Yet, current available data remain insufficient to support the use of chromium supplements as a weight-loss strategy [(42)](#reference42). In the US, the claim that chromium picolinate promotes weight loss is not allowed on supplement labels because it is unsubstantiated [(34, 35)](#reference34). Despite stating that scientific evidence is severely limited, the US FDA allows a single claim on supplement labels: "One small study suggests that chromium picolinate may reduce the risk of insulin resistance, and therefore possibly may reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes. FDA concludes, however, that the existence of such a relationship between chromium picolinate and either insulin resistance or type 2 diabetes is highly uncertain." [(35](#reference35), [43)](#reference43). Type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) is characterized [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia) (elevated blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentration) and [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance). Because resistance to [insulin](../glossary#insulin) is usually associated with a compensatory rise in insulin secretion, circulating insulin concentrations in people with type 2 diabetes may be higher than in healthy individuals. Yet, the resistance of peripheral tissues (especially liver and skeletal muscle) to insulin also implies that the physiological effects of insulin are reduced. Since cell culture and rodent models of diabetes have implicated chromium in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and blood glucose levels, the relationship between chromium nutritional [status](../glossary#status) and type 2 diabetes mellitus has generated considerable scientific interest. Early reports observed that individuals with overt type 2 diabetes for over two years had higher rates of urinary chromium loss than healthy individuals [(44)](#reference44). Small, well-designed studies of chromium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) in individuals with type 2 diabetes showed no improvement in blood glucose control, although they provided some evidence of reduced insulin concentrations and improved blood [lipid](../glossary#lipid) profiles [(45)](#reference45). In 1997, the results of a [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial conducted in China indicated that chromium supplementation might be beneficial in the treatment of type 2 diabetes [(46)](#reference46). One hundred and eighty participants were [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) to receive either a placebo or chromium supplements in the form of chromium picolinate at either 200 g/day or 1,000 g/day. After four months of treatment, fasting blood glucose concentrations were found to be 15% to 19% lower in those who took 1,000 g/day of chromium compared to those who took the placebo. Yet, blood glucose concentrations in those taking 200 g/day of chromium did not differ significantly from those who took placebo. Chromium picolinate at either 200 g/day or 1,000 g/day was also associated with reduced insulin concentrations compared to placebo. The level of [glycated hemoglobin](../glossary#glycated-hemoglobin) A1c (HbA1c), a measure of glycemic control over the past four months, was also significantly reduced in both chromium-supplemented groups. However, a number of limitations made it difficult to extrapolate the results to the US population [(47)](#reference47). Besides, the study was excluded from [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) due to insufficient data quality [(29](#reference29), [48)](#reference48). In a recent [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials in patients with type 2 diabetes, chromium supplementation (50-1,000 g/day for 4 to 25 weeks) reduced concentrations of fasting [plasma](../glossary#plasma) glucose (23 trials) and insulin (14 trials), and improved HbA1c values (18 trials) [(49)](#reference49). These effects were not dose dependent [(49)](#reference49). Yet, other meta-analyses in patients with type 2 diabetes did not find significant benefits of chromium supplementation on fasting glucose and insulin [(50)](#reference50) or HbA1C [(51)](#reference51). Moreover, a systematic review on 20 randomized controlled trials found that only a handful of chromium supplementation studies resulted in glycemic changes that are considered clinically meaningful, i.e., consistent with treatment goals of a 7.2-mmol/dL decrease in fasting glucose, a decrease of 0.5% in HbA1c, or reaching 7% HbA1c [(52)](#reference52). Few studies have examined the effects of chromium supplementation on [gestational](../glossary#gestation) [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), a condition that is estimated to affect 5.8% to 9.2% of pregnant women in the US [(53)](#reference53). The occurrence of gestational diabetes during pregnancy is associated with insufficient [insulin](../glossary#insulin) secretion and glucose intolerance of variable severity [(54)](#reference54). Peripheral [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance) usually increases in the second or third trimester of pregnancy. Because elevated maternal blood glucose concentrations can have adverse effects on the developing fetus, women with gestational diabetes are at increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of pregnancy complications [(55)](#reference55). After delivery, impaired glucose tolerance generally reverts to normal glucose tolerance. However, nearly one-third of women who have had gestational diabetes develop postpartum glucose intolerance (prediabetes or type 2 diabetes) [(56, 57)](#reference56). The question also arises as to whether low chromium levels might be an effect rather than a contributing factor in gestational diabetes. An [observational study](../glossary#observational-study) in pregnant women did not find [serum](../glossary#serum) chromium levels to be associated with measures of glucose tolerance or insulin resistance in late pregnancy [(58)](#reference58). However, it is not known whether measures of serum chromium levels truly reflect tissue chromium levels and chromium status during pregnancy. A more recent [prospective study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) following 425 pregnant women also failed to find a correlation between serum chromium concentrations and incidence of gestational diabetes [(59)](#reference59). A [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) of 90 pregnant women in southern India found that those with gestational diabetes had significantly lower serum chromium concentrations compared to gestational diabetes-free women. Given the above mixed results, it should be noted that different methods were used to measure circulating chromium concentrations in each study. Also, it is possible that nutritional chromium status may vary among ethnically distinct populations so that studies including pregnant women from different ethnic backgrounds and/or geographical areas would give different results. In addition, there is currently insufficient evidence to evaluate the effect of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) chromium on gestational diabetes. Women with gestational diabetes whose diets were supplemented with 4 g of chromium per kilogram of body weight daily as chromium picolinate for eight weeks had decreased fasting blood glucose and insulin concentrations compared to those who took a [placebo](../glossary#placebo). Yet, insulin therapy rather than chromium picolinate was required to normalize severely elevated blood glucose levels [(6](#reference6), [60)](#reference60). [Metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome) is a combination of medical conditions, including [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure), [dyslipidemia](../glossary#dyslipidemia), central obesity, and [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance), that places one at increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for [cardiovascular type A [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) that followed 3,648 young US adults for 23 years found an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between toenail chromium concentration measured at baseline and risk of developing metabolic syndrome [(61)](#reference61). An inverse association between [plasma](../glossary#plasma) chromium concentration and metabolic syndrome was also observed in a [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) in 4,282 Chinese adults [(62)](#reference62). However, low toenail and plasma chromium may be the result of metabolic syndrome, rather than suggesting a cause or contributing factor. Only a few [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have examined whether chromium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) might benefit patients with metabolic syndrome. In a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 65 patients with metabolic syndrome, 300 g/day of supplemental chromium (from chromium-enriched yeast) for 24 weeks had no effect on measured parameters of [glucose](../glossary#glucose), [insulin](../glossary#insulin), and [lipid](../glossary#lipid) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [(63)](#reference63). While large-scale trials would be needed, there is presently no evidence that chromium can help treat metabolic syndrome. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a common [endocrine](../glossary#endocrine) disorder affecting women of childbearing age, with an estimated worldwide [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of 21% [(64)](#reference64). The disorder has a multifactorial [etiology](../glossary#etiology) and is characterized by menstrual irregularities, polycystic ovaries, and infertility. Similar to metabolic syndrome, women with PCOS often have various metabolic abnormalities, including [dyslipidemia](../glossary#dyslipidemia), [obesity](../glossary#obesity) (especially abdominal obesity), [impaired glucose tolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance), [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance), and are at increased 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) [(65)](#reference65). Several [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have evaluated whether chromium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) might help treat PCOS, but the results are conflicting. A 2017 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of seven clinical trials found that chromium picolinate supplementation (of either 200 g/day or 1,000 ug/day) for 8 to 24 weeks decreased [BMI](../glossary#body-mass-index) (3 studies), lowered free testosterone concentration (5 studies), and decreased fasting [serum](../glossary#serum) [insulin](../glossary#insulin) concentration (5 studies) but had no effect on concentrations of fasting blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) (4 studies), total testosterone (3 studies), luteinizing hormone (3 studies), or follicle-stimulating hormone (2 studies) [(66)](#reference66). However, other recent systematic reviews and meta-analyses have concluded that chromium supplementation in women with PCOS does not result in significant or clinically meaningful health benefits, including with respect to glucose and insulin [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [(67-69)](#reference67). The amount of chromium in food is variable and has been measured accurately in relatively few foods. Presently, there is no large database for the chromium content of food. Whole-grain products, high-bran cereals, green beans, broccoli, nuts, and egg yolk are good sources of chromium. Processed meats may also be high in chromium, depending on the processing equipment and method [(70)](#reference70). Foods high in simple sugars, such as [sucrose](../glossary#sucrose) and [fructose](../glossary#fructose), are usually low in chromium and may actually promote chromium [excretion](../glossary#excretion) [(6](#reference6), [71)](#reference71). Estimated average chromium intakes in the US range from 23 g/day-29 g/day for adult women and 39-54 g/day for adult men [(5)](#reference5). The chromium content of some foods is listed in Table 2 and expressed in micrograms (g) [(72)](#reference72). Since chromium content varies significantly between different batches of the same food, the information provided in the table should serve only as a guide to the chromium content of [supplement](../glossary#supplement) in several forms, including chromium chloride, chromium nicotinate, chromium picolinate, and high-chromium yeast. These are available as stand-alone supplements or in combination products, including multivitamin/mineral supplements. Doses typically range from 100 to 300 g of elemental chromium in single-nutrient supplements and from 10 to 180 g in multivitamin/mineral supplements [(73)](#reference73). Much of the research on [impaired glucose tolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance) and type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) uses chromium picolinate as the source of chromium, although investigations suggest that its [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) may not be greater than that of dietary chromium [(74)](#reference74). Some concerns have been raised over the long-term safety of chromium picolinate supplementation (see [Safety](#safety)). Hexavalent chromium (chromium VI; inhalation causing lung, nasal, and sinus [cancers](../glossary#cancer) [(75)](#reference75). Exposure to hexavalent chromium in dust has been associated with an increased incidence of lung cancer and is known to cause [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) of the skin ( [dermatitis](../glossary#dermatitis)). In contrast, there is little evidence that trivalent chromium (chromium III; Cr3+) is toxic to humans. The toxicity from oral intakes is considered to be low because ingested chromium is poorly absorbed, and most absorbed chromium is rapidly [excreted](../glossary#excretion) in the urine [(76)](#reference76). Because no adverse effects have been convincingly associated with excess intake of trivalent chromium from food or [supplements](../glossary#supplement), the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the Institute of Medicine (now the National Academy of Medicine) did not set a tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for chromium. Yet, despite limited evidence for adverse effects, the FNB acknowledged the possibility of a negative impact of high oral intakes of supplemental trivalent chromium on health and advised caution [(5)](#reference5). Most of the concerns regarding the long-term safety of trivalent chromium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) arise from several studies in cell culture, suggesting trivalent chromium, especially in the form of chromium picolinate, may increase [DNA](../glossary#DNA) damage [(77-80)](#reference77). A study in 10 women taking 400 g/day of chromium as chromium picolinate found no evidence of increased [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) to DNA as measured by [antibodies](../glossary#antibody) to an oxidized DNA base [(81)](#reference81). Many studies have demonstrated the safety of daily doses of up to 1,000 g of chromium for several months [(46](#reference46), [82)](#reference82). However, there have been a few isolated reports of serious adverse reactions to chromium picolinate. Kidney failure was reported five months after a six-week course of 600 g/day of chromium in the form of chromium picolinate [(83)](#reference83), while kidney failure and impaired liver function were reported after the use of 1,200 to 2,400 g/day of chromium in the form of chromium picolinate over a period of four to five months [(84)](#reference84). Additionally, a 24-year old healthy male reportedly developed reversible, acute [renal](../glossary#renal) failure after taking chromium picolinate-containing supplements for two weeks [(85)](#reference85). Individuals with pre-existing kidney or liver disease may be at increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of adverse effects and should limit supplemental chromium intake [(5)](#reference5). Little is known about drug interactions with chromium in humans. Large doses of calcium carbonate or magnesium hydroxide-containing antacids decreased chromium absorption in rats. In contrast, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, aspirin and indomethacin, can increase chromium absorption in rats [(7)](#reference7). The lack of any known indicators of chromium nutritional [status](../glossary#status) in humans makes it difficult to determine the level of chromium intake most likely to promote optimum health, if such exists. Following the Linus Pauling Institute recommendation to take a multivitamin/mineral [supplement](../glossary#supplement) containing 100% of the daily values ( [DV](../glossary#DV)) of most nutrients may provide 10 to 180 g/day of chromium, which is generally considered safe. Although the requirement for chromium is not known to be higher for older adults, one study found that chromium concentrations in hair, sweat, and urine decreased with age [(86)](#reference86). Following the Linus Pauling Institute recommendation to take a multivitamin/mineral [supplement](../glossary#supplement) containing 100% of the daily values ( [DV](../glossary#DV)) of most nutrients should provide sufficient chromium for older adults. Because [impaired glucose tolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance), type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), and [metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome) are associated with serious health problems, individuals with any of these conditions should seek medical advice if considering the use of high-dose chromium supplements.
