Metabolism. 1997;46(5):469-473. ] [(PubMed)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9160809/) Contents Copper (Cu) is an essential trace [element](../glossary#element) for humans and other mammals. In biological systems, copper readily shifts between the cuprous (Cu1+) and cupric (Cu2+) forms. The [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction) properties of copper underlie its important role in [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation)- [reduction](../glossary#reduction) reactions and in [scavenging](../glossary#scavenge) [free radicals](../glossary#free-radicals) [(1)](#references). Although Hippocrates is said to have prescribed copper compounds to treat diseases as early as 400 B.C. [(2)](#reference2), scientists are still uncovering new information regarding the functions of copper in the human body [(3)](#reference3). Copper is critical for the function of several essential [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) known as cuproenzymes, which are integral parts of various metabolic pathways [(4, 5)](#reference4). Physiologic functions of these copper-dependent biochemical pathways in which they function [(6, 7)](#reference6), are outlined below. The copper-dependent [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) cytochrome c oxidase (CCO) plays a critical role in cellular energy production in [mitochondria](../glossary#mitochondria) by catalyzing the [reduction](../glossary#reduction) of molecular oxygen (O2) to water (H2O), thereby generating an electrical gradient that is required for [ATP](../glossary#ATP) production [(8)](#reference8). Redox-active copper contained within the CCO enzyme complex is required for the [electron](../glossary#electron) transfer reactions that are critical for its function. Another cuproenzyme, lysyl oxidase (LOX), is required for the cross-linking of [collagen](../glossary#collagen) and [elastin](../glossary#elastin) fibers, which is essential for the formation of strong and flexible connective tissue. LOX function is critical for bone formation and maintenance of connective tissue in the heart and blood vessels [(2)](#reference2). Multi-copper (Fe2+) to the ferric (Fe3+) form, which enables binding to transferrin (the main iron carrier) in the blood, thus allowing iron transport to sites of utilization (e.g., the bone marrow). The MCOs include: (1) [ceruloplasmin](../glossary#ceruloplasmin) (CP), which contains a membrane-bound form of CP (GPI-CP), expressed in brain and other and (3) the membrane-bound ferroxidases hephaestin (HEPH) and zyklopen, [placenta](../glossary#placenta), respectively [(9, 10)](#reference9). CP knockout (Cp-/-) mice accumulate iron but have normal copper [status](../glossary#status) [(11, 12)](#reference11). Similarly, humans with aceruloplasminemia, who lack functional CP, display iron overload in liver, brain, and [retina](../glossary#retina) but have no observable defects in copper homeostasis [(13)](#reference13). Moreover, absorption of dietary iron and iron mobilization from storage sites (e.g., liver) are impaired in copper deficiency, when CP and HEPH activity is reduced, further supporting a role for the MCOs in iron metabolism [(14)](#reference14). Several physiological processes within the brain and nervous system, including [neurotransmitter](../glossary#neurotransmitter) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) and formation and maintenance of [myelin](../glossary#myelin), depend upon [catalysis](../glossary#catalyze) mediated by cuproenzymes. Dopamine -hydroxylase, for example, catalyzes the conversion of dopamine to the neurotransmitter norepinephrine [(15)](#reference15). Also, CCO is required for the biosynthesis of [phospholipids](../glossary#phospholipid), which are critical structural components of the myelin sheath [(2)](#reference2). The cuproenzyme tyrosinase (TYR) is required for the biosynthesis of [melanin](../glossary#melanin) in melanocytes, which is critical for normal pigmentation of hair, skin, and eyes [(2)](#reference2). Low TYR activity most likely explains the achromotrichia seen in copper-deficient laboratory and agricultural animals, and the depigmentation noted in severely copper-depleted patients with Menkes disease. Superoxide dismutase (SOD) functions as [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) by [catalyzing](../glossary#catalyze) the [reactive oxygen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species), such as the superoxide anion (O2-) and the hydroxyl radical (OH), to hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), which is subsequently reduced to water by other antioxidant systems [(16)](#reference16). Two forms of SOD contain copper: copper/zinc SOD (SOD1), which is expressed in cells, including red blood cells; and extracellular SOD (EcSOD), which is highly expressed in the lungs and found at lower levels in [plasma](../glossary#plasma) [(2)](#reference2). Also, as outlined above, ceruloplasmin has antioxidant properties relating to [iron](iron) metabolism. The ferroxidase activity of ceruloplasmin may prevent ferrous iron (Fe2+) from participating in harmful free-radical-generating reactions via Fenton chemistry [(16)](#reference16). Copper-related gene expression pathways seem to be mainly regulated at a post- [translation](../glossary#translation) level, in some cases via [protein](../glossary#protein) trafficking-related mechanisms that respond to intracellular copper levels [(17)](#reference17). Cytosolic copper may also influence [mRNA](../glossary#mRNA) expression levels of specific genes, in a dose-dependent manner [(18-20)](#reference18), implicating possible transcriptional regulation. For example, intracellular copper may alter the [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction) state of cells and thus induce [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress), which can activate [signal transduction](../glossary#cell-signaling) pathways that increase the expression of [genes](../glossary#gene) encoding proteins involved in the detoxification of [reactive oxygen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species) [(21)](#reference21). Adequate copper nutritional [status](../glossary#status) is necessary for normal [iron](iron) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) and red blood cell production and function. Copper depletion results in an iron deficiency-like [anemia](../glossary#anemia), and iron accumulates in the livers of copper-deficient animals. The development of anemia during copper deficiency may be linked to low CP activity, impaired iron release from stores in the liver, and reduced iron delivery to the erythroid marrow, thus leading to iron-restricted [erythropoiesis](../glossary#erythropoiesis) (see [Iron metabolism](#iron-metabolism)) [(2)](#reference2). However, this may not be the whole story, as was recently suggested by longtime copper researcher, Dr. Joseph R. Prohaska (Univ. of Minnesota, Duluth) [(22)](#reference22). Copper depletion also reduces CP activity in humans, leading to hepatic iron overload and thus increasing [risk](../glossary#risk) for [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) and liver [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis) [(14)](#reference14). [serum](../glossary#serum) CP levels and [plasma](../glossary#plasma) ferroxidase activity, and corrected iron metabolism defects in a copper-deficient subject [(23)](#reference23). Moreover, infants fed a formula with a high-iron content absorbed less copper than infants fed a low-iron formulation, suggesting that high iron intakes may interfere with copper absorption in infants [(24)](#reference24). This observation was also confirmed in rats and mice, where high dietary iron caused copper depletion, thus increasing the copper nutritional requirement [(25, 26)](#reference25). Excess intake of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) [zinc](zinc), at doses of 50 mg/day or more for extended periods of time, may result in copper depletion. The mechanism may relate to increased [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of metallothionein (MT), an intracellular zinc- and copper-binding protein. MT has a stronger affinity for copper than zinc, so high levels of MT induced by excess zinc may trap copper within [enterocytes](../glossary#enterocyte) thus limiting its [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability). This postulate, however, was called into question by studies done in MT-deficient mice, in which high enteral zinc still decreased copper absorption, suggesting that high zinc may block a copper transporter [(27)](#reference27). Conversely, elevated copper intakes have not been found to affect zinc nutritional [status](../glossary#status) [(2](#reference2), [24)](#reference24). Moreover, zinc supplementation at 10 mg/day for eight weeks restored normal [plasma](../glossary#plasma) copper/zinc ratios in 65 subjects on long-term [hemodialysis](../glossary#hemodialysis) who initially exhibited low [serum](../glossary#serum) zinc and high copper. Whether improving zinc and copper status of hemodialysis patients can impact clinical outcomes, however, needs to be assessed [(28)](#reference28). Evidence of copper- [fructose](../glossary#fructose) interactions comes mainly from studies using experimental animals. High-fructose diets exacerbated copper deficiency in male rats, but not in pigs whose [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) system is anatomically and functionally more like humans. Also, very high levels of dietary fructose (20% of total calories) did not result in copper depletion in humans, suggesting that fructose intake does not result in copper depletion at levels relevant to normal diets [(2](#reference2), [24)](#reference24). However, high fructose consumption and low copper availability may be risk factors for functional copper deficiency in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease [(29)](#reference29). Although [vitamin C](../vitamins/vitamin-C) [supplements](../glossary#supplement) have produced copper deficiency in guinea pigs [(30)](#reference30), the effect of vitamin C supplementation on copper nutritional [status](../glossary#status) in humans is less clear. Two small studies in healthy, young adult men indicated that [ceruloplasmin](../glossary#ceruloplasmin) oxidase activity may be impaired by relatively high doses of supplemental vitamin C. In one study, vitamin C intakes of 1,500 mg/day for two months resulted in a significant decline in CP oxidase activity [(31)](#reference31). In the other study, supplements of 605 mg/day of vitamin C for three weeks resulted in decreased CP oxidase activity, although copper absorption did not decline [(32)](#reference32). Neither of these studies found vitamin C supplementation to adversely affect copper nutritional status. Clinically evident, or frank, dietary copper deficiency is relatively uncommon. [Serum](../glossary#serum) copper and [CP](../glossary#ceruloplasmin) levels may fall to 30% of normal in cases of severe copper deficiency. Hypocupremia is also observed in genetic disorders of copper [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), including Wilson disease (WD) and aceruloplasminemia; however, neither disorder has been linked to low dietary copper intake. One of the most common clinical signs of copper deficiency is an [anemia](../glossary#anemia) that is unresponsive to [iron](iron) therapy but is corrected by copper [supplementation](../glossary#supplement). It was [hypothesized](../glossary#hypothesis) that this anemia could result from defective iron mobilization due to decreased CP activity, yet individuals with inherited aceruloplasminemia do not always develop overt anemia [(33)](#reference33). Moreover, in copper-deficient swine, intestinal iron absorption is impaired but iron distribution among tissues/organs is normal [(34-36)](#reference34). Low serum iron from reduced absorption is an unlikely cause of this anemia since [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) provision of iron did not correct it. An alternative postulate is that copper-deficiency anemia is caused principally by impaired [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) production and red blood cell proliferation, and a shortened [erythrocyte](../glossary#erythrocyte) lifespan. These physiological processes are thus likely to require copper. Copper deficiency may also lead to [neutropenia](../glossary#neutropenia), which can increase susceptibility to infection. Copper depletion studies demonstrated that low copper might affect [erythroid](../glossary#erythroid) and [myeloid](../glossary#myeloid) cell lineages, supporting a role for copper in the regulation of blood cell proliferation and maturation [(37, 38)](#reference37). More research is clearly needed to further define the mechanisms underlying copper deficiency-induced anemia and neutropenia [(4](#reference4), [39)](#reference39). Furthermore, [osteoporosis](../health-disease/osteoporosis) and other abnormalities of bone development have been described in copper-deficient, low-birth-weight infants and young children. Less common features of copper deficiency may include impaired growth, depigmentation, and development of [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) [pathologies](../glossary#pathology) [(2](#reference2), [8)](#reference8). Currently, there is not a sensitive and specific [biomarker](../glossary#biomarker) to detect copper inadequacy in humans [(5](#reference5), [40-42)](#reference40). Blood copper [(43)](#reference43) and [ceruloplasmin](../glossary#ceruloplasmin) concentrations are reduced in severe copper deficiency [(3](#reference3), [6)](#reference6). However, both of these parameters are also influenced by pregnancy, [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), and infection [(5)](#reference5), thus limiting the usefulness of these assays to estimate body copper [status](../glossary#status). Experimental work has recently identified other copper-related biomarkers, but further experimental validation is required, including clinical testing in humans. Bovine milk is relatively low in copper, and cases of copper deficiency have been reported in infants fed only cow's milk formula [(47)](#reference47). Other individuals at elevated risk for copper deficiency include premature and low-birth-weight infants; individuals with severe burns [(48)](#reference48) or prolonged diarrhea, which accelerate copper losses; infants and children recovering from malnutrition; and individuals and [short bowel syndrome](../glossary#short-bowel-syndrome), possibly due to surgical removal of large portions of the intestine [(48-50)](#reference48). Also, gastric bypass surgery for morbid [obesity](../glossary#obesity) significantly increases the risk for copper depletion [(51-53)](#reference51). Individuals receiving [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) [total parenteral nutrition](../glossary#total-parenteral-nutrition) lacking copper or those on certain restricted diets may also require [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with copper (and other trace elements) [(2](#reference2), [8)](#reference8). Moreover, copper deficiency in infants with [cholestasis](../glossary#cholestatic-liver-disease) has been linked to long-term parenteral nutrition lacking copper [(54)](#reference54). [Case reports](../glossary#case-report) indicated that [cystic fibrosis](../glossary#cystic-fibrosis) patients may also be at increased risk of copper insufficiency [(55, 56)](#reference55). And finally, excessive [zinc](zinc) intake has been associated with secondary copper deficiency in individuals taking zinc supplements or using zinc-enriched dental creams [(57-59)](#reference57). Copper deficiency is atypical in the general population; however, it was recently suggested that copper deficiency may be more widespread than currently recognized, and that (covert) pathophysiological links exist between low copper nutritional [status](../glossary#status) and [Alzheimer's postmenopausal [osteoporosis](../health-disease/osteoporosis) [(61)](#reference61). Part of the rationale for such an assertion relates to the difficulty in clinically evaluating the copper status of humans, so moderate to even severe copper deficiency is unlikely to be detected in individuals with no notable risk factors [(62)](#reference62). Firmly establishing links between low copper status and increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for these, and possibly other, [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease) awaits further [epidemiological](../glossary#epidemiological-study) and clinical testing. Furthermore, a [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) syndrome associated with copper deficiency was recently described in adults [(63)](#reference63). The symptoms included [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system) [demyelination](../glossary#demyelination), polyneuropathy, myelopathy, and [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) of the optic nerve. The [etiology](../glossary#etiology) is unknown and risk factors have not been established (see [Individuals at risk of deficiency](#deficiency-risk)). [Case reports](../glossary#case-report) suggested that copper malabsorption underlies this disorder, but [mutations](../glossary#mutation) in the [gene](../glossary#gene) encoding the main intestinal copper exporter, ATP7A, were not detected in affected patients (see [Inherited copper deficiency](#inherited-deficiency)) [(64)](#reference64). Oral copper supplementation (2 mg/day) normalized [serum](../glossary#serum) copper and CP concentrations, and stabilized individuals afflicted with the disease and significantly improved their quality of life. Optimal duration and dose of copper administration has not, however, been experimentally evaluated [(63)](#reference63). ATPase copper transporting alpha, or ATP7A, is a dual function Cu1+-transporting ATPase that is expressed in most cell types, except for, notably, [hepatocytes](../glossary#hepatocyte). ATP7A transports copper from the [cytosol](../glossary#cytosol) into the trans-Golgi (TGN), where cuproenzymes are [synthesized](../glossary#synthesis) within the secretory pathway, and exports copper from cells. [Mutations](../glossary#mutation) in ATP7A, which underlie Menkes disease (MD), critically block copper export from [enterocytes](../glossary#enterocyte) and [vascular endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) cells [(65)](#reference65). Impaired absorption of dietary copper results in systemic copper deficiency in MD. Decreased cuproenzyme expression/activity is caused by low intracellular copper, and defective copper transport into the TGN. Copper accumulation in microvascular endothelial cells in the blood-brain barrier reduces copper transport into the brain, leading to low brain copper and reduced cuproenzyme activity in [neurons](../glossary#neuron). Other mutations in ATP7A have been linked to a less severe [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) copper deficiency disorder called occipital horn syndrome (OHS). The clinical features of MD include intractable [seizures](../glossary#seizure), connective tissue disorders, subdural [hemorrhage](../glossary#hemorrhage), and hair abnormalities (so called "kinky hair"). OHS patients exhibit muscular hypotonia and connective tissue abnormalities, including formation of [exostoses](../glossary#exostosis) on occipital bones. [Subcutaneous](../glossary#subcutaneous) injections of copper-histidine improve copper-related metabolic functions in MD and OHS patients. Copper entry into the brain, however, remains limited (reviewed in [66](#reference66)). Furthermore, [gene](../glossary#gene) therapy approaches have been recently validated in a pre-clinical mouse model of MD, with long-term goals of using such treatments in humans with the disease [(67, 68)](#reference67). Recently, another inherited copper-deficiency disorder was described in identical twin male infants, who were [homozygous](../glossary#homozygous) for a novel missense variant in the gene encoding copper transporter 1 (CTR1) [(69)](#reference69). This genetic aberration caused a distinctive [autosomal](../glossary#autosomal) [recessive](../glossary#recessive-trait) syndrome of infantile seizures and neurodegeneration, consistent with profound [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system) copper deficiency. Disease [pathology](../glossary#pathology) was most likely caused by defective intestinal copper transport which resulted in severe systemic copper deficiency. This outcome is supported by experimental laboratory studies which demonstrated that intestine-specific ablation (deletion) of CTR1 significantly impaired absorption of dietary copper in mice [(70)](#reference70). Patients with Wilson disease (WD) may have increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for copper [toxicosis](../glossary#toxicosis) even at copper intakes in the normal range. WD is an [autosomal](../glossary#autosomal) [recessive](../glossary#recessive-trait) disorder that is typified by defective copper distribution and storage [(71)](#reference71). The disease is caused by [mutations](../glossary#mutation) in the ATP7B [gene](../glossary#gene), which encodes a copper-transporting ATPase that is highly expressed in liver and brain. Dysfunctional ATP7B disrupts copper flux in these organs. A recent review provides a nice summary of this devastating human disease [(72)](#reference72). WD [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) is ~1:30,000 individuals globally [(73)](#reference73), although much higher prevalence rates have been reported. It was suggested that differences in the penetrance of disease-causing genetic variants explain the apparent discrepancy between [epidemiological](../glossary#epidemiological-study) and genetic prevalence studies of WD [(74)](#reference74). In WD, [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction)-active copper accumulates in liver, brain, and [cornea](../glossary#cornea) due to impaired ATP7B-mediated copper [excretion](../glossary#excretion), which increases [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) leading to eventual tissue and organ damage. Untreated WD patients are likely to develop liver damage, [cancer](../glossary#cancer), and eventual [hepatic](../glossary#hepatic) failure, and severe hemolytic crisis. Elevated brain copper content can lead to [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) damage, and copper accumulation in the eye in so-called Kayser-Fleisher rings can result in abnormal eye movements. Blood concentrations of ceruloplasmin are characteristically low in WD patients, since hepatic ATP7B is required for its biosynthesis, and urinary copper losses may be enhanced. Early intervention can prevent development of some of the most severe pathophysiological outcomes. Treatments for WD include [zinc](zinc) supplementation, which attenuates enteral copper with penicillamine or trientine [(75)](#reference75). Additional [pathologies](../glossary#pathology) associated with liver copper loading include Indian childhood [cirrhosis](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/glossary#cirrhosis) (ICC) and idiopathic copper [toxicosis](../glossary#toxicosis) (ICT). In ICC, notable liver copper loading and progressive liver failure are observed [(76)](#reference76). In contrast to Wilson disease when ceruloplasmin is low, in ICC, ceruloplasmin is normal or elevated. ICC is most likely caused by inadvertent excess copper ingestion, possibly from the use of copper-lined, food/beverage storage containers in a genetically susceptible individual. It seems likely that the unknown genetic defect in ICC relates to the efficiency of [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of excess copper in the [bile](../glossary#bile), but this has not been definitively established. Also, about one-third of ICC patients have -1-antitrypsin deficiency, which calls into question a primary role for copper in disease outcomes [(77)](#reference77). ICT is another [hepatic](../glossary#hepatic) copper overload disorder that predominantly afflicts infants and children. ICT displays [autosomal](../glossary#autosomal) [recessive](../glossary#recessive-trait) inheritance, and an unidentified genetic aberration results in defective copper [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) leading to an increased susceptibility to excess copper. Affected individuals are at increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for copper-related, hepatic toxicosis due to inadvertent consumption of excess copper. However, the source of extra copper remains unidentified in many ICT patients, perhaps suggesting a more complex disease [pathogenesis](../glossary#pathogenesis) [(78)](#reference78). A variety of bioindicators were used to establish the [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for copper, including [plasma](../glossary#plasma) copper concentration, [serum](../glossary#serum) [ceruloplasmin](../glossary#ceruloplasmin) activity, superoxide dismutase activity in red blood cells, and platelet copper concentration [(24)](#reference24). However, whether these are accurate and sensitive [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) of copper nutritional [status](../glossary#status) uncertain [(40)](#reference40). Also, estimates of copper concentrations in various foods and water sources may not be accurate and reliable [(40](#reference40), [62)](#reference62). The RDA for copper reflects the results of [depletion-repletion studies](../glossary#depletion-repletion-study) and is based on the prevention of deficiency (Table 1). For infants up to one year of age, an adequate intake ( [AI](../glossary#AI)) was established due to the lack of experimental evidence to set a requirement. |Life Stage||Age Range||Males (g/day)||Females (g/day)| |Infants||0-6 deficiency results in [cardiomyopathy](../glossary#cardiomyopathy) in some animal species [(79)](#reference79); however, this [pathology](../glossary#pathology) differs from the [atherosclerotic](../glossary#atherosclerosis) [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) that is [prevalent](../glossary#prevalence) humans [(24)](#reference24). Outcomes of cardiovascular disease (CVD)-related [clinical studies](../glossary#clinical-trial) in humans are inconsistent, possibly since the copper [status](../glossary#status) of participants is uncertain given the lack of reliable [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) of copper nutritional status. Ionic copper is a [pro-oxidant](../glossary#pro-oxidant), and it can [oxidize](../glossary#oxidation) low-density [lipoprotein](../glossary#lipoprotein) ( [LDL](../glossary#LDL)) in the test tube. CP can also stimulate LDL oxidation in the laboratory setting [(80)](#reference80). As such, some researchers have proposed that excess copper could increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) for developing atherosclerosis by promoting the oxidation of LDL in vivo. However, there is scant experimental evidence to support this possibility. Moreover, superoxide dismutase and ceruloplasmin have known [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) properties, leading some experts to propose that copper deficiency, rather than copper excess, increases the risk for cardiomyopathy [(81, 82)](#reference81). Outcomes of [observational](../glossary#observational-study) and [intervention nutritional status to [relative risk](../glossary#relative-risk) for CVD are summarized below. [Observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have linked elevated [serum](../glossary#serum) copper levels to an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for developing [CVD](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease). For example, a [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) examined serum copper levels in more than 4,500 men and women 30 years of age and older in the United States [(83)](#reference83). During the subsequent 16 years, 151 participants died from [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) (CHD). After adjusting for other risk factors, those with serum copper levels in the two highest [quartiles](../glossary#quartile) had a significantly greater risk of dying from CHD. [Case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) conducted in Europe also had similar outcomes. For example, a case-cohort study of 2,087 adults in Germany reported an association between higher serum copper concentrations and increased risk of incident CVD, including [myocardial infarction](../health-disease/heart-attack) and [stroke](../health-disease/stroke) [(84)](#reference84). Another study in 60 patients with chronic [heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure) or ischemic heart disease reported that serum copper was a predictor of short-term outcomes [(85)](#reference85). Higher serum copper was also linked to an increased risk of heart failure in a prospective cohort study of 1,866 middle-aged and older men in Finland [(86)](#reference86). Another prospective cohort study in 4,035 middle-aged men in France reported that high serum copper levels were significantly related to a 50% increase in all-cause mortality; however, serum copper was not significantly associated with CVD mortality in this study [(87)](#reference87). Serum copper was also elevated in patients with rheumatic heart disease [(88)](#reference88). In sum, these studies may indicate that high serum copper reflects elevated body copper content, which increases [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) and accelerates tissue/organ damage and disease development. Importantly, however, most copper in the serum is contained within CP, up to 90% depending upon the species, with the remaining, smaller proportion of serum copper bound to albumin protein](../glossary#acute-phase-reactant-protein), with levels increasing by up to 50% as a result of trauma or infection and during chronic inflammatory states. Changes in circulating CP are associated with proportional changes in serum copper levels, independent of body copper [status](../glossary#status). Therefore, elevated serum copper in CHD patients may simply reflect increased CP production due to the inflammation that typifies [atherosclerosis](../health-disease/atherosclerosis). Collectively, these observations raise concerns about linking elevated serum copper to increased tissue copper content and chronic disease development in humans [(91)](#reference91). In contrast to the observational findings discussed above linking high serum copper levels to heart disease, two autopsy studies found copper levels in cardiac muscle were actually lower in patients who died of CHD than in those who died of other causes [(92)](#reference92). Additionally, the copper content of white blood cells has been positively correlated with the degree of [patency](../glossary#patency) of [coronary arteries](../glossary#coronary-artery) in CHD patients [(93, 94)](#reference93). Further, patients with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) had lower concentrations of copper-dependent, extracellular superoxide dismutase than those without a history of MI [(95)](#reference95). Thus, due to the lack of specific, reliable [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) of copper nutritional status, it is not clear whether copper is related to cardiovascular disease. It is also important to note that altered copper [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) may be symptomatic of a cardiovascular condition, rather than a factor that primarily influences its development. Studies examining dietary intake of copper are scarce. In a prospective cohort study in Japan, which included 58,646 participants followed for a median of 19 years, dietary copper intake — measured by a [food frequency questionnaire](../glossary#food-frequency-questionnaire) — was not associated with CHD mortality [(96)](#reference96). Yet, this study associated higher copper intakes with an increased risk of mortality from stroke and other cardiovascular diseases [(96)](#reference96). Notably, it was suggested that elevated [plasma](../glossary#plasma) copper concentrations could be linked to high circulating [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) levels in individuals with cardiovascular disease [(97-99)](#reference97). Increased blood homocysteine may precipitate development of arterial wall lesions and increase risk of CVD [(100)](#reference100); however, this matter is currently open to debate [(101)](#reference101). In animal models, copper-homocysteine interactions were linked to impaired [vascular endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) function [(102, 103)](#reference102). Copper restriction in experimental animals decreased homocysteine levels and reduced incidence of atherogenic lesions [(104, 105)](#reference104), but it is not known whether copper imbalance contributes to a possible [atherogenic](../glossary#atherogenic) effect of homocysteine in humans [(106)](#reference106). Small studies in adults deprived of dietary copper documented adverse changes in blood [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol), including increased total and [LDL](../glossary#LDL) cholesterol concentrations and decreased [HDL](../glossary#HDL) cholesterol concentrations [(107)](#reference107), but these outcomes were not confirmed in other studies [(108)](#reference108). For example, in one recent study, copper supplementation of 2 to 3 mg/day for 4 to 8 weeks did not result in clinically significant changes in blood cholesterol levels [(81](#reference81), [109, 110)](#reference109). Additionally, 8 mg/day of copper for six months had no effect on blood cholesterol levels [(111)](#reference111). Interpretation of these outcomes is, however, challenging since the copper [status](../glossary#status) of participants was presumably not well defined. Additional research failed to link increased copper intake to elevated [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress). In a multi-center, [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled [clinical trial](../glossary#clinical-trial), copper supplementation of 3 or 6 mg/day for six weeks did not result in increased susceptibility of LDL to oxidation by copper [(112)](#reference112). Moreover, supplementation with 3 or 6 mg/day of copper did not increase [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) to red blood cells [(113)](#reference113). Collectively, these studies indicated that copper intakes several times above the [RDA](../glossary#RDA) do not increase oxidative stress, at least as measured by these assays in these populations. Although free copper and [CP](../glossary#ceruloplasmin) can promote [LDL](../glossary#LDL) [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) in the laboratory, there is little evidence that high dietary copper increases [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) in the human body. Increased [serum](../glossary#serum) copper levels have been associated with increased [CVD](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) [risk](../glossary#risk), as outlined above, but the significance of these findings is unclear due to the complex association among serum copper, CP, and [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) mediators. Clarification of the relationships of copper intake, copper nutritional [status](../glossary#status), CP levels, and CVD risk thus requires further research. Copper is known to play several important roles in the development and maintenance of immune system function, including [innate](../health-disease/immunity#innate-immunity) and [adaptive](../health-disease/immunity#adaptive-immunity) immunity (reviewed in [114](#reference114)). Neutropenia is a clinical sign of copper deficiency in humans. Adverse effects of insufficient copper on immune system function appear most pronounced in infants. For example, infants with Menkes disease, a genetic copper-deficiency disorder, suffer from frequent and severe infections [(115, 116)](#reference115). Moreover, in a study of 11 malnourished infants with evidence of copper deficiency, the ability of white blood cells to engulf [pathogens](../glossary#pathogen) increased significantly after one month of copper [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) [(117)](#reference117). Moreover, 11 men on a low-copper diet (0.66 mg/day of copper for 24 days and 0.38 mg/day for another 40 days) showed an impaired [monocyte](../glossary#monocyte) proliferative response in an [ex vivo](../glossary#ex-vivo) immune challenge assay [(118)](#reference118). Mechanistic studies also support a role for copper in the innate immune response to [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) and viral infections (reviewed in [119, 120](#reference119)). Severe copper deficiency thus has adverse effects on immune system function; however, whether marginal copper insufficiency impairs immunity in humans has not been established. Progressive decrease of [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) (BMD) is commonly observed in the elderly, frequently leading to development of [osteopenia](../glossary#osteopenia) (pre- [osteoporosis](../health-disease/osteoporosis)) and osteoporosis. Women are more often affected by osteoporosis than men, (e.g., [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) ratio is 5:1 in non-Hispanic whites) [(121)](#reference121), primarily due to the postmenopausal reduction in the production of [estrogen](../glossary#estrogen), which is essential for maintaining strength of muscle, bone, and connective tissue [(122)](#reference122). Osteoporosis is associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of falls, bone [fracture](../glossary#fracture), and mortality in individuals over 65 years of age [(123)](#reference123). Osteoporosis has been reported in infants with severe copper deficiency [(124, 125)](#reference124), but how copper depletion affects bone and connective tissue health in adults is less certain. One recent investigation documented bone [resorption](../glossary#resorption) (breakdown) in 11 healthy adult males consuming marginal copper for six weeks (0.7 mg/day) [(126)](#reference126). Also, supplementation of 3 to 6 mg/day of copper for six weeks had no effect on biochemical markers of bone resorption or bone formation in two studies of healthy adult men and women [(127, 128)](#reference127). An effect of copper deficiency on bone integrity seems likely, since a copper-dependent enzyme, lysyl oxidase (LOX), is required for the maturation (cross-linking) of [collagen](../glossary#collagen), a key element in the organic matrix of bone. In individuals with marginal copper intake and less efficient copper absorption, such as the elderly, it seems plausible that LOX activity is decreased, possibly increasing risk for bone and connective tissue effects. Collectively, research examining the role of copper nutritional [status](../glossary#status) in age-related osteoporosis is limited. An early study found that [serum](../glossary#serum) copper levels in 46 elderly patients with hip [fractures](../glossary#fracture) were significantly lower than those of age-matched controls [(129)](#reference129). Another study, however, found no differences in serum copper levels among postmenopausal women showed that blood copper concentrations were lower than the normal reference range in postmenopausal women with osteopenia (N=28) and osteoporosis (N=23) [(131)](#reference131). In another cross-sectional study in 728 postmenopausal women, 491 of which had confirmed osteoporosis, lower serum copper concentrations were associated with osteoporosis in the younger women (ages 40-59 years) but not the older women (ages 60-80 years) [(132)](#reference132). Furthermore, in a national survey in the US, including 8,224 adults (compiling data from NHANES 2007-2010, 2013-2014, and 2017-2018), higher daily copper intakes (from diet and [supplements](../glossary#supplement)) were associated with higher BMD at the femur and lumbar spine and a lower risk of osteoporosis [(133)](#reference133). Limited studies of copper [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) and bone health outcomes have been undertaken. A small study in [perimenopausal](../glossary#perimenopause) women, who consumed ~1 mg of dietary copper daily, reported decreased loss of [BMD](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) from the lumbar spine after copper supplementation of 3 mg/day for two years [(134)](#reference134). Additionally, a two-year, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 59 postmenopausal women found that daily intake of supplemental calcium plus trace minerals, including 2.5 mg of copper, resulted in maintenance of spinal BMD. Supplemental calcium or trace minerals, alone, were not as effective at preventing loss of bone density [(135)](#reference135). Another [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), double-blind, placebo-controlled study in 224 healthy, postmenopausal women ages 51 to 80 years, found daily supplementation with 600 mg of calcium, 2 mg of copper, and 12 mg of zinc for two years decreased whole-body BMD compared to supplemental calcium alone. Another trial showed that BMD was reduced in subjects with dietary copper intakes below the [RDA](../glossary#RDA) (0.9 mg/day), but copper supplementation did not prevent the progressive loss of BMD as well as a calcium regimen alone [(136)](#reference136). Finally, several studies have suggested that tooth loss might be related to defects in the maintenance of BMD [(137, 138)](#reference137). When compared with 20 healthy-matched controls, 50 patients (mean age, 47.5 years) with low spinal BMD and advanced tooth wear were found to have significantly lower copper content in tooth enamel. However, despite evidence of bone demineralization, [serum](../glossary#serum) copper levels in this population were similar to those of the healthy group [(139)](#reference139). In sum, additional research is required to draw meaningful conclusions regarding the effects of marginal copper depletion and copper supplementation on bone metabolism and risk for developing age-related osteoporosis. [Cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) deterioration in individuals with [Alzheimer's disease](../health-disease/alzheimer-disease) (AD) is linked to the presence of - [amyloid plaques](../glossary#amyloid-plaque) and abnormal Tau protein-forming aggregates. The possibility that copper imbalance is involved in the onset of AD is under investigation. A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) described higher blood concentrations of copper in AD patients (N=2,929) as compared to healthy subjects (N=3,547), from a total of 46 studies reviewed [(140)](#reference140). Also, 'free' serum copper (i.e., not bound to [CP](../glossary#ceruloplasmin)) was higher in AD patients (N=1,595) than in healthy control subjects (N=2,399), representing 18 total studies. These observations were confirmed in another recent review of published studies [(141)](#reference141). An additional meta-analysis of 12 case-control studies revealed AD patients had lower copper concentrations in various brain regions compared to healthy controls [(142)](#reference142), further exemplifying dysregulation of copper [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) in Alzheimer's disease. Among the many [hypotheses](../glossary#homeostasis) supporting a role for copper in AD onset or progression includes copper involvement in the formation of [senile plaques](../glossary#senile-plaque) through [hypermetallation](../glossary#hypermetallation) of the -amyloid peptides, possibly leading to [zinc](zinc) depletion, enhanced [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress), and brain damage [(143-145)](#reference143). Recent research has also identified [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) in the ATP7B [gene](../glossary#gene) that may be associated with the [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing copper imbalance and AD [(140, 142)](#reference140). ATP7B is a copper-transporting ATPase expressed in the liver and brain. Impairment of ATP7B function causes Wilson disease, which is typified by elevated 'free' copper level in blood and copper accumulation in liver and brain. Additional research is required to determine whether genetic variation could influence individual susceptibility to environmental exposure of high copper levels. Copper administered in drinking water was associated with development of enhanced [pathological](../glossary#pathology) features in animal models of AD [(146, 147)](#reference146). One study in a rabbit model reported that combining a high- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) diet and copper (0.12 mg/L in drinking water) impaired [cognition](../glossary#cognition) [(146)](#reference146). A [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) in 3,718 elderly participants in the Chicago Health and Aging Project, followed for 5.5 years, evaluated the impact of fat and copper intakes using food frequency questionnaires on cognitive function. For individuals with high intakes of [saturated](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid) and [trans fat](../glossary#trans-fat), cognitive decline was greater for those in the highest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of total copper intake compared to the lowest quintile (median intake of 2.75 vs. 0.88 mg copper per day) [(148)](#reference148). Although dysfunctional copper [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) is suggested as a risk factor for AD, it could also be symptomatic of the disease, rather than causative. Moreover, it is still unclear whether copper supplementation or restriction could delay the progression of AD. A small, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 68 individuals with mild AD found that supplementation of 8 mg/day of copper for one year delayed the decrease of the -amyloid peptide A42 in [cerebrospinal fluid](../glossary#cerebrospinal-fluid); a decrease in A42 has been linked to cognitive deterioration [(149)](#reference149). This delay, however, was not associated with improved cognitive performance [(150)](#reference150). Relating to the use of [zinc](zinc) supplementation to block copper absorption in Wilson disease, slow-release zinc acetate administration (150 mg/day for six months) in a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), placebo-controlled study of 60 patients with mild-to-moderate AD resulted in a decrease in serum 'free' copper and stabilization of cognition deficits [(143)](#reference143). A specific role for copper was not, however, determined in these notable outcomes. In summary, additional human studies are needed to clarify the role of copper in AD prevention, development, and progression. [Neurologically](../glossary#neurologic) presenting Wilson disease and inherited aceruloplasminemia are characterized by copper accumulation in the brain and development of neurological symptoms, including dystonia and [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) impairment, that resemble [Parkinson's disease](../glossary#parkinson-disease) (PD) [(151)](#reference151). of copper [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) has been documented in PD [(152)](#reference152). Copper depletion occurs in brain regions with loss of [neurons](../glossary#neuron) in PD patients [(153, 154)](#reference154). Moreover, some studies have documented lower [serum](../glossary#serum) copper and/or [CP](../glossary#ceruloplasmin) concentrations in PD patients compared to healthy controls [(155-157)](#reference155). Dietary copper intake did not, however, relate to the [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing PD in two small [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) [(158, 159)](#reference158). As in AD, further research is required to elucidate whether copper imbalance contributes to the [pathogenesis](../glossary#pathogenesis) of PD. Similar to findings from animal models [(160)](#reference160), human studies have documented low circulating copper [(161, 162)](#reference161) or low [hepatic](../glossary#hepatic) copper content [(161](#reference161), [163, 164)](#reference163) in adults and children nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. An [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between hepatic copper content and liver disease severity has also been observed [(163](#reference163), [165)](#reference165). However, it is not known whether low dietary intake of copper might be a contributor to disease [pathogenesis](../glossary#pathogenesis) or whether dysregulated copper [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) is only a manifestation of liver disease. Copper is found in a wide variety of foods and is most plentiful in organ meats, shellfish, [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts), and seeds. Wheat-bran cereals and whole-grain products are also good sources of copper. According to national surveys (NHANES), the mean dietary intake of copper in the US is 1.1 mg/day for adult women and 1.3 mg/day for adult men [(166)](#reference166), levels that exceed the established [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for copper for adults of 900 µg/day (see [Table 1](#table-1)). The estimated copper content of some foods that are relatively rich in copper is listed in Table 2. For more information on the nutrient content of of those at risk for copper depletion is challenging since sensitive and specific, copper nutrition-related bioindicators have yet to be identified. Nonetheless, a range of copper [supplements](../glossary#supplement) are available for purchase, including cupric oxide, copper gluconate, copper sulfate, and copper [amino acid](../glossary#amino-acid) [chelates](../glossary#chelate) [(167)](#reference167). The relative [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of these different chemical forms of copper, however, has not yet been established in humans [(168)](#reference168). Copper supplements may contain a few µg up to 15 mg of elemental copper, which exceeds the [UL](/glossary#UL) for copper by 1.5 fold [(169)](#reference169). Moreover, copper is typically included in multivitamin/mineral supplements [(169)](#reference169) and added to [fortified](../glossary#fortification) breakfast cereals. Supplementation of adults with 10 mg/day of cupric gluconate for 12 weeks did not cause copper toxicity [(170)](#reference170). Importantly, however, higher copper intakes could be detrimental in some at-risk (unknown) individuals. Copper supplementation of infants should be approached with caution since [homeostatic](../glossary#homeostasis) regulators of copper absorption and [excretion](../glossary#excretion) are not fully developed, thus increasing the potential for copper [toxicosis](../glossary#toxicosis). From a clinical perspective, copper overload most frequently presents in biliary atresia, biliary cirrhosis and in WD patients, and as such, individuals suffering from these conditions should avoid taking supplemental copper. Copper toxicity is rare in the general population. Acute copper poisoning has occurred by storing beverages in copper-containing containers, as well as from contaminated water supplies [(171)](#reference171). Guideline values for copper in drinking water have been set by the US Environmental Protection Agency (1.3 mg/liter) and by the World Health Organization (2 mg/liter) [(172)](#reference172). Symptoms of acute copper toxicity include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea; such symptoms help prevent additional ingestion and absorption of copper. More serious signs of acute copper toxicity include severe liver damage, kidney failure, coma, and death. Of more concern from a nutritional standpoint is the possibility of liver damage resulting from long-term exposure to lower doses of copper. In generally healthy individuals, daily doses of up to 10,000 g (10 mg) have not resulted in liver damage. The US Food and Nutrition Board has thus set the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) in adults at 10 mg/day of copper from food and [supplements](../glossary#supplement) combined (Table 3) [(24)](#reference24). It should be noted that individuals with genetic disorders affecting copper [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) (e.g., Wilson disease, Indian childhood [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis), and idiopathic copper [toxicosis](../glossary#toxicosis)) may be at risk for adverse effects of chronic copper toxicity at significantly lower intake levels. There is some concern that the UL of 10 mg/day might be too high. For example, one study in adult men who consumed 7.8 mg/day of copper for 147 days showed that they loaded excess copper during that time, and some indices of immune function and [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) status suggested that these functions were adversely affected by the high intakes of copper [(173, 174)](#reference173). However, another study did not report any adverse effects in individuals supplemented with 8 mg/day of copper for six should be from food and formula only.| Relatively little is known about the interaction of copper with drugs. Penicillamine is used to bind copper and enhance its elimination in Wilson disease, a genetic disorder resulting in [hepatic](../glossary#hepatic) copper overload. Because penicillamine dramatically increases the urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of copper, individuals taking the medication for reasons other than copper overload may have an increased dietary copper requirement. Additionally, antacids may interfere with copper absorption when used in very high amounts [(2)](#reference2). Also, the anti- [tuberculosis](../glossary#tuberculosis) drug ethambutol may [chelate](../glossary#chelate) copper in [mitochondria](../glossary#mitochondria) and reduce cytochrome c oxidase activity specifically in optic nerve [axons](../glossary#axon), possibly contributing to optic neuropathy which is a documented side-effect of this drug [(175)](#reference175). The [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for copper (900 g/day for adults) is sufficient to prevent deficiency, but the lack of clear [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) of copper nutritional [status](../glossary#status) in humans makes it difficult to determine the level of copper intake most likely to promote optimum health or prevent [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease). A varied diet should provide enough copper for most people. For those who are concerned that their diet may not provide adequate copper, a multivitamin/mineral [supplement](../glossary#supplement) will generally provide at least the RDA for copper. Because aging has not been associated with significant changes in the requirement for copper, our recommendation for older adults is the same as that for adults 50 and younger [(176)](#reference176). Am J Clin Nutr. 1995;62(3):493-505. ] [(PubMed)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7661110/) Contents Fluorine occurs naturally as the negatively charged [ion](../glossary#ion), fluoride (F-). Fluoride is considered a trace [ element](../glossary#element) because only small amounts are present in the body (about 2.6 grams in adults), and because the daily requirement for maintaining dental health is only a few milligrams a day. About 95% of the total body fluoride is found in bones and teeth [(1)](#references). Although its role in the prevention of [dental caries](../glossary#dental-caries) (tooth decay) is well established, fluoride is not generally considered an essential [ mineral](../glossary#mineral) element because humans do not require it for growth or to sustain life [(2)](#reference2). However, if one considers the prevention of [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease) (dental caries) an important criterion in determining essentiality, then fluoride might well be considered an essential trace element [(3)](#reference3). Fluoride is absorbed in the stomach and [ small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine). Once in the bloodstream it rapidly enters mineralized tissue (bones and developing teeth). At usual intake levels, fluoride does not accumulate in soft tissue. The predominant mineral elements in bone are crystals of calcium and phosphate, known as [hydroxyapatite](../glossary#hydroxyapatite) crystals. Fluoride's high chemical reactivity and small radius allow it to either displace the larger hydroxyl (-OH) ion in the hydroxyapatite crystal, forming fluoroapatite, or to increase crystal density by entering spaces within the hydroxyapatite crystal. Fluoroapatite hardens tooth [enamel](../glossary#enamel) and stabilizes bone mineral [(4)](#reference4). Both [calcium](calcium) and [magnesium](magnesium) form [ insoluble](../glossary#insoluble) complexes with fluoride and are capable of significantly decreasing fluoride absorption when present in the same meal. However, the absorption of fluoride in the form of monofluorophosphate (unlike sodium fluoride) is unaffected by calcium. Also, a diet low in chloride (salt) has been found to increase fluoride retention by reducing urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of fluoride [(1)](#references). In humans, the only clear effect of inadequate fluoride intake is an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [dental caries](../glossary#dental-caries) (tooth decay) for individuals of all ages. [Epidemiological](../glossary#epidemiological-study) investigations of patterns of water consumption and the [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of dental caries across various US regions with different water fluoride concentrations led to the development of a recommended optimum range of fluoride concentration of 0.7-1.2 milligrams/liter (mg/L) or parts per million (ppm); the lower concentration was recommended for warmer climates where water consumption is higher, and the higher concentration was recommended for colder climates. In 2015, the US Department of Health and Human Services recommended that all community water systems adjust the fluoride concentration to 0.7 mg/L, as more recent studies did find a relationship between water intake and outdoor air temperature. This recommendation was made in an effort to reduce the risk of dental fluorosis (see below) and in light of the widespread availability of fluoride from other sources, including fluoride-containing oral-care products [(5)](#reference5). A number of studies conducted prior to the introduction of fluoride-containing toothpastes demonstrated that the prevalence of dental caries was 40% to 60% lower in communities with optimal water fluoride concentrations than in communities with low water fluoride concentrations [(6)](#reference6). The Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the US Institute of Medicine updated its recommendations for fluoride intake in 1997. Because data were insufficient to establish a Recommended Dietary Allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)), Adequate Intake ( [AI](../glossary#AI)) levels were set based on estimated intakes that have been shown to reduce the occurrence of dental caries most effectively without causing the unwanted side effect of tooth enamel mottling known as dental fluorosis (0.05 mg/kg of body weight) (Table 1; [6](#reference6)). See the section below on [Safety](#safety) for plaque are capable of metabolizing fermentable [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) (sugars) and converting them to organic acids that can dissolve sensitive tooth enamel. If unchecked, the bacteria may penetrate deeper layers of the tooth and progress into the soft pulp tissue at the center. Untreated caries can lead to severe pain, local infection, tooth loss or extraction, nutritional problems, and serious systemic infections in susceptible individuals [(7)](#reference7). Dental caries — both treated and untreated — contribute to diminished overall oral health, which, in turn, may affect systemic health. For example, some [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have suggested a link between systemic [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) in individuals with periodontal (gum) infection and linked to [rheumatoid arthritis](../glossary#rheumatoid-arthritis) [(12, 13)](#reference12). Poor oral health in general may constitute a risk factor for coronary heart disease [(14)](#reference14) and other cardiovascular diseases [(15, 16)](#reference15). Increased fluoride exposure, most commonly through community water fluoridation, has been found to decrease the incidence of [dental caries](../glossary#dental-caries) in children and adults [(17, 18)](#reference17). Between 1976 and 1987, clinical studies in several countries demonstrated that the addition of fluoride to community water supplies (0.7-1.2 ppm) reduced caries by 30%-60% in primary (baby) teeth and 15%-35% in permanent teeth [(19)](#reference19). A 2015 review and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of prospective observational studies found a 35% and 26% reduction in number of decayed, missing, and filled primary and permanent teeth with consumption of fluoridated versus non-fluoridated water, respectively [(20)](#reference20). While fluoride's prevention of dental caries is primarily through topical action, fluoride consumed in water appears to have a systemic effect in children before all teeth have erupted — typically through 12 years of age. Fluoride is incorporated into the developing [enamel](../glossary#enamel) of teeth and increases the resistance to caries. Since the caries preventative effect of fluoride is also [topical](../glossary#topical) (surface) in children after teeth have erupted and in adults, the optimal protection achieved by fluoridated water likely occurs through both systemic exposure before and after tooth eruption and topical exposure after tooth eruption. Research has indicated that the primary action of fluoride occurs [topically](../glossary#topical) after the teeth erupt into the mouth. Ingested fluoride is secreted in the saliva and contributes to topical protection. When [enamel](../glossary#enamel) is partially demineralized by organic acids, fluoride in the saliva can enhance the remineralization of enamel through its interactions with calcium and phosphate. Fluoride containing remineralized enamel is more resistant to acid attack and demineralization. In salivary concentrations associated with optimum fluoride intake, fluoride has been found to inhibit [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme), resulting in reduced acid production by cariogenic bacteria [(7](#reference7), [17)](#reference17). The use of topically applied fluoride-containing products, including toothpaste, gel, varnish, and mouth rinse, is thought to have contributed to the substantial decrease in the [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of caries over the last decades [(21)](#reference21). A 2013 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of fluoride interventions in children and adolescents (up to 16 years of age) found that the application of fluoride varnish for at least one year was associated with a 37% reduction in decayed, missing, and filled tooth surfaces in decayed tooth surfaces of primary teeth; the anti-caries effect on the permanent teeth corresponded to a 43% decrease compared to no treatment or [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(22)](#reference22). A recent (2021) meta-analysis of topical fluoride reviewed 15 clinical trials with 9,541 participants. Specifically, the meta-analysis evaluated 14 trials of fluoride varnish compared to placebo or no fluoride and one trial of fluoride foam, and found that topical fluoride reduced dental caries increment by about one tooth surface over a two-year period [(23)](#reference23). The same meta-analysis also found that fluoride varnish significantly prevented any incident dental caries, but only for children who were younger than 2 years of age [(23)](#reference23). The effects of fluoride-containing toothpaste has been more extensive. A 2017 meta-analysis of 96 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), including more than 65,000 participants, found tooth brushing with a fluoridated toothpaste reduced caries in primary teeth of children and in permanent teeth of adults compared to brushing with non-fluoridated toothpaste [(24)](#reference24). In participants overall, use of toothpastes containing 1,000 to 1,500 ppm of fluoride had a caries-preventative effect compared to use of toothpastes with lower fluoride concentrations or with 17 [clinical use of fluoridated toothpaste effectively reduced dental caries in primary teeth of children younger than 6 years who were at high risk of developing dental caries [(25)](#reference25). The attack of dental hard tissue by acids other than those produced by the [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) plaque may lead to the loss of tooth [enamel](../glossary#enamel), also known as dental erosion. Factors involved in dental erosion include acidic foods and beverages (e.g., carbonated drinks) and [acid reflux](../glossary#gastroesophageal-reflux-disease) [(26)](#reference26). The protective effect of fluoridated agents against dental erosion has mainly been observed in [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) studies (reviewed in [26](#reference26)). Nevertheless, a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of four small, randomized trials examining the effect of fluoride in toothpaste, varnish, and saliva on dental erosion did not find any overall benefit compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(27)](#reference27). Larger clinical studies are needed to evaluate whether [topical](../glossary#topical) fluoride applications can prevent dental erosion and/or reduce the progression of existing erosive lesions. Although fluoride in [pharmacologic doses](../glossary#pharmacologic-dose) has been shown to be a potent therapeutic agent for increasing spinal bone mass (see [Disease Treatment](#disease-treatment)), there is little evidence that water fluoridation at optimum levels for the prevention of [dental caries](../glossary#dental-caries) is helpful in the prevention of [osteoporosis](../health-disease/osteoporosis). The majority of studies conducted to date have failed to find clinically significant differences in [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) (BMD) or [fracture](../glossary#fracture) incidence when comparing residents of areas with fluoridated water supplies to residents in areas without fluoridated water supplies [(28, 29)](#reference28). However, two studies found that drinking water fluoridation was associated with decreased incidence of hip fracture in the elderly. In addition, one study in Italy found a significantly greater [risk](../glossary#risk) of femoral (hip) fractures in men and women residing in an area with low water fluoridation (0.05 ppm) compared to the risk in a similar population whose water supply was naturally fluoridated (1.45 ppm) at higher than optimum levels for prevention of dental caries [(30)](#reference30). Another study in Germany found no significant difference in BMD between residents of a community whose water supply had been optimally fluoridated for 30 years (1 ppm) compared with those who resided in a community without fluoridated water. However, this study reported that the incidence of hip fracture in men and women, aged 85 years or older, was significantly lower in the community with fluoridated water compared to the community with non-fluoridated water, despite higher calcium levels in the non-fluoridated water supply [(31)](#reference31). Another community-based study in 1,300 women found that elevated [serum](../glossary#serum) fluoride concentrations were not related to BMD or to osteoporotic fracture incidence [(32)](#reference32). Finally, a nationwide cohort study in Sweden found no association between chronic exposure to fluoridated water and incidence of hip fracture [(33)](#reference33). A 2015 meta-analysis, which pooled results of 13 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) and one [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study), found that fluoride exposure in drinking water was not associated with risk of hip fracture [(34)](#reference34). Moreover, because bone mineral accretion early in life affects risk for osteoporosis in later adulthood, studies have examined the association of fluoride intake during adolescence and bone outcomes. Reports from the Iowa Bone Development Study, an ongoing prospective cohort study, indicate little to no association of fluoride intake during childhood and adolescence with measures of bone microstructure throughout adolescence [(35-37)](#reference35) and into early adulthood [(38)](#reference38). [Osteoporosis](../health-disease/osteoporosis) is characterized by decreased [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) (BMD) and increased bone fragility and susceptibility to [fracture](../glossary#fracture). In general, decreased BMD is associated with increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of fracture. However, the usual relationship between BMD and fracture risk does not always hold true when very high ( [pharmacologic](../glossary#pharmacologic-dose)) doses of fluoride are used to treat osteoporosis. Most available therapies for osteoporosis (e.g., [estrogen](../glossary#estrogen), calcitonin, and bisphosphonates) decrease bone loss ( [resorption](../glossary#resorption)), resulting in very small increases in BMD. Pharmacologic doses of fluoride are capable of producing large increases in the BMD of the [lumbar spine](../glossary#lumbar-spine). Overall, therapeutic trials of fluoride in patients with osteoporosis have not consistently demonstrated significant decreases in the occurrence of [vertebral](../glossary#vetebral) fracture despite dramatic increases in lumbar spine BMD [(39)](#reference39). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 11 controlled studies, including 1,429 participants, found that fluoride treatment resulted in increased BMD at the lumbar spine but was not associated with a lower risk of vertebral fractures [(40)](#reference40). This meta-analysis also found that higher concentrations of fluoride were associated with increased risk of non-vertebral fractures after four years of treatment. Early studies using high doses of fluoride (>20 mg/day) may have induced rapid bone mineralization in the absence of adequate calcium and vitamin D, resulting in denser bones that were not mechanically stronger [(41, 42)](#reference41). Analysis of bone architecture has also shed some light on the inconsistent effect of fluoride therapy in reducing vertebral fractures. Research has indicated that osteoporosis may be associated with an irreversible change in the architecture of bone known as decreased trabecular connectivity. Normal bone consists of a series of plates interconnected by thick rods. Severely osteoporotic bone has fewer plates, and the rods may be fractured or disconnected (decreased trabecular connectivity) [(43)](#reference43). Despite fluoride therapy increasing bone density, it probably cannot reduce bone resorption and restore connectivity in patients with severe bone loss. Thus, fluoride therapy may be less effective in osteoporotic individuals who have already lost substantial trabecular connectivity [(39](#reference39), [44)](#reference44). On the other hand, [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) using lower fluoride doses (20 mg/day), intermittent dosage schedules, or slow-release formulations (enteric coated sodium fluoride) have demonstrated a decreased incidence of vertebral and non-vertebral fractures along with increased bone density of the lumbar spine [(45)](#reference45). Yet, bone biopsies from postmenopausal, osteoporotic women treated with 20 mg/day of fluoride showed evidence of abnormal bone mineralization despite calcium and vitamin D supplementation [(46)](#reference46). Additionally, a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study did not find any increase in lumbar spine BMD in 180 postmenopausal women with [osteopenia](../glossary#osteopenia) (early osteoporosis) who were given daily supplements of up to 10 mg/day of fluoride for one year [(47)](#reference47). Additional studies are required to assess whether a safe dose of fluoride can be found to maximize bone formation while preventing mineralization defects. Serious side effects have been associated with the high doses of fluoride used to treat [osteoporosis](../health-disease/osteoporosis) [(45)](#reference45). They include [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) irritation, joint pain in the lower extremities, and the development of [calcium](../minerals/calcium) deficiency and [stress fractures](../glossary#stress-fracture). The reasons for the occurrence of lower extremity joint pain and stress fractures in patients taking fluoride for osteoporosis remain unclear, but they may be related to rapid increases in bone formation without sufficient calcium to support such an increase [(39)](#reference39). Presently, enteric coated sodium fluoride or monofluorophosphate preparations offer a lower side effect profile than the high-dose sodium fluoride used in earlier trials. Additionally, sufficient calcium and vitamin D must be provided to support fluoride-induced bone formation. Although fluoride therapy may be beneficial for the treatment of osteoporosis in appropriately selected and closely monitored individuals, uncertainty about its safety and benefit in reducing fractures has kept the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) from approving fluoride therapy for osteoporosis [(48)](#reference48). Combinations of lower doses of fluoride with [antiresorptive agents](../glossary#antiresorptive-agent), such as [estrogen](../glossary#estrogen) or bisphosphonates, may improve therapeutic results while minimizing side effects [(49, 50)](#reference49). Yet, randomized studies have shown that the risk of fractures remained unchanged whether treatments include fluoride, antiresorptives, or both [(45, 46)](#reference45). Additional studies are warranted to determine whether any treatment combinations could provide substantial therapeutic benefits over [monotherapy](../glossary#monotherapy). The major source of dietary fluoride in the US diet is drinking water. Controlled addition of fluoride to water is used by communities as a public health measure to adjust fluoride concentration in drinking water to prevent [dental caries](../glossary#dental-caries). Originally, an optimal range of 0.7 to 1.2 milligrams (mg) per liter (corresponding to 0.7-1.2 ppm) was established, which was shown to decrease the incidence of dental caries while minimizing the risk of dental fluorosis and other adverse effects. In 2015, the US Department of Health and Human Services recommended that the optimal concentration in drinking water be set at 0.7 ppm (see [Safety](#safety)) [(51)](#reference51). Approximately 73% of the US population receives water with sufficient fluoride for the prevention of dental caries [(52)](#reference52). The average fluoride intake for adults living in fluoridated communities ranges from 1.4 to 3.4 mg/day compared to 0.3 to 1 mg/day in non-fluoridated areas [(6)](#reference6). Since well water can vary greatly in its fluoride content, people who consume water from wells should have the fluoride content of their water tested by their local water district or health department. Water fluoride testing may also be warranted in households that use home water treatment systems. While water softeners are not thought to change water fluoride levels, reverse osmosis systems, distillation units, and some water filters have been found to remove significant amounts of fluoride from water. However, Brita-type carbon-charcoal filters do not remove fluoride [(6](#reference6), [48)](#reference48). Bottled water sales have grown exponentially in the US in the last decades, and studies have found that most bottled waters contain sub-optimal levels of fluoride, although there is considerable variation [(53)](#reference53). For example, a study of 105 different bottled water products in the Greater Houston metropolitan area found that over 80% had fluoride concentrations of less than 0.4 ppm; only 5% of the tested products had fluoride concentrations within the recommended range [(54)](#reference54). Several other studies have reported similar findings, with most bottled waters relatively low in fluoride, but a few in the optimal range or higher [(55-57)](#reference55). The FDA-approved claim that "drinking fluoridated water may reduce the risk of tooth decay" is only used by bottlers when the water contains greater than 0.6 ppm of fluoride but no more than 1.0 ppm of fluoride. However, bottlers are not required to provide the fluoride concentration in bottled water unless fluoride was added [(58)](#reference58). While consumption of fluoride from water presents very little [risk](../glossary#risk) of adverse effects in adults except in extreme circumstances (see [Safety](#safety)), consumption of relatively large amounts of water mixed with formula concentrates appears to increase the risk for the development of dental fluorosis in infants [(59-61)](#reference59). One study found that, on average, at least half of all fluoride ingested by infants 6 months and younger was from water mixed with formula concentrates [(62)](#reference62). The study of 49 commercially available infant formulas in the Chicago area showed that milk-based ready-to-feed, liquid concentrate, and powdered formulas (reconstituted with deionized water) had mean fluoride concentrations of 0.27 ppm, and 0.12 ppm, respectively [(63)](#reference63). Fluoride content was significantly higher in soy-based compared to milk-based liquid concentrate formulas (0.50 ppm vs. 0.27 ppm). Using average body weights and total formula intakes during the first year of life, the authors estimated that the risk of exceeding the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for fluoride ingestion was minimal when liquid concentrate and powdered formulas were reconstituted with water containing less than 0.5 ppm of fluoride, but the risk was maximal with 1.0 ppm fluoridated "distilled," or "produced through reverse-osmosis" can be used in order to minimize the risk for mild fluorosis [(58)](#reference58). However, infants between 6 and 12 months may not reach the adequate intake of fluoride if they are fed ready-to-feed formulas or formulas reconstituted with water containing less than 0.4 ppm [(63)](#reference63). For additional information on fluoride and infant formulas, see the [CDC website](https://www.cdc.gov/fluoridation/faqs/infant-formula.html?web=1&wdLOR=c808934EF-40E4-474F-8F9F-AB6FD9A37309). The fluoride content of most foods is low (less than 0.05 mg/100 grams or 0.5 ppm). Rich sources of fluoride include tea, which concentrates fluoride in its leaves, and marine fish that are consumed with their bones (e.g., sardines). Foods made with mechanically separated (boned) chicken, such as canned meats, hot dogs, and infant foods, also add fluoride to the diet [(64)](#reference64). In addition, certain fruit juices, particularly grape juices, often have relatively high fluoride concentrations [(65)](#reference65). Foods generally contribute only 0.3-0.6 mg of the daily intake of fluoride. An adult male residing in a community with fluoridated water has an intake range from 1 mg/day-3 mg/day. Intake is less than 1 mg/day in non-fluoridated areas [(2)](#reference2). Table 2 provides a range of fluoride content for a few fluoride-rich foods.
