Accessed 08/11/2015.] Contents Iron is the fourth most abundant [element](../glossary#element) of Earth's crust and one of the best studied [micronutrients](../glossary#micronutrient) in nutrition science [(1, 2)](#references). It is a key element in the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of all living organisms. Iron exists in two biologically relevant [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) states: the ferrous form (Fe2+) and the ferric form (Fe3+). Iron is an essential component of hundreds of [proteins](../glossary#protein) and [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) supporting essential biological functions, such as oxygen transport, energy production, [DNA](../glossary#DNA) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis), and cell growth and replication. [Heme](../glossary#heme) is an iron-containing compound found in a number of biologically important molecules (Figure 1). Some, but not all, iron-dependent [proteins](../glossary#protein) are heme-containing proteins (also called hemoproteins). Iron-dependent proteins that carry out a broad range of biological activities may be classified as follows [(1, 3)](#references): Iron-containing proteins support a number of functions, some of which are listed below. Globin-hemes are [heme](../glossary#heme)-containing [proteins](../glossary#protein) that are involved in the transport and storage of oxygen and, to a lesser extent, may act as [free radical](../glossary#free-radical) [scavengers](../glossary#scavenge) [(1)](#references). [Hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) is the primary protein found in red blood cells and represents about two-thirds of the body's iron [(3)](#reference3). The vital role of hemoglobin in transporting oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body is derived from its unique ability to acquire oxygen rapidly during the short time it spends in contact with the lungs and to release oxygen as needed during its circulation through the tissues. [Myoglobin](../glossary#myoglobin) functions in the transport and short-term storage of oxygen in muscle cells, helping to match the supply of oxygen to the demand of working muscles [(1)](#references). A third globin called neuroglobin is preferentially expressed in the [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system), but its function is not well understood [(4)](#reference4). Cytochromes are [heme](../glossary#heme)-containing [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) that have important roles in [mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) [electron](../glossary#electron) transport required for cellular energy production and thus life. Specifically, cytochromes serve as electron carriers during the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of [ATP](../glossary#ATP), the primary energy storage compound in cells. [Cytochrome P450](../glossary#cytochrome-P450) (CYP) is a family of enzymes involved in the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of a number of important biological molecules (including organic acids; [fatty acids](../glossary#fatty-acid); [prostaglandins](../glossary#prostaglandin); [steroids](../glossary#steroid); sterols; and vitamins A, D, and K), as well as in the detoxification and metabolism of drugs and pollutants. Nonheme iron-containing enzymes in the [citric acid cycle](../glossary#citric-acid-cycle), such as NADH dehydrogenase and succinate dehydrogenase, are also critical to energy metabolism [(1)](#references). Catalase and some peroxidases are [heme](../glossary#heme)-containing [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) that protect cells against the accumulation of hydrogen peroxide, a potentially damaging [reactive oxygen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species) (ROS), by [catalyzing](../glossary#catalyst) a reaction that converts hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. As part of the immune response, some white blood cells engulf [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria) and expose them to ROS in order to kill them. The [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of one such ROS, hypochlorous acid, by [neutrophils](../glossary#neutrophil) is catalyzed by the catalyzes the iodination of thyroglobulin the production of thyroid [hormones](../glossary#hormone) such that thyroid [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) can be impaired in iron deficiency and iron-deficiency [anemia](../glossary#anemia) (see [Nutrient Interactions](#nutrient-interactions)). Inadequate oxygen (hypoxia), such as that experienced by those who live at high altitudes or those with chronic lung disease, induces compensatory physiologic responses, including increased red blood cell formation ( [erythropoiesis](../glossary#erythropoiesis)), increased blood vessel growth ( [angiogenesis](../glossary#angiogenesis)), and increased production of [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) utilized in [anaerobic](../glossary#anaerobic) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism). Hypoxia is also observed in conditions and [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) disorders. [transcription factors](../glossary#transcription-factor) known as hypoxia-inducible factors (HIF) bind to response elements in [genes](../glossary#gene) that encode various [proteins](../glossary#protein) involved in compensatory responses to hypoxia and increase their [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis). Iron-dependent enzymes [FIH-1]), have been implicated in HIF regulation. When cellular oxygen tension is adequate, newly synthesized HIF- subunits (HIF-1, HIF-2, that degradation. FIH-1-induced asparaginyl recruitment [transcriptional](../glossary#transcription) complex and therefore prevents HIF- transcriptional activity. When cellular oxygen tension drops below a critical threshold, prolyl hydroxylase can no longer target HIF- for degradation, allowing HIF- to bind to HIF-1 and form a transcription complex that enters the [nucleus](../glossary#nucleus) and binds to specific hypoxia response elements (HRE) on target genes like the required for [DNA](../glossary#DNA) replication. RNRs also facilitate DNA repair in response to DNA damage. Other enzymes essential for DNA synthesis and repair, such as DNA polymerases and DNA helicases, are Fe-S cluster [proteins](../glossary#protein). Although the underlying mechanisms are still unclear, depletion of intracellular iron was found to inhibit cell cycle progression, growth, and division. Inhibition of [heme](../glossary#heme) synthesis also induced cell cycle arrest in breast cancer cells [(6)](#reference6). Iron is required for a number of additional vital functions, including growth, reproduction, healing, and immune function. While iron is an essential [mineral](../glossary#mineral), it is potentially toxic because free iron inside the cell can lead to the generation of [free radicals](../glossary#free-radical) causing [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) and cellular damage. Thus, it is important for the body to systemically regulate iron [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis). The body tightly regulates the transport of iron throughout various body compartments, such as developing red blood cells (erythroblasts), circulating [macrophages](../glossary#macrophage), liver cells (hepatocytes) that store iron, and other tissues [(7)](#reference7). Intracellular iron concentrations are regulated according to the body's iron needs (see below), but extracellular signals also regulate iron homeostasis in the body through the action of hepcidin. Hepcidin, a [peptide](../glossary#peptide) [hormone](../glossary#hormone) primarily [synthesized](../glossary#synthesis) by liver cells, is the key regulator of systemic iron homeostasis. Hepcidin can induce the internalization and degradation of the iron-efflux protein, ferroportin-1; ferroportin-1 regulates the release of iron from certain cells, such as [enterocytes](../glossary#enterocyte), hepatocytes, and iron-recycling macrophages, into [plasma](../glossary#plasma) [(8)](#reference8). When body iron concentration is low and in situations of iron-deficiency [anemia](../glossary#anemia), hepcidin [expression](../glossary#expression) is minimal, allowing for iron absorption from the diet and iron mobilization from body stores. In contrast, when there are sufficient iron stores or in the case of iron overload, hepcidin inhibits dietary iron absorption, promotes cellular iron sequestration, and reduces iron [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability). Hepcidin expression is up-regulated in conditions of deficiency due to [mutations](../glossary#mutation) in the hepcidin gene, HAMP, causes abnormal iron accumulation in tissues (see [Iron Overload](#iron-overload)). Of note, hepcidin is also thought to have a major [antimicrobial](../glossary#antimicrobial) role in the [innate immune response](../micronutrients-health/immunity#innate-immunity) by limiting iron availability to invading microorganisms (see [Iron withholding defense during infection](#iron-withholding-defense-infection)) [(10)](#reference10). Iron-responsive elements (IREs) are in the messenger RNAs ( [mRNAs](../glossary#mRNA)) that code for key [proteins](../glossary#protein) in the regulation of iron storage, transport, and utilization. Iron regulatory proteins (IRPs: IRP-1, IRP-2) can bind to IREs and control mRNA stability and [translation](../glossary#translation), thereby regulating the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of specific proteins, such as ferritin (iron storage protein) and transferrin receptor-1 (TfR; controls cellular iron uptake) [(1, 2)](#references). When the iron supply is low, iron is not available for storage or release into [plasma](../glossary#plasma). Less iron binds to IRPs, allowing the binding of IRPs to IREs. The binding of IRPs to IREs located in the 5'end of mRNAs coding for ferritin and ferroportin-1 (iron efflux protein) inhibits mRNA translation and protein synthesis. Translation of mRNA that codes for the key regulatory [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) of [heme](../glossary#heme) synthesis in immature red blood cells is also reduced to conserve iron. In contrast, IRP binding to IREs in the 3' end of mRNAs code for TfR and divalent metal transporter-1 (DMT1) stimulates the synthesis of iron transporters, thereby increasing iron uptake into cells [(1, 2)](#references). When the iron supply is high, more iron binds to IRPs, thereby preventing the binding of IRPs to IREs on mRNAs. This allows for an increased synthesis of proteins involved in iron storage (ferritin) and efflux (ferroportin-1) and a decreased synthesis of iron transporters (TfR and DMT1) such that iron uptake is limited [(2)](#reference2). In the brain, IRPs are also prevented from binding to the 5'end of amyloid precursor protein (APP) mRNA, allowing for APP expression. APP stimulates iron efflux from [neurons](../glossary#neuron) through stabilizing ferroportin-1. In [Parkinson's disease](../glossary#parkinson-disease) (PD), APP expression is inappropriately suppressed, leading to iron accumulation in dopaminergic neurons [(11, 12)](#reference11). Iron is required by most infectious agents to grow and spread, as well as by the infected host in order to mount an effective immune response. Sufficient iron is critical for the [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation) and [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) of T [lymphocytes](../glossary#lymphocyte) and the generation of [reactive oxygen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species) (ROS) required for killing [pathogens](../glossary#pathogen) and [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), hepcidin [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) is up-regulated, [serum](../glossary#serum) iron concentrations decrease, and concentrations of ferritin (the iron storage protein) increase, supporting the idea that sequestering iron from pathogens is an important host defense mechanism [(2)](#reference2). Total body content of iron in adults is estimated to be 2.3 g in women and 3.8 g in men [(2)](#reference2). The body [excretes](../glossary#excretion) very little iron; basal losses, [menstrual](../glossary#menstruation) blood loss, and the need of iron for the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of new tissue are compensated by the daily absorption of a small proportion of dietary iron (1 to 2 mg/day). Body iron is primarily found in red blood cells, which contain 3.5 mg of iron per g of [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin). Senescent red blood cells are engulfed by [macrophages](../glossary#macrophage) in the spleen, and about 20 mg of iron can be recovered daily from [heme](../glossary#heme) recycling. The released iron is either deposited to the ferritin of spleen macrophages or exported by ferroportin-1 (iron efflux protein) to transferrin (the main iron carrier in blood) that delivers iron to other tissues. Iron recycling is very efficient, with about 35 mg being recycled daily [(1)](#references). Measurements of iron stores, circulating iron, and [hematological](../glossary#hematology) parameters may be used to assess the iron status of healthy people in the absence of [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) disorders, parasitic infection, and [obesity](../glossary#obesity). Commonly used iron status [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) include [serum](../glossary#serum) ferritin (iron-storage protein), serum iron, total iron binding capacity (TIBC), and saturation of transferrin (the main iron carrier in blood; TSAT). Soluble transferrin [receptor](../glossary#receptor) (sTfR) is also an indicator of iron status when iron stores are depleted. In iron deficiency and iron-deficiency [anemia](../glossary#anemia), the abundance of cell surface-bound transferrin receptors that bind diferric transferrin is increased in order to maximize the uptake of available iron. Therefore, the concentration of sTfR generated by the cleavage of cell-bound transferrin receptors is increased in iron deficiency. Hematological markers, including [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) concentration, mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration, mean corpuscular volume of red blood cells, and reticulocyte hemoglobin content can help detect abnormality if anemia is present [(9](#reference9), [14)](#reference14). Of note, [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation). Importantly, serum hepcidin concentration is also increased by inflammation to limit iron availability to [pathogens](../glossary#pathogen). Therefore, it is important to include inflammation markers (e.g., [C-reactive protein](../glossary#c-reactive-protein), fibrinogen) when assessing iron status to rule out inflammation [(14)](#reference14). [Vitamin A](../vitamins/vitamin-A) deficiency often coexists with iron deficiency and may exacerbate iron-deficiency [anemia](../glossary#anemia) by altering iron [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [(15)](#reference15). Vitamin A [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) has been shown to have beneficial effects on iron-deficiency anemia and improve iron nutritional status among children and pregnant women [(15, 16)](#reference15). The combination of vitamin A and iron seems to reduce anemia more effectively than either supplemental iron or vitamin A alone [(17)](#reference17). Vitamin A may facilitate the mobilization of iron from storage sites to developing red blood cells for incorporation into [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) [(15, 16)](#reference15). Moreover, studies in rats have shown that iron deficiency alters [plasma](../glossary#plasma) and liver levels of vitamin A [(18, 19)](#reference18). Adequate [copper](copper) nutritional status is necessary for normal iron [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) and red blood cell formation. [Anemia](../glossary#anemia) is a clinical sign of copper deficiency, and iron has been found to accumulate in the livers of copper-deficient animals, indicating that copper (via copper-containing [ceruloplasmin](../glossary#ceruloplasmin)) is required for iron transport to the bone marrow for red blood cell formation [(20)](#reference20). The connection between copper availability and iron metabolism has also been established in humans; copper deficiency can lead to secondary ceruloplasmin deficiency and hepatic iron overload and/or [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis) [(21)](#reference21). Oral copper [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) restored normal ceruloplasmin levels and plasma ferroxidase activity and corrected the iron metabolism disorder in a copper-deficient subject [(22)](#reference22). Moreover, infants fed a high-iron formula absorbed less copper than infants fed a low-iron formula, suggesting that high iron intakes may interfere with copper absorption in infants [(23)](#reference23). [Zinc](zinc) is essential to maintain adequate [erythropoiesis](../glossary#erythropoiesis). When zinc deficiency coexists with iron deficiency, it may exacerbate iron-deficiency [anemia](../glossary#anemia) [(24)](#reference24). On the other hand, high doses of iron [supplements](../glossary#supplement), taken together with zinc supplements on an empty stomach, may inhibit the absorption of zinc. When taken with food, supplemental iron does not appear to inhibit zinc absorption. Iron- [fortified](../glossary#fortification) foods have not been found to impair zinc absorption [(25, 26)](#reference25). The presence of [calcium](calcium) decreases iron absorption from both nonheme (i.e., most [supplements](../glossary#supplement) and food sources other than meat, poultry, and seafood) and [heme](../glossary#heme) sources [(27)](#reference27). However, calcium supplementation up to 12 weeks has not been found to change iron nutritional status, probably due to a compensatory increase in iron absorption [(28)](#reference28). Individuals taking iron supplements should take them two hours apart from calcium-rich food or supplements to maximize iron absorption. Severe iron-deficiency [anemia](../glossary#anemia) can impair [thyroid](../glossary#thyroid) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) in the following ways: (1) by altering the thyroid-stimulating [hormone](../glossary#hormone) response of the [pituitary gland](../glossary#pituitary-gland); (2) by reducing the activity of thyroid peroxidase that [catalyzes](../glossary#catalyst) the iodination of thyroglobulin for the production of thyroid hormones; and (3) in the liver by limiting the conversion of T4 to T3, increasing T3 turnover, and decreasing T3 binding to [nuclear](../glossary#nucleus) [receptors](../glossary#receptor) [(29)](#reference29). It is estimated that [goiter](../glossary#goiter) and iron-deficiency anemia coexist in up to 25% of school-age children in west and north Africa [(30)](#reference30). A [randomized controlled study](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in iron-deficient children with goiter showed a greater reduction in thyroid size following the consumption of iodized salt together with 60 mg/day of iron four times per week compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(31)](#reference31). Additional [interventions](../glossary#intervention-trial) have confirmed that correcting iron-deficiency anemia improved the efficacy of [iodine](iodine) [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) to mitigate thyroid disorders (reviewed in [29, 30](#reference29)). Iron deficiency is the most common nutrient deficiency in the US and the world. Levels of iron deficiency are listed below from least to most severe. Iron stores are depleted, but the functional iron supply is not limited. Before the development of frank [anemia](../glossary#anemia), the supply of functional iron to tissues, including bone marrow, is inadequate such as to impair [erythropoiesis](../glossary#erythropoiesis). By definition, [anemia](../glossary#anemia) is present when individual [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) concentrations fall below two standard deviations of the distribution mean for hemoglobin in a healthy population of the same gender and age and living at the same altitude [(32)](#reference32). In 2013, iron-deficiency anemia was the leading cause of years lived with disability in children and adolescents in the 50 most populous countries. The countries with the highest [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of iron-deficiency anemia in individuals younger than 19 years were Afghanistan (41%) and Yemen (39.8%); India contributed the largest number of cases of anemia (147.9 million). The prevalence in the US was estimated to be 19.3% with nearly 16 million cases of iron-deficiency anemia in children and adolescents [(33)](#reference33). Iron-deficiency anemia occurs when there is inadequate iron to support normal red blood cell formation. The anemia of iron deficiency is usually characterized as microcytic and hypochromic, i.e., red blood cells are measurably smaller than normal and their hemoglobin content is decreased such that they are paler than normal. At this stage of iron deficiency, symptoms may be a result of inadequate oxygen delivery due to anemia and/or suboptimal function of iron-dependent [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme). Changes in [hematological](../glossary#hematology) parameters are used in the clinical diagnosis of iron-deficiency anemia (see [Assessment of iron status](#iron-status-assessment)). It is important to remember that iron deficiency is not the only cause of anemia, and that the diagnosis or treatment of iron deficiency solely on the basis of anemia may lead to misdiagnosis or inappropriate treatment of the underlying cause [(34)](#reference34). See also the articles on [Folate](../vitamins/folate#deficiency) and [Vitamin B12](../vitamins/vitamin-B12#deficiency) for information on other nutritional causes of anemia. Most of the symptoms of iron deficiency are a result of the associated [anemia](../glossary#anemia) and may include fatigue, rapid heart rate, palpitations, and rapid breathing on exertion. Iron deficiency impairs athletic performance and physical work capacity in several ways. In iron-deficiency anemia, the reduced [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) content of red blood cells results in decreased oxygen delivery to active tissues. Decreased [myoglobin](../glossary#myoglobin) levels in muscle cells limit the amount of oxygen that can be delivered to [mitochondria](../glossary#mitochondria) for [oxidative](../glossary#oxidation) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism). Iron depletion also decreases the oxidative capacity of muscle by diminishing the mitochondrial content of cytochromes and other iron-dependent [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) [(35)](#reference35). Poor [thyroid](../glossary#thyroid) function and impaired thyroid [hormone](../glossary#hormone) synthesis likely disrupt the ability to maintain a normal body temperature on exposure to cold in iron-deficient individuals (see [Function](#function)). Iron deficiency may also impair [neutrophil](../glossary#neutrophil) [phagocytosis](../glossary#phagocytosis) and microbicidal activity and T- [lymphocyte](../glossary#lymphocyte) [proliferative](../glossary#proliferation) responses to infection [(1)](#references). Severe iron-deficiency anemia may result in brittle and spoon-shaped nails, sores at the corners of the mouth, taste bud [atrophy](../glossary#atrophy), and a sore tongue. In rare cases, advanced iron-deficiency anemia may cause difficulty in swallowing due to the formation of webs of tissue in the throat and [esophagus](../glossary#esophagus) due to a degradation of the pharyngeal muscles [(36)](#reference36). The development of esophageal webs, also known as Plummer-Vinson syndrome, may require a genetic predisposition in addition to iron deficiency. Iron deficiency and iron-deficiency anemia in early childhood have been shown to impair psychomotor development and induce short- and long-term behavioral and [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) alterations (reviewed in [37](#reference37)). Further, pica, a behavioral disturbance characterized by the consumption of non-food items, may be a symptom and a cause of iron deficiency [(38)](#reference38). Neonates and infants up to six months of age: Inadequate maternal iron body stores and [anemia](../glossary#anemia) during pregnancy may reduce the duration of [gestation](../glossary#gestation) and birth weight; preterm and/or low body-weight newborns are at increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of iron-deficiency anemia [(14)](#reference14). Pregnancy complications, including [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia) and gestational [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), may also lead to low iron stores in preterm and term infants [(14)](#reference14). Most of the 150 to 250 mg of iron present in a full-term healthy newborn is accumulated during the third trimester of pregnancy and is sufficient for the first four to six months of life [(34)](#reference34). Iron stores are essential for infants less than six months of age because breast milk is relatively poor in iron (0.2 mg/L-0.4 mg/L), and intestinal absorption of iron remains low until six months of age. High iron requirements during this period of sustained and rapid growth rate can worsen the deficit in body iron in preterm infants [(14)](#reference14). Moreover, a review of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) suggested that infants with an early umbilical cord clamping (1 min after birth) are at least twice more likely to be iron-deficient at three to six months compared to those with delayed cord clamping [(39)](#reference39). Yet, healthy full-term infants have little need for external sources of iron before six months of age [(1)](#references). Infants and children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years: A full-term infant's iron stores are usually sufficient to last for the early months of life, but there is an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of iron deficiency for infants older than six months [(1)](#references). Given the sustained need of iron for increasing tissue mass, blood volume, and replenishing iron stores, the recommended dietary allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) for iron is 11 mg/day for infants aged seven to 12 months, as established by the US Institute of Medicine (see [Table 1](#table-1)). The RDA for iron is 7 mg/day for toddlers aged 1 to 3 years old. Based on the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 1999-2002 data, the [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of iron deficiency in toddlers aged 12 to 35 months varies from 6.6%-15.2%, and the prevalence of iron-deficiency anemia is 0.9%-4.4%, depending on ethnicity and socioeconomic status [(14)](#reference14). Of note, the World Health Organization (WHO) and the American Academy of Pediatrics recommend universal screening for anemia at one year of age. Yet, a recent report by the US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) stated there was insufficient evidence to assess the benefits versus harms of screening [(34](#reference34), [40)](#reference40). Adolescents: Early adolescence is period of rapid growth. Blood loss that occurs with [menstruation](../glossary#menstruation) in adolescent girls adds to the increased iron requirement of adolescence [(1)](#references). The [RDA](../glossary#RDA) of iron is 11 mg/day and 15 mg/day for adolescent boys and girls, respectively (see [Table 1](#table-1)). Nonpregnant women of childbearing age: Based on data from NHANES 2003-2006, the percentage of US women with two out of three markers of iron status (i.e., [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin), ferritin, and % transferrin saturation) below cutoff values for deficiency was 9.8% in nonpregnant women [(41)](#reference41). The use of oral contraceptives decreases [menstrual](../glossary#menstruation) blood losses and is thus associated with improved iron status compared to intrauterine devices (copper coil) [(1)](#references). Breast-feeding is associated with lower dietary iron needs, allowing for the [repletion](../glossary#replete) of iron stores depleted during pregnancy and delivery. However, iron repletion may be incomplete in high-parity women who are therefore at increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of iron deficiency [(41)](#reference41). Pregnant women: The requirement for iron is significantly increased during pregnancy due to increased iron utilization by the developing fetus and [placenta](../glossary#placenta), as well as maternal blood volume expansion [(42)](#reference42). Analysis of data from NHANES 2005-2006 found that 18.1% of pregnant women (mean age, 27.5 years) were deficient in iron, as assessed by the log ratio of soluble transferrin receptor to [serum](../glossary#serum) ferritin [(43)](#reference43). The [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of iron deficiency was greater during the second (20.7%) and third (29.7%) trimesters compared to the first trimester (4.5%) of [gestation](../glossary#gestation). Further, iron deficiency in pregnancy was found to be more prevalent in Mexican (23.6%) and Black Americans (29.6%) than in non-Hispanic White Americans (13.9%) [(43)](#reference43). Chronic bleeding or acute blood loss may result in iron deficiency. One milliliter (mL) of blood with a [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) concentration of 150 g/L contains 0.5 mg of iron. Thus, chronic loss of very small amounts of blood may result in iron deficiency. Parasitic infestation: A common cause of chronic blood loss and iron deficiency in developing countries is intestinal parasitic infection [(44)](#reference44). Frequent blood donation: Individuals who donate blood frequently, especially [menstruating](../glossary#menstruation) women, may need to increase their iron intake to prevent deficiency because each 500 mL of blood donated contains between 200 and 250 mg of iron [(45, 46)](#reference45). Regular intense exercise: Daily iron losses have been found to be greater in athletes involved in intense endurance training. This may be due to expanding blood cell mass and muscle mass, increased microscopic bleeding from the [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) tract (with the regular use of anti-inflammatory drugs), or increased fragility and [hemolysis](../glossary#hemolysis) of red blood cells [(47)](#reference47). The Food and Nutrition Board estimates that the average requirement for iron may be 30% higher for those who engage in regular intense exercise Celiac disease: [Celiac disease](../glossary#celiac-disease) (celiac estimated to occur in 1% of the population. When people with celiac disease consume food or products that contain gluten, the immune system response damages the intestinal mucosa, which may result in nutrient [malabsorption](../glossary#malabsorption) and iron-deficiency [anemia](../glossary#anemia) [(48)](#reference48). Atrophic gastritis: This condition is usually associated with the presence of [antibodies](../glossary#antibody) directed towards stomach cells and has been implicated in [pernicious anemia](../glossary#pernicious-anemia) (see the article on [Vitamin B12](../vitamins/vitamin-B12#atrophic-gastritis)). [Atrophic gastritis](../glossary#atrophic-gastritis) impairs the absorption of both vitamin B12 and iron; yet, in [menstruating](../glossary#menstruation) women, iron deficiency may occur years before the depletion of vitamin B12 body stores [(47)](#reference47). Helicobacter pylori infection: H. pylori infection is associated with iron-deficiency [anemia](../glossary#anemia), especially in children, even in the absence of [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) bleeding. Data from NHANES 2000-2001 in individuals older than three years showed that the presence of iron deficiency (based on [serum](../glossary#serum) ferritin concentrations) was 40% more [prevalent](../glossary#prevalent) in those infected with H. pylori than in H. pylori-free individuals [(49)](#reference49). Occult gastrointestinal bleeding and competition for dietary iron by [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria) may explain iron deficiency in infected individuals. Moreover, Helicobacter pylori infection may also play a role in the pathogenesis of [atrophic gastritis](../glossary#atrophic-gastritis) [(47)](#reference47). Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD): Iron-deficiency patients with [IBD](../glossary#inflammatory-bowel-disease) (e.g., [ulcerative colitis](../glossary#ulcerative-colitis), [Crohn's disease](../glossary#crohn-disease)), likely due to both impaired intestinal absorption of iron and blood loss from ulcerated mucosa [(50)](#reference50). Gastric bypass surgery: Some types of gastric bypass (bariatric) surgery increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of iron deficiency by causing [malabsorption](../glossary#malabsorption) of iron, among other nutrients [(51)](#reference51). Obesity: An [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between body weight and iron status has been reported in several [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) in children and adults [(52, 53)](#reference52). Higher hepcidin expression in [obese](../glossary#obesity) people may impair iron absorption despite adequate dietary intake of iron. Weight loss might lower [serum](../glossary#serum) hepcidin concentration and improve iron status in obese individuals [(9)](#reference9). Anemia of chronic disease: [Acute](../glossary#acute) and chronic [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) may lead to abnormally low circulating concentrations of iron and to the development of [anemia](../glossary#anemia). This type of anemia of inflammation, also known as anemia of chronic disease (ACD), is commonly observed in inflammatory disorders, [cancer](../glossary#cancer), critical illness, trauma, chronic infection, and parasitic infestation. It is thought that anemia develops because dietary iron absorption and iron mobilization from body stores are inhibited by inflammation-induced hepcidin up-regulation (see also [Systemic regulation of iron homeostasis](#systemic-regulation-iron-homeostasis)) [(9)](#reference9). Vegetarian diet with inadequate sources of iron: Because iron from plants (nonheme iron) is less efficiently absorbed than that from animal sources (see [Sources](#sources)), the US Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the Institute of Medicine (IOM) estimated that the [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of iron from a vegetarian diet was only 10% versus 18% from a mixed Western diet. Therefore, the recommended dietary allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) of iron for individuals consuming a completely vegetarian diet may be 1.8 times higher than the RDA for non-vegetarians [(25)](#reference25). Yet, a vegetarian diet does not appear to be associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of iron deficiency when it includes [whole grains](../food-beverages/whole-grains), [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes), [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts), seeds, dried fruit, iron- [fortified](../glossary#fortification) cereal, and green leafy vegetables (see [Sources](#sources)) [(54)](#reference54). Chronic kidney disease (CKD): Iron losses in CKD patients are due to significant [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) blood loss (1.2 L blood loss/year corresponding to ~400 mg iron/year) compared to individuals with normal kidney function (0.83 mL blood loss/day corresponding to ~100 mg iron/year). Estimated blood losses are even larger in patients on [hemodialysis](../glossary#hemodialysis), and iron losses may be 1,000 to 2,000 mg/year or higher. Persistent [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) in CKD patients may also contribute to inadequate iron supply for red blood cell formation despite adequate body iron stores [(55)](#reference55). The [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for iron was revised in 2001 and is based on the prevention of iron deficiency and maintenance of adequate iron stores in individuals eating a mixed diet of iron deficiency or iron-deficiency [anemia](../glossary#anemia) can limit the impact of iron inadequacy and defective [erythropoiesis](../glossary#erythropoiesis) on the following health conditions and diseases. Iron is critical for the development of the [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system), and iron deficiency is thought to be especially detrimental during the prenatal and early postnatal periods. Iron-dependent [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) are required for energy [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [(56)](#reference56). Most [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have found relationships between iron deficiency — with or without [anemia](../glossary#anemia) — in children and poor [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) development, poor school achievement, and abnormal behavior patterns (reviewed in [37](#reference37)). Whether psychomotor and mental deficits may be attributed to the lack of iron, only, or to a combination effect of iron deficiency and low [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) concentrations — like in iron-deficiency anemia and anemia of [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) — in early childhood remains unclear [(14)](#reference14). A recent [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) of six small [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials (published between 1978 and 1989) in children with iron-deficiency anemia younger than 27 months found no convincing evidence that iron therapy (for less than 11 days) had any consistent effect on measures of psychomotor and mental development within 30 days of treatment initiation [(57)](#reference57). Only one [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind) trial in anemic, iron-deficient infants examined the impact of iron therapy for four months and found a significant benefit on indices of cognitive development that needs to be further confirmed [(58)](#reference58). A review of five [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in non-anemic, iron-deficient infants (0-9 months old) suggested an improvement in psychomotor (but not mental) development throughout the first 18 months of life [(59)](#reference59). Iron supplementation in early infancy (4 to 6 months) also failed to demonstrate any long-term effect on cognitive performance and school performance at the age of 9 years compared to placebo [(60)](#reference60). At present, evidence supporting any benefits of iron therapy on neurodevelopment outcomes in infants with iron deficiency, with or without anemia, remains limited. Iron therapy might be more effective at improving cognitive outcomes in older children with anemia and/or iron deficiency. A systematic review of 17 randomized controlled trials found that iron supplementation had no effect on mental development of children under the age of 27 months but modestly improved scores of mental development in children over seven years of age [(61)](#reference61). A more recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of randomized controlled trials in children older than six years, adolescents, and women with iron deficiency, anemia, or iron-deficiency anemia suggested that supplemental iron could improve attention and concentration irrespective of participants' iron status [(62)](#reference62). A potential improvement in IQ measures with iron therapy was also reported in anemic participants regardless of their iron status. No additional benefits were observed regarding measures of memory performance, psychomotor function, and school achievements. Alterations in brain functions due to iron deficiency are likely to be resistant to iron therapy when they occur in early childhood. Long-term consequences of early life iron deficiency may include poor socioeconomic achievements and increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of certain psychopathologies, including anxiety, depression, and [schizophrenia](../glossary#schizophrenia) [(56)](#reference56). [Epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study) provide strong evidence of an association between severe [anemia](../glossary#anemia) in pregnant women and adverse pregnancy outcomes, such as low birth weight, preterm birth, and neonatal and maternal mortality [(63)](#reference63). Although iron deficiency can be a major contributing factor to severe anemia, evidence that iron-deficiency anemia causes poor pregnancy outcomes is still lacking. In addition, iron supplementation during pregnancy was shown to improve iron status and [hematological](../glossary#hematology) parameters in women but failed to significantly reduce adverse pregnancy outcomes, including low birth weight and/or prematurity, neonatal death, and [congenital anomalies](../glossary#congenital-anomaly) [(64)](#reference64). Moreover, routine supplementation during pregnancy had no effect on the length of gestation or newborn [Apgar scores](../glossary#Apgar-score) [(40)](#reference40). Nevertheless, most experts consider the control of maternal anemia to be an important part of prenatal health care, and the IOM recommends screening for anemia in each trimester of pregnancy [(65)](#reference65). The requirement for iron is greatly increased in the second and third trimesters, and the [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for pregnant women is 27 mg/day of iron (see [The Recommended Dietary Allowance](#RDA)) [(25)](#reference25). The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommend screening all pregnant women for anemia and advise iron supplementation when required [(66)](#reference66). Nonetheless, the US Preventive Services Task Force [(40)](#reference40) and the American Academy of Family Physicians [(67)](#reference67) consider that evidence is lacking to evaluate the harms and benefits of screening for iron-deficiency anemia and supplementing with iron during pregnancy. In [malaria](../glossary#malaria)-endemic regions, however, iron supplementation may improve pregnancy outcomes when provided in conjunction with measures of prevention and management of malaria. Two recent [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials failed to find an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of malaria infection in both iron-deficient and iron- [replete](../glossary#replete) pregnant women supplemented with iron, supporting the use of universal iron supplementation in malaria-endemic countries that adopt malaria intermittent preventive treatment (IPT) [(68, 69)](#reference68). Children who are chronically exposed to lead, even in small amounts, are more likely to develop learning disabilities, behavioral problems, and have low IQs. Deficits in growth and [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) development may occur in the infants of women exposed to lead during pregnancy and lactation. In adults, lead toxicity may result in kidney damage and high blood pressure. Although the use of lead in paint products, gasoline, and food cans has been discontinued in the US, lead toxicity continues to be a significant health problem, especially in children living in inner cities [(70)](#reference70). In 2012, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention set the reference value for blood lead concentration at 5 micrograms per deciliter (g/dL) to identify children at [risk](../glossary#risk). Yet, there is no known blood lead concentration below which children are 100% safe [(71)](#reference71). Iron deficiency and lead poisoning share a number of the same risk factors, including low socioeconomic status, ethnic minority groups, and residence in urban areas. Iron deficiency may increase the risk of lead poisoning in children, especially by increasing the intestinal absorption of lead via the DMT1 intestinal transporter [(72)](#reference72). However, the use of iron [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) in lead poisoning might be reserved for children who are truly iron deficient or for iron- [replete](../glossary#replete) children with chronic lead exposure (e.g., living in lead-exposed housing) [(72)](#reference72). Restless legs syndrome (RLS; also called Willis-Ekbom disease) is a [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) movement disorder of unknown [etiology](../glossary#etiology). People with RLS experience unpleasant sensations resulting in an irresistible urge to move their legs and transient relief with movement. These sensations are more common at rest and often interfere with sleep [(73)](#reference73). The [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of RLS is higher in women than in men and increases with age [(74)](#reference74). This syndrome appears to be inherited in about 50% of patients but has also been related to chronic kidney failure [(73)](#reference73). Iron deficiency may be involved in RLS development, possibly by affecting the activity of tyrosine hydroxylase, a rate limiting iron-dependent [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) in the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of the [neurotransmitter](../glossary#neurotransmitter), dopamine [(74)](#reference74). The management of RLS includes iron therapy and the use of drugs like dopamine agonists [(73)](#reference73). Current clinical evidence is insufficient to evaluate whether iron therapy may help relieve some RLS symptoms [(74)](#reference74). Yet, the Medical Advisory Board of the Willis-Ekbom Disease Syndrome Foundation suggests that iron status should be assessed in all patients with RLS, and iron therapy be attempted on a case-by-case basis in those who might benefit from it [(73)](#reference73). The amount of iron in food or [supplements](../glossary#supplement) that is absorbed and used by the body is influenced by the iron nutritional status of the individual and whether or not the iron is in the form of [heme](../glossary#heme). Because it is absorbed by a different mechanism than nonheme iron, heme iron is more readily absorbed and its absorption is less affected by other dietary factors [(2)](#reference2). In an attempt to improve body iron status, iron absorption is enhanced in individuals who are [anemic](../glossary#anemia) or iron deficient compared to iron- [replete](../glossary#replete) individuals. [Heme](../glossary#heme) iron comes mainly from [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) and [myoglobin](../glossary#myoglobin) in meat, poultry, and fish. Although heme iron accounts for only 10%-15% of the iron found in the diet, it may provide up to one-third of total absorbed dietary iron [(54)](#reference54). The absorption of heme iron is less influenced by other dietary factors than that of nonheme iron [(27)](#reference27). Plants, dairy products, meat, and iron salts added to food and [supplements](../glossary#supplement) are all sources of nonheme iron. The absorption of nonheme iron is strongly influenced by enhancers and inhibitors present in the same meal [(27)](#reference27). Enhancers of nonheme iron absorption Inhibitors of nonheme iron absorption National surveys in the US have indicated that the average dietary intake of iron is 16 to 18 mg/day in men, 12 mg/day in pre- and postmenopausal women, and about 15 mg/day in pregnant women [(25)](#reference25). Thus, the majority of premenopausal and pregnant women in the US consume less than the [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for iron, and many men consume more than the RDA (see [The Recommended Dietary Allowance](#RDA)). In the US, most grain products are [fortified](../glossary#fortification) with nonheme iron. The iron content of some relatively iron-rich foods is listed in milligrams (mg) in Table 2. For more information on the nutrient content of specific is about the size of a deck of cards.| Iron [supplements](../glossary#supplement) are indicated for the prevention and treatment of iron deficiency and iron deficiency anemia. Individuals who are not at [risk](../glossary#risk) of iron deficiency (e.g., adult men and postmenopausal women) should not take iron supplements without an appropriate medical evaluation. A number of iron supplements are available, and different forms provide different proportions of elemental iron. Ferrous sulfate heptahydrate is 20% elemental iron, ferrous sulfate monohydrate is 33% elemental iron, ferrous gluconate is 12% elemental iron, and ferrous fumarate is 33% elemental iron. If not stated otherwise, the iron discussed in this article is elemental iron. Deregulation of intestinal iron absorption will result in iron overload because the body cannot [excrete](../glossary#excretion) excess iron [(2)](#reference2). However, iron overload due to prolonged iron [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) is very rare in healthy individuals without a genetic predisposition. Several genetic disorders may lead to [pathological](../glossary#pathology) accumulation of iron in the body despite normal iron intake. Supplementation of individuals who are not iron deficient should be avoided due to the frequency of undetected inherited diseases and recent concerns about the more subtle effects of chronic excess iron intake (see [Diseases associated with iron overload](#iron-overload-associated-diseases)). [Hereditary hemochromatosis](../glossary#hereditary-hemochromatosis) [autosomal](../glossary#autosomal) [recessive](../glossary#recessive-trait) disorders of iron [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) that result in iron accumulation in the liver, heart, and other tissues. Disorders may lead to [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis) of the liver, [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), [cardiomyopathy](../glossary#cardiomyopathy) (heart muscle damage), hypogonadism, arthropathy (joint problems), and increased skin pigmentation (reviewed in [78](#reference78)). There are four main types of HH, which are classified according to the specific [gene](../glossary#gene) that is [mutated](../glossary#mutation). The most common type of HH, called Type 1 or HFE-related HH, results from mutations in the HFE gene [(79, 80)](#reference79). The majority of Type 1 HH cases are [homozygous](../glossary#homozygous) for mutation C282Y G>A (rs1800560) in the HFE gene. Another mutation found in 4% of patients with Type 1 HH is H63D C>G (rs1799945) in the HFE gene. The [protein](../glossary#protein) encoded by the HFE gene is thought to play a role in regulating intestinal absorption of dietary iron and with sensing the body's iron stores [(81)](#reference81). HFE gene mutations are associated with an increased cellular uptake of iron. With a typical disease onset before age 30, juvenile hemochromatosis (HH Type 2) is much rarer than Type 1 HH and results from genetic mutations affecting either hemojuvelin (Type 2A) or hepcidin (Type 2B) function [(82)](#reference82). HH Type 3 results from mutations in the transferrin receptor 2 gene (TFR2), and HH Type 4 (also called Ferroportin disease) results from mutations in the gene encoding ferroportin-1 (SLC40A1), a protein important in the export of iron from cells (see [Regulation](#regulation)). Type 4 HH is the second most common inherited iron overload disorder after Type 1 HH [(78)](#reference78). Iron overload in HH is treated by [phlebotomy](../glossary#phlebotomy), the removal of 500 mL of blood at a time, at intervals determined by the severity of the iron overload. [Chelation](../glossary#chelate) therapy is an alternate option to deplete iron in HH patients who cannot undergo phlebotomy treatment. Individuals with HH are advised to avoid [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) iron, but generally not told to avoid iron-rich food. High-dose [vitamin C](../vitamins/vitamin-C) regimens may worsen iron overload in patients with HH [(75)](#reference75). Alcohol consumption is strongly discouraged due to the increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of cirrhosis of the liver [(83)](#reference83). Genetic testing, which requires a blood sample, is available for those who may be at risk for HH, for example, individuals with a family history of hemochromatosis. Other genetic disorders leading to iron overload Friedreich's ataxia, and porphyria cutanea tarda [(2)](#reference2). may develop in individuals with severe hereditary [anemias](../glossary#anemia) that are not caused by iron deficiency. Excessive dietary absorption of iron may occur in response to the body's continued efforts to form red blood cells. Beta-thalassemia is characterized by defective [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) A [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) due to [mutations](../glossary#mutation) in the -globin [gene](../glossary#gene). Patients affected by thalassemia intermedia do not require blood transfusion as do those affected by the most severe form of the disease (called thalassemia major), yet they develop iron overload due to increased intestinal iron absorption [(84)](#reference84). Other anemic patients at [risk](../glossary#risk) of iron overload include those with sideroblastic anemia, [hemolytic anemia](../glossary#hemolytic-anemia), pyruvate kinase deficiency, and thalassemia major, especially because they are treated with numerous transfusions. Patients with hereditary spherocytosis and thalassemia minor do not usually develop iron overload unless they are misdiagnosed as having iron deficiency and treated with large doses of iron over many years. Iron overload has also been associated with [hemodialysis](../glossary#hemodialysis) and chronic liver diseases (metabolic, viral, and alcoholic) [(2)](#reference2). Toxic iron deposition in vital organs in [hereditary hemochromatosis](../glossary#hereditary-hemochromatosis) (HH) has been associated with an increased incidence of liver [cancer](../glossary#cancer), type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), and [neurodegenerative disease](../glossary#neurodegenerative-disease). Iron overload also increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease) in HH-free individuals. Nevertheless, whether iron tissue accumulation in those unaffected by genetic disorders is due to high dietary iron intakes is not yet fully understood [(1)](#references). [Hereditary hemochromatosis](../glossary#hereditary-hemochromatosis) that is characterized by abnormal hepatic iron accumulation is a [risk](../glossary#risk) factor for liver [cancer](../glossary#cancer) (hepatocellular carcinoma; HCC). Iron accumulation is thought to function as a [carcinogen](../glossary#carcinogen) by increasing [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) that causes damage to and [DNA](../glossary#DNA). [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine [observational an increased risk with the C282Y [mutation](../glossary#mutation) in the HFE [gene](../glossary#gene) of healthy participants and patients with chronic liver disease (see [Iron Overload](#iron-overload)) [(85)](#reference85). Other meta-analyses have reported associations between HFE gene mutations C282Y and H63D and increased risks of overall cancer [(86, 87)](#reference86). However, studies reporting on HFE gene mutations and risk of cancer at extra-hepatic sites are rather scarce and/or inconsistent. Some, but not all, observational studies found significant associations between the C282Y mutation and risk of [colorectal](../glossary#colorectal-cancer) [(88)](#reference88), breast [(88, 89)](#reference88), and epithelial ovarian cancer [(90)](#reference90). The presence of the H63D mutation in the HFE gene was linked to an increased risk of [leukemia](../glossary#leukemia) [(91, 92)](#reference91) and [gastric](../glossary#gastric) cancer [(93)](#reference93). Whether high dietary iron could increase the risk of cancer in individuals without hemochromatosis has also been investigated. The consumption of red or processed meat (but not white meat), rich in [heme](../glossary#heme) iron, has been linked to an increased risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) [(94)](#reference94). Exposure to carcinogenic compounds (called heterocyclic amines) generated when meat is cooked at high temperatures and to carcinogenic N-nitroso compounds formed in the [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) tract following consumption of red and processed meat may explain such an association [(95)](#reference95). Several meta-analyses of observational studies have also suggested a potential association of heme iron in red meat with CRC [(96-98)](#reference96). This has been explained by an increased exposure of colonic cells to potentially damaging N-nitroso compounds and derived from heme iron- [catalyzed](../glossary#catalyst) reactions [(99)](#reference99). Further, recent results from the large European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC) study suggested a higher risk of [esophageal](../glossary#esophagus) adenocarcinoma with high intakes of red/processed meat and heme iron [(100)](#reference100). Experimental studies have suggested a role for iron-induced [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) in vessel wall damage and the development of [atherosclerosis](../glossary#atherosclerosis), which underlies most forms of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) [(101)](#reference101). However, [epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study) of iron nutritional status and cardiovascular disease in humans have yielded conflicting results. A recent [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 17 [prospective cohort or [myocardial infarction](../glossary#myocardial-infarction) [MI]) did not find evidence to support the existence of strong associations between a number of different measures of iron status and CHD/MI [(102)](#reference102). Only individuals in the highest versus lowest [tertile](../glossary#tertile) of [serum](../glossary#serum) transferrin saturation exhibited an 18% lower incidence of CHD/MI meta-analysis of 21 prospective studies found saturation and serum iron to be [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with the [risk](../glossary#risk) of CHD. However, the authors noted that most studies failed to adjust for the [confounding](../glossary#confounder) effects of [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) [(103)](#reference103). The review also reported an inverse association between CHD incidence and total dietary iron intake, but dietary [heme](../glossary#heme) iron was positively associated with CHD incidence [(103)](#reference103). Although the relationship between iron stores and CHD/MI requires further clarification, it would be prudent for those who are not at risk of iron deficiency (e.g., adult men and postmenopausal women) to avoid excess iron intake (see the [LPI Rx for Health](../../rx-health)). Individuals with [hereditary hemochromatosis](../glossary#hereditary-hemochromatosis) (HH) are known to be at a heightened [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) [(104)](#reference104). Increasing evidence also suggests a role for iron excess in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes independent of hemochromatosis. [Cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study), [case-control](../glossary#case-control-study), and [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have reported an increased risk of type 2 diabetes [(105)](#reference105) and [metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome) [(106)](#reference106) with high versus low ferritin concentrations (reflecting iron body stores) after adjustment for [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation). It is currently unclear how other indices of iron status relate to the risk of type 2 diabetes [(107-110)](#reference107). Iron overload-induced [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) in patients with HH to damage [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) -cells and impair [insulin](../glossary#insulin) secretion. In subjects free of HH, iron excess might damage the liver, interfering with [glucose](../glossary#glucose) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) and triggering insulin resistance, rather than impair -cell function [(111, 112)](#reference111). Iron removal by [phlebotomy](../glossary#phlebotomy) has been shown to improve metabolic parameters in subjects with type 2 diabetes [(113)](#reference113) and metabolic syndrome [(114)](#reference114). Additional [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) are needed to determine whether lowering body stores of iron will aid in the prevention of type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome. Iron is required for normal brain and nerve function through its involvement in cellular [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), as well as in the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of [neurotransmitters](../glossary#neurotransmitter) and [myelin](../glossary#myelin). Deregulation of iron [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) has been observed disease) [(115-117)](#reference115). The abnormal accumulation of iron in the brain does not appear to be a result of increased dietary iron, but rather a disruption in the complex process of cellular iron regulation [(117)](#reference117). Brain iron accumulation can result in increased [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress), and the brain is particularly susceptible to [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage). Mechanisms behind the disruption of iron homeostasis in the brain of patients affected by neurodegenerative disease are actively being investigated. For example, studies using genetically modified mouse models indicated that the suppression of amyloid precursor protein (APP) [expression](../glossary#gene-expression) by upstream [nitric oxide](../glossary#nitric-oxide) (NO) elevation [(11)](#reference11) or loss of Tau protein [(12)](#reference12) could impair [neuronal](../glossary#neuron) export of iron and lead to iron accumulation in specific brain regions affected in Parkinson's disease. A [pilot](../glossary#pilot-study), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in patients with early-stage Parkinson's disease demonstrated oral administration of the iron [chelator](../glossary#chelate), deferiprone, for 12 months reduced iron deposition in the part of the brain called substantia nigra and improved motor performance without compromising systemic iron homeostasis [(118, 119)](#reference118). Accidental overdose of iron-containing products is the single largest cause of poisoning fatalities in children under six years of age. Although the oral lethal dose of elemental iron is approximately 180 to 250 mg/kg of body weight, considerably less has been fatal. Symptoms of [acute](../glossary#acute) toxicity may occur with iron doses of 20 to 60 mg/kg of body weight. Iron overdose is an emergency situation because the severity of iron toxicity is related to the amount of elemental iron absorbed. Acute iron poisoning produces symptoms in four stages: (1) Within one to six hours of ingestion, symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, tarry stools, lethargy, weak and rapid pulse, low blood pressure, fever, difficulty breathing, and coma; (2) If not immediately fatal, symptoms may subside for about 24 hours; (3) Symptoms may return 12 to 48 hours after iron ingestion and may include serious signs of failure in the following organ systems: [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular), kidney, liver, [hematologic](../glossary#hematology) (blood), and [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system); and (4) Long-term damage to the central nervous system, liver ( [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis)), and stomach may develop two to six weeks after ingestion [(25](#reference25), [120)](#reference120). At therapeutic levels used to treat iron deficiency, iron [supplements](../glossary#supplement) may cause [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) irritation, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation. Stools will often appear darker in color. Iron-containing liquids can temporarily stain teeth, but diluting the liquid helps to prevent this effect [(120)](#reference120). Taking iron supplements with food instead of on an empty stomach may relieve gastrointestinal effects. The Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the Institute of Medicine based the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for iron on the prevention of gastrointestinal distress (Table 3). The UL for adolescents (14-18 years) and adults, including pregnant and breast-feeding women, is 45 mg/day. It should be noted that the UL is not meant to apply to individuals being treated with iron under close medical supervision. Individuals with [hereditary hemochromatosis](../glossary#hereditary-hemochromatosis) or other conditions of iron overload, as well as individuals with alcoholic [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis) and other liver diseases, may experience adverse effects at iron intake levels below stomach acidity, such as antacids, histamine (H2) [receptor](../glossary#receptor) omeprazole, lansoprazole), may impair iron absorption. Taking iron [supplements](../glossary#supplement) at the same time as the following medications may result in decreased absorption and efficacy of the Therefore, it is best to take these medications two hours apart from iron supplements. Cholestyramine (Questran) and colestipol (Colestid), used to lower blood [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentrations, should also be taken at least four hours apart from iron supplements because they may interfere with iron absorption [(121)](#reference121). Despite the critical functions of iron in the immune response, the nature of the relationship between iron status and susceptibility to infection, especially with respect to [malaria](../glossary#malaria), has been controversial. Because iron withholding is a recognized defense mechanism against [pathogens](../glossary#pathogen) (see [Iron withholding defense during infection](#iron-withholding-defense-infection)), concerns have been raised regarding the safety of iron [supplementation](../glossary#supplement), especially in iron- [replete](../glossary#replete) children living in malaria-endemic regions [(122)](#reference122). Iron supplementation of children residing in the tropics has been associated with increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of clinical malaria and other infections like [pneumonia](../glossary#pneumonia) [(123, 124)](#reference123). A [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 24,076 children (ages, 1-35 months) living in a malaria-endemic region of eastern Africa (Tanzania) investigated the effects of supplemental iron and [folic acid](../vitamins/folate), with or without [zinc](zinc), compared to the effects of zinc alone or a [placebo](../glossary#placebo), on all-cause mortality and hospital admissions [(125)](#reference125). The administration of iron, folic acid, and/or zinc was found to increase the risk of serious adverse effects, hospital admission, and death, and was therefore prematurely halted. Further analyses of the trial revealed that iron-replete children were more likely than iron deficient-children (with or without [anemia](../glossary#anemia)) to be at risk of adverse effects following iron supplementation [(125)](#reference125). Such a potential risk of adverse effects with routine iron supplementation was not observed in preschool children in settings without malaria (southern Nepal) [(126)](#reference126). A recent review of 35 trials indicated that iron supplementation did not increase the risk of clinical malaria or other parasitic diseases, infections, and all-cause mortality in children living in malaria-endemic regions in which prevention and management of malaria are available [(127)](#reference127). Moreover, a pooled analysis of three high-quality trials demonstrated that supplemental iron combined with anti-malarial treatment protected children against clinical malaria and improved [hematological](../glossary#hematology) parameters [(127)](#reference127). The World Health Organization (WHO) currently recommends the provision of iron supplementation in infants and children, together with measures of malaria prevention, diagnosis, and treatment in malaria-endemic areas [(128)](#reference128). Following the [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for iron should provide sufficient iron to prevent deficiency without causing adverse effects in most individuals. Although sufficient iron can be obtained through a varied diet, a considerable number of people do not consume adequate iron to prevent deficiency. A [multivitamin/mineral supplement](../micronutrients-health/multivitamin-mineral-supplements) containing 100% of the daily value ( [DV](../glossary#DV)) for iron provides 18 mg of elemental iron. While this amount of iron may be beneficial for premenopausal women, it is well above the RDA for men and postmenopausal women. Since [hereditary hemochromatosis](../glossary#hereditary-hemochromatosis) is not uncommon and the effects of long-term dietary iron excess on [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease) [risk](../glossary#risk) are not yet clear, men and postmenopausal women who are not at risk of iron deficiency should take a [multivitamin/mineral supplement](../micronutrients-health/multivitamin-mineral-supplements) without iron. A number of multivitamins formulated specifically for men or those over 50 years of age do not contain iron. Moderately elevated iron stores might be much more common than iron deficiency in middle-age and older individuals [(129)](#reference129). Thus, older adults should not generally take nutritional [supplements](../glossary#supplement) containing iron unless they have been diagnosed with iron deficiency. Moreover, it is extremely important to determine the underlying cause of the iron deficiency, rather than simply treating it with iron supplements (see [The Recommended Dietary Allowance](#RDA)).
