Magnesium is involved in many deficiency can impede [vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D) and [calcium](calcium) [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis). Certain individuals are more susceptible to magnesium deficiency, especially those with [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) or [renal](../glossary#renal) disorders, those suffering from chronic alcoholism, and older people. [(More information)](#deficiency) Inadequate dietary intakes and/or low [serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of magnesium have been associated with increased risk of [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease), [osteoporosis](../health-disease/osteoporosis), and metabolic 2 [diabetes Preliminary studies have shown that magnesium improved [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) in individuals at risk for type 2 diabetes mellitus. [Randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have also investigated the role of magnesium supplementation in the prevention of complications following [stroke](../health-disease/stroke) or heart surgery. [(More information)](#disease-prevention) Magnesium sulfate is used in obstetric care for the prevention of [seizures](../glossary#seizure) in pregnant women with [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia) or [eclampsia](../glossary#eclampsia). [Observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) and randomized controlled trials also support a role for magnesium in preventing brain damage in premature infants. [(More information)](#pregnancy-complications) The use of magnesium supplementation is currently being explored in the management of various conditions, including hypertension, cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, [asthma](../glossary#asthma) and pain. [(More information)](#disease-treatment) About half of the US adult population may have insufficient magnesium intakes to support nutritional adequacy. Dietary sources rich in magnesium include green leafy vegetables, unrefined grains, [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes), beans, and [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts). [(More information)](#food-sources) The tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for supplemental magnesium is 350 mg/day. Excessive intake of supplemental magnesium can result in adverse effects, especially in individuals with impaired kidney functions. [(More information)](#safety) Magnesium plays important roles in the structure and the function of the human body. The adult human body contains about 25 grams (g) of magnesium. About 50 to 60% of all the magnesium in the body is found in the skeleton and the remainder is found in soft tissue, primarily in muscle. Magnesium is the second most abundant intracellular [cation](../glossary#cation) after [potassium](potassium). Blood contains less than 1% of total body magnesium. Only the free, [ionized](../glossary#ion) form magnesium (Mg2+) active. [Protein](../glossary#protein)-bound and of free, ionized magnesium [(1)](#references). Magnesium is involved in more than 300 essential metabolic reactions, some of which are discussed below [(2)](#reference2). The [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) and [fats](../glossary#fat) to produce energy requires numerous magnesium-dependent chemical reactions. Magnesium is required by the adenosine triphosphate ( [ATP](../glossary#ATP))-synthesizing [protein](../glossary#protein) in [mitochondria](../glossary#mitochondria). ATP, the molecule that provides energy for almost all metabolic processes, exists primarily as a complex with magnesium (MgATP) [ (3)](#reference3). Magnesium is required for a number steps during of deoxyribonucleic acid acid ( [RNA](../glossary#RNA)), [proteins](../glossary#protein). the synthesis of [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) and [lipids](../glossary#lipid) require magnesium for their activity. [Glutathione](../glossary#glutathione), an important [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant), requires magnesium for its synthesis [(3)](#reference3). Magnesium plays a role in bone, [cell membranes](../glossary#cell-membrane), and [chromosomes](../glossary#chromosome) [(3)](#reference3). Magnesium is required for the of [ions](../glossary#ion) like [potassium](potassium) and [calcium](calcium) across [cell membranes](../glossary#cell-membrane). Through its role in ion transport systems, magnesium affects the conduction of [nerve impulses](../glossary#nerve-impulse), muscle contraction, and normal heart rhythm [Cell signaling](../glossary#cell-signaling) requires MgATP for the [phosphorylation](../glossary#phosphorylation) of formation of the cell-signaling molecule, cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). cAMP is involved in many processes, including the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) from the [parathyroid glands](../glossary#parathyroid-glands) (see the articles on [Vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D) and [Calcium](calcium) for information on the role of PTH in the body) [(3)](#reference3). [Calcium](calcium) and magnesium concentrations in the fluid surrounding cells affect the migration of a number of different cell types. Such effects on cell migration may be important in wound healing [(3)](#reference3). High doses of [zinc](../minerals/zinc) in [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) form apparently interfere with the absorption of magnesium. One study reported that zinc supplements of 142 mg/day (well above the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) of 40 mg/day for zinc) in healthy adult males significantly decreased magnesium absorption and disrupted magnesium balance (the difference between magnesium intake and magnesium loss) [(4)](#reference4). Large increases in the intake of [dietary fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber) have been found to decrease magnesium utilization in experimental studies. However, the extent to which dietary fiber affects magnesium nutritional status in individuals with a varied diet outside the laboratory is not clear [(2, 3)](#reference2). Dietary [protein](../glossary#protein) intake may affect magnesium absorption. One study in adolescent boys found that magnesium absorption was directly related to protein intake, with magnesium absorption the lowest when protein intake was less than 30 g/day [(5)](#reference5). The active form of [vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D) (calcitriol) may slightly increase intestinal absorption of magnesium [(6)](#reference6). However, it is not clear whether magnesium absorption is calcitriol-dependent as is the absorption of [calcium](calcium) and phosphate. High calcium intake has not been found to affect magnesium balance in most studies. Inadequate blood magnesium concentrations are known to result in low blood calcium concentrations, resistance to parathyroid hormone (PTH) action, and resistance to some of the effects of vitamin D [(2, 3)](#reference2). Magnesium deficiency in healthy individuals who are consuming a balanced diet is quite rare because magnesium is abundant in both plant and animal foods and because the kidneys are able to limit urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of magnesium when intake is low. The following conditions increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of magnesium deficiency [(7)](#reference7): Poor dietary intake, [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) problems, and increased urinary loss of magnesium may all contribute to magnesium depletion in people suffering from alcoholism. Older adults have relatively low dietary intakes of magnesium [(8, 9)](#reference8). Intestinal magnesium absorption tends to decrease with age, and urinary magnesium excretion tends to increase with age; thus, suboptimal dietary magnesium intake may increase the risk of magnesium depletion in the elderly [(2)](#reference2). Although severe magnesium deficiency is uncommon, it has been induced experimentally. When magnesium deficiency was induced in humans, the earliest sign was a decrease in [serum](../glossary#serum) magnesium concentration. Hypomagnesemia usually describes serum [calcium](calcium) concentration also began to decrease (hypocalcemia) despite adequate dietary calcium. Hypocalcemia persisted despite increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which regulates calcium [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis). Usually, increased PTH secretion quickly results in the mobilization of calcium from bone and normalization of blood calcium concentration. As the magnesium depletion progressed, PTH secretion diminished to low concentrations. In addition to hypomagnesemia, signs of severe magnesium deficiency included hypocalcemia, low serum [potassium](potassium) concentrations (hypokalemia), retention of [sodium](sodium), low circulating PTH concentrations, [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) and muscular symptoms ( [tremor](../glossary#tremor), muscle spasms, [tetany](../glossary#tetany)), loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, and personality changes [(3)](#reference3). While mild magnesium deficiency may not elicit clinical symptoms, it may be associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease) (see [Disease Prevention](#disease-prevention)) [(1)](#references). There currently no reliable indicator of magnesium [status](../glossary#status). The magnesium tolerance test, which basically determines magnesium retention (using 24-h urine collection) following the [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) administration of magnesium, is considered to be the gold standard [(1)](#references). If this method is a good indicator of hypomagnesemia in adults, it appears to be poorly sensitive to changes in magnesium status in healthy people. Moreover, the method is invasive and cumbersome, and thus difficult to use routinely [(10)](#reference10). Another method to assess magnesium status is through measurements of [plasma](../glossary#plasma) ionized magnesium, which represents the physiologically active form of magnesium. However, it is unknown whether plasma ionized magnesium reflect body stores [(10)](#reference10). In practice, magnesium status is usually determined through assessments of dietary magnesium intake, [serum](../glossary#serum) magnesium concentration, and/or urinary magnesium concentration [(10)](#reference10). However, each of these indicators has limitations. Although predominantly used in [epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study) and the sole indicator available to clinicians, serum magnesium concentration has been found to poorly respond to magnesium supplementation. Regarding dietary intakes of magnesium, about 30 to 40% of ingested magnesium is absorbed, yet absorption varies with the amount of magnesium ingested and with the food matrix composition. Finally, a state of magnesium deficiency has not been associated to a clear cutoff concentration of magnesium in the urine. Urinary magnesium concentration fluctuates rapidly with dietary intakes, but measurements of 24-hour urinary magnesium can be used in addition to other indicators to assess population status. Presently, a combination of all three markers — dietary, serum, and urinary magnesium — may be used to get a valid assessment of magnesium status (reviewed in [10](#reference10)). In 1997, the Food and Nutrition Board of the Institute of Medicine increased the Recommended Dietary Allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) for magnesium, based on the results of tightly controlled [balance studies](../glossary#balance-study) that utilized more accurate methods of measuring magnesium (Table 1) [(2)](#reference2). Balance studies are useful for determining the amount of a nutrient that will prevent deficiency; however, such studies provide little information regarding the amount of a nutrient required for [chronic the concomitant presentation of several metabolic disorders in an individual, including dyslipidemia, [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure), [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance), and [obesity](../glossary#obesity) [(11)](#reference11). People with metabolic [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease), and some types of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [(12-14)](#reference12). A 2015 analysis of data from the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES 2001-2010) in 9,148 adults (mean age, 50 years) found a 32% lower risk of metabolic syndrome in those in the highest versus lowest [quantile](../glossary#quantile) of magnesium intake (355 mg/day reported an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between dietary magnesium intake and risk of metabolic syndrome [(16-18)](#reference16). Moreover, lower [serum](../glossary#serum) magnesium concentrations have been reported in individuals with metabolic syndrome compared to controls [(18, 19)](#reference18). However, circulating magnesium represents only 1% of total body stores and is tightly regulated; thus, serum magnesium concentrations do not best reflect magnesium status [(1)](#references). At present, additional evidence is needed from prospectively designed studies to inform the potential relationship between dietary and circulating magnesium and the risk of metabolic syndrome. Systemic [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), which contributes to the development of metabolic disorders, has been inversely correlated with magnesium intakes in a cross-sectional study of 11,686 women (45 years). In this study, the lowest [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of metabolic syndrome was found in the group of women in the highest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of magnesium intakes (median intake, 422 mg/day) [(20)](#reference20). Several reported a reduction in circulating [C-reactive protein](../glossary#c-reactive-protein) (CRP) — a marker of inflammation — following oral magnesium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) [(21)](#reference21). This might constitute a potential mechanism through which magnesium could play a role in the prevention of metabolic disorders. Large [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have examined the relationship between magnesium and blood pressure. However, the fact that foods high in magnesium (fruit, vegetables, whole grains) are frequently high in [potassium](potassium) and [dietary fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber) has made it difficult to evaluate the independent effect of magnesium on blood pressure. Findings from large cohorts, including the Health Professionals Follow-up Study (HPFS) [(22)](#reference22), the Nurses' Health Study Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities (ARIC) study [(24)](#reference24), and the Coronary Artery Risk Development in Young Adults (CARDIA) study [(25)](#reference25), have been summarized in a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) [(26)](#reference26). The pooled analysis of seven prospective studies showed an 8% lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure) with higher versus lower dietary magnesium intakes [(26)](#reference26). In one of these studies, data from 5,511 men and women followed for a median period of 7.6 years found that the highest concentrations of urinary magnesium corresponded to a 25% reduction in the risk of hypertension, whereas there was no association between [plasma](../glossary#plasma) magnesium concentrations and the risk of hypertension [(27)](#reference27). There was also no evidence of an association between circulating magnesium concentrations and the risk of hypertension in a meta-analysis of three prospective cohort studies [(26)](#reference26). The relationship between magnesium intake and risk of hypertension suggests that improving diet quality or using magnesium [supplements](../glossary#supplement) might play a role in the prevention of hypertension in those with inadequate dietary intakes. The buildup of plaque inside arterial walls — a process called [atherosclerosis](../health-disease/atherosclerosis) — is an early event in the development of [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease). The [calcification](../glossary#calcification) of atherosclerotic plaques that occurs with the progression of atherosclerosis has been associated with a three- to four-fold increase in the [risk](../glossary#risk) of cardiovascular events and mortality [(28)](#reference28). Individuals with chronic kidney disease (CKD): Abnormalities in mineral and bone [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) are not uncommon in individuals with impaired kidney function and have been associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) and mortality [(29, 30)](#reference29). In particular, elevated blood [phosphorus](phosphorus) concentration and increased deposition of [calcium](calcium) phosphate within the vasculature are thought to promote vascular [calcification](../glossary#calcification). Since magnesium can function as a calcium [antagonist](../glossary#antagonist), it has been suggested that it could be utilized to slow down or reverse the calcification of vessels observed in patients with CKD. In a [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) in patients with pre-dialysis CKD, higher [serum](../glossary#serum) magnesium concentrations were associated with lower coronary artery calcification density scores in those in the higher end of normal serum phosphorus concentrations (i.e., 3.4 mg/dL) [(31)](#reference31). One small [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in participants with CKD examined the effect of oral, slow-release magnesium hydroxide on the calcification propensity of serum by measuring the time needed for primary calciprotein particles (containing amorphous calcium phosphate) to transform into secondary calciprotein particles (containing crystalline [hydroxyapatite](../glossary#hydroxyapatite)) [(32)](#reference32). Increased serum calcification propensity has been associated with greater risk of mortality in patients with impaired kidney function [(33, 34)](#reference33). The trial found an increase in serum magnesium concentration and a reduction in serum calcification propensity — i.e., an increase in the time needed for 50% of the transformation to occur (T50) — with 720 mg/day of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) magnesium for eight weeks compared to placebo [(32)](#reference32). Serum calcification propensity was also reduced when magnesium concentration was increased (from 1 to 2 mEq/L for 28 days) in the dialysate of patients with established kidney failure [(35)](#reference35). A larger [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in patients with pre-dialysis CKD is underway to examine further the effect of oral magnesium on markers of vascular calcification, markers of mineral and bone metabolism, incidence of [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events, and deterioration of kidney function [(36)](#reference36). Individuals with normal kidney function: The [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) analysis of data from 2,695 middle-aged participants in the Framingham Heart Study showed that the odds of having [coronary artery](../glossary#coronary-arteries) [calcification](../glossary#calcification) was 58% lower in those in the highest versus lowest [quartile](../glossary#quartile) of total magnesium intakes (median values, 427 mg/day versus 259 mg/day) [(37)](#reference37). magnesium concentration with vascular calcification in recent population-based cross-sectional studies [(38-40)](#reference38). No research has yet examined whether improving magnesium [status](../glossary#status) of generally healthy people could play a role in [atherosclerosis](../health-disease/atherosclerosis) prevention. Dietary magnesium intakes: Several large [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), including the Health Professionals Follow-up Study (HPFS) and the Nurses' Health Study (NHS), have examined magnesium intakes in relation to [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) outcomes. In the most recent analysis of the NHS, which followed nearly 90,000 female nurses for 28 years, those in the highest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of magnesium intake had a 39% lower [risk](../glossary#risk) (but not nonfatal [coronary heart versus <246 mg/day) [(41)](#reference41). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine prospective cohort studies, mostly conducted in participants without [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) at baseline, reported a 22% lower risk of CHD per 200 mg/day incremental intake in dietary magnesium [(42)](#reference42). A more recent meta-analysis by Fang et al. [(43)](#reference43) included six studies and reported a 10% lower risk of CHD with higher versus lower dietary magnesium intakes. Higher magnesium intakes were associated with an 8 to 11% reduction in [stroke](../health-disease/stroke) risk in two meta-analyses of prospective studies, each including over 240,000 participants [(44, 45)](#reference44). The most recent pooled analysis of 14 studies found a 12% lower risk of stroke with higher versus lower magnesium intakes and estimated a 7% risk reduction of stroke associated with each 100-mg increment in daily magnesium intake [(43)](#reference43). Only two prospective studies have examined the risk of [heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure) in relation to magnesium intakes. The pooled analysis suggested a 31% lower risk of heart failure with higher dietary magnesium intakes [(43)](#reference43). Finally, a meta-analysis of 13 prospective studies in over 475,000 participants reported that the risk of total [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events, including stroke, nonfatal myocardial infarction, and CHD, was 15% lower in individuals with higher intakes of magnesium [(46)](#reference46). However, in the recent meta-analysis of eight studies by Fang et al. [(43)](#reference43), there was no association between dietary magnesium intake and risk of total cardiovascular disease. It is important to note that while these prospective cohort studies assessed the association between dietary magnesium and cardiovascular disease, they did not account for the use of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) magnesium by a significant fraction of participants. Serum magnesium concentrations: One large [prospective study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) (almost 14,000 men and women) associated higher [serum](../glossary#serum) magnesium concentrations with a lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of [CHD](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) in women but not in men [(47)](#reference47). This study was included in a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of four studies that showed no evidence of a reduced risk of CHD with increasing serum magnesium concentrations [(42)](#reference42). In contrast, a 0.2 mmol/L increment in serum magnesium concentration was associated with a 30% lower risk of total [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) in a pooled analysis of eight [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) [(42)](#reference42). In the recently published British Regional Heart Study that followed 3,523 men for a mean 15 years, there was no association between serum magnesium concentration and incidental CHD events, yet serum magnesium concentration was [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with the risk of [heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure) [(48)](#reference48). A number of early studies found lower [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular)-related mortality in populations who routinely consume "hard" water. Hard ( [alkaline](../glossary#alkaline)) water is generally high in magnesium but may also contain more [calcium](calcium) and [fluoride](fluoride) than "soft" water, making the cardioprotective effects of hard water difficult to attribute to magnesium alone [(49)](#reference49). Additionally, [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [prospective studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have found no associations between magnesium intake and cardiovascular [(50)](#reference50) or all-cause mortality [(43)](#reference43). In a prospective analysis of NHANES data from 14,353 participants, followed for a median period of 28.6 years, the [risk](../glossary#risk) of all-cause and [stroke](../health-disease/stroke) mortality was significantly increased in those with low rather than normal [serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of magnesium than hypomagnesemia — in people with [heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure) was associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular and all-cause mortality [(52)](#reference52). Occurrence of hypomagnesemia has been reported in patients who suffered from a subarachnoid [hemorrhage](../glossary#hemorrhage) (a type of [stroke](../health-disease/stroke)) caused by the rupture of a [cerebral](../glossary#cerebral) aneurysm [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) outcomes following an (aSAH) have been linked to inappropriate [calcium](calcium)-dependent contraction of arteries (known as cerebral arterial vasospasm), leading to delayed cerebral [ischemia](../glossary#ischemia) [(54)](#reference54). Because magnesium is a calcium [antagonist](../glossary#antagonist) and potent several [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have examined whether [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) magnesium sulfate infusions could reduce the incidence of vasospasm after aSAH. A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine randomized controlled trials found that magnesium therapy after aSAH significantly reduced vasospasm but failed to prevent neurologic deterioration or decrease the [risk](../glossary#risk) of death [(55)](#reference55). Another meta-analysis of 13 trials in 2,413 aSAH sufferers concluded that the infusion of magnesium sulfate had no benefit regarding neurologic outcome and mortality, despite a reduction in the incidence of delayed cerebral ischemia [(56)](#reference56). The post-hoc analysis of a small randomized controlled trial suggested that maintaining magnesium sulfate infusion for 10 days post-aSAH or until signs of vasospasm disappear might protect against secondary cerebral infarction when markers of [vasoconstriction](../glossary#vasoconstriction) and reduced brain perfusion are present [(57, 58)](#reference57). Current evidence does not support the use of magnesium supplementation in clinical practice for aSAH patients normalization. Atrial [arrhythmia](../health-disease/arrhythmia) (also called [atrial fibrillation](../glossary#atrial-fibrillation)) is a condition defined as the occurrence of persistent heart rate abnormalities; such arrhythmias often complicate the recovery of patients after cardiac surgery. The use of magnesium in the [prophylaxis](../glossary#prophylaxis) of postoperative atrial arrhythmia after [coronary artery bypass grafting](../glossary#coronary-artery-bypass-graft) has been evaluated as a sole or adjunctive agent to classical antiarrhythmic molecules (namely, -blockers and amiodarone) in several prospective, [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 21 intervention studies showed [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) magnesium infusions could significantly reduce postoperative atrial arrhythmia in treated compared to untreated patients [(59)](#reference59). The results of a more recent meta-analysis of 22 [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials suggested that magnesium may effectively reduce atrial arrhythmia when administered post-operatively, as a bolus, and for more than 24 hours [(60)](#reference60). However, another meta-analysis of four trials found that magnesium was no more effective than other antiarrhythmic agents [(60)](#reference60). Moreover, the meta-analysis of five randomized controlled trials also suggested that intravenous magnesium added to -blocker treatment did not decrease the risk of atrial arrhythmia compared to -blocker alone and was associated with more adverse effects (bradycardia and hypotension) [(61)](#reference61). Presently, high-quality evidence is still lacking to support the use of magnesium in the prophylaxis of post-operative atrial fibrillation and other in patients with contraindications to first-line antiarrhythmic agents [(60)](#reference60). Public health concerns regarding the epidemics of [obesity](../glossary#obesity) and type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) and the prominent role of magnesium in [glucose](../glossary#glucose) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) have led scientists to investigate the relationship between magnesium intake and type 2 diabetes mellitus. A [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) that followed more than 25,000 individuals, 35 to 65 years of age, for seven years found no difference in incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus when comparing the highest (377 mg/day) [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of magnesium intake to the lowest quintile (268 mg/day) [(62)](#reference62). However, inclusion of this study in a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of eight cohort studies showed that the [risk](../glossary#risk) of type 2 diabetes was [inversely correlated](../glossary#inverse-association) with magnesium intake [(62)](#reference62). The most recent meta-analysis of 25 prospective cohort studies, including 637,922 individuals and 26,828 new cases of type 2 diabetes mellitus, found that higher magnesium intakes were associated with a 17% lower risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus [(63)](#reference63). Several meta-analyses conducted to date reported an 8 to 15% decrease in the risk of developing type 2 diabetes mellitus with each 100 mg-increment in dietary magnesium intake [(63-66)](#reference63). [Insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance), characterized by alterations in both [insulin](../glossary#insulin) secretion by the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas) and insulin action on target tissues, has been linked to inadequate magnesium [status](../glossary#status). A [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) analysis of the Cohorts for Heart and Aging Research in Genomic Epidemiology (CHARGE) consortium, which included 15 cohorts with a total of 52,684 diabetes-free participants, showed that magnesium intakes were inversely associated with fasting insulin concentrations after multiple adjustments, including various lifestyle factors, [body mass index](../glossary#body-mass-index) (BMI), caffeine intake, and [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber) intake [(65)](#reference65). It is thought that pancreatic -cells, which secrete insulin, could become less responsive to changes in [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) in magnesium-deficient subjects [(67)](#reference67). A [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled healthy with significant hypomagnesemia ( [serum](../glossary#serum) magnesium concentration 0.70 mmol/L) showed that daily consumption of 638 mg of magnesium (from a solution of magnesium chloride) for three months improved the function of pancreatic -cells, resulting in lower fasting glucose and insulin concentrations [(68)](#reference68). In a follow-up [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-contolled-trial), the administration of 382 mg/day of magnesium for four months to participants (mean age, 42 years) with both hypomagnesemia (serum magnesium concentration <0.74 mmoles/L) and impaired fasting glucose improved serum magnesium concentrations, as well as fasting and post-load glucose concentrations [(69)](#reference69). Other metabolic markers, including serum [triglycerides](../glossary#triglycerides), [HDL](../glossary#HDL)-cholesterol, and a measure of insulin resistance, also improved in magnesium- versus placebo-treated individuals [(69)](#reference69). Additionally, similar metabolic improvements have been reported following the supplementation of magnesium (382 mg/day for four months) to participants who were both hypomagnesemic and lean yet metabolically obese (i.e., with metabolic disorders usually associated with obesity) [(70)](#reference70). In another study, supplementation with 365 mg/day of magnesium (from magnesium aspartate hydrochloride) for six months reduced insulin resistance in 27 overweight individuals with normal values of serum and intracellular magnesium [(71)](#reference71). This latter study suggests that magnesium might have additional effects on glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity that go beyond the normalization of serum magnesium concentrations in hypomagnesemic individuals. Although decreased [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) (BMD) is the primary feature of [osteoporosis](../health-disease/osteoporosis), other osteoporotic changes in the [collagenous matrix](../glossary#collagenous-matrix) and [mineral](../glossary#mineral) composition of bone may result in bones that are brittle and more susceptible to [fracture](../glossary#fracture) [(72)](#reference72). Around 60% of total body magnesium is stored in the skeleton and is known to influence both bone matrix and bone mineral [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism). Magnesium at the surface of bones is also available for dynamic exchange with blood [(73)](#reference73). As the magnesium content of bone mineral decreases, [hydroxyapatite](../glossary#hydroxyapatite) crystals of bone may become larger and more brittle. Some studies have found lower magnesium content and larger hydroxyapatite crystals in bones of women with osteoporosis compared to disease-free women [(74)](#reference74). Inadequate [serum](../glossary#serum) magnesium concentrations are known to result in low serum calcium concentrations, resistance to parathyroid hormone (PTH) action, and resistance to some of the effects of vitamin D (calcitriol), all of which can lead to increased bone loss (see the articles on [Vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D) and [Calcium](calcium)). Lower serum magnesium concentrations may not be unusual in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis [(75)](#reference75), and hypomagnesemia has been reported as an adverse effect of using the prescription drug teriparatide (Forteo) in the treatment of osteoporosis [(76)](#reference76). Higher dietary magnesium intakes have been associated BMD [(78)](#reference78) in [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study), including studies of older adults. More recently, a large cohort study conducted in almost two-thirds of the Norwegian population found the level of magnesium in drinking water to be [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with the [risk](../glossary#risk) of hip fracture [(79)](#reference79). In the Women's Health Initiative study, data analysis from 4,778 participants (mean age, 63 years) followed for about seven years showed that higher magnesium intakes were associated with higher hip and whole-body BMD but not with reduced hip or total fractures [(80)](#reference80). Moreover, the highest versus lowest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of total magnesium intakes was associated with a 23% increased risk of lower arm and wrist fractures [(80)](#reference80). In a case-cohort study nested within the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC)-Norfolk study, which included 5,319 individuals, total magnesium and potassium intakes were found to be inversely associated with heel bone (calcaneus) broadband ultrasound attenuation (BUA) measurements — which are predictive of the risk of incidental fracture — and with the risk of hip fractures [(81)](#reference81). Few studies have addressed the effect of magnesium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) on BMD or osteoporosis in humans. In a small group of postmenopausal women with osteoporosis, magnesium supplementation of 750 mg/day for six months followed by 250 mg/day for 18 more months resulted in increased BMD at the wrist after one year, with no further increase after two years of supplementation [(82)](#reference82). A study in postmenopausal women who were taking [estrogen](../glossary#estrogen) replacement therapy and a multivitamin supplement found that supplementation with an additional 400 mg/day of magnesium and 600 mg/day of calcium resulted in increased BMD at the heel compared to postmenopausal women receiving estrogen replacement therapy only [(83)](#reference83). A more recent randomized controlled study conducted in 20 postmenopausal women with osteoporosis suggested that high-dose supplementation with magnesium citrate (1,830 mg/day) for one month could reduce the rapid rate of bone loss that characterizes osteoporosis [(84)](#reference84). Evidence is not yet sufficient to suggest that supplemental magnesium in excess of the RDA could be effective in the prevention of osteoporosis unless normalization of serum magnesium concentration is required [(85)](#reference85). Sarcopenia is a condition characterized by a loss of skeletal muscle mass that increases frailty and [risk](../glossary#risk) of falls in older adults [(86)](#reference86). Several [cross-sectional studies](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) have reported a positive association between dietary magnesium intakes and proxy measures of skeletal muscle mass in middle-age and older adults [(87-90)](#reference87). A 2014 [randomized controlled study](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 139 physically active and healthy older women (mean age, 71.5 years) found little-to-no impact of magnesium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) (900 mg/day of magnesium oxide) for 12 weeks on body composition and muscle strength, yet the Short Physical Performance Battery [SPPB] test score — a composite indicator of physical function — improved [(91)](#reference91). More research is needed to examine further the effect of magnesium supplementation on body composition, muscle strength, and physical performance in older adults, whether physically active or sedentary, and with normal or inadequate magnesium [status](../glossary#status). The use of [pharmacologic doses](../glossary#pharmacological-dose) of magnesium to treat specific disorders is discussed below. Although many of the cited studies utilized [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) magnesium at doses considerably higher than the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)), which is 350 mg/day set by the Food and Nutrition Board (see [Safety](#safety)), it is important to note that these studies were all conducted under medical supervision. Because of the potential side effects of high doses of magnesium, especially in the presence of impaired kidney function, any disease treatment trial using oral magnesium doses higher than the UL should be conducted under medical supervision. Moreover, [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) magnesium has been used in the management of several conditions. [Preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia) and [eclampsia](../glossary#eclampsia) are hypertensive disorders of pregnancy that may occur at any time after 20 weeks' [gestation](../glossary#gestation) and persist up to six weeks following birth. Preeclampsia (sometimes called toxemia of pregnancy) affects approximately 4% of pregnant women in the US [(92)](#reference92). Preeclampsia is defined as the presence of elevated blood pressure ( [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure)), [protein](../glossary#protein) in the urine, and severe swelling ( [edema](../glossary#edema)) during pregnancy [(93)](#reference93). Eclampsia occurs with the addition of [seizures](../glossary#seizure) to the triad of preeclamptic symptoms and is a significant cause of [perinatal](../glossary#perinatal) and maternal mortality [(93, 94)](#reference93). Although cases of preeclampsia are at high [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing eclampsia, one-quarter of eclamptic women do not initially exhibit preeclamptic symptoms [(95)](#reference95). Although lower magnesium concentrations have been reported in the blood and brain of women with preeclampsia than in healthy pregnant women, there is no evidence that magnesium imbalance may cause adverse pregnancy events. A 2014 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 10 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found no effect of oral magnesium salt administration during normal and at-risk pregnancies on the risk of preeclampsia, perinatal mortality, and small-for-gestational age infants [(96)](#reference96). For many years, high-dose [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) magnesium sulfate has been the treatment of choice for preventing eclamptic seizures that may occur in association with severe preeclampsia in pregnancy or during labor [(97, 98)](#reference97). A [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) of seven [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) trials in 1,396 women with eclampsia compared the effect of magnesium sulfate administration with diazepam (a known [anticonvulsant](../glossary#anticonvulsant)) treatment on perinatal outcomes. Risks of recurrent seizures and maternal death were significantly reduced by the magnesium regimen compared to diazepam. Moreover, the use of magnesium for the care of eclamptic women resulted in newborns with higher [Apgar scores](../glossary#Apgar-score); there was no significant difference in the risk of preterm birth and perinatal mortality [(95)](#reference95). Additional research has confirmed that infusion of magnesium sulfate should always be considered in the management of severe preeclampsia and eclampsia to prevent initial and recurrent seizures [(99)](#reference99). Moreover, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the use of magnesium sulfate — administered either intramuscularly or intravenously — as first-line treatment for the prevention of eclampsia in women with severe preeclampsia, in preference to other anticonvulsants [(100)](#reference100). Further research is needed to evaluate the efficacy of magnesium salt infusion in eclampsia [prophylaxis](../glossary#prophylaxis) in women with mild preeclampsia [(101)](#reference101). In addition, it is unclear whether prolonging magnesium use post-partum in women who presented with severe preeclampsia during pregnancy is necessary to lower the risk of eclampsia after delivery [(102)](#reference102). While [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) magnesium sulfate is included in the medical care of [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia) and [eclampsia](../glossary#eclampsia), the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine support its use in two additional situations: specific conditions of short-term prolongation of pregnancy and neuroprotection of the fetus in anticipated premature delivery [(103)](#reference103). Preterm birth, which is defined by the premature delivery of an infant between the 20th and 37th weeks of estimated [gestation](../glossary#gestation), is associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [perinatal](../glossary#perinatal) mortality and both short- and long-term morbidity. The ACOG approves the use of different classes of drugs — known as tocolytics — that are meant to delay delivery for long enough so that antenatal corticoids can be used to accelerate lung maturation in the fetus of women at imminent risk of preterm labor [(104)](#reference104). A 2014 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 37 trials found that intravenous infusion of magnesium sulfate was no more efficacious than commonly used tocolytics (e.g., -adrenergic [receptor](../glossary#receptor) agonists, calcium channel blockers, prostaglandin inhibitors) in delaying delivery or preventing serious infant outcomes [(105)](#reference105). Very limited evidence also suggested that high- versus low-dose magnesium infusion may reduce the length of hospital stays in neonates admitted to intensive care units [(106)](#reference106). The relationship between magnesium sulfate and risk of [cerebral](../glossary#cerebral) damage in premature infants has been assessed in [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study). A meta-analysis of six [case-control](../glossary#case-control-study) and five [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) showed that the use of magnesium significantly reduced the risk of cerebral palsy, as well as mortality [(107)](#reference107). However, the high degree of [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) among the cohort studies and the fact that [corticosteroid](../glossary#corticosteroid) exposure (which is known to decrease antenatal mortality) was higher in the cases of children exposed to magnesium compared to controls imply a cautious interpretation of the results. Nonetheless, a meta-analysis of five [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), which included 5,493 women at risk of preterm birth and 6,135 babies, found that magnesium therapy given to mothers delivering before term decreased the risk of cerebral palsy by 32% without causing severe adverse maternal events, but this treatment did not reduce the risk of other [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) impairments or mortality in early childhood [(108)](#reference108). Another meta-analysis conducted on five randomized controlled trials found that intravenous magnesium administration to newborns who suffered from perinatal [asphyxia](../glossary#asphyxia) could be beneficial in terms of short-term neurologic outcomes, although there was no effect on mortality [(109)](#reference109). Additional trials are needed to evaluate the long-term benefits of magnesium in pediatric care. While results from [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-study) have not been entirely consistent [(2)](#reference2), the latest review of the data highlighted a therapeutic benefit of magnesium [supplements](../glossary#supplement) in treating [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure). A 2012 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) examined [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials of magnesium supplementation conducted in 1,173 individuals with either normal blood pressure (normotensive) or hypertension (treated with medication or untreated). Oral supplementation with magnesium (mean dose of 410 mg/day; range of 120 to 973 mg/day) for a median period of 11.3 months significantly reduced [systolic blood pressure](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) by 2 to 3 mm Hg and [diastolic blood pressure](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) by 3 to 4 mm Hg [(110)](#reference110); a greater effect was seen at higher doses (370 mg/day). The results of 19 of the 22 trials included in the meta-analysis were previously reviewed together with another 25 intervention studies [(111)](#reference111). The systematic examination of these 44 trials suggested a blood pressure-lowering effect associated with supplemental magnesium in hypertensive but not in normotensive individuals. Magnesium doses required to achieve a decrease in blood pressure appeared to depend on whether participants with high blood pressure were treated with antihypertensive medications, including [diuretics](../glossary#diuretic). Intervention trials on treated participants showed a reduction in hypertension with magnesium doses from 243 mg/day to 486 mg/day, whereas untreated patients required doses above 486 mg/day to achieve a significant decrease in blood pressure. A more recent meta-analysis of randomized controlled studies with 2,028 participants found that supplemental magnesium at a median dose of 368 mg/day (range: 238-960 mg/day) for a median duration of three months (range: 3 weeks-6 months) increased [serum](../glossary#serum) magnesium concentration by 0.05 mmol/L (27 trials) and reduced systolic blood pressure by 2 mm Hg and diastolic blood pressure by 1.78 mm Hg (37 trials) [(112)](#reference112). A 2017 meta-analysis restricted to trials in participants with underlying preclinical ( [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance) or prediabetes) or clinical conditions (type mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) or [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease)) found a 4.18 mm Hg reduction in systolic blood pressure and a 2.27 mm Hg reduction in diastolic blood pressure with supplemental doses of magnesium ranging between 365 mg/day and 450 mg/day for one to six months [(113)](#reference113). While oral magnesium supplementation may be helpful in hypertensive individuals who are depleted of magnesium due to chronic diuretic use and/or inadequate dietary intake [(7)](#reference7), several dietary factors play a role in hypertension. For example, adherence to the DASH diet — a diet rich in fruit, vegetables, and low-fat dairy and low in [saturated](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid) and total fats — has been linked to significant reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressures [(114)](#reference114). See the Blood Pressure](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/health-disease/high-blood-pressure). [Vascular endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) cells line arterial walls where they are in contact with the blood that flows through the circulatory system. Normally functioning vascular endothelium promotes [vasodilation](../glossary#vasodilation) when needed, for example, during exercise, and inhibits the formation of blood clots. Conversely, endothelial dysfunction results in widespread [vasoconstriction](../glossary#vasoconstriction) and [coagulation](../glossary#coagulation) abnormalities. In [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease), chronic [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) is associated with the formation of [atherosclerotic](../health-disease/atherosclerosis) plaques in arteries. [Atherosclerosis](../health-disease/atherosclerosis) impairs normal endothelial function, increasing the [risk](../glossary#risk) of vasoconstriction and clot formation, which may lead to [heart attack](../health-disease/heart-attack) or [stroke](../health-disease/stroke) (reviewed in [115](#reference115)). A recent [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) identified six [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) that examined the of [pharmacologic doses](../glossary#pharmacological-dose) of oral magnesium on vascular endothelial function [(116)](#reference116). Three out of six trials, which individuals with [coronary artery disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) [(117)](#reference117), [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) dilation (FMD) with [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) magnesium compared to control. In other words, the normal dilation response of the brachial (arm) artery to increased blood flow was improved. In contrast, there was no evidence of an effect of magnesium supplementation on FMD in three trials conducted in [hemodialysis](../glossary#hemodialysis) patients [(120)](#reference120) or healthy participants with normal [(121)](#reference121) or high [body mass index](../glossary#body-mass-index) (BMI) [(122)](#reference122). A pooled analysis of the six trials in 262 participants found that supplementation with 107 to 730 mg/day of magnesium for one to six months resulted in an overall improvement of FMD, regardless of the health status or baseline magnesium concentrations of participants [(116)](#reference116). The measurement of the thickness of the inner layers of the [carotid arteries](../glossary#carotid-arteries) is sometimes used as a surrogate marker of atherosclerosis [(123)](#reference123). Higher [serum](../glossary#serum) magnesium concentrations have been associated with reduced carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT) in all women and in Caucasian men participating in the Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities (ARIC) study [(124)](#reference124). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of four small (145 participants in total) and [heterogeneous](../glossary#heterogeneous) [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-study) found no effect of magnesium supplementation (98.6 to 368 mg/day for 2 to 6 months) on CIMT [(116)](#reference116). Results from several [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials have suggested that an [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) magnesium administered early after a suspected [myocardial infarction](../health-disease/heart-attack) could decrease the risk of death. The most influential study was a randomized, placebo-controlled trial in 2,316 patients that found a significant reduction in mortality in the group of patients given intravenous magnesium sulfate within 24 hours of suspected myocardial infarction (7.8% all-cause mortality in the experimental group vs. 10.3% all-cause mortality in the placebo group) [(125)](#reference125). Follow-up from one to five years after treatment revealed that the mortality from [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) was 21% lower in the magnesium-treated group [(126)](#reference126). However, a larger placebo-controlled trial in more than 58,000 patients found no significant reduction in five-week mortality in patients treated with intravenous magnesium sulfate within 24 hours of suspected myocardial infarction, resulting in controversy regarding the efficacy of this treatment [(127)](#reference127). A US survey of the treatment of more than 173,000 individuals with acute myocardial infarction found that only 5% were given intravenous magnesium in the first 24 hours post-infarction and that mortality was higher in this group compared to the group of patients not treated with magnesium [(128)](#reference128). A 2007 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) of 73,363 participants, concluded that intravenous magnesium administration does not appear to reduce post-myocardial infarction mortality and thus should not be utilized as a treatment [(129)](#reference129). Thus, the use of intravenous magnesium sulfate in the therapy of acute myocardial infarction remains controversial. Magnesium depletion has been associated with type 1 ( [insulin](../glossary#insulin)-dependent) and type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), as well as with [gestational](../glossary#gestation) diabetes. Low [serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of magnesium (hypomagnesemia) have been reported in 13.5 to 47.7% of individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus [(130)](#reference130). One cause of the depletion may be an increased urinary loss of magnesium caused by an increased urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of [glucose](../glossary#glucose) that accompanies poorly controlled diabetes. Magnesium depletion has been shown to increase [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance) in a few studies and may adversely affect blood glucose control in diabetes mellitus (see also [Diabetes mellitus](#diabetes-prevention) under Disease Prevention) [(131)](#reference131). A small study in nine individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus reported that [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) magnesium (300 mg/day for 30 days), in the form of a liquid, magnesium-containing salt solution, improved fasting insulin but not fasting glucose concentrations [(132)](#reference132). One [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in 63 individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypomagnesemia found that those taking an oral magnesium chloride solution (638 mg/day of elemental magnesium) for 16 weeks had improved measures of [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) and glycemic control compared to those taking a placebo [(133)](#reference133). The most recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine randomized, double-blind, controlled trials concluded that oral supplemental magnesium lowered fasting [plasma](../glossary#plasma) glucose concentrations in individuals with diabetes [(134)](#reference134). However, magnesium supplementation did not improve other markers of glucose [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis), such as [glycated hemoglobin](../glossary#glycated-hemoglobin) (HbA1c) concentration, fasting and post-glucose load insulin concentrations, and measures of insulin resistance [(134)](#reference134). Another meta-analysis of trials that included participants either at-risk of diabetes mellitus or with diabetes mellitus suggested that evidence to support a benefit of magnesium supplementation on measures of insulin resistance was stronger in subjects who were magnesium deficient than in those with normal serum concentrations of magnesium [(135)](#reference135). Correcting existing magnesium deficiencies may improve glucose metabolism and insulin sensitivity in subjects with diabetes, but it remains uncertain whether magnesium supplementation can have any therapeutic benefit in patients with adequate magnesium [status](../glossary#status). The occurrence of hypomagnesemia may be greater in patients with [asthma](../glossary#asthma) than in individuals without asthma [(136)](#reference136). Several [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have examined the effect of [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) magnesium infusions on acute asthmatic attacks in children or adults who did not respond to initial treatment in the emergency room. Indeed, magnesium can promote bronchodilation in subjects with asthma by interfering with mechanisms like the activation of N-methyl D-aspartate (NMDA) [receptors](../glossary#receptor) that trigger bronchoconstriction through facilitating calcium influx in airway smooth muscle cells [(137)](#reference137). In a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of six (quasi) [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 325 children with acute asthma treated with a short-acting 2-adrenergic receptor agonist (e.g., salbutamol) and systemic [steroids](../glossary#steroid), intravenous magnesium sulfate treatment improved measurements of the respiratory function and reduced the [risk](../glossary#risk) of hospital admission by 30% compared to control [(138)](#reference138). Another meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials primarily conducted in adults with asthma exacerbations indicated that single infusions of 1.2 to 2 g of magnesium sulfate over 15 to 30 minutes could reduce the risk of hospital admission and improve lung function after initial treatments failed (i.e., oxygen, short-acting 2 agonist, and steroids) [(139)](#reference139). The use of nebulized, inhaled magnesium for treating asthma has also been investigated. A recent [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) of 25 randomized controlled trials, including adults, children, or both, found little evidence that inhaled magnesium sulfate alone or along with a 2-adrenergic receptor agonist and/or a muscarinic anticholinergic (e.g., ipratropium) could improve pulmonary function in patients with acute asthma [(140)](#reference140). In addition, oral magnesium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) is of no known value in the management of chronic asthma [(141-143)](#reference141). The potential analgesic effect of magnesium is attributed in particular to its capacity to block NMDA [receptors](../glossary#receptor), which are located in the brain and spinal cord and are involved in pain transduction [(144)](#reference144). Several intervention studies have examined the role of magnesium on pain control and analgesic requirement in patients during the immediate post-surgery period. After cesarean section: Pain management strategies after cesarean section usually involve the injection of an analgesic into either the epidural space (for epidural analgesia) or the subarachnoid space (for spinal [intrathecal] analgesia). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) summarized the evidence regarding the potential use of magnesium sulfate to control or relieve postoperative pain in 827 women who underwent cesarean section [(145)](#reference145). All the trials evaluated the effect of a first-line analgesic regimen (i.e., bupivacaine or lidocaine, with or without opioids) with and without the addition of magnesium sulfate. The results suggested that the anesthesia (8 studies) and sensory blockade (6 studies) lasted longer in women who received the additional magnesium sulfate. The use of magnesium sulfate also resulted in lower pain score (3 studies) and in lower postoperative consumption of analgesics (4 studies). Additionally, there was no difference in occurrence of side effects between regimens [(145)](#reference145). A recent randomized controlled trial in 60 healthy women undergoing elective cesarean section confirmed that the addition of magnesium sulfate to a bupivacaine/opioid regimen increased the duration of spinal anesthesia and lowered the pain level, yet did not improve the potency of bupivacaine [(146)](#reference146). In another study in women with mild preeclampsia who received an epidural injection of ropivacaine after cesarean section, spinal infusion of magnesium sulfate increased the duration of sensory and motor blockade, as well as the time before patients requested an analgesic, compared to midazolam [(147)](#reference147). After a variety of other surgeries: The efficacy of [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) magnesium has also been examined for local, regional, or systemic pain control following a range of different surgeries. A review of four small [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) suggested that, when added to local analgesics, magnesium infusion to patients undergoing tonsillectomy might decrease pain and incidence of [laryngospasm](../glossary#laryngospasm), extend the time to first post-operative analgesic requirement, and reduce the number of post-operative analgesic requests [(148)](#reference148). Similar observations were reported in two additional [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis), yet there was discrepancy regarding the ability of magnesium to alleviate pain [(149, 150)](#reference149). Indeed, the review of eight trials by Xie et al. [(150)](#reference150), of which only two scored pain using the same scale, showed no pain reduction with magnesium compared to control. Finally, both meta-analyses reported no reduction in risk of post-operative nausea and vomiting with intravenous magnesium administration [(148, 150)](#reference148). A 2018 meta-analysis of four randomized controlled trials in 263 patients also suggested that magnesium sulfate infusion may help reduce pain scores at 2 and 8 hours (but not 24 hours) after laparoscopic [cholecystectomy](../glossary#cholecystectomy) [(151)](#reference151). Recent studies have examined the use of magnesium sulfate for pain control after other surgeries, including hysterectomy [(152, 153)](#reference152), spinal [(156)](#reference156) or cochlear implantation [(157)](#reference157) surgery. Despite conflicting results or reports of limited benefits of magnesium, further research is needed before any conclusions can be drawn. The effect of magnesium on [neuropathic](../glossary#neuropathy) pain has been examined in some clinical studies. The [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) administration of magnesium sulfate was found to partially or completely alleviate pain in patients with postherpetic neuralgia, a type of neuropathic pain caused by herpes zoster infection (shingles) [(158, 159)](#reference158). In a more recent [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 45 patients with either postherpetic neuralgia or neuropathic pain of traumatic or surgical origin, oral [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) of magnesium failed to improve measures of pain and quality of life compared to a [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(160)](#reference160). Another trial is underway to examine the impact of intravenous magnesium with ketamine on neuropathic pain [(161)](#reference161). Lower intracellular magnesium concentrations (in both red blood cells and white blood cells) have been reported in individuals who suffer from recurrent [migraine headaches](../glossary#migraine-headache) compared to migraine-free individuals [(162)](#reference162). Additionally, the incidence of hypomagnesemia also appeared to be greater in women who experience migraines with [menstruation](../glossary#menstruation) compared to women without menstrual migraines [(163)](#reference163). A few [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-study) have examined whether an increase in intracellular magnesium concentration with [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) (oral) magnesium could help decrease the frequency and severity of migraine headaches in affected individuals. Two early [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials demonstrated modest decreases in the frequency of migraine headaches after supplementation with 600 mg/day of magnesium [(162, 164)](#reference162). Another placebo-controlled trial in 86 children with frequent migraine headaches found that oral magnesium oxide (9 mg/kg body weight/day) reduced headache frequency over the 16-week intervention [(165)](#reference165). However, there was no reduction in the frequency of migraine headaches with 485 mg/day of magnesium in another placebo-controlled study conducted in 69 adults suffering migraine attacks [(166)](#reference166). The efficiency of magnesium absorption varies with the type of oral magnesium complex, and this might explain the conflicting results. Although no serious adverse effects were noted during these migraine headache trials, 19 to 40% of individuals taking the magnesium supplements have reported diarrhea and [gastric](../glossary#gastric) irritation. The efficacy of magnesium infusions was also investigated in a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), single-blind, trial](../glossary#cross-over-trial) of 30 patients with migraine [(167)](#reference167). The administration of 1 gram of [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) magnesium sulfate ended the attacks, abolished associated symptoms, and prevented recurrence within 24 hours in nearly 90% of the subjects. While this promising result was confirmed in another trial [(168)](#reference168), two additional randomized, placebo-controlled studies found that magnesium sulfate was less effective than other molecules (e.g., metoclopramide) in treating migraines [(169, 170)](#reference169). The most recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of five randomized, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), controlled trials reported no beneficial effect of magnesium infusion for migraine in adults [(171)](#reference171). Another two more recent intervention studies suggested that magnesium sulfate infusion could be more effective and faster than dexamethasone/metoclopramide [(172)](#reference172) or caffeine citrate [(173)](#reference173) to relieve pain in patients with acute migraine. The efficacy of magnesium should be examined in larger studies that consider the magnesium [status](../glossary#status) of migraine sufferers [(174)](#reference174). Hypomagnesemia is not uncommon in patients admitted to intensive care units (ICU). Two recent [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [prospective](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) and [retrospective](../glossary#retrospective-study) cohort studies reported [serum](../glossary#serum) magnesium concentrations 0.75 mmol/L in ICU patients at admission or within 24 hours following admission to be associated with a greater need for mechanical ventilation, longer ICU stay, and higher [risk](../glossary#risk) of hospital mortality [(175, 176)](#reference175). A pooled analysis of three studies also suggested a higher risk of sepsis in ICU patients with hypomagnesemia [(175)](#reference175). A recent prospective study conducted in patients admitted with severe head injury found better [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) outcomes after six months in those who presented with normal serum magnesium concentrations at admission compared to those with hypomagnesemia (serum magnesium concentrations <0.65 mmol/L) [(177)](#reference177). However, evidence is currently unavailable to suggest that magnesium administration could improve outcomes in critically ill or severely injured patients [(178)](#reference178). The analysis of US national nutrition survey data (NHANES 2003-2006) showed an average magnesium intake in adults (ages 19 years) of 278 mg/day when only unfortified food sources were considered [(179)](#reference179). Considering all sources of magnesium intakes (i.e., unfortified and fortified food and [supplements](../glossary#supplement)), the average intake in adults was estimated to be around 330 mg/day — a value close to the estimated average requirements ( [EAR](../glossary#EAR)) for magnesium — suggesting that about one-half of the adult population may be at [risk](../glossary#risk) of magnesium inadequacy [(179)](#reference179). Yet, the long-term consequences of inadequate dietary intakes remain unclear [(1)](#references). Since magnesium is part of [chlorophyll](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/chlorophyll-chlorophyllin), the green pigment in plants, green leafy vegetables are good sources of magnesium. Unrefined grains ( [whole grains](../food-beverages/whole-grains)) and [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts) also have high magnesium content. Meats and milk have an intermediate content of magnesium, while refined foods generally have the lowest. Water is a variable source of intake; harder water usually has a higher concentration of magnesium salts [(2)](#reference2). Some foods that are relatively rich in magnesium are listed in Table 2, along with their magnesium content in milligrams (mg). For more information on the nutrient content search [gastric](../glossary#gastric) hyperacidity and symptoms of [gastroesophageal reflux disease](../glossary#gastroesophageal-reflux-disease) [(180)](#reference180). Adverse effects have not been identified from magnesium occurring naturally in food. However, adverse effects from excessive magnesium have been observed with intakes of various magnesium salts (i.e., [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) magnesium) [(6)](#reference6). The initial symptom of excess magnesium supplementation is diarrhea — a well-known side effect of magnesium that is used therapeutically as a laxative. Individuals with impaired kidney function are at higher [risk](../glossary#risk) for adverse effects of magnesium supplementation, and symptoms of magnesium toxicity have occurred in people with impaired kidney function taking moderate doses of magnesium-containing laxatives or antacids. Elevated [serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of magnesium (hypermagnesemia) may result in a fall in blood pressure (hypotension). Some of the later effects of magnesium toxicity, such as lethargy, confusion, disturbances in normal cardiac rhythm, and deterioration of kidney function, are related to severe hypotension. As hypermagnesemia progresses, muscle weakness and difficulty breathing may occur. Severe hypermagnesemia may result in cardiac arrest [(2, 3)](#reference2). The Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the US Institute of Medicine set the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for magnesium at 350 mg/day; this UL represents the highest level of daily supplemental magnesium intake likely to pose no risk of diarrhea or [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) disturbance in almost all individuals. The FNB cautions that individuals with [renal](../glossary#renal) impairment are at higher risk for adverse effects from excess supplemental magnesium intake. However, the FNB also notes that there are some conditions that may warrant higher doses of magnesium under medical supervision intake should be from food and formula only.| Magnesium interferes with the absorption of digoxin (a heart medication), nitrofurantoin (an antibiotic), and certain anti- [malarial](../glossary#malaria) drugs, which could potentially reduce drug efficacy. Bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate, etidronate), which are drugs used to treat [osteoporosis](../health-disease/osteoporosis), and magnesium should be taken two hours apart so that the absorption of the bisphosphonates is not inhibited [(181, 182)](#reference181). Magnesium has also been found to reduce the efficacy of chlorpromazine (a tranquilizer), penicillamine, oral [anticoagulants](../glossary#anticoagulant), and antibiotics [(181, 182)](#reference181). [Intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) magnesium might inhibit calcium entry into smooth muscle cells and lead to hypotension and muscular weakness if administered with calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipin, nicardipin) [(182)](#reference182). Because intravenous magnesium has increased the effects of certain muscle-relaxing medications used during anesthesia, it is advisable to let medical staff know if you are taking oral magnesium [supplements](../glossary#supplement), laxatives, or antacids prior to surgical procedures. Moreover, long-term use (three months or longer) of proton-pump inhibitors (drugs used to reduce the amount of stomach acid) may increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of hypomagnesemia [(183, 184)](#reference183). High some thiazide [diuretics](../glossary#diuretic) (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide), if taken for extended periods, may interfere with magnesium reabsorption in the kidneys and result in magnesium depletion [(182)](#reference182). Many other medications may also result in [renal](../glossary#renal) magnesium loss [(3)](#reference3). The Linus Pauling Institute supports the latest [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for magnesium intake (400 to 420 mg/day for men and 310 to 320 mg/day for women). Despite magnesium being plentiful in foods, it is considered a shortfall nutrient (see the article on [Micronutrient Inadequacies in the US Population](../micronutrient-inadequacies/overview#magnesium)). Following the Linus Pauling Institute recommendation to take a daily multivitamin/mineral supplement might ensure an intake of at least 100 mg/day of magnesium. Few multivitamin/mineral supplements contain more than 100 mg of magnesium due to its bulk. Eating a varied diet that provides green vegetables, [whole grains](../food-beverages/whole-grains), and [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts) daily should provide the rest of an individual's magnesium requirement. Older adults are less likely than younger adults to consume enough magnesium to meet their needs and should therefore take care to eat magnesium-rich foods in addition to taking a multivitamin/mineral [supplement](../glossary#supplement) daily (see the article on [Micronutrient Inadequacies: Subpopulations at Risk](../micronutrient-inadequacies/subpopulations-at-risk)). Since older adults are also more likely to have impaired kidney function, they should avoid taking more than 350 mg/day of supplemental magnesium without medical consultation (see [Safety](#safety)).
