Accessed 10/22/18. Contents Manganese is a mineral element that is both nutritionally essential and potentially toxic. The derivation of its name from the Greek word for magic remains appropriate, because scientists are still working to understand the diverse effects of manganese deficiency and manganese toxicity in living organisms [(1)](#references). Manganese (Mn) plays an important role in a number of physiologic processes as a constituent of multiple [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) and an activator of other enzymes [mitochondria](../glossary#mitochondria). Because mitochondria consume over 90% of the oxygen used by cells, they are especially vulnerable to [ oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress). The superoxide radical is one of the [ oxygen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species) produced in mitochondria during [ATP](../glossary#ATP) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis). MnSOD [ catalyzes](../glossary#catalyze) the conversion of superoxide radicals to hydrogen peroxide, which can be reduced to water by other antioxidant enzymes [(3)](#reference3). A number of manganese-activated [ enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) roles [glucose](../glossary#glucose) from non-carbohydrate [precursors](../glossary#precursor). Arginase, another manganese-containing enzyme, is required by the liver for the urea cycle, a process that detoxifies ammonia generated during amino acid metabolism [(3)](#reference3). In the brain, the manganese-activated enzyme, glutamine synthetase, converts Glutamate is an [excitotoxic](../glossary#excitoxicity) [neurotransmitter](../glossary#neurotransmitter) (GABA) [(5, 6)](#reference5). Manganese deficiency results in abnormal skeletal development in a number of animal species. Manganese is the preferred [ cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) of [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) called glycosyltransferases; these enzymes are required for the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of [ proteoglycans](../glossary#proteoglycan) that are needed for the formation of healthy [ cartilage](../glossary#cartilage) and bone [(7)](#reference7). Wound healing is a complex process that requires increased production of [collagen](../glossary#collagen). Manganese is required for the activation of prolidase, an [ enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) that functions to provide the [amino acid](../glossary#amino-acid), proline, for collagen formation in human skin cells [(8)](#reference8). A genetic disorder known as prolidase deficiency results in abnormal wound healing among other problems and is characterized by abnormal manganese [ metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [ (7)](#reference7). Glycosaminoglycan [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis), which requires manganese-activated glycosyltransferases, may also play an important role in wound healing [(9)](#reference9). [Iron](iron) and manganese share common absorption and transport proteins, including the divalent metal transporter 1, the lactoferrin receptor, transferrin, and ferroportin (reviewed in [10](#reference10)). Absorption of manganese from a meal decreases as the meal's iron content increases [(7)](#reference7). Iron [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) (60 milligrams [mg]/day for four months) has been associated with decreased blood manganese concentrations and decreased MnSOD activity in [leukocytes](../glossary#leukocyte), indicating a reduction in manganese nutritional [status](../glossary#status) [(11)](#reference11). Additionally, an individual's iron status can affect manganese [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability). Intestinal absorption of manganese is increased during iron deficiency and decreased when iron stores are elevated (i.e., high ferritin concentrations) [(12)](#reference12). Small studies have found increased blood concentrations of manganese in iron-deficient infants [(13)](#reference13) and children [(14)](#reference14), and a national survey of adults residing in South Korea found men and women with low ferritin levels had higher blood concentrations of manganese compared to those with normal ferritin levels [(15)](#reference15). In this analysis, anemia was associated with higher blood concentrations of manganese in women but not in men [(15)](#reference15). Men generally absorb less manganese than women, which may be related to the fact that men usually have higher iron stores than women [(16)](#reference16). Iron deficiency has also been shown to increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of manganese accumulation in the brain [(17)](#reference17). [Supplemental](../glossary#supplement) magnesium (200 mg/day) has been shown to slightly decrease manganese [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) in healthy adults, either by decreasing manganese absorption or by increasing its [excretion](../glossary#excretion) [(18)](#reference18). In one set of studies, [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) calcium (500 mg/day) slightly decreased manganese [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) in healthy adults. As a source of calcium, milk had the least effect, while calcium carbonate and calcium phosphate had the greatest effect [(18)](#reference18). Several other studies have found minimal effects of supplemental calcium on manganese [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [(19)](#reference19). Although manganese is a nutritionally essential [mineral](../glossary#mineral), it is potentially toxic; thus, it is important for the body to tightly regulate manganese [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis). While the exact mechanisms that govern manganese homeostasis are not completely understood, systemic regulation is achieved through intestinal control of manganese absorption and [hepatic](../glossary#hepatic) [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of manganese into [bile](../glossary#bile) [(20)](#reference20). At the cellular level, influx of manganese into cells is regulated by several different transport [proteins](../glossary#protein), including the transferrin [receptor](../glossary#receptor), the divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT 1), zinc-interacting proteins 8 and 14 (ZIP8 and ZIP14), as well as others (reviewed in [21](#reference21)). Efflux of manganese from cells is accomplished by various transporters, including SLC30A10; the sodium-calcium exchanger; and the iron transporter, ferroportin endosome) utilize various transporters for manganese trafficking within the cell, but the exact mechanisms of regulation are not fully understood [(21)](#reference21). Manganese deficiency has been observed in a number of animal species, but manganese deficiency is not a concern in humans. Signs of manganese deficiency vary among animal species and may include impaired growth, impaired reproductive function, skeletal abnormalities, [impaired glucose tolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance), and altered [carbohydrate](../glossary#carbohydrate) and [lipid](../glossary#lipid) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism). In humans, demonstration of a manganese deficiency syndrome has been less clear [(2](#reference2), [7)](#reference7). A child on long-term [total parenteral nutrition](../glossary#total-parenteral-nutrition) (TPN) lacking manganese developed bone demineralization growth that were corrected by manganese [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) [(23)](#reference23). Young men who were fed a low-manganese diet developed decreased [serum](../glossary#serum) [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentrations and a transient skin rash [(24)](#reference24). Blood concentrations of calcium, phosphorus, and alkaline phosphatase were also elevated, which may indicate increased [bone remodeling](../glossary#bone-remodeling) as a consequence of insufficient dietary manganese. Young women fed a manganese-poor diet developed mildly abnormal [glucose tolerance](../glossary#glucose-tolerance) in response to an [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) (IV) infusion of [glucose](../glossary#glucose) [(19)](#reference19). Overall, manganese deficiency is quite rare, and there is more concern for toxicity related to manganese overexposure (see [Safety](#safety)). Because there was insufficient information on manganese requirements to set a Recommended Dietary Allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)), the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the Institute of Medicine (now the National Academy of Medicine) set an adequate intake ( [AI](../glossary#AI)). Since overt manganese deficiency has not been documented in humans eating natural diets, the FNB based the AI on average dietary intakes of manganese determined by the Total Diet Study — an annual survey of the [mineral](../glossary#mineral) content of representative American diets [(4)](#reference4). AI values for manganese are listed in Table 1 in milligrams (mg)/day by age and gender. Manganese requirements are increased in pregnancy and lactation [(4)](#reference4). |Life manganese intake or low levels of manganese in blood or tissue have been associated with various [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease). Although manganese insufficiency is not currently thought to cause the diseases discussed below, more research may be warranted to determine whether suboptimal manganese nutritional [status](../glossary#status) contributes to certain disease processes. Early studies found women with [osteoporosis](../health-disease/osteoporosis) had decreased [plasma](../glossary#plasma) or [serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of manganese and an enhanced plasma response to an oral dose of manganese [(25, 26)](#reference25), suggesting they may have lower manganese [status](../glossary#status) than women without osteoporosis. However, more recent studies in postmenopausal women have reported conflicting results, with one study finding lower blood manganese concentrations among women with osteoporosis compared to those without osteoporosis [(27)](#reference27) and another finding no differences [(28)](#reference28). A study in healthy postmenopausal women found that a [supplement](../glossary#supplement) containing manganese (5 mg/day), [copper](copper) (2.5 mg/day), and [zinc](zinc) (15 mg/day) in combination with a calcium supplement (1,000 mg/day) was more effective than the calcium supplement alone in preventing spinal bone loss over a two-year period [(29)](#reference29). However, the presence of other trace elements in the supplement makes it impossible to determine whether manganese supplementation was the beneficial agent for maintaining [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density). In animal models, manganese deficiency results in impaired insulin secretion and [glucose intolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance) similar to [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) [(30)](#reference30); however, results of human studies on manganese and type 2 diabetes have been somewhat conflicting. Manganese intake was inversely associated with type 2 diabetes in 71,270 French women participating in the E3N-EPIC cohort study [(31)](#reference31). In an analysis of two prospective cohorts of Chinese adults (ages 20-74 years at baseline), followed for a mean of 4.2 and 5.3 years, higher dietary intakes of manganese were associated with a lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of type 2 diabetes; these associations were independent of dietary total [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) capacity, a measure of dietary antioxidant intake [(32)](#reference32). Most recently, a prospective cohort study of 19,862 adults (ages 40-79 at baseline) participating in the Japan Collaborative Cohort Study, followed for five years, found higher dietary intake of manganese to be associated with a lower risk of type 2 diabetes in women but not in men [(33)](#reference33). While these studies of dietary manganese intake are suggestive of a protective association with type 2 diabetes, studies employing [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) of manganese intake - either blood concentrations of manganese or urinary manganese [excretion](../glossary#excretion) — have reported mixed results. Most studies conducted have been small [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study); studies to date have reported blood manganese concentrations in patients with diabetes were higher [(34-36)](#reference34), lower [(37)](#reference37), or similar [(38-40)](#reference38) compared to blood manganese concentrations in controls without diabetes. Additionally, a case-control study that included 3,228 adults in China reported a U-shaped relationship between plasma concentration of manganese and type 2 diabetes, meaning those with low or high blood concentrations had a higher odds of diabetes when compared to those with an intermediate blood concentration of manganese [(41)](#reference41). In a cross-sectional analysis of adults participating in the Korean National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey, blood concentrations of manganese were significantly lower among those with diabetes compared to those without diabetes [(42)](#reference42). Further, one case-control study found higher urinary manganese excretion in patients with diabetes compared to controls without diabetes [(37)](#reference37). Results of case-control studies are more likely to be distorted by bias (i.e., the selection bias with the selection of cases and controls, as well as dietary [recall bias](../glossary#recall-bias)) than results of prospective cohort studies. Moreover, one study of functional manganese status found the activity of the antioxidant [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme), MnSOD, to be lower in the white blood cells of patients with diabetes than in those without diabetes [(43)](#reference43). When given at the same time as an oral glucose challenge, an acute oral dose of 15 mg or 30 mg manganese did not improve [glucose tolerance](../glossary#glucose-tolerance) in subjects with diabetes or in controls without diabetes [(44)](#reference44). Although manganese appears to play a role in glucose [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), it is not clear whether higher manganese status might improve glucose tolerance and protect against the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Manganese deficient rats are more susceptible to [seizures](../glossary#seizure) than manganese sufficient rats, and rats that are genetically prone to [epilepsy](../glossary#epilepsy) have lower than normal brain and blood manganese concentrations. Certain subgroups of humans with epilepsy reportedly have lower whole blood manganese concentrations than control subjects without epilepsy [(45)](#reference45). One study found blood manganese concentrations of individuals with epilepsy of unknown origin were lower than those of individuals whose epilepsy was induced by trauma (e.g., head injury) or disease [(46)](#reference46), suggesting a possible genetic relationship between epilepsy and abnormal manganese [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism). While manganese deficiency does not appear to be a cause of epilepsy in humans, the relationship between manganese metabolism and epilepsy deserves further research [(7](#reference7), [45, 47)](#reference45). In the US, estimated average intakes of dietary manganese range from 2.1 to 2.3 mg/day for men and 1.6 to 1.8 mg/day for women [(4)](#reference4). Surveys have found those adhering to a vegetarian diet have manganese intakes of up to 7.0 mg/day (reviewed in sources of manganese [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes), vegetables, and [teas](../food-beverages/tea) [(49)](#reference49). Foods high in phytic acid, such as beans, seeds, nuts, whole grains, and soy products, or foods high in oxalic acid, such as cabbage, spinach, and sweet potatoes, may slightly inhibit manganese absorption. Although teas are rich sources of manganese, the [tannins](../glossary#tannins) present in tea may moderately reduce the absorption of manganese [(18)](#reference18). Intakes of other [minerals](../glossary#minerals), including [iron](iron), [calcium](calcium), and have been found to limit retention of manganese [(4)](#reference4). The manganese content of some manganese-rich foods is listed in milligrams (mg) in Table 2. For more information on the nutrient content of foods, (black)||1 cup (8 ounces)||0.18-0.77| Infants are exposed to varying amounts of manganese depending on their source of nutrition. Manganese concentrations in breast milk, cow-based formula, and soy-based formula range from 3 to 10 micrograms/liter (g/L), 30 to 50 g/L, and 200 to 300 g/L, respectively. However, the [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of manganese from breast milk is higher than from infant formulas, and manganese deficiencies in breast-fed infants or toxicities in formula-fed infants have not been reported [(20)](#reference20). Manganese concentrations in drinking water range from 1 to 100 micrograms (g)/L, but most sources contain less than 10 g/L [(51)](#reference51). The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) recommends 0.05 mg (50 g)/L as the maximum allowable manganese concentration in drinking water [(52)](#reference52). Several forms of manganese are found in [supplements](../glossary#supplement), including gluconate, manganese. Manganese is available as a stand-alone supplement or in combination products [(53)](#reference53). Relatively high levels of manganese ascorbate may be found in a bone/joint health product containing chondroitin sulfate and glucosamine hydrochloride (see [Safety](#safety)). Manganese may be present in solutions of parenteral nutrition either included as a trace element or as an incidental contaminant (see [Intravenous manganese](#intravenous-manganese-safety) in the a manganese transporter expressed in the liver and brain, causes a manganese overload syndrome. Such loss-of-function mutations lead to manganese accumulation in certain brain regions and in the liver, causing hypermanganesemia, dystonia parkinsonism, and hepatic dysfunction at an 57)](#reference56). Autosomal recessive mutations in the SLC39A14 gene have also been reported, leading to hypermanganesemia and similar a neurological phenotype, but liver disease is absent with this specific mutation [(58)](#reference58). [Chelation](../glossary#chelate) therapy is important to treat these inherited manganese-overload disorders [(59)](#reference59). Manganese toxicity may result in multiple [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) problems and is a well-recognized health hazard for people who inhale manganese dust, such as welders, miners, and smelters [(1](#references), [4)](#reference4). Unlike ingested manganese, inhaled manganese is transported directly to the brain before it can be metabolized in the liver [(60, 61)](#reference60). The symptoms of manganese toxicity generally appear slowly over a period of months to years. In its worst form, manganese toxicity can result in a permanent neurological disorder with symptoms similar to those of [Parkinson's disease](../glossary#parkinson-disease), including tremors, difficulty walking, and facial muscle spasms. This syndrome, often called manganism, is sometimes preceded by psychiatric symptoms, such as irritability, aggressiveness, and even hallucinations [(62, 63)](#reference62). Additionally, environmental or occupational inhalation of manganese can cause an [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) response in the lungs [(64)](#reference64), with clinical symptoms including cough, acute bronchitis, and decreased lung function [(65)](#reference65). Methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl (MMT) is a manganese-containing compound used in gasoline as an anti-knock additive. Although it has been used for this purpose in Canada for more than 20 years, uncertainty about adverse health effects from inhaled exhaust emissions kept the US EPA from approving its use in unleaded gasoline. In 1995, a US court decision made MMT available for widespread use in unleaded gasoline [(60)](#reference60). A study in Montreal, where MMT had been used for more than 10 years, found airborne manganese levels to be similar to those in areas where MMT was not used [(66)](#reference66). Another Canadian study found higher concentrations of respirable manganese in an urban versus a rural area, but average concentrations in both areas were below the safe level set by the US EPA [(67)](#reference67). The impact of long-term exposure to low levels of MMT combustion products, however, has not been thoroughly evaluated and will require additional study [(68)](#reference68). A single case of reversible neurotoxicity and seizures following unintentional MMT ingestion has been documented: a 54-year old man accidentally drank an MMT-containing anti-knock agent that he assumed was an energy drink due so similar product labeling [(69)](#reference69). Limited evidence suggests that high manganese intakes from drinking water may be associated with [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) symptoms similar to those of [Parkinson's disease](../glossary#parkinson-disease). Severe neurological symptoms were reported in 25 people who drank water contaminated with manganese — and probably other contaminants — from dry cell batteries for two to three months [(70)](#reference70). Water manganese concentrations were found to be 14 mg/L almost two months after symptoms began and may have already been declining [(1)](#references). A study of older adults in Greece found a high [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of neurological symptoms in those exposed to water manganese levels of 1.8 to 2.3 mg/L [(71)](#reference71), while a study in Germany found no evidence of increased neurological symptoms in people drinking water with manganese levels ranging from 0.3 to 2.2 mg/L compared to those drinking water containing less than 0.05 mg/L of manganese [(72)](#reference72). Manganese in drinking water may be more [bioavailable](../glossary#bioavailability) than manganese in food. However, none of the studies measured dietary manganese, so total manganese intake in these cases is unknown. In the US, the EPA recommends 0.05 mg/L as the maximum allowable manganese concentration in drinking water [(52)](#reference52), but the World Health Organization does not currently have a health-based limit for manganese in drinking water [(73, 74)](#reference73). Additionally, several cross-sectional studies have associated high levels of manganese in drinking water with cognitive and behavioral deficits in children (reviewed in [75](#reference75)). For example, a cross-sectional study of 362 children (ages 6-13 years) in Canada found children with the highest manganese concentrations in home tap water (median of 216 g/L) had a 6.2-point lower Full Scale IQ (lower Performance IQ but not Verbal IQ) than those with lowest manganese levels in home tap water (median of 1 g/L) [(76)](#reference76). A cohort study that followed 287 of these children for a mean of 4.4 years found that exposure to higher concentrations of manganese in drinking water was linked to a lower Performance IQ among girls but a higher Performance IQ among boys [(77)](#reference77). Additionally, a [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) among 1,265 children in Bangladesh did not find manganese concentration in drinking water (medians of 0.20 mg/L during pregnancy and 0.34 mg/L at 10 years) to be associated with any measure of cognitive ability (i.e., IQ, verbal comprehension, perceptual reasoning, working memory, processing speed) when assessed at age 10 [(78)](#reference78). Yet, this study associated manganese in drinking water with higher [risks](../glossary#risk) of conduct problems among boys and low prosocial scores among girls [(78)](#reference78). In a population-based cohort study in Denmark that followed 643,401 children, exposure to higher manganese concentrations in drinking water was linked to a heightened risk of one subtype of attention-deficit hyperactive disorder [(79)](#reference79). Specifically, exposure to a manganese concentration in drinking water of at least 100 g/L was associated with a 51% higher risk of the ADHD-Inattentive subtype in girls and a 20% higher risk in boys, in comparison to exposure of <5 g/L — using these exposure comparisons, a 9% increased risk of ADHD-Overall was observed in girls and no difference found in boys [(79)](#reference79). Only a few adverse effects of manganese intake from [supplements](../glossary#supplement) have been documented. A single case of manganese toxicity was reported in a person who took large amounts of mineral supplements for years [(51)](#reference51), while another case was reported as a result of a person taking a Chinese herbal supplement [(62)](#reference62). More recently, Parkinson's disease was reported in a woman taking 100 mg/day of manganese chloride for at least two years, followed by 30 mg/day for two months [(80)](#reference80). Manganese toxicity resulting from food alone has not been reported in humans, even though certain vegetarian diets could provide up to 20 mg/day of manganese [(4](#reference4), [51)](#reference51). Manganese [total parenteral nutrition](../glossary#total-parenteral-nutrition) (TPN), both as a result of excessive manganese in the solution and as an incidental contaminant [(54)](#reference54). Neonates are especially vulnerable to manganese-related neurotoxicity receiving manganese-containing TPN can be exposed manganese concentrations about 100-fold higher than breast-fed infants [(20)](#reference20). Because of potential toxicities, some argue against including manganese in parenteral nutrition [(82)](#reference82). Due to the severe implications of manganese [ neurotoxicity](../glossary#neurotoxic), the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the Institute of Medicine (now the National Academy of Medicine) set very conservative tolerable upper intake levels ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for manganese; the ULs are listed in Table to age [(4)](#reference4). should be from food and formula only.| Magnesium-containing antacids and laxatives and the antibiotic medication, tetracycline, may decrease the absorption of manganese if taken together with manganese-containing foods or [supplements](../glossary#supplement) [(53)](#reference53). Two studies have found that [supplements](../glossary#supplement) containing a combination of glucosamine hydrochloride, chondroitin sulfate, and manganese ascorbate are beneficial in relieving pain due to mild or moderate [osteoarthritis](../glossary#osteoarthritis) of the knee when compared to a [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(93, 94)](#reference93). The dose of elemental manganese supplied by the supplements was 30 mg/day for eight weeks in one study [(94)](#reference94) and 40 mg/day for six months in the other study [(93)](#reference93). No adverse effects were reported during either study, and blood manganese concentrations were not measured. Neither study compared the treatment containing manganese ascorbate to a treatment containing glucosamine hydrochloride and chondroitin sulfate without manganese ascorbate, so it is impossible to determine whether the supplement would have resulted in the same benefit without high doses of manganese. The adequate intake ( [AI](../glossary#AI)) for manganese (2.3 mg/day for adult men and 1.8 mg/day for adult women) appears sufficient to prevent deficiency in most individuals. The daily intake of manganese most likely to promote optimum health is not known. Following the Linus Pauling Institute's recommendation to take a multivitamin/mineral [supplement](../glossary#supplement) containing 100% of the daily values ( [DV](../glossary#DV)) of most nutrients will generally provide 2.3 mg/day of manganese. Because of the potential for toxicity and the lack of information regarding benefit, manganese supplementation beyond 100% of the DV (2.3 mg/day) is not recommended. There is presently no evidence that the consumption of a manganese-rich plant-based diet results in manganese toxicity. The requirement for manganese is not known to be higher for older adults. However, liver disease is more common in older adults and may increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of manganese toxicity by decreasing the elimination of manganese from the body (see [Toxicity](#toxicity)). Manganese [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) beyond 100% of the DV (2.3 mg/day) is not recommended. Mil Med. 1999;164(2):85-91. ] [(PubMed)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10050562/) Contents Molybdenum is an essential trace element for virtually all life forms. It functions as a [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) for a number of [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) that [catalyze](../glossary#catalyze) important chemical transformations in the global carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur cycles [(1)](#references). Thus, molybdenum-dependent enzymes are not only required for human health, but also for the health of our ecosystem. The biological form of the molybdenum atom is an organic molecule known as the molybdenum [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) (Moco) present in the active site of Moco-containing [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) (molybdoenzymes) [(2)](#reference2). In humans, molybdenum is known to function as a cofactor for four enzymes [(3)](#reference3): Of these enzymes, sulfite oxidase is known to be crucial for human health [(12)](#reference12). Hereditary xanthinuria, characterized by a deficiency in xanthine oxidase (Type I) or by a deficiency in both xanthine oxidase and aldehyde oxidase (Type II), can be asymptomatic. However, in less than half of the cases, affected individuals exhibit a range of health issues of variable severity [(13, 14)](#reference13). An early study reported that molybdenum intakes of 500 g/day and 1,500 g/day from sorghum increased urinary copper [excretion](../glossary#excretion) [(2)](#reference2). However, the results of a more recent, well-controlled study indicated that very high dietary molybdenum intakes (up to 1,500 g/day) did not adversely affect copper nutritional [status](../glossary#status) in eight, healthy young men [(15)](#reference15). Excess dietary molybdenum has been found to result in copper deficiency in grazing animals ( [ruminants](../glossary#ruminant)). In the digestive tract of ruminants, the formation of compounds containing sulfur and molybdenum, known as thiomolybdates, prevents the absorption of copper and can cause fatal copper-dependent disorders [(16, 17)](#reference16). Tetrathiomolybdate (TM) is a molecule that can form high-affinity complexes with copper, controlling free copper (copper that is not bound to [ceruloplasmin](../glossary#ceruloplasmin)), and inhibiting copper [chaperones](../glossary#molecular-chaperone) and copper-containing [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) [(18, 19)](#reference18). TM's ability to lower free copper levels is exploited in the treatment of Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder characterized by copper accumulation in tissues responsible for [hepatic](../glossary#hepatic) and [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) disorders. Neurologic worsening has been linked with toxic levels of free copper in the [serum](../glossary#serum) of neurologically presenting patients. TM therapy seems able to stabilize neurologic status and prevent neurologic deterioration in these patients, as opposed to the standard initial treatment of choice [(20)](#reference20). Copper is also a required [cofactor](../glossary#cofactor) for enzymes involved in [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) and [angiogenesis](../glossary#angiogenesis) that are known to accelerate [cancer](../glossary#cancer) progression and [metastasis](../glossary#metastasize). Copper depletion studies employing TM have been initiated in patients with advanced [malignancies](../glossary#malignant) with the aim of preventing disease progression or relapse. These pilot trials showed promising results in individuals with metastatic kidney cancer [(21)](#reference21), metastatic colorectal cancer [(22)](#reference22), and breast cancer with high [risk](../glossary#risk) of relapse [(23)](#reference23). TM was relatively well-tolerated and stabilized disease or prevented relapse in correlation with copper depletion. TM's efficacy has also been investigated in animal models of inflammatory and immune-related diseases [(24, 25)](#reference24), but clinical studies are needed to evaluate whether copper depletion might stabilize diseases and improve survival in humans, as suggested by a trial of TM therapy with patients with [biliary](../glossary#bile) [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis) [(26)](#reference26). Dietary molybdenum deficiency has never been observed in healthy people [(2)](#reference2). The only documented case of acquired molybdenum deficiency occurred in a patient with [Crohn's disease](../glossary#crohn-disease) on long-term [ total parenteral nutrition](../glossary#total-parenteral-nutrition) (TPN) without molybdenum added to the TPN solution [(27)](#reference27). The patient developed rapid heart and respiratory rates, headaches, and night blindness, and ultimately became comatose. The patient was diagnosed with defects in [uric acid](../glossary#uric-acid) production and sulfur [amino acid](../glossary#amino-acid) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism). The patient's clinical condition improved and the amino acid intolerance disappeared when the TPN solution was discontinued and instead supplemented with molybdenum in the form of ammonium molybdate (300 g/day) [(27)](#reference27). Because molybdenum functions only in the form of the Moco in humans, any disturbance of Moco [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) can disrupt the function of all molybdoenzymes. Current understanding of the essentiality of molybdenum in humans is based largely on the study of individuals with very rare inborn metabolic disorders caused by a deficiency in Moco. Moco is synthesized [de novo](../glossary#de-novo-synthesis) [Figure 1](#figure-1) more than 60 [mutations](../glossary#mutation) affecting mostly MOCS1 and MOCS2 have been identified [(28)](#reference28). The absence of a functional Moco has a direct impact on the activity of the molybdoenzymes. Metabolic disorders specifically associated with deficiency in sulfite oxidase activity include an accumulation of sulfite, thiosulfate (see [Figure 2](#figure-2) below). This metabolic profile is identical to that observed in isolated sulfite oxidase deficiency (ISOD), an inherited condition caused by mutations in the SUOX gene that codes for sulfite oxidase [(29)](#reference29). Compared with ISOD, Moco deficiency (MocoD) also affects the xanthine pathway and leads to an accumulation of hypoxanthine and xanthine, and low to undetectable uric acid concentrations in blood (see [Figure 3](#figure-3) below). MocoD and ISOD have been diagnosed in more than 100 individuals worldwide. However the global prevalence of MocoD is likely to be underestimated as a result of a failure to diagnose or to report [(28, 30, 31)](#reference30). The incidence of MocoD has been recently estimated at one in 100,000 to 200,000 live births [(32)](#reference32). Both MocoD and ISOD result from [recessive traits](../glossary#recessive-trait), meaning that only individuals who inherit two copies of the abnormal gene (one from each parent) develop the disease. Individuals who inherit only one copy of the abnormal gene are known as carriers of the trait but do not exhibit any symptoms. ISOD and MocoD can be diagnosed relatively early in pregnancy (10-14 weeks' gestation) by [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) activity assays using amniotic cell chorionic villus sampling and by genetic testing [(30, 33)](#reference30). These disorders typically occur in the first days of life, although a few cases of MocoD with late presentation have been described [(34-37)](#reference34). The loss of sulfite oxidase activity in ISOD and MocoD leads to severe [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) dysfunction characterized by cerebral [atrophy](../glossary#atrophy), mental retardation, intractable [seizures](../glossary#seizure), and dislocation of [ocular](../glossary#ocular) lenses. At present, it is not clear whether the neurologic effects are a result of the accumulation of a toxic metabolite, such as sulfite, or inadequate sulfate production. Patients with ISOD and MocoD were also found (-AASA) [(38)](#reference38). -AASA of a deficiency in -AASA dehydrogenase observed in patients with [pyridoxine](../vitamins/vitamin-B6)-dependent [epilepsy](../glossary#epilepsy). The enzymatic deficiency in these individuals causes an increase in -AASA and its cyclic form piperideine-6-carboxylate (P6C). P6C can (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine), leading to a deficiency in PLP, which is corrected with supplemental pyridoxine. A decrease in PLP has also been observed in the [cerebrospinal fluid](../glossary#cerebrospinal-fluid) from ISOD and MocoD patients [(39)](#reference39). It is not clear whether sulfite is responsible for the accumulation of -AASA and the deficiency in PLP in ISOD and MocoD patients. Nevertheless, pyridoxine and folic acid supplementation in patients with MocoD successfully normalized the PLP level and abolished seizures in two patients with mutations in MOCS2 (MocoD Type B) [(40)](#reference40). Although anti-seizure medications and dietary restriction of sulfur-containing amino acids may be beneficial in some cases [(41)](#reference41), there are no treatment options for patients with mutations in the MOCS2, GPHN (MocoD Type C), or SUOX genes. Pyridoxine supplementation is an option being considered to alleviate specific clinical features in patients. A successful treatment using cyclic pyranopterin monophosphate (cPMP) has been described for patients with mutations in the MOCS1 gene (i.e., those with MocoD Type A) [(42)](#reference42). The MOCS1 gene controls the initial step in the Moco biosynthetic pathway, catalyzing the conversion of guanosine triphosphate into cPMP. Therefore, patients with mutations in the MOCS1 gene lack cPMP. Daily administration of cPMP to patients resolved all metabolic abnormalities associated with defective sulfite oxidase and xanthine pathways and prevented further signs of neurologic deterioration [(43, 44)](#reference43). Early diagnosis and initiation of treatment are essential to ensure success [(44)](#reference44). A [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) of 16 young infants, followed for five years, found that intravenous cPMP treatment was associated with clinical improvement in most infants with MocoD Type A but not in those with MocoD Type B [(42)](#reference42). The US Food and Drug Administration recently approved the cPMP replacement drug, fosdenopterin (brand name: Nulibry), for [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) treatment of MocoD Type A [(45)](#reference45). Since cPMP replacement therapy can only benefit MocoD Type A, additional treatment methods are required. A mouse model for MocoD Type B has been recently developed, which may aid in the development of a therapy for those suffering from the MOSC2 mutation [(46)](#reference46). The recommended dietary allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) for molybdenum was most recently revised in January 2001 by the Food and Nutrition Board of the Institute of Medicine (now the National Academy of Medicine) [(2)](#reference2). It was based on the results of nutritional [balance studies](../glossary#balance-study) conducted in eight, healthy young men under controlled laboratory conditions [(47, 48)](#reference47). The RDA values for molybdenum are listed in Table 1 in micrograms (g)/day by age and gender. Adequate intake ( [AI](../glossary#AI)) levels were set for infants based on mean molybdenum intake from human milk, exclusively. The Daily Value ( [DV](../glossary#DV)), derived from the RDA, is 45 g/day for individuals 4 years of age or is a small region in northern China where the incidence of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) of the [esophagus](../glossary#esophagus) and stomach is very high (10 times higher than the average in China and 100 times higher than the average in the US). The soil in this region is low in molybdenum and other [mineral](../glossary#mineral) elements; therefore, dietary molybdenum intake is also low. Studies conducted in other areas of low and high incidence of esophageal cancer showed that content of molybdenum and zinc in hair and nails is significantly lower in inhabitants of high- [risk](../glossary#risk) regions compared to cold spots. Moreover, esophageal cancer patients display reduced content of the trace elements compared to healthy relatives [(50, 51)](#reference50). Increased intake of nitrosamines, which are known [carcinogens](../glossary#carcinogen), may be one of a number of dietary and environmental factors that contributes to the development of esophageal cancer in residents of high-risk regions. Adding ammonium molybdate to the soil may help decrease the risk of esophageal cancer by limiting nitrosamine exposure. It is not clear whether dietary molybdenum supplementation is beneficial in decreasing the risk of esophageal cancer. A [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled, [intervention trial](../glossary#intervention-trial) conducted in the Linxian area molybdenum (30 g/day) and [vitamin C](../vitamins/vitamin-C) (120 mg/day) for 5.25 years did not decrease the incidence or mortality from esophageal cancer [(52-54)](#reference52). The 25-year follow-up of this trial found that co-supplementation with these two micronutrients actually led to small increases in risk of death from gastric cardia cancer and cancer in general, but not death from esophageal cancer [(54)](#reference54). However, a subanalysis of this 25-year follow-up revealed that co-supplementation with molybdenum and vitamin C slightly increased risk of mortality from esophageal cancer in those who were 55 years or older when the trial initially began (HR, 1.16; 95% [CI](../glossary#confidence-interval): 1.04-1.30) [(54)](#reference54). Rugao is a county in Jiangsu province (China) renowned for the longevity of its residents. Extended longevity can hardly be attributed to significant differences in traditions, lifestyles, or dietary habits among the residents, and most longevous people are not related to one another, limiting the possible influence of genetics. However, the county has a large number of different soils whose compositions could affect the distribution of trace elements in water and crops and ultimately be linked with human health and longevity. Significant correlations were found between the ratio of people over 90 years old per 100,000 inhabitants and trace elements, including molybdenum, in soils, drinking water, and rice, which constitute key elements of their natural environment [(55)](#reference55). The percentage of long-lived people (>80 years old) in Zhongxiang (Hubei province) was also positively linked to the content of molybdenum in their staple food, rice [(56)](#reference56). In these regions, it is likely that combinations of trace elements contribute to optimum health and longevity as opposed to the sole effect of molybdenum. The Total Diet Study, an annual survey of the mineral content in the typical American diet, indicates that the dietary intake of molybdenum averages 76 g/day for women and 109 g/day for men. Thus, usual molybdenum intakes are well above the [ RDA](#RDA) for molybdenum. Legumes, such as beans, lentils, and peas, are the richest sources of molybdenum. Grain products and nuts are considered good sources, while animal products, fruit, and many vegetables are generally low in molybdenum [(2)](#reference2). Because the molybdenum content of plants depends on the soil molybdenum content and other environmental conditions, the molybdenum content of foods can vary considerably [(51](#reference51), [57)](#reference57). Molybdenum in single-nutrient and multiple nutrient [supplements](../glossary#supplement) may be present in solutions of parenteral nutrition either included as a trace element or as an incidental contaminant [(59, 60)](#reference59). The toxicity of molybdenum compounds appears to be relatively low in humans. Increased [serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of [uric acid](../glossary#uric-acid) and [ceruloplasmin](../glossary#ceruloplasmin) (an iron-oxidizing enzyme) have been reported in occupationally exposed workers in a molybdenite roasting plant [(61)](#reference61). [Gout](../glossary#gout)-like symptoms have also been reported in an Armenian population consuming 10 to 15 milligrams (mg) of molybdenum from food daily [(62)](#reference62). In other studies, blood and urinary uric acid concentrations were not elevated by molybdenum intakes up to 1.5 mg/day [(2)](#reference2). There has been only one report of acute toxicity related to molybdenum from a dietary supplement: an adult male reportedly consumed a total of 13.5 mg of molybdenum over a period of 18 days (300 to 800 g/day) and developed acute psychosis with hallucinations, [seizures](../glossary#seizure), and other [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) symptoms [(63)](#reference63). However, a controlled study in four, healthy young men found that molybdenum intakes, ranging from 22 g/day to 1,490 g/day (almost 1.5 mg/day), elicited no serious adverse effects when molybdenum was given for 24 days [(47)](#reference47). The Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the Institute of Medicine (now the National Academy of Medicine) found little evidence that molybdenum excess was associated with adverse health outcomes in generally healthy people. To determine the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)), the FNB selected adverse reproductive effects in rats as the most sensitive index of toxicity and applied a large uncertainty factor because animal data were used [(2)](#reference2). The UL for molybdenum is listed by age Table (2.0 mg/day)| |*Source of intake should be from food and formula only.| High doses of molybdenum have been found to inhibit the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of acetaminophen in rats [(64)](#reference64); however, it is not known whether this occurs at clinically relevant doses in humans. The [ RDA](#RDA) for molybdenum (45 g/day for adults) is sufficient to prevent deficiency. Although the intake of molybdenum most likely to promote optimum health is not known, there is presently no evidence that intakes higher than the RDA are beneficial. Most people in the US consume more than sufficient molybdenum in their diets, making supplementation unnecessary. Following the Linus Pauling Institute's general recommendation to take a multivitamin/mineral supplement that contains 100% of the daily values ( [DV](../glossary#DV)) for most nutrients is likely to provide 45 g/day of molybdenum. Because aging has not been associated with significant changes in the requirement for molybdenum [(2)](#reference2), our recommendation for older adults is the same as that for adults 50 years and younger. Toxicology. 2000;146(1):23-35. ] [(PubMed)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10773360) Contents Phosphorus is an essential [mineral](../glossary#mineral) that is required by every cell in the body for normal function [(1)](#references). Bound to oxygen in all biological systems, phosphorus is found as phosphate (PO43-) in the body. Approximately 85% of the body's phosphorus is found in bones and teeth [(2)](#reference2). Phosphorus is a major structural component of bone in the form of a calcium phosphate salt called [hydroxyapatite](../glossary#hydroxyapatite). [Phospholipids](../glossary#phospholipid) (e.g., phosphatidylcholine) are major structural components of [cell membranes](../glossary#cell-membrane). All energy production and storage are dependent on [phosphorylated](../glossary#phosphorylation) compounds, such which are responsible for the storage and transmission of genetic information, are long chains of phosphate-containing molecules. A number of [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme), [hormones](../glossary#hormone), and [cell-signaling](../glossary#cell-signaling) molecules depend on phosphorylation for their activation. Phosphorus also helps maintain normal acid-base balance ( [pH](../glossary#pH)) by acting as one of the body's most important [buffers](../glossary#buffer). Additionally, the phosphorus-containing molecule 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) binds to [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) in red blood cells and regulates oxygen delivery to the tissues of the body [(1)](#references). Dietary phosphorus is readily absorbed in the [small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine), and in healthy individuals, excess phosphorus is [excreted](../glossary#excretion) by the kidneys under the regulatory action of the [endocrine](../glossary#endocrine-system) [hormones](../glossary#hormone): parathyroid hormone (PTH), [vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D), and The acute regulation of blood [calcium](../minerals/calcium) and phosphorus concentrations is controlled through the actions of PTH and the active form of vitamin D. A slight drop in blood calcium levels (e.g., in the case of inadequate calcium intake) is sensed by the [parathyroid glands](../glossary#parathyroid-glands), resulting in their increased secretion of PTH, which rapidly decreases urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of calcium but increases urinary excretion of phosphorus and stimulates bone [resorption](../glossary#resorption). This results in the release of bone mineral (calcium and phosphate) — actions that restore serum calcium concentrations. Although the action is not immediate, PTH also stimulates conversion of vitamin D to its active form (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D; calcitriol) in the kidneys. Increased circulating 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D in turn stimulates increased intestinal absorption of both calcium and phosphorus. A third hormone, FGF-23, plays a central role in [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis). FGF-23 is secreted by bone-forming cells ( [osteoblasts](../glossary#osteoblast)/osteocytes) in response to increases in phosphorus intake. In a negative feedback loop, FGF-23 inhibits the production and stimulates the degradation of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, as well as promotes an increase in urinary phosphorus excretion independently of PTH and 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D [(3)](#reference3). phosphorus intake rarely results levels (hypophosphatemia) because [renal](../glossary#renal) reabsorption of phosphorus increases to compensate for decreased intake. The effects of moderate to severe hypophosphatemia may include loss of appetite, [anemia](../glossary#anemia), muscle weakness, bone pain, [rickets](../glossary#rickets) (in children), [osteomalacia](../glossary#osteomalacia) (in adults), increased susceptibility to infection, numbness and tingling of the extremities, difficulty walking, and respiratory failure. Severe hypophosphatemia may occasionally be life threatening. Since phosphorus is so widespread in food, dietary phosphorus deficiency is usually seen only in cases of near-total starvation. Other individuals at [risk](../glossary#risk) of hypophosphatemia include alcoholics, diabetics recovering from an episode of [diabetic ketoacidosis](../glossary#diabetic-ketoacidosis), patients with respiratory alkalosis, and starving or anorexic patients on refeeding regimens that are high in calories but too low in phosphorus (reviewed in [4](#reference4)). Hypophosphatemia caused by inherited disorders of phosphorus [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) (phosphorus wasting disorders) has been linked to elevated urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) or impaired renal reabsorption of phosphorus in affected subjects (reviewed in [5](#reference5)). The Recommended Dietary Allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) for phosphorus is based on the maintenance of normal [serum](../glossary#serum) phosphorus levels in adults (2.5-4.5 milligrams/deciliter [mg/dL]) and is believed to represent adequate phosphorus intakes to meet cellular and bone formation needs ( [6](#reference6); Table 1). The RDA, which is the average daily intake that meets the requirements of 97.5% of healthy individuals in a specific life stage and gender group, is based on the Estimated Average Requirement ( [EAR](../glossary#EAR); 580 mg/day of phosphorus for adults) — the nutrient intake that meets the requirements of 50% of healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group. |Life Stage||Age|| Males | (mg/day) | Females | (mg/day) |Infants||0-6 months|| 100 ( | Phosphorus is found in most food because it is a critical constituent of all living organisms. Dairy foods, cereal products, meat, and fish are particularly rich sources of phosphorus [(7)](#reference7). Phosphorus is also a component of many food additives that are used in food processing and is present in cola soft drinks as phosphoric acid [(8)](#reference8). In the nationally representative NHANES survey, phosphorus intakes were well above the EAR and RDA, with average daily intakes of 1,602 mg in men and 1,128 mg in women [(8)](#reference8). Dietary phosphorus derived from food additives is not always included in food nutrient composition databases, so the total amount of phosphorus consumed by the average person in the US can be underestimated by more than 20% [(9)](#reference9). Segments of the US population who consume more highly processed foods and whose phosphorus intakes approach the tolerable upper intake level of 4,000 mg/day are thought by some to be at high [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing adverse health outcomes (see [Safety](#safety)) [(7, 9)](#reference7). The phosphorus in plant seeds (beans, peas, cereals, and nuts) is present in a storage form of phosphate called phytic acid or phytate. Only about 50% of the phosphorus from phytate is available to humans because we lack [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) (phytases) that liberate phosphorus from phytate [(10)](#reference10). Yeasts possess phytases, so whole grains incorporated into leavened breads have more [bioavailable](../glossary#bioavailability) phosphorus than whole grains incorporated into breakfast cereals or flat breads [(6)](#reference6). Sodium phosphate and potassium phosphate salts are used for the treatment of hypophosphatemia that occurs in hereditary disorders of phosphate wasting, and their use requires medical supervision. Calcium phosphate salts are sometimes used as [calcium](../minerals/calcium) supplements [(13)](#reference13). Commonly used over-the-counter and prescription drugs also contribute to phosphorus intakes at levels yet to be defined [(10)](#reference10). Several disorders characterized by [serum](../glossary#serum) phosphorus levels above normal (hyperphosphatemia) have been described, including those resulting from increased intestinal absorption of phosphate salts taken by mouth or by [colonic](../glossary#colon) absorption of the phosphate salts in enemas [(1)](#references). Yet, the disruption of phosphorus [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) is most often associated with [excretion](../glossary#excretion) failure in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) or end-stage [renal](../glossary#renal) disease (advanced CKD). When kidney function is only 20% of normal, even phosphorus intakes within the recommended range may lead to hyperphosphatemia. Hyperphosphatemia may also affect individuals with inappropriately low parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels ( [hypoparathyroidism](../glossary#hypoparathyroidism)) as they lack PTH stimulation of renal phosphate excretion and fail to stimulate [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (the active form of [vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D)). These individuals cannot excrete excess phosphorus in the absence of both hormones [(14)](#reference14). Elevated serum phosphorus concentrations have been associated with accelerated disease progression in individuals with impaired kidney function and have been linked to increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of adverse health outcomes in the general population [(9](#reference9), [15)](#reference15). High [serum](../glossary#serum) phosphorus within the normal range (2.5-4.5 mg/dL) has recently been associated with increased incidence of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) (CVD) in individuals with normal kidney function. Two studies conducted in the general population and in individuals with prior CVD have linked high-normal serum phosphorus found concentrations equal to or above 4 mg/dL were associated with a doubling of the risk of developing incident CKD and end-stage [renal](../glossary#renal) disease in individuals free of renal disease at study inception [(18)](#reference18). In a [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), which followed 4,005 healthy young adults for more than 15 years, higher serum phosphorus within the normal range was also associated with [left ventricular hypertrophy](../glossary#left-ventricular-hypertrophy), a condition often linked to adverse cardiovascular outcomes [(19)](#reference19). In another study of 3,088 middle-aged healthy participants followed for over 17 years, serum phosphorus concentrations in the top [quartile](../glossary#quartile) of the normal range were associated with a two-fold higher risk of heart failure compared to the lowest quartile (3.5 mg/dL vs. <2.9 mg/dL) [(16)](#reference16). It is thought that vascular [calcification](../glossary#calcification), which may explain the relationship between high phosphorus and cardiovascular disease risk in CKD patients (see [Hyperphosphatemia in subjects with kidney disease](#hyperphosphatemia-kidney-disease)), contributes to this association in individuals with normal kidney function, even when their serum phosphorus is within the normal range and their intakes are below the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) [(20, 21)](#reference20). PTH/ [vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D)/FGF-23 axis in individuals with normal kidney function (see [Regulation](#regulation)). Increased secretion of PTH and FGF-23 helps maintain phosphorus serum concentrations in the normal range (2.5-4.5 mg/dL) even in the setting of high phosphorus intake [(9)](#reference9). This contributes to serum phosphorus being only weakly correlated to phosphorus consumption [(22)](#reference22). Thus, it is reasonable to assume that measuring serum phosphorus in people with normal renal function cannot adequately reflect early disturbances in phosphorus [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) due to high phosphorus consumption. [Observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have reported high rates of mortality and [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events in association with high blood phosphorus levels in subjects with CKD. A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 13 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), conducted in over 90,000 CKD patients, found an 18% increase in all-cause mortality per 1 mg/dL increase in [serum](../glossary#serum) phosphorus concentration increased [risk](../glossary#risk) in [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) (CVD)-related death was also calculated for each 1 mg/dL higher concentration in the meta-analysis of three studies [(25)](#reference25). Although no causality has been established between [vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D) deficiency and CVD risk, it has been suggested that failure to produce 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D in hyperphosphatemic individuals may modify the risk of developing cardiovascular and [renal](../glossary#renal) disease, as well as worsen kidney insufficiency in CKD patients [(26)](#reference26). Another plausible mechanism for hyperphosphatemia-induced cardiovascular dysfunction is the deposition of calcium phosphate in non-skeletal tissues, especially the vasculature [(27)](#reference27). Indeed, high phosphorus concentrations may stimulate the expression of bone specific markers in blood vessel-forming cells, resulting in a shift in their functions; this process, called osteochondrogenic [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation), transforms vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) into bone-like cells. The culture of human aortic VSMCs in hyperphosphatemic conditions was found to result in with at least a three-fold increase in risk for cardiovascular events and mortality; the risk for cardiovascular events is twice as high (i.e., six-fold increased risk) in individuals with kidney insufficiency [(29)](#reference29). In CKD patients, disorders in [bone remodeling](../glossary#bone-remodeling) may result in excess release of phosphorus and calcium into the blood, which exacerbates hyperphosphatemia and vascular calcification and accelerates the decline of kidney function. Currently, dietary phosphorus restriction is recommended to normalize serum concentrations in CKD patients, although the impact on CVD and mortality risks is not known. To avoid the adverse effects of hyperphosphatemia, the US Food and Nutrition Board set a tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for oral phosphorus in generally healthy individuals ( [6](#reference6); Table 3). The lower UL for individuals over 70 years of age, compared to younger age groups, reflects the increased likelihood of impaired kidney function in elderly individuals. Some investigators are concerned about the increasing amounts of phosphates in the diet, which they largely attribute to phosphoric acid in some soft drinks and the increasing use of phosphate additives in processed foods [(31, 32)](#reference31). High [serum](../glossary#serum) phosphorus has been shown to impair [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of the active form of vitamin D (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D) in the kidneys, reduce blood [calcium](../minerals/calcium), and lead to increased PTH release by the [parathyroid glands](../glossary#parathyroid-glands) [(8)](#reference8). PTH stimulation then results in decreased urinary calcium [excretion](../glossary#excretion) and increased bone [resorption](../glossary#resorption); both contribute to serum calcium concentrations returning to normal [(8)](#reference8). If sustained, elevated PTH levels could have an adverse effect on bone mineral content, but this effect appears to be observed with diets that are high in phosphorus and low in calcium, underscoring the importance of a balanced dietary calcium-to-phosphorus ratio. In a small [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study), which enrolled 147 premenopausal women with adequate calcium intakes, participants with lower calcium-to-phosphorus (Ca:P) intakes (ratios 0.5) had significantly higher serum PTH levels and urinary calcium excretion than those with higher Ca:P ratios (ratios >0.5) [(33)](#reference33). A controlled trial in 10 young women found no adverse effects of a phosphorus-rich diet (3,000 mg/day) on bone-related [hormones](../glossary#hormone) and biochemical markers of bone resorption when dietary calcium intakes were maintained at almost 2,000 mg/day (Ca:P = 0.66), again demonstrating the importance of the balance between dietary calcium and phosphorus [(34)](#reference34). A cross-sectional study conducted in 2,344 Brazilian men and women (median age, 58 years) showed an association between higher phosphorus intakes and increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [fracture](../glossary#fracture). Yet, intakes of other [minerals](../glossary#mineral) and [vitamins](../glossary#vitamin) relevant to bone health, such as [calcium](../minerals/calcium), [magnesium](../minerals/magnesium), and [vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D), were below the RDA in this population, whereas phosphorus intakes were close to the RDA [(35)](#reference35). While it appears that hormonal and calcium disorders might be prevented by an adequate calcium-to-phosphorus intake ratio, there is no convincing evidence that the dietary phosphorus levels experienced in the US adversely affect [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density). Nevertheless, the substitution of phosphate-containing soft drinks and snack foods for milk and other calcium-rich food may represent a serious risk to bone health (see the article on [Calcium](../minerals/calcium)) [(36)](#reference36). Aluminum-containing antacids reduce the absorption of dietary phosphorus by forming aluminum phosphate, which is unabsorbable. When consumed in high doses, aluminum-containing antacids can produce abnormally low blood phosphorus levels (hypophosphatemia), as well as aggravate phosphorus deficiency due to other causes [(37)](#reference37). The reduction of stomach acidity by proton-pump inhibitors may also limit the efficacy of phosphate-binder therapy in patients with kidney failure [(38)](#reference38). Excessively high doses of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, the active form of vitamin D, or its [analogs](../glossary#analog), may result in hyperphosphatemia [(6)](#reference6). [Potassium](../minerals/potassium) [supplements](../glossary#supplement) or potassium-sparing [diuretics](../glossary#diuretic) taken together with phosphorus supplements may result in high blood levels of potassium (hyperkalemia). Hyperkalemia can be a serious problem, resulting in life-threatening heart rhythm abnormalities ( [arrhythmias](../glossary#arrhythmia)). People taking such a combination must inform their health care provider and have their [serum](../glossary#serum) potassium levels checked regularly [(37)](#reference37). Additionally, prevention of bone demineralization by [hormone](../glossary#hormone) replacement therapy in postmenopausal women is associated with higher urinary phosphorus [excretion](../glossary#excretion) and lower serum phosphorus levels in treated compared to untreated women [(39, 40)](#reference39). The Linus Pauling Institute supports the [RDA](#RDA) for phosphorus (700 mg/day for adults). Although some multivitamin/mineral supplements contain more than 15% of the current RDA for phosphorus, a varied diet should easily provide adequate phosphorus for most people. At present, there is no evidence that phosphorus requirements of older adults differ from that of younger adults, and a varied diet should easily provide the RDA (700 mg/day) of phosphorus for those over 50 years of age.
