The term electrolyte refers to a substance that dissociates into [ions](../glossary#ion) (charged particles) in solution, making it capable of conducting electricity. Normal body function depends on tight regulation of potassium concentrations both inside and outside of cells [(1)](#references). Potassium (K+) is the principal positively charged [ion](../glossary#ion) ( [cation](../glossary#cation)) in the fluid inside of cells, while sodium (Na+) is the principal cation in the extracellular fluid. Potassium concentrations are about 30 times higher inside than outside cells, while [sodium](sodium) concentrations are more than 10 times lower inside than outside cells. The concentration differences between potassium and sodium across [cell membranes](../glossary#cell-membrane) create an electrochemical gradient known as the [membrane potential](../glossary#membrane-potential). A cell's membrane potential is maintained by ion pumps in the cell membrane, especially the Na+/K+-ATPase pumps. These pumps use [ATP](../glossary#ATP) (energy) to pump sodium out of the cell in exchange for potassium (Figure 1). Their activity has been estimated to account for 20%-40% of the resting energy expenditure in a typical adult. The large proportion of energy dedicated to maintaining sodium/potassium concentration gradients emphasizes the importance of this function in sustaining life. Tight control of cell membrane potential is critical for nerve impulse transmission, muscle contraction, and heart function [(2-4)](#reference2). A limited number of [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) require the presence of potassium for their activity. The activation of Na+/K+-ATPase requires the presence of sodium and potassium. The presence of potassium is also required for the activity of pyruvate kinase, an important enzyme in [carbohydrate](../glossary#carbohydrate) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [(5)](#reference5). An [plasma](../glossary#plasma) potassium concentration is referred to as hypokalemia. Hypokalemia is most commonly a result of excessive loss of potassium, e.g., from prolonged vomiting or diarrhea, use of some [diuretics](../glossary#diuretic) and other medications (see [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions)), some forms of kidney disease, or metabolic disturbances. The symptoms of hypokalemia are related to alterations in [membrane potential](../glossary#membrane-potential) and cellular [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [(1)](#references). They include fatigue, muscle weakness and cramps, and intestinal paralysis, which may lead to bloating, constipation, and abdominal pain. Chronic hypokalemia is associated with hypertension and kidney stone formation (see [Disease Prevention](#disease-prevention) and [Disease Treatment](#disease-treatment)). Severe hypokalemia may result in muscular paralysis or abnormal heart rhythms (cardiac [arrhythmias](../health-disease/arrhythmia)) that can be fatal [(1](#references), [6)](#reference6). Low dietary potassium intake alone does not generally result in hypokalemia. However, insufficient dietary potassium in patients at risk of hypokalemia can precipitate hypokalemia [(1)](#references). In rare cases, habitual consumption of large amounts of black licorice has resulted in hypokalemia [(7, 8)](#reference7). Licorice contains a compound (i.e., glycyrrhizic acid) with similar physiologic effects to those of aldosterone, a [hormone](../glossary#hormone) that increases urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of potassium. The Dietary Reference Intakes ( [DRIs](../glossary#DRI)) for potassium have been recently revised by the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the National Academy of Medicine. The FNB did not find sufficient evidence to determine an Estimated Average Requirement ( [EAR](../glossary#EAR)) and derive a Recommended Dietary Allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)); instead, they established an adequate intake ( [AI](../glossary#AI)) based on median intakes in generally healthy people (Table 1) [(9)](#reference9). The FNB found insufficient evidence from human studies that examined potassium intakes in relation to [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease) and mortality (reviewed recently by the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality; [10](#reference10)) to inform the DRIs for potassium [(11)](#reference11). people residing in Western industrialized countries are quite different from those that were consumed before the agricultural revolution and the shift towards the consumption of highly refined, processed food [(12)](#reference12). Among other differences, the daily intake of sodium chloride (salt) in modern diets is about three times higher than the daily intake of potassium on a [molar](../glossary#mole) basis, whereas salt intake in primitive cultures is about seven times lower than potassium intake [(13)](#reference13). The relative deficiency of dietary potassium in the modern diet and a higher sodium-to-potassium ratio may contribute to the development of some [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease). [Observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have consistently reported an increased with elevated dietary sodium intakes [(14, cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have also found an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between potassium intake and risk of [stroke](../health-disease/stroke). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine prospective cohort studies showed that daily potassium intakes ranging between 3,510 mg and 4,680 mg were associated with a 30% reduced risk of stroke [(16)](#reference16). No associations were found with [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) or total cardiovascular disease. In a more recent meta-analysis of 16 studies, the highest versus lowest dietary potassium intake was found to be associated with a 13% lower risk of stroke after multiple adjustments (including for blood pressure) [(17)](#reference17). The lowest risk of stroke corresponded to daily potassium intakes around 3,500 mg. Subgroup analyses showed a reduced risk of [ischemic stroke](../glossary#ischemic-stroke), but not [hemorrhagic stroke](../glossary#hemorrhagic-stroke). Finally, in a recent meta-analysis of 16 observational studies, each 1-unit increase in the dietary sodium-to-potassium ratio was found to be associated with a 22% higher risk of stroke [(12)](#reference12). Abnormally high increases the [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing [kidney stones](../glossary#kidney-stones). In individuals with a history of developing calcium-containing kidney stones, increased dietary acid load has been significantly associated with increased urinary calcium [excretion](../glossary#excretion) [(18)](#reference18). Increasing dietary potassium (and alkali) intake by increasing fruit and vegetable intake or by taking potassium bicarbonate (KHCO3) [supplements](../glossary#supplement) has been found to decrease urinary calcium excretion. Conversely, potassium deprivation has been found to increase urinary calcium excretion [(19, 20)](#reference19). Three large US [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) — the Health Professionals Follow-up Study and the Nurses' Health Studies I and II — which included 193,676 participants, have examined dietary potassium intake and animal protein-to-potassium ratio (a marker of dietary acid load) in the diet in relation to the risk of developing kidney stones [(21)](#reference21). In all three cohorts, dietary potassium intake was derived almost entirely from potassium-rich foods, such as fruit and vegetables. Across the three cohorts, individuals in the highest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of potassium intake were found to be 33%-56% less likely to develop symptomatic kidney stones than those in the lowest quintile of intake. Additionally, a pooled analysis of the data from all three cohorts showed that those with the highest versus lowest animal protein-to-potassium ratio were 41% more likely to develop kidney stones [(21)](#reference21). Urinary alkalinization with supplemental potassium citrate is used in stone formers to reduce the risk of recurrent stone formation (reviewed in [22](#reference22)). However, potassium citrate therapy should only be initiated under the supervision of a medical provider. In a 2015 case-cohort study nested within the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC)-Norfolk study, which included 5,319 individuals, dietary intakes of potassium (alone or combined with intakes of magnesium) were found to be [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with heel bone (calcaneus) broadband ultrasound attenuation (BUA) measurements (a predictor of the [risk](../glossary#risk) of incidental fracture) and risk of hip fracture in women but not in men [(23)](#reference23). More recently, a [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) in older Korean adults reported higher total hip and femur neck [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) (BMD) in those in the top versus bottom [tertile](../glossary#tertile) of potassium intakes [(24)](#reference24). Although these [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) suggest a link between potassium intakes and bone health, they cannot establish whether there is a cause-and-effect relationship. The mechanisms by which potassium might influence bone health are poorly understood. Modern (Western) diets tend to be relatively low in sources of alkali ( [fruit and vegetables](../food-beverages/fruit-vegetables)) and high in sources of acid (fish, meat, and cheese) [(25)](#reference25). When the quantity of bicarbonate ions is insufficient to maintain normal [pH](../glossary#pH), the body is capable of mobilizing [alkaline](../glossary#alkaline) calcium salts from bone in order to neutralize acids consumed in the diet or generated by [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [(26)](#reference26). Because fruit and vegetables are rich in both potassium and [precursors](../glossary#precursor) to bicarbonate ions, increasing their consumption might help reduce the net acid content of the diet and preserve calcium in bones, which might otherwise be mobilized to maintain normal pH (see the article on [Fruit and Vegetables](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/food-beverages/fruit-vegetables#osteoporosis-prevention)). Alternatively, potassium bicarbonate supplementation might decrease urinary acid and calcium [excretion](../glossary#excretion) and influence bone turnover — a small trial in postmenopausal women found that potassium bicarbonate supplementation increases [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) of bone formation and a of bone [resorption](../glossary#resorption) [(27)](#reference27). A two-year [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), controlled trial in 201 older adults without [osteoporosis](../health-disease/osteoporosis) (mean age, 69 years) found evidence of increased lumbar spine, hip, femoral neck, and total-body BMD, as well as trabecular BMD of the radius and tibia, with supplemental (2,340 mg/day) compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(28)](#reference28). Potassium citrate was found to increase the [serum](../glossary#serum) concentration of N-terminal propeptide of type I procollagen (PINP) — a marker of bone formation — and reduce the urine concentration of N-telopeptide of collagen type I (NTX) — a marker of bone resorption [(28)](#reference28). Another three-month, randomized, placebo-controlled trial in 244 adults (50 years) examined the effect of oral potassium bicarbonate, at either 39 mg/kg/day or 58.5 mg/kg/day, on markers of bone turnover [(29)](#reference29). Both dosage regimens led to reductions in serum PINP concentration and urine NTX concentration, yet evidence of an effect was stronger with the lowest dose (median dose administered, 3,160 mg/day) rather than with the highest dose (median dose administered, 4,760 mg/day). In contrast, a two-year [randomized controlled (721 mg/day or 2,165 mg/day) nor an increase in fruit and vegetable intake (300 mg/day) had an impact on markers of bone turnover or increased BMD in postmenopausal women [(30)](#reference30). A 2015 meta-analysis of [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) found that supplemental potassium citrate or potassium bicarbonate could reduce urinary net acid and calcium excretion, but evidence to support an effect on markers of bone turnover and bone density was weak [(31)](#reference31). The most recent randomized, double-blind, controlled trial in 40 postmenopausal women with [osteopenia](../glossary#osteopenia) found no difference in markers of bone turnover over a six-month period between those supplemented with potassium citrate and those taking a placebo [(32)](#reference32). The authors highlighted the possibility that an effect of supplemental potassium might have an impact on bone health in a subset of subjects with low potassium intakes and/or signs of low-grade acidosis. In this study, all participants received daily supplements of calcium carbonate (500 mg/day) and [vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D) (10 µg/day). Overall, whether consuming potassium-rich fruit and vegetables can influence bone health and help lower the risk of osteoporosis remains uncertain (see also the article on [Fruit and Vegetables](../food-beverages/fruit-vegetables#osteoporosis-prevention)). Forty-five percent of US adults have [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure) (blood pressure levels 130/80 mm Hg) [(33)](#reference33). Chronic hypertension damages the heart, blood vessels, and kidneys, thereby increasing the [risk](../glossary#risk) of heart disease and [stroke](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/health-disease/stroke), as well as hypertensive kidney disease [(34, 35)](#reference34). Modern diets, which are high in [sodium](sodium) and low in potassium, are recognized as largely contributing to the high [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of hypertension (see the article on [Sodium](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/minerals/sodium#health-risks-excess-sodium)). Unlike 24-hour dietary recalls, 24-hour urine collections provide accurate estimates of dietary intakes of sodium and potassium [(36)](#reference36). An analysis of the 2014 US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) showed an increase in [systolic blood pressure](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) with increasing sodium excretion and increasing sodium-to-potassium ratio in the urine [(37)](#reference37). In this study, the highest versus lowest [quartile](../glossary#quartile) potassium excretion (mid-values, with a 62% lower risk of hypertension [(37)](#reference37). The Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) trial provided evidence of the blood pressure-lowering effect of a diet higher in [potassium](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/minerals/potassium) and [calcium](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/minerals/calcium), modestly higher in protein, and lower in total fat, [saturated fat](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/glossary#saturated-fatty-acid), [cholesterol](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/health-disease/cholesterol), red meat, sweets, and sugar-containing beverages compared to the typical US diet [(38)](#reference38). Indeed, compared to the control diet providing only 3.5 servings/day of [fruit and vegetables](../food-beverages/fruit-vegetables) and 1,700 mg/day of potassium, adherence to the DASH diet that included 8.5 servings/day of fruit and vegetables and 4,100 mg/day of potassium lowered systolic/ [diastolic](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) blood pressures by an average 11.4/5.5 [mm Hg](../glossary#mm-Hg) in people with hypertension and 3.5/2.1 mm Hg in those without hypertension [(38)](#reference38). A 2014 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 17 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) that examined the effect of the DASH diet compared to a control diet in a total of 2,561 adults found overall reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressure by 6.7 mm Hg and 3.5 mm Hg, respectively [(39)](#reference39). However effective the DASH diet is, the blood pressure-lowering effects can hardly be solely attributed to potassium intakes [(40)](#reference40). A 2015 meta-analysis of 15 randomized controlled trials, including 917 individuals, assessed the effects of increased potassium intake, mostly in the form of potassium chloride (KCl) [supplements](../glossary#supplement), on blood pressure [(41)](#reference41). Thirteen studies included hypertensive participants who were not taking anti-hypertensive medication and two studies included [normotensive](../glossary#normotensive) or at-risk subjects. Most studies used supplemental potassium doses between 2,340 and 2,535 mg/day (60-65 mmol/L). Increased potassium intake resulted in overall reductions of systolic blood pressure by 4.7 mm Hg and diastolic blood pressure by 3.5 mm Hg. The blood pressure-lowering effect of supplemental potassium was more pronounced when the analysis was restricted to individuals with hypertension: systolic and diastolic blood pressure were found to be reduced by 6.8 mm Hg and 4.6 mm Hg, respectively [(41)](#reference41). Two additional meta-analyses published in 2017 also confirmed a blood pressure-lowering effect of supplemental potassium. Findings suggested some evidence of a greater effect when baseline potassium intake was less than 3,510 mg/day (vs. 3,510 reported a dose-response relationship between the intake of potassium and the lowering of blood pressure [(42, 43)](#reference42). Supplemental potassium can help lower blood pressure, but potassium supplements should only be used in consultation with a medical provider (see [Supplements](#supplements)). Increasing potassium intake to recommended levels (see [Adequate Intake](#AI)) by consuming a diet rich in fruit and vegetables can help lower blood pressure and may have additional benefits to health (see the article on [Fruit and Vegetables](../food-beverages/fruit-vegetables)). Blood pressure is a reliable [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) risk marker [(44)](#reference44). Yet, although reducing sodium consumption while increasing potassium intake helps with lowering blood pressure [(45)](#reference45), current evidence suggests that dietary advice and support interventions may not be sufficient to deliver long-term cardiovascular benefits in individuals with hypertension [(46)](#reference46). The richest sources of potassium are [fruit and vegetables](../food-beverages/fruit-vegetables). [Nuts](../food-beverages/nuts), seeds, and dairy products are also good sources of potassium. A dietary survey in the US indicated that the average dietary potassium intake was 2,408 mg/day for adult women and 3,172 mg/day for adult men [(47)](#reference47). Because many individuals in the population consume potassium in amounts that are well below the [AI](../glossary#AI) and because underconsumption of potassium is linked with adverse health effects, potassium has been recognized as a "nutrient of public health concern" in the [2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans](https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/2015/guidelines/). In 2016, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) required manufacturers to display potassium content of foods on the Nutrition Facts food label [(48)](#reference48). Some relatively good dietary sources of potassium are listed in the Table 2, along with their potassium content in milligrams (mg). For more information on the nutrient content search the US do not contain more than 99 mg of potassium per serving [(50)](#reference50). One milliequivalent (mEq) or one millimole (mmol) corresponds to about 39 mg of potassium. Higher doses of supplemental potassium are generally prescribed to prevent and treat potassium depletion and hypokalemia. The use of more potent potassium supplements in potassium deficiency requires close monitoring of [serum](../glossary#serum) potassium concentrations. Potassium is available in different supplemental forms, including potassium chloride, potassium citrate, potassium gluconate, potassium bicarbonate, potassium aspartate, and potassium orotate [(50)](#reference50). Because of the potential for serious side effects, one should seek medical advice before deciding to use a potassium supplement (see [Safety](#safety)). The best way to increase one's potassium intake is by increasing the consumption of potassium-rich food and beverages [(50)](#reference50). Finally, many salt substitutes contain potassium chloride, and acesulfame potassium (Ace-K) is an FDA-approved general purpose sweetener. Abnormally elevated [serum](../glossary#serum) potassium concentrations are referred to as hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia occurs when potassium intake exceeds the capacity of the kidneys to eliminate it. Acute or chronic kidney failure, the use of potassium-sparing [diuretics](../glossary#diuretic), and insufficient aldosterone secretion (hypoaldosteronism) may result in the accumulation of potassium due to a decreased urinary potassium [excretion](../glossary#excretion). Oral doses of potassium >18 g taken at one time in individuals not accustomed to high intakes may lead to severe hyperkalemia, even in those with normal kidney function [(6](#reference6), [50)](#reference50). Hyperkalemia may also result from a shift of intracellular potassium into the circulation, which may occur with the rupture of red blood cells ( [hemolysis](../glossary#hemolysis)) or tissue damage (e.g., trauma or severe burns). Symptoms of hyperkalemia may include tingling of the hands and feet, muscular weakness, and temporary paralysis. The most serious complication of hyperkalemia is the development of an abnormal heart rhythm ( [cardiac arrhythmia](../health-disease/arrhythmia)), which can lead to cardiac arrest [(51)](#reference51). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) showed that heart rate in healthy adults was unlikely to be affected by the chronic use of supplemental potassium doses of 2 to 3 g/day [(52)](#reference52). See the section on [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions) for a discussion of the medications that increase the risk of hyperkalemia. [Gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) symptoms are the most common side effects of potassium [supplements](../glossary#supplement), including nausea, vomiting, abdominal discomfort, and diarrhea. Intestinal ulceration has been reported after the use of enteric-coated potassium chloride tablets. Taking potassium with meals or taking a microencapsulated form of potassium may reduce gastrointestinal side effects [(50)](#reference50). Rashes may occasionally occur. The most serious adverse reaction to potassium supplementation is hyperkalemia, yet is rare in subjects with normal kidney function (see [Toxicity](#toxicity)). Individuals with abnormal kidney function and those on potassium-sparing medications (see [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions)) should be monitored closely to prevent hyperkalemia [(50, 53)](#reference50). Corticoids cause sodium retention that leads to a compensatory increase in urinary potassium excretion. As a consequence, median potassium intakes observed in apparently healthy people were used to set adequate intakes ( [AI](../glossary#AI)) by age/life stage in the recent revision of the Dietary Reference Intakes ( [DRIs](../glossary#DRI)) for potassium. [Fruit and vegetables](../food-beverages/fruit-vegetables) are among the richest sources of dietary potassium, and a large body of evidence supports the association of increased fruit and vegetable intakes with reduced risk of [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) (see the article on [Fruit and Vegetables](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/food-beverages/fruit-vegetables)). The Linus Pauling Institute recommends the consumption of a diet high in potassium-rich foods (see [Sources](#sources)), especially fruit, vegetables, [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts), and dairy products to ensure adequate potassium intakes. A diet rich in [fruit and vegetables](../food-beverages/fruit-vegetables) that supplies 2.6-3.4 g/day of potassium (see [AI](../glossary#AI)) should contribute to maintaining a low [risk](../glossary#risk) of [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease) in generally healthy older adults. This recommendation does not apply to individuals who have been advised to limit potassium consumption by a health care professional (see [Safety](#safety)). Contents [Selenium is a trace ] [element](../glossary#element) that is essential in small amounts, but like all essential elements, selenium can be toxic at high levels. Unlike plants, most animals — including humans — require selenium for the appropriate functioning of a number of incorporated into elongating proteins at very specific locations in the amino acid sequence in order to form functional selenoproteins. Although higher plants do not appear to require selenium for survival, they can incorporate it non-specifically into sulfur-containing molecules when the mineral is present in the soil [(1)](#references). Of note, in animals, the amino acid selenomethionine can be nonspecifically incorporated into proteins in place of [methionine](../glossary#methionine) [(2)](#reference2). However, only selenocysteine-containing proteins are regarded as selenoproteins (Figure 1). Twenty-five genes coding for selenoproteins have been identified in humans [(3)](#reference3). The insertion of selenocysteine into selenoproteins during [translation](../glossary#translation) is directed by the presence of a selenocysteine-insertion sequence (SECIS) within selenoprotein [mRNAs](../glossary#mRNA). [Spermatogenesis](../glossary#spermatogenesis) and male fertility are highly dependent on GPx4 and selenoprotein P (SEPP1; see [below](#selenoprotein-P)). The [thyroid](../glossary#thyroid) gland releases very small amounts of biologically active thyroid [hormone](../glossary#hormone) (triiodothyronine or T3) and larger amounts of an inactive form of thyroid hormone (T3 [precursor](../glossary#precursor): thyroxine or T4) into the circulation. Most of the biologically active T3 in the circulation and inside cells is generated by the removal of one [iodine](iodine) atom from T4 in a reaction different and 2) can deiodinate T4, thus increasing circulating T3, while a third iodothyronine deiodinase (DIO type 3) can convert both T3 and T4 to inactive [metabolites](../glossary#metabolite) (Figure 3) [(8)](#reference8). Of note, inactivation of the [genes](../glossary#gene) encoding DIOs in rodent models has revealed a role for DIO type 1 in iodine [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) and the importance of DIOs type 2 and 3 in the maturation of auditory and visual systems during fetal development [(8)](#reference8). Thus the importance of selenium in normal development, growth, and [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) is not limited to its role in the regulation of thyroid gland function. Selenoprotein P (SEPP1) is predominantly produced by the liver, a major storage site for selenium, and secreted in the [plasma](../glossary#plasma). The full-length glycoprotein contains a selenium-rich domain with nine selenocysteine residues, as well as a thioredoxin-like [catalytic](../glossary#catalyze) site with one selenocysteine residue. SEPP1 constitutes the major form of selenium transport to peripheral tissues [(9)](#reference9). SEPP1 also functions as an [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) that protects cells from [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) by enabling full activity of thioredoxin reductases and [glutathione](../glossary#glutathione) peroxidases through adequate extrahepatic tissues (see [Glutathione peroxidases](#glutathione-peroxidases)). SEPP1 appears to be especially critical for selenium [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) in the brain and testes where apolipoprotein E receptor 2 (apoER2) facilitates the uptake of SEPP1. Megalin is another SEPP1-specific re-uptake by the kidneys [(10)](#reference10). Moreover, SEPP1 has been recently implicated in the regulation [glucose](../glossary#glucose) and [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) isoforms (homologues) and is highly conserved across species. In humans, SEPW is expressed in numerous tissues, with highest levels found in skeletal muscle and heart [(12)](#reference12). SEPW contains a selenocysteine residue and a cysteine residue that binds to a [glutathione](../glossary#glutathione) molecule, suggesting a role in [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction) regulation [(13)](#reference13). The expression of SEPW is correlated with selenium status and appears to be sensitive to low-selenium supply [(14, 15)](#reference14). SEPW expression in the brain has been found to confer protection against [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress)-induced [neuronal](../glossary#neuron) cell death [(16)](#reference16). SEPW also appears to a negative regulator for 14-3-3 [proteins](../glossary#protein). Indeed, 14-3-3 inhibition by SEPW in breast cancer cells was found to increase cell [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) and cell survival through increasing resistance to genotoxic stress [(17)](#reference17). In skeletal muscle cells, SEPW was shown to reduce the binding of 14-3-3 to TAZ, allowing TAZ translocation to the [nucleus](../glossary#nucleus) and activation of muscle cell [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation) [genes](../glossary#gene) [(18)](#reference18). Finally, SEPW was found to prevent the degradation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) in breast and prostate epithelial cells in culture. EGFR is constitutively activated in many tumors, and evidence of a role for SEPW in EGFR activation and signaling may help shed light on the relationship between selenium status and cancer risk [(19)](#reference19). There is no free pool of the [amino acid](../glossary#amino-acid) selenocysteine in cells such that selenocysteine [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) takes place on a specialized tRNA during the [translation](../glossary#translation) of selenoprotein (Figure 4) [(20)](#reference20). synthetase 2 is a selenoenzyme that catalyzes the synthesis of selenophosphate from hydrogen selenide (Figure 4) [(3)](#reference3). The methionine sulfoxide reduction system is involved in the protection against [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) and is especially critical for the regeneration of [proteins](../glossary#protein) damaged by [reactive oxygen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species) (ROS). Indeed, ROS can [oxidize](../glossary#oxidation) [methionine](../glossary#methionine) residues (methionine sulfoxides) within proteins and potentially impair their activities. In humans, two stereospecific families of methionine sulfoxide reductases (MsrA and MsrB) three genes of methionine sulfoxide is reduced by MsrB1, 2, or 3. Only MsrB1 has been characterized as a selenoprotein with one selenocysteine residue in its catalytic site. MsrB1 appears to be involved in the [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction) regulation of certain proteins. In macrophages, reorganization of the actin cytoskeleton necessary for chemotaxis and requires MsrB1-dependent methionine-R-sulfoxide residues within actin [(21)](#reference21). Studies using MSR gene inactivation in mice have also shown that methionine sulfoxide reduction is implicated in the regulation of the methionine cycle (reviewed in [22](#reference22)). Although its function is not known, SEP15 was found to interact with the endoplasmic reticulum UDP-glucose:glycoprotein glucosyltransferase (UGGT), an [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) folding [(24, 25)](#reference24). Because SEP15 has a thioredoxin-like [catalytic](../glossary#catalyze) site, SEP15 is thought to either regulate UGGT activity or the [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction) state of UGGT substrates [(26)](#reference26). Mice lacking a functional SEP15 were found to develop nuclear [cataract](../glossary#cataract) (lens opacification) at a very early age suggesting that SEP15 may be critical to the quality control system of protein folding in the [lens](../glossary#lens) [(27)](#reference27). SEP15 may also be implicated in anticancer mechanisms (reviewed in [28](#reference28)). The mammalian selenoprotein S (known as SEPS1, (ER) membrane [protein](../glossary#protein). SEPS1 is involved in the cellular response to ER stress (ER-associated degradation; ERAD) activated by the detection of misfolded proteins. SEPS1 contributes to the removal and transfer (retrotranslocation) of misfolded proteins from the ER [lumen](../glossary#lumen) to the [cytosol](../glossary#cytosol) where proteins are tagged with ubiquitin before being degraded. A [polymorphism](../glossary#polymorphism) or variation in the sequence within an ER-response element located in the SEPS1 promoter was found to result in reduced SEPS1 promoter activity and [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression) [(29)](#reference29). The polymorphism corresponding to the substitution of a guanine (G) by an adenine (A) at [nucleotide](../glossary#nucleotide) -105 (-105G>A) has been associated with increased plasma levels of pro- [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) [cytokines](../glossary#cytokine). In addition, a [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) recently reported that the A [allele](../glossary#allele) was more [prevalent](../glossary#prevalence) in individuals affected by Hashimoto thyroiditis (HT) — a T-cell-mediated [autoimmune disease](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) resulting in the destruction of thyroid cells — than in healthy controls [(30)](#reference30). Other associations between SEPS1 polymorphism (including -105G>A) and susceptibility to various conditions, such as [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia), [coronary artery disease](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease), or [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) [cancers](../glossary#cancer), strongly suggest a role for this selenoprotein in the regulation of [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) and immune responses [(31-34)](#reference31). Other less well-characterized selenoproteins, which are also localized in the ER lumen and/or membrane, include selenoproteins K, M, N, and T [(35)](#reference35). The importance of selenium to biological systems, and specifically to the cellular [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction) ( [pro-oxidant](../glossary#pro-oxidant)/ [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant)) balance, is derived from its presence as selenocysteine in the [catalytic](../glossary#catalyze) site of selenoproteins (see [Function](#function)). Other [minerals](../glossary#mineral) that are in synergy with the antioxidant vitamins, [vitamin C](../vitamins/vitamin-C) (ascorbic acid) and [vitamin E](../vitamins/vitamin-E) (-tocopherol), by regenerating them from their oxidized forms and promoting maximal antioxidant protection [(36-38)](#reference36). While [iodine](iodine) is [hormones](../glossary#hormone), the selenium-containing iodothyronine deiodinases (DIOs) are [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) the conversion of thyroxine (T4) to the biologically active thyroid hormone, triiodothyronine (T3) (see [Function](#function)). DIO1 activity may also be regulating iodine [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) [(39)](#reference39). The selenoenzymes, glutathione peroxidases, also play a critical role in thyroid function because they [catalyze](../glossary#catalyze) the degradation of peroxides generated during thyroid hormone [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) [(8)](#reference8). The epidemiology of coexisting iodine and selenium deficiencies in central Africa, but not in China, has been linked to the [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of myxedematous [cretinism](../glossary#cretinism), a severe form of [congenital hypothyroidism](../glossary#congenital-hypothyroidism) accompanied by mental and physical retardation. Selenium deficiency may be only one of several undetermined factors that might exacerbate the detrimental effects of iodine deficiency [(40)](#reference40). Interestingly, selenium deficiency in rodents was found to have little impact on DIO activities as it appears that selenium is being supplied in priority for adequate synthesis of DIOs at the expense of other selenoenzymes [(8)](#reference8). Insufficient selenium intake may negatively affect the activity (MsrB1). Even when severe, isolated selenium deficiency does not usually result in obvious clinical illness. Yet, compared to subjects with adequate selenium status, selenium-deficient individuals might be more susceptible to additional physiological stresses [(41)](#reference41). Prolonged selenium deficiency may likely contribute to Keshan and Kashin-Beck diseases (see [below](#Keshan-disease)). Selenium deficiency has been reported in chronically ill patients who were receiving [total parenteral nutrition](../glossary#total-parenteral-nutrition) (TPN) without added selenium for prolonged periods of time. Muscular weakness, muscle wasting, and [cardiomyopathy](../glossary#cardiomyopathy) ( [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) and damage to the heart muscle) have been observed in these patients. Nowadays, TPN solutions are routinely [supplemented](../glossary#supplement) with selenium. The risk of selenium deficiency may be increased following bariatric surgery or in severe [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) conditions, such as [Crohn's disease](../glossary#crohn-disease). Some specialized medical diets like those used to treat certain metabolic disorders, including [phenylketonuria](../glossary#phenylketonuria), homocystinuria, and maple syrup urine disease, need to be supplemented with selenium to ensure optimum selenium status in patients [(42)](#reference42). Keshan disease is a fatal form of dilated [cardiomyopathy](../glossary#cardiomyopathy) that was first described in young women and children in a selenium-deficient region in China. The [acute](../glossary#acute) form of the disease is characterized by the sudden onset of cardiac insufficiency, while the chronic form results in moderate-to-severe heart enlargement with varying degrees of cardiac insufficiency [(43)](#reference43). The incidence of Keshan disease is closely associated with very low dietary intakes of selenium and poor selenium nutritional status. Selenium supplementation (in the form of sodium selenite; Na2SeO3) was found to protect people from developing Keshan disease but could not reverse heart muscle damage once it had occurred [(43)](#reference43). A recent [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) reported that selenium-responsive glutathione peroxidase 1 (GPx1) activity was significantly lower in Keshan patients compared to healthy individuals. Interestingly, a specific GPX1 [polymorphism](../glossary#polymorphism) resulting in a proline-to-leucine transition at position 198 (Pro198Leu) is associated with a reduction in GPx1 activity and found to be more [prevalent](../glossary#prevalence) in Keshan patients. This GPX1 polymorphism might confer a greater susceptibility to Keshan disease in carriers with low selenium nutritional status [(44)](#reference44). While selenium deficiency is a major etiological factor of Keshan disease, the seasonal and annual variation in disease occurrence suggested that other factors, especially an infectious agent, might be involved in addition to selenium deficiency [(45)](#reference45). Coxsackie [virus](../glossary#virus) B3 is one virus type that has been isolated from Keshan patients, and animal studies have shown that this virus was capable of causing an [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) of the heart ( [myocarditis](../glossary#myocarditis)) in selenium-deficient mice. Studies in mice also indicated that [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) induced by selenium deficiency could result in changes in the viral [genome](../glossary#genome), such as to convert a relatively harmless strain of coxsackie virus B3 into a myocarditis-causing strain [(43)](#reference43). Although not proven in Keshan disease, it is possible that selenium deficiency may increase the [virulence](../glossary#virulent) of viruses with the potential to invade and damage the heart muscle [(46)](#reference46). Kashin-Beck disease (KBD) is another endemic condition that affects an estimated 2.5 million people in Tibet, northern and central China, North Korea, and southeastern Siberia [(47)](#reference47). KBD is characterized by the degeneration of articular [cartilage](../glossary#cartilage) between joints ( [osteoarthritis](../glossary#osteoarthritis)) that can result in joint deformities and dwarfism in the most severe forms of the disease. The disease affects children as young as two years old. As with Keshan disease, KBD is [prevalent](../glossary#prevalence) in selenium-deficient provinces and thus generally affects people with very low selenium intakes [(47)](#reference47). Recent studies have suggested that increased susceptibility to KBD in selenium-deficient populations might result from a reduced [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) protection associated with [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) in GPX [genes](../glossary#gene) [(48, 49)](#reference48). the [etiology](../glossary#etiology) be [multifactorial](../glossary#multifactorial), as a number of other causative factors have been suggested for KBD, including fungal toxins in grain, [iodine](iodine) deficiency, and contaminated drinking water [(43)](#reference43). Recent [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of a few small trials and [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have indicated that improving selenium nutritional status in children living in endemic areas may help reduce KBD incidence [(50)](#reference50). Also, there is limited evidence to suggest that selenium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) could be useful in the treatment of patients with KBD. A meta-analysis of 10 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) reported a significant increase in the repairing rate of bone lesions in KBD children supplemented with sodium selenite for at least one year [(51)](#reference51). Larger trials of higher quality are needed to assess whether selenium supplementation could result in disease remission. The dietary reference intakes ( [DRIs](../glossary#DRI)) for selenium were last revised in 2000 by the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the US Institute of Medicine. The most recent [RDA](../glossary#RDA) is based on the estimated average requirement ( [EAR](../glossary#EAR)) needed to Of note, the third National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES III) reported that over 99% of the US participants had serum selenium concentrations consistent with selenium requirements being met [(52)](#reference52), suggesting selenium supplementation is not needed for Americans. There has been considerable research on the effect of selenium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) on the incidence of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) in animals. More than two-thirds of over 100 published studies in 20 different animal models of spontaneous, [viral](../glossary#virus), and chemically induced cancers found that selenium supplementation (to at least adequate intake levels) significantly reduces tumor incidence, especially in comparison to selenium-deficient diets [(53)](#reference53). Evidence of cancer-inhibiting effects of selenium has provided a strong rationale for investigating potential associations between selenium intake and cancer [risk](../glossary#risk) in humans. Most of the early [epidemiological evidence](../glossary#epidemiological-study) from [case-control](../glossary#case-control-study) and [nested case-control studies](../glossary#nested-case-control-study) suggested either null or inverse between selenium exposure and [risk](../glossary#risk) of site-specific [cancers](../glossary#cancer) [(54)](#reference54). Markers of selenium exposure include toenail and selenium content, as well as [plasma](../glossary#plasma) glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activity. However, it is not clear whether they adequately reflect selenium exposure from dietary and supplemental sources (see [Sources](#sources)) or selenium distribution in tissues and organs that may be affected by cancer. In the Danish Prospective Diet, Cancer, and Health prospective study that followed over 57,000 men and women for 14 years, the risk of [rectal](../glossary#rectum) cancer was found to be 42% higher in current smokers compared to nonsmokers. No difference between smokers and nonsmokers regarding supplemental and dietary intakes of [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) [micronutrients](../glossary#micronutrient), including selenium, was found to contribute to the association of smoking and rectal cancer [(55)](#reference55). Yet, because studies have consistently reported lower blood selenium concentrations and GPx activities in smokers compared to nonsmokers (reviewed in [56](#reference56)), estimation of selenium intakes might not be a reliable marker of selenium exposure in this population. Also, the chemical forms of selenium found in food are varied (see [Sources](#sources)) and may have very different biological and toxicological effects [(57, 58)](#reference57). A recent Cochrane review included 55 completed [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) — mostly with a nested case-control design — published over three decades [(54)](#reference54). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 16 of these observational studies, including over 144,000 individuals, reported that higher versus lower selenium status was associated with a 31% lower risk of cancer at any site and a 40% lower risk of cancer-related mortality. A significantly lower risk was reported for bladder cancer (5 studies) and [prostate](../glossary#prostate) cancer (17 studies); however, higher selenium status was not inversely associated with risks of breast cancer (8 studies), lung cancer (12 studies), [colorectal cancer](../glossary#colorectal-cancer) (5 studies), and [gastric](../glossary#gastric) cancer (5 studies) [(54)](#reference54). Another meta-analysis of 16 observational studies reported an inverse relationship between breast cancer and serum selenium concentrations [(59)](#reference59). Gender differences in cancer susceptibility have been reported in some studies, although consistent evidence of different effects in men and women appears to be lacking. Single [nucleotide](../glossary#nucleotide) variations ( [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism)) in the sequence of [genes](../glossary#gene) can modify [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression) level and the stability and activity of the [synthesized](../glossary#synthesis) [proteins](../glossary#protein). For example, a proline-to-leucine transition caused by a specific polymorphism in the GPX1 gene (rs1050450 C>T) is associated with reduced GPx1 [enzymatic](../glossary#enzyme) activity. The description of several polymorphisms in genes encoding selenoproteins has led to evaluation of possible associations with selenium status and cancer incidence. Notably, certain polymorphisms in genes coding for selenoproteins have been associated with increased risks of gastric and [colorectal cancers](../glossary#colorectal-cancer) (reviewed in [60](#reference60)). Additionally, a number of studies have investigated the effect of selenoprotein polymorphisms on the relationship between selenium status and prostate cancer risk. A nested case-control study within the EPIC-Heidelberg cohort has combined genotyping for several selenoprotein variants with markers of selenium status [(61)](#reference61). Briefly, the study showed that a GPX1 gene polymorphism (rs1050450 C>T) affected the association between selenium concentrations and prostate cancer risk. Specifically, selenium concentrations were found to be inversely associated with prostate cancer risk only among carriers of the GPX1 T allele. Additional variants in selenoprotein genes may mitigate the effect of selenium status on the risk of prostate cancer [(62, 63)](#reference62). In another nested case-control study within the Physicians' Health Study (PHS), individuals in the highest versus lowest [quartile](../glossary#quartile) of selenium concentrations were found to have a reduced risk of prostate cancer-related mortality except if carrying a specific variant in 15kDa selenoprotein gene (SEP15 rs561104 G>A) [(64)](#reference64). More research is needed to further unravel the mechanisms underlying the influence of gene-diet interactions on the risk of developing cancer. Community-based studies: A very early [intervention study](../glossary#intervention-trial) of selenium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) was undertaken in China among a general population of 130,471 individuals living in a high- [risk](../glossary#risk) area for [viral](../glossary#virus) [hepatitis](../glossary#hepatitis) B infection and liver cancer. The trial provided table salt enriched with sodium selenite to the population of one township (20,847 people) using four other townships as controls. During an eight-year follow-up period, the average incidence of liver cancer was reduced by 35% in the selenium-supplemented population, while no reduction was found in the control populations. In a [clinical trial](../glossary#clinical-trial) in the same region, 226 individuals with evidence of chronic hepatitis B infection were supplemented daily with either 200 g of selenium in the form of a selenium-enriched yeast tablet or a [placebo](../glossary#placebo) yeast tablet. During the 4-year follow-up period, 7 out of 113 individuals on the placebo developed primary liver cancer, while none of the 113 subjects supplemented with selenium developed liver cancer [(65)](#reference65). Randomized controlled trials: The [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled Nutritional Prevention of Cancer (NPC) study in 1,312 older adults with a history of nonmelanoma skin cancer found that supplementation with 200 g/day of selenium-enriched yeast (selenized yeast) for an average of 7.4 years resulted in a 52% decrease in prostate cancer incidence in men (reviewed in [66](#reference66)). The protective effect of selenium supplementation was greatest in men with lower baseline [plasma](../glossary#plasma) selenium and [prostate-specific antigen](../glossary#prostate-specific-antigen) (PSA) levels. A reduced incidence in lung, colorectal, and total cancer was also associated with supplementation with 200 g/day [(67)](#reference67) but not with 400 g/day of selenium-enriched yeast [(68)](#reference68). Besides, selenium supplementation increased the risk of one type of skin cancer (squamous cell carcinoma) by 25%. A larger [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), placebo-controlled intervention trial (the SELECT study) in more than 35,000 middle-aged and selenium-replete men, randomized to receive selenium (in of selenomethionine, 200 g/day) and/or [vitamin E](../vitamins/vitamin-E) supplementation, was halted because of concerns regarding an increased risk of type 2 diabetes with selenium and increased risk of prostate cancer with vitamin E [(69, 70)](#reference69). In addition, the supplementation of selenium, alone or together with vitamin E, did not show any benefits regarding the risk of prostate, lung, or colorectal cancers after 5.5 years of follow-up [(71, 72)](#reference71). Outcomes from other smaller trials (reviewed in [66](#reference66)) also suggested either a lack of an effect or the possibility of an increased risk of cancer. The lack of a beneficial effect of selenium supplementation was supported in a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) [(54)](#reference54). Theoretically, the maintenance of an optimal selenium status has the potential to protect against oxidative stress (including [lipid peroxidation](../glossary#lipid-peroxidation)) and could eventually prevent chronic [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) and [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) disorders. Yet, analyses of [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) data from 13,887 US adults included in the Third National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES III, 1988-1994) failed to show any significant associations between serum selenium concentrations and individuals with [renal](../glossary#renal) insufficiency are at higher risk of developing CAD compared to those with normal kidney function, that risk was not found to be greater with low rather than normal selenium concentrations in serum (98 ng/mL vs. >98 ng/mL) [(75)](#reference75). cross-sectional study based on NHANES 2003-2004 data from 2,638 participants ages 40 years and over found that the risk of high blood pressure ( [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension)), a major contributing factor for CVD, was 73% higher in individuals in the upper versus lowest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of [serum](../glossary#serum) selenium concentrations (150 Yet, a recent [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) of the literature failed to find enough evidence to support any relationship between serum selenium concentrations and hypertension [(77)](#reference77). Besides, a few [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have also reported associations between normal-to-high selenium status and elevated serum [lipid](../glossary#lipid) levels in selenium- [replete](../glossary#replete) populations, speculating that selenium might interfere with lipid [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) and adversely affect cardiovascular health [(78, 79)](#reference78). At present, [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have not provided consistent results regarding the effect of selenium supplementation on lipid levels nor have they demonstrated any additional cardiovascular benefits of selenium in individuals with suboptimal or optimal selenium intakes [(80)](#reference80). Selenium deficiency has been associated with impaired immunity and chronic [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) [(81)](#reference81). A considerable amount of research conducted in cell culture and animal models indicates that selenium plays essential roles in regulating the migration, [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation), [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation), activation, and optimal function of immune cells, thus influencing innate immunity, B-cell dependent [antibody](../glossary#antibody) production, and T-cell immunity (reviewed in [82](#reference82)). Recent evidence on the role of selenium and selenoproteins in the production of [lipid](../glossary#lipid) mediators (called [eicosanoids](../glossary#eicosanoid)) involved in inflammatory responses suggests that selenium supplementation might mitigate dysfunctional inflammatory responses that contribute to the pathogenesis of many chronic health conditions [(83)](#reference83). At present, [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) are needed to evaluate the potential benefits of selenium supplementation in inflammatory disorders, such as [asthma](../glossary#asthma) [(84)](#reference84) and [inflammatory bowel disease](../glossary#inflammatory-bowel-disease) [(85)](#reference85). In areas of widespread malnutrition, deficiencies in [micronutrients](../glossary#micronutrient) (including selenium) are common in individuals infected by the human immunodeficiency virus ( [HIV](../glossary#HIV)) that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome ( [AIDS](../glossary#AIDS)). Before antiretroviral therapy (ART) became the standard for HIV treatment, [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) had consistently reported associations between low [serum](../glossary#serum) selenium concentrations and HIV infection in well-nourished subjects [(86)](#reference86). Poor selenium status has been linked to increased [risks](../glossary#risk) of dilated [cardiomyopathy](../glossary#cardiomyopathy) and mortality in HIV-infected children and adults, as well as mother-to-child HIV transmission and perinatal mortality (reviewed in [87](#reference87). Early laboratory studies have suggested that HIV might disrupt normal [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) defenses in infected T-cells by reducing the levels of selenoproteins, i.e., thioredoxine glutathione [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) found that HIV-seropositive individuals receiving ART for more than two years had undetectable [plasma](../glossary#plasma) [viral](../glossary#virus) loads, higher CD4 [lymphocyte](../glossary#lymphocyte) concentrations compared ART-naïve subjects [(88)](#reference88). Because the antioxidant activity of selenoproteins may interfere with viral replication in HIV-infected immune cells [(89,90)](#reference89), it has been suggested that selenium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) might serve as a potential [adjunct](../glossary#adjunct) to ART for HIV patients. A few trials of selenium supplementation in HIV-infected individuals have been conducted. A [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 186 HIV-positive adults initially found that selenium supplementation at 200 g/day for two years significantly decreased the rate of hospital admissions [(91)](#reference91). Another randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in 174 HIV-positive individuals reported that 200 g/day of selenium supplementation (in the form of selenium-enriched yeast) for nine months increased serum selenium concentrations, improved CD4 lymphocyte T-cell count, and prevented any progression of the HIV viral load [(92)](#reference92). In a third double-blind trial in Tanzania, 913 pregnant women between 12 and 27 weeks' gestation were randomized to receive 200 g/day of selenium (as selenomethionine) or a placebo until six months after birth. Selenium supplementation had no effect on maternal CD4, CD8, and CD3 T-cell counts and on HIV viral load, but it significantly decreased the risk of acute or persistent diarrhea [(93, 94)](#reference93). In addition, the risk of death between six weeks and six months postpartum was significantly reduced in infants of mothers supplemented with selenium compared to placebo [(94)](#reference94). A recent four-armed trial in Botswana randomized 878 HIV-positive adults at an early stage of the infection to receive either a placebo treatment, multivitamins (vitamins B, C, and E), 200 g/day of selenium, or both multivitamins and selenium for 24 months [(95)](#reference95). Unlike selenium alone, supplementation with multivitamins (with or without selenium) reduced the risk of immune decline by significantly increasing the time before ART initiation became necessary (i.e., when CD4 T-cell count fell below 251 cells/mcL) compared to placebo. In the study, a combined outcome of (1) CD4 T-cell count falling below 251 cells/mcL; (2) occurrence of AIDS-defining conditions; and (3) AIDS-related death — whichever happened first — was used to evaluate disease progression in the different arms of treatment. Compared to placebo, there was a longer period of time from randomization to the date of the composite outcome in individuals supplemented with multivitamins plus selenium, but not in those who received multivitamins or selenium alone [(95)](#reference95). More research is needed to replicate these preliminary results, especially in settings and communities where malnutrition hastens the progression of HIV infection and access to antiretroviral therapy may be limited. The systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) results from a systemic [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) response that can be due to an infection (sepsis) [(96)](#reference96). Severe sepsis and septic shock — defined as persistent sepsis-induced low blood pressure — are associated with elevated mortality rates in critically ill patients [(96, 97)](#reference96). Because systemic inflammatory responses involve excessive [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress), it has been suggested that providing [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) nutrients like selenium may improve the outcome of critically ill patients in intensive care units. Two recent [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found that [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) selenium supplementation (as sodium selenite) in critically ill patients with SIRS, sepsis, or septic shock resulted in significantly reducing the risk of mortality by 17% to 27% [(98, 99)](#reference98). More trials are needed to identify the appropriate schedule of selenium administration (in terms of dose, route, and treatment duration) and to assess additional outcomes (e.g., infectious complications and length of hospital stay). Hashimoto thyroiditis (HT; chronic autoimmune thyroiditis) is an [autoimmune disease](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) characterized T-cell infiltration in the [thyroid gland](../glossary#thyroid) and circulating autoantibodies (predominantly raised against thyroid peroxidase), causing prolonged [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), tissue damage, and hypothyroidism [(8)](#reference8). While the function of the thyroid gland of healthy individuals is usually protected from variations in selenium supply, selenium deficiency and genetic [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) affecting the activity of selenoproteins might be potential contributing factors to autoimmune thyroid diseases. A recent [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) [(100)](#reference100) identified four [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) that evaluated the effect of selenium supplementation as an [adjunct](../glossary#adjunct) treatment to T4 replacement therapy (levothyroxine) in HT patients [(101-104)](#reference101). While three out of four studies suggested a reduction in levels of circulating autoantibodies, none of them provided information on whether selenium may improve mood- and health-related symptoms to allow for a decreased dosage of levothyroxine. Another randomized controlled trial found that selenium supplementation improved the well being of patients affected by another autoimmune thyroid disease leading to hyperthyroidism (Graves disease) [(105)](#reference105). The results of two ongoing, randomized, placebo-controlled trials — the CATALYST in HT patients and the GRASS trial in patients with Graves disease — may provide insight into an effect of selenium on thyroid-specific quality-of-life criteria and inform clinical decision making [(106, 107)](#reference106). The richest food sources of selenium are organ meats and seafood, followed by muscle meats. Drinking water is not considered to be a significant source of selenium in North America. However, in areas, where high levels of selenium in soil contribute to the selenium content of the water, higher levels of selenium may be found in wells used for drinking water [(108)](#reference108). In general, there is wide variation in the selenium content of plants and grains, especially because some plants, including garlic, Brazil nuts, and multiple Brassica species, tend to accumulate selenium ('selenium accumulators'), while other assimilate selenium to a lesser extent ('non-accumulators'). The assimilation of selenium by plants also depends on soil selenium content. Brazil nuts grown in areas of Brazil with selenium-rich soil may provide more than 100 g of selenium in one nut, while those grown in selenium-poor soil provide 10 times less [(109)](#reference109). In the US, grains are a good source of selenium, but fruit and vegetables tend to be relatively poor in selenium. Various chemical forms (species) of selenium are Although the two latter compounds are predominant in plants of the Allium and Brassicaceae families (which include garlic, onion, and broccoli), wheat, other grains (including Brazil nuts), and soy are rich in selenomethionine and contain smaller amounts of selenocysteine and selenate. Less is known about selenium species and distribution in dietary sources of animal origin. Animal nutrition and growth conditions certainly contribute to the selenium species formed and their relative quantities, and it is assumed that the metabolic pathway of dietary selenium in animals is similar to that in humans. Selenocysteine is predominantly formed in animals fed inorganic selenium, while selenomethionine is derived from dietary sources of plant origin (reviewed in [110](#reference110)). In the US, the national survey NHANES III reported mean dietary intakes ranging between 100.5 g/day and 158.5 g/day in adults ages 19-50 years [(52)](#reference52). Sodium selenite and sodium selenate are inorganic forms of selenium. Sodium selenate is almost completely absorbed, but a significant amount is [excreted](../glossary#excretion) in the urine before it can be incorporated into [proteins](../glossary#protein). Sodium selenite is only about 50% absorbed but is better retained than selenate once it is absorbed. Selenomethionine is about 90% absorbed [(52)](#reference52); however, only about 34% may then actually be converted to free selenomethionine [(111)](#reference111). Selenomethionine and selenium-enriched yeast, which mainly supply selenomethionine, are also available as supplements. The consumer should be aware that some forms of selenium-enriched yeast on the market contain yeast plus mainly inorganic forms of selenium. Although both inorganic and organic forms of selenium can be metabolized to selenocysteine by the body and incorporated into selenoenzymes, they may not equally contribute to the maintenance of an adequate selenium status. In [intervention trials](../glossary#intervention-trial), supplementation with an organic form of selenium (selenomethionine) more effectively increased blood selenium concentrations compared to supplementation with inorganic forms (i.e., sodium selenite and sodium forms may increase [plasma](../glossary#plasma) glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activity more effectively than organic forms (reviewed in [112](#reference112)). It has also been suggested that the incorporation of selenomethionine in place of [methionine](../glossary#methionine) into tissue [proteins](../glossary#protein) may ensure that selenium is available upon protein turnover [(110)](#reference110). Selenium-enriched foods have been of interest to scientists, especially because of the suggestion that some of the chemical forms of selenium produced by plants might be more potent modifiers of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [risk](../glossary#risk) than those currently available in [supplements](../glossary#supplement). Although there is currently no evidence of long-term health benefits associated with the consumption of selenium-enriched foods, results from animal studies and [intervention trials](../glossary#intervention-trial) suggest that protein-based sources of selenium are more effective at increasing GPx activity than selenium-enriched yeast and selenomethionine [(112)](#reference112). Food [fortification](../glossary#fortification) may also represent a cost-effective strategy to improve selenium nutritional status in populations at risk of inadequacy [(113)](#reference113). Although selenium is required for health, high doses of selenium can be toxic. Acute and fatal toxicities have occurred with accidental or suicidal ingestion of gram quantities of selenium. Clinically significant selenium toxicity was reported in 13 individuals after taking supplements that contained 27.3 mg (27,300 g) per tablet due to a manufacturing error. Chronic selenium toxicity (selenosis) may occur with smaller doses of selenium over long periods of time. The most frequently reported symptoms of selenosis are hair and nail brittleness and loss. Other symptoms may include [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) disturbances, skin rashes, a garlic breath odor, fatigue, irritability, and [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) disorders. In an area of China with a high [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of selenosis, toxic effects occurred with increasing frequency when blood selenium concentrations reached a level corresponding to an intake of 850 g/day. The Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the US Institute of Medicine set the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for selenium at 400 g/day in adults based on the prevention of hair and nail brittleness and loss and early signs of chronic selenium toxicity [(52)](#reference52). In the [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) analysis of NHANES III (1988-1994) data from 8,876 adult participants, the highest versus lowest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of [serum](../glossary#serum) selenium concentrations (137 ng/mL vs. <111 ng/mL) was associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes [(114)](#reference114). Data analyses from 917 participants (40 years of age) of NHANES 2003-2004 also indicated an increased [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of type 2 diabetes in the highest versus lowest [quartile](../glossary#quartile) of serum selenium concentrations (147 ngm/L vs. <124 ng/mL). in the highest versus lowest quartile of serum selenium concentrations also had higher levels of [plasma](../glossary#plasma) glucose and glycated hemoglobin, suggestive of poor The [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in 1,312 participants in the Nutritional Prevention of Cancer (NPC) trial found that selenium supplementation (200 g/day; mean follow-up of 7.7 years) significantly increased the risk for type 2 diabetes in participants in the highest tertile of baseline plasma selenium concentrations [(116)](#reference116). In addition, in the Selenium and Vitamin E Cancer Prevention Trial (SELECT), more cases of type 2 diabetes were found in the selenium group (200 g/day; median follow-up of 5.5 years) than in the placebo group, but this was only a trend and not statistically significant [(72)](#reference72). At present, the mechanisms behind these observations are not well understood. An increase in [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) has been reported in individuals with congenital (inborn) deficiency of most selenoproteins [(117)](#reference117). Results from several animal studies also indicated that selenium [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) and selenoproteins may interfere with [insulin](../glossary#insulin) action and [glucose](../glossary#glucose) [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) (reviewed in [118](#reference118)). On the other hand, recent studies have found that impaired glucose [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) in patients with type 2 diabetes may affect SEPP1 expression and selenium homeostasis [(11](#reference11), [119, 120)](#reference119). While more research is needed to fully understand the interplay between [carbohydrate](../glossary#carbohydrate) metabolism and selenium homeostasis, the use of selenium supplements is considered unlikely to increase the risk of type 2 diabetes in healthy individuals but should be discouraged in those with high selenium status and/or at increased risk for developing type 2 diabetes [(118)](#reference118). At present, few interactions between selenium and medications have been reported [(121)](#reference121). For example, the [anticonvulsant](../glossary#anticonvulsant) drug valproic acid and the chemotherapeutic agent cisplatin may lower circulating selenium concentrations in treated subjects [(122, 123)](#reference122). Also, supplemental sodium selenite was found to reduce the toxicity of the antibiotic nitrofurantoin and the herbicide paraquat in animal studies [(124)](#reference124). A three-year [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 160 patients disease](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease) (CAD) and low high-density-lipoprotein ( [HDL](../glossary#HDL)) of simvastatin (Zocor) and [niacin](../vitamins/niacin) increased HDL2 subfraction levels, inhibited the progression of coronary artery [stenosis](../glossary#stenosis) (narrowing), and decreased the frequency of [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events [(125)](#reference125). Surprisingly, when an [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) combination (1,000 mg of vitamin C, 800 IU of vitamin E (d--tocopherol), 100 g of selenium, and 25 mg of -carotene daily) was taken with the simvastatin-niacin combination, the protective effects were diminished. However, the individual contribution of selenium cannot be established, and other studies have reported that antioxidant vitamins alone could interfere with the action of HDL-raising drugs, including statins [(126)](#reference126). The average American diet is estimated to provide about 100 g/day of selenium, an amount that is well above the current [RDA](../glossary#RDA) (55 g/day) and appears sufficient to optimize [plasma](../glossary#plasma) and cellular glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activity. A recent 10-week [randomized controlled study](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in healthy British adults (ages, 50-64 years) estimated that about 105 g/day of total selenium intake was required to maximize the plasma concentrations of selenoprotein P (SEPP1), another useful [biomarker](../glossary#biomarker) of selenium status [(127)](#reference127). However, a similar trial in an American cohort with higher baseline plasma selenium concentrations found no effect of selenium supplementation on SEPP1 concentrations [(128)](#reference128). While the in multivitamin/mineral (MVM) [supplements](../glossary#supplement) varies considerably, MVM supplements rarely provide more than the Daily Value ( [DV](../glossary#DV)) of 70 g. Eating a varied diet and taking a daily MVM supplement should provide sufficient selenium for most people in the US and help improve selenium status in populations with lower selenium intakes outside the US. At present, the effect of selenium supplementation on [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [risk](../glossary#risk) is not clear enough to support a general recommendation for an extra selenium [supplement](../glossary#supplement), especially in men with serum selenium concentrations consistent with adequate selenium intakes. The SELECT trial found that 200 g/day of selenium did not reduce the risk of [prostate](../glossary#prostate) cancer [(72)](#reference72), refuting the results of the NPC trial (see [Cancer](#cancer-prevention)). Another recent multicenter, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial (the Negative Biopsy Trial) in 699 men at high risk of prostate cancer found no effect of either 200 g/day or 400 g/day of selenium on prostate cancer risk during a mean follow-up of 36 months [(129)](#reference129). In addition, because current evidence suggests a U-shaped relationship between selenium status and prostate cancer risk [(130)](#reference130), men should avoid taking supplemental selenium that would exceed 200 g/day. At present, there is no clinical evidence showing that selenium supplementation above recommended levels decreases the risk of breast cancer although some, but not all, [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have found an inverse relationship between selenium status and breast cancer in women [(59)](#reference59).
