Total body sodium in an average 70-kg person is of about 4,200 mmol (~100 g), of which 40% is found in bone and 60% in the fluid inside and outside of cells [(1)](#references). Total body chloride averages 2,310 mmol (~82 g), of which 70% is distributed in the [extracellular fluid](../glossary#extracellular-fluid) and the remaining is found in the [collagen](../glossary#collagen) of connective tissue [(1)](#references). Multiple mechanisms work in concert to tightly regulate the body's sodium and chloride concentrations. Although this review emphasizes the function and requirements of sodium, sodium and chloride [ions](../glossary#ion) work together to control extracellular volume and blood pressure [(1)](#references). Sodium (Na+) and chloride (Cl-) are the principal [ions](../glossary#ion) in the extracellular compartment, which includes blood [plasma](../glossary#plasma), interstitial fluid (fluid between cells), and transcellular fluid (e.g., [cerebrospinal fluid](../glossary#cerebrospinal-fluid), joint fluid). As such, they play critical roles in a number of life-sustaining processes. Sodium and chloride are [electrolytes](../glossary#electrolytes) that contribute to the maintenance of concentration and charge differences across [cell membranes](../glossary#cell-membrane). [Potassium](potassium) (K+) is the principal positively charged [ion](../glossary#ion) ( [cation](../glossary#cation)) inside of cells, while sodium is the principal cation in [extracellular fluid](../glossary#extracellular-fluid). Potassium concentrations are about 30 times higher inside than outside cells, while sodium concentrations are more than 10 times lower inside than outside cells. The concentration differences between potassium and sodium across cell membranes create an electrochemical gradient known as the [membrane potential](../glossary#membrane-potential). A cell's membrane potential is maintained by ion pumps in the cell membrane, especially the Na+/K+ ATPase pumps. These pumps use [ATP](../glossary#ATP) (energy) to pump sodium out of the cell in exchange for potassium (Figure 1). Their activity has been estimated to account for 20%-40% of the resting energy expenditure in a typical adult. The large proportion of energy dedicated to maintaining sodium/potassium concentration gradients emphasizes the importance of this function in sustaining life. Tight control of cell membrane potential is critical for [nerve impulse](../glossary#nerve-impulse) transmission, muscle contraction, and cardiac function [(2-4)](#reference2). Absorption of sodium in the [small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine) plays an important role in the absorption of chloride, [amino acids](../glossary#amino-acid), [glucose](../glossary#glucose), and water. Similar mechanisms are involved in the reabsorption of these nutrients after they have been filtered from the blood by the kidneys. Chloride, in the form of hydrochloric acid (HCl), is also an important component of [gastric](../glossary#gastric) juice, which aids the digestion and absorption of many nutrients [(5)](#reference5). Because sodium is the primary determinant of [extracellular fluid](../glossary#extracellular-fluid) volume, including blood volume, a number of physiological mechanisms that regulate blood volume and blood pressure work by adjusting the body's sodium content. In the circulatory system, pressure receptors (baroreceptors) sense changes in blood pressure and send excitatory or inhibitory signals to the nervous system and/or [endocrine](../glossary#endocrine-system) glands to affect sodium regulation by the kidneys. In general, sodium retention results in water retention, and sodium loss results in water loss [(6)](#reference6). Below are descriptions of three mechanisms contributing to a larger multifactorial [homeostatic](../glossary#homeostasis) control system that governs blood volume and blood pressure through regulation of sodium balance. These regulatory mechanisms are especially important for the control of sodium transport in various segments of the nephron (basic structural unit of the kidney), including the proximal and distal convoluted tubules, the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, and the collecting duct. In response to a significant decrease in blood volume or pressure (e.g., serious blood loss or dehydration), the kidneys release renin into the circulation. Renin is an [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) that splits a small [peptide](../glossary#peptide) (angiotensin I) from a larger [protein](../glossary#protein) (angiotensinogen) produced by the liver. Angiotensin I is split into a smaller peptide (angiotensin II) by angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE), an enzyme present on the inner surface of blood vessels and in the lungs, liver, and kidneys. Angiotensin II stimulates the constriction of small arteries, resulting in increased blood pressure. Angiotensin II is also a potent stimulator of aldosterone [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) by the [adrenal glands](../glossary#adrenal-glands). Aldosterone is a [steroid](../glossary#steroid) [hormone](../glossary#hormone) that acts on the kidneys to increase the reabsorption of sodium and the [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of [potassium](potassium). Retention of sodium by the kidneys increases the retention of water, resulting in increased blood volume and blood pressure [(7)](#reference7). Secretion of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH; by the posterior [pituitary gland](../glossary#pituitary-gland) is stimulated by a significant decrease in blood volume or pressure. In conjunction with the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, ADH stimulates epithelial sodium channels nephron distal increase the reabsorption of sodium and water [(8)](#reference8). Dopamine is produced from L-DOPA in the kidney proximal tubules and acts on dopamine [receptors](../glossary#receptor) distributed along the proximal tubules and the thick ascending limbs of the loop of Henle to regulate sodium transport. Dopamine promotes sodium [excretion](../glossary#excretion) (natriuresis) by inhibiting the effect of (ANP), which is muscle cells into the circulation [(9)](#reference9). Hyponatremia, defined as a [serum](../glossary#serum) sodium concentration ([Na+]) <136 mmol/liter (mM), may result from increased fluid retention (dilutional hyponatremia) or increased sodium loss. Inadequate sodium intakes rarely result in hyponatremia, even in those on very low-salt diets, because the kidneys increase the [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of water in order to maintain serum osmolality (i.e., [electrolyte](../glossary#electrolytes)-water balance). The results of the 1999-2004 US National Health And Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) indicated an overall [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of hyponatremia of 1.9% in a US population representative sample of 14,697 participants aged 18 and older [(10)](#reference10). Hyponatremia was found to be more prevalent among older individuals (3.1% in those aged 65 to 84 years) and in those suffering from (2.9%) [(10)](#reference10). Hyponatremia is also common in hospitalized patients, with an estimated 15%-30% having mild hyponatremia (serum [Na+]: inappropriate anti-diuretic [hormone](../glossary#hormone) (ADH) secretion, which is associated with disorders affecting the [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system), and with use of certain drugs (see [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions-deficiency)). In some cases, excessive water intake may also lead to dilutional hyponatremia (see also [Exercise-associated hyponatremia](#exercise-associated-hyponatremia)). Conditions that increase the loss of sodium and chloride include severe or prolonged vomiting or diarrhea, excessive and persistent sweating, the use of some [diuretics](../glossary#diuretic), and some forms of kidney disease. Too severe restriction of dietary sodium intake in [renal](../glossary#renal) patients with [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure) and [congestive heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure) might also result in harmful body depletion of sodium [(1)](#references). Exercise-associated hyponatremia (EAH) is dilutional hyponatremia occurring in individuals competing in endurance (up to 6 h in duration) and ultra-endurance (>6 h in duration) exercise events, such as marathons, Ironman triathlons, mountain bike races, hiker treks, and open-water ultra-distance swimming events. Of note, symptomatic EAH has been increasingly reported in shorter events, such as half-marathons and sprint triathlons. The development of hyponatremia during or up to 24 h after intense and/or sustained physical activity has been linked to fluid overload due to excessive water intakes, impaired urinary water [excretion](../glossary#excretion) due to persistent ADH secretion, and very low or very high ambient temperature [(12)](#reference12). Risk factors include pre-exercise hyperhydration, use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and prolonged exercise (>4 h) (reviewed in [12](#reference12)). Symptoms of hyponatremia include headache, nausea, vomiting, muscle cramps, fatigue, disorientation, and fainting. Complications of severe and rapidly developing hyponatremia may include cerebral [edema](../glossary#edema) (swelling of the brain), seizures, coma, and brain damage. Acute or severe hyponatremia may be fatal without prompt and appropriate medical treatment [(13)](#reference13). Chronic mild hyponatremia has been associated with deficits in gait and attention, falls, and bone loss and [fractures](../glossary#fracture), especially in women and the elderly [(14, 15)](#reference14). Excessive intakes of sodium chloride lead to an increase in [extracellular fluid](../glossary#extracellular-fluid) volume as water is pulled from cells to maintain normal sodium concentrations outside of cells. However, as long as water needs can be met, normally functioning kidneys can [excrete](../glossary#excretion) the excess sodium and restore the system to normal [(1)](#references). Ingestion of large amounts of salt may lead to nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal cramps [(25)](#reference25). Hypernatremia, defined as [serum](../glossary#serum) sodium concentrations ([Na+]) >145 mM, is much less common than hyponatremia and rarely caused by excessive sodium intake (e.g., from the ingestion of large amounts of seawater or [intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) infusion of concentrated saline solution) [(26)](#reference26). Hypernatremia generally develops from excess water loss (e.g., burns, respiratory infections, [renal](../glossary#renal) loss, osmotic diarrhea, [hypothalamic](../glossary#hypothalamus) disorders) or reduced water intake, frequently accompanied by an impaired thirst mechanism [(6)](#reference6). Symptoms of hypernatremia with evidence of dehydration from excessive water loss may include dizziness or fainting, low blood pressure, and diminished urine production. Severe hypernatremia ([Na+] >158 mM) may result in altered mental status, lethargy, irritability, stupor, convulsions, and coma. Acute brain shrinkage can lead to intracranial and subarachnoid [hemorrhage](../glossary#hemorrhage) [(26)](#reference26). The Dietary Reference Intakes ( [DRIs](../glossary#DRI)) for sodium were recently revised by the Food and Nutrition Board of the National Academy of Medicine [(20)](#reference20). Using a new expanded DRI model, the National Academy of Medicine did not find sufficient evidence of adverse toxicological effects of excessive sodium intake; therefore, they did not establish a tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for sodium [(20)](#reference20). Normal blood pressure is defined by a [systolic blood pressure](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) below 120 [mm Hg](../glossary#mm-Hg) and a [diastolic blood pressure](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) below 80 mm Hg, often noted <120/80 mm Hg [(27)](#reference27). Currently, about one-third of US adults have [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure) (blood pressure levels 140/90 mm Hg), and another one-third have elevated blood pressure (prehypertension, corresponding to levels 120/80 mm Hg and <140/90 mm Hg) that places them at [risk](../glossary#risk) for hypertension [(28)](#reference28). Chronic hypertension damages the heart, blood vessels, and kidneys, thereby increasing the risk of heart disease and [stroke](../health-disease/stroke), as well as hypertensive kidney disease. In a number of [clinical studies](../glossary#clinical-trial), salt intake has been significantly correlated with [left ventricular hypertrophy](../glossary#left-ventricular-hypertrophy), an abnormal thickening of the heart muscle, which is associated with increased mortality from [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) [(29)](#reference29). Several lines of research, conducted over the last decades, have provided evidence of a relationship between sodium consumption and health outcomes. For instance, [observational](../glossary#observational-study) [cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), like the well-designed International Study of Salt and Blood Pressure (INTERSALT), have associated excess sodium intake with a progressive increase of blood pressure with age [(30, 31)](#reference30). Further, a number of [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial), including the Trial of Nonpharmacologic Interventions in the Elderly (TONE), Trials Of Hypertension Prevention (TOHP), and Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH)-sodium, have demonstrated that dietary sodium reduction could effectively prevent or improve hypertension among population subgroups at elevated risk (see [Blood pressure clinical trials](#blood-pressure-clninical-trials)). Salt sensitivity: Blood pressure responses to short-term changes in sodium intake are [heterogeneous](../glossary#heterogeneity). Indeed, some individuals have little-to-no change in blood pressure in response to sodium manipulation and are identified as "salt-resistant." In contrast, individuals who experience a greater change in blood pressure following dietary sodium manipulation are labeled "salt sensitive" [(32, 33)](#reference32). Most of the protocols used in salt sensitivity studies involve extreme manipulations of sodium intake (sodium loading and sodium depletion) over a short timespan of a few days or up to one week. A typical controlled [isocaloric](../glossary#isocaloric) intervention may include a two-phase, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [cross-over](../glossary#cross-over-trial) seven-day dietary sodium manipulation with a high-sodium diet (6.9 to 8.1 g/day) and a very-low-sodium diet (0.5 g/day). Salt resistance is often defined as a change of 5 mm Hg in 24-h mean arterial pressure (MAP) between a high-sodium diet and a low-sodium diet. Conversely, salt sensitivity is defined by changes of >5 mm Hg in MAP between high- and low-sodium diets [(34)](#reference34). About 26% of [normotensive](../glossary#normotensive) and 51% of [hypertensive](../glossary#hypertension) individuals are estimated to be salt sensitive [(35)](#reference35). Salt sensitivity among normotensive subjects has been found to predict future [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure) [(36, 37)](#reference36). Long-term [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) also provided substantial evidence suggesting that sensitivity to salt may be an independent risk factor for [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) (reviewed in [38](#reference38)). Salt sensitivity involves greater sodium reabsorption in the kidney proximal tubules and higher [glomerular](../glossary#glomerulus) filtration rate (GFR) on a high-sodium diet than salt resistance. The rise in blood pressure is thought to compensate high sodium and fluid retention by triggering increased [renal](../glossary#renal) [excretion](../glossary#excretion). Conversely, salt resistance is associated with adequate excretion of excess sodium such that consumption of large amounts of sodium does not markedly increase blood pressure [(1)](#references). Earlier observations suggested that certain subgroups of the population, including African Americans, older individuals (>45 years), and hypertensive patients, tended to have greater average blood pressure responses to changes in sodium intake [(38)](#reference38). Nevertheless, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found marginal ethnic differences in blood pressure response to sodium reduction (for at least one week) compared to previously reported data [(39)](#reference39). Research examining a genetic basis for salt sensitivity may eventually lead to better and reliable classification of individuals for salt sensitivity. Yet, at present, the analyses of common variations (known as [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism)) in the sequence of specific [genes](../glossary#gene) involved in sodium retention by the kidney failed to show consistent results (reviewed in [40](#reference40)). A recent meta-analysis of nine [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) failed to show significant associations between specific gene polymorphisms in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and blood pressure response to salt [(41)](#reference41). Other polymorphisms in genes like those coding for G-protein coupled receptor kinase type 4 (GRK4), epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) and regulators, or -adducin may favor sodium retention by the kidney, hence predisposing to blood pressure sensitivity to salt (reviewed in [40](#reference40)). Finally, in addition to genetic predispositions, factors like diet quality (e.g., [the DASH diet](#blood-pressure-clninical-trials)) and body weight probably influence blood pressure sensitivity to salt [(38)](#reference38). [Blood pressure clinical trials: Of particular importance are the results of long-term multicenter trials that are the most relevant to clinical and public health practice, i.e., TONE ] [(42)](#reference42), TOHP [(43)](#reference43), and DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension)-sodium. TONE showed that modest reduction in sodium intake by about 1.0 g/day (~2.5 g/day of salt) resulted in a better control of [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension) in older adults who initially were on blood pressure medication [(42)](#reference42). TOHP-Phase II (the second of two hypertension prevention trials) showed that a similar level of sodium reduction significantly reduced [systolic](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) (but not [diastolic](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure)) blood pressure by 1.2 mm Hg in overweight participants with prehypertension after three years and limited the onset of hypertension by 18% after four years compared to usual care (no dietary intervention) [(43, 44)](#reference43). Adherence to the DASH diet, which emphasizes fruit, vegetables, whole grains, poultry, fish, nuts, and low-fat dairy products, was found to substantially lower systolic/diastolic blood pressures by 11.4/5.5 mm Hg in hypertensive and 3.5/2.1 mm Hg in normotensive people compared to a typical US diet [(45)](#reference45). The DASH diet is also markedly higher in [potassium](potassium) and [calcium](calcium), modestly higher in protein, and lower in total fat, [saturated fat](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid), [cholesterol](../health-disease/cholesterol), red meat, sweets, and sugar-containing beverages than the typical US diet. The DASH-sodium trial compared the DASH diet to a typical US (control) diet at three levels of sodium intake: low (1.5 g/day, current AI), intermediate (2.3 g/day, recommended as an upper level by US dietary guidelines), and high (3.2 g/day, typical US intake) levels [(46)](#reference46). At each level of sodium intake, systolic and diastolic blood pressures were systematically lower in (pre)hypertensive people (blood pressure >120/80 mm Hg) consuming the DASH diet compared to the control diet. Reduction of sodium intake also significantly reduced blood pressure in hypertensive consumers of either the DASH diet or the typical US diet. Yet, in prehypertensive participants, the blood pressure-lowering effect of sodium reduction was only significant in those consuming the typical US diet; sodium reduction failed to reduce blood pressure in all prehypertensive participants assigned to the DASH diet, with the exception of African Americans. Compared to the high-salt control diet, average blood pressure in (pre)hypertensive participants on the low-sodium DASH diet was decreased by 8.9/4.5 mm Hg. Results of the DASH trials support the idea that sodium reduction in the context of a healthful dietary pattern offers an effective approach to the prevention and treatment of hypertension [(47)](#reference47). A majority of [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have examined the effect of dietary sodium reduction on blood pressure in (pre)hypertensive rather than in normotensive (normal blood pressure) people. A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) assessed the results of modest sodium reduction from 22 trials in 990 participants with hypertension (blood pressure 140/90 mm Hg) and 12 trials in 2,240 participants without hypertension (blood pressure <140/90 mm Hg). A modest sodium reduction by 1.8 g/day (equivalent to 4.4 g/day of salt; based on 24-hour urinary sodium [excretions](../glossary#excretion)) for at least four weeks decreased systolic and diastolic blood pressure by an average of 5.4/2.8 mm Hg in subjects with hypertension and 2.4/1.0 mm Hg in those without hypertension [(48)](#reference48). Another pooled analysis of eight [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) demonstrated a dose-response relationship between sodium reduction (by 1.8 to 3.2 g/day) and blood pressure in subjects with blood pressure over 130/80, but there was no such relationship in subjects whose blood pressure was below 130/80 [(49)](#reference49). The 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans concurred with the 2013 American Heart Association (AHA)/American College of Cardiology (ACC) Guideline to recommend that individuals who would benefit from blood pressure lowering, particularly prehypertensive and hypertensive adults, should follow the DASH eating pattern to lower sodium intakes [(50)](#reference50). Recommendations include sodium intakes of no more than 2.4 g/day, further sodium intake reduction to 1.5 g/day for an even greater blood pressure-lowering effect, or a reduction is sodium intake of at least 1 g/day if sodium intakes of 1.5 g/day or 2.4 g/day cannot be achieved [(50, 51)](#reference50). More information about the DASH diet is available from the [National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) of the National Institutes of Health (NIH)](https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health-topics/dash-eating-plan). Early studies in animals and humans reported that high-salt intake was associated with [pathological](../glossary#pathology) alterations in the structure and function of large elastic arteries, independent of changes in blood pressure (reviewed in [52](#reference52)). [Endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) dysfunction is considered to be an early step in the development of [atherosclerosis](../health-disease/atherosclerosis). Alterations in the structure and function of the [vascular endothelium](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) that lines the inner surface of all blood vessels are associated with the loss of normal [nitric oxide](../glossary#nitric-oxide) (NO)-mediated endothelium-dependent [vasodilation](../glossary#vasodilation). Endothelial dysfunction results The measurement of brachial artery flow-mediated dilation (FMD) is often used as a marker of endothelial function; FMD values are [inversely correlated](../glossary#inverse-association) with the [risk](../glossary#risk) of future [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events [(53)](#reference53). The link between sodium intake and [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) has traditionally involved [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure). Yet, recent investigations in salt-resistant normotensive individuals have reported that dietary sodium loading could impair endothelial function independent of changes in blood pressure [(54, 55)](#reference54). A study using controlled dietary sodium conditions also demonstrated that a high-sodium diet (6.9 g/day for one week) reduced brachial artery FMD to the same extent in salt-sensitive and salt-resistant normotensive participants [(56)](#reference56). On the other hand, a three-week dietary sodium intake of 3 g following a baseline intake of 2.4 g/day of sodium did not lower FMD in 36 untreated (pre)hypertensive adults with baseline FMD values significantly lower than those usually observed in healthy normotensive subjects [(57)](#reference57). Circulating markers of endothelial function and low-grade inflammation were unchanged; only urinary sodium and [systolic blood pressure](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) increased [(57)](#reference57). In healthy normotensive adults in whom FMD significantly decreased following a meal containing 1.5 g of sodium, [potassium](potassium) supplementation (1.5 g) could limit high sodium-induced FMD reduction normotensive subjects, a diet containing 2.3 g/day reduced FMD after two days and for six weeks, compared to a diet containing 3.5 g/day [(60)](#reference60). In another randomized, cross-over, [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial, dietary sodium restriction (1.2 g/day vs. 3.5 g/day) for five weeks significantly lowered systolic (but not [diastolic](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure)) blood pressure by 12 [mm Hg](../glossary#mm-Hg) and increased FMD by 68% in 17 (pre)hypertensive subjects (mean age, 62 years) [(61)](#reference61). The improvements in both blood pressure and endothelial function suggest that sodium restriction has a strong potential for reducing CVD risk by preserving the vasculature. A high dietary sodium intake is a [risk](../glossary#risk) factor for [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease). A pooled analysis of 13 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) in 177,025 participants followed for 3 to 17 years found greater risks of [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) (+17%) and [stroke](../health-disease/stroke) (+23%) with an average difference of 2 g of sodium (5 g of salt) between higher and lower daily consumption across the studies [(62)](#reference62). Higher sodium intakes were also found to be associated with an increased risk of stroke (+24%) — but not with the risk of cardiovascular disease or [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) — in a more recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 10 prospective cohort studies and randomized controlled trials [(63)](#reference63). A meta-analysis of [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) examined the effect of dietary sodium reduction on cardiovascular events and mortality [(64)](#reference64). Dietary interventions aiming at reducing sodium intake failed to demonstrate an effect on all-cause mortality in [hypertensive](../glossary#hypertension) and non-hypertensive individuals. Current evidence also fails to support a decrease in cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in patients with hypertension [(64)](#reference64). Likewise, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)-sponsored 2013 report on Sodium Intake in Populations by the US Institute of Medicine (IOM; renamed the National Academy of Medicine) indicated that evidence was scarce and of poor quality to assess whether sodium intakes below 2.3 g/day may lower the risk of heart disease, stroke, and all-cause mortality in the general US population [(65)](#reference65). In addition, the IOM committee found no evidence of benefits but some evidence of potential harm in reducing sodium intakes to 1.5 g/day-2.3 g/day in individuals with [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), kidney disease, or cardiovascular disease [(65)](#reference65). However, in a recent review of the literature, the US Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) identified low strength evidence to suggest that sodium reduction could decrease the risk of a composite measure of cardiovascular outcomes (seven trials) and the risk of combined cardiovascular morbidity and mortality (eight trials) [(66)](#reference66). In the evidence-based report, Food, Nutrition, Physical Activity, and the Prevention of Cancer (2007), the World Cancer Research Fund/American Institute for Cancer Research concluded that salt was a probable cause of stomach [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [(67)](#reference67). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of seven [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) in nearly 270,000 participants showed a 68% greater [risk](../glossary#risk) of [gastric](../glossary#gastric) cancer with the highest versus lowest salt intake level [(68)](#reference68). Findings from [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study), conducted mainly in Asian countries, also suggested an increased risk of gastric cancer with high intakes of salted foods, pickled foods, and processed meat products [(68-70)](#reference68). Low intakes of [fruit and vegetables](../food-beverages/fruit-vegetables), which are protective against gastric cancer, in populations with high intakes of salted foods might also contribute to increasing the risk of gastric cancer [(69, 71)](#reference69). Animal studies suggested that high concentrations of salt may damage the cells lining the stomach, potentially increasing the risk of [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) infection by Helicobacter pylori [(72, 73)](#reference72) and cancer-promoting genetic damage [(74)](#reference74). The colonization by H. pylori is a recognized risk factor for gastric cancer. [Case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) examining the potential interaction between salt intake and H. pylori infection in the risk of gastric cancer have provided mixed results [(75-78)](#reference75). Although there is little evidence that salt itself is a [carcinogen](../glossary#carcinogen), high intakes of salted foods may increase the risk of gastric cancer in individuals infected with H. pylori or exposed to gastric carcinogens [(67)](#reference67). Salty foods, like processed meat, cured meat, and salted fish, contain high levels of nitrosated compounds that may contribute to increasing the risk of gastric cancer [(67)](#reference67). [Osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis) is a multifactorial skeletal disorder in which bone strength is compromised, resulting in an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [fracture](../glossary#fracture). Nutrition is one of many factors contributing to the development and progression of osteoporosis. Dietary sodium is a major determinant of urinary [calcium](calcium) loss [(79)](#reference79). High-sodium intake results in increased loss of calcium in the urine, possibly due to competition between sodium and calcium for reabsorption in the kidneys or by an effect of sodium on parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion (see the article on [Calcium](calcium)). Every 1-g increment in sodium (2.5 g of salt) [excreted](../glossary#excretion) by the kidneys has been found to draw about 26.3 mg of calcium into the urine [(79)](#reference79). A study conducted in adolescent girls reported that a high-salt diet had a greater effect on urinary sodium and calcium excretion in White compared to Black girls, suggesting differences among ethnic groups [(80)](#reference80). In adult women, each extra gram of sodium consumed per day is projected to produce an additional rate of bone loss of 1% per year if all of the calcium loss comes from the skeleton. A number of [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) and [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) have suggested that high-sodium intakes are deleterious to bone health, especially in older women [(81)](#reference81). In particular, high-sodium intake in conjunction with low-calcium intake may be especially detrimental to bone health [(82-84)](#reference82). A two-year longitudinal study in postmenopausal women found increased urinary sodium excretion (an indicator of increased sodium intake) to be associated with decreased [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) (BMD) at the hip [(85)](#reference85). Linear regression analysis estimated that BMD could be maintained by reducing sodium intake to a level of 2.3 g/day and by increasing calcium intake to 1.2 g/day. A second longitudinal study in postmenopausal women found that habitual sodium intake of approximately 3 g/day was not detrimental to BMD over three years of follow-up [(86)](#reference86). Notably, the average calcium intake in this study population was 1.3 to 1.5 g/day — slightly above the [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for calcium in women over 50 years. Another study in 40 postmenopausal women found that adherence to a low-sodium diet (2 g/day) for six months was associated with significant reductions in sodium excretion, calcium excretion, and aminoterminal propeptide of type I [collagen](../glossary#collagen) (a [biomarker](../glossary#biomarker) of bone [resorption](../glossary#resorption)). Yet, these associations were only observed in women with elevated baseline urinary sodium excretions [(87)](#reference87). Finally, in a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in 60 postmenopausal women, potassium citrate supplementation prevented an increase in calcium excretion induced by the consumption of a high-sodium diet (5 g/day of sodium) for four weeks [(88)](#reference88). Most [kidney stones](../glossary#kidney-stones) are composed of calcium oxalate or calcium phosphate. Subjects with an abnormally high level of calcium in the urine (hypercalciuria) are at higher [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing kidney stones (a process called nephrolithiasis) [(89)](#reference89). A large [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) that followed more than 90,000 women over a 12-year period found that women with a sodium intake averaging 4.9 g/day (12.6 g/day of salt) had a 30% higher risk of developing symptomatic kidney stones than women whose sodium intake averaged 1.5 g/day (3.8 g/day of salt) [(90)](#reference90). Because urinary calcium [excretion](../glossary#excretion) is increased by high sodium intakes [(79)](#reference79), dietary sodium restriction may reduce the risk of stone formation, especially in patients with a history of kidney stones, by limiting calcium excretion [(91)](#reference91). A five-year, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) [intervention study](../glossary#intervention-trial) that enrolled 120 men with idiopathic hypercalciuria (mean age, 45 years) reported that those assigned to a normal-to-high calcium (1.2 g/day) and low-sodium diet (1.2 g/day) had a 49% reduced risk of kidney stone recurrence compared to those on a low-calcium diet (~0.4 g/day) [(92)](#reference92). In 2004, the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the National Academy of Medicine (formerly, the Institute of Medicine [IOM]) established a tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) of 2.3 g/day sodium (5.8 g/day of salt) for adults based on the adverse effects of high sodium intakes on blood pressure, a major [risk](../glossary#risk) factor for [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) and kidney diseases [(93)](#reference93). The 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans report also recognizes that excess sodium consumption poses potential health risks and emphasizes the reduction of sodium intake in the context of a healthful dietary pattern, following the UL set by the IOM panel [(50)](#reference50). In a 2019 update of the Dietary Reference Intakes ( [DRIs](../glossary#DRI)) for sodium, the National Academy of Medicine made use of a new expanded DRI model [(20)](#reference20). As a consequence, only evidence of a toxicological risk associated with excessive sodium intakes was considered to establish a UL for sodium [(20)](#reference20), whereas previously the UL for sodium was based on evidence of any type of adverse effects [(93)](#reference93). In addition, the evidence of the relationship between sodium intake levels, blood pressure, and cardiovascular disease — considered toward establishing a UL in the previous report — has now been reviewed to establish a new DRI category, namely the Chronic Disease Risk Reduction Intake (CDRR) for sodium [(20)](#reference20). Using the expanded DRI model, the National Academy of Medicine did not find sufficient evidence of adverse toxicological effects to establish a UL for sodium [(20)](#reference20). In contrast, substantial evidence from trials showing a lowering of the risks of hypertension and cardiovascular disease with reduction of sodium intakes was used to set a CDRR for sodium in apparently healthy adults at 2,300 mg/day [(20)](#reference20). The CDRR for healthy adults means that a lowering of usual sodium intakes to at least 2,300 mg/day from higher levels is expected to reduce the risk of [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease). The CDRR values for other ages/life stages have been extrapolated from the CDRR value set for adults using estimated energy requirements; these CDRR-based recommendations for each age/life stage are older||Reduce intakes if above 2,300 mg/day| |*Extrapolated from the adult CDRR using estimated energy requirements.| Of note, in its 2013 report on Sodium Intake in Populations, the FNB committee considered that recommendations to population subgroups, including those who are most sensitive to the blood pressure effects of sodium, like older people (51 years), African Americans, and individuals with [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension), [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), or chronic kidney disease, should be similar to those for the general US population [(65)](#reference65). The IOM committee found no supportive evidence to recommend that these subgroups lower their sodium intake to 1.5 g/day or below [(65)](#reference65). In contrast, the 2013 American Heart Association (AHA)/American College of Cardiology (ACC) Guideline on Lifestyle Management to Reduce Cardiovascular Risk advises adults with (pre)hypertension to consume no more than 2.4 g/day of sodium, further reduce sodium intake to 1.5 g/day for an even greater blood pressure-lowering effect, or reduce their daily intake by at least 1 g if sodium intakes of 1.5 g/day or 2.4 g/day cannot be achieved [(51)](#reference51). Finally, the 2010 IOM report on Strategies to Reduce Sodium Intake in the United States suggested that the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) revisit the Generally Recognized As Safe (GRAS) status of salt added to processed food, restaurant food, and food additives, in order to reduce the salt content in the food supply and assist in achieving sodium intakes consistent with US Dietary Guidelines and IOM recommendations [(21)](#reference21). These recommendations are currently being reviewed by the FDA [(22)](#reference22). Taking sodium bicarbonate orally may reduce the efficacy of the antibiotic cefpodoxime and the antidiabetic drug chlorpropamide by limiting drug absorption or increasing drug urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion). [Intravenous](../glossary#intravenous) administration of sodium bicarbonate may also reduce the effects of aspirin and the nasal decongestant pseudoephedrine. Excessive intake of sodium bicarbonate may increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of hypokalemia (abnormally low blood [potassium](potassium) concentration) in patients potassium-depleting is strong and consistent evidence that diets relatively low in sodium (2.3 g/day or less) and high in [potassium](potassium) are associated with decreased [risk](../glossary#risk) of high blood pressure and the related risks of [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) and kidney diseases. Moreover, the DASH trial demonstrated that a diet emphasizing [fruit](../food-beverages/fruit-vegetables), [vegetables](../food-beverages/fruit-vegetables), [whole grains](../food-beverages/whole-grains), [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts), and low-fat dairy products substantially lowered blood pressure, an effect that was enhanced by reducing salt intake to 2.3 g/day of sodium (5.8 g/day of salt). The Linus Pauling Institute recommends a diet that is rich in fruit and vegetables (at least 9 servings/day) and limits processed foods that are high in salt. Since sensitivity to the blood pressure-raising effect of salt increases with age, sodium reduction in the context of a healthful dietary pattern may especially benefit older adults, who are at increased risk of high blood pressure, [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease), and kidney disease.
