Contents Zinc is an essential trace element for all forms of life. Clinical zinc deficiency in humans was first described in 1961, when the consumption of diets with low zinc [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) due to high phytate content (see [Food sources](#food-sources)) was associated with "adolescent nutritional dwarfism" in the Middle East [(1)](#references). Since then, zinc insufficiency has been recognized by a number of experts as an important public health issue, especially in low-resource countries [(2, 3)](#reference2). Numerous aspects of cellular [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) are zinc-dependent. Zinc plays important roles in growth and development, immune function, neurotransmission, vision, reproduction, and intestinal [ion](../glossary#ion) transport [(4)](#reference4). Using data mining approaches, it has been estimated that over 3,000 proteins in humans have functional zinc-binding sites [(5)](#reference5). At the cellular level, the function of zinc can be divided into three categories: (1) catalytic, (2) structural, and (3) regulatory [(6)](#reference6). Over 50 different [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) depend on zinc for their ability to [catalyze](../glossary#catalyze) vital chemical reactions [(7)](#reference7). Zinc-dependent enzymes can be found in all six classes of enzymes [(8)](#reference8), as defined by the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology [(9)](#reference9). During enzymatic reactions, zinc may have either a direct catalytic role or a structural role (i.e., stabilizing the structure of catalytic enzymes; see below). Zinc plays an essential role in the folding of some [proteins](../glossary#protein). A finger-like structure, known as a zinc finger motif, stabilizes the structure several proteins. Examples of zinc finger proteins include the superfamily of [nuclear](../glossary#nuclear) [receptors](../glossary#receptor) that bind and respond to [steroids](../glossary#steroid) other and [vitamin A](../vitamins/vitamin-A) [(10)](#reference10). Zinc finger motifs in the structure of nuclear receptors allow them to bind to [DNA](../glossary#DNA) and act as [transcription factors](../glossary#transcription-factor) to regulate [gene](../glossary#gene) expression (see [Regulatory role](#regulatory-function)). Zinc finger motifs are also involved in interactions of proteins with other proteins, [ribonucleotides](../glossary#ribonucleotide), and [lipids](../glossary#lipid) [(6)](#reference6). Removal of zinc from zinc-containing proteins results in protein misfolding and loss of function. Metallothioneins are examples of proteins with a zinc-binding motif. Metallothioneins are small metal-binding cysteine-rich proteins with a high affinity for zinc. They work in concert with zinc transporters, regulating free zinc concentrations in the [cytosol](../glossary#cytosol) [(11)](#reference11). Metallothioneins are also involved in the regulation of metal ion [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis), cellular defense against [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress), and detoxification copper-zinc superoxide is made of two identical [dimers](../glossary#dimer), each including an active site with a catalytic [copper](copper) [ion](../glossary#ion) and a structural zinc ion. Demetalation of SOD1 has been implicated in the formation of amyloid aggregates in some forms of inherited [amyotrophic lateral sclerosis](../glossary#amyotrophic-lateral-sclerosis) (ALS) — a motor [neuron](../glossary#neuron) disease leading to muscle [atrophy](../glossary#atrophy) and paralysis [(13)](#reference13). Zinc finger [proteins](../glossary#protein) have been found to regulate [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression) by acting as [transcription factors](../glossary#transcription-factor) (see above). Zinc also plays a role in [cell signaling](../glossary#cell-signaling) via the metal-response element (MRE)-binding transcription factor 1 (MTF1); MTF1 has a zinc finger domain that allows its binding to MRE sequences in the [promoter](../glossary#promoter) of target [genes](../glossary#gene) and the subsequent expression of zinc-responsive genes [(6)](#reference6). Zinc may also have a direct regulatory function, modulating the activity of cell-signaling [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) and transcription factors [(6)](#reference6). Extracellular zinc can also stimulate a zinc-sensing [receptor](../glossary#receptor) that triggers the release of intracellular calcium, a second messenger in signaling pathways [(14)](#reference14). Zinc has been found to influence [hormone](../glossary#hormone) release (see [Type 2 diabetes mellitus](#type-2-diabetes-mellitus-prevention)) [(15)](#reference15) and [nerve impulse](../glossary#nerve-impulse) transmission [(16)](#reference16). Taking large quantities of zinc (50 mg/day or more) over a period of weeks can interfere with [copper](copper) [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability). High intake of zinc induces the intestinal [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of a copper-binding [protein](../glossary#protein) called metallothionein (see the article on [Copper](copper#nutrient-interactions-zinc)). Metallothionein traps copper within intestinal cells and prevents its systemic absorption (see [Wilson's disease](#Wilson-disease-treatment)). More typical intakes of zinc do not affect copper absorption, and high copper intakes do not affect zinc absorption [(17)](#reference17). [Iron](iron) for absorptive pathways [(18)](#reference18). [Supplemental](../glossary#supplement) (38-65 mg/day of elemental iron) but not dietary levels of iron may decrease zinc absorption [(18, 19)](#reference18). This interaction is of concern in the management of iron supplementation during pregnancy and lactation and has led some experts to recommend zinc supplementation for pregnant and lactating women taking iron supplements [(20, 21)](#reference20). Food [fortification](../glossary#fortification) with iron has not been shown to negatively affect zinc absorption [(22)](#reference22). In a [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study, supplementation with zinc (10 mg/day) for three months in children aged eight to nine years significantly decreased [serum](../glossary#serum) iron concentrations, yet not to the extent of causing [anemia](../glossary#anemia) [(23)](#reference23). Additional [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have reported a worsening of nutritional iron [status](../glossary#status) with chronic zinc supplementation [(24, 25)](#reference24). High levels of dietary [calcium](calcium) impair zinc absorption in animals, but it is uncertain whether this occur in humans [(17)](#reference17). One study showed that increasing the calcium intake of postmenopausal women by 890 mg/day in the form of milk or calcium phosphate (total calcium intake, 1,360 mg/day) reduced zinc absorption and zinc balance in postmenopausal women [(26)](#reference26). However, another study found that increasing the calcium intake of adolescent girls by 1,000 mg/day in the form of calcium citrate malate (total calcium intake, 1,667 mg/day) did not affect zinc absorption or balance [(27)](#reference27). Calcium in combination with phytate might affect zinc absorption, which would be particularly relevant to individuals who very frequently consume tortillas made with lime (i.e., calcium oxide). A study in 10 healthy women (age range, 21-47 years) found that high intake of dietary calcium (~1,800 mg/day) did not impair zinc absorption regardless of the phytate content of the diet [(28)](#reference28). For more information on phytate, see [Food sources](#food-sources). The [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of dietary [folate](../vitamins/folate) (vitamin B9) is increased by the action of a zinc-dependent [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme). Accordingly, some studies found low zinc intake decreased folate absorption. It was also suggested that [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with folic acid — the synthetic form of folate — might impair zinc utilization in individuals with marginal zinc [status](../glossary#status) [(17](#reference17), [29)](#reference29). However, one study reported that supplementation with a relatively high dose of folic acid (800 µg/day) for 25 days did not alter zinc absorption or status in a group of students being fed a low-zinc diet (3.5 mg/day) [(30)](#reference30). Zinc and [vitamin A](../vitamins/vitamin-A) interact in several ways. Zinc is a component of retinol-binding protein, a protein necessary for transporting vitamin A in the blood. Zinc is also required for the [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) that converts retinol (vitamin A) to retinal. This latter form of vitamin A is necessary for the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of rhodopsin, a [protein](../glossary#protein) in the eye that absorbs light and thus is involved in dark adaptation. Zinc deficiency has been associated with a decreased release of vitamin A from the liver, which may contribute to symptoms of night blindness that are seen with zinc deficiency [(31, 32)](#reference31). Much of what is known about severe zinc deficiency was derived from the study of individuals born with [acrodermatitis enteropathica](../glossary#acrodermatitis-enteropathica), a genetic disorder resulting from the impaired uptake and transport of zinc [(33)](#reference33). The symptoms of severe zinc deficiency include the slowing or cessation of growth and development, delayed sexual maturation, characteristic skin rashes, chronic and severe diarrhea, immune system deficiencies, impaired wound healing, diminished appetite, impaired taste sensation, night blindness, swelling and clouding of the [cornea](../glossary#cornea), and behavioral disturbances. Before the cause of acrodermatitis enteropathica was known, patients typically died in infancy. Oral zinc therapy results in the complete remission of symptoms, though it must be maintained indefinitely in individuals with the genetic disorder [(33, 34)](#reference33). It is now recognized that milder zinc deficiency contributes to a number of health problems, especially common in children who live in low-resource countries. An estimated 2 billion people worldwide are affected by dietary zinc deficiency [(3)](#reference3). The lack of a sensitive and specific indicator of marginal zinc deficiency hinders the scientific study of its health implications [(8)](#reference8). However, controlled trials of moderate zinc [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) have demonstrated that marginal zinc deficiency contributes to impaired physical and neuropsychological development and increased susceptibility to life-threatening infections in young children [(34)](#reference34). In fact, zinc deficiency has been estimated to cause more than 450,000 deaths annually in children under five years of age, comprising 4.4% of global childhood deaths [(35)](#reference35). For a more detailed discussion of the relationship of zinc deficiency to health problems, see the section on [Disease Prevention](#disease-prevention). In industrialized countries, dietary zinc deficiency is unlikely to cause severe zinc deficiency in individuals without a genetic disorder, zinc malabsorption or conditions of increased zinc loss, such as severe burns or prolonged diarrhea. Severe zinc deficiency has also been reported in individuals undergoing [total parenteral nutrition](../glossary#total-parenteral-nutrition) without zinc, in those who abuse alcohol, and in those who are taking certain medications like penicillamine (see [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions)) [(36)](#reference36). Currently, there is not a sensitive and specific [biomarker](../glossary#biomarker) to detect zinc deficiency in humans. Low [plasma](../glossary#plasma) or [serum](../glossary#serum) zinc concentrations are typically used as indicators of zinc [status](../glossary#status) in populations and in [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-study), but they have a number of limitations, including lack of sensitivity to detect marginal zinc deficiency, diurnal variations, and [confounding](../glossary#confounder) by [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), stress, and [hormones](../glossary#hormone) [(38, 39)](#reference38). The recommended dietary allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) for zinc is listed by gender and age group in Table 1. Infants, children, adolescents, and pregnant and lactating women are at increased risk of zinc deficiency. Since a sensitive indicator of zinc nutritional [status](../glossary#status) is not readily available, the RDA for zinc is based on a number of different indicators of zinc nutritional status and represents the daily intake likely to prevent deficiency in nearly all individuals in a specific age and gender group [(29)](#reference29). |Life Stage||Age||Males (mg/day)||Females (mg/day)| |Infants||0-6 months|| 2 | Estimates based on national food supply indicate that dietary zinc intake is likely inadequate in most low- and middle-income countries, especially those in Sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia [(40)](#reference40). Inadequate zinc [status](../glossary#status) during pregnancy interferes with fetal development, and preterm neonates from zinc-deficient mothers suffer from growth retardation and [dermatitis](../glossary#dermatitis) and are at [risk](../glossary#risk) of infections, necrotizing enterocolitis, chronic lung disease, and retinopathy of prematurity [(4)](#reference4). Maternal zinc deficiency has also been associated with a number of pregnancy complications and poor outcomes. A recent [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) conducted in an Iranian hospital reported higher odds of [congenital malformations](../glossary#congenital-malformation) in newborns of mothers with low serum zinc concentrations during the last month of pregnancy [(41)](#reference41). A 2016 review of 64 [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) found an [inverse relationship](../glossary#inverse-association) between maternal zinc status and the severity of [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia), as well as between maternal zinc intake and the risk of low-birth-weight newborns [(42)](#reference42). There were no apparent associations between maternal zinc status and the risk of [gestational](../glossary#gestation) [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) and preterm birth. However, the conclusions of this analysis were limited by the fact that most observational studies were conducted in women from populations not at risk for zinc deficiency [(42)](#reference42). To date, available evidence from maternal zinc [intervention trials](../glossary#intervention-trial) conducted worldwide does not support the recommendation of routine zinc supplementation during pregnancy. A 2015 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 21 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in over 17,000 women and their babies found a 14% reduction in premature deliveries with zinc supplementation during pregnancy, mainly in low-income women [(43)](#reference43). This analysis, however, did not find zinc supplementation to benefit other indicators of maternal or infant health, including stillbirth or neonatal death, low birth weight, small-for-gestational age, and pregnancy-induced [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure). There was also no effect of supplemental zinc on postpartum [hemorrhage](../glossary#hemorrhage), maternal infections, congenital malformations, and child development outcomes [(43)](#reference43). A recent review of 17 trials (of which 15 were conducted in low- and middle-income countries) found that maternal supplementation with multiple micronutrients (including, among others, zinc, iron, and folic acid) reduced the risk of low-birth-weight newborns and small-for-gestational age infants when compared to supplemental iron with or without folic acid [(44)](#reference44). While multiple micronutrient supplementation would likely benefit pregnant women with coexisting micronutrient deficiencies in low- and middle-income countries, there is no evidence to recommend zinc supplementation in isolation in pregnant women from any settings [(43, 45)](#reference43). Significant delays in linear growth and weight gain, known as growth retardation or failure to thrive, are common features of mild zinc deficiency in children. In the 1970s and 1980s, several [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled studies of zinc [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) in young children with significant growth delays were conducted in Denver, Colorado. Modest zinc supplementation (5.7 mg/day) resulted in increased growth rates compared to placebo [(46)](#reference46). Several [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of growth data from zinc [intervention trials](../glossary#intervention-trial) have confirmed the widespread occurrence of growth-limiting zinc deficiency in young children, especially in low- and middle-income countries [(47-49)](#reference47). A 2018 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and meta-analysis identified 54 trials that examined the impact of zinc supplementation during infancy (on average, 7.6 mg/day for 30.9 weeks) or childhood (on average, 8.5 mg/day for 38.9 weeks) on child [anthropometric](../glossary#anthropometric) measurements [(50)](#reference50). There was evidence of a positive effect of supplemental zinc on children's height, weight, and weight-for-age Z score (WAZ), but neither on height-for-age Z score (HAZ) or weight-for-height Z score (WHZ). In addition, zinc supplementation did not reduce the risks of underweight (WAZ<-2 standard deviation [SD]), wasting (WHZ<-2 SD), or stunting (HAZ<-2 SD) in children [(50)](#reference50). Although the exact mechanisms for the growth-limiting effect of zinc deficiency are not known, research indicates that zinc availability affects [cell-signaling](../glossary#cell-signaling) systems that coordinate the response to the growth-regulating [hormone](../glossary#hormone), insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) [(51)](#reference51). Adequate nutrition in essential for brain growth and development, especially during the first 1,000 days of life — a critical period of development for all organs and systems spanning from conception to 24 months of age [(52)](#reference52). Animal studies have established that zinc deficiency in early life interferes with normal brain development and [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) functions (reviewed in [53](#reference53)). Data on the effect of zinc [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) during pregnancy on infants' [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) and psychomotor outcomes is very limited. In a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in African-American women, daily maternal supplementation with 25 mg of zinc from about 19 weeks' [gestation](../glossary#gestation) had no effect on neurologic development test scores in their children at five years of age [(54)](#reference54). Several studies have reported on the effect of postnatal zinc supplementation on mental and motor development. Two early [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), one conducted in India and the other in Guatemala, suggested that postnatal supplementation with 10 mg/day of zinc resulted in toddlers being more vigorous [(55)](#reference55) and functionally active [(56)](#reference56). In one trial conducted in Brazilian newborns from low-income families and weighing between 1,500 g and 2,499 g at birth, neither zinc supplementation for eight weeks with 1 mg/day or 5 mg/day improved mental and psychomotor development at 6 or 12 months of age compared to a placebo and assessed using the Bayley Scales of Infant Development (BSID) for Mental Development Index (MDI) and Psychomotor Development Index (PDI) [(57)](#reference57). Additionally, a randomized, placebo-controlled, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind) trial in Chilean newborns (birth weights >2,300 g) from low-income families reported no effect of zinc supplementation (5 mg/day) on mental and psychomotor development indices at 6 and 12 months [(58)](#reference58). Two other trials found that supplemental zinc failed to improve MDI or PDI at 12 months of age when zinc (10 mg/day) was given to six-month-old infants for six months [(59)](#reference59) or at the end of the intervention in toddlers aged 12-18 months when zinc (30 mg/day) was given for four months [(60)](#reference60). A 2012 Cochrane review of eight [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) found no evidence that postnatal zinc supplementation improves mental or motor development of infants and children from populations with presumably inadequate zinc [status](../glossary#status) [(61)](#reference61). Adequate zinc intake is essential in maintaining the integrity of the immune system [(62)](#reference62), specifically for normal development and function of cells that mediate both [innate](../health-disease/immunity#innate-immunity) ( [neutrophils](../glossary#neutrophil), [macrophages](../glossary#macrophage), T-lymphocytes) immune responses [(63)](#reference63). Because [pathogens](../glossary#pathogen) also require zinc to thrive and invade, a well-established [antimicrobial](../glossary#antimicrobial) defense mechanism in the body sequesters free zinc away from microbes [(64)](#reference64). Another opposite mechanism consists in intoxicating intracellular microbes within macrophages with excess zinc [(65)](#reference65). Through weakening innate and adaptive immune responses, zinc deficiency diminishes the capacity of the body to combat pathogens [(63, 64)](#reference63). As a consequence, zinc-deficient individuals experience an increased susceptibility to a variety of infectious agents [(66)](#reference66). Diarrhea: Zinc promotes mucosal resistance to infections by supporting the activity of immune cells and the production of [antibodies](../glossary#antibody) against invading [pathogens](../glossary#pathogen) [(63, 64](#reference63), [67)](#reference67). Therefore, a deficiency in zinc increases the susceptibility to intestinal infections and constitutes a major contributor to diarrheal diseases in children [(66)](#reference66). In turn, persistent diarrhea contributes to zinc deficiency and malnutrition [(66)](#reference66). Research indicates that zinc deficiency may also potentiate the effects of toxins produced by diarrhea-causing bacteria like E. coli [(68)](#reference68). It is estimated that diarrheal diseases are responsible for the deaths of about 500,000 children under five years of age annually in low- and middle-income countries [(69)](#reference69). Zinc [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) in combination with oral rehydration therapy has been shown to significantly reduce the duration and severity of acute and persistent childhood diarrhea and to increase survival in a number of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) [(70)](#reference70). A 2016 meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials found that zinc supplementation reduced the duration of acute diarrhea by one day in children aged >6 months who presented signs of malnutrition (5 trials; 419 children) [(71)](#reference71). However, there was little evidence to suggest that zinc could be as efficacious to reduce the duration of acute diarrheal episodes in children aged <6 months and in well-nourished children aged >6 months. Zinc supplementation also reduced the duration of persistent diarrhea in children by more than half a day (5 trials; 529 children) [(71)](#reference71). The World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) currently recommend supplementing young children with 10 to 20 mg/day of zinc as part of the treatment for acute diarrheal episodes and to prevent further episodes in the two to three months following zinc supplementation [(72)](#reference72). Pneumonia: [Pneumonia](../glossary#pneumonia) — caused by lower respiratory tract viral or bacterial infections (LRTIs) — accounts for nearly 1 million deaths among children annually, primarily in low-and middle-income countries [(69)](#reference69). Vaccinations against Haemophilus influenzae type B, pneumococcus, pertussis (whooping cough), and measles can help prevent pneumonia [(73)](#reference73). According to a 2009 WHO report on disease [risk](../glossary#risk) factors, zinc deficiency may be responsible for 13% of all LRTI cases, primarily pneumonia and flu cases, in children younger than 5 years [(74)](#reference74). Accordingly, a 2016 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of six trials found that zinc supplementation in children under 5 years old reduced the risk of pneumonia by 13% [(75)](#reference75). However, it remains unclear whether supplemental zinc, in conjunction with antibiotic therapy, is beneficial in the treatment of pneumonia. A recent [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial conducted in Gambian children who were not zinc deficient failed to show any benefit of zinc supplementation (10 mg/day or 20 mg/day [depending on child's age] for 7 days) given alongside antibiotics in the treatment of severe pneumonia [(76)](#reference76). A 2018 meta-analysis of five trials (1,822 participants) found no improvement when zinc was used as an [adjunct](../glossary#adjunct) to antibiotic treatment in children with pneumonia [(77)](#reference77). There was, however, evidence that supplemental zinc reduced the risk of pneumonia-related mortality (3 trials; 1,318 participants) [(77)](#reference77). Malaria: Early studies have indicated that zinc supplementation may reduce the incidence of clinical attacks of [malaria](../glossary#malaria) in children [(78)](#reference78). A [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in preschool-aged children in Papua New Guinea found that zinc supplementation reduced the frequency of health center attendance due to Plasmodium falciparum malaria by 38% [(79)](#reference79). Additionally, the number of malaria episodes accompanied by high circulating parasite concentrations was reduced by 68%, suggesting that zinc supplementation may be of benefit in preventing more severe episodes of malaria. However, a six-month trial in more than 700 West African children did not find any difference in the frequency or severity of malaria episodes between children supplemented with zinc and those given a placebo [(80)](#reference80). Another [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) reported that zinc supplementation did not benefit preschool-aged children with acute, uncomplicated malaria [(81)](#reference81). There is also little evidence to suggest that zinc supplementation could reduce the risk of malaria-related mortality in children [(82)](#reference82). At present, there is not enough evidence to suggest a [prophylactic](../glossary#prophylaxis) and/or therapeutic role for supplemental zinc in the management of childhood malaria [(48)](#reference48). A recent randomized, placebo-controlled trial did not provide clear-cut evidence of a protective effect of zinc (25 mg/day) administered to Tanzanian women during their first gestational trimester until delivery on the risk of [placental](../glossary#placenta) malaria infection [(83)](#reference83). Inadequate zinc [status](../glossary#status) in elderly subjects is not uncommon and is thought to exacerbate the age-related decline in immune function [(84)](#reference84). In one study, low [serum](../glossary#serum) zinc concentrations in nursing home residents were associated with higher risks of [pneumonia](../glossary#pnemonia) and pneumonia-related and all-cause mortality [(85)](#reference85). Trials examining the effects of zinc [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) on immune function in middle-aged and elderly adults have given mixed results (reviewed in [86](#reference86)). Some studies showed mixed or no effects of zinc supplementation on parameters of immune function [(87-89)](#reference87). However, zinc supplementation was found to have a positive impact on certain aspects of immune function that are affected by zinc deficiency, such as the decline in T-cell (a type of [lymphocyte](../glossary#lymphocyte)) function [(90)](#reference90). For example, a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-trial), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in adults over 65 years of age found that zinc supplementation (25 mg/day) for three months increased blood concentrations of helper T-cells and cytotoxic T-cells [(91)](#reference91). Additionally, a randomized, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), placebo-controlled trial in 101 older adults (aged 50-70 years) with normal blood zinc concentrations showed that zinc supplementation at 15 mg/day for six months improved the helper T-cells/cytotoxic T-cells ratio, which tends to decline with age and is a predictor of survival [(92)](#reference92). However, the study also suggested that a dose of 30 mg/day of zinc might reduce the number of B-lymphocytes, which play a central role in humoral immunity. Further, zinc supplementation had no effect on various immune parameters, including markers of [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), measures of granulocyte and [monocyte](../glossary#monocyte) [phagocytic](../glossary#phagocytosis) capacity, or [cytokine](../glossary#cytokine) production by activated monocytes [(92)](#reference92). A more recent trial examined the effect of daily supplementation with a multiple [micronutrients](../glossary#micronutrient), including 5 mg or 30 mg of zinc for three months, on zinc status and markers of immune function in institutionalized elderly participants (mean age, >80 years) with low serum zinc concentrations [(93)](#reference93). Zinc status was improved with the 30 mg/day dose — but not with 5 mg/day — yet the most zinc-deficient individuals failed to achieve normal serum zinc concentrations within the intervention period. The number of circulating T-cells was also significantly increased in those who took the micronutrient supplement with the higher versus low dose of zinc [(93)](#reference93). More research is warranted before zinc supplementation could be recommended to older adults, especially those with no symptoms of declining immunity. Nonetheless, the high [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of zinc deficiency among institutionalized elderly adults should be addressed and would likely improve the performance of their immune systems [(86)](#reference86). There is a close relationship between zinc and [insulin](../glossary#insulin) action. Specifically, in [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) -cells, zinc is involved in insulin [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) and storage in secretory vesicles. Zinc is released with the [hormone ](../glossary#hormone)when blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentrations increase [(15)](#reference15). Zinc is also understood to stimulate glucose uptake and [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) by insulin-sensitive tissues through triggering the intracellular insulin [nucleotide](../glossary#nucleotide) [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) (SNPs) SLC30A8 (solute carrier family 30 member 8) [gene](../glossary#gene), coding for a zinc transporter that co-localizes with insulin in -cells, have been associated with higher [risks](../glossary#risk) of type 1 and type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) [(95)](#reference95), though the risk for type 2 diabetes mellitus was found to be reduced with rare protein-truncating variants of the gene [(96)](#reference96). The first [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) to examine the risk of type 2 diabetes in relation to zinc intakes — the Nurses' Health Study (NHS) — followed 82,297 US registered female nurses for 24 years. The data analysis showed an 8% lower risk of type 2 diabetes with the highest versus lowest intake of dietary zinc (median values, 11.8 mg/day versus 4.9 mg/day) [(97)](#reference97). This finding was consistent with the result of the Australian Longitudinal Study on Women's Health (ALSWH) that enrolled 8,921 women for six years and showed a 50% lower risk of diabetes with the highest versus lowest intake of energy-adjusted dietary zinc [(98)](#reference98). Both NHS and ALSWH studies also reported a reduced risk of diabetes with higher versus lower zinc-to- [heme](../glossary#heme) iron ratios in the diet [(97, 98)](#reference97), although the significance is unclear as nonheme iron, rather than heme iron, is known to interfere with dietary zinc absorption (see [Nutrient interactions](#nutrient-interactions)). Heme iron may be an indicator of red meat consumption, which has been positively associated with the risk of type 2 diabetes [(99)](#reference99). However, two other prospective cohort studies — the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA; 4,982 participants) and the National Institutes of Health-American Association of Retired Persons (NIH-AARP) Diet and Health Study (232,007 participants) — failed to find evidence for an association between zinc intake and risk of type 2 diabetes [(100, 101)](#reference100). Another recent prospective cohort study, the Malmo Diet and Cancer Study in 26,132 middle-aged Swedish participants followed for 19 years, found an increased risk of diabetes with higher dietary zinc intakes yet a lower risk of diabetes in zinc supplement users (versus non-users) and in those with a higher zinc-to-iron intake ratio [(102)](#reference102). The authors reported a stronger [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between zinc-to-iron intake ratio and risk of diabetes among obese participants carrying a specific SLC30A8 [genotype](../glossary#genotype) [(102)](#reference102). The results of a few short-term [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) suggest that zinc supplementation may improve glucose handling in subjects with prediabetes. A 2015 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) identified three short trials (4 to 12 weeks) conducted in adults with prediabetes and found little evidence of an improvement in [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance) with zinc supplementation [(103)](#reference103). However, a 2016 randomized, [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 55 Bangladeshi with prediabetes showed that daily supplementation with zinc sulfate (30 mg/day for 6 months) improved fasting blood glucose, as well as measures of -cell function and [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) [(104)](#reference104). Similar observations were made in another recent trial in 100 Sri Lankan randomized to receive daily supplementation with zinc (20 mg of elemental zinc) or a placebo for one year [(105)](#reference105). Supplemental zinc improved zinc [status](../glossary#status) and measures of glycemic control [(105)](#reference105). Large-scale, long-term studies are necessary to provide definite conclusions regarding the potential benefit of zinc supplementation in subjects at risk of type 2 diabetes. Doses of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) zinc in many of the below-mentioned [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) exceeded the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)). Such high intake of supplemental zinc may lead to adverse health effects with prolonged use (see [Safety](#safety)). The protein, ATP7B, is responsible for the [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of [hepatic](../glossary#hepatic) [copper](copper) into the [biliary](../glossary#bile) tract, and its impairment in Wilson's disease results in an increased concentration of 'free' copper (i.e., not bound to the copper-carrying protein, [ceruloplasmin](../glossary#ceruloplasmin)) in blood, an increased excretion of copper in the urine (hypercupriuria), the deposition of copper in part of the [cornea](../glossary#cornea) (forming Kayser-Fleischer rings), and the accumulation of copper in the liver and brain [(106)](#reference106). This inherited condition is progressive and fatal if untreated. The standard-of-care for symptomatic patients usually includes an initial phase (around 2-6 months) of copper [chelation](../glossary#chelate) with agents, such as penicillamine or trientine (triethylenetetramine), followed by lifelong maintenance therapy with penicillamine and/or trientine and/or zinc salts [(107)](#reference107). Patients presenting without symptoms can be treated with maintenance therapeutic doses of a chelating agent or with zinc [(108)](#reference108). Zinc-induced metallothionein in the intestinal mucosa binds copper and prevents its absorption (see [Nutrient interactions](#nutrient-interactions)). There is growing evidence to suggest that zinc salts are a safer, much cheaper, and efficacious alternative to metal-chelating agents — which have been associated with a worsening of symptoms during the initial phase of treatment in some patients [(109)](#reference109). The use of zinc is advocated as safe and efficacious in both pediatric [(110, 111)](#reference110) and adult patients [(112-114)](#reference112). There is no proven treatment for [common cold](../health-disease/common-cold) [(115)](#reference115). The use of zinc lozenges within 24 hours of the onset of cold symptoms, and continued intake every two to three hours while awake until symptoms resolve, have been advocated for reducing the duration of the common cold [(116)](#reference116). Several [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) examining the effect of zinc have been published to date. A 2012 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 13 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) reported that zinc [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) in the form of lozenges or syrup shortened the duration of cold symptoms, but there was significant [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) (inconsistent effects across the included studies) for the primary outcomes [(117)](#reference117). A 2013 Cochrane review confirmed that oral zinc administrated within 24 hours of symptom onset could reduce the duration of cold symptoms (14 trials, 1,656 participants) [(118)](#reference118). Subgroup analyses also suggested that oral zinc was effective regardless of the age of participants (children or adults) and the type of zinc formulation (gluconate/acetate lozenges or sulfate syrup). In addition, beneficial effects on cold duration were seen in trials that provided more than 75 mg/day of zinc but not in trials that used lower doses. The pooled analysis of five trials found no evidence of an effect of oral zinc on the severity of cold symptoms. The analysis of secondary trial outcomes suggested a faster resolution of specific cold symptoms (cough, nasal congestion, nasal drainage, sore throat) and a lower proportion of participants exhibiting cold symptoms after seven days of treatment in zinc- versus [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-supplemented participants [(118)](#reference118). Inconsistent findings among trials have been partly attributed to different amounts of zinc released from various forms used in the lozenges (particularly zinc acetate and zinc gluconate) [(119, 120)](#reference119). It has been argued that the unpleasant taste of zinc gluconate forming complexes with [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) may have led to poor compliance, thereby explaining negative trial results [(119, 121)](#reference119). However, when a meta-analysis was recently conducted on results from seven trials (575 participants) that employed zinc lozenges at doses >75 mg/day, there was no evidence of a difference in efficacy observed between trials that used either zinc acetate (3 trials) or zinc gluconate (4 trials) [(122)](#reference122). With numerous well-controlled trials and meta-analyses, the efficacy of zinc lozenges or syrup in treating common cold symptoms is no longer questionable. A meta-analysis of seven trials recently reported a 33% reduction in the duration of cold symptoms with the intake of zinc lozenges (>75 mg/day of elemental zinc) [(122)](#reference122). However, many supplemental zinc formulations available over-the-counter have been found to release zero zinc ions (i.e., the biologically active form of zinc) or to contain additives (e.g., magnesium, certain [amino acids](../glossary#amino-acid), citric acid) that either cancel out the benefit of zinc or worsen cold symptoms [(119)](#reference119). Finally, although taking zinc lozenges for a cold every two to three hours while awake will result in daily zinc intakes well above the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) of 40 mg/day for adults (see [Safety](#safety)), the use of zinc at daily doses of 50 to 180 mg for one to two weeks has not resulted in serious side effects [(117)](#reference117). Bad taste and nausea were the most frequent adverse effects reported in therapeutic trials [(117)](#reference117). Use of zinc lozenges for prolonged periods (e.g., 6-8 weeks) is likely to result in [copper](copper) deficiency (see [Nutrient interactions](#nutrient-interactions) and [Safety](#safety)). Intranasal zinc preparations, designed to be applied directly to the nasal [epithelium](../glossary#epithelium) (cells lining the nasal passages), are marketed as over-the-counter cold remedies. While two [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials found that intranasal zinc gluconate modestly shortened the duration of cold symptoms [(123, 124)](#reference123), another one found intranasal zinc to be of no benefit [(125)](#reference125). The pooled analysis of these three trials showed no overall benefit of intranasal zinc on the [risk](../glossary#risk) of still experiencing cold symptoms by day 3 [(126)](#reference126). The existence of a mouth-nose biologically close electric circuit (BCEC) has been proposed to explain the efficacy of oral rather than intranasal zinc delivery [(119)](#reference119). Specifically, it is suggested that the positively charged interior of the nose repels [ionic](../glossary#ion) zinc (Zn2+) such that ionic zinc delivered by throat lozenges and migrating from the mouth to the nose are more effective against rhinovirus infection than those directly delivered into the nose [(119)](#reference119). Of serious concern are several [case reports](../glossary#case-report) of individuals experiencing loss of the sense of smell (anosmia) after using intranasal zinc as a cold remedy [(127)](#reference127). Since zinc-associated anosmia may be irreversible, intranasal zinc preparations should be avoided. Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a degenerative disease of the [macula](../glossary#macula) and a leading cause of blindness in people aged >65 years in the US [(128)](#reference128). The macula is the portion of the [retina](../glossary#retina) in the back of the eye involved with central vision. Zinc is [hypothesized](../glossary#hypothesis) to play a role in the development of AMD for several reasons: (1) zinc is found at high concentrations in the part of the retina affected by AMD, (2) retinal zinc content has been shown to decline with age, and (3) the activities of some zinc-dependent retinal enzymes have been shown to decline with age. To date, [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have shown limited evidence suggesting an association between dietary zinc intake and the incidence of AMD [(129-131)](#reference129). However, an early [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) provoked interest when it found that 200 mg/day of zinc sulfate (81 mg/day of elemental zinc) over two years limited the loss of vision in patients with AMD [(132)](#reference132). Yet a later trial using the same dose and duration found no benefit to patients with a more advanced form of AMD in one eye [(133)](#reference133). Small trials have generally not reported a protective effect of [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin) and [mineral](../glossary#mineral) supplementation on AMD [(134, 135)](#reference134). However, a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 74 patients with AMD reported that supplementation with 50 mg/day of zinc monocysteine for six months improved measures of macular function, including visual acuity, contrast sensitivity, and photorecovery [(136)](#reference136). A large randomized, placebo-controlled trial of daily [vitamin C](../vitamins/vitamin-C), 400 IU [vitamin E](../vitamins/vitamin-E), and 15 mg of -carotene) and high-dose zinc (80 mg of zinc as zinc oxide and 2 mg of copper as cupric oxide) — the Age-Related Eye Disease Study (AREDS) — found that administration of high-dose zinc alone or with the antioxidant combination to individuals with signs of moderate-to-severe macular degeneration significantly reduced the [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing advanced macular degeneration over a mean follow-up of 6.3 years [(137)](#reference137). A follow-up analysis conducted four years after the cessation of the trial in 2001, including nearly 85% of the surviving participants, found that the benefit of the AREDS (combined antioxidants plus zinc) formulation had persisted [(138)](#reference138). Indeed, the odds of developing late AMD, especially neovascular AMD, was lower in both participants with a low risk of developing AMD and those who were at risk and recommended to continue taking the AREDS formulation after the trial ended. There was, however, no effect of AREDS formulation on the risk of developing central geographic atrophy [(138)](#reference138). Another trial, AREDS2, examined the effect of an AREDS formulation without -carotene and/or containing 25 mg instead of 80 mg of zinc [(139)](#reference139). The trial showed no apparent difference in the risk of developing advanced AMD with the use of AREDS formulations containing either 25 mg or 80 mg of zinc and/or -carotene [(140)](#reference140). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of five trials (including the original AREDS study) confirmed the protective effect of supplemental zinc against neovascular and advanced AMD [(141)](#reference141). In conclusion, the AREDS formulation combining antioxidants and zinc (25 mg or 80 mg) may delay the progression of the disease in patients with AMD. Patients, especially smokers and those with vascular disease, are advised to discuss with their physician the benefits versus potential harms that could be associated with the long-term use of high-dose antioxidant vitamins and [carotenoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/carotenoids) [(141)](#reference141). Poor glycemic control and frequent urination in patients with [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) may be driving urinary loss of zinc and contribute to marginal zinc deficiency [(142, 143)](#reference142). Yet, because of the role of zinc in -cell function and [insulin](../glossary#insulin) action (see [Disease Prevention](#disease-prevention)), a number of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have examined whether [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with zinc (alone or with other [minerals](../glossary#mineral) and [vitamins](../glossary#vitamin)) could play a role in diabetes management, especially by improving glycemic control in people with type 2 diabetes [(15)](#reference15). Out of the 12 trials that measured participants' zinc [status](../glossary#status) at baseline, supplementation with zinc (20-240 mg/day) for 4 to 16 weeks improved fasting blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) in patients who presented with zinc deficiency (6 studies). Supplemental zinc also reduced the proportion of [glycated hemoglobin](../glossary#glycated-hemoglobin) ( [HbA1c](../glossary#hemoglobin-A1c)) in two trials conducted in zinc-deficient participants, yet not in four studies including participants without zinc deficiency [(15)](#reference15). Patients with type 2 diabetes should ensure that their diet provides enough zinc to cover their needs, especially if their blood glucose is poorly controlled. [Gestational](../glossary#gestation) [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) is defined as [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia) that is first diagnosed during pregnancy. The condition is associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for adverse pregnancy outcomes [(144)](#reference144). A group of investigators in Iran conducted two small [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials to examine the effect of zinc [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) in pregnant women with gestational diabetes. Supplemental zinc (30 mg/day) for six weeks during pregnancy improved zinc [status](../glossary#status), reduced fasting blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose), and improved [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) in women with gestational diabetes but had no impact on pregnancy outcomes, including the need for cesarean section, need for insulin therapy, newborn's birth size and [Apgar scores](../glossary#Apgar-score), or incidence of hyperbilirubinemia [(145, 146)](#reference145). Similar improvements of markers of glycemic control were reported in another placebo-controlled trial that randomized pregnant women with gestational diabetes to receive zinc (4 mg) together with [magnesium](magnesium) (100 mg), [calcium](calcium) (400 mg), and [vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D) (200 IU) twice a day for six weeks [(147)](#reference147). There was also some evidence suggesting that supplemental zinc might help correct other metabolic disorders (e.g., abnormal blood lipid profile) associated with gestational diabetes [(147, 148)](#reference147). Sufficient zinc is essential to maintain immune system function, and [HIV](../glossary#HIV)-infected individuals are particularly susceptible to zinc deficiency. In HIV-infected patients, low [serum](../glossary#serum) zinc concentrations have been associated with disease progression and increased mortality [(149, 150)](#reference149). In one study conducted in [AIDS](../glossary#AIDS) patients, 45 mg/day of zinc for one month resulted in a decreased incidence of opportunistic infections compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(151)](#reference151). A placebo-controlled trial in 231 HIV-positive adults with low zinc [status](../glossary#status) found that zinc [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) (12 mg/day for women and 15 mg/day for men) for 18 months reduced the incidence of immunological failure (defined by a CD4+ count <200 cells/mm3) by 76% and the rate of diarrhea by 60% [(152)](#reference152). A 2011 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) that identified three [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in primarily resource-poor settings concluded that zinc supplementation was safe and efficacious in reducing opportunistic infections in HIV-positive adults [(153)](#reference153). Evidence of benefits of zinc supplementation in HIV-positive pregnant women and children is very limited. In a [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), placebo-controlled trial in Tanzania, the administration of zinc (25 mg/day) to women between 12 and 27 weeks' gestation until six months after delivery failed to reduce maternal viral load or limit mother-to-child HIV transmission [(154)](#reference154). A randomized placebo-controlled trial of zinc supplementation (10 mg/day for 6 months) in 96 HIV-positive children (6 months to 5 years old) in South Africa showed no effect on CD4+ count and viral load [(155)](#reference155). There was evidence showing a reduction in the incidence of watery diarrhea in zinc-supplemented children compared to those taking a placebo, yet no differences in the incidence of [pneumonia](../glossary#pneumonia), ear infection, or upper respiratory tract infection [(155)](#reference155). Another trial in Uganda showed that supplemental zinc in children with severe pneumonia effectively reduced case fatality regardless of children's HIV status [(156)](#reference156). While zinc supplementation during pregnancy and infancy is recommended in populations likely to be zinc deficient [(43](#reference43), [71](#reference71), [75)](#reference75), its use in HIV infection management requires further investigation [(157)](#reference157). Abnormal [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) of trace metals, in particular [copper](copper) and zinc, has been reported in individuals affected by [Alzheimer's disease](../health-disease/alzheimer-disease) — the most common form of [dementia](../glossary#dementia). Specifically, results from [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) have shown higher [serum](../glossary#serum) copper concentrations and lower serum zinc concentrations in people with Alzheimer's disease compared to [cognitively](../glossary#cognitive) healthy controls [(158-160)](#reference158). Based on the utilization of zinc salts in Wilson's disease, it has been proposed that zinc [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) could improve zinc and copper [status](../glossary#status) and limit further cognitive deterioration in individuals with Alzheimer's disease. The use of slow-release zinc acetate (150 mg/day for six months) in a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study of 60 patients with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's disease corrected low zinc status and decreased serum 'free' copper (i.e., unbound to [ceruloplasmin](../glossary#ceruloplasmin)) [(161)](#reference161). Moreover, when a post-hoc analysis was restricted to participants over 70 years of age (N=29), it was found that zinc supplementation prevented the deterioration of [cognition](../glossary#cognition) scores over the trial period [(161)](#reference161). Additional evidence is needed to confirm whether zinc supplementation could play a role in stabilizing cognitive deficits in older adults with dementia. A data analysis of the Boston Area Community Health (BACH) survey, including 3,708 participants (ages, 30-79 years), reported higher odds of depression symptoms in women (but not in men) in the lowest versus highest [quartiles](../glossary#quartile) of total (median values, 8.7 mg/day versus 26.8 mg/day) and dietary (median values, 7.6 mg/day versus 13.1 mg/day) zinc intakes [(162)](#reference162). The possibility that zinc could play a role in preventing or alleviating depression has been explored in two trials conducted by one research group. The data from these trials were analyzed following a per-protocol approach (i.e., restricted to the participants who completed the studies). A preliminary [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 20 subjects (mean age, 43 years) treated for major depression showed that [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with 25 mg/day of zinc reduced depression symptoms at 6 and 12 weeks as assessed by the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) and Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) scores [(163)](#reference163). A second placebo-controlled trial in 60 participants treated with the antidepressant imipramine (Tofranil; 100-200 mg/day) assessed the therapeutic response to supplemental zinc (25 mg/day) using HDRS, BDI, Clinical Global Impression scale (CGI), and Montgomery-Åsberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) scores [(164)](#reference164). Zinc supplementation improved score-based measures of therapeutic response and remission after six weeks but only when the analysis was restricted to participants resistant to imipramine. There was, however, no evidence of an effect of zinc after 12 weeks [(164)](#reference164). Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that causes organ dysfunction as a consequence of a dysregulated host's response to infection [(165)](#reference165). Sepsis is accompanied by changes in zinc [homeostasis ](../glossary#homeostasis)characterized in particular by a decrease in [serum](../glossary#serum) zinc concentration and an increase in liver zinc concentration [(166)](#reference166). These changes in zinc distribution are thought to be part of a host's defense mechanism whereby the host can limit zinc availability to [pathogens](../glossary#pathogen), as well as stimulate the immune system. Such a mechanism has been described for other transition metals, including iron and manganese [(167)](#reference167). However, lower serum zinc concentrations in critically ill patients at high [risk](../glossary#risk) of organ failure have been associated with recurrent sepsis episodes and poorer outcomes [(168, 169)](#reference168). A 2018 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) identified four trials that examined the effect of zinc [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) in newborns with sepsis [(166)](#reference166). Zinc supplementation was found to result in decreased [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) [(170)](#reference170) and better [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) development [(171, 172)](#reference171). Three out of four trials that examined the rate of mortality showed no effect of zinc supplementation [(170](#reference170), [172, 173)](#reference172). Shellfish, beef, and other red meats are rich sources of zinc; [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts) and [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes) are relatively good plant sources of zinc. Zinc [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) (the fraction of zinc retained and used by the body) is relatively high in meat, eggs, and seafood because of the relative absence of compounds that inhibit zinc absorption and the presence of sulfur-containing [amino acids](../glossary#amino-acid) (cysteine and [methionine](../glossary#methionine)) that improve zinc absorption. Zinc in whole-grain products and plant proteins is less [bioavailable](../glossary#bioavailability) due to their relatively high content of phytate, which inhibits zinc absorption [(174)](#reference174). The enzymatic action of yeast reduces the level of phytate in foods; therefore, leavened whole-grain breads have more bioavailable zinc than unleavened whole-grain breads. National dietary surveys in the US estimate that average dietary zinc intake from naturally and [fortified](../glossary#fortification) food is about 12.3 mg/day in adults, with about 12% of the adult population being at risk for inadequate intake [(175)](#reference175). The zinc content of some foods relatively rich in zinc is listed in Table 2 in milligrams (mg). For more information on the nutrient content of is about the size of a deck of cards.| A number of zinc [supplements](../glossary#supplement) are commercially available, including zinc acetate, zinc gluconate, zinc picolinate, and zinc sulfate. Zinc picolinate has been promoted as a more absorbable form of zinc, but few data support this idea in humans. Limited work in animals suggests that increased intestinal absorption of zinc picolinate may be offset by increased elimination [(29)](#reference29). Isolated outbreaks of acute zinc toxicity have occurred as a result of the consumption of food or beverages contaminated with zinc released from galvanized containers. Signs of acute zinc toxicity are abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. Single doses of 225 to 450 mg of zinc usually induce vomiting. Milder [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) distress has been reported at doses of 50 to 150 mg/day of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) zinc. Metal fume fever has been reported after the inhalation of zinc oxide fumes. Specifically, profuse sweating, weakness, and rapid breathing may develop within eight hours of zinc oxide inhalation and persist for 12 to 24 hours after exposure is terminated [(6](#reference6), [29)](#reference29). The major consequence of long-term consumption of excessive zinc is copper deficiency. Total zinc intakes of 60 mg/day (50 mg [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) and 10 mg dietary zinc) for up to 10 weeks have been found to result in signs of copper deficiency [(29)](#reference29). Copper deficiency has also been reported following chronic use of excessive amounts of zinc-containing denture creams (2 tubes per week containing 17-34 mg/g of zinc) [(177)](#reference177). In order to prevent copper deficiency, the US Food and Nutrition Board set the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for adults at 40 mg/day, including dietary and Intranasal zinc is known to cause a loss of the sense of smell (anosmia) in laboratory animals [(178)](#reference178), and there have been several [case reports](../glossary#case-report) of individuals who developed anosmia after using gluconate [(127)](#reference127). Since zinc-associated be irreversible, the use of zinc nasal gels and sprays should be avoided. The use of zinc [supplements](../glossary#supplement) decreases the absorption of certain medications, including cephalexin (Keplex) and penicillamine (Cuprimine, Depen), as well drugs atazanavir (Reyataz) and ritonavir (Norvir) [(179)](#reference179). Concomitant administration of zinc supplements with certain medications like tetracycline and quinolone antibiotics may decrease the absorption of both zinc and the medications, potentially reducing drug efficacy. Taking zinc supplements and these medications at least two hours apart should prevent this interaction. The therapeutic use of metal-chelating agents, such as penicillamine (used to treat copper overload in Wilson's disease) and diethylenetriamine pentaacetate (DTPA; used to treat iron overload), has resulted in severe zinc deficiency. [Anticonvulsant](../glossary#anticonvulsant) drugs, especially sodium valproate, may also precipitate zinc deficiency. Prolonged use of [diuretics](../glossary#diuretic) may increase urinary zinc [excretion](../glossary#excretion), resulting in increased loss of zinc. Because supplemental zinc can lower blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose), those taking anti-diabetic agents are advised to use zinc supplements with caution. The [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for zinc (8 mg/day for adult women and 11 mg/day for adult men) appears sufficient to prevent deficiency in most individuals, but the lack of sensitive indicators of zinc nutritional status in humans makes it difficult to determine the level of zinc intake most likely to promote optimum health. Following the Linus Pauling Institute recommendation to take a multivitamin/mineral supplement will generally provide at least the RDA for zinc. Daily total (supplemental + dietary) intakes of zinc should not exceed the [UL](../glossary#UL) (40 mg/day for adults) in order to limit the risk of copper deficiency in particular (see [Safety](#safety)). Although the requirement for zinc is not known to be higher for older adults, many have inadequate dietary zinc intakes [(180, 181)](#reference180). A reduced capacity to absorb zinc, increased likelihood of disease states that alter zinc utilization, and increased use of drugs that decrease zinc [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) may all contribute to an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of mild zinc deficiency in older adults. Adequate dietary intake of zinc is essential for older adults because the consequences of mild zinc deficiency, such as impaired immune system function, are especially relevant to maintenance of their health. Select a nutrient from the list for more information. Contents Although choline is not by strict definition a [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin), it is an essential nutrient. Despite the fact that humans can [synthesize](../glossary#synthesis) it in small amounts, choline must be consumed in the diet to maintain health. The majority of the body's choline is found in specialized fat molecules known as [phospholipids](../glossary#phospholipid), the most common of which is called phosphatidylcholine [(1)](#references). Choline and compounds derived from choline (i.e., [metabolites](../glossary#metabolite)) serve a number of vital biological functions (Figure 1) [(1)](#references). Choline is used in the [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) of certain [phospholipids](../glossary#phospholipid) (phosphatidylcholine and sphingomyelin) that are essential structural components of [cell membranes](../glossary#cell-membrane). Phosphatidylcholine accounts for about 95% of total choline in tissues [(2)](#reference2). This phospholipid can be synthesized from dietary choline via the cytidine diphosphocholine (CDP-choline) pathway or through of another phospholipid, phosphatidylethanolamine (Figure 2) [(3)](#reference3). Sphingomyelin is a type of sphingosine-containing phospholipid (sphingolipid) that is synthesized by the transfer of a phosphocholine residue from a phosphatidylcholine to a ceramide (Figure 3). Sphingomyelin is found in cell membranes and in the fatty sheath that envelops [myelinated](../glossary#myelin) The generating phosphocholine is released the degradation of phosphatidylcholine by phospholipases. Choline CDP-choline (citicoline) administration was also found to stimulate the synthesis and release of a family of neurotransmitters derived from tyrosine (i.e., the [catecholamines](../glossary#catecholamine), including noradrenaline, adrenaline, and dopamine) [(5)](#reference5). Of note, non-neuronal cells of various tissues and organ systems also synthesize and release acetylcholine, which then binds and stimulates cholinergic [receptors](../glossary#receptor) on target cells (reviewed in [6](#reference6)). Fat and [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) consumed in the diet are transported to the liver by [lipoproteins](../glossary#lipoprotein) called [chylomicrons](../glossary#chylomicrons). In the liver, fat and cholesterol are packaged into lipoproteins called very-low-density lipoproteins ( [VLDL](../glossary#VLDL)) for transport in the bloodstream tissues. [Polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) of the PEMT [gene](../glossary#gene) increase the dietary requirements of choline [(9)](#reference9). Without adequate phosphatidylcholine, fat and cholesterol accumulate in the liver (see [Deficiency](#deficiency)). Choline may be [oxidized](../glossary#oxidation) in the liver and kidney to form a [metabolite](../glossary#metabolite) called betaine via a two-step [enzymatic](../glossary#enzyme) then converted to betaine by betaine aldehyde dehydrogenase in either the mitochondrial matrix or the [cytosol](../glossary#cytosol) [(2)](#reference2). Betaine is a source of up to 60% of the methyl (CH3) groups required methyltransferase convert homocysteine to [methionine](../glossary#methionine) in [one-carbon](../glossary#one-carbon-unit) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) (Figure 4). also using the folate derivative, 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, as a methyl donor (see [Nutrient interactions](#nutrient-interactions)). Elevated concentrations of homocysteine in the blood have been associated with increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) [(11)](#reference11). The conversion is irreversible. Betaine is an osmolyte that regulates cell volume and protect cell integrity against osmotic stress (especially in the kidney). Osmotic stress has been associated with a reduced BHMT expression such that the role of betaine in osmoregulation may be temporarily prioritized over its function as a methyl donor [(2)](#reference2). Men and women fed [intravenously](../glossary#intravenous) (IV) with solutions that contained adequate [methionine](../glossary#methionine) and [folate](../vitamins/folate) but lacked choline have been found to develop a condition called nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and signs of liver damage that resolved when choline was provided [(12)](#reference12). The occurrence of NAFLD is usually associated with the co-presentation of metabolic disorders, including [obesity](../glossary#obesity), with [metabolic syndrome](../disease-index/metabolic-syndrome). NAFLD is estimated to progress to a more severe condition called nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) in about one-third of NAFLD patients, as well as to increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis) and liver [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [(13)](#reference13). Because low-density lipoprotein ( [LDL](../glossary#LDL)) particles are formed from VLDL particles, choline-deficient individuals also show reduced blood concentrations of LDL-cholesterol [(14)](#reference14). Abnormally elevated [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) of organ dysfunction creatine phosphokinase, Choline deficiency-induced organ dysfunction has also been associated with increased [DNA](../glossary#DNA) damage and [apoptosis](../glossary#apoptosis) in circulating [lymphocytes](../glossary#lymphocyte) [(15)](#reference15). In the liver, the accumulation of [lipids](../glossary#lipid) is thought to impair [mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) function, thus reducing [fatty acid](../glossary#fatty-acid) [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) and increasing the production of [reactive oxygen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species) (ROS) that trigger [lipid peroxidation](../glossary#lipid-peroxidation), DNA damage, and apoptosis. Further, oxidative stress is thought to be responsible for prompting inflammatory processes that can lead to the progression of NAFLD to NASH and cirrhosis (end-stage liver disease) [(16)](#reference16). An intervention study in 57 healthy adults who were fed choline-deficient diets under controlled conditions found that 77% of men, 80% of postmenopausal women, and 44% of premenopausal women developed fatty liver, liver damage, and/or muscle damage [(17)](#reference17). These signs of organ dysfunction resolved upon choline reintroduction in the diet. Because estrogen stimulates the endogenous of phosphatidylcholine via the phosphatidylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PEMT) pathway, premenopausal women may be less likely to develop signs of choline deficiency in response to a low-choline diet compared to postmenopausal women [(18, 19)](#reference18). Further, rs12325817) of the PEMT [gene](../glossary#gene), which may affect the expression and/or activity of the PEMT [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme), is thought to increase the susceptibility to choline deficiency-induced organ dysfunction [(18)](#reference18). Additional genetic polymorphisms occurring in choline and one-carbon metabolic pathways may alter the dietary requirement for choline and thus increase the likelihood of developing signs of deficiency when choline intake is inadequate [(9](#reference9), [20, 21)](#reference20). Of note, the composition of one's intestinal microbiota has been identified as a potential predictor of susceptibility to choline deficiency-induced NAFLD [(22)](#reference22). Intestinal microbiota-dependent metabolism of dietary phosphatidylcholine might also be involved in the pathogenesis of cardiovascular disease (see [Safety](#safety)) [(23, 24)](#reference23). Daily intake recommendations are higher during pregnancy and lactation (see [The AI](#AI)), placing pregnant and lactating individuals at increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of choline inadequacy [(25, 26)](#reference25). Vegetarians may also be at increased risk of choline inadequacy [(26)](#reference26). Patients with cystic fibrosis who have pancreatic insufficiency are at risk of choline depletion due to increased fecal losses [(27)](#reference27). Circulating choline has been directly correlated with lung function in cystic fibrosis patients [(28)](#reference28), and results of a pilot study in 10 patients suggested that choline supplementation may have utility in improving clinical outcomes in cystic fibrosis patients [(29)](#reference29). SAM is [synthesized](../glossary#synthesis) from the essential amino acid, [methionine](../glossary#methionine). Three molecules of SAM are required for the methylation reaction that converts phosphatidylethanolamine into phosphatidylcholine ( [Figure 2](#figure-2b)). Once SAM donates a methyl group it becomes S-adenosylhomocysteine (SAH), which is then metabolized to [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine). Homocysteine can be converted back to methionine in a reaction [catalyzed](../glossary#catalyze) by vitamin B12-dependent methionine synthase, which requires 5-methyltetrahydrofolate (5-meTHF) a methyl donor. Alternately, betaine (a [metabolite](../glossary#metabolite) of choline) is used as the methyl donor for the methylation of homocysteine vitamin B6-dependent transsulfuration pathway ( [Figure 4](#figure-4)). Thus, the human requirement for choline is especially influenced by the relationship between choline and other methyl group donors, such as folate and S-adenosylmethionine. A low intake of folate leads to an increased demand for choline-derived metabolite, betaine. Moreover, the [de novo synthesis](../glossary#de-novo-synthesis) of phosphatidylcholine is not sufficient to maintain adequate choline nutritional [status](../glossary#status) when dietary intakes of folate and choline are low [(30)](#reference30). Conversely, the demand for folate is increased when dietary supply for choline is limited [(31)](#reference31). In 1998, the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the Institute of Medicine (now the National Academy of Medicine) established a dietary reference intake ( [DRI](../glossary#DRI)) for choline [(32)](#reference32). The FNB felt the existing scientific evidence was insufficient to calculate an [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for choline, so they set an Adequate Intake ( [AI](../glossary#AI); Table 1). The main criterion for establishing the AI for choline was the prevention of liver damage.
