Most trials were limited by small sample sizes and short duration — up to three years may be necessary to see an effect on relapse rates given the natural relapsing-remitting course of the disease. The two largest and most recent trials (EPIC-1 and EPIC-2) showed no significant effect of omega-3 supplementation on indicators of Crohn's disease remission compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(162)](#reference162). Other systematic reviews of the literature reached similar conclusions [(163-165)](#reference163). Three short-term trials showed positive effects of omega-3 supplementation on [plasma](../glossary#plasma) biochemical parameters (e.g., reduced [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) [cytokine](../glossary#cytokine) expression, increased plasma EPA and DHA concentrations) compared to controls [(161)](#reference161). In spite of its impact on biochemical changes in the short-term, however, the ability of omega-3 supplementation to maintain remission or effect clinically meaningful changes in Crohn's disease is not supported by the current evidence [(164)](#reference164). Ulcerative colitis: Seven [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) of fish oil [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) in patients with active [ulcerative colitis](../glossary#ulcerative-colitis) reported significant improvement in at least one outcome measure, such as decreased [corticosteroid](../glossary#corticosteroid) use, improved disease activity scores, or improved [histology](../glossary#histology) scores [(163)](#reference163). In patients with inactive ulcerative colitis, omega-3 supplementation had no effect on relapse rates compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) in four separate trials [(163, 165)](#reference163). While no serious side effects were reported in any trials of fish oil supplementation for the maintenance or remission of [inflammatory bowel disease](../glossary#inflammatory-bowel-disease), diarrhea and upper [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) symptoms occurred with treatment (AA; 20:4n-6) are thought to play an important role in the [pathology](../glossary#pathology) of [asthma](../glossary#asthma) [(32)](#reference32). Because increasing omega-3 [fatty acid](../glossary#fatty-acid) intake has been found to decrease the formation of AA-derived leukotrienes, a number of [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) of long-chain omega-3 fatty acid supplementation on asthma. Although there is some evidence that omega-3 fatty acid supplementation can decrease the production of inflammatory mediators in asthmatic patients [(166, 167)](#reference166), evidence that omega-3 fatty acid supplementation decreases the clinical severity of asthma in controlled trials has been inconsistent [(168)](#reference168). Three [systematic reviews](../glossary#systematic-review) fatty acid supplementation in asthmatic adults and children found no consistent effects on clinical outcome measures, including pulmonary function tests, asthmatic symptoms, medication use, or bronchial hyperreactivity [(169-171)](#reference169). Immunoglobulin A (IgA) [nephropathy](../glossary#nephropathy) is a kidney disorder that results from the deposition of IgA in the [glomeruli](../glossary#glomerulus) of the kidneys. The cause of IgA nephropathy is not clear, but progressive [renal](../glossary#renal) failure may eventually develop in 15%-40% of patients [(172)](#reference172). Since glomerular IgA deposition results production of [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) mediators, omega-3 [fatty acid](../glossary#fatty-acid) [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) could potentially modulate the inflammatory response and preserve renal function. A 2012 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) assessed the efficacy of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation on adult IgA nephropathy [(173)](#reference173). Five [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) were included in an analysis involving 239 patients (mean age, 37-41 years) who received [placebo](../glossary#placebo) or supplemental EPA + DHA at doses of 1.4 to 5.1 g/day for 6 to 24 months. Compared with control groups, omega-3 supplementation had no significant effect on urine [protein](../glossary#protein) [excretion](../glossary#excretion) or glomerular filtration rate. Only two trials measured changes in [serum](../glossary#serum) creatinine (a marker of renal function) and end-stage renal disease — omega-3 treatment had a beneficial effect on these two parameters in both trials. No adverse events associated with omega-3 supplementation were reported in any of the trials. A more recent review of the literature identified six trials showing evidence of omega-3 supplementation slowing IgA nephropathy disease progression and three trials reporting no effect [(174)](#reference174). Additionally, preliminary data suggested that the potential synergistic actions of aspirin and long-chain omega-3 PUFAs might constitute a promising treatment option [(168)](#reference168). Autism spectrum disorders (ASD) refer to three neurodevelopmental disorders of variable severity, namely autism, Asperger syndrome, and pervasive development disorder. ASD are characterized by abnormal information processing in the brain due to alterations in the way [nerve cells](../glossary#neuron) and their [synapses](../glossary#synapse) connect and organize. ASD are thought to have a strong genetic basis, yet environmental factors including diet may play an important role. Given that omega-3 and omega-6 [PUFA](../glossary#polyunsaturated-fatty-acid) are necessary for [neuronal](../glossary#neuron) growth and synapse formation (see [Biological Activities](#biological-activities)), they may be of significant benefit in the prevention and/or management of ASD. This is supported by observations of PUFA abnormalities in blood of children with ASD, when compared to their peers with no neurodevelopmental disorders [(175)](#reference175). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) reported lower blood concentrations of DHA and EPA in children with ASD compared to typically developing children; yet, the ratio of total omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids was similar between children with and without ASD symptoms [(176)](#reference176). A [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) by the same authors identified six [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) that examined the effect of primarily long-chain omega-3 PUFA on ASD symptoms [(176)](#reference176). All the studies included children; one study also included adults 28 years [(177)](#reference177). Four trials used EPA (0.70-0.84 g/day) plus DHA (0.46-0.70 g/day) [(178-181)](#reference178), one trial used DHA (0.24 g/day) plus AA (0.24 g/day) [(177)](#reference177), and one trial only used only DHA (0.20 g/day) [(182)](#reference182). A pooled analysis of four [(177-180)](#reference177) of these trials, including a total of 107 participants, showed a small improvement in measures of social interaction and repetitive and restrictive interests and behaviors with long-chain PUFA supplementation for 6 to 16 weeks; however, there was no effect on measures of communication and ASD co-existing conditions, such as hyperactivity, irritability, sensory issues, and [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) symptoms [(176)](#reference176). Two additional systematic reviews and meta-analyses, also published in 2017, identified the same set of trials. One meta-analysis suggested a benefit of long-chain PUFA on measures of lethargy and stereotypy but found no overall clinical improvement compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(183)](#reference183). The other meta-analysis suggested an improvement regarding lethargy yet a worsening of externalizing behavior and social skills in children supplemented with omega-3 PUFA [(184)](#reference184). The available evidence is based on few trials of small sample sizes and is thus too limited to draw firm conclusions regarding the potential benefit of long-chain PUFA supplementation in ASD management. Data from [ecologic studies](../glossary#ecologic-study) across different countries suggested an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between seafood consumption and national rates of major depression [(185)](#reference185) and [bipolar disorder](../glossary#bipolar-disorder) [(186)](#reference186). Several small studies have found [fatty be lower in [plasma](../glossary#plasma) [(187-189)](#reference187) and [adipose tissue](../glossary#adipose) [(190)](#reference190) of individuals suffering from depression compared to controls. Although it is not known how omega-3 fatty acid intake affects the incidence of depression, modulation of [neuronal](../glossary#neuron) [signaling](../glossary#cell-signaling) pathways and [eicosanoid](../glossary#eicosanoid) production have been proposed as possible mechanisms [(191)](#reference191). There may be some benefit of omega-3 [PUFA](../glossary#polyunsaturated-fatty-acid) [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) on depressive disorders, but it is difficult to compare studies and draw conclusions due to great [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) among the trials [(192, 193)](#reference192). Small sample sizes, lack of standardization of therapeutic doses, type of omega-3 PUFA administered, co-treatment with pharmacological agents, and diagnostic criteria vary among the trials. A 2012 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) of all published [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) investigated the effect of omega-3 PUFA supplementation on the prevention and treatment of several types of depression and other neuropsychiatric disorders [(192)](#reference192). With respect to major depression, most studies reported a positive effect of omega-3 supplements on depressive symptoms, though efficacy is still considered inconclusive given the great variability among trials. A few themes emerged from this review: more trials reported positive effect for omega-3 PUFA supplements as an [adjunct](../glossary#adjunct) to pharmacological treatment; in [monotherapy](../glossary#monotherapy) trials, EPA alone was more effective than DHA alone; and in combination trials, positive effects were more likely if an EPA:DHA ratio of >1.5-2.0 was administered. A 2014 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) grouped trials by type of diagnosis of depression [(194)](#reference194). A positive effect of omega-3 supplementation was found in 11 trials in participants with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder (according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders [DSM] criteria). Omega-3 supplementation also appeared to be effective in the pooled analysis of eight trials in participants not formally diagnosed with major depressive disorder, i.e., adults with depressive symptoms despite ongoing treatment, untreated patients with mild-to-severe depressed mood, patients with a history of at least one major depressive episode, women with borderline personality disorder, patients with recurrent self-harm, and postmenopausal women with psychological distress and depressive symptoms. There was no mood improvement with omega-3 supplements in generally healthy adults experiencing depressive symptoms, as suggested by the pooled analysis of six trials [(194)](#reference194). Finally, a 2017 Cochrane systematic review and meta-analysis of 20 randomized controlled trials reported a small benefit of omega-3 supplementation on depressive symptoms when compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo), yet the evidence was deemed of very low quality and the positive effect was judged likely to be [biased](../glossary#bias) and not clinically significant [(195)](#reference195). Unipolar depression and bipolar disorder are considered distinct psychiatric conditions, although major depression occurs in both. A 2016 meta-analysis of eight [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) that compared the PUFA composition of red blood [cell membranes](../glossary#cell-membrane) between patients with bipolar disorder and healthy subjects showed abnormally low red blood cell DHA concentrations with bipolar disorder [(196)](#reference196). As with major depression, reviews of trials indicated that omega-3 supplementation may have a positive effect as an adjunct to therapy in patients with bipolar disorder [(192, 194)](#reference192). Additionally, a 2016 [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), placebo-controlled trial in 100 participants with bipolar disorder reported a reduction in the severity of manic episodes with daily supplementation of 1,000 mg omega-3 PUFA for three months [(197)](#reference197). While there is some promising evidence for the use of omega-3 fatty acids for major depression and bipolar disorder, additional trials that account for dietary omega-3 intake, changes in red blood cell PUFA concentrations, the ratio of EPA:DHA provided, and co-treatment with medications are necessary. A 2013 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 18 studies compared the [PUFA](../glossary#polyunsaturated-fatty-acid) composition of red blood [cell membranes](../glossary#cell-membrane) in patients with [schizophrenia](../glossary#schizophrenia) to individuals without the disorder [(198)](#reference198). The majority of studies investigated medicated patients, though the authors separated the analysis into three groups of patients at time of measurement in order to account for possible [confounding](../glossary#confounder) from pharmacologic agents: antipsychotic-medicated, antipsychotic-naïve, and antipsychotic-free. Overall, decreased concentrations of DPA, DHA, and AA in red blood cell membranes were associated with the schizophrenic state. Several mechanisms may account for PUFA abnormalities in schizophrenia, such as altered [lipid](../glossary#lipid) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), increased [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress), or changes in diet consequent behavior. The use of long-chain omega-3 [fatty acid](../glossary#fatty-acid) [supplements](../glossary#supplement) to alleviate symptoms of schizophrenia or to mitigate adverse effects of antipsychotic medications has been investigated in a number of [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) [(194](#reference194), [199)](#reference199). In a recent [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 50 subjects with recent onset of schizophrenia who were medicated, daily supplementation with EPA (740 mg) and DHA (400 mg) reduced psychotic symptoms (assessed with the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale) only in those who were not taking the [anxiolytic](../glossary#anxiolytic), lorazepam (Ativan) [(200)](#reference200). Overall, however, there was no effect of long-chain PUFA supplements on schizophrenia symptoms. Yet, given the high safety profile of fish oil supplements and some evidence of a positive effect of EPA supplementation in a subset of trials, some clinicians may consider EPA a useful [adjunct](../glossary#adjunct) to antipsychotic therapy in patients with schizophrenia. Several mechanisms suggest that omega-3 [PUFA](../glossary#polyunsaturated-fatty-acid) [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) may improve the [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) performance of individuals with [Alzheimer's disease](../health-disease/alzheimer-disease) and other types of [dementia](../glossary#dementia). In particular, the [antioxidative](../glossary#antioxidant) and anti- [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) properties of these PUFA may help protect [neurons](../glossary#neuron), promote [synaptic plasticity](../glossary#synaptic-plasticity), and limit cellular death. The PUFA composition of the diet appears to influence blood [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol), which may play a role in the [pathology](../glossary#pathology) of Alzheimer's disease. However, the current evidence from [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) is not supportive of omega-3 supplementation in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease in humans. A 2016 Cochrane review identified three [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials in patients with Alzheimer's disease of mild-to-moderate severity [(201)](#reference201). These trials compared daily supplementation with DHA (between 675 mg and 1,700 mg) and EPA (between 600 mg and 975 mg) to a placebo for 12 months [(202, 203)](#reference202) or 18 months [(204)](#reference204). Of note, the study by Quinn et al. [(204)](#reference204) also included 4 mg/day of [vitamin E](../vitamins/vitamin-E) (used as preservative — see also [Nutrient interactions](#nutrient-interactions)) in the intervention arm, and the study by Freund-Levi et al. [(202)](#reference202) included DHA (900-1,100 mg/day) but no EPA. The pooled analysis of these trials showed no beneficial effect of omega-3 supplementation on measures of global and specific cognitive functions, measures of functional outcomes, and measures of dementia severity [(201)](#reference201). There was no difference between intervention and placebo arms regarding the occurrence of adverse effects [(201)](#reference201). The content of EPA and DHA varies in each of these preparations, making it necessary to read product labels in order to determine the EPA and DHA levels provided by a particular supplement. All omega-3 fatty acid supplements are absorbed more efficiently with meals. Dividing one's daily dose into two or three smaller doses throughout the day will decrease the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) side effects (see [Safety](#safety)). In 2001, the FDA began permitting the addition of DHA and AA to infant formula in the United States [(208)](#reference208). Presently, manufacturers are not required to list the amounts of DHA and AA added to infant formula on the label. However, most infant formula manufacturers provide this information. The amounts added to formulas in the US range from 8 to 17 mg DHA/100 calories (5 fl oz) and from 16 to 34 mg AA/100 calories. For example, an infant drinking 20 fl oz of DHA-enriched formula daily would receive 32 to 68 mg/day of DHA and 64 to 136 mg/day of AA. [Supplemental](../glossary#supplement) -linolenic acid is generally well tolerated, and serious adverse side effects have not been observed at doses up to 2.8 g/day for 12 months [(209)](#reference209). High doses of borage seed oil, evening primrose oil, or black currant seed oil may cause [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) upset, loose stools, or diarrhea [(206)](#reference206). Because of [case reports](../glossary#case-report) that supplementation with evening primrose oil induced in people with undiagnosed temporal lobe [epilepsy](../glossary#epilepsy) [(210)](#reference210), people with a history of seizures or a seizure disorder are generally advised to avoid evening primrose oil and other -linolenic acid-rich oils [(206)](#reference206). Although flaxseed oil is generally well tolerated, high doses may cause loose stools or diarrhea [(211)](#reference211). Allergic and [anaphylactic](../glossary#anaphylaxis) reactions have been reported with flaxseed and flaxseed oil ingestion [(212)](#reference212). Serious adverse reactions have not been reported in those using fish oil or other EPA and DHA [supplements](../glossary#supplement). The most common adverse effect of fish oil or EPA and DHA supplements is a fishy aftertaste. Belching and heartburn have also been reported. Additionally, high doses may cause nausea and loose stools. Potential for excessive bleeding: The potential for high omega-3 [fatty acid](../glossary#fatty-acid) intakes, especially EPA and DHA, to prolong bleeding times has been well studied and may play a role in the cardioprotective effects of omega-3 fatty acids. Although excessively long bleeding times and increased incidence of [hemorrhagic stroke](../glossary#hemorrhagic-stroke) have been observed in Greenland Eskimos with very high intakes of EPA + DHA (6.5 g/day), it is not known whether high intakes of EPA and DHA are the only factor responsible for these observations [(1)](#references). The US FDA has ruled that intakes up to 3 g/day of long-chain omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA) are Generally Recognized As Safe (GRAS) for inclusion in the diet, and available evidence suggests that intakes less than 3 g/day are unlikely to result in clinically significant bleeding [(107)](#reference107). Although the US Institute of Medicine did not establish a tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for omega-3 fatty acids, caution was advised with the use of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) EPA and DHA, especially in those who are at increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of excessive bleeding (see [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions) and [Nutrient interactions](#nutrient-interactions)) [(1](#references), [206)](#reference206). Some species of fish may contain significant levels of methylmercury, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), or other environmental contaminants [(218)](#reference218). In general, larger predatory fish, such as swordfish, tend to contain the highest levels of these contaminants. Removing the skin, fat, and internal organs of the fish prior to cooking and allowing the fat to drain from the fish while it cooks will decrease exposure to a number of fat-soluble pollutants, such as PCBs [(219)](#reference219). However, methylmercury is found throughout the muscle of fish, so these cooking precautions will not reduce exposure to methylmercury. Organic mercury compounds are toxic and excessive exposure can cause brain and kidney damage. The developing fetus, infants, and young children are especially vulnerable to the toxic effects of mercury on the brain. In order to limit their exposure to methylmercury, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and Environmental Protection Agency have formulated joint recommendations for women who may become pregnant, pregnant women, breast-feeding women, and parents. These recommendations are presented in Table 5. For more information about the FDA/Environmental Protection Agency advisory for pregnant women and parents of young children on eating fish, see their [online brochure](https://www.fda.gov/food/metals/mercury-levels-commercial-fish-and-shellfish-1990-2012). More information about mercury levels in commercial fish and shellfish is available from the FDA. Of note, the 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommend the consumption of salmon, anchovies, herring, shad, sardines, Pacific oysters, trout, and Atlantic and Pacific mackerel (not king mackerel), which are higher in EPA and DHA and lower in methylmercury [(220)](#reference220). The absence of methylmercury in omega-3 fatty acid supplements can be explained by the fact that mercury accumulates in the muscle, rather than the fat of fish [(107)](#reference107). Inside the body, results of animal studies and limited data in humans suggest that the amount of vitamin E required to prevent [lipid peroxidation](../glossary#lipid-peroxidation) increases with the amount of PUFA consumed [(225)](#reference225). One widely used recommendation for vitamin E intake is 0.6 mg of -tocopherol per gram of dietary PUFA. This recommendation was based on a small study in men and the ratio of -tocopherol to LA in the US diet and has not been verified in more comprehensive studies. Although EPA and DHA are easily oxidized outside the body, it is presently unclear whether they are more susceptible to [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) within the body [(226)](#reference226). High vitamin E intakes have not been found to decrease [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) of oxidative damage when EPA and DHA intakes are increased [(227, 228)](#reference227), but some experts believe that an increase in PUFA intake, particularly omega-3 PUFA intake, should be accompanied by an increase in vitamin E intake [(1)](#references). ALA, -linolenic acid; EPA, eicosapentaenoic acid; DHA, docosahexaenoic acid.| Given the established health benefits of consuming at least two servings of oily fish per week, providing approximately 400 to 500 mg EPA + DHA, some researchers have proposed that the US Institute of Medicine (now the National Academy of Medicine) establish dietary reference intakes ( [DRIs](../glossary#DRI)) for EPA + DHA [(27)](#reference27). For now, there are no DRIs for EPA and DHA specifically. Because maternal dietary intake of long-chain PUFA determines the DHA status of the newborn, several expert panels in the US recommend that pregnant and lactating women consume at least 200 mg DHA per day, close to the amount recommended for adults in general (250 mg/day) [(70](#reference70), [229)](#reference229). The potential benefits associated with obtaining long-chain omega-3 [fatty acids](../glossary#fatty-acid) through moderate consumption of fish (e.g., 1-2 servings weekly) during pregnancy and lactation outweigh any risks of contaminant exposure, though fish with high concentrations of methylmercury should be avoided [(218)](#reference218). For information about contaminants in fish and guidelines for fish consumption by women of childbearing age, see [Contaminants in fish](#contaminants-fish). The [2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines](https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/2015/) provide recommendations for nutritional goals for linoleic acid and -linolenic acid based on the [DRIs](../glossary#DRI) (see [Tables 6 and 7](#table-6)). Seafood, [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts), seeds, and oils, which are all part of healthy dietary patterns, provide essential fatty acids. Estimates of daily calorie needs according to age, gender, and physical activity can be found in the Appendix 2 of the '2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans' report | Oz-eq, ounce-equivalent The American Heart Association recommends that people without documented [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) (CHD) eat a variety of fish (preferably oily) at least twice weekly [(230)](#reference230). Two servings of oily fish provide approximately 500 mg of EPA plus DHA. Pregnant women and children should avoid fish that typically have higher levels of methylmercury (see [Contaminants in fish](#contaminants-fish)). People with documented CHD and those with [heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure) without preserved left [ventricular](../glossary#ventricles) function are advised to consume approximately 1 g/day of EPA + DHA preferably from oily fish, or to consider EPA + DHA supplements in consultation with a physician [(104](#reference104), [107)](#reference107). Patients who need to lower [serum](../glossary#serum) [triglycerides](../glossary#triglyceride) may take 2 to 4 g/day of EPA + DHA supplements under a physician's care (see [Hypertriglyceridemia](#hypertriglyceridemia-treatment)). Upon request of the European Commission, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) proposed adequate intakes (AI) for the essential [fatty acids](../glossary#fatty-acid) LA and ALA, as well as the long-chain omega-3 fatty acids EPA and DHA [(231)](#reference231). EFSA recommends an LA intake of 4% of total energy and an ALA intake of 0.5% of total energy; an AI of 250 mg/day is recommended for EPA plus DHA [(232)](#reference232). The European Food and Safety Authority (EFSA) recommends that pregnant and lactating women consume an additional 100 to 200 mg of preformed DHA on top of the 250 mg/day EPA plus DHA recommended for healthy adults [(231)](#reference231). For adults, the World Health Organization recommends an acceptable macronutrient distribution range (AMDR) for omega-6 fatty acid intake of 2.5%-9% of energy and for omega-3 fatty acid intake of 0.5%-2% of energy [(233)](#reference233). Their AMDR for EPA plus DHA is 0.25 to 2 g/day (the upper level applying to secondary prevention of [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease)). The International Society for the Study of Fatty Acids and Lipids (ISSFAL) recommends healthy adults have an LA intake of 2% energy, an ALA intake of 0.7% energy, and a minimum of 500 mg/day of EPA plus DHA for cardiovascular health [(234)](#reference234). The Linus Pauling Institute supports the AI for the essential fatty acids (see [Tables 6 and 7](#table-6)) and recommends that generally healthy adults increase their intake of long-chain omega-3 [fatty acids](../glossary#fatty-acid) by eating fish twice weekly and consuming foods rich in ALA, such as walnuts, flaxseeds, and flaxseed or canola oil. If you don't regularly consume fish, consider taking a two-gram fish oil [supplement](../glossary#supplement) several times a week. If you are prone to bleeding or take [anticoagulant](../glossary#anticoagulant) drugs, consult your physician. Contents All dietary fibers are resistant to digestion in the [small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine), meaning they arrive intact in the large intestine [(1)](#references). Although most fibers are [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate), one important factor that determines their susceptibility to digestion by human [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) is the conformation of the chemical bonds between sugar molecules (glycosidic bonds). Humans lack digestive enzymes capable of [hydrolyzing](../glossary#hydrolysis) (breaking apart) most -glycosidic bonds, which explains why amylose, a [glucose](../glossary#glucose) [polymer](../glossary#polymer) with -1,4 glycosidic bonds, is digestible by human enzymes, while cellulose, a glucose polymer with -1,4 glycosidic bonds, is indigestible (Figure 1). Although nutritional scientists and clinicians generally agree that a healthy diet should include plenty of fiber-rich foods, agreement on the actual definition of fiber has been more difficult to achieve [(2-4)](#reference2). In the 1970s, dietary fiber was defined as remnants of plant cells that are resistant to digestion by human [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) [(5)](#reference5). This definition includes a component of some plant cell walls called lignin, as well as indigestible [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) found in plants. However, this definition omits indigestible carbohydrates derived from animal sources (e.g., chitin) and synthetic (e.g., fructooligosaccharides, polydextrose, wheat dextrin) and carbohydrates that are inaccessible to human digestive enzymes (e.g., resistant starch) [(6)](#reference6). These compounds share many of the characteristics of fiber present in plant foods. Before establishing intake recommendations for fiber in 2001, a panel of experts convened by the Institute of Medicine (now the National Academy of Medicine) developed definitions of fiber that made a distinction between fiber that occurs naturally in plant foods (dietary fiber) and isolated or synthetic fibers that may be added to foods or used as dietary [supplements](../glossary#supplement) (functional fiber) [(4)](#reference4). However, these distinctions are controversial, and there are other classification systems for dietary fiber (see [Other classification systems](#classification-systems) below). According to the Institute of Medicine's definition, functional fiber "consists of isolated, nondigestible [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) that have beneficial physiological effects in humans" [(4)](#reference4). Functional fibers may be nondigestible carbohydrates that have been isolated or extracted from a natural plant or animal source, or they may be manufactured or synthesized. However, designation as a functional fiber by the Institute of Medicine requires the presentation of sufficient evidence of physiological benefit in humans. Fibers identified as potential functional fibers by the Institute of Medicine include: Total fiber is defined by the Institute of Medicine as "the sum of dietary fiber and functional fiber" [(4)](#reference4). Fibers can be classified into four clinically meaningful categories according to their physiochemical properties, i.e., their [solubility](../glossary#soluble), viscosity, and [fermentability](../glossary#fermentation) (reviewed in [11](#reference11)): E.g., -glucans from oats and barley, raw guar gum [Soluble](../glossary#soluble) fibers dissolve in water, while [insoluble](../glossary#insoluble) fibers do not. Viscous fibers thicken in the presence of water, forming very viscous solutions or even visco-elastic gels. [Fermentable](../glossary#fermentation) fibers are readily [metabolized](../glossary#metabolism) by the gut [microbiota](../glossary#intestinal-microbiota) (i.e., [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria) that normally colonize the [large intestine](../glossary#large-intestine)). Fermentation of fiber results in the formation of short-chain [fatty acids](../glossary#fatty-acid) (acetate, propionate, and butyrate) and gases [(1)](#references). Short-chain fatty acids can be absorbed and metabolized to produce energy. Interestingly, the preferred energy source for colonocytes ( [epithelial](../glossary#epithelium) cells that line the colon) is butyrate. Fermentation of fiber is estimated to contribute up to 10% of daily energy intake [(12)](#reference12). Fibers that are fermentable and can stimulate the growth and/or activity of beneficial gut bacteria are called [prebiotic](../glossary#prebiotic) fibers [(13)](#reference13). Fibers that are soluble, viscous, and fermentable have been shown to improve glycemic control and to lower blood [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentration. However, their water-holding capacity is lost when they are fermented in the colon such that they have no laxative effect (see [Biological Activities](#biological-activities)). E.g., psyllium These fibers can dissolve in water and form viscous gels. They can improve glycemic control and lower blood [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentration. In addition, they retain their water-holding/gel-forming capacity in the [large intestine](../glossary#large-intestine) since they are resistant to fermentation. As a consequence, they can exert a stool-normalizing effect, preventing constipation or softening hard stool as well as firming loose/liquid stool in diarrhea and incontinence inulin, wheat dextrin, oligosaccharides, resistant starches Although these fibers can dissolve in water, they cannot provide any health benefits associated with fiber viscosity. They are fully [fermented](../glossary#fermentation) and thus do not exert a laxative effect. They can nonetheless exert a [prebiotic](../glossary#prebiotic) effect by influencing the composition of the gut [microbiota](../glossary#intestinal-microbiota). [In vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) studies have shown inulin to selectively stimulate the [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) of beneficial [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria) and limit the growth of potentially [pathogenic](../glossary#pathogen) bacteria ) (see [Isolated fibers and supplements](#isolated-fibers-supplements)) (reviewed in [14](#reference14)). However, no health benefit is currently associated with this fiber-driven prebiotic effect. E.g., wheat bran, cellulose, lignin These fibers do not dissolve in water, do not trap water, and are poorly [fermented](../glossary#fermentation). Large/coarse fiber particles can have a laxative effect. They can irritate the [large intestine](../glossary#large-intestine) mucosa and trigger the secretion of mucus and water, which increases the water content of stools. Small, insoluble fiber particles (e.g., finely ground wheat bran) have no laxative effect and can actually have a constipating effect by adding only to the dry stool mass (see [Improving regularity in stool elimination](#improving-regularity-stool-elimination)). Some, but not all, fibers can improve blood [lipid](../glossary#lipid) abnormalities observed in conditions like [dyslipidemia](../glossary#dyslipidemia), overweight/ [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), and with highly viscous fibers (i.e., gel-forming [soluble](../glossary#soluble) fibers), such as high molecular weight (MW) -glucan (found in oat bran), raw guar gum, and psyllium, has been shown to decrease total and [LDL](../glossary#LDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentrations when compared to appropriate controls (e.g., fiber-free supplement, low-fiber supplement, or supplementation with [insoluble](../glossary#insoluble) fiber) [(15)](#reference15). A 2009 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) that combined the results of 21 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 1,717 participants with hypercholesterolemia found dose- and time-dependent reductions in total and LDL-cholesterol with psyllium supplementation (3.0-20.4 g/day for >2 weeks) [(16)](#reference16). Additionally, results from two trials showed that, compared to [statins](../glossary#statin) alone, combining psyllium and statins resulted in larger reductions in LDL-cholesterol concentrations in individuals with hypercholesterolemia [(17)](#reference17). Another more recent meta-analysis of 28 randomized controlled trials examined the cholesterol-lowering effect of psyllium fiber on LDL-cholesterol, non- [HDL](../glossary#HDL)-cholesterol, and apolipoprotein B (apo B) [(18)](#reference18) — non-HDL-cholesterol and apo B appear to better predict cardiovascular events than LDL-cholesterol [(19)](#reference19). Supplementation with psyllium at a median dose of 10.2 g/day and for a median of eight weeks to participants with or without hypercholesterolemia reduced LDL-cholesterol by and apo B by 0.05 g/L (9 trials; 895 participants) [(18)](#reference18). Despite considerable [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) across studies, the cholesterol-lowering efficacy of other highly viscous fibers, including -glucans from oat or barley and glucomannan (a hemicellulose), was also reported in recent meta-analyses of trials conducted by one research team [(20-22)](#reference20). The cholesterol-lowering effect of soluble fibers, such as psyllium and -glucan, is directly linked to their high viscosity. Reduction of the gel-forming capacity of these fibers with pressure and/or heat during processing leads to the loss of their cholesterol lowering capacity [(23)](#reference23). Accordingly, low-viscosity soluble fibers (e.g., gum arabic/acacia gum, wheat dextrin), and insoluble fibers (e.g., wheat bran) do not decrease [serum](../glossary#serum) cholesterol at physiologic levels [(15)](#reference15). Highly viscous fibers can trap [bile](../glossary#bile) that is released in the [small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine) in response to a meal to assist the digestion and absorption of [fatty acids](../glossary#fatty-acid). The main mechanism underlying the cholesterol-lowering effect of these fibers is thus linked to their ability to prevent the reabsorption of bile in the terminal [ileum](../glossary#ileum) and facilitate its elimination in the stool. In order to maintain sufficient bile for digestion, hepatocytes must increase LDL-cholesterol clearance to [synthesize](../glossary#synthesis) more bile acids as cholesterol is a component of bile [(15)](#reference15). These findings led the FDA to approve health claims in relation to the prevention of heart disease on labels of low cholesterol/ [saturated fat](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid) foods containing 0.75 g/serving of -glucan from whole oat or barley or 1.7 g/serving of psyllium (see also [Cardiovascular disease](#cardiovascular-disease-prevention)) [(24)](#reference24). As with [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) lowering, the efficacy of fiber on glycemic control is dependent on viscosity. A 2017 review of 14 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) showed that none of the examined (i.e., inulin, oligofructose) could lead to reductions in and/or fasting blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentrations [(15)](#reference15). Supplementation with [insoluble](../glossary#insoluble) fiber also failed to improve glycemic control in subjects with elevated fasting blood glucose concentrations [(25)](#reference25). In contrast, the capacity of dietary viscous fiber [(26, 27)](#reference26) and isolated viscous fibers [(28-31)](#reference28) to improve glycemic control has been demonstrated in numerous controlled [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) conducted over three decades [(15)](#reference15). A 2015 review of the efficacy of psyllium showed evidence of reductions in postprandial blood glucose concentration following a single meal in people with type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) (6 studies) as well as in nondiabetic/ [euglycemic](../glossary#euglycemia) subjects (11 studies) [(32)](#reference32). Supplementation with psyllium also resulted in reductions in postprandial blood [insulin](../glossary#insulin) concentrations in subjects without type 2 diabetes (6 studies) but not in those with type 2 diabetes (3 studies). Longer-term studies of psyllium supplementation also found reductions in mean fasting glucose (4 studies) and mean [glycated hemoglobin](../glossary#glycated-hemoglobin) ( [HbA1c](../glossary#hemoglobin-A1c); 3 studies) in subjects with type 2 diabetes. Finally, while there was no effect of long-term exposure to psyllium on fasting glucose concentration in healthy individuals with euglycemia (14 studies), the glycemic benefit of psyllium was found to increase proportionally with the increase of baseline fasting glucose concentration (reviewed in [32](#reference32)). The role of soluble viscous fibers on glycemic control is related to their ability to increase [chyme](../glossary#chyme) viscosity, thereby slowing the degradation of complex nutrients and allowing the absorption of nutrients, including glucose, along the entire [small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine) rather than in the upper small intestine. Absorption of nutrients in the distal ileum has been associated with a reduction in gastric emptying and intestinal transit — through a distal to proximal feedback mechanism — which in turn reduces hunger and food intake (reviewed in [15](#reference15)). Nutrient delivery in the distal ileum also triggers the release of short-lived glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) into the circulation. GLP-1 improves insulin secretion by [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) -cells in response to glucose absorption and is involved in the regulation of food intake at the [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system) level [(33)](#reference33). An analysis of 2004-2014 US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) data from 18,433 participants found [inverse associations](../glossary#inverse-association) between either total, cereal, or vegetable fiber intake and the odds of [hypertension](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure) (defined according to new 2017 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association clinical practice guidelines; [34](#reference34)). A 2018 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 22 randomized control trials that examined the effect of isolated [soluble](../glossary#soluble) fiber [supplements](../glossary#supplement) or diets enriched with soluble viscous fiber in either normotensive or hypertensive participants found an overall 1.59 [mm Hg](../glossary#mm-Hg) reduction in [systolic blood pressure](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) and 0.39 mm Hg reduction in [diastolic blood pressure](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) [(35)](#reference35). Further analyses showed that, among all the soluble viscous fiber under examination (-glucan, guar gum, konjac glucomannan, pectin, and psyllium), only psyllium could reduce systolic blood pressure (mean reduction of 2.39 mm Hg) [(35)](#reference35). It is not yet understood how soluble viscous fiber would induce a lowering of blood pressure, but this effect may be indirect and dependent on established benefits of these fiber on other cardiometabolic parameters (see the above sections). The benefit of fiber on the regularity with which bulky, soft, easy-to-pass stools are eliminated is best assessed by an increase in stool output and an increase in the water content of stool. There are two mechanisms that support the laxative effects of certain fiber types: (i) large/coarse [insoluble](../glossary#insoluble) fiber (e.g., wheat bran) has an irritating effect on the [colonic](../glossary#colon) mucosa, which stimulates the secretion of water and mucus (unlike finely ground wheat bran that has a stool-hardening/constipating effect); and (ii) the presence of [soluble](../glossary#soluble) viscous, gel-forming fiber (e.g., psyllium) helps stool to resist dehydration in the colon [(15)](#reference15). Therefore, only fibers that remain relatively intact during the transit throughout the length of the colon (i.e., that resists [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) [fermentation](../glossary#fermentation)) and are thus found in the stool can have a potential laxative effect. In contrast, a 2016 meta-analysis of seven randomized controlled trials identified psyllium and nonprebiotics as effectively able to increase stool frequency and improve stool consistency in participants affected by and reductions in [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease) [risk](../glossary#risk) have generally assessed only fiber-rich foods, rather than fiber itself, making it difficult to determine whether the observed benefits are related to fiber or other nutrients and [phytochemicals](../glossary#phytochemical) commonly found in fiber-rich foods. In contrast, [intervention trials](../glossary#intervention-trial) often use isolated fibers to determine whether a specific fiber component has beneficial health effects. [Prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have consistently reported associations between high intakes of fiber-rich foods and low [risks](../glossary#risk) of [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) (CHD) and total [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) (CVD). Three large prospective cohort studies [(38-40)](#reference38) found that dietary fiber intakes of approximately 14 g per 1,000 kcal of energy were associated with substantial (16-33%) decreases in the risk of CHD; these results are the basis for the Institute of Medicine's [Adequate Intake](../glossary#AI) (AI) recommendation for fiber (see [Intake Recommendations](#intake-recommendations)) [(4)](#reference4). A 2013 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 17 prospective cohort studies found each 7 g/day increase in total dietary fiber intake to be associated with a 9% decrease in risk of coronary or total cardiovascular events [(41)](#reference41). The most recent meta-analysis that included 18 prospective studies, with a total of 672,408 participants, found a 7% lower risk of CHD and a 17% lower risk of CHD-related mortality with the highest versus lowest intakes of total dietary fiber [(42)](#reference42). Subgroup analyses by type or source of dietary fiber showed evidence of [inverse associations](../glossary#inverse-association) between cereal, fruit, or [soluble](../glossary#soluble) fiber intake and the risk of CHD [(42)](#reference42). The US FDA has approved health claims like the following on the labels of foods containing at least 0.75 g/serving of -glucan soluble fiber: "Diets low in [saturated fat](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid) [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) that include at least 3 g/day of -glucan soluble fiber from either whole oats or barley or a combination of both may reduce the risk of coronary heart disease" [(24)](#reference24). Similarly, the FDA has approved health claims on the labels of foods containing at least 1.7 g/serving of psyllium: "Diets low in saturated fat and cholesterol that include at least 7 g/day of soluble fiber from psyllium seed husk may reduce the risk of heart disease" [(24)](#reference24). While the cholesterol-lowering effect of viscous/gel-forming soluble fibers is recognized as a major contributor to the cardioprotective effects of fiber (see [Lowering serum cholesterol](#lowering-serum-cholesterol)), other mechanisms are likely to be involved. Findings from pooled analyses of prospective cohort studies found some evidence of an inverse association between the risks of CHD and total CVD and intakes of [insoluble](../glossary#insoluble) fiber [(41, 42)](#reference41). In addition, a [cross-sectional analysis](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) of 2005-2010 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) data found dietary fiber intake to be inversely associated with [serum](../glossary#serum) [LDL](../glossary#LDL)-cholesterol concentration, but also with blood pressure, [body mass index](../glossary#body-mass-index) (BMI), and serum [insulin](../glossary#insulin) concentration [(43)](#reference43). Beneficial effects of fiber-rich diets or isolated fiber consumption on blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) and insulin responses and on blood pressure may also likely contribute to observed reductions in CHD risk (see [Biological Activities](#biological-activities)). A 2014 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) (488,293 participants) found intakes of total fiber (12 studies), cereal fiber (10 studies), fruit fiber (8 studies), and [insoluble](../glossary#insoluble) fiber (3 studies) to be [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with the [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) [(44)](#reference44). A dose-response data analysis reported a nonlinear relationship between total fiber intake and diabetes risk, with evidence of risk reduction with total fiber intakes 25 g/day. A linear dose-response relationship between cereal fiber intake and diabetes risk indicated a 6% reduction in diabetes risk for each 2 g-increment in daily cereal fiber intake. There was no evidence of an inverse association between either vegetable fiber (9 studies) or [soluble](../glossary#soluble) fiber (3 studies) and the risk of type 2 diabetes [(44)](#reference44). Similar findings were reported in another meta-analysis of 18 prospective cohort studies in 617,968 participants [(45)](#reference45). Higher versus lower intakes of total fiber were found to be associated with a 15% lower risk of type 2 diabetes (17 studies); the risk of type 2 diabetes was inversely related to the intake of cereal fiber (13 studies) and insoluble fiber (3 studies) but not related to the intake of fruit fiber (11 studies), vegetable fiber (11 studies), or soluble fiber (3 studies) [(45)](#reference45). However, only randomized controlled interventions can establish whether there is a link of causality between an exposure (fiber intake) and an outcome (type 2 diabetes). For a discussion of the difference between observational studies and intervention studies, see the article "Epidemiological Studies" in the [Spring/Summer LPI 2016 Research Newsletter](../../../sites/lpi.oregonstate.edu/files/pdf/newsletters/ss16.pdf#page=7). contain insoluble cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin. To date, [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) examining the effect of cereal fiber supplementation on the risk of type 2 diabetes are limited [(46)](#reference46). In a [randomized controlled study](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) of 61 adults with [metabolic syndrome](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/glossary#metabolic-syndrome), the consumption of a diet based on several whole-grain cereal products for 12 weeks had no effect on fasting plasma concentrations of [glucose](../glossary#glucose), [insulin](../glossary#insulin), or [lipids](../glossary#lipid), or on measures of [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance) compared with a refined grain-based diet [(47)](#reference47). There was only some weak evidence of an effect of whole-grain cereals on [postprandial](../glossary#postprandial) insulin response [(47)](#reference47). A recent 24-month, randomized, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial examined the effect of daily supplementation with 15 g of primarily insoluble fiber on glycemic control in 180 adults with [impaired glucose tolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance) who were counselled to adopt more healthy lifestyle habits. Insoluble fiber supplementation failed to improve fasting glucose concentration, measures of [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitivity), [HbA1c](../glossary#hemoglobin-A1c) concentration (a marker of glycemic control), as well as glucose and insulin responses after a glucose load compared to placebo [(25)](#reference25). Although [observational data](../glossary#observational-study) suggest a protective association of cereal fiber against type 2 diabetes, the current (yet limited) evidence from intervention trials does not support a role for insoluble fiber in glycemic control in individuals at risk of type 2 diabetes. Fiber-related benefits on glucose [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) have been linked to the viscosity of certain soluble fibers (e.g., psyllium, -glucan, raw guar gum) (see [Improving glycemic control](#improving-glycemic-control)). Soluble viscous fibers in cereal, particularly -glucans, rather than insoluble fiber (and soluble nonviscous fiber), are thus more likely to be involved in a protective effect of cereal intake against type 2 diabetes [(48)](#reference48). Apart from fiber, other bioactive compounds in cereal, like magnesium, might contribute to improving glycemic control in people with impaired glucose tolerance (see the article on [Magnesium](../minerals/magnesium#diabetes-prevention)) [(49)](#reference49). The current position of the American Diabetes Association is to encourage people at risk of type 2 diabetes to achieve the daily Adequate Intake (AI) of 14 g/1,000 kcal for dietary fiber (see [Intake Recommendations](#intake-recommendations)) [(50, 51)](#reference50). Adherence to a Mediterranean-style diet, the composition of which intends to meet the AI for fiber, has been associated with a lower risk of developing type 2 diabetes [(52, 53)](#reference52). [Metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome) is estimated to affect nearly 35% of US adults and half of those older than 60 years [(54)](#reference54). The term metabolic syndrome refers to a cluster of metabolic disorders that increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) and type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus). The diagnosis in an individual is based on the presence at once of at least three of the following metabolic risk factors: abdominal obesity, [dyslipidemia](../glossary#dyslipidemia), of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have reported an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between total fiber intake and odds of metabolic syndrome in [cross-sectional studies](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) but [(55, 56)](#reference55). Numerous [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have examined the relationship between consumption of fiber and [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) at various sites. A 2014 review compiled published analyses of data from the large, multicenter European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC) prospective cohort (>500,000 participants). This umbrella review reported evidence of [inverse associations](../glossary#inverse-association) between higher versus lower daily total fiber intakes (28.5 g/day versus 16.4 g/day) and the risk of [colorectal](../glossary#colorectal-cancer), liver, and breast cancers [(57)](#reference57). Total fiber intakes were not associated with the risk of cancer at other sites, i.e., the biliary tract, endometrium, prostate, kidney, or bladder. In addition, further analyses suggested that the consumption of cereal fiber was inversely related to the risk of colorectal, stomach, and liver cancers, and vegetable fiber intake was inversely associated with breast cancer. Yet, associations between the consumption of specific fiber types were not examined in relation to the risk of endometrial, kidney, or bladder cancer in EPIC participants [(57)](#reference57). Pooling information from individual observational studies can be helpful to draw conclusions regarding the potential associations between dietary fiber consumption and cancer risk. Several mechanisms have been proposed to explain why consuming fiber can have a protective effect against colorectal cancer. First, the presence of [insoluble](../glossary#insoluble), coarse fiber can increase stool bulk thereby promoting the fecal [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of [carcinogens](../glossary#carcinogen) like nitrosamines [(62)](#reference62). Fiber can also reduce exposure of the gut mucosa to carcinogens by shortening transit time [(62)](#reference62). Secondly, fiber consumption influences the composition of the gut [microbiota](../glossary#intestinal-microbiota). [In vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) studies have shown inulin to selectively stimulate the [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) of beneficial [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria) while limiting the growth of potentially [pathogenic](../glossary#pathogen) bacteria (reviewed in [14](#reference14)). Gut bacterial imbalance ( [dysbiosis](../glossary#dysbiosis)) has been associated with the incidence of several conditions, including colorectal cancer [(63)](#reference63). The major health benefits conferred by the consumption of fiber are thus likely mediated by the bacteria the fiber contributes to feed. Depending on the physicochemical characteristics of fiber, some fiber, like inulin, can be fermented by colonic bacteria and lead to the formation of short-chain fatty acids, namely acetate, propionate, and butyrate. These short-chain fatty acids have been found to protect against [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) bacterial pathogens [(64)](#reference64) and to display anti-inflammatory [(65, 66)](#reference65). A few controlled [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have examined the effect of fiber consumption on the recurrence of [colorectal adenomas](../glossary#colorectal-adenoma) (precancerous [polyps](../glossary#polyp)), but none have been conducted in the last two decades. These trials examined the effect of wheat bran fiber [(67-71)](#reference67), psyllium [(72)](#reference72), and a high-fiber diet [(73)](#reference73) on the risk of adenomas in participants with a history of adenomas. A 2017 meta-analysis of these trials found no difference between intervention and control groups in the number of participants with at least one new adenomatous polyp during the follow-up period (2-8 years), regardless of the type of fiber intervention [(74)](#reference74). Dietary fiber might interfere with estrogen reabsorption by reducing -glucoronidase activity [(80)](#reference80). Alterations in gut bacteria composition have also been reported in women with breast cancer and might contribute to increased estrogen metabolism and absorption, resulting in higher circulating estrogen concentrations [(81)](#reference81). However, it is not known whether fiber-associated effects on [endogenous](../glossary#endogenous) estrogen concentrations have a clinically significant impact on breast cancer risk [(4)](#reference4). Finally, a healthy [microbiota](../glossary#intestinal-microbiota) might also promote the degradation of plant-derived molecules other than fiber, such as lignans, which are precursors of [metabolites](../glossary#metabolite) with anti-estrogenic activities [(82)](#reference82). A review of the most recent [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) suggests that dietary fiber consumption is [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) the [risk](../glossary#risk) [(87, 88)](#reference87). The evidence linking fiber intake and esophageal cancer was exclusively based on observations from [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study), and for the other cancer sites, the evidence is primarily derived from case-control studies (Table 2). It is important to note that the evidence of an inverse association between fiber intake and risk of ovarian cancer (2 meta-analyses) was observed in case-control but not in prospective cohort studies (Table 2). Additionally, there was no evidence of an association between fiber intake and risk of endometrial cancer (1 meta-analysis; [83](#reference83)), prostate cancer (2 meta-analyses; [ 91, 92)](#reference91), or renal cell carcinoma (1 meta-analysis; [93](#reference93)) (Table 2). At present, evidence from randomized controlled trials of a causal relationship between fiber intake and risk of any cancer is lacking. Of note, a recent study in a mouse model presenting a [dysbiotic](../glossary#dysbiosis) [microbiota](../glossary#intestinal-microbiota) characterized by an increase in fiber- [fermenting](../glossary#fermentation) [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria) showed that the consumption of an obesogenic, high-fat diet enriched with soluble fiber could cause icteric hepatocarcinoma [(94)](#reference94). Such findings suggest that a prolonged consumption of fermentable fiber may have detrimental consequences in contexts of dysbiosis. No such observations were found when insoluble fiber were substituted for soluble fiber [(94)](#reference94). [Gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) disorders associated with enteral nutrition prolong the time to recovery. A 2015 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 14 [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) found that fiber-enriched enteral formulas and/or fiber [supplements](../glossary#supplement) reduced the overall incidence of diarrhea in patients requiring enteral nutrition [(95)](#reference95). There was no reduction in incidental diarrhea when the analysis was restricted to studies that used [prebiotic](../glossary#prebiotic) fiber (i.e., fermentable fiber influencing [microbiota](../glossary#intestinal-microbiota) composition). Subgroup analyses also showed a benefit of fiber in non-critically ill patients but not in critically ill patients [(95)](#reference95). A [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) that followed nearly 60,000 older women for four years found that the highest versus lowest level of fiber intake (mean, 25 g/day versus 13.5 g/day) was associated with a 17% lower risk of developing fecal [incontinence](../glossary#incontinence) (defined here as an incontinence episode of liquid or solid stool at least once a month) [(96)](#reference96). A limited number of studies have also examined whether fiber [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) might help treat established fecal incontinence. In one [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial, 206 subjects suffering from fecal incontinence were [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) for 32 days to receive fibers with different degrees of fermentability: gum arabic (on average, 16.6 g/day; highly fermentable), sodium carboxymethylcellulose (16.2 g/day; partially fermentable), and psyllium (14.6 g/day; poorly fermentable) [(97)](#reference97). The frequency of fecal incontinence increased with sodium carboxymethylcellulose but decreased with gum arabic and psyllium compared to placebo. Stool consistency and amount did not differ among groups [(97)](#reference97). A randomized, [cross-over trial](../glossary#cross-over-trial) in 80 community-dwelling participants with at least one fecal incontinence episode per week found that the reduction in fecal incontinence frequency and severity with psyllium supplementation was equivalent to that observed with antidiarrheal drug loperamide (Imodium) [(98)](#reference98). It has been suggested that higher fiber intakes could help maintain weight or promote weight loss by increasing satiation (causing meal termination) and/or extending the feeling of fullness after a meal (satiety). Several mechanisms have been proposed to explain the potential satiating effect of fibers and the subsequent reduction in food intake. The presence of fiber in food may indirectly stimulate the production of hormones involved in the regulation of appetite in particular through (i) increasing the processing time in the mouth due to increased efforts required to masticate large particles containing fibers, and/or (ii) increasing the duration of stomach distention due to a lower rate of gastric emptying, and/or (iii) increasing the colonic production of short-chain [fatty acids](../glossary#fatty-acid) that can bind to [receptors](../glossary#receptor) present on gut endocrine cells (reviewed in [99](#reference99)). Adverse effects like gas production and bloating observed with the supplementation of isolated fibers (e.g., wheat dextrin) might also reduce hunger and increase satiety. A 2013 review of 44 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found that -glucans from oat or barley, lupin kernel fiber, whole grain rye, rye bran, and a mixed high-fiber diet could enhance satiety, whereas psyllium, whole grain barley, whole grain buckwheat, resistant starch, and wheat bran had no benefit or even reduced measures of satiety [(100)](#reference100). However, for many types of fiber examined, results from interventions were mixed, some showing a positive effect on satiety, and others showing no effect. Additionally, there seemed to be no relationship between the physicochemical properties of fiber (i.e., solubility, viscosity, fermentability) and evidence of efficacy. For example, among soluble viscous fibers, -glucans appeared to enhance satiety, but pectin or psyllium did not. Similarly, among fermentable fibers, -glucans enhanced satiety, but guar gum, inulin, fructooligosaccharides, and resistant starch did not. Finally, a positive effect of fiber on satiety was not consistently associated with a reduction in food intake [(100)](#reference100). A 2011 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) of 61 randomized controlled studies examined the effect of different fiber types on body weight [(101)](#reference101). This analysis found that dextrins and marine polysaccharides reduced body weight in all the studies, while chitosan, arabinoxylans, and fructans reduced body weight in at least two-thirds of the studies. Average weight reductions were greatest for the fructans and marine polysaccharides groups (~1.3 kg or 2.8 lb/4 weeks for a 79 kg person in both groups). For all fiber types combined, however, the average weight reduction was only 0.3 kg (0.7 lb) per 4 weeks for a 79-kg person [(101)](#reference101). A few randomized controlled trials in overweight or obese subjects suggested that psyllium supplementation may influence body composition and/or promote weight loss (reviewed in [102](#reference102)). In one randomized, placebo-controlled trial in 159 Australian with [body mass indices](../glossary#body-mass-index) (BMI) 25 kg/m2, psyllium (5 g/day) reduced waist circumference, waist-to-hip ratio, and body fat percentage, and increased the percentage of lean mass after 3, 6, and 12 months [(103)](#reference103). Psyllium appeared to transiently reduce body weight at 3 and 6 months, yet there was no difference in body weight between psyllium and placebo at the end of the intervention (12 months) [(103)](#reference103). More research needs to be conducted in order to clarify which types of fiber might play a role in appetite regulation and weight management [(99)](#reference99). Several [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have examined dietary fiber intake in relation to all-cause and cause-specific mortality. A 2015 report from the NIH-AARP Diet and Health Study, which followed 364,442 older adults for an average of 14 years, found that men and women in the highest versus lowest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of dietary fiber intake (mean, 10.2 g/day versus 2.0 g/day) had lower risks of all-cause [(104)](#reference104). Another prospective study that made use of data collected from 15,740 participants in the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 1988-1994 found a 13% lower risk of all-cause mortality in subjects with total fiber intake between 14.5 g/day and 22.1 g/day — but not in those with higher intake (>22.1 g/day) — compared to those with fiber intake less than 9.3 g/day, over a mean follow-up period of 13.7 years [(105)](#reference105). No associations were found between intakes of either insoluble or soluble fiber and all-cause mortality [(105)](#reference105). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of prospective cohort studies published before 2013, which included a total of 1,752,848 participants followed for a mean 12.4 years, found higher versus lower total fiber intake to be associated with lower risks of all-cause mortality (-23%; 9 studies), cancer-related mortality (-17%; 5 studies), and cardiovascular disease-related mortality (-23%; 16 studies) [(106)](#reference106). Another meta-analysis identified 14 prospective cohort studies that examined cereal fiber intake in relation to mortality [(107)](#reference107). Participants in the highest versus lowest [quartile](../glossary#quartile) of cereal fiber intake had lower risks of all-cause mortality (-19%; 3 studies), cardiovascular disease-related mortality (-18%; 10 studies), and cancer-related mortality (-25%; 2 studies) [(107)](#reference107).
