Am J Emerg Med. 1989;7(5):474-480. ] [(PubMed)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2787993/) Plant-based foods, including fruit, vegetables, legumes, whole grains, and nuts, are prominent features of healthy dietary patterns. In addition to providing energy and essential micronutrients, plant-based foods contribute thousands of biologically active phytochemicals (plant chemicals that may affect health) to the human diet. While there is ample evidence to support the health benefits of diets rich in fruit, vegetables, legumes, whole grains, and nuts, evidence that these effects are due to specific nutrients or phytochemicals is limited. Although scientists are very interested in the potential for specific phytochemicals to prevent or treat disease, current scientific evidence suggests that plant-based foods are the healthiest phytochemical delivery system. Contents Despite disagreements regarding the optimal components of a healthy diet, the importance of fruit and vegetables is rather undisputed. The results of numerous [epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study) provide consistent evidence suggesting associations between diets rich in fruit and vegetables and lower [risks](../glossary#risk) of [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease). On the other hand, evidence that very high doses of individual [micronutrients](../glossary#micronutrient) or [phytochemicals](../glossary#phytochemical) found in fruit and vegetables can provide similar health benefits is inconsistent and relatively weak. In addition to essential micronutrients, fruit and vegetables contain thousands of biologically active phytochemicals that are likely to interact in a number of ways to prevent disease and promote health [(1)](#references). Fruit and vegetables are rich in [antioxidants](../glossary#antioxidant), which help protect the body from [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) induced by [pro-oxidants](../glossary#pro-oxidant). The best way to take advantage of these complex interactions is to eat a variety of fruit and vegetables. [Prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have consistently reported [inverse associations](../glossary#inverse-association) between high intakes of fruit and vegetables of [cardiovascular 2017 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of prospective cohort studies found a 16% lower risk of CVD with high versus low fruit and vegetable intake and an 8% lower risk with every 200 grams (g)/day increment in daily fruit and vegetable intake in a dose-response analysis [(2)](#reference2). Similar risk reductions were reported for daily 200-g increments in fruit and/or vegetable intake and risks of CHD and stroke [(2)](#reference2). However, regarding primary CVD prevention in high-risk subjects, evidence that increasing intakes of fruit and vegetable can improve cardiovascular risk factors is scarce because of a lack of long-term [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) [(5)](#reference5). In a small 12-week intervention study in 109 overweight adults at high risk for CVD, no differences in blood pressure and [serum](../glossary#serum) lipoprotein](../glossary#LDL) a [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation)) were found between participants consuming two (~160 g), four (~320 g), or seven (~560 g) daily servings of fruit and vegetables [(6)](#reference6). Nonetheless, adherence to the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet, which emphasizes fruit, vegetables, whole grains, poultry, fish, nuts, and low-fat dairy, was found to substantially lower [systolic](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure)/ [diastolic](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) blood pressures by 11.4/5.5 [mm Hg](../glossary#mm-Hg) in [hypertensive](../glossary#hypertension) and 3.5/2.1 mm Hg in [normotensive](../glossary#normotensive) people compared to a typical US diet (for additional information on the DASH diet, see the [National Institutes of Health](http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/health-topics/topics/dash/) website) [(7)](#reference7). Blood pressure lowering effectively reduces CVD risk [(8)](#reference8). Adherence to a Mediterranean-style dietary pattern, also characterized by high fruit and vegetable intake, might further contribute to preventing cardiovascular events in healthy and high-risk subjects through normalizing total and LDL-cholesterol concentrations in the circulation [(9)](#reference9). A number of compounds may play a part in the cardioprotective effects of fruit and vegetables, including individual micronutrients or phytochemicals has not generally resulted in significantly decreased incidence of cardiovascular events in [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial). Thus, in the case of fruit and vegetables, the benefit of the whole may be greater than the sum of its parts. Of note, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the daily consumption of >400 g of fruit and vegetables as part of a healthy diet low in fat, sugar, and salt (sodium chloride), in order to minimize the risk of certain non-communicable diseases like CVD and type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) [(12)](#reference12). Nearly 10% of the US population is affected by type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) and another 34% has [impaired glucose control](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance) (prediabetes) that places them at high [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing type 2 diabetes [(13)](#reference13). Adherence to a Mediterranean-style or Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet — both rich in vegetables, [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes), fruit, and [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts) — has been associated with a lower risk of developing type 2 diabetes [(14)](#reference14). Yet, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) failed to find any association between intakes of vegetables, legumes, fruit, or nuts and the risk of type 2 diabetes [(15)](#reference15). In contrast, high intakes of whole-grain and dairy foods were linked to a lower risk of type 2 diabetes, while consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages and red and processed meat were associated with an increased risk of diabetes [(15)](#reference15). Whether evidence for a potential protective effect of fruit and vegetables regarding type 2 diabetes is more easily detectable when they are combined with other food groups within a diet rather than when their effect is singled out is unclear. A recent meta-analysis of 12 [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) and two prospective cohort studies found a 27% lower risk of type 2 diabetes with the consumption of a vegetarian diet [(16)](#reference16). Yet, it is unclear whether the potential benefit of such a diet is linked to the fact that it does not include foods that are associated with a higher diabetes risk (i.e., red and processed meat) and/or because of the inclusion of foods like fruit and vegetables that may be protective. Nevertheless, in the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and nutrition (EPIC)-Norfolk, a prospective study that followed 3,704 participants for nearly 11 years, a lower risk of type 2 diabetes was linked to higher intakes of vegetables (but not fruit), as well as with a greater diversity of consumed fruit and vegetables [(17)](#reference17). A dose-response analysis found an 8% lower risk of diabetes with every increase of two items added to the variety of fruit or vegetables consumed each week [(17)](#reference17). A follow-up study also showed that a composite score reflecting fruit and vegetable consumption, derived from circulating concentrations of vitamin C, -carotene, and lutein, was also [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with the risk of type 2 diabetes in this cohort [(18)](#reference18). Without changes in lifestyle behavior, especially regarding dietary habits and physical activity, individuals with prediabetes will eventually progress to develop overt type 2 diabetes. Strategies promoting healthier eating habits to improve glucose control usually encourage the consumption of more fruit and vegetables and the concomitant reduction of sugar and fat intake. The American Diabetes Association does not specifically emphasize an increase in fruit and vegetable intake for diabetes prevention yet recommends dietary strategies that include reducing caloric and fat intake, as well as increasing intake of whole-grain foods and dietary fiber that can be sourced in fruit and vegetables [(19)](#reference19). A plethora of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) has investigated the relationship between intakes of fruit and vegetables and [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing site-specific [cancers](../glossary#cancer). A 2014 report summarized the findings of 27 studies that examined fruit and vegetable consumption in relation to incidental cancer in participants of the ongoing, multicenter European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and nutrition (EPIC) study [(20)](#reference20). This report found the highest versus lowest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of fruit intake (356 g/day vs. 89 g/day) to be associated with a 40% lower risk of oropharyngeal, [laryngeal](../glossary#larynx), and [esophageal](../glossary#esophagus) cancers and a 20% lower risk of lung cancer. No associations were observed between fruit intake and cancers of the lymphatic system, stomach, [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas), breast, cervix, [prostate](../glossary#prostate), or bladder. There were also no inverse associations between intakes of vegetables and risk of cancer. More recently published EPIC data analyses also failed to find significant inverse associations between fruit and/or vegetable intakes and risk of thyroid carcinoma [(24)](#reference24). Further, mixed results from recent [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of observational studies are reported in Table 1, with significant associations noted in bold. Some of the discrepancies might be attributed to study design. Compared to prospective cohort studies, which collect dietary information from participants before they are diagnosed with cancer, retrospective [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) are more susceptible to [bias](../glossary#bias) in the selection of participants (cases and controls) and with dietary recall [(25)](#reference25). For example, this might explain why fruit intake is associated with the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma in the meta-analysis of six case-control studies but not in that of three cohort studies in the meta-analysis by Li et al. [(26)](#reference26). Inaccurate measurements (introducing measurement bias) and changes in the diet during follow-up in [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) may also contribute to reporting associations that are proven spurious or to missing true associations. A 2012 meta-analysis of prospective studies suggested that, when compared to direct measurements of [plasma](../glossary#plasma) carotenoids, the use of a [food-frequency questionnaire](../glossary#food-frequency-questionnaire) to assess carotenoid intake introduced measurements errors that led to underestimating the strength of the association between carotenoid intake and reduced breast cancer risk [(27)](#reference27). |Type of Cancer||References||Highest versus Lowest Quantile of Intake||Type cancer types|| Aune et al. (2017) | Additional evidence from observational studies, discussed in MIC articles focusing specifically on [cruciferous vegetables](../food-beverages/cruciferous-vegetables), [garlic](../food-beverages/garlic), [carotenoid](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/carotenoids)-rich vegetables, and [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes) suggests that high intakes of certain classes of vegetables are associated with reduced risk of individual cancers. The 2007 report from the World Cancer Research Fund International (WCRF)/American Institute for Cancer Research (AICR) concluded that fruit and non-starchy vegetables were probably protective against some cancers, recommending a daily consumption of five portions (400 g; based on an average portion weighing 80 g) of a variety of vegetables and fruit [(40)](#reference40). AICR continuously collates evidence from cohort and [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) through its Continuous Update Project (CUP), and updated CUP-derived Cancer Prevention Recommendations are expected to be published in late 2017 [(41)](#reference41). Fruit and vegetables are rich in [precursors](../glossary#precursor) of bicarbonate ions (HCO3-), which serve to buffer [acids](../glossary#acidic) in the body. When the quantity of bicarbonate ions is insufficient to maintain normal [pH](../glossary#pH), the body is capable of mobilizing [alkaline](../glossary#alkaline) calcium salts from bone in order to neutralize acids consumed in the diet and generated by [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [(42)](#reference42). It has been [hypothesized](../glossary#hypothesis) that higher consumption of fruit and vegetables could help reduce the net acid content of the diet and preserve [calcium](../minerals/calcium) in bones, which might otherwise be mobilized to maintain normal pH to the detriment of bone health. Results from the ancillary DASH-Sodium study, which emphasizes the intake of fruit, vegetables, whole-grain foods, and low-fat dairy, supported a beneficial link between bone health and fruit and vegetable intake. Compared to a control diet, one month-administration of the DASH diet to (pre)hypertensive middle-aged adults significantly lowered the rate of bone turnover, as shown by reduced [serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of osteocalcin (OC), a marker of bone formation released by [osteoblasts](../glossary#osteoblast) into circulation during the mineralization of newly [synthesized](../glossary#synthesis) [collagen](../glossary#collagen). C-terminal telopeptide of type 1 collagen (CTX) — a marker of bone resorption released from bone collagen into circulation following bone degradation by osteoclasts — was also decreased [(43)](#reference43). However, more recent [randomized controlled interventions](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found no effect of increasing fruit and vegetable intake on markers of bone turnover [(44-46)](#reference44). The results of a [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 276 healthy postmenopausal women suggested that supplementing the diet with alkali, either through [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) potassium citrate or an additional 300 g/day of fruit and vegetables, did not reduce bone turnover, increase [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) (BMD), or blunt the age-associated bone loss over a two-year period [(45)](#reference45). The effect of five portions of fruit and vegetables on measures of dietary acid/base balance and bone turnover markers was also reported as a secondary outcome in the Ageing and Dietary Intervention Trial that included 83 healthy older participants (ages, 65-85 years) [(46)](#reference46). Compared to habitual fruit and vegetable intakes of 2 portions/day, the consumption of five portions per day for 16 weeks increased the alkalinity of the diet but failed to reduce markers of bone turnover [(46)](#reference46). There were also no significant reductions in circulating bone turnover markers in postmenopausal women with [osteopenia](../glossary#osteopenia) supplemented with six extra servings of fruit and vegetables per day (~400 g/day) for 12 weeks [(44)](#reference44). Several [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have examined intakes of fruit and vegetables in relation to [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) (BMD) in men and women, providing mixed results (reviewed in [47](#reference47)). In an early [cross-sectional analysis](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) of the longitudinal Framingham Osteoporosis Study in elderly adults (mean age, 75 years), baseline intakes of fruit and vegetables were positively associated with BMD at various sites, including trochanter, femoral neck, and radius [(48)](#reference48). Baseline fruit and vegetable intakes were also positively associated with longitudinal changes of trochanter BMD over four years in elderly men but not elderly women [(48, 49)](#reference48). Two recent cross-sectional studies in Chinese cohorts reported positive relationships between BMD and intakes of fruit rather than vegetables [(50, 51)](#reference50). In the cross-sectional analysis of two Hong-Kong-based cohorts of 3,995 older participants (65 years), higher daily intakes of fruit — but not vegetables — were associated with significantly higher whole-body and femoral neck BMD in men and women [(50)](#reference50). The cross-sectional study of 3,089 Chinese adults (ages, 40-75 years) reported positive associations between whole-body, total hip, and femoral neck BMD and higher intakes of apples, pears, peaches, pineapples, plums, and to a lesser extent, citrus fruit [(51)](#reference51). However, the two-year supplementation of 300 g/day of fruit and vegetables failed to reduce BMD loss in healthy postmenopausal women [(45)](#reference45). A pooled analysis of data from several [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), including the EPIC-Elderly Greece (9,534 participants), EPIC-Elderly Sweden (3,276 participants), Cohort of Men (COSM; 20,150 men), Swedish Mammography Cohort (SMC; 17,506 women), Study (NHS; women), a 39% higher [risk](../glossary#risk) of hip [fracture](../glossary#fracture) with intakes of fruit and vegetables 1 serving/day compared to 4-5 daily servings [(52)](#reference52). Further subgroup analysis linked higher hip fracture risk specifically with low intakes of vegetables rather than fruit. Finally, compared to 4-5 daily servings of fruit and vegetables, there was no reduction in hip fracture risk with intakes greater than 5 servings/day [(52)](#reference52). The consumption of fruit and vegetables has been recently examined in relation to 415 fracture-related hospitalizations identified during a 14.5-year follow-up of 1,468 elderly participants (70 years) of the Perth Longitudinal Study of Aging in Women (PLSAW) [(53)](#reference53). Whereas no association was found between fruit intakes and fracture risk, high versus low intake of total vegetables (3 servings/day versus <2 servings/day) was associated with a 27% reduced risk of all fractures and a 39% reduced risk of hip fractures. Further analyses suggested an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between consumption of allium vegetables (onion, leek, and garlic) and risk of fracture [(53)](#reference53). Although observational studies suggest a positive relationship between diets rich in fruit and vegetables and bone health during aging, [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) are needed to examine the nature of this association. [Cataracts](../glossary#cataract) are thought to be caused by [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) of [proteins](../glossary#protein) in the eye's [lens](../glossary#lens) induced by long-term exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light [(54)](#reference54). The resulting cloudiness and discoloration of the lens leads to vision loss that becomes more severe with age. A 2015 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) found a 28% lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of age-related cataracts with the highest versus lowest intakes of vegetables [(55)](#reference55). In a large Swedish [prospective study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) that followed 30,607 middle-aged and elderly women for a mean 7.7 years, the risk of age-related cataracts has been examined in relation to the estimated total [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) capacity of the diet [(56)](#reference56). Higher versus lower estimates of total dietary antioxidant capacity were associated with a 13% lower risk of cataracts. Subgroup analyses showed that this [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) was statistically significant in women younger than 65 years and in [corticosteroid](../glossary#corticosteroid) users [(56)](#reference56). Pooled analyses of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) that investigated the relationships between individual nutrients with antioxidant properties and the risk of cataracts have also suggested a lower risk of cataracts with higher intakes or higher blood concentrations of [vitamin C](../vitamins/vitamin-C), [vitamin A](../vitamins/vitamin-A), or -carotene, although the results vary according to study design (i.e., [case-control](../glossary#case-control-study) versus [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) versus longitudinal) [(57, 58)](#reference57). However, a 2012 review of nine [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) found no substantial effect of -carotene, vitamin C, and [vitamin E](../vitamins/vitamin-E), administered individually or in combination over 2.1 to 12 years, on the risk of cataracts or cataract surgery [(59)](#reference59). In addition, a large [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 5,802 subjects at high risk for [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) recently reported no difference in cataract surgery incidence over a seven-year follow-up period between participants assigned to a Mediterranean diet that included the whole range of antioxidant nutrients and those assigned to a control diet [(60)](#reference60). A secondary analysis reported a 29% lower cataract surgery risk in participants in the highest versus lowest [tertile](../glossary#tertile) of [vitamin K1](../vitamins/vitamin-K) intake [(61)](#reference61). In industrialized countries, degeneration of the [macula](../glossary#macula), located in the center of the [retina](../glossary#retina), is the leading cause of blindness in older adults [(62)](#reference62). Long-term light exposure and [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) in the outer segments of photoreceptors may lead to [drusen](../glossary#drusen) and/or pigment abnormalities in the macula, increasing the [risk](../glossary#risk) of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and central blindness. Several recent [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have examined AMD [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence), incidence, progression, or severity in relation to dietary patterns. Most of them used constructed scoring systems reflecting the level of adherence to specific dietary patterns by individuals. The European Eye (EUREYE) study examined associations between the prevalence of AMD and dietary patterns among 4,753 individuals from seven European countries. Adherence to the Mediterranean diet was assessed using a Mediterranean Diet Score system that captured high intakes of key food items, such as olive oil, wine, fruit, vegetables or salad, fish, and [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes), and low intakes of meat. High adherence to the Mediterranean Diet was associated with a reduced risk of developing large drusen, but there was no association with the risk of early or advanced AMD [(63)](#reference63). In the Carotenoids in the Age-Related Eye Disease Study (CAREDS) that included 1,313 US women (ages, 50-79 years), high adherence to a Mediterranean-like dietary pattern characterized by high intakes of fruit, vegetables, [whole grains](../food-beverages/whole-grains), legumes, [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts), and fish, and moderate intakes of red meat and [alcohol](../food-beverages/alcoholic-beverages), were found to be associated with a 66% lower risk of early AMD [(64)](#reference64). This Mediterranean-like dietary pattern, which is closer to dietary patterns occurring in the US, was also associated with a 26% lower risk of progression to advanced AMD in 2,525 subjects followed for a mean 8.7 years in the Age-Related Eye Disease Study (AREDS) [(65)](#reference65). Of note, this association was no longer valid when the analysis was restricted to individuals with a genetically determined susceptibility to AMD, i.e., those [homozygous](../glossary#homozygous) for the risk [allele](../glossary#allele) of the complement factor H [CFH] [gene](../glossary#gene) (rs1410996) [(65)](#reference65). [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) that from 4,088 AREDS participants, among whom 2,739 had no AMD, 4,599 had early AMD, and 765 had advanced AMD, identified two main dietary patterns: so-called "Oriental" and "Western" patterns [(66)](#reference66). High adherence to the "Oriental" dietary pattern characterized by consumption of vegetables, legumes, fruit, fish, whole grains, poultry, and low-fat dairy products was associated with lower risks of early and advanced AMD. In contrast, higher risks of early and advanced AMD were found in individuals with high adherence to a "Western" diet that included red and processed meat, potatoes, French fries, butter, high-fat dairy products, eggs, refined grains, and sweets and desserts [(66)](#reference66). Among observational studies that focused on individual food groups or nutrients, some have suggested that high intakes of fruit, vegetables, or [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) nutrients, such as [vitamin C](../vitamins/vitamin-C), [vitamin E](../vitamins/vitamin-E), and [carotenoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/carotenoids), might be protective against In two early [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study), high intakes of dark-green leafy vegetables especially rich in lutein and zeaxanthin, two carotenoids present in the retina, were associated with a significantly lower risk of developing AMD [(67, 68)](#reference67). In a [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) of more than 118,000 men and women, those who consumed 3 servings/day of fruit had a 36% lower risk of developing AMD over the next 12 to 18 years than those who consumed <1.5 servings/day [(69)](#reference69). Interestingly, vegetable intake was not associated with the risk of AMD in this cohort. Another study combining lutein and zeaxanthin intake was not associated with the prevalence of intermediate AMD in a cohort of women aged 50-79 years [(70)](#reference70). However, further analysis of the data revealed that women younger than 75 years with stable intakes of lutein and zeaxanthin had a 43% lower risk of developing intermediate AMD [(70)](#reference70). In the AREDS trial, oral [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with -carotene (15 mg/day), vitamin C (500 mg/day), vitamin E (400 IU/day), [zinc](../minerals/zinc) (80 mg/day as zinc oxide), and [copper](../minerals/copper) (2 mg/day as cupric oxide) for five years was shown to reduce the risk of developing advanced AMD by 25% [(71)](#reference71). In a follow-up study — the AREDS2 trial — supplemental lutein (10 mg/day) and zeaxanthin (2 mg/day) in combination with the 'AREDS formulation' only reduced the risk of progression to late AMD in the subset of participants with the lowest dietary intakes of lutein and zeaxanthin [(72)](#reference72). A more detailed account of the [epidemiological](../glossary#epidemiological-study) evidence regarding the relationship between dietary and supplemental carotenoids and AMD risk can be found in the article on [ Carotenoids](http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/dietary-factors/phytochemicals/carotenoids#eye-diseases-prevention). [Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease](../glossary#chronic-obstructive-pulmonary-disease) (COPD) is a condition that combines [emphysema](../glossary#emphysema) and [chronic bronchitis](../glossary#bronchitis), two chronic lung conditions that are characterized by airway obstruction. Smoking and indoor/outdoor pollution are considered to be primary contributors to COPD development, but dietary patterns low in fruit and vegetables and providing inadequate [vitamin](../glossary#vitamin) intakes may also affect lung function and [risk](../glossary#risk) for COPD (reviewed in [73, 74](#reference73)). Early [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) in Europe indicated that higher fruit intakes, especially apple intakes, were associated with higher spirometric values (including forced expiratory volume in 1 second [FEV1]), indicative of better lung function [(75-77)](#reference75). In a [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) of 2,500 middle-aged Welsh men, slower declines in lung function were associated with the consumption of at least five apples weekly compared to no consumption [(76)](#reference76). Another study of 2,917 European men followed over 20 years found that each 100 g (3.5 oz) increase in daily fruit consumption was associated with a 24% lower risk of COPD-related mortality [(78)](#reference78). Additionally, when compared to a Western dietary pattern of refined grains, cured and red meats, French fries, and desserts, a prudent diet emphasizing fruit, vegetables, fish, and [whole grains](../food-beverages/whole-grains) was associated with a 25%-50% lower risk of COPD in two large cohorts of men [(79)](#reference79) and women [(80)](#reference80). In a large [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) that followed 44,335 Swedish men (mean age, 60.2 years) for a mean 13.2 years, the highest versus lowest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) (5.3 servings/day versus <2 servings/day) of fruit and vegetable intakes was associated with a 35% lower risk of developing COPD [(81)](#reference81). Subgroup analyses showed that fruit and vegetable intakes were [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with COPD risk in current and former smokers, but not in men who never smoked. Because [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) and [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) play key roles in the [etiology](../glossary#etiology) of chronic obstructive lung disease, it has been suggested that fruit and vegetables high in [antioxidants](../glossary#antioxidant), such as [vitamin C](../vitamins/vitamin-C), -carotene, or [flavonoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/flavonoids), could play protective role against COPD. A three-year [randomized controlled study](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 120 patients with COPD (mean age, 68.1 years) assigned to a diet rich in antioxidants, such as fresh fruit, fruit juice, and vegetables, or a control diet has provided support for the antioxidant [hypothesis](../glossary#hypothesis) [(82)](#reference82). Shifting to a higher consumption of fruit and vegetables prevented the decline of lung function observed in subjects who consumed the control diet [(82)](#reference82). Environment and lifestyle changes, including shifts toward unhealthy diets, are thought to contribute to the increasing [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of [asthma](../glossary#asthma) and allergic diseases in industrialized countries. [Observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) that examined asthma and allergic symptoms in relation to fruit and vegetable intakes have provided mixed results [(83)](#reference83). A [cross-sectional analysis](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) of a population-based study in 32,644 Portuguese adults identified five dietary patterns, of which one included fish, fruit, and vegetables — three essential components of the Mediterranean diet. This dietary pattern was found to be [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with self-reported asthma symptoms and self-reported use of asthma drugs — yet not with self-reported medical diagnosis of asthma [(84)](#reference84). In contrast, the most recent cross-sectional study of 3,202 participants in the European Global Allergy and Asthma Network of Excellence (GA2LEN) showed no association between fruit and vegetable intake and [risk](../glossary#risk) of asthma and chronic rhino-sinusitis [(85)](#reference85). A 2017 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) identified 58 studies (in addition to the two above-cited studies) reporting fruit and vegetable intake in relation to lung function, wheeze, or asthma, of which 30 were cross-sectional studies and 41 conducted in children and/or adolescents [(83)](#reference83). A majority of studies (8 in adults and 22 in children) reported inverse associations between diets high in fruit and vegetables and risk of asthma and/or wheeze: 20 studies (8 in adults and 12 in children) showed that intakes of either fruit or vegetables were inversely associated with asthma and/or wheeze, and eight studies (one in adults and seven in children) found no associations. Pooled data analyses showed an inverse association between vegetable intake and risk of asthma, as well as fruit intake and asthma severity and risk of wheeze [(83)](#reference83). A previous [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of observational studies reported lower risks of wheeze and asthma with higher intakes of fruit and vegetables in adults and children in cross-sectional studies, but not all [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have supported these findings [(86)](#reference86). Subgroup analyses also suggested inverse associations between intakes of apples, citrus fruit, and tomatoes and risks of wheeze and asthma. Finally, pooled analyses of prospective cohort studies have revealed no association between fruit or vegetable intake during pregnancy and risk of wheeze or asthma in the offspring [(86)](#reference86). Results from most [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) and longitudinal studies suggest that diets rich in fruit and vegetables might help prevent age-related [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) deterioration and reduce the [risk](../glossary#risk) of 11 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) [(88)](#reference88), of which four examined fruit and vegetable intakes in relation to incidence of neurodegenerative diseases. All four prospective studies reported [inverse associations](../glossary#inverse-association) between consumption of fruit and vegetables and risk of developing mild cognitive impairments or [dementia](../glossary#dementia), including AD [(89-92)](#reference89). Among the seven prospective cohort studies positively linking fruit and vegetable intakes to better cognitive performance (reviewed in [88](#reference88)), a two-year follow-up of 13,388 women (mean age, 74 years) in the Nurses' Health Study (NHS) found less cognitive decline in those in the highest versus lowest intakes of green leafy vegetables, [cruciferous vegetables](../food-beverages/cruciferous-vegetables), and [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes) [(93)](#reference93). Fruit consumption was not associated with changes in cognitive performance in this study [(93)](#reference93). However, a more recently published NHS study in 16,010 women analyzed intakes of major [flavonoid](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/flavonoids)-containing foods in relation to cognitive test scores and reported less cognitive decline with higher long-term intakes of strawberries and blueberries [(94)](#reference94). Finally, a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 13 prospective cohort studies showed better global [cognition](../glossary#cognition) in healthy older adults consuming the Mediterranean diet compared to control diets. In contrast, there were no differences in measures of episodic, semantic, and working memory between diets [(95)](#reference95). To date, only a few [interventions](../glossary#intervention-trial) have examined the overall effect of fruit- and vegetable-rich diets on [cognition](../glossary#cognition) in cognitively healthy older adults. One trial assessed cognitive changes in 334 older adults (mean age, 66.9 years) at high risk for [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) (CVD) randomly assigned to either a Mediterranean diet supplemented with extra-virgin olive oil, a Mediterranean diet supplemented with [nuts](../food-beverages/nuts), or a control diet [(96)](#reference96). Following a median of 4.1 years, both Mediterranean diets prevented the deterioration of cognitive function that was observed in those ascribed the control diet. Compared to participants in the control diet group, those who followed the Mediterranean diet plus nuts had improved composite cognitive test scores for memory, while those in the Mediterranean diet plus olive oil group had better composite scores for frontal function and global cognition [(96)](#reference96). However, in a six-month trial in 137 CVD-free Australian adults (mean age, 72 years), consumption of a Mediterranean diet rich in fruit, [legumes](../food-beverages/legumes), dairy, nuts, olive oil, and seafood did not result in improved cognitive function — measured by a battery of 13 neuropsychological tests — compared to the habitual diet [(97, 98)](#reference97). Because regular consumption of fruit and vegetables may reduce the [risk](../glossary#risk) of some [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease), it may also improve overall health and longevity. A 2017 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 95 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) found that daily consumption of fruit and vegetables was [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with cause-specific and all-cause mortality [(2)](#reference2). The risk of all-cause mortality was found to be 24% lower with five daily serving of fruit and vegetables combined (~400 mg/day) compared to little or no daily intake of fruit and vegetables. Five daily servings of fruit and vegetables were also associated with lower risks of [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular)-related (-19%) and [cancer](../glossary#cancer)-related (-12%) mortality. In addition, the risk of all-cause mortality was lower with higher intakes of specific types of fruit and vegetables. There was evidence of lower risk of all-cause mortality with the highest versus lowest intake level of apples (-20%), berries (-8%), citrus fruit (-10%), cruciferous vegetables (-12%), and green leafy vegetables (-8%). This meta-analysis further reported a reduced risk of all-cause mortality with both cooked (-13%) and raw vegetable (-12%) intakes [(2)](#reference2). Although the Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommend fresh, frozen, and canned fruit equally, the consumption of the latter has been associated with increased risks of all-cause and cardiovascular related mortality in a pooled analysis of three UK-based prospective studies found with consumption of tinned fruit [(99)](#reference99). While added sugar content in tinned fruit or exposure to bisphenol A (a chemical component of tin cans) may explain these results, further studies are needed to clarify whether fresh fruit and canned fruit can provide similar health benefits when included as part of a healthy diet. Finally, although increasing daily intakes of fruit and vegetables would very likely reduce the number of premature deaths caused by cardiovascular disease and cancer in the US population, it is estimated that about 8 in 10 Americans do not meet the current intake recommendations [(100)](#reference100). The 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans — issued jointly by the US Department of Health and Human Services and the US Department of Agriculture — recommend to consume a healthy diet which includes, among other things, a variety of vegetables from all of the subgroups and fruit, especially whole fruit [(101)](#reference101). In the 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans, the unit of measure of a fruit or vegetable serving size is the cup-equivalent (c-eq). In general, one cup-equivalent of fruit corresponds to (1) one cup of cut-up, raw, or canned fruit; (2) one cup (eight fluid ounces) of 100% fruit juice; or (3) one-half cup of dried fruit. Contents Cruciferous or Brassica vegetables come from plants in the family known to botanists and biologists as Cruciferae or alternately, Brassicaceae. The Brassicaceae family, which includes the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana, comprises approximately 375 genera and over 3,000 species [(1)](#references). Many, but not all, commonly consumed cruciferous vegetables come from the Brassica genus; examples include broccoli, turnips, bok choy, and Chinese cabbage vegetables are unique in that they are a rich source of sulfur-containing compounds called glucosinolates (-thioglucoside N-hydroxysulfates) that impart a pungent aroma and spicy (some say bitter) taste (Figure 1). Glucosinolates can be classified into three categories based on the chemical structure of their [amino gluconasturtiin) (Figure 1) [(1)](#references). Around 130 glucosinolate structures have been described to date [(3)](#reference3), but only a subset can be found in the human diet. In a cohort of 2,121 German participants in the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC study), glucobrassicin, sinigrin, glucoraphasatin (dehydroerucin), glucoraphanin, and glucoiberin were most to total glucosinolate intake [(4)](#reference4). Glucosinolates and their breakdown derivatives ( [metabolites](../glossary#metabolite)), especially [isothiocyanates](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/isothiocyanates) and [indole-3-carbinol](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/indole-3-carbinol), exert a variety of biological activities that may be relevant to health promotion and disease prevention in humans (see the MIC articles on [Indole-3-Carbinol](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/indole-3-carbinol) and [Isothiocyanates](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/isothiocyanates)). The [hydrolysis](../glossary#hydrolysis) of glucosinolates, which is [catalyzed](../glossary#catalyst) by a class of [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) called myrosinases (-thioglucosidases), leads to the formation of breakdown such thiocyanates, isothiocyanates, indoles, oxazolidine-2-thiones (e.g., goitrin), epithionitrile, and nitrile (Figure 2). In intact plant cells, myrosinase is physically separated from glucosinolates. Yet, when plant cells are damaged, myrosinase is released and comes in contact with glucosinolates, catalyzing their conversion into highly reactive [metabolites](../glossary#metabolite). In plants, isothiocyanates, epithionitrile, and against [pathogens](../glossary#pathogen), insects, and herbivores [(1)](#references). When raw cruciferous vegetables are chopped during the cooking process, glucosinolates are rapidly hydrolyzed by myrosinase, generating metabolites that are then absorbed in the proximal intestine. In contrast, boiling cruciferous vegetables before consumption inactivates myrosinase, thus preventing the breakdown of glucosinolates. A small fraction of intact glucosinolates may be absorbed in the [small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine), but a large proportion reaches the [colon](../glossary#colon) [(5)](#reference5). Of note, boiling cruciferous vegetables has also been found to reduce their glucosinolate content to a much greater extent than steam cooking, microwaving, and stir-frying do [(5)](#reference5). Nonetheless, when cruciferous vegetables are cooked, [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) myrosinase-like activity in the colon is mainly responsible for glucosinolate degradation, generating a wide range of metabolites [(5, 6)](#reference5). A neutral [pH](../glossary#pH) may favor the formation of isothiocyanates from glucosinolates (Figure 2). Once absorbed, isothiocyanates, such as glucoraphanin-derived sulforaphane, are [conjugated](../glossary#conjugation) to [glutathione](../glossary#glutathione) in the liver, and then sequentially metabolized in the mercapturic acid pathway (Figure — sulforaphane-glutathione, sulforaphane-cysteine-glycine, sulforaphane-cysteine, and sulforaphane N-acetylcysteine — collectively known as dithiocarbamates, are ultimately [excreted](../glossary#excretion) in the urine [(5)](#reference5). The composition and content of glucosinolates in cruciferous vegetables are relatively stable, yet depend on the genus and species and can vary with plant growing and post-harvest storage conditions and culinary processing [(7, 8)](#reference7). Since most cruciferous vegetables are cooked prior to eating, [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) myrosinase-like activity in the gut rather than plant myrosinase is responsible for the initial step in glucosinolate degradation (Figure 2). In a feeding study involving 45 healthy subjects, the mean conversion rate of glucosinolates (of which 85% was glucoraphanin) to dithiocarbamates over a 24-hour period was estimated to be around 12% with wide variations among participants (range, 1.1 to 40.7%) [(7)](#reference7). In contrast, 70%-75% of ingested isothiocyanates were found to be [metabolized](../glossary#metabolism) to dithiocarbamates. Therefore, following the ingestion of cooked cruciferous vegetables, the conversion of glucosinolates into isothiocyanates by gut bacteria appears to be a limiting step in the generation of dithiocarbamates [(7)](#reference7). However, differences in individuals' capacity to metabolize glucosinolates have not been linked to differences in gut [microbiota](../glossary#intenstinal-microbiota) composition [(9)](#reference9). Like most other vegetables, cruciferous vegetables are good sources of a variety of nutrients and [phytochemicals](../glossary#phytochemical) that synergistically contribute to health promotion (see [Bioactive compounds in cruciferous vegetables](#bioactive-compounds)) [(10)](#reference10). One challenge in studying the relationships between cruciferous vegetable intake and disease [risk](../glossary#risk) in humans is dissociating the benefits of whole diets that are generally rich in vegetables from those that are specifically rich in cruciferous vegetables [(11)](#reference11). One characteristic that sets cruciferous vegetables apart from other vegetables is their high glucosinolate content (see [Introduction](#introduction)). Glucosinolate [hydrolysis](../glossary#hydrolysis) products may play important roles in disease prevention by triggering [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) and anti-inflammatory response and contributing to the maintenance of cell [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) (see the MIC articles on [Isothiocyanates](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/isothiocyanates) and [Indole-3-Carbinol](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/indole-3-carbinol)). Once absorbed, glucosinolate-derived isothiocyanates (like sulforaphane) are promptly [conjugated](../glossary#conjugation) to [glutathione](../glossary#glutathione) by a class of phase II detoxification [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) known as glutathione S-transferases (GSTs) (Figure 3). This mechanism is meant to increase the solubility of [isothiocyanates](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/isothiocyanates), thereby promoting a rapid [excretion](../glossary#excretion) in the urine. Isothiocyanates are thought to play a prominent role in the potential anticancer and [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) benefits associated with cruciferous vegetable consumption [(12, 13)](#reference12). Genetic variations in the sequence of [genes](../glossary#gene) coding for GSTs may affect the activity of these enzymes. Such variations have been identified in humans. Specifically, null variants of the GSTM1 and GSTT1 [alleles](../glossary#allele) contain large deletions, and individuals who inherit two copies of the GSTM1-null or GSTT1-null alleles cannot produce the corresponding GST enzymes [(14)](#reference14). It has been proposed that a reduced GST activity in these individuals would slow the rate of excretion of isothiocyanates, thereby increasing tissue exposure to isothiocyanates after cruciferous vegetable consumption [(15)](#reference15). However, human interventional studies with watercress report there is no difference in the isothiocyanate excretion rate between positive (+/+) and null (-/-) genotypes [(16)](#reference16). Similar studies with broccoli have shown that GSTM1-/- individuals excreted a greater proportion of ingested sulforaphane via mercapturic acid metabolism than GSTM1+/+ individuals [(17, 18)](#reference17). In addition, GSTs are involved in "detoxifying" potentially harmful substances like [carcinogens](../glossary#carcinogen), suggesting that individuals with reduced GST activity might also be more susceptible to [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [(19-21)](#reference19). Finally, induction of the expression and activity of GSTs and other phase II detoxification/antioxidant enzymes by isothiocyanates is an important defense mechanism against [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) and [damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) associated with the development of diseases like cancer and [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) [(22)](#reference22). The ability of sulforaphane (glucoraphanin-derived isothiocyanate) to reduce oxidative stress in different settings is linked to activation of the nuclear factor E2-related factor 2 (Nrf2)-dependent pathway. Yet, whether potential protection conferred by isothiocyanates via the Nrf2-dependent pathway is diminished in individuals carrying GST-/- variants is currently unknown. Some, but not all, [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have found that GST [genotypes](../glossary#genotype) could influence the associations between isothiocyanate intake from cruciferous vegetables and [risk](../glossary#risk) of disease [(23)](#reference23). High intakes of [fruit and vegetables](fruit-vegetables) have been consistently reduced disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) (CVD) [(24, 25)](#reference24). Yet, few have specifically examined the potential benefits of cruciferous vegetable consumption. In the Shanghai Women's Health Study (mean follow-up, 10.2 years) and the Shanghai Men's Health Study (mean follow-up, 4.6 years), which included a total of 134,796 Chinese adults, participants in the highest versus lowest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of cruciferous vegetable intakes had a 22% reduced risk of all cause-mortality and a 31% reduced risk of CVD-related mortality [(26)](#reference26). In contrast, a pooled analysis of two large US [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), the Nurses' Health Study (70,870 women) and the Health Professionals' Follow-Up Study (38,918 men), found no significant association between cruciferous vegetable intake and combined risk of [myocardial infarction](../glossary#myocardial-infarction) (MI) [ischemic stroke](../glossary#ischemic-stroke) in 2,042 subjects <75 years) who survived a first acute myocardial infarction (MI), and matched healthy controls with no CVD history found that the individuals in the highest versus lowest [tertile](../glossary#tertile) of cruciferous vegetable intakes (6 times/week versus <1 time/week) had 27% lower odds of MI [(28)](#reference28). However, further analyses showed that the association between cruciferous vegetable intake and MI events was significant in individuals with two functional GSTT1 alleles but not in carriers of two alleles of the GSTT1 null variant (-/-) [(28)](#reference28). Analysis of data from two 12-week [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 130 participants with mild or moderate CVD risk found that the consumption of 400 g/week of high-glucosinolate broccoli (containing 3 to 6 times more glucoraphanin and glucoiberin than standard broccoli) resulted in a significant reduction in [low-density lipoprotein](../glossary#LDL) (LDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentration in [plasma](../glossary#plasma) compared with standard [(29)](#reference29). Whether the effect of glucosinolates on cholesterol [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) might be beneficial in the prevention of CVD needs further investigation. A recent [intervention study](../glossary#intervention-trial) demonstrated that cruciferous vegetables could increase the detoxification of [carcinogens](../glossary#carcinogen) and other [xenobiotics](../glossary#xenobiotic) in humans. In this 12-week [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 391 healthy Chinese adults exposed to high levels of air pollution, daily consumption of a broccoli sprout-rich beverage (providing 600 µmol/day of glucoraphanin and 40 µmol/day of sulforaphane) significantly increased the urinary [excretion](../glossary#excretion) of a known [carcinogen](../glossary#carcinogen), benzene, and a toxicant, acrolein, compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(20)](#reference20). The biological activities of isothiocyanates and which include modulation but also [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) and anti-inflammatory properties, induction of cell cycle arrest and [apoptosis](../glossary#apoptosis), and inhibition of [angiogenesis](../glossary#angiogenesis), likely contribute to the potential benefits of cruciferous vegetables in the prevention of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) (see the MIC articles on [Isothiocyanates](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/isothiocyanates) and [Indole-3-Carbinol](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/indole-3-carbinol)) [(23)](#reference23). Numerous [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have examined the relationship between cruciferous vegetable intake and [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [risk](../glossary#risk). [Retrospective](../glossary#retrospective-study) case-control studies are susceptible to [bias](../glossary#bias) in the selection of participants (cases and controls) and prone to dietary recall bias compared to prospective cohort studies, which collect dietary information from participants before they are diagnosed with cancer [(47)](#reference47). The method of cooking cruciferous vegetables, which strongly affects the [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) and potential anticancer benefits of isothiocyanates (see [Metabolism and Bioavailability of Glucosinolates](#metabolism-bioavailability-glucosinolates)) may be a source of bias and explain variation in the results of the studies ( [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) among studies). The lack of information regarding cooking methods prevented data adjustment to reduce bias. In the past decades, some observational studies have examined the effect of individuals' genetic variations on the relationship between cruciferous vegetable intake and the risk of different cancer types. For example, a pooled analysis of two prospective cohort studies and six case-control studies found an inverse association between cruciferous vegetable consumption and risk of colorectal neoplasm in carriers of the GSTT1 null variant but not in individuals with the GSTM1 null variant or those with both the GSTT1and GSTM1 null variants (-/-) [(36)](#reference36). The results of a pooled analysis of five case-control studies also suggested a stronger association between cruciferous vegetable intake and lung cancer in carriers of both the GSTT1-/- and GSTM1-/- variants compared to carriers of wild-type [alleles](../glossary#allele) (+/+); however, it was not reported whether results from these two groups of individuals were significantly different [(39)](#reference39). There is also a significant body of evidence suggesting that GSTM1+/+ individuals gain greater cancer protection from consumption total cruciferous vegetables or broccoli compared to GSTM1-/- variant carriers [(25](#reference25), [48, 49)](#reference48). Current evidence is scarce, and adequately powered, well-designed studies are required to assess and explain potential interactions between cruciferous vegetable intake and GST [genotypes](../glossary#genotype). A few observational studies have looked at whether cruciferous vegetable intake could be associated with reduced risks of disease progression and mortality. The highest versus lowest intake of cruciferous vegetables (assessed before diagnosis) was associated with a better survival rate over 72 months after diagnosis in 547 women with lung cancer [(50)](#reference50). A prospective study in 29,361 men who underwent a [prostate-specific antigen](../glossary#prostate-specific-antigen) (PSA) test found that intake of cruciferous vegetables was inversely associated with risk of [metastatic](../glossary#metastasis) prostate cancer — cancer that has spread beyond the prostate (i.e., late-stage prostate cancer) — during a mean follow-up of 4.2 years [(51)](#reference51). Another prospective study in 1,560 men diagnosed with non-metastatic prostate cancer reported that higher post-diagnosis intake of cruciferous vegetables was associated with a 59% lower risk of prostate cancer progression during a two-year period after completion of the dietary assessment [(52)](#reference52). In contrast, cruciferous vegetable consumption in a cohort of 11,390 women with stage I-III invasive breast cancer (from four US and Chinese prospective studies), assessed about two years after diagnosis, was not found to be associated with risk of cancer recurrence or total mortality [(53)](#reference53). Very high intakes of cruciferous vegetables, such as cabbage and turnips, have been found to cause [hypothyroidism](../glossary#hypothyroidism) (insufficient production of [thyroid](../glossary#thyroid) [hormones](../glossary#hormone)) in animals [(54)](#reference54). Two mechanisms can potentially explain this effect. The [hydrolysis](../glossary#hydrolysis) of progoitrin, found in cruciferous vegetables (see [Figure 1](#figure-1)), may yield a compound known as goitrin, which may interfere with thyroid hormone synthesis. The hydrolysis of another class of glucosinolates, known as indole glucosinolates, results in the release of thiocyanate [ions](../glossary#ion) (see [Figure 2](#figure-2)) that can compete with iodine for uptake by the thyroid gland [(55)](#reference55). However, increased exposure to thiocyanate ions from cruciferous vegetable consumption or, more commonly, from cigarette smoking, does not appear to increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of hypothyroidism unless accompanied by [iodine](../minerals/iodine) deficiency. One study in humans found that the consumption of 150 g/day (5 oz/day) of cooked Brussels sprouts for four weeks had no adverse effects on thyroid function [(56)](#reference56). Similarly, consumption of high amounts of cruciferous vegetables has been associated with increased thyroid [cancer](../glossary#cancer) risk only in iodine-deficient areas [(57)](#reference57). The 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommend eating a variety of vegetables daily (2½ cup-equivalents/day for a 2,000 calorie diet) from all of the five vegetable subgroups (dark green, red and orange, legumes, starchy, and other; see [58](#reference58)). No separate recommendations have been established for cruciferous vegetables, yet the 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommend that adults consume 1½-2½ cup-equivalents of dark-green vegetables (which include cruciferous vegetables) per week [(58)](#reference58). Cruciferous vegetables are important sources of some [vitamins](../glossary#vitamin) and [minerals](../glossary#mineral), fiber, and various phytochemicals other than glucosinolates (Table 2). Garlic is a particularly rich source of organosulfur compounds, which are thought to be responsible for its flavor and aroma, as well as its potential health benefits [(2)](#reference2). Consumer interest in the health benefits of garlic is strong enough to place it among the best-selling herbal [supplements](../glossary#supplement) in the United States [(3)](#reference3). Scientists are interested in the potential for organosulfur compounds derived from garlic to prevent and treat [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease), such as [cancer](../glossary#cancer) and [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) [(4)](#reference4). When raw garlic cloves are crushed, chopped, or chewed, an [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) known as alliinase is released. Alliinase [catalyzes](../glossary#catalyst) the formation of sulfenic acids from L-cysteine sulfoxides (Figure 2). Sulfenic acids spontaneously react with each other to form unstable compounds called thiosulfinates. In the case of alliin, the resulting sulfenic acids react with each other to form a thiosulfinate known as allicin (half-life in crushed garlic at 23°C is 2.5 days). The formation of thiosulfinates is very rapid and has been found to be complete within 10 to 60 seconds of crushing garlic. In studies conducted in rodents, orally administrated alliin was found to be absorbed intact and to reach [plasma](../glossary#plasma) and liver without being converted to allicin. There are no thiosulfinates (like allicin) in intact garlic cloves, and none can be generated in the stomach because alliinase would be irreversibly inhibited under [acidic](../glossary#acidic) conditions [(6)](#reference6). The absorption and [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of allicin and allicin-derived compounds (see [Figure 2](#figure-2)) are only partially understood [(7)](#reference7). In humans, no allicin has been detected in the [serum](../glossary#serum) or urine up to 24 hours after the ingestion of 25 g of raw garlic containing a significant amount of allicin [(8)](#reference8). Before ingestion in garlic preparations and after ingestion in the stomach, allicin likely breaks down to release a number of volatile compounds, including DAS and DADS. These organosulfur compounds are metabolized to allyl mercaptan, allyl methyl sulfide, and allyl methyl disulfide, which have been detected in human breath after garlic consumption [(9-11)](#reference9). Although a number of biological activities have been attributed to various allicin-derived compounds, it is not yet clear which of these compounds or [metabolites](../glossary#metabolite) actually reaches target tissues [(5)](#reference5). Allyl methyl sulfide — but not allyl mercaptan — has been detected in the urine within four hours of garlic ingestion, suggesting that this compound is absorbed into the circulation and rapidly [excreted](../glossary#excretion) [(11)](#reference11). Other allicin-derived compounds, including diallyl sulfides, ajoenes, and vinyldithiins, have not been detected in human blood, urine, or stool, even after the consumption of up to 25 g of fresh garlic or 60 mg of pure allicin [(5)](#reference5). In normal cells, the cell cycle is tightly regulated to ensure faithful [DNA](../glossary#DNA) replication and [chromosomal](../glossary#chromosome) segregation prior to cell division. When defects occur during DNA replication or chromosomal segregation and in case of DNA damage, the cell cycle can be transiently arrested at check points to allow for repair. [Apoptosis](../glossary#apoptosis) is triggered when repair fails. Defective check points and evasion of apoptosis allow the unregulated division of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) cells [(69)](#reference69). Organosulfur compounds, including allicin, DAS, DADS, DATS, ajoene, and SAMC, have been found to induce cell cycle arrest when added to cancer cells in cell culture experiments (reviewed in [4](#reference4), [70](#reference70)).
