Most [systematic reviews](../glossary#systematic-review) and/or [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) to date have provided mixed results regarding the potential blood pressure-lowering effect of garlic, possibly because most of these trials enrolled both [normotensive](../glossary#normotensive) and [hypertensive](../glossary#hypertension) subjects [(90](#reference90), [101-105)](#reference101). A systematic review and meta-analysis by Xiong et al. [(106)](#reference106) included seven [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trials that exclusively enrolled individuals with high blood pressure, i.e., with [systolic blood pressure](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) (SBP) 140 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) 90 mm Hg. Five out of seven trials identified in this systematic review reported statistically significant reductions in SBP and DBP with several garlic preparations (dried garlic homogenate, garlic powder, and aged garlic extract) [(106)](#reference106). Another recent meta-analysis included nine randomized controlled trials in 482 hypertensive individuals who were given garlic powder (six studies), garlic homogenate (one study), aged garlic extract (two studies), or placebo for 8 to 26 weeks [(107)](#reference107). Garlic preparations were found to significantly reduce SBP by a mean of 9.1 mm Hg and DBP by a mean of 3.8 mm Hg compared to placebo. The most recent meta-analysis found that garlic preparations reduced SBP by a mean 8.7 mm Hg (10 trials, 440 subjects) and DBP by 6.1 mm Hg (8 trials, 257 subjects) [(102)](#reference102). Such reductions in blood pressure seem comparable to those reported with currently used classes of blood pressure-lowering medications (average reduction, -9.1 mm Hg for SBP and -5.5 mm Hg for DBP) [(108)](#reference108). The effect of blood pressure reduction from such medications at standard dose has been estimated to lower the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [coronary heart disease](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease) events by about one-quarter and the risk of [stroke](../glossary#stroke) by about one-third [(108)](#reference108). Nonetheless, evidence showing that garlic [supplements](../glossary#supplement) may reduce the risk of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality is still lacking [(109)](#reference109). In a recent 12-week, randomized, placebo-controlled trial in untreated hypertensive subjects, daily intake of aged garlic extract (1.2 g of which contained 1.2 mg of S-allyl-L-cysteine [SAC]) was shown to significantly lower SBP by 11 mm Hg and DBP by 6 mm Hg on average in 50%-60% of participants, but reductions in blood pressure were not reported in 40%-50% of participants compared to placebo [(110)](#reference110). Whether interindividual differences in nutritional status and genetic [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) can explain differences in blood pressure response to garlic treatment need to be explored in future studies [(53](#reference53), [110)](#reference110). Overall, short-term garlic supplementation appears to effectively reduce blood pressure with minimal side effects in hypertensive patients. The results of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have suggested that garlic [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) modestly improves [serum](../glossary#serum) [lipid](../glossary#lipid) profiles in individuals with elevated serum [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) and reduces blood pressure in [hypertensive](../glossary#hypertension) subjects. It is not yet clear whether garlic supplementation can reduce [atherosclerosis](../glossary#atherosclerosis) or prevent [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events, such as [myocardial infarction](../glossary#myocardial-infarction) or [stroke](../glossary#stroke). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 17 studies (mostly [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study)) reported an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between high versus low garlic consumption and the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [gastric](../glossary#gastric) [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [(111)](#reference111). Nevertheless, this conclusion is hindered by a number of limitations, especially related to the [retrospective](../glossary#retrospective-study) design of most studies included in the analysis, as well as great variations in the amount and duration of garlic intakes. In a 2009 review of the literature, Kim et al. [(112)](#reference112) identified 20 human studies that examined garlic intake in relation to gastric cancer risk: three [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial), one case-cohort study, 13 case-control studies, and three [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study)/ [ecologic](../glossary#ecologic-study) studies. Using the Food and Drug Administration (FDA)'s evidence-based criteria for the scientific evaluation of health claims [(113)](#reference113), the authors excluded 16 studies for methodological flaws; only four studies (two case-control [(114, and one intervention [(85)](#reference85)) received moderate-to-high quality ratings [(112)](#reference112). Among these four studies, garlic intake during adolescence or 20 years prior to the interview was not found to be associated with the risk of gastric cancer in one of the case-control studies in Sweden (338 gastric cancer patients and 669 control subjects) [(114)](#reference114). Another case-control study in Korea failed to show an association between past garlic consumption and gastric cancer in 136 people diagnosed with gastric cancer and 136 cancer-free subjects [(115)](#reference115). In addition, a [prospective](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) case-cohort study in the Netherlands found no association between the use of garlic supplements (unknown composition) and gastric cancer risk [(116)](#reference116). Finally, a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled intervention study in 3,365 subjects from the Shandong province of China found that supplementation with aged garlic extract and steam-distilled garlic oil for 7.3 years did not reduce the [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of precancerous gastric lesions or the incidence of gastric cancer [(85)](#reference85). An updated analysis of the data collected 7.3 years after garlic supplementation ended provided further confirmation for a lack of significant reduction in gastric cancer incidence or mortality with supplemental garlic [(117)](#reference117). Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection and gastric cancer: Infection with some strains of H. pylori [bacteria](../glossary#bacteria) markedly increases the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [gastric](../glossary#gastric) [cancer](../glossary#cancer). Although garlic preparations and organosulfur compounds could inhibit the growth of H. pylori in the laboratory [(118, 119)](#reference118), there is little evidence to suggest that high garlic intakes or garlic [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) may help prevent or eradicate H. pylori infection in humans [(120)](#reference120). Higher intakes of garlic were not associated with a significantly lower [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of H. pylori infection in China or Turkey [(121, 122)](#reference121). Moreover, [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) using garlic cloves garlic oil [(84](#reference84), [124)](#reference124), garlic oil macerate [(125)](#reference125), or garlic powder [(126)](#reference126) have not found garlic supplementation to be effective in eradicating H. pylori infection in humans. A 2014 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [prospective in 335,923 subjects (including 4,610 [colorectal cancer](../glossary#colorectal-cancer) [CRC] cases) found no association of consuming raw or cooked garlic (three studies, four cohorts) or [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) garlic (four studies, five cohorts) with CRC [(127)](#reference127). Another recent [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and meta-analysis that combined data from seven cohort and seven case-control studies also failed to find a statistically significant reduction in CRC [risk](../glossary#risk) with garlic intake [(128)](#reference128). Yet, these results are in contrast with previous pooled analyses of data from case-control studies [(129)](#reference129) or from both [case-control](../glossary#case-control-study) and prospective studies [(130)](#reference130) that reported an approximate 30% lower CRC risk in individuals with the highest garlic intakes compared to those with the lowest intakes. Inclusion of case-control studies, which are more susceptible to bias, may explain these discrepancies among meta-analyses [(128)](#reference128). For information regarding different types of [epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study), see the [Spring/Summer 2016 LPI Research Newsletter](../../sites/lpi.oregonstate.edu/files/pdf/newsletters/ss16.pdf). A preliminary [intervention trial](../glossary#intervention-trial) in 37 patients with [colorectal adenomas](../glossary#colorectal-adenoma) examined whether supplementation with aged garlic extract for 12 months affected adenoma size and recurrence. Both the number and size of adenomas were significantly reduced in patients given a high dose of aged garlic extract compared to those given a much lower dose (0.16 mL/day) [(131, 132)](#reference131). Larger [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) are needed to determine whether garlic or garlic extracts can substantially reduce adenoma progression to advanced cancer and recurrence. In a small, [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled [intervention study](../glossary#intervention-trial) in 50 patients with [cancer](../glossary#cancer) (42 with liver cancer, seven with [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) cancer, and one with [colon](../glossary#colon) cancer), supplementation with 500 mg/day of aged garlic extract for six months failed to prevent quality of life deterioration caused by disease progression and [chemotherapy](../glossary#chemotherapy)-associated adverse effects [(133)](#reference133). Yet, the active treatment limited the decline in [natural killer cell](../glossary#natural-killer-cells) count and activity that accompanies digestive cancer progression and reduces patient survival [(133)](#reference133). At present, evidence from trials is limited and results from [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) do not suggest a role of high intakes of garlic in the prevention of cancer in humans [(112)](#reference112). Allium vegetables, including garlic and onions, are the richest sources of organosulfur compounds in the human diet [(134)](#reference134). To date, the majority of scientific research relating to the health effects of organosulfur compounds has focused on those derived from garlic. Fresh garlic cloves contain about 2 to 6 mg/g of -glutamyl-S-allyl-L-cysteine (0.2%-0.6% fresh weight) and 6 to 14 mg/g of alliin (0.6%-1.4% fresh weight). Garlic cloves yield about 2.5 to 4.5 mg of allicin per gram of fresh weight when crushed. One fresh garlic clove weighs 2 to 4 g [(5)](#reference5). The [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) alliinase can be inactivated by heat. In one study, microwave cooking of unpeeled, uncrushed garlic totally destroyed alliinase enzyme activity [(135)](#reference135). An [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) study found that prolonged oven heating or boiling (i.e., six minutes or longer) suppressed the inhibitory effect of uncrushed and crushed garlic on [platelet](../glossary#platelet) aggregation, but crushed garlic retained more anti-aggregatory activity compared to uncrushed garlic [(136)](#reference136). Administering raw garlic to rats significantly decreased the amount of [DNA](../glossary#DNA) damage caused by a chemical [carcinogen](../glossary#carcinogen), but heating uncrushed garlic cloves for 60 seconds in a microwave oven or 45 minutes in a convection oven prior to administration blocked the protective effect of garlic [(137)](#reference137). The protective effect of garlic against DNA damage can be partially conserved by crushing garlic and allowing it to stand for 10 minutes prior to microwave heating for 60 seconds or by cutting the tops off garlic cloves and allowing them to stand for 10 minutes before heating in a convection oven. Because organosulfur compounds derived from alliinase- [catalyzed](../glossary#catalyst) reactions may play a role in some of the biological effects of garlic, some scientists recommend that crushed or chopped garlic be allowed to "stand" for at least 10 minutes prior to cooking [(135)](#reference135). Several different types of garlic preparations are available commercially, and each type provides a different profile of organosulfur compounds depending on how it was processed (see [Table 1](#table-1)). Not all garlic preparations are standardized, and even standardized brands may vary with respect to the amount and the [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of the organosulfur compounds they provide [(5)](#reference5). Powdered or dehydrated garlic is made from garlic cloves that are usually sliced and dried at a low temperature to prevent alliinase inactivation [(138)](#reference138). The dried garlic is pulverized and often made into tablets. To meet United States Pharmacopeial Convention (USP) standards, powdered garlic [supplements](../glossary#supplement) must contain no less than 0.1% -glutamyl-S-allyl-L-cysteine and no less than 0.3% alliin (dry weight) [(139)](#reference139). Although powdered garlic supplements do not actually contain allicin, the manufacturer may provide a value for the "allicin potential" or "allicin yield" of a supplement on the label. These values represent the maximum achievable allicin yield of a supplement [(140)](#reference140). It is determined by dissolving powdered garlic in water at room temperature and measuring the allicin content after 30 minutes [(139)](#reference139). Because alliinase is inactivated by the [acidic](../glossary#acidic) [pH](../glossary#pH) of the stomach, most powdered garlic tablets are enteric-coated to keep them from dissolving before they reach the neutral pH of the [small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine). It has been argued that it is more appropriate to measure "allicin release" using a USP method for assessing drug release from enteric-coated tablets under conditions that mimic those of the stomach and intestine [(139)](#reference139). Allicin release by this method has been shown to parallel true [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) [(140)](#reference140). Most tablet brands have been found to produce little allicin under these conditions, due mainly to low alliinase activity and prolonged disintegration times [(140, 141)](#reference140). Many manufacturers provide information on the "allicin potential" of their powdered garlic supplements, but few provide information on the "allicin release." A number of controlled [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have examined the effect of powdered or dehydrated garlic supplements on [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) [risk](../glossary#risk) factors (see [Cardiovascular disease](#cardiovascular-disease-prevention)). The most commonly used doses ranged from of 600 to 900 mg/day and provided 3.6 to 5.4 mg/day of potential allicin [(90)](#reference90). When garlic cloves are incubated in a solution of ethanol and water for up to 20 months, allicin is mainly converted to allyl sulfides, which are lost by evaporation or converted to other compounds [(138)](#reference138). The resulting extract contains primarily water-soluble organosulfur compounds, such as SAC and SAMC (see [Figure 3](#figure-3)) [(142)](#reference142). Garlic fluid extracts, including aged garlic extracts, are standardized to their S-allyl-L-cysteine content. In controlled [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial), daily intakes of aged garlic extract at doses between 1.2 g-2.4 g (containing 1.2 to 2.4 mg of S-allyl-L-cysteine) consistently resulted in reductions in SBP by 9 mm Hg-10 mm Hg and reductions in DBP by 4 mm Hg-8 mm Hg in a majority of patients with uncontrolled [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension) [(110](#reference110), [143)](#reference143). Additionally, aged garlic extract at doses of 2.4 to 7.2 g/day resulted in short-term reductions in ex vivo [platelet](../glossary#platelet) aggregation [(144)](#reference144) and reductions in [serum](../glossary#serum) [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentrations up to 12 weeks [(16)](#reference16). Steam distillation of crushed garlic cloves results in a product that contains mainly allyl sulfides, including DATS, DADS, and DAS (see [Figure 2](#figure-2)) [(138)](#reference138). These fat-soluble steam distillation products are usually dissolved in vegetable oil. Incubation of crushed garlic cloves in oil at room temperature results in the formation of vinyldithiins and ajoene from allicin, in addition to allyl and DATS (see [Figure 2](#figure-2)) [(5)](#reference5). [Gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) symptoms have also been reported, including heartburn, abdominal pain, belching, nausea, vomiting, flatulence, constipation, and diarrhea [(106)](#reference106). The most serious adverse effects associated with oral garlic supplementation are related to uncontrolled bleeding. Several cases of serious postoperative or spontaneous bleeding associated with garlic supplementation have been reported in the medical literature [(147-150)](#reference147). Garlic may also trigger allergic responses in some individuals, including [asthma](../glossary#asthma) in people with occupational exposure to garlic powder or dust [(151)](#reference151). Exposure of the skin to garlic has been reported to cause contact [dermatitis](../glossary#dermatitis) in some individuals [(146](#reference146), [152)](#reference152). More serious skin lesions, including blisters and burns, have also been reported with [topical](../glossary#topical) exposure to garlic for six or more hours. The safety characteristics of the various garlic preparations likely depend on their specific chemical composition (see [Table 1](#table-1)). Aged garlic extract — the only water-based garlic supplement — showed a safe profile in toxicity studies and exhibited no undesirable side effects when combined with [anticoagulants](../glossary#anticoagulant) (warfarin), antiplatelets methotrexate) in clinical settings (reviewed in [6](#reference6)). Safety and toxicity data are lacking for lipophilic ( [hydrophobic](../glossary#hydrophobic)) garlic preparations, but some of their constituents have been shown to interfere with drug-metabolizing [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) and transporters (see [Drug interactions](#drug-interactions)). No adverse effects on pregnancy outcomes have been reported when garlic is consumed in the diet. Although no adverse pregnancy outcomes were reported in a study of Iranian women who took dehydrated garlic tablets (800 mg/day) for two months during the third trimester of pregnancy [(153)](#reference153), the safety of garlic [supplements](../glossary#supplement) in pregnancy has not been established. There is some evidence that garlic consumption alters the odor and possibly the flavor of breast milk. In a controlled [cross-over trial](../glossary#cross-over-trial), oral consumption of 1.5 g of garlic extract by lactating women increased the perceived intensity of breast milk odor [(154)](#reference154). Infants spent more time breast-feeding after their mothers consumed the garlic extract compared to a [placebo](../glossary#placebo), but the amount of milk consumed and number of feedings were not significantly different. Additionally, it is not known if [topical](../glossary#topical) use of garlic is safe during pregnancy or lactation. Garlic may enhance the [anticoagulant](../glossary#anticoagulant) effects of warfarin (Coumadin). There have been two [case reports](../glossary#case-report) in which prothrombin time ( [INR](../glossary#international-normalized-ratio)) increased in patients who started taking garlic tablets or garlic oil without changing their warfarin dose or other habits [(155)](#reference155). However, a more recent study in closely monitored patients on warfarin therapy found that garlic fluid extracts (aged garlic extract) did not increase [hemorrhagic](../glossary#hemorrhage) [risk](../glossary#risk) [(156)](#reference156). Since garlic [supplements](../glossary#supplement) have been found to inhibit [platelet](../glossary#platelet) aggregation [(90)](#reference90), there is a potential for additive effects when garlic supplements are taken together with other medications or supplements that inhibit platelet aggregation, such as high-dose fish oil or vitamin E [(157)](#reference157). More research is needed to determine whether garlic supplements are safe for people on anticoagulatory therapy. [Supplementation](../glossary#supplement) of healthy volunteers with garlic caplets twice daily (allicin yield, 7.2 mg/day) for three weeks resulted in a 50% decrease in the [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of the protease inhibitor, CYP3A4, supplementation with garlic extract for two weeks did not significantly alter a measure of CYP3A4 activity in healthy volunteers [(159)](#reference159). The mechanisms responsible for garlic - drug interactions and their in vivo relevance. Curr Drug Contents Legumes are plants of the Leguminosae family with seed pods that split into two halves. Edible seeds from plants of this family include beans, peas, lentils, soybeans, and peanuts. The most recent Dietary Guidelines for Americans do not include green peas or green (string) beans as legumes due to a dissimilar nutritional profile when compared to the other legume family members [(1)](#references). Peanuts are nutritionally similar to tree nuts; therefore, information on their health effects is presented in a separate article on [Nuts](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/food-beverages/nuts) and not discussed below. Many studies have examined how the consumption of pulses is related to health; pulses are legumes harvested as dry grain and thus exclude green peas, green beans, as well as crops used for oil extraction (soybeans, peanuts) [(2)](#reference2). Although legumes are an important part of traditional diets around the world, they are often neglected in typical Western diets. Legumes are inexpensive, nutrient-dense sources of protein that can be substituted for dietary animal protein [(3)](#reference3). While sources of animal protein are often rich in [saturated fats](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid), the small quantities of fats in legumes are mostly [unsaturated fats](../glossary#unsaturated-fatty-acid). Legumes are also good sources of several essential [minerals](../glossary#mineral), rich in dietary [fiber](../glossary#fiber) (both soluble fiber and resistant starch), and considered to be low- [glycemic index](../food-beverages/glycemic-index-glycemic-load) foods [(4, 5)](#reference4). Moreover, legumes contain numerous [phytochemicals](../glossary#phytochemical) that may affect health. Soybeans have attracted the most scientific interest, mainly because they are a unique source of [phytoestrogens](../glossary#phytoestrogen) known as [isoflavones](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/soy-isoflavones) [(6)](#reference6). Overall, legumes represent unique packages of nutrients and phytochemicals that may work synergistically to reduce risk of [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease), as other edible seeds do [(7)](#reference7). Note: Research on the health effects of diets rich in legumes, including peas and soy foods, is summarized below. For a discussion of the potential health benefits and risks of soy isoflavones, see the separate article on [Soy Isoflavones](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/soy-isoflavones#disease-prevention). Consumption of legumes, which are rich in dietary [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber), other nutrients, and bioactive compounds, might help improve [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitivity) and regulate blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentrations, thereby influencing [risk](../glossary#risk) of type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus). The glycemic index is a measure of the potential for [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) in different foods to raise blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentrations. In general, consuming foods with high-glycemic index values causes blood glucose concentrations to rise more rapidly, which results in greater [insulin](../glossary#insulin) secretion by the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas), than after consuming foods with low-glycemic index values. Chronically elevated blood glucose concentrations and excessive insulin secretion are thought to play important roles in the development of type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) [(8)](#reference8). Low-glycemic load diets have been associated with reduced [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing type 2 diabetes in some, but not all, [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) (see the article on [Glycemic Index and Glycemic Load](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/food-beverages/glycemic-index-glycemic-load)). High- [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber) diets have also been associated with a decreased risk of type 2 diabetes (see the article on [Fiber](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/other-nutrients/fiber)). Together, the high-fiber content and low-glycemic index nature of legumes may contribute to help lower risk of type 2 diabetes in those who incorporate them into their daily diets. However, a 2017 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 12 prospective cohort studies found that higher legume intakes were not associated with risk of developing type 2 diabetes compared to lower intakes (range, 0-190 g/day; ~0-2 servings/day) [(9)](#reference9), although a more recent prospective study not included in this pooled analysis found an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) [(10)](#reference10). Results of [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) of legume or pulse consumption have been more promising. A meta-analysis of 41 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) (some in individuals with normoglycemia and some in individuals with type 1 or type 2 diabetes) found that pulse consumption, either alone or in combination with a low-glycemic index diet or a high-fiber diet, improved some measures of glucose control, including fasting blood glucose and insulin concentrations, as well as markers of long-term glycemic control [(11)](#reference11). The effect was stronger in patients with diagnosed diabetes compared to individuals with normoglycemia [(11)](#reference11). In a three-month trial in 114 people with type 2 diabetes, those randomized to a low-glycemic diet that emphasized 1 cup/day of legumes had significant improvements in their [hemoglobin A1C value](../glossary#hemoglobin-A1c) — the main fraction of glycated [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) that reflects glycemic control over the past four months — compared to those randomized to a high-wheat fiber diet [(12)](#reference12). Small studies in healthy individuals have found that consumption of legumes improved postprandial glucose response at the subsequent meal (called the 'subsequent meal effect' or 'second meal effect') [(13-15)](#reference13), although this has not been extensively studied. In addition to improving glycemic and insulin control, consumption of legumes may increase [satiety](../glossary#satiety) and decrease both food intake and body weight, indirectly improving glycemic control (see [Obesity](#obesity-prevention) below). [Observational studies](../glossary#observationa-study) on the association of soy intake and type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) have reported mixed results. A 2018 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of eight observational studies (six [prospective cohort](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) and two [cross sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study)) found an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between soy intake and risk of type 2 diabetes; however, there was a high degree of [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) in the analysis [(16)](#reference16). Moreover, when a subgroup analysis was done and only prospective cohort studies were examined, the association was no longer significant [(16)](#reference16). A meta-analysis of 19 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), including 1,518 participants, found that soy consumption — as soy foods/whole soy, isolated soy protein, or [soy isoflavone](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/soy-isoflavones) [supplements](../glossary#supplement) — had no effect on fasting [glucose](../glossary#glucose) or [insulin ](../glossary#insulin)concentrations [(17)](#reference17). Yet, subgroup analyses reported the effect on [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia) differed by type of soy intervention: adherence to a whole-soy diet lowered fasting glucose concentrations, while soy protein isolate or isoflavone supplementation had no effect on fasting glucose concentrations [(17)](#reference17). Several characteristics of legumes may contribute to protection against [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease). They are rich in [soluble](../glossary#soluble) [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber) and [phytosterols](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/phytosterols), which are known to have [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol)-lowering effects, and their high [folate](../vitamins/folate) content may help lower [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) concentrations. Additionally, legumes are good sources of [magnesium](../minerals/magnesium) and [potassium](../minerals/potassium), which may decrease cardiovascular disease [risk](../glossary#risk) by helping to lower blood pressure [(18)](#reference18). The low-glycemic index values of beans mean that they are less likely to raise blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) and [insulin](../glossary#insulin) concentrations (see [Type 2 diabetes mellitus](#type-2-diabetes-prevention) above), and this may also decrease cardiovascular disease risk. Further, the substitution of legumes for foods high in [saturated fat](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid) or refined [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) may offer some cardioprotection. Some, but not all, [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have found regular legume intake to be associated with a lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events, and overall, most [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have found legume consumption decreases cardiometabolic risk factors, especially circulating [LDL](../glossary#LDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentrations. In a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of eight [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), legume intake as part of a Mediterranean diet was associated with a 9% lower risk of [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease), although one of the included studies grouped legume consumption with nuts, which are known to be cardioprotective (see the article on [Nuts](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/food-beverages/nuts#cardiovascular-disease-prevention)) [(19)](#reference19). In a [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and meta-analysis of five prospective cohort studies, consuming four 100-g servings of legumes (beans, peas, lentils, tofu) weekly was associated with a 14% lower risk of [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) (CHD) [(20)](#reference20). This association was driven mainly by a prospective cohort study that followed participants for 19 years, finding those who ate dry beans, peas, or peanuts at least four times weekly had a 21% lower CHD risk compared to those who ate them less than once weekly [(21)](#reference21). Most recently, in a meta-analysis that included both CHD incidence and CHD-related mortality together as outcomes (eight prospective cohort studies in total), the highest versus lowest legume intakes were associated with a 10% decreased risk [(22)](#reference22). In contrast, legume intake has not been linked to risk of [stroke](../health-disease/stroke) in four separate meta-analyses [(20](#reference20), [22-24)](#reference22). Serum lipid profiles: Some, but not all, [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have found that regular legume consumption results in favorable changes in the [lipid](../glossary#lipid) profile. A 2014 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 26 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) reported that pulse intake (beans, lentils, peas; median intake of 130 g/day or ~1.3 servings/day) reduced [LDL](../glossary#LDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentrations by 0.17 (6.6 mg/dL) compared to an [isocaloric](../glossary#isocaloric) diet without pulses; however, there was no effect of pulse intake on non- [HDL](../glossary#HDL) cholesterol or apolipoprotein B concentrations [(25)](#reference25). It is important to note that there was significant [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) among included trials of this meta-analysis, and the baseline lipid status of participants varied among the trials: eight trials included hyperlipidemic subjects, three trials were done in participants with normal lipid profiles, and 15 trials had a combination of normal and high lipid levels [(25)](#reference25). A previous meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials found that non-soy legume consumption decreased total and LDL-cholesterol concentrations by 11.76 mg/dL (10 studies) and 7.98 mg/dL (9 studies), respectively, when compared to a matched control (matched for total calories or macronutrients; baseline total cholesterol concentrations of participants ranged from 199 to 295 mg/dL among studies) [(26)](#reference26). A trend for a reduction in [serum](../glossary#serum) [triglycerides](../glossary#triglyceride) (-18.94 mg/dL, p=0.05) was observed in this meta-analysis, and no effect on HDL cholesterol was found [(26)](#reference26). Hypertension: Adherence to the [Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) eating plan](https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health-topics/dash-eating-plan), which includes dry beans and peas among many other components [(27)](#reference27), has been shown to reduce blood pressure [(28)](#reference28), but it is not known whether legumes contribute to this effect. A 2014 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of eight [isocaloric](../glossary#isocaloric), controlled feeding trials (median of 10 weeks' duration) — including both [normotensive](../glossary#normotensive) and [hypertensive](../health-disease/high-blood-pressure) participants (n=554; median age, 49 years) — found that pulse consumption (median of 162 g/day or ~1.6 daily servings) decreased [systolic blood pressure](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) by 2.25 mm Hg but had no effect on [diastolic blood pressure](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) [(29)](#reference29). It is important to note that there was significant [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) among trials included in the meta-analysis [(29)](#reference29). Serum lipid profiles: In 1999, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved the following health claim: "Diets low in saturated fat and cholesterol that include 25 grams of soy protein a day may reduce the risk of heart disease" [(30)](#reference30). Most of the evidence to support this health claim was included in the Anderson et al. [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 38 controlled [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) that was published in 1995. This meta-analysis found that an average intake of 47 g/day of soy protein decreased [serum](../glossary#serum) total [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentrations by an average of 9% and [LDL](../glossary#LDL)-cholesterol concentrations by an average of 13% [(31)](#reference31). Hypocholesterolemic effects were primarily noted in individuals with high baseline cholesterol concentrations [(31)](#reference31). A meta-analysis of 33 studies published since 1995 confirmed the hypocholesterolemic effect of soy protein reported in the Anderson et al. publication [(32)](#reference32). Another meta-analysis of 30 studies in individuals with normal or mildly elevated cholesterol levels concluded that about 25 g/day of soy protein significantly lowers LDL-cholesterol concentrations by about 6% [(33)](#reference33). Yet, a 2006 science advisory from the Nutrition Committee of the American Heart Association concluded that earlier research indicating that soy protein consumption results in clinically important reductions in LDL-cholesterol compared to other proteins has not been confirmed [(34)](#reference34). A 2011 meta-analysis of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), mostly in participants with hypercholesterolemia, found consumption of soy protein decreased LDL-cholesterol by 5.5% in parallel-design studies (20 trials; median soy protein intake of 31.5 g/day for a mean of 9.2 weeks) and 4.2% in [cross-over studies](../glossary#cross-over-trial) (23 trials; median soy protein intake of 26.0 g/day for a mean of 6.0 weeks) — such decreases may translate to 6%-10% decreases in risk for [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) [(35)](#reference35). Consumption of isolated soy isoflavones (as [supplements](../glossary#supplement) or extracts), however, does not appear to have favorable effects on serum lipid profiles [(35-42)](#reference35). In addition to possibly lowering cholesterol, incorporating soy foods into the diet may benefit overall [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) health due to their relatively high content of [polyunsaturated fat](../glossary#polyunsaturated-fatty-acid), [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber), and [phytosterols](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/phytosterols) compared to including contain [fermentable](../glossary#fermentation) dietary certain [micronutrients](../glossary#micronutrient) and [phytochemicals](../glossary#phytochemical) that may have anticancer effects. Some legumes serine protease inhibitors of the "Bowman-Birk family" (called Bowman-Birk inhibitors) that may have potential chemopreventive effects in the large intestine [(44)](#reference44). Moreover, simply replacing red and processed meats, which are linked to a higher [risk](../glossary#risk) of [colorectal cancer](../glossary#colorectal-cancer) [(45)](#reference45), with legumes in the diet might lower risk. To date, [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) of legume intake and colorectal cancer have reported conflicting findings. A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 14 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) found that higher legume intake was linked to a 9% lower risk of [colorectal cancer](../glossary#colorectal-cancer), although there was significant [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) among studies [(46)](#reference46). Subgroup analyses revealed an [inverse 0.73-0.99) (RR, 1.00; 95% CI, 0.89-1.13) [(46)](#reference46). An earlier meta-analysis of cohort and [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) found that higher versus lower legume intake was associated with a 17% lower risk of [colorectal adenoma](../glossary#colorectal-ademona) [(47)](#reference47). Although beans, peas, and lentils are rich in a number of compounds that could potentially reduce the [risk](../glossary#risk) of certain [cancers](../glossary#cancer), the results of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) are too inconsistent to draw any firm conclusions regarding bean intake and cancer risk in general [(48, 49)](#reference48). [Prostate cancer: Several ] [prospective cohort non-soy legume intake to be [inversely related](../glossary#inverse-association) to incidence of [prostate](../glossary#prostate) [cancer](../glossary#cancer). In a six-year prospective study of more than 14,000 Seventh Day Adventist men living in the United States, those with the highest intakes of legumes (beans, lentils, or split peas) had a 47% lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of prostate cancer [(50)](#reference50). In a prospective study of more than 58,000 men in the Netherlands, those with the highest intakes (median intake, 62 g/day) of legumes (including pulses and dried seeds) had a risk of prostate cancer that was 29% lower than those with the lowest intakes (median intake, 11 g/day) [(51)](#reference51). Moreover, a prospective study in a multiethnic cohort of 82,483 men examined the risk of prostate cancer in men who consumed legumes excluding soy products. In this study, men who consumed the highest amount of non-soy legumes had a 10% lower risk of total prostate cancer and a 28% lower risk of nonlocalized or high-grade prostate cancer compared to those who consumed the least amount of non-soy legumes [(52)](#reference52). However, another study found no association between dry bean intake and prostate cancer [(53)](#reference53). Most recently, in a prospective study in 3,313 French men, non-soy legume consumption was linked to a 44% reduced risk of prostate cancer [(54)](#reference54). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of these five prospective cohort studies found legume consumption was associated with a 15% lower risk of prostate cancer development (95% [CI](../glossary#confidence-interval), 0.72-0.99) [(55)](#reference55). Moreover, a pooled analysis of 13 prospective cohort studies found a similar association: a 14% lower risk of prostate cancer in men who consumed 100 g/day of mature beans (all beans excluding green beans and soybeans) compared to those who had intakes lower than 15 g/day [(56)](#reference56). Prostate cancer: Incidence rates of [prostate](../glossary#prostate) [cancer](../glossary#cancer) are much higher in North America, Northern and Western Europe, Australia, and New Zealand compared to Asian countries, such as Japan and China, where soy is common in the diet [(57)](#reference57). Soy food consumption has been associated with a reduced [risk](http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/glossary#risk) of prostate cancer in pooled analyses of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) [(58-62)](#reference58). In the most recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis), total soy intake (16 studies) and unfermented soy intake (11 studies) were associated with a 29% and 35% lower risk of prostate cancer, respectively; no association was found between fermented soy intake and prostate cancer (eight studies) [(62)](#reference62). Subgroup analyses revealed that the protective association of total soy intake was much stronger in [case-control](../glossary#case-control-study) (39% lower risk) versus [prospective (10% lower risk) — unfermented soy intake was only associated with prostate cancer risk in case-control studies (45% lower risk) [(62)](#reference62). Results of case-control studies are more likely to be distorted by [bias](../glossary#bias) (i.e., the selection bias with the selection of cases and controls, as well as dietary [recall bias](../glossary#recall-bias)) than results of prospective cohort studies. For a review of studies on soy isoflavone intake and prostate cancer, see the separate article on [Soy Isoflavones](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/dietary-factors/phytochemicals/soy-isoflavones#prostate-cancer-prevention). [Breast cancer: More than 25 ] [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have assessed the relationship between soy food intake and the [risk](../glossary#risk) of breast [cancer](../glossary#cancer). A 2008 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) and [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) reported differential effects based on the typical level of soy consumption [(63)](#reference63). In Asian populations, where soy intake is high, the authors found an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between soy food intake and breast cancer; however, no association was observed in studies completed in Western populations, where soy food intake is much lower [(63)](#reference63). A 2016 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 10 prospective cohort studies — four conducted in Japan, three in the US, two in China, and one in France — found that higher intake of soy food was associated with an 8% lower incidence of breast cancer compared to lower intake [(64)](#reference64). Age at exposure to soy might affect subsequent risk of developing breast cancer. For instance, a few case-control studies have reported that higher soy intake during childhood or adolescence was associated with a lower risk of developing breast cancer later in life [(65-68)](#reference65). Soy intake later in life may not have as strong as an effect on breast cancer compared to exposure during childhood and adolescence [(63)](#reference63), and lifelong exposure to soy food may be needed to lower risk of breast cancer [(69)](#reference69). Isoflavones are likely responsible for any protection of soy against the development of breast cancer; studies of soy isoflavone intake and breast cancer are reviewed in the separate article on [Soy Isoflavones](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/dietary-factors/phytochemicals/soy-isoflavones#breast-cancer-prevention). [Endometrial cancer: Since soy isoflavones have ] [estrogenic](../glossary#estrogen) activity, studies have investigated whether isoflavone intake from soy food or [supplements](../glossary#supplement) might be related to development of [endometrial](../glossary#endometrium) [cancer](../glossary#cancer). There is only limited evidence of an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association), primarily from case-control studies [(70)](#reference70); see the separate [Soy Isoflavones](https://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/dietary-factors/phytochemicals/soy-isoflavones#endometrial-cancer-prevention). [Gastrointestinal cancers: Results of ] [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) [cancers](../glossary#cancer), including [gastric](../glossary#gastric) cancer and [colorectal cancer](../glossary#colorectal-cancer), have been mixed. A 2016 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) that included 18 [case-control](../glossary#case-control-study) and 16 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) found soy consumption was associated with a 7% lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of gastrointestinal cancer; however, soy intake was not significantly linked to gastrointestinal cancer when the data from only cohort studies were considered ( [OR](../glossary#odds-ratio), 0.97; 95% [CI](../glossary#confidence-interval), 0.90-1.03) [(71)](#reference71). A soybean intake was associated with a 15% lower risk of colorectal cancer (95% CI, 0.73-0.99), but only three prospective cohort studies were included in this analysis [(46)](#reference46). High-quality studies that control for potential [confounders](../glossary#confounder) are needed to determine whether soy food intake — or legume intake in general — is linked to a lower risk of gastric or colorectal cancer. Numerous [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have shown that consuming low-glycemic index food delays the return of hunger, decreases subsequent food intake, and increases the sensation of fullness compared to consuming high-glycemic index food [(72, 73)](#reference72). Some trials have specifically examined the effect of legume or pulse consumption on food intake amount, [satiety](../glossary#satiety), or body weight. A 2016 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) that included 21 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), mostly in overweight or obese subjects, reported an overall weight loss of 0.34 kg (0.75 lb) with diets that contained pulses (median intake 132 g/day for a median of six weeks; one serving ~100 g/day) [(74)](#reference74). This analysis found a greater weight loss in negative-energy balance trials (i.e., energy-restricted diets; weight loss averaging 1.74 kg or 3.8 lb) than in neutral energy-balance trials (i.e., weight-maintenance diets; weight loss averaging 0.29 kg or 0.64 lb), although both effects were statistically significant [(74)](#reference74). Six trials included in this meta-analysis examined the effect of pulse consumption (161 g/day; trial average duration of 10 weeks) on other measures of obesity: no effect was seen on waist circumference, but a trend for reduced body fat percentage was found with pulse consumption (p=0.07) [(74)](#reference74). A meta-analysis of 21 controlled clinical trials (duration ranging from 4 weeks to 2 years) found that soy consumption — as whole soy or soy protein — had no effect on body weight, and a subgroup analysis showed that soy consumption actually increased body weight in obese subjects [(75)](#reference75). Additionally, this meta-analysis found no effect of soy intake on fat mass (10 trials) or waist circumference (16 trials) [(75)](#reference75). A meta-analysis of nine acute, feeding trials in mostly normal-weight subjects reported pulse consumption, administered as a single bolus, increased measures of satiety by 31% compared to an isocaloric control; however, no effect on food intake at the subsequent/second meal was seen (seven trials) [(76)](#reference76). Increases in acute satiety, likely due to the high protein and [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber) content and the low-glycemic load of legumes, could lead to reduced food intake and the weight loss observed in some studies. Although currently available studies are limited, the effect on satiety appears to be following consumption of pulses and not soy food (reviewed in [77](#reference77)). High-quality trials are needed to determine whether regular pulse or legume consumption results in weight loss in the long term. Some studies have linked adherence to either the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension eating pattern [(78, 79)](#reference78) or a Mediterranean-style diet [(78](#reference78), [80-82)](#reference80) with better overall [cognitive function](../health-disease/cognitive-function-in-brief) in healthy older adults. Legumes are one of many components included in these dietary patterns that might contribute to this purported association; studies reporting specifically on legume intake and cognitive endpoints are limited and have reported mixed results. In a [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) of 2,613 middle-age and older adults (ages 43-70 years) residing in the Netherlands, followed for five years, legume intake was not associated with changes in global cognitive function (memory, speed of information processing, and cognitive flexibility) [(83)](#reference83). In contrast, a prospective, [nested case-control study](../glossary#nested-case-control-study) of the Chinese Longitudinal Health Longevity Study found that older adults (65 years) who included legumes in their diets nearly every day had a 22% lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of cognitive decline over a three-year period compared to those who had lower intakes — this study included 5,691 illiterate older adults who had no evidence of cognitive decline at baseline [(84)](#reference84). Most recently, a small study in 214 older, Italian adults (65 years) with normal cognitive function used the method of principal component analysis and identified legumes as one of the food categories linked to better cognitive scores at the end of a one-year period [(85)](#reference85). Large-scale prospective cohort studies are needed to examine whether legume intake is associated with improvements in cognitive health or risk of [dementia](../glossary#dementia) in older adults. A 2017 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of six [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) found a weak, [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between a large, international prospective cohort study (N=135,335) not included in the 2017 meta-analysis, stronger inverse associations were found with respect to all-cause mortality and non-cardiovascular mortality; however, legume consumption was not associated with cardiovascular-related mortality [(87)](#reference87). In this study, consuming more than one serving of legumes daily was associated with a 42% lower risk of non-cardiovascular mortality and a 41% lower risk of all-cause mortality compared to consuming fewer than one legume serving per month [(87)](#reference87). In a smaller prospective study (N=7,212) in Spain, conducted among older individuals at high risk for cardiovascular disease, non-soy legume intake was associated with a lower risk of cancer-related mortality but a higher risk of cardiovascular-related mortality [(88)](#reference88). It is important to note that average intakes of legumes in this study were low, with those in the highest [tertile](../glossary#tertile) consuming a mean 28 g/day of legumes — less than one-third of a serving [(88)](#reference88). Moreover, a meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies did not find soy intake to be associated with all-cause (six studies), cardiovascular-related (six studies), or cancer-related (eight studies) mortality [(89)](#reference89). Substituting beans, peas, and lentils for foods that are high in [saturated fat](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid) or refined [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) is likely to help lower the [risk](../glossary#risk) of type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) and [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease). Soybeans and foods made from soybeans (soy foods) are excellent sources of protein. In fact, soy protein is complete protein, meaning it provides all of the essential [amino acids](../glossary#amino-acid) in adequate amounts for human health [(6)](#reference6). Like beans, peas, and lentils, soy foods are also excellent substitutes for protein sources that are high in saturated fat like red meat or cheese. Legumes are not only good sources of protein and dietary [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber) but also of [vitamins](../glossary#vitamin), [minerals](../glossary#mineral), as well as [phytochemicals](../glossary#phytochemical) that may benefit health (see Table 1). The 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans — healthy eating recommendations issued jointly by the US Department of Health and Human Services and the US Department of Agriculture — include legumes (beans, lentils, dried peas, and edamame [green soybeans]) in two different food groups: the protein group and the vegetable group [(1)](#references). Recommended intake of legumes at the 2,000-calorie level translates to 1½ cup-equivalents weekly for those who follow a Healthy US-style or a Healthy Mediterranean-style eating pattern and 3 cup-equivalents weekly for those following a Healthy Vegetarian eating pattern [(1)](#references). Current intakes of legumes among Americans are well below these recommendations (see [Figure 2-4](https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/2015/guidelines/chapter-2/a-closer-look-at-current-intakes-and-recommended-shifts/#figure-2-4) in the Dietary Guidelines). The Dietary Guidelines also recommend 8 oz-equivalents/week of soy products for vegetarians consuming 2,000 calories/day and 5 oz-equivalents per week for those following other recommended eating patterns, although nuts and seeds can contribute to meet this recommendation. Recent research, however, suggests that regular nut consumption is an important part of a healthful diet. Although the fat content of nuts is relatively high (13-20 grams (g)/ounce), most of the fats in nuts are [monounsaturated](../glossary#monounsaturated-fatty-acid) and [polyunsaturated fats](../glossary#polyunsaturated-fatty-acid) rather than [saturated fats](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid) (see [Table The term "nuts" refers nuts, cashews, hazelnuts, macadamia nuts, pecans, pistachios, and walnuts. Despite their name, peanuts are legumes like peas and beans. However, because they are nutritionally similar to tree nuts, they may share some of the same beneficial properties. Studies mentioned in this article have examined the effects of tree nuts and peanuts either together or separately. In large [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), regular nut consumption has been consistently associated with significant reductions in the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) (CHD). An early study that followed more than 30,000 Seventh Day Adventists over 12 years found that participants who consumed nuts at least five times weekly had a 48% lower risk of death from CHD and a 51% lower risk of nonfatal [myocardial infarction](../health-disease/heart-attack) (MI) compared to those who consumed nuts less than once weekly [(1)](#references). In addition, the risk of death from CHD was 39% lower in Seventh Day Adventists older than 83 years who ate nuts at least five times weekly compared to those who consumed nuts less than once weekly [(2)](#reference2). More recently, an analysis of data from the Nurses' Health Study I that followed 84,136 women (ages at enrollment, 30-55 years) for 26 years reported a 32% lower risk of CHD in those who ate an average of 2.8 servings/week compared to those who never ate nuts [(3)](#reference3). A 2014 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 13 prospective cohort studies, including the Seventh Day Adventists and Nurses' Health Studies, found a 34% lower risk of CHD with the highest versus lowest level of nut consumption [(4)](#reference4). A dose-response analysis indicated that every 1 serving/week increment in nut consumption was associated with a 5% reduction in CHD risk [(4)](#reference4). In another meta-analysis that included data from over 200,000 participants enrolled in three large cohort studies, weekly intake of at least five servings of nuts was associated with a 20% lower risk of CHD when compared to no consumption [(5)](#reference5). However, there was no evidence of an association between nut consumption and risk of stroke. In contrast, another recent meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies found a 12% lower risk of stroke (14 studies) and a 19% lower risk of stroke-related death (seven studies) with the highest versus lowest intake of nuts [(6)](#reference6). The PREDIMED (Prevención con Dieta Mediterránea) study that between 2003-2011 was a multicenter, [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) that examined the effect of a Mediterranean diet, with either extra-virgin olive oil or nuts, compared to a control diet, in the primary prevention of cardiovascular events in 7,447 adults (55 years) at high risk of [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) [(7)](#reference7). Adherence to a Mediterranean diet, supplemented with olive oil or mixed nuts for nearly five years resulted in a 30% lower risk of cardiovascular events and no weight gain [(7)](#reference7). Finally, a modeling study estimated that an increase in daily nut intake from 5 g to 30 g could have prevented 7,680 incidental cardiovascular events and saved about 65,000 years of life that were lost to stroke or heart attack in a scenario based on data from the Swedish population in 2013 [(8)](#reference8). Blood lipids: In a [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) analysis of a representative sample of the US population — the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey [NHANES] 2005-2010 — tree nut consumers (¼ ounce/day) were found to have higher blood [HDL](../glossary#HDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentrations and lower [body mass index](../glossary#body-mass-index) (BMI), waist [systolic blood pressure](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) than subjects consuming <¼ ounce/day [(9)](#reference9). However, these observations may be due to [reverse causation](../glossary#reverse-causation), in particular because health-conscious people are more likely to consume healthy diets that include nuts. A 2015 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) assessed the evidence of the effect of tree nut consumption on blood [lipid](../glossary#lipid) profile using findings from 42 [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in a total of 2,101 participants, among which 45% were at risk of [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) and untreated. Results indicated lower concentrations of total and [LDL](../glossary#LDL)-cholesterol concentrations but no effect on concentrations of HDL-cholesterol or [triglycerides](../glossary#triglycerides) [(10)](#reference10). Similar observations were made in meta-analyses of interventions examining the specific effect of walnut [(11, 12)](#reference11), almond [(13)](#reference13), hazelnut [(14)](#reference14), or pistachio [(15)](#reference15) consumption on blood lipid profile of people with normal or elevated blood cholesterol. Interestingly, in a small recent trial in 46 statin-treated participants, the daily consumption of 100 g (~3.5 ounces) of almonds for four weeks led to a 4.9% reduction in non-HDL-cholesterol (i.e., total cholesterol minus HDL-cholesterol) concentration [(16)](#reference16). Blood pressure: Adherence to a Mediterranean diet for nearly four years in the PREDIMED trial led to significant improvements in [diastolic](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) (but not [systolic](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure)) blood pressure compared to a control diet. However, there were no differences in blood pressure changes whether the Mediterranean diet was supplemented with nuts or olive oil [(17)](#reference17). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 21 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 1,652 participants found little evidence for an effect of nut supplementation on either systolic or diastolic blood pressure. A blood pressure-lowering effect of nuts was reported when only subjects without type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) were considered. Of note, this meta-analysis included four trials that used either peanuts or soy nuts, which are not tree nuts [(18)](#reference18). Endothelial function: Measures of brachial flow-mediated [endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) function, associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with risk of [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events. A 2017 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) eight [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) suggested that supplementation with walnuts (four studies), pistachios (three studies), or almonds (one study) for up to 12 weeks may help increase FMD in subjects at risk of [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) [(19)](#reference19). Similar observations were reported in another recent meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials [(20)](#reference20). Chronic low inflammation: A 2016 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 20 small [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) conducted primarily in subjects at high risk for [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) found no evidence of an effect of nut supplementation for up to 12 weeks (only two studies lasted longer) on markers of [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) in blood [(21)](#reference21). Of note, four of the trials included in this meta-analysis exclusively supplemented participants with either peanuts or soy nuts. Nonetheless, a similar conclusion was reached in another meta-analysis of 25 interventions [(19)](#reference19). Of note, a recent systematic review of meta-analysis corroborated the account of the cardiovascular health benefits of nut consumption presented above [(22)](#reference22). Nuts are energy-dense in particular because of their high fat content; yet, most of their fat is in the form contain one or more carbon-carbon double bonds (C=C) in their chemical structure, as opposed to [saturated fatty acids](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid) that have none. Tree nuts contain more MUFAs than PUFAs with the exception of walnuts and pine nuts, which have more PUFAs than MUFAs, and Brazil nuts, which contain equivalent amounts of MUFAs and PUFAs (Table 1). Walnuts are especially rich in acid (~0.8 g/ounce), an omega-3 fatty acid Acids](../other-nutrients/essential-fatty-acids)). Other bioactive compounds, including [micronutrients](../glossary#micronutrient), [phytosterols](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/phytosterols), and [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber), may also contribute to improving the cardiometabolic profile (Table 1 and Figure 1). Some nuts (pecans, pistachios, almonds, and hazelnuts) are a source of [flavonoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/flavonoids) that may contribute to cardiovascular health (see the article on [Flavonoids](..dietary-factors/phytochemicals/flavonoids#cardiovascular-disease-prevention)) [(23)](#reference23). The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has acknowledged the current evidence for a relationship between nut consumption and cardiovascular disease by approving the following qualified health claim for nuts [(24)](#reference24): "Scientific evidence suggests but does not prove that eating 1.5 ounces per day of most nuts (such as macadamia nuts [(25)](#reference25)) as part of a diet low in saturated fat and cholesterol may reduce the risk of heart disease" [(24)](#reference24). Early results from the Nurses' Health Study I suggested that nut and peanut butter consumption might be [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with the [risk](../glossary#risk) of type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) in women [(26)](#reference26). However, two independent [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of more recent prospective cohort reported no evidence of an association between nut consumption and risk of type 2 diabetes [(27, 28)](#reference27). Nonetheless, a meta-analysis of 12 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 450 participants with type 2 diabetes showed that supplementation with tree nuts for a median of eight weeks could reduce fasting [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentration and [glycated hemoglobin](../glossary#glycated-hemoglobin) (HbA1c) concentration, a measure of glycemic control [(29)](#reference29). Although there were no significant effects on fasting [insulin](../glossary#insulin) concentration or a measure of [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance) (HOMA-IR) [(29)](#reference29), these findings suggest that nuts might be part of a healthful diet for the management of [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia) in individuals with type 2 diabetes. Peanuts and tree nuts are among the most common foods to trigger allergic reactions, potentially severe ( [anaphylaxis](../glossary#anaphylaxis)) and fatal [(48)](#reference48). Such reactions can be triggered by a primary [antibody](../glossary#antibody) response against some nut [proteins](../glossary#protein) or by antibodies raised against protein in pollen but cross-reacting with structurally similar proteins in nuts. Mixed method-based estimates of peanut allergy in US children suggest that the condition is increasingly [prevalent](../glossary#prevalence) and ranges between 2 and 5% [(49)](#reference49). Estimates based solely on self reports suggest a prevalence of tree nut allergy <1% in US adults and <2% in US children [(50)](#reference50). Individuals with peanut or tree nut allergies need to take special precautions to avoid inadvertently consuming peanuts or tree nuts by checking labels and avoiding unlabeled snacks, candies, and desserts [(50)](#reference50). See the [Food Allergy Research and Education](https://www.foodallergy.org/) [ website](https://www.foodallergy.org/) for additional tips to avoiding unintentional peanut or tree nut exposure. In the 2010 'Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Management of Food Allergy in the United States,' the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases discourages nut avoidance during pregnancy or breastfeeding as a way of preventing food intolerance in the offspring [(51)](#reference51). Results from two birth cohort studies suggested an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between maternal peanut or tree nut consumption during, shortly before, or just after their pregnancy and the [risk](../glossary#risk) of food allergy (including nut allergy) in the offspring [(52, 53)](#reference52), supporting the current recommendations. Yet, prior studies found higher peanut consumption in mothers of children with peanut allergy [(54)](#reference54). Additional studies are needed to clarify the effect of maternal nut intake on food tolerance in the offspring. A 2017 addendum to the 2010 'Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Management of Food Allergy in the United States' included recommendations for the prevention of peanut allergy through the early introduction of peanuts in infants' diet [(55)](#reference55) (Table 2). |Infant Criteria||Earliest allergies||Age-appropriate and in accordance with family preferences|| | Brazil nuts grown in areas of Brazil with [selenium](../minerals/selenium)-rich soil may provide more than 100 µg of selenium in one nut, while those grown in selenium-poor soil may provide 10 times less [(56)](#reference56). For information regarding toxicity of selenium, see the article on [Selenium](../minerals/selenium#toxicity). Regular nut consumption, equivalent to 1 ounce of nuts five times weekly, has been consistently associated with significant reductions in risk of [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) in [epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study). Consuming nuts daily as part of a diet that is low in [saturated fat](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid) has been found to lower [serum](../glossary#serum) total and [LDL](../glossary#LDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) in a number of controlled [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial). Since an ounce of most nuts provides at least 160 calories (kcal), simply adding an ounce of nuts daily to one's habitual diet without eliminating other foods may result in weight gain. Substituting unsalted nuts for less healthy snacks or for meat in main dishes are two ways to make nuts part of a healthful diet. A modeling study that used 2009-2012 NHANES data from 17,444 individuals (1 year old) estimated that substituting tree nuts for between-meal snacks on a calorie-per-calorie basis would improve the nutritional quality of dietary intakes through a shift in [fatty acid](../glossary#fatty-acid) intake (less saturated and more unsaturated fatty acids), a reduction in added sugar and [sodium](../minerals/sodium) (salt), and an increase in [potassium](../minerals/potassium), [magnesium](../minerals/magnesium), and [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber) [(57)](#reference57). The [2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans](https://health.gov/dietaryguidelines/2015/) encourage the consumption of nuts, seeds, and soy products as part of a healthy diet.
