Nutr J. 2017;16(1):17. ] [(PubMed)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28270158) Contents Grains are seeds of plants belonging to the Poaceae family (also called Gramineae or true grasses). Some examples of edible grains include wheat, rice, maize (corn), barley, oats, rye, triticale (wheat-rye hybrid), millet, bulgur, and sorghum [(1)](#references). Although they are not members of the Poaceae family, whole-grain ingredients also include pseudo-grains like quinoa, amaranth, and buckwheat. A whole grain has an outer layer of bran, a [carbohydrate](../glossary#carbohydrate)-rich middle layer called the endosperm, and an inner germ layer (Figure 1). Whole-grain foods contain entire grain seeds either intact, cracked, crushed, or flaked, as long as the bran, endosperm, and germ are retained in the same proportions as they exist in the intact kernel [(1)](#references). Whole grains are rich in potentially beneficial compounds, including [vitamins](../glossary#vitamin), [minerals](../glossary#mineral), [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber), and [phytochemicals](../glossary#phytochemical), such as [lignans](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/lignans) and [phytosterols](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/phytosterols) [(2)](#reference2). Most of these compounds are located in the bran or the germ of the grain, both of which are lost during the refining (milling) process, leaving only the starchy endosperm [(1)](#references). Compared to diets high in refined grains, diets rich in whole grains are associated with reduced risks of several [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease). The health benefits of whole grains are not entirely explained by the individual contributions of the nutrients and phytochemicals they contain. Whole grains represent a unique package of energy, [micronutrients](../glossary#micronutrient), and phytochemicals that work synergistically to promote health and prevent disease [(3)](#reference3). Because there is no globally accepted definition as to what constitutes a whole-grain food, it is difficult to compare studies that examined the effects of whole-grain consumption on markers of health and disease outcomes. The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved health claims for whole grains (see [Finding whole grain foods](#increasing-intake)) to foods containing 51% of whole-grain ingredients by weight or 8 g of whole grains per one ounce (~30 g)-serving size [(4)](#reference4). An international multidisciplinary expert group recently proposed to label "whole grain" a food with a whole-grain content of 8 g per ounce [(5)](#reference5). Yet, to date, most [epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study) that examined the health impact of consuming whole-grain foods have included foods containing 25% of whole grains and added brans by weight [(6)](#reference6). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of eight large [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), including 385,868 participants, have found that high versus low intakes of total grains and whole grains were associated with a significant reduction in the [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) [(7)](#reference7). On the other hand, no relationship was found between refined-grain intake and diabetes in a meta-analysis of six prospective studies of 258,078 subjects [(7)](#reference7). Specifically, the consumption of three daily servings of whole-grain foods was associated with a 32% lower risk of diabetes (see below for [Examples of one serving of whole grains](#serving-examples)). Further analyses showed a significantly lower risk of diabetes with high versus low consumption of whole grains as a single food (i.e., brown rice, wheat bran) or as an ingredient in food (i.e., whole-grain bread, whole-grain breakfast cereal) but not with refined grains like white rice and wheat germ [(7)](#reference7). In addition, a pooled analysis of three large prospective cohorts — the Health Professionals Follow-up Study [HPFS] and the Nurses' Health Studies [NHS I and II] — reported a 17% increased risk of type 2 diabetes in participants in the highest (5 servings/week) versus lowest (<1 serving/month) [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of white rice intake, while brown rice consumption (2 servings/week versus <1 serving/month) was associated with an 11% reduction in risk [(8)](#reference8). Interestingly, substituting 50 g/day ( serving/day) of brown rice or other whole grains for the same amount of white rice could be associated with a predicted diabetes risk reduction of 16% or more [(8)](#reference8). Whole grains have been [hypothesized](../glossary#hypothesis) to reduce the [risk](../glossary#risk) of type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) by improving [postprandial](../glossary#postprandial) glycemia. Immediately after a meal, blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) and [lipid](../glossary#lipid) concentrations are increased, and secretion of [insulin](../glossary#insulin) by the pancreas stimulates glucose and lipid storage into tissues. Prolonged postprandial [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia) and [hyperlipidemia](../glossary#hyperlipidemia) have [insulin resistance,](../glossary#insulin-resistance) and [endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) dysfunction, all contributing to the development of [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease) like type 2 diabetes mellitus [(9)](#reference9). The refining process that removes bran and germ facilitates the digestion of the [carbohydrate](../glossary#carbohydrate)-rich endosperm such that carbohydrates from refined grains were thought to elicit a higher and more rapid elevation in blood [glucose](http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/infocenter/glossary.html#glucose), as well as a greater demand for insulin, than whole grains [(10)](#reference10). However, compared with foods made from refined grains, whole-grain products do not necessarily have a lower glucose-raising potential, i.e., a lower [glycemic index](../glossary#glycemic-index) (GI) [(11)](#reference11). The GI concept is based on the idea that foods containing carbohydrates that are easily digested, absorbed, and [metabolized](../glossary#metabolism) have a high GI (GI 70 on the glucose scale); in contrast, foods containing slowly digestible carbohydrates that elicit a reduced postprandial glucose response are considered to have a low GI (GI 55 on the glucose scale) (see also the article on [Glycemic Index and Glycemic Load](glycemic-index-glycemic-load)) [(12)](#reference12). Bread, breakfast cereal, rice, and snack products have been attributed either a low or high GI, whether or not they include whole grains [(11)](#reference11), suggesting that the type of food rather than its whole-grain content affects postprandial blood glucose concentrations. In some [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study), higher whole-grain intakes have been associated with decreased insulin resistance [(13)](#reference13) and increased [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) [(14)](#reference14) in healthy individuals. In a controlled [cross-over trial](../glossary#cross-over-trial) in 11 overweight or obese adults, consumption of a diet rich in whole grains for six weeks lowered several clinical measures of insulin resistance compared with a diet high in refined grains [(15)](#reference15). However, in a recent [randomized controlled study](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) of 61 adults with [metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome), the consumption of a diet based on several whole-grain cereal products for 12 weeks had no effect on fasting [plasma](../glossary#plasma) concentrations of glucose, insulin, lipids, or on insulin resistance compared with a refined grain-based diet. Yet, postprandial plasma insulin and [triglycerides](../glossary#triglycerides) — but not postprandial plasma glucose — were significantly reduced with the whole grain-based diet [(16)](#reference16). A decreased postprandial insulin response may be associated with an increase in tissue sensitivity to insulin [(3)](#reference3). In another [intervention trial](../glossary#intervention-trial) in 20 healthy volunteers, three-day consumption of whole barley-based bread induced a lower insulin peak value following a standard breakfast than the same course with refined wheat bread. Whole barley-based bread consumption was also associated with an increase in circulating concentrations of gut-related [hormones](../glossary#hormone) (e.g., peptide YY, glucagon-like peptide) and a higher gut [fermentation](../glossary#fermentation) activity. This suggested improvements in hormonal control of digestion and in [colonic](../glossary#colon) fermentation of resistant starch (indigestible fiber) [(17)](#reference17), possibly promoting the feeling of satiety [(18)](#reference18) and increasing insulin sensitivity [(19)](#reference19). Whole-grain consumption might be improving insulin sensitivity rather than blunting postprandial hyperglycemia; however, well-designed, large randomized controlled trials are necessary to provide further insight into how whole-grain consumption may protect against type 2 diabetes. A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 10 large [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) published between 1998 and 2010 found that the highest intake of whole grains (about three servings daily) was associated with an overall 21% reduced [risk](../glossary#risk) of cardiovascular disease (CVD), including [coronary heart disease](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease) (CHD), ischemic heart disease, heart failure, and [ischemic stroke](../glossary#ischemic-stroke), when compared to the lowest intake of whole grains and after adjustment for several CVD risk factors [(20)](#reference20). Further, although evidence is currently limited, whole-grain intake may be associated with a reduced risk of [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension), a risk factor for cardiovascular disease [(21, 22)](#reference21). Compared to refined grains, whole grains are rich in nutrients associated with cardiovascular risk reduction. In the Health Professionals Follow-up Study (HPFS) in 42,850 men, the top versus bottom [quintile](../glossary#quintile) (49.6 g/day vs. 3.3 g/day) of whole-grain intake was associated with a 16% reduced risk of CHD after multiple adjustments for age, gender, and CHD risk factors [(23)](#reference23). Further adjustments for whole-grain constituents, association such that it was no longer statistically significant, suggesting that the micronutrient and fiber content may explain the cardiovascular benefits of consuming whole grains. Protective cardiovascular effects associated with higher intakes of whole grains and lower intakes of refined grains have included improvements in blood [lipid](../glossary#lipid) profiles and reductions in markers of [subclinical](../glossary#subclinical) [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation). A meta-analysis of 21 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) indicated that whole-grain interventions for 4 to 16 weeks could improve an individual's blood concentrations of fasting [glucose](../glossary#glucose), [insulin](../glossary#insulin), total and [LDL](../glossary#LDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol), as well as reduce [diastolic](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) and [systolic blood pressure](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) [(20)](#reference20). Consistent with this, a recently updated [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 23 randomized controlled trials published between 1988 and 2015 indicated that consumption of whole grains (28 g/day-213 g/day for 2 to 16 weeks), especially whole-grain oats in cereal and other products, for a couple of weeks resulted in significant reductions in blood concentrations of [triglycerides](../glossary#triglycerides) and total and LDL-cholesterol when compared to control diets with refined grain [(24)](#reference24). Interventions that included mixed whole-grain products (bread, muesli, ready-to-eat cereal, pasta, rice, crisps, muffins, cookies) also improved blood [HDL](../glossary#HDL)-cholesterol concentrations [(24)](#reference24). In addition, although wheat fiber has not been found to lower [serum](../glossary#serum) cholesterol concentrations, numerous clinical studies have demonstrated that increasing intakes of oat fiber and soluble fiber from barley resulted in modest reductions in total and LDL-cholesterol [(25-27)](#reference25). In light of such findings, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved claims regarding whole grains and reduction in risk of CHD that apply to diets low in saturated fat and cholesterol providing at least 3 g/day of -glucan soluble fiber from oats (oat bran, rolled oats [oatmeal], whole oat flour) or whole-grain barley [(28)](#reference28). Whole grains are also sources of [phytosterols](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/phytosterols) — compounds that can decrease serum cholesterol by interfering with its intestinal absorption [(2)](#reference2). Evidence from [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) suggested an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) and metabolic diseases [(29)](#reference29). However, [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) have provided mixed results. In a recent [cross-over trial](../glossary#cross-over-trial) in healthy low whole-grain consumers, the effect of increased consumption of mixed whole grains (mean intake, 168 g/day) for six weeks was compared to whole-grain consumption of less than 16 g/day. Increasing whole-grain intake had no effect on absolute counts of immune cells in blood ( [leukocytes](../glossary#leukocyte), [lymphocytes](../glossary#lymphocyte), [natural killer cells](../glossary#natural-killer-cells)), on ex vivo [phagocytic](../glossary#phagocytosis) activities of these cells, or on markers of inflammation (e.g., IL-10, TNF-, [C-reactive protein](../glossary#c-reactive-protein) [CRP]) in blood [(30)](#reference30). Previous studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in healthy normal weight, overweight, or [obese](../glossary#obesity) subjects have also failed to demonstrate any benefits of whole-grain intake on markers of inflammation [(31-35)](#reference31). One eight-week dietary intervention study in 80 overweight or obese subjects found that replacement of refined products in the habitual diet by whole-grain wheat products resulted in a significant reduction in pro-inflammatory [cytokine](../glossary#cytokine) TNF-, a transient increase in anti-inflammatory IL-10, and no change in CRP compared to intake of refined wheat [(36)](#reference36). In another randomized cross-over intervention study, overweight/obese children (ages, 8-15 years) were provided with a list of whole-grain products and asked to either obtain half of their grain servings from whole-grain foods every day for six weeks (whole-grain group) or abstain from consuming any of these foods (control group). Mean daily consumption of 98 g of whole-grain products (compared to 11 g/day) resulted in reductions in [serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of CRP, sICAM-1 (soluble intercellular adhesion molecule-1), protein amyloid A), and [leptin](../glossary#leptin) [(37)](#reference37). An increased whole-grain intake to about five daily servings (compared to <1 serving/day) also reduced blood concentrations of CRP but had no effect on IL-10 and TNF- concentrations in obese adults with [metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome) following a hypocaloric diet [(38)](#reference38). Inconsistency among studies may be attributed to differences in the health status of participants, the duration of interventions, and/or the types of whole grains selected. In particular, if foods with a low glycemic index (GI) can lower cardiometabolic and inflammation markers [(39)](#reference39), substituting refined grain products by whole grains with high GI may not demonstrate any benefits regarding the [risk](../glossary#risk) of heart disease. Although the protective effects of whole grains against various types of cancer are not as well established as those against type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) and [cardiovascular [risk](../glossary#risk) [(40-42)](#reference40). An early [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 40 case-control studies examining 20 different types of cancer found that people with higher whole-grain intakes had an overall risk of cancer that was 34% lower than those with lesser whole-grain intakes [(40)](#reference40). Higher intakes of whole grains were most consistently associated with decreased risk of [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) tract cancers, including cancers of the mouth, throat, [esophagus](../glossary#esophagus), stomach, [colon](../glossary#colon), and rectum. A [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) that followed more than 61,000 Swedish women for 15 years found that those who consumed more than 4.5 servings of whole grains daily had a 35% lower risk of colon cancer than those who consumed less than 1.5 servings of whole grains daily [(43)](#reference43). In the large National Institutes of Health (NIH)-AARP Diet and Health prospective study in 291,988 men and 197,623 women, mean whole-grain intakes — much lower than in the above-mentioned Swedish cohort — were also inversely associated with risk of [colorectal cancer](../glossary#colorectal-cancer), especially rectal cancer [(44)](#reference44). Specifically, the highest versus lowest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of whole-grain intake (2.6 servings/day vs. 0.4 servings/day) was associated with a 36% lower risk of developing rectal cancer [(44)](#reference44). In a [nested case-control study](../glossary#nested-case-control-study), including participants of the multicenter European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC), the top versus bottom [quartile](../glossary#quartile) of [plasma](../glossary#plasma) alkylresorcinol concentrations, used as a surrogate marker of whole-grain wheat and rye intakes, was found to be associated with a 52% lower incidence of distal colon cancer. No correlations were reported with the incidence of rectal cancer, colon cancer, and proximal colon cancer, or with the overall incidence of colorectal cancers [(45)](#reference45). Not all cohort studies have suggested that whole grains might protect against intestinal cancers [(46, 47)](#reference46). However, a dose-response analysis based on the results of six cohort studies found a 17% reduction in colorectal cancer risk with an increment of three servings (three oz-eq or 90 g) of whole grains daily [(48)](#reference48). Of note, a recent analysis of three Scandinavian cohorts that are also part of the EPIC study and include over 110,000 participants showed an inverse correlation between total whole-grain intake and esophageal cancer risk. Each 10 g-increase in whole-grain wheat intake was found to be associated with a 50% lower risk of esophageal cancer. Such an association was not observed with whole-grain rye or with whole-grain oats [(49)](#reference49). In contrast to refined-grain products, whole grains are rich in numerous compounds that may be protective against cancer, particularly cancers of the gastrointestinal tract [(50)](#reference50). Whole grains are a major source of [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber), and high-fiber intakes are thought to speed up the passage of stool through the colon, allowing less time for potentially [carcinogenic](../glossary#carcinogen) compounds to stay in contact with cells that line the inner surface of the colon [(51)](#reference51). Dietary fiber can also exert chemopreventive effects via short-chain [fatty acids](../glossary#fatty-acid) that are generated when fiber is fermented by the colonic microbiota [(52)](#reference52). Whole grains also contain acids, [lignans](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/lignans), [phytoestrogens](../glossary#phytoestrogen), [signal transduction pathways](../glossary#signal-transduction-pathway) that promote the development of cancer or bind potentially damaging free metal [ions](../glossary#ion) in the gastrointestinal tract [(53, 54)](#reference53). Recent large [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have investigated the relationship between whole-grain consumption and the [risk](../glossary#risk) of all-cause and cause-specific mortality. Higher versus lower intakes of whole grains (1.20 oz-eq/day versus 0.13 oz-eq/day) have been associated with a 17% lower risk of all-cause mortality in the NIH-AARP Diet and Health Study of 367,442 older adults [(55)](#reference55). Higher whole-grain intakes were significantly associated with a decreased risk of mortality from [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) (-17%), and infections (-23%). These associations were largely attenuated after adjustments for cereal fiber intakes, suggesting a major role for fiber in the protective effects of whole grains on mortality [(55)](#reference55). Another recent analysis of two US prospective cohort studies, the Nurses' Health Study (NHS) in 74,341 women and the Health Professionals Follow-up Study (HPFS) in 43,744 men, reported a 9% lower risk of all-cause mortality in individuals in the highest versus lowest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of whole-grain intake [(56)](#reference56). Higher whole-grain consumption was associated with a 15% lower risk of cardiovascular disease-related mortality, but no correlation was found with cancer-related mortality. Finally, the association of whole-grain intake with mortality was also examined in over 110,000 participants of the Scandinavian HELGA cohort [(57)](#reference57). In this cohort, a doubling of the consumption of whole-grain products or that of specific whole-grain wheat, rye, or oats was associated with a reduced risk of all-cause and cause-specific mortality. These results from cohort studies in the US and northern Europe consistently suggested a role of whole-grain consumption in the prevention of early death. Diets rich in whole grains and fiber may help prevent or improve constipation symptoms by softening and adding bulk to stool and by speeding its passage through the [colon](../glossary#colon) [(58, 59)](#reference58). Such diets are also associated with decreased risk of [diverticulosis](../glossary#diverticulosis), a condition characterized by the formation of small pouches (diverticula) in the colon. Although most people with diverticulosis experience no symptoms, about 10%-25% may develop pain or [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), known as [diverticulitis](../glossary#diverticulitis) [(58)](#reference58). Diverticulitis was virtually unheard of before the practice of milling (refining) flour began in industrialized countries, and the role of a low-fiber diet in the development of diverticular disease is well established [(60)](#reference60). If high-fiber diets reduce the risk of diverticular disease [(61, 62)](#reference61), then the source of fiber (e.g., from cereal, fruit, vegetables) may be important. Interestingly, a 5 g-increase in intake of fiber from cereal was found to be associated with a 14% reduced risk of diverticular disease in a UK-based cohort of 690,075 women (mean age, 60 years) followed for up to six years; the risk of diverticular disease was decreased by 15% and 5% with a 5 g-increase in the consumption of fruit fiber and vegetable fiber, respectively [(62)](#reference62). High-fiber diets are also recommended for people with diverticulosis in order to prevent the formation of additional diverticula rather than to resolve formed diverticula [(58)](#reference58). People with diverticulosis are sometimes advised to avoid eating small seeds and husks to prevent them from becoming lodged in diverticula and causing diverticulitis, especially if they do not consume a high-fiber diet [(58)](#reference58). However, it should be noted that no study has ever shown that avoiding seeds or popcorn reduces the risk of diverticulitis in an individual with diverticulosis [(60)](#reference60). [Prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have consistently suggested that whole-grain consumption is associated with lower [body mass index](../glossary#body-mass-index) (BMI) and lower [risks](../glossary#risk) of weight gain [obesity](../glossary#obesity) [20)](#reference20). However, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) published between 1988 and 2012 reported no significant effects of whole-grain intakes (from 18.2 g/day-150 g/day for 2 to 16 weeks) on body weight (26 trials), body fat (7 studies), and waist circumference (9 studies) in up to 2,060 normal-weight or overweight/obese adults without chronic health conditions [(63)](#reference63). In a recent [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [open-label](../glossary#open-label-trial), controlled trial in 60 overweight/obese individuals with metabolic syndrome, the consumption of whole grains (about 6-12 servings/day) was compared to that of refined grains during a 12-week intervention period that included a weight-maintenance diet for the first six weeks followed by six weeks of a hypocaloric diet [(64)](#reference64). Increased whole-grain intake failed to lower body weight, BMI, percentage of body fat, or waist circumference beyond reductions also observed with consumption of refined grains. Of note, individuals who consumed whole grains showed an improved fasting glycemia compared to those fed refined grains, but other cardiometabolic variables remained unchanged [(64)](#reference64). These results contrast with other energy-restricted dietary interventions showing a more favorable effect of whole grains on percentage of body fat compared to refined grains [(38](#reference38), [65)](#reference65). Further investigation is warranted to clarify whether whole-grain consumption could play a role in body weight regulation. Whole-grain intakes approaching three servings daily are associated with significant reductions in [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease) [risk](../glossary#risk) in populations with relatively low whole-grain intakes. The 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans — issued jointly by the US Department of Health and Human Services and US Department of Agriculture — recommend that at least half of all grains consumed be whole grains and to increase whole-grain intake by replacing refined grains with whole grains [(66)](#reference66). In the 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans, the unit of measure of a whole-grain serving size is the ounce-equivalent (oz-eq). A whole-grain serving size corresponds to (1) one ounce (~30 g) of a 100% whole-grain food in its ready-to-eat form, (2) two ounces of partly whole-grain products, or (3) the amount of food containing 16 g of whole-grain ingredients [(67)](#reference67). New York: Simon & Schuster; 2001.] Contents In the past, [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) were classified as simple or complex based on the number of simple sugars in the molecule. Carbohydrates composed of one or two simple sugars like [fructose](../glossary#fructose) or sucrose (table sugar; a disaccharide composed of one molecule of glucose and one molecule of fructose) were labeled simple, while starchy foods were labeled complex because starch is composed of long chains of the simple sugar, [glucose](../glossary#glucose). Advice to eat less simple and more complex carbohydrates (i.e., polysaccharides) was based on the assumption that consuming starchy foods would lead to smaller increases in blood glucose than sugary foods [(1)](#references). This assumption turned out to be too simplistic since the blood glucose (glycemic) response to complex carbohydrates has been found to vary considerably. The concept of glycemic index (GI) has thus been developed in order to rank dietary carbohydrates based on their overall effect on [postprandial](../glossary#postprandial) blood glucose concentration relative to a referent carbohydrate, generally pure glucose [(2)](#reference2). The GI is meant to represent the relative quality of a carbohydrate-containing food. Foods containing carbohydrates that are easily digested, absorbed, and [metabolized](../glossary#metabolism) have a high GI (GI70 on the glucose scale), while low-GI foods (GI55 on the glucose scale) have slowly digestible carbohydrates that elicit a reduced postprandial glucose response. Intermediate-GI foods have a GI between 56 and 69 [(3)](#reference3). The GI of selected carbohydrate-containing foods can be found in [Table 1](#table-1). To determine the [glycemic index](../glossary#glycemic-index) (GI) of a food, healthy volunteers are typically given a test food that provides 50 grams (g) of [carbohydrate](../glossary#carbohydrate) and a control food (white, wheat bread or pure [glucose](../glossary#glucose)) that provides the same amount of carbohydrate, on different days [(4)](#reference4). Blood samples for the determination of glucose concentrations are taken prior to eating, and at regular intervals for a few hours after eating. The changes in blood glucose concentration over time are plotted as a curve. The GI is calculated as the incremental area under the glucose curve (iAUC) after the test food is eaten, divided by the corresponding iAUC after the control food (pure glucose) is eaten. The value is multiplied by 100 to represent a percentage of the control food [(5)](#reference5): GI = (iAUCtest food/iAUCglucose) x 100 For example, a boiled white potato has an average GI of 82 relative to glucose and 116 relative to white bread, which means that the blood glucose response to the carbohydrate in a baked potato is 82% of the blood glucose response to the same amount of carbohydrate in pure glucose and 116% of the blood glucose response to the same amount of carbohydrate in white bread. In contrast, cooked brown rice has an average GI of 50 relative to glucose and 69 relative to white bread. In the traditional system of classifying carbohydrates, both brown rice and potato would be classified as complex carbohydrates despite the difference in their effects on blood glucose concentrations. While the GI should preferably be expressed relative to glucose, other reference foods (e.g., white bread) can be used for practical reasons as long as their preparation has been standardized and they have been calibrated against glucose [(2)](#reference2). Additional recommendations have been suggested to improve the reliability of GI values for research, public health, and commercial application purposes [(2](#reference2), [6)](#reference6). By definition, the consumption of high-GI foods results in higher and more rapid increases in blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentrations than the consumption of low-GI foods. Rapid increases in blood glucose (resulting in [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia)) are potent signals to the -cells of the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas) to increase [insulin](../glossary#insulin) secretion [(7)](#reference7). Over the next few hours, the increase in blood insulin concentration (hyperinsulinemia) induced by the consumption of high-GI foods may cause a sharp decrease in the concentration of glucose in blood (resulting in [hypoglycemia](../glossary#hypoglycemia)). In contrast, the consumption of low-GI foods results in lower but more sustained increases in blood glucose and lower insulin demands on pancreatic -cells [(8)](#reference8). Many [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have [GI](../glossary#glycemic-index) and [risk](../glossary#risk) of [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease), relying on published GI values of individual foods and using the following formula to calculate meal (or diet) GI [(9)](#reference9): Meal GI = [(GI x amount of available [carbohydrate](../glossary#carbohydrate))Food A + (GI x amount of available carbohydrate)Food B +...]/ total amount of available carbohydrate Yet, the use of published GI values of individual foods to estimate the average GI value of a meal or diet may be inappropriate because factors such as food variety, ripeness, processing, and cooking are known to modify GI values. In a study by Dodd et al., the estimation of meal GIs using published GI values of individual foods was overestimated by 22 to 50% compared to direct measures of meal GIs [(9)](#reference9). Besides the GI of individual foods, various food factors are known to influence the [postprandial](../glossary#postprandial) [glucose](../glossary#glucose) and [insulin](../glossary#insulin) responses to a carbohydrate-containing mixed diet. A recent [cross-over](../glossary#cross-over-trial), [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) trial in 14 subjects with type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) examined the acute effects of four types of breakfasts with high- or low-GI and high- or low- [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber) content on postprandial glucose concentrations. [Plasma](../glossary#plasma) glucose was found to be significantly higher following consumption of a high-GI and low-fiber breakfast than following a low-GI and high-fiber breakfast. However, there was no significant difference in postprandial glycemic responses between high-GI and low-GI breakfasts of similar fiber content [(10)](#reference10). In this study, meal GI values (derived from published data) failed to correctly predict postprandial glucose response, which appeared to be essentially influenced by the fiber content of meals. Since the amounts and types of carbohydrate, fat, [protein](../glossary#protein), and other dietary factors in a mixed meal modify the glycemic impact of carbohydrate GI values, the GI of a mixed meal calculated using the above-mentioned formula is unlikely to accurately predict the postprandial glucose response to this meal [(3)](#reference3). Moreover, the GI is a property of a given food carbohydrate such that it does not take into account individuals' characteristics like ethnicity, metabolic status, or eating habits (e.g., the degree to which we masticate) which might, to a limited extent, also influence the glycemic response to a given carbohydrate-containing meal [(11-14)](#reference11). Using direct measures of meal GIs in future trials — rather than estimates derived from GI tables — would increase the accuracy and predictive value of the GI method [(2](#reference2), [6)](#reference6). In addition, in a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 28 studies examining the effect of low- versus high-GI diets on [serum](../glossary#serum) [lipids](../glossary#lipid), Goff et al. indicated that the mean GI of low-GI diets varied from 21 to 57 across studies, while the mean GI of high-GI diets ranged from 51 to 75 [(15)](#reference15). Therefore, a stricter use of GI cutoff values may also be warranted to provide more reliable information about carbohydrate-containing foods. The [glycemic index](../glossary#glycemic-index) (GI) compares the potential of foods containing the same amount of [carbohydrate](../glossary#carbohydrate) to raise blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose). However, the amount of carbohydrate contained in a food serving also affects blood glucose concentrations and [insulin](../glossary#insulin) responses. For example, the mean GI of watermelon is 76, which is as high as the GI of a doughnut (see [Table 1](#table-1)). Yet, one serving of watermelon provides 11 g of available carbohydrate, while a medium doughnut provides 23 g of available carbohydrate. The concept of [glycemic load](../glossary#glycemic-load) (GL) was developed by scientists to simultaneously describe the quality (GI) and quantity of carbohydrate in a food serving, meal, or diet. The GL of a single food is calculated by multiplying the GI by the amount of carbohydrate in grams (g) provided by a food serving and then dividing the total by 100 [(4)](#reference4): GLFood = (GIFood x amount (g) of available carbohydrateFood per serving)/100 For a typical serving of a food, GL would be considered high with GL20, intermediate with GL of 11-19, and low with GL10. Using the above-mentioned example, despite similar GIs, one serving of watermelon has a GL of 8, while a medium-sized doughnut has a GL of 17. Dietary GL is the sum of the GLs for all foods consumed in the diet. It should be noted that while healthy food choices generally include low-GI foods, this is not always the case. For example, intermediate-to-high-GI foods like parsnip, watermelon, banana, and pineapple, have low-to-intermediate GLs (see [Table 1](#table-1)). The consumption of high-GI and -GL diets for several years might result in higher [postprandial](../glossary#postprandial) blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentration and excessive [insulin](../glossary#insulin) secretion. This might contribute to the loss of the insulin-secreting function of pancreatic -cells and lead to [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) [(16)](#reference16). A US [ecologic study](../glossary#ecologic-study) of national data from 1909 to 1997 found that the increased consumption of refined [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate) in the form of corn syrup, coupled with the declining intake of dietary [fiber](../other-nutrients/fiber), has paralleled the increased [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of type 2 diabetes [(17)](#reference17). In addition, high-GI and -GL diets have been associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of type 2 diabetes in several large [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study). A recent updated analysis of three large US cohorts indicated consumption of foods with the highest versus lowest GI was associated with a risk of developing type 2 diabetes that was increased by 44% in the Nurses' Health Study (NHS) I, 20% in the NHS II, and 30% in the Health Professionals Follow-up Study (HPFS). High-GL diets were associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes (+18%) only in the NHS I and in the pooled analysis of the three studies (+10%) [(18)](#reference18). Additionally, the consumption of high-GI foods that are low in cereal fiber was associated with a 59% increase in diabetes risk compared to low-GI and high-cereal-fiber foods. High-GL and low-cereal-fiber diets were associated with a 47% increase in risk compared to low-GL and high-cereal-fiber diets. Moreover, [obese](../glossary#obesity) participants who consumed foods with high-GI or -GL values had a risk of developing type 2 diabetes that was more than 10-fold greater than lean subjects consuming low-GI or -GL diets [(18)](#reference18). However, a number of prospective cohort studies have reported a lack of association between GI or GL and type 2 diabetes [(19-24)](#reference19). The use of GI food classification tables based predominantly on Australian and American food products might be a source of GI value misassignment and partly explain null associations reported in many prospective studies of European and Asian cohorts. Nevertheless, conclusions from several recent [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of prospective studies (including the above-mentioned studies) suggest that low-GI and -GL diets might have a modest but significant effect in the prevention of type 2 diabetes [(18](#reference18), [25, 26)](#reference25). Organizations like Diabetes UK [(27)](#reference27) and the European Association for the Study of Diabetes [(28)](#reference28) have included the use of diets of low GI/GL and high in dietary fiber and whole grains in their recommendations for diabetes prevention in high-risk individuals. The use of GI and GL is currently not implemented in US dietary guidelines [(29)](#reference29). Numerous observational studies have examined the relationship between dietary [GI](../glossary#glycemic-index)/ [GL](../glossary#glycemic-load) and the incidence of [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events, especially [coronary heart disease](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease) (CHD) and cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) (229,213 participants; follow-up of 11.5 years) and 23% increased risk of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) (CVD) with high versus low dietary GI and GL, respectively [(30)](#reference30). Three independent meta-analyses of prospective studies also reported that higher GI or GL was associated with increased risk of CHD in women but not in men [(31-33)](#reference31). A recent analysis of the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC) study in 20,275 Greek participants, followed for a median of 10.4 years, showed a significant increase in CHD incidence and mortality with high dietary GL specifically in those with high [BMI](../glossary#body-mass-index) (28 kg/m2) [(34)](#reference34). This is in line with earlier findings in the Nurses' Health Study (NHS) showing that a high dietary GL was associated with a doubling of the risk of CHD over 10 years in women with higher (23 kg/m2) vs. lower BMI [(35)](#reference35). A similar finding was reported in a cohort of middle-aged Dutch women followed for nine years [(36)](#reference36). Additionally, high dietary GL (but not GI) was associated with a 19% increased risk of stroke in pooled analyses of prospective cohort studies [(32](#reference32), [37)](#reference37). A meta-analysis of seven prospective studies (242,132 participants; 3,255 stroke cases) found that dietary GL was associated with an overall 23% increase in risk of stroke and a specific 35% increase in risk of [ischemic stroke](../glossary#ischemic-stroke); GL was not found to be related to [hemorrhagic stroke](../glossary#hemorrhagic-stroke) [(38)](#reference38). Overall, observational studies have found that higher glycemic load diets are associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease, especially in women and in those with higher BMIs. The GI/GL of carbohydrate foods may modify cardiometabolic markers associated with CVD risk. A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 27 randomized controlled trials (published between 1991 and 2008) examining the effect of low-GI diets on [serum](../glossary#serum) [lipid](../glossary#lipid) profile reported a significant reduction in total and [LDL](../glossary#LDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) independent of weight loss [(15)](#reference15). Yet, further analysis suggested significant reductions in serum lipids only with the consumption of low-GI diets with high fiber content. In a three-month, randomized controlled study, an increase in the values of flow-mediated dilation (FMD) of the brachial artery, a surrogate marker of vascular health, was observed following the consumption of a low- versus high-GI hypocaloric diet in obese subjects [(39)](#reference39). High dietary GLs have been associated with increased concentrations of markers of systemic [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), such as [C-reactive In a small 12-week dietary intervention study, the consumption of a Mediterranean-style, low-GL diet (without caloric restriction) significantly reduced waist circumference, [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance), [systolic blood pressure](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure), as well as plasma LDL-cholesterol, and TNF- in women with [metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome). A reduction in the [expression](../glossary#gene-expression) of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl (HMG)-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis), in blood cells further confirmed an effect for the low-GI diet on cholesterol [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) [(42)](#reference42). Well-controlled, long-term [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) are needed to confirm the potential cardiometabolic benefits of low GI/GL diets in people at risk for CVD. Evidence that high-GI or -GL diets are related to [cancer](../glossary#cancer) is inconsistent. A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 32 [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) and 20 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) found modest and nonsignificant increased risks of [hormone](../glossary#hormone)-related cancers (breast, [prostate](../glossary#prostate), ovarian, and cancers) and digestive tract cancers ( [esophageal](../glossary#esophagus), [gastric](../glossary#gastric), [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas), and liver cancers) with high versus low dietary GI and GL [(43)](#reference43). A significant positive association was found only between a high dietary GI and [colorectal cancer](../glossary#colorectal-cancer) [(43)](#reference43). Yet, earlier meta-analyses of prospective cohort studies failed to find a link between high-GI or -GL diets and colorectal cancer [(44-46)](#reference44). Another recent meta-analysis of prospective studies suggested a borderline increase in breast cancer risk with high dietary GI and GL. Adjustment for [confounding factors](../glossary#confounder) across studies found no modification of menopausal status or [BMI](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) on the association [(47)](#reference47). Further investigations are needed to verify whether GI and GL are associated with various cancers. Results of two studies indicate [GI](../glossary#glycemic-index) and [GL](../glossary#glycemic-load) may be related to [gallbladder](../glossary#gallbladder) disease: a higher dietary GI and GL were associated with significantly increased [risks](../glossary#risk) of developing [gallstones](../glossary#gallstones) in a cohort of men participating in the Health Professionals Follow-up Study [(48)](#reference48) and in a cohort of women participating in the Nurses' Health Study [(49)](#reference49). However, more [epidemiological](../glossary#epidemiological-study) research is needed to determine an association between dietary glycemic index/load and gallbladder disease. Whether low-GI foods could improve overall blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) control in people with type 1 or type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) has been investigated in a number of [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 19 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) that included 840 diabetic patients (191 with type 1 diabetes and 649 with type 2 diabetes) found that consumption of low-GI foods improved short-term and long-term control of blood glucose concentrations, reflected by significant decreases in fructosamine and glycated hemoglobin ( [HbA1c](../glossary#hemoglobin-A1c)) levels [(50)](#reference50). However, these results need to be cautiously interpreted because of significant [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) among the included studies. The American Diabetes Association has rated poorly the current evidence supporting the substitution of low-GL foods for high-GL foods to improve glycemic control in adults with type 1 or type 2 diabetes [(51, 52)](#reference51). Well-controlled studies are needed to further assess whether the use of low-GI/GL diets could significantly improve long-term glycemic control and the quality of life of subjects with diabetes. A randomized controlled study in 92 pregnant women (20-32 weeks) diagnosed with [gestational](../glossary#gestation) diabetes found no significant effects of a low-GI diet on maternal metabolic profile (e.g., blood concentrations of glucose, [insulin](../glossary#insulin), fructosamine, HbA1c; [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance)) and pregnancy outcomes (i.e., maternal weight gain and neonatal anthropometric measures) compared to a conventional high-fiber, moderate-GI diet [(53)](#reference53). The low-GI diet consumed during the pregnancy also failed to improve maternal [glucose tolerance](../glossary#glucose-tolerance), [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive), and other [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) risk factors, or and infant anthropometric data in a three-month postpartum follow-up study of 55 of the mother-infant pairs [(54)](#reference54). In addition, another trial in 139 pregnant women (12-20 weeks' gestation) at high risk for gestational diabetes showed no statistical differences regarding the diagnosis of gestational diabetes during the second and third trimester of pregnancy, the requirement for insulin therapy, and pregnancy outcomes and neonatal anthropometry whether women followed a low-GI diet or a high-fiber, moderate-GI diet [(55)](#reference55). At present, there is no evidence that a low-GI diet provides benefits beyond those of a healthy, moderate-GI diet in women at high risk or affected by gestational diabetes. [Obesity](../glossary#obesity) is often associated with metabolic disorders, such as [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia), [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance), [dyslipidemia](../glossary#dyslipidemia), and [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension), which place individuals risk for type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease), and early energy-restricted, with >50% of calories from carbohydrates, 30% from fat, and the remainder from [protein](../glossary#protein). However, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [randomized controlled intervention studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) (6 months' duration) has reported that or moderate-carbohydrate diets (4%-45% carbohydrate) and low-fat diets (10%-30% fat) were equally effective at reducing body weight and waist circumference in overweight or obese subjects [(58)](#reference58). Several dietary [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) have examined how low-GI/GL diets compared with conventional low-fat diets to promote weight loss. Lowering the GI of conventional energy-restricted, low-fat diets was proven to be more effective to reduce postpartum body weight and waist and hip circumferences and prevent type 2 diabetes mellitus in women with prior [gestational](../glossary#gestation) diabetes mellitus [(59)](#reference59). In a six-month dietary intervention study in 73 obese adults, no differences in weight loss were reported in subjects following either a low-GL diet (40% carbohydrate and 35% fat) or a low-fat diet (55% carbohydrate and 20% fat). Yet, the consumption of a low-GL diet increased [HDL](../glossary#HDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) and decreased [triglyceride](../glossary#triglycerides) concentrations significantly more than the low-fat diet, but [LDL](../glossary#LDL)-cholesterol concentration was significantly more reduced with the low-fat than low-GI diet [(60)](#reference60). A one-year randomized controlled study of 202 individuals with a [body mass index](../glossary#body-mass-index) (BMI) 28 and at least another metabolic disorder compared the effect of two dietary counseling-based interventions advocating either for a low-GL diet (30%-35% of calories from low-GI carbohydrates) or a low-fat diet (<30% of calories from fat) [(61)](#reference61). Weight loss with each diet was equivalent (~4 kg). Both interventions similarly reduced triglycerides, [C-reactive protein](../glossary#c-reactive-protein) (CRP), and fasting [insulin](../glossary#insulin), and increased HDL-cholesterol. Yet, the reduction in waist and hip circumferences was greater with the low-fat diet, while blood pressure was significantly more reduced with the low-GL diet [(61)](#reference61). In the GLYNDIET study, a six-month randomized dietary intervention trial, the comparison of two moderate-carbohydrate diets (42% of calories from carbohydrates) with different GIs (GI of 34 or GI of 62) and a low-fat diet (30% of calories from fat; GI of 65) on weight loss indicated that the low-GI diet reduced body weight more effectively than the low-fat diet. Additionally, the low-GI diet improved fasting insulin concentration, -cell function, and insulin resistance better than the low-fat diet. None of the diets modulated hunger or satiety or affected [biomarkers](../glossary#biomarker) of [endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) function or [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation). Finally, no significant differences were observed in low- compared to high-GL diets regarding weight loss and insulin [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) [(62)](#reference62). In a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 14 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) published between 2005 and 2011, neither high- nor low-GI/GL dietary interventions conducted for 6 to 17 months had any significant effect on body weight and waist circumference in a total of 2,344 overweight and obese subjects [(63)](#reference63). Low-GI/GL diets were found to significantly reduce [C-reactive protein](../glossary#c-reactive-protein) and fasting [insulin](../glossary#insulin) but had no effect on blood [lipid](../glossary#lipid) profile, fasting [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentration, or [HbA1c](../glossary#hemoglobin-A1c) concentration compared to high-GI/GL diets. It has been suggested that the consumption of low-GI foods delayed the return of hunger, decreased subsequent food intake, and increased satiety when compared to high-GI foods [(64)](#reference64). The effect of isocaloric low- and high-GI test meals on the activity of brain regions controlling appetite and eating behavior was evaluated in a small [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), blinded, [cross-over study](../glossary#cross-over-trial) in 12 overweight or obese men [(65)](#reference65). During the [postprandial](../glossary#postprandial) period, blood glucose and insulin rose higher after the high-GI meal than after the low-GI meal. In addition, in response to the excess insulin secretion, blood glucose dropped below fasting concentrations three to five hours after high-GI meal consumption. [Cerebral](../glossary#cerebrum) blood flow was significantly higher four hours after ingestion of the high-GI meal (compared to a low-GI meal) in a specific region of the striatum (right nucleus accumbens) associated with food intake reward and craving. If the data suggested that consuming low- rather than high-GI foods may help restrain overeating and protect against weight gain, this has not yet been confirmed in long-term randomized controlled trials. In the recent multicenter, randomized controlled Diet, Obesity, and Genes (DiOGenes) study in 256 overweight and obese individuals who lost 8% of body weight following an eight-week calorie-restricted diet, consumption of ad libitum diets with different [protein](../glossary#protein) and GI content for 12 months showed that only high-protein diets — regardless of their GI — could mitigate weight regain [(66)](#reference66). However, the dietary interventions only achieved a modest difference in GI (~5 units) between high- and low-GI diets such that the effect of GI in weight maintenance remained unknown. Lifestyle modification programs do not currently include the reduction of calories from carbohydrate as an alternative to standard prescription of low-fat diets, nor do they suggest the use of GI/GL as a guide to healthier dietary choices [(67)](#reference67).
