Diabetes Care. 2008;31(12):2281-2283. ] [(PubMed)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18835944) Contents Coffee, an infusion of ground, roasted coffee beans, is among the most widely consumed beverages in the world. The main types of coffee consumed are (1) boiled unfiltered coffee, (2) filtered coffee, and (3) decaffeinated coffee [(1)](#references). Although caffeine has received the most attention from scientists, coffee is a complex mixture of many chemicals, including [carbohydrates](../glossary#carbohydrate), The composition of coffee varies with the source of coffee beans (Coffea arabica or Coffea canephora var. robusta) [(3)](#reference3), as well as with the method of preparation (i.e., filtration methods, boiling, steeping, or brewing under pressure) [(1, 4)](#references). Chlorogenic acids are a family of [esters](../glossary#ester) formed between quinic acid and [phenolic compounds](../glossary#phenolic-compound) known as cinnamic acids (mostly caffeic acid and ferulic acid) [(1)](#references). The most abundant chlorogenic acid in coffee is 5-O-caffeoylquinic acid, an ester formed between quinic acid and caffeic acid (Figure 1). Coffee represents one of the richest dietary sources of chlorogenic acids. The chlorogenic acid content of a 200 mL (7-oz) cup of coffee has been reported to range from 70 to 350 mg, which would provide about 35 to 175 mg of caffeic acid. Although chlorogenic and caffeic acids have demonstrated [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) activities [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) [(5)](#reference5), it is unclear how much antioxidant activity they contribute [in vivo](../glossary#in-vivo) because they are extensively [metabolized](../glossary#metabolism), and the [metabolites](../glossary#metabolite) often have lower antioxidant activity than the parent compounds [(6, 7)](#reference6). Additionally, the antioxidant capacity of coffee is attenuated by the decaffeination process, which decreases total polyphenol content [(8)](#reference8). Other phenolic compounds in coffee, though less abundant than chlorogenic acids, include tannins, [lignans](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/lignans), and anthocyanine [(1)](#references). Caffeine (1,3,7-trimethylxanthine) is a purine alkaloid that occurs naturally in coffee beans (Figure 2). At intake levels associated with coffee consumption, caffeine appears to exert most of its biological effects through [antagonism](../glossary#antagonism) of the A1 and A2A subtypes of the [(1)](#references). Adenosine of [neurons](../glossary#neuron) to [neurotransmitters](../glossary#neurotransmitter). Adenosine has mostly inhibitory effects in the [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system), so the effects of adenosine antagonism by caffeine are generally stimulatory. Caffeine is rapidly and almost completely absorbed in the stomach and [small intestine](../glossary#small-intestine) and then distributed to all tissues, including the brain. Caffeine concentrations in coffee beverages can be quite variable. A standard cup of coffee is often assumed to provide 100 mg of caffeine, but an analysis of 14 different specialty coffees purchased at coffee shops in the US found that the amount of caffeine in 8 oz (~240 mL) of brewed coffee ranged from 72 to 130 mg [(9)](#reference9). Caffeine in espresso coffees ranged from 58 to 76 mg in a single shot (~35 to 50 mL). In countries other than the US, coffee is often stronger, but the volume per cup is smaller, making 100 mg of caffeine/cup a reasonable estimate. Cafestol and kahweol are fat-soluble compounds known as diterpenes (Figure 3), which have been found to raise [serum](../glossary#serum) total and [LDL](../glossary#LDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentrations in humans [(10)](#reference10). Some cafestol and kahweol are extracted from ground coffee during brewing, but are largely removed from coffee by paper filters. Scandinavian boiled coffee, Turkish coffee, and French press (cafetiere) coffee contain relatively high levels of cafestol and kahweol (6 to 12 mg/cup), while filtered coffee, percolated coffee, and instant coffee contain low levels of cafestol and kahweol (0.2 to 0.6 mg/cup) [(11)](#reference11). Although diterpene concentrations are relatively high in espresso coffee, the small serving size makes it an intermediate source of cafestol and kahweol (4 mg/cup). Since coffee beans are high in cafestol and kahweol, ingestion of coffee beans or grounds on a regular basis may also raise serum total and LDL-cholesterol. Trigonelline (N-methylnicotinic acid) is a plant alkaloid derived from [niacin](../vitamins/niacin) (vitamin B3) (Figure 4). Trigonelline is largely broken down to nicotinic acid during the roasting process, although some intact molecules remain in roasted beans. Trigonelline has been found to exert [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant), [hypoglycemic](../glossary#hypoglycemia), and hypolipidemic activities (reviewed in [1](#references)). The three largest [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) in the US to examine the relationship between caffeinated coffee consumption and type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) were the Health Professionals Follow-up Study the Nurses' Health 84,276 women), and the NHS II (88,259 women). Men who drank at least six cups of coffee daily had a 54% lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing type 2 diabetes than men who did not drink coffee. In the NHS I cohort, women who drank at least six cups of coffee daily had a 29% lower risk of type 2 diabetes than women who did not drink coffee [(12)](#reference12). In the NHS II cohort, women who consumed 4 cups of coffee daily had a 39% lower risk of developing type 2 diabetes; similar results were found in women who drank 2 to 3 cups/day of coffee [(13)](#reference13). In a pooled analysis of all three cohorts, an increase in caffeinated coffee intake by >1 cup/day over a four-year period was associated with a 13% decreased risk of type 2 diabetes in the subsequent four years; those who decreased their intake of caffeinated coffee by >1 cup/day had a 20% increased risk of type 2 diabetes over the four-year period [(14)](#reference14). Several other cohort studies have found higher coffee intakes to be associated with significant reductions in the risk of type 2 diabetes. A [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 18 prospective cohort studies (published between 1966 and 2009), including more than 450,000 men and women, found that the risk of developing type 2 diabetes was 24% lower in those consuming 3 to 4 cups/day of coffee compared to those consuming 2 cups/day or none [(15)](#reference15). Two additional meta-analyses that included data from more recent prospective cohort studies were published concomitantly and found similar results [(16, 17)](#reference16). The data analysis of 28 prospective studies in over 1 million participants with 45,335 incident cases of diabetes reported a 30% decreased risk of type 2 diabetes with coffee intake of 5 cups/day versus 0 cups/day [(16)](#reference16). In addition, a 9% reduction in the incidence of type 2 diabetes was estimated for every one cup per day increase in total coffee intake. Likewise, a dose-response analysis of 11 studies found a 6% reduction in type 2 diabetes incidence for every one cup per day increase in decaffeinated coffee intake. Every 140 mg/day (~1 cup/day of coffee) increment in caffeine intake was also associated with an 8% reduction in the risk of type 2 diabetes [(16)](#reference16). Although decaffeinated coffee consumption is associated with a more modest decrease in the risk of type 2 diabetes, it is likely that compounds other than caffeine contribute to the reduction in diabetes risk. The mechanisms that might contribute to the association between coffee consumption and lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of type 2 [diabetes](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) in [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) are unclear. Bioactive compounds other than caffeine appear to show temporary [hypoglycemic](../glossary#hypoglycemia) effects. For example, the acute ingestion of chlorogenic acid (1 g) and trigonelline (0.5 g) transiently lowered blood [glucose](../glossary#glucose) concentration shortly after the administration of 75 g of glucose in an oral [glucose tolerance](../glossary#glucose-tolerance) test [(18)](#reference18). Conversely, short-term [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have found that acute administration of caffeine (3 to 6 mg/kg) impaired glucose tolerance and decreased [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) in healthy participants [(19)](#reference19). In addition, incremental doses of decaffeinated coffee (1, 2, and 4 servings) failed to lower [postprandial](../glossary#postprandial) blood glucose in the presence of 100 mg of caffeine [(20)](#reference20). However, despite the deleterious effect of caffeine on glucose [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis), caffeinated coffee consumption may favorably affect other metabolic pathways. In a single-blinded clinical trial, subjects at risk for type 2 diabetes abstained from drinking caffeinated coffee for one month, then consumed 4 cups/day of coffee for another month, and finally consumed 8 cups/day for a third month. Compared to one month of coffee abstinence, the consumption of 8 cups/day of coffee for one month appeared to increase [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) capacity and reduce [subclinical](../glossary#subclinical) [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), as indicated by changes in [plasma](../glossary#plasma) markers of [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) and inflammation [(21)](#reference21). Until the relationship between long-term coffee consumption and type 2 diabetes risk is better understood, it is premature to recommend coffee consumption as a means of preventing type 2 diabetes [(12](#reference12), [22)](#reference22). Studies in animal models of [Parkinson's disease](../glossary#parkinson-disease) suggest that caffeine may protect dopaminergic [neurons](../glossary#neuron) by acting as an adenosine A2A- [receptor](../glossary#receptor) the brain [(23)](#reference23). Several large [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have examined coffee and/or caffeine intakes in association with Parkinson's disease [risk](../glossary#risk). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine prospective cohort studies found higher caffeine intake to be associated with significant reductions in Parkinson's disease risk in both men (-39%) and women (-29%) [(24)](#reference24). In another meta-analysis of six [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) and seven prospective studies, including 901,764 participants and 3,954 cases, an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between coffee intake and Parkinson's disease risk — only significant in men — was found to be nonlinear, with no further risk reduction beyond 3 to 4 cups/day of coffee. This meta-analysis also reported significant reductions in Parkinson's disease risk in men (-43%) and women (-36%) with the highest (700 mg/day) versus lowest (100 mg/day) intake of caffeine [(25)](#reference25). However, while prospective studies have consistently found a lower risk of developing Parkinson's disease with higher coffee and caffeine intakes in men, such an association has not always been observed in women [(26-28)](#reference26). It is hypothesized that [estrogen](../glossary#estrogen) replacement therapy may modify the interaction between caffeine and risk of Parkinson's disease in postmenopausal women. Indeed, because estrogen and caffeine are metabolized by hepatic [cytochrome P450](../glossary#cytochrome-P450) (CYP) 1A2 in the body, estrogen might compete for CYP1A2 activity and hinder the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of caffeine in estrogen users [(29)](#reference29). An analysis of data from more than 77,000 female nurses, followed for 18 years in NHS I, revealed that coffee consumption was inversely associated with Parkinson's disease risk in women who had never used postmenopausal estrogen [(30)](#reference30). However, drinking 6 cups of coffee was associated with an increased risk or Parkinson's disease in women who had used postmenopausal estrogen [(30)](#reference30). In a prospective cohort study that included more than 238,000 women, a significant inverse association between coffee consumption and Parkinson's disease mortality was also observed in women who had never used postmenopausal estrogen, but not in those who had used postmenopausal estrogen [(31)](#reference31). Yet, in a recent analysis of the National Institutes of Health (NIH)-AARP Diet and Health Study, which included 303,880 participants and 1,100 cases, the highest versus lowest intake of caffeine was associated with a reduced risk of Parkinson's disease in postmenopausal women who ever used hormones but not among never users [(24)](#reference24). At present, it remains unclear whether caffeine consumption can prevent Parkinson's disease, particularly in women taking estrogen. Of note, whether caffeine could help reduce some common symptoms associated with Parkinson's disease (e.g., sleepiness, freezing of gait) is under investigation [(32, 33)](#reference32). Results from [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) regarding a possible link between coffee consumption and [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) disorders are inconclusive. A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) in 34,282 older adults reported an 18% reduced [risk](../glossary#risk) of cognitive disorders with 1 to 2 cups/day of coffee compared to <1 cup/day [(34)](#reference34). Yet, there was no difference in risk of cognitive disorders between daily coffee intakes >3 cups and <1 cup [(34)](#reference34). Two other meta-analyses of prospective studies failed to find an association between high versus low intakes of coffee and risk of cognitive disorders [(35, 36)](#reference35). No dose-response relationship was reported between coffee intake and risk of cognitive disorders [(36)](#reference36). Whether moderate coffee intake may reduce the risk of cognitive decline and [dementia](../glossary#dementia) later in life is still not known. Chronic [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation)-inducing liver injury may result in [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis). In cirrhosis, the formation of fibrotic scar tissue leads to the progressive deterioration of liver function and other complications, including liver [cancer](../glossary#cancer) (primarily hepatocellular carcinoma [HCC]) [(37)](#reference37). The most common causes of cirrhosis in developed countries are alcohol abuse and chronic infections with [hepatitis](../glossary#hepatitis) B and C [viruses](../glossary#virus). Often associated with metabolic disorders, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a liver condition that can progress to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) in about one-third of NAFLD patients, thereby increasing the [risk](../glossary#risk) of cirrhosis and HCC [(38)](#reference38). A [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) in 177 subjects with chronic liver disease (especially chronic hepatitis B or C and NASH) found an association between daily caffeine intake >308 mg — equivalent to >2 cups/day of coffee — and a lower risk of having advanced liver fibrosis [(39)](#reference39). Of note, no association was reported with non-coffee sources of caffeine like caffeinated soda or green and black tea [(39)](#reference39). Recent cross-sectional studies also suggested a protective association of coffee intake against fibrosis development in patients with hepatitis C [(40, 41)](#reference40). Additional studies have suggested that consumption of coffee, but not of caffeine, was [inversely associated ](../glossary#inverse-association)with the risk of advanced liver fibrosis in patients with NAFLD or NASH [(42-44)](#reference42). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of four [case-control](../glossary#case-control-study) and three [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) reported an inverse association between coffee consumption and risk of cirrhosis [(45)](#reference45). In addition, a few large prospective cohort studies found that coffee drinking was associated with reduced mortality from alcoholic cirrhosis [(46-49)](#reference46). A 17-year study of more than 51,000 men and women in Norway found that those who consumed 2 cups/day of coffee had a risk of cirrhosis-related death that was 40% lower than those who never consumed coffee [(49)](#reference49). A 22-year prospective cohort study in 125,580 US adults found that coffee drinking was protective against alcoholic cirrhosis but not nonalcoholic cirrhosis [(48)](#reference48). Specifically, the risk of developing alcoholic cirrhosis was 40% lower in those who drank 1 to 3 cups/day of coffee and 80% lower in those who drank 4 cups/day [(48)](#reference48). Recent data from 63,275 Chinese participants of the Singapore Chinese Health Study showed that consumption of 2 cups/day of coffee was associated with a 66% lower risk of death from non-viral hepatitis-related cirrhosis — no such association was found with mortality from cirrhosis due to viral hepatitis [(46)](#reference46). Several case-control and prospective cohort studies have found significant inverse associations between coffee consumption and the risk of HCC (reviewed in [50](#reference50)). In a recent 18-year prospective cohort study of 162,022 US adults — comprising Japanese Americans, Caucasians, Mexican Americans, African Americans, and Native Hawaiians — consumption of coffee, but not decaffeinated coffee, was inversely associated with risk of developing HCC [(51)](#reference51). Specifically, drinking 2 to 3 cups/day of coffee was associated with a 38% reduced risk of HCC compared to no coffee drinking [(51)](#reference51). In addition, the risk of chronic liver disease-related mortality was 71% lower in individuals consuming 4 cups/day of regular coffee and 46% lower in those consuming 2 cups/day of decaffeinated coffee compared to non-consumers [(51)](#reference51). A pooled analysis of this study with 10 other prospective cohort studies found an overall 46% lower risk of liver cancer with coffee consumption (see also [Cancer](#cancer-prevention)) [(52)](#reference52). Numerous [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have examined the relationship between coffee consumption and [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [risk](../glossary#risk) [(53, 54)](#reference53). Results from recently published [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of observational studies are reported in Table 1. In addition, a recent meta-analysis of [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) by Wang et al. [(54)](#reference54) investigated the relationships between the highest versus lowest categories of coffee intake and the risk of most cancer types. Coffee consumption was found to be associated with reduced risks of oral/pharyngeal cancer (6 studies; -31%), [colon](../glossary#colon) -11%) [(54)](#reference54). Overall, these results are in agreement with those from other pooled analyses of prospective studies presented in Table 1. However, unlike the results reported by Wang et al. [(54)](#reference54), coffee consumption has been [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with the risk of colon cancer in [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study), but not in prospective cohort studies (see Table 1). Also, in the case of prostate cancer, several meta-analyses suggested a reduced risk with increased coffee intake in prospective but not case-control studies [(54-56)](#reference54). However, whether this association exists only in certain study populations or at specific cancer stages remains unclear [(57, 58)](#reference57). There seems to be little evidence of associations between coffee consumption and breast cancer, [esophageal](../glossary#esophagus) cancer, glioma, laryngeal cancer, [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) cancer, [rectal](../glossary#rectum) cancer, stomach and [thyroid](../glossary#thyroid) cancer (Table 1) [(54)](#reference54). |Type of Cancer||Type of Observational Risk Ratio [OR]# (95% Confidence Interval)||Relative Risk [RR] or Odds Ratio [OR] Subgroup Analyses (e.g., by study types)||References| |Breast cancer||10 and RR: 1.01 (0.93-1.09) | Li et al. 0.94 (0.89-1.00) for case-control (0.53-0.89) among BRCA1 mutation carriers Finally, there is some evidence suggesting a potential increase in the risk of lung cancer with the highest versus lowest levels of coffee intakes. Yet, cigarette smoking has a major [confounding](../glossary#confounder) effect on this association (see [Health risks associated with coffee consumption](#potential-health-risks)) [(54](#reference54), [70)](#reference70). Three large [prospective women), NHS II (93,054 women), and HPFS (40,557 men), examined whether coffee drinking was associated with all-cause, [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease)-related, or [cancer](../glossary#cancer)-related mortality [(80)](#reference80). Compared to no coffee consumption, the consumption of coffee, whether caffeinated or decaffeinated, up to 5 cups/day, was [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with all-cause mortality. There was no difference in [risk](../glossary#risk) of death between non-consumers and consumers of >5 cups/day of coffee. Coffee consumption was also found to be inversely associated with mortality related to cardiovascular disease, [neurological](../glossary#neurologic) disease, and suicide [(80)](#reference80). Other large cohort studies have reported habitual consumption of any coffee being inversely associated with all-cause and cardiovascular disease-related mortality, but generally not with cancer-related mortality [(81-86)](#reference81). Moreover, the associations have not always been consistent among women and men, especially regarding cancer-related mortality [(85, 86)](#reference85). A dose-response [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 21 prospective studies found a nonlinear inverse association between coffee consumption and all-cause and cardiovascular disease-related mortality [(87)](#reference87). Consumption of only 1 cup/day of coffee was significantly associated with lower risk of all-cause (-8%) and cardiovascular disease-related mortality (-11%). The largest risk reductions for all-cause (-16%) and cardiovascular disease-related mortality (-21%) were found to be associated with the consumption of 4 cups/day and 3 cups/day of coffee, respectively [(87)](#reference87). Most adverse effects attributed to coffee consumption are related to caffeine. In healthy adults, daily caffeine consumption 400 mg — corresponding to 6.5 mg/kg body weight/day for a 70-kg person — is usually not associated with adverse effects [(88)](#reference88). Caffeine intakes of less than 300 mg/day in women of childbearing age (equivalent to 4.3 mg/kg body weight/day for a 70-kg woman) and less than 2.5 mg/kg body weight/day in children are unlikely to cause adverse effects [(88)](#reference88). Adverse reactions to caffeine may include tachycardia (rapid heart rate), palpitations, insomnia, restlessness, nervousness, tremor, headache, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and diuresis (increased urination) [(89)](#reference89). Very high caffeine intakes, not usually coffee, may induce hypokalemia (abnormally low [serum](../glossary#serum) [potassium](../minerals/potassium)) [(90)](#reference90). Sudden cessation of caffeine consumption after long-term use may result in caffeine withdrawal symptoms [(91)](#reference91). Gradual withdrawal from caffeine appears less likely to result in withdrawal symptoms than abrupt withdrawal [(92)](#reference92). Commonly reported caffeine withdrawal symptoms include headache, fatigue, drowsiness, irritability, difficulty concentrating, and depressed mood. [Serum lipids: An early ] [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found that the consumption of unfiltered, boiled coffee dose-dependently increased [serum](../glossary#serum) total and [LDL](../glossary#LDL)- [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) concentrations, while the consumption of filtered coffee resulted in very little change [(93)](#reference93). A more recent meta-analysis of 12 randomized controlled trials reported that the consumption of coffee increased serum total cholesterol by 8.1 mg/dL, LDL-cholesterol by 5.1 mg/dL, and [triglycerides](../glossary#triglycerides) by 12.6 mg/dL [(94)](#reference94). The consumption of filtered coffee raised total cholesterol by only 3.6 mg/dL compared to an increase of 12.9 mg/dL with unfiltered coffee consumption. Unlike filtered coffee, consumption of unfiltered coffee significantly increased LDL-cholesterol and triglycerides by 11.9 mg/dL and 18.8 mg/dL, respectively [(94)](#reference94). The cholesterol-raising factors in unfiltered coffee have been identified as cafestol and kahweol, two diterpenes that are largely removed from coffee by paper filters (see [Diterpenes](#diterpenes)) [(10)](#reference10). [Homocysteine: An elevated ] [plasma](../glossary#plasma) total [homocysteine](../glossary#homocysteine) concentration has been associated with increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease), including coronary heart disease, [stroke](../health-disease/stroke), and [peripheral vascular disease](../glossary#peripheral-arterial-disease), but the relationship may not be causal [(95)](#reference95). Higher coffee intakes have been associated with increased plasma homocysteine concentrations in [cross-sectional studies](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) conducted in Europe, Scandinavia, and the US [(96-100)](#reference96). Controlled [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have confirmed the homocysteine-raising effect of coffee at intakes of about 4 cups/day [(101-103)](#reference101). [Hypertension: of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) showed that high intakes of coffee (3 to 5 cups/day) for <85 days significantly increased [systolic](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure)/ Hg](../glossary#mm-Hg) [(104)](#reference104) or 2.4/1.2 mm Hg [(105)](#reference105). Although the increases in blood pressure seem modest by individual standards, it has been estimated that an average systolic blood pressure reduction of 2 mm Hg in a population may result in 10% lower mortality from [stroke](../health-disease/stroke) and 7% lower mortality from [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) [(106)](#reference106). However, a more recent pooled analysis excluding the trials that used decaffeinated coffee in control groups — and thus assessed the effect of caffeine rather than that of coffee — found no significant changes in systolic blood pressure and diastolic blood pressure with high coffee intakes [(107)](#reference107). Additionally, two meta-analyses combined the data from [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) that examined prospectively the association between habitual coffee consumption and risk of hypertension [(107, 108)](#reference107). One meta-analysis of six [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) included 172,567 non-hypertensive participants (one study enrolled pre-hypertensive subjects) of which 37,135 cases of incident hypertension were reported over follow-up periods spanning from 6.4 years to 33 years [(108)](#reference108). Compared to coffee intakes of <1 cup/day, intakes of 1 to 3 cups/day were found to be associated with a 9% increased risk of hypertension. However, no such association could be observed for coffee intakes >3 cups/day [(108)](#reference108). Another meta-analysis of four prospective cohort studies found no association between coffee consumption and risk of hypertension [(107)](#reference107). Also, a recent analysis of data from 29,985 postmenopausal women followed for nearly four years in the Women's Health Initiative Observational Study found no increased risk of hypertension with intakes of caffeinated coffee, decaffeinated coffee, or caffeine [(109)](#reference109). While there is little evidence of an association between long-term coffee consumption and risk of hypertension, the available evidence from trials suggests that consumption of caffeine modestly raises systolic blood pressure. Whether this may result in increased risk of stroke and coronary heart disease in the population, particularly in those with hypertension, is still uncertain. Yet, to date, regular coffee consumption in hypertensive subjects has not been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease [(110)](#reference110). [Coronary heart disease: A ] [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 20 including 407,806 participants and 15,599 incident [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) (CHD) cases, found no significant association between coffee consumption and CHD risk [(111)](#reference111). Yet, a more recent meta-analysis of 22 prospective cohort studies reported a modest reduction in CHD risk with moderate (3-5 cups/day) — but not high (6 cups/day) — coffee intakes compared to low intakes (<1 cup/day) [(112)](#reference112). In addition, [cross-sectional studies](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) have provided little evidence that the formation of [atherosclerotic](../health-disease/atherosclerosis) plaques, an early event in the development of CHD, is more prevalent in regular coffee drinkers than in non-drinkers [(113-116)](#reference113). Coffee consumption has not been linked to the development of atherosclerosis in two prospective cohort studies. In the Coronary Artery Risk Development in Young Adults (CARDIA) study that followed approximately 4,000 young US adults for 15 to 20 years, there was no evidence of an association between regular coffee intake and progression of [coronary artery](../glossary#coronary-artery) [calcification](../glossary#calcification), a measure of [subclinical](../glossary#subclinical) atherosclerosis [(117)](#reference117). Moreover, in the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) that followed about 6,500 US adults over a median period of 11.1 years, occasional but not regular drinking of coffee was associated with a 28% increased risk of cardiovascular disease compared with no drinking [(114)](#reference114). This study found no association between coffee intake and progression of coronary artery calcification [(114)](#reference114). [Cardiac arrhythmias: Early ] [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) found coffee or caffeine intake equivalent to 5 to 6 cups/day did not increas the frequency or severity of cardiac [arrhythmias](../health-disease/arrhythmia) in healthy people or in people with [coronary heart disease](../health-disease/coronary-heart-disease) [(118, 119)](#reference118). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of six [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) in 214,316 participants found no association between coffee consumption and [risk](../glossary#risk) of [atrial fibrillation](../glossary#atrial-fibrillation), the most common type of cardiac arrhythmias. In addition, a recent meta-analysis of 11 short-term [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) (single dose to two-week trials) found that caffeine consumption did not increase the occurrence of [ventricular](../glossary#ventricles) arrhythmias [(120)](#reference120). Finally, two meta-analyses of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) found no evidence to suggest that caffeine consumption was associated with an increased risk of atrial fibrillation and even reported a modest reduction in risk with moderate intakes [(121, 122)](#reference121). Thus, consumption of coffee or caffeine at usual intakes does not appear to increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias. The current evidence does not support clinical recommendations that discourage moderate consumption of coffee in patients at risk or with suspicions of cardiac arrhythmia [(120, 123)](#reference120). [Stroke: A 2011 ] [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) that included eight [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) — all following participants who were free of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) and [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) at baseline — found that consumption of 3 to 4 cups/day of coffee was associated with an 18% lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of [stroke](../glossary#stroke) compared with no consumption and that higher intakes were not associated with an increased risk [(124)](#reference124). Since this meta-analysis, a few large prospective studies have reported mixed results on the association between coffee consumption and stroke incidence or stroke-related mortality. Results from 42,659 participants in the German cohort of the European Prospective Investigation in Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC-Germany) reported no association between coffee consumption and stroke incidence over an 8.9 year-period [(125)](#reference125). Compared to no intake, consumption of 3-6 cups/week of coffee was associated with a reduced risk of stroke in a prospective study of 82,369 Japanese participants [(126)](#reference126). Also, the consumption of 4 to 5 cups/day of coffee was associated with a reduced risk of stroke-related mortality among men, but not women, followed in the large prospective NIH-AARP Diet and Health Study [(81)](#reference81). Several [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have examined the relationship between coffee intake and lung [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [risk](../glossary#risk) in humans. A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 12 [case-control](../glossary#case-control-study) and 5 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), including a total of 12,276 cases and 102,516 controls, found an overall 31% increased risk of lung cancer with the highest versus lowest levels of coffee intake (see [Table 1](#table-1)). Subgroup analyses outlined a significant increase in lung cancer risk with coffee intake in hospital-based case-control (+36%) and prospective cohort studies (+59%), in studies conducted in American (+34%) and Asian (+49%) populations, in men (+41%), and in smokers (+24%); conversely, no significant association between coffee intake and lung cancer risk was found in community-based case-control studies, in studies conducted in European populations, in women, and in non-smokers [(70)](#reference70). Another meta-analysis of 13 case-control and 8 prospective cohort studies, including 19,892 cases and 623,645 controls, found a 9% increased risk of lung cancer in coffee drinkers compared to non-drinkers [(127)](#reference127). However, a pooled analysis restricted to the 16 (out of 21) studies that adjusted for smoking found no significant association between coffee intake and risk of lung cancer [ [RR](../glossary#relative-risk): 1.03 (0.95-1.12)]. Cigarette smoking is a major [confounding](../glossary#confounder) factor in the association between coffee consumption and lung cancer risk, and the evidence suggests that coffee intake is unlikely to be a risk factor for lung cancer. Of note, [residual confounding](../glossary#residual-confounding) by smoking remains a concern when a slight increase in lung cancer risk is still observed in studies even after adjustment for tobacco smoking [(127)](#reference127). It has been suggested that in utero exposure to caffeine through maternal coffee consumption might have adverse effects on the embryo/fetus during pregnancy and the offspring. Miscarriage: The results of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) that have examined the relationship between maternal coffee or caffeine intake and the [risk](../glossary#risk) of miscarriage (spontaneous abortion) have been conflicting. While some [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have observed significant associations between high caffeine intakes, particularly from coffee, and the risk of spontaneous abortion [(128-132)](#reference128), other studies have not [(133-136)](#reference133). The most recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 14 prospective cohort studies in 130,456 pregnant women and 3,429 cases of miscarriage found risk of miscarriage increased by 40% and 72% with maternal caffeine intakes of 350 to 699 mg/day and 700 mg/day during pregnancy, respectively [(137)](#reference137). No significant associations were found for daily doses of caffeine less than 350 mg. A dose-response analysis found a 7% increase in the risk of miscarriage per 100 mg/day-increment in caffeine intake during pregnancy [(137)](#reference137). Of note, one prospective cohort study that assessed caffeine intake by measuring [serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of paraxanthine, a caffeine [metabolite](../glossary#metabolite), found that the risk of spontaneous abortion was only elevated in women with paraxanthine concentrations that suggested caffeine intakes of 600 mg/day [(138)](#reference138). It has been proposed that an association between caffeine consumption and the risk of spontaneous abortion could be explained by the relationship between nausea and fetal viability [(139)](#reference139). Nausea is more common in women with viable pregnancies than nonviable pregnancies, such that women with viable pregnancies may be more likely avoid or limit caffeine consumption due to nausea [(140)](#reference140). However, at least one study found that the significant increase in risk of spontaneous abortion observed in women with caffeine intakes >300 mg/day was independent of nausea in pregnancy [(141)](#reference141). Additionally, two other studies found that caffeine consumption was associated with an increased risk of spontaneous abortion in women who experienced nausea or aversion to coffee during pregnancy [(131](#reference131), [142)](#reference142). Nonetheless, this does not exclude the possibility of reverse causality, when the loss of fetal viability results in reduction of pregnancy symptoms, like nausea and aversion to coffee, and may be followed by an increase in coffee intake [(137)](#reference137). Of note, consumption of <400 mg/day of caffeine or <4 cups/day of caffeinated coffee by women prior to pregnancy has not been linked to the risk of miscarriage in an analysis of a large prospective study (NHS I) that followed 11,072 women and a total of 15,590 pregnancies [(143)](#reference143). Although the topic remains unsettled, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends that women limit their daily caffeine intake to <200 mg during pregnancy [(144)](#reference144). Intrauterine growth restriction and low birth weight: [Observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) examining the effects of maternal caffeine and coffee consumption on fetal growth have assessed intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR; also known as small-for-gestational age; defined as fetal weight <10th percentile for gestational age), and/or incidence of low birth weight (defined as weight at birth <2,500 g [5.5 pounds]). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) reported a 38% increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of low birth weight with the highest versus lowest intakes of caffeine during pregnancy [(145)](#reference145). This risk appeared to increase linearly with incremental doses of caffeine [(145, 146)](#reference145). A dose-response meta-analysis of six prospective cohort and five case-control studies found a 7% increased risk of low-birth-weight infants per 100 mg of caffeine consumed daily during pregnancy [(146)](#reference146). Likewise, a 100 mg-increment in maternal caffeine intakes has been associated with a 10% increased risk of small-for-gestational age infants in the dose-response analysis of 10 prospective cohort and 5 case-control studies [(146)](#reference146). At present, only one study has examined the impact of limiting caffeine intake during pregnancy on birth weight. In a [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [intervention trial](../glossary#intervention-trial) that [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) 1,197 regular coffee drinkers (3 cups/day of coffee) to drink decaffeinated (median caffeine intake of 117 mg/day) or caffeinated coffee (median caffeine intake of 317 mg/day) throughout the second half of their pregnancy, no differences in length of [gestation](../glossary#gestation) or infant birth weight were found between the two groups [(147)](#reference147). Although the relationship between maternal caffeine consumption and fetal growth requires further clarification, it appears that even moderate caffeine intakes might adversely affect fetal growth in non-smoking women [(145, 146, 148)](#reference145). Limiting caffeine intake to 100 mg/day (1 cup/day of coffee) during pregnancy may be recommended to avoid any adverse effect, assuming that the associations of caffeine intake with the risk of IUGR and low birth weight are causal [(145, 146)](#reference145). Birth defects: Potential relationships between coffee consumption during pregnancy and [congenital birth defects](../glossary#congenital-anomaly) have been investigated in the US population-based National Birth Defects Prevention Study (NBDPS), an ongoing multi-site [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study). In an analysis that included mothers of 1,531 infants with cleft lips (with or without cleft palates), 813 infants with cleft palates only, and 5,711 control infants, no association was found between the highest versus lowest intakes of coffee and caffeine and the [risk](../glossary#risk) of orofacial clefts [(149)](#reference149). Another analysis, including mothers of 3,346 cases and 6,642 control infants, suggested an increased risk of [anotia](../glossary#anotia)/ [microtia](../glossary#microtia) and [craniosynostosis](../glossary#craniosynostosis) with the consumption of coffee or caffeine. However, no dose-response could be detected [(150)](#reference150). Further, an analysis of the NBDPS in mothers of 844 infants with limb deficiencies and 8,069 control infants found no increased risk associated with coffee and/or caffeine intake during pregnancy [(151)](#reference151). There was no association between maternal coffee or caffeine intake during pregnancy and risk of congenital talipes equinovarus (known as "clubfoot") in another US population-based case-control study of mothers of 646 infants with isolated clubfoot and 2,037 control infants [(152)](#reference152). Finally, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) that combined data from one [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) and six case-control studies found no association between maternal coffee consumption during pregnancy and risk of [neural tube defects](../glossary#neural-tube-defect) [(153)](#reference153). At present, there is no convincing evidence that maternal consumption of 3 cups/day of coffee or 300 mg/day of caffeine during pregnancy increases the risk of congenital malformations in humans. Childhood acute leukemia: The [etiology](../glossary#etiology) of acute lymphoblastic [leukemia](../glossary#leukemia) (ALL) and acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML), which primarily affect children, is unclear. It has been suggested that exposure to caffeine during pregnancy might have long-lasting adverse effects on the health of the offspring. A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of seven [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) that examined maternal coffee consumption during pregnancy in relation to the incidence of childhood acute leukemia found coffee consumption was associated with increased risks of overall acute leukemia (+72%), ALL (+65%), and AML (+58%) [(154)](#reference154). Another meta-analysis of eight case-control studies found an increased risk of ALL (+43%), but not AML, with the highest versus lowest intakes of coffee during pregnancy [(155)](#reference155). High versus low consumption of other sources of caffeine during pregnancy (tea, cola beverages) and childhood (cola beverages) were not found to be associated with childhood acute leukemia [(155)](#reference155). The evidence of a positive association between maternal coffee intake and childhood acute leukemia is currently limited to case-control studies. Case-control studies usually include more [cancer](../glossary#cancer) cases than prospective cohort studies, but they are subject to [recall bias](../glossary#recall-bias) with respect to coffee consumption and selection [bias](../glossary#bias) with respect to the control group [(156)](#reference156). Further studies with a prospective design are needed to confirm the possible link between coffee intake during pregnancy and childhood acute leukemia. The American Academy of Pediatrics categorizes caffeine as a maternal medication that is usually compatible with breast-feeding [(157)](#reference157). Although high maternal caffeine intakes have been reported to cause irritability and poor sleeping patterns in infants, no adverse effects have been reported with moderate maternal intake of caffeinated beverages equivalent to 2 to 3 cups of coffee daily. [Osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis) is a multifactorial bone disorder that compromises bone mass and strength and increases the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [fracture](../glossary#fracture). The results of early controlled studies in humans indicated that coffee and caffeine consumption decreased the efficiency of calcium absorption resulting in a loss of about 4 to 6 mg of calcium per cup of coffee [(158, 159)](#reference158). However, there is little evidence to suggest detrimental effects of coffee on bone health in populations with adequate calcium intakes [(160)](#reference160). To date, results from [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) that examined associations between coffee intakes and measures of [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) (BMD) loss — generally used to diagnose osteoporosis — have been mixed [(161-164)](#reference161). Further, two [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of observational studies reported no significant associations between coffee intake and risk of hip fracture [(165, 166)](#reference165). A third meta-analysis of six case-control and nine prospective cohort studies found no overall association between coffee intake and total fracture [(167)](#reference167). Yet, a gender subgroup analysis of eight studies showed a 14% increased risk of fracture in women — but not in men — with the highest versus lowest intakes of coffee. Another subgroup analysis of six studies found a 35% increased risk of osteoporotic fracture in participants with the highest versus lowest intakes of coffee [(167)](#reference167). Current evidence is scarce to suggest that coffee consumption could increase the risk of bone loss and fracture. Limiting coffee consumption to 3 cups/day while ensuring adequate [calcium](../minerals/calcium) and [vitamin D](../vitamins/vitamin-D) intakes should prevent any potential adverse effects on calcium absorption and bone health. [Phenolic compounds](../glossary#phenolic-compound) in coffee can bind [nonheme iron](../minerals/iron#non-heme-iron) and inhibit its [intestinal](../glossary#small-intestine) absorption [(168)](#reference168). Drinking 150 to 250 mL of coffee with a test meal has been found to inhibit iron absorption by 24%-73% [(169, 170)](#reference169). To maximize iron absorption from a meal or supplements, people with poor iron status should not consume coffee at the same time. Habitual caffeine consumption increases hepatic [cytochrome P450](../glossary#cytochrome-P450) (CYP) 1A2 activity, which has implications for the [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) for a number of medications [(171)](#reference171). Conversely, drugs that inhibit the activity of CYP1A2 interfere with the metabolism and elimination of caffeine, thereby increasing the [risk](../glossary#risk) of adverse effects [(172)](#reference172). The following medications may impair the [hepatic](../glossary#hepatic) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of caffeine, delaying its [excretion](../glossary#excretion) and potentially ephedrine and caffeine can lead to life-threatening adverse effects, including heart attack, [stroke](../health-disease/stroke), [seizures](../glossary#seizure), and death [(173)](#reference173). Use of the drug phenytoin (Dilantin) or cigarette smoking increases the hepatic metabolism of caffeine, resulting in increased elimination and decreased [plasma](../glossary#plasma) caffeine concentrations [(89)](#reference89). Caffeine and other methylxanthines may enhance the effects and side effects of -adrenergic stimulating agents, such as epinephrine and albuterol [(89](#reference89), [171)](#reference171). Caffeine doses of 400 to 1,000 mg may inhibit the [hepatic](../glossary#hepatic) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of the antipsychotic medication, clozapine clozapine concentration and increasing the [risk](../glossary#risk) of toxicity. Those taking levothyroxine are advised to avoid drinking coffee at the same time they take their medication because coffee may reduce the absorption of levothyroxine in some patients. Caffeine consumption can decrease the elimination of theophylline, potentially increasing serum theophylline levels. Caffeine has been also found to decrease the systemic elimination of acetaminophen (i.e., paracetamol) and to increase the [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of aspirin, which may partially explain its efficacy in enhancing their analgesic effects. This is important because many pain-relievers on the market today combine caffeine with aspirin and/or acetaminophen. Further, caffeine may decrease the bioavailability of lithium and alendronate (Fosamax) by enhancing their elimination [(173)](#reference173). Contents Tea is an infusion of the leaves of the Camellia sinensis plant and, aside from water, is the most widely consumed beverage in the world [(1)](#references). Different processing methods of tea leaves involve variable degrees of oxidation yielding different types of tea (green, oolong, or black tea). In 2014, Americans consumed 3.6 billion gallons of tea, of which 84% was black tea, 15% was green tea, and the remaining was white, oolong, and dark tea [(2)](#reference2). Herbal teas are infusions of herbs or plants other than Camellia sinensis and will not be discussed in this article. Although tea contains a number of bioactive chemicals, including caffeine and [fluoride](../minerals/fluoride), most research has focused on the potential health benefits of a class of compounds in tea known as [flavonoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/flavonoids). In many cultures, tea is an important source of dietary flavonoids. All teas are derived from the leaves of the tea plant Camellia sinensis, but different processing methods produce different types of tea. Fresh tea leaves are rich in polyphenolic compounds known as flavonoids (see the article on [Flavonoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/flavonoids)). contain a polyphenol oxidase (PPO) [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) in separate compartments from flavan-3-ol [monomers](../glossary#monomer) or catechins (Figure 2) [(3)](#reference3). When tea leaves are intentionally broken or rolled during processing, cell compartmentalization is disrupted and PPO comes into contact with catechins. This causes catechins to condense (join together) forming [dimers](../glossary#dimer) and [polymers](../glossary#polymer) known as theaflavins (Figure 3) and thearubigins, respectively [(4)](#reference4). This [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) process is often described as "fermentation" in the tea industry. Steaming, firing, or baking tea leaves inactivates PPO and stops the oxidation process [(5)](#reference5). The two prominent varieties of Camellia sinensis used in tea cultivation are Camellia sinensis var. sinensis and Camellia sinensis var. assamica. The former is native of China and usually used to make white and green tea. The latter originates from the Assam region of India, as well as regions of Southeast Asia, and is often used to make black teas, including pu-erh tea in the Yunnan province of China. Although there are thousands of tea cultivars derived from the principal Camellia sinensis tea varieties, teas are usually divided into five types based on the extent of oxidation they undergo during processing. The withering method (the process of allowing the fresh leaves to dry) and the process of deactivating PPO may also differ among tea preparations [(1)](#references). White tea is made from unopened buds and immature leaves, which are steamed or fired to inactivate polyphenol oxidase, and then dried. Thus, due to minimal oxidation, white tea retains the high concentrations of catechins present in fresh tea leaves (see [Flavonoids](#flavonoids) below). Green tea is made from more mature tea leaves than white tea, and tea leaves may be withered prior to steaming or firing, and then rolled and dried. Like white teas, green teas are high in catechins, but the total content and composition of catechins may vary depending on the cultivar and the commercial source [(6)](#reference6). Of note, green teas and white teas may sometimes contain similar amounts of catechins but still exhibit different [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) capacities; this is due to the presence of other non-catechin antioxidants in teas [(6)](#reference6). Tea leaves destined to become oolong teas are "bruised" to allow the release of some of the polyphenol oxidase present in the leaves. Oolong teas are allowed to [oxidize](../glossary#oxidation) to a greater extent than for white or green teas, but for less time than black teas, before they are heated and dried. Consequently, the catechin, theaflavin, and thearubigin levels in oolong teas are generally between those of unfermented green and white teas and completely oxidized black teas [(1)](#references). Tea leaves destined to become black tea are fully rolled or broken to maximize the interaction between catechins and polyphenol oxidase. Because they are allowed to [oxidize](../glossary#oxidation) completely before drying, most black teas are relatively low in [monomeric](../glossary#monomer) flavan-3-ols, like (-)-epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG), [Table 1](#table-1) shown greater [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) activities than EGCG [(7)](#reference7). Most pu-erh tea is produced in the Yunnan province of China from the larger leaves of the assamica variety of Camellia sinensis. The making process may include both [enzymatic](../glossary#enzyme) [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) and fungus-led [fermentation](../glossary#fermentation). In the case of "raw (aged) pu-erh tea," the initial preparation resembles that used to make green tea. The leaves are heated, dried, and then dampened before being pan-fired and compressed; the preparation is then carefully stored in a controlled environment and left to age for decades. A faster aging process, combining oxidation and fermentation by the fungus Aspergillus niger for several months, can also be used to produce "ripened pu-erh tea." The definition of a cup of tea varies in different countries or regions. In Japan, a typical cup of green tea may contain only 100 mL (3.5 ounces). A traditional European teacup holds approximately 125 to 150 mL (5 ounces), while a mug of tea may contain about 240 mL (8 ounces). Tea contains over 2,000 components, including polyphenols [elements](../glossary#element) [(8)](#reference8). Only some of them are described below. Dietary flavonoids are divided in six subclasses: flavan-3-ols, anthocyanidins, on [Flavonoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/flavonoids)). Total flavonoid content in green tea and black tea is of about 138 mg and 118 mg per 100 mL, respectively [(9)](#reference9). A major subclass of flavonoids in tea is that of flavan-3-ols. Flavan-3-ol monomers, also known as catechins, constitute 30%-42% of the solid weight of brewed green tea. The principal catechins found in tea are (-)-epicatechin polyphenol oxidase during the [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) process that yields black tea, they form low molecular weight [dimers](../glossary#dimer) known as theaflavins (see [Figure 3](#figure-3)) and complex [polymers](../glossary#polymer) (of mostly unknown structures) called thearubigins. Tea is also a good source of another class of flavonoids called flavonols. Flavonols found in tea include kaempferol, quercetin, and myricetin. The flavonol content of tea is minimally affected by processing, and flavonols are present in comparable quantities in oxidized and non-oxidized teas. Unlike flavan-3-ols, flavonols are usually present in tea as [glycosides](../glossary#glycoside), i.e., bound to a sugar molecule (Figure 4). Despite their poor bioavailability, flavonoids are thought to contribute substantially to the health benefits associated with daily tea consumption [(10)](#reference10). For more detailed information, see the article on [Flavonoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/flavonoids). All teas contain caffeine, unless they are deliberately decaffeinated during processing. The caffeine content of different varieties of tea may vary considerably and is influenced by factors like brewing time, the amount of tea and water used for brewing, and whether the tea is loose or in teabags. In general, a mug of tea contains about half as much caffeine as a mug of coffee [(11)](#reference11). The caffeine contents of more than 20 green and black teas prepared according to package directions are presented in Table 2 [(12)](#reference12). The caffeine content of oolong teas is comparable to green teas [(13)](#reference13). There is little information on the caffeine content of white teas, since they are often grouped together with green teas [(14)](#reference14). Buds and young tea leaves have been found to contain higher levels of caffeine than older leaves [(15)](#reference15), suggesting that the caffeine content of some white teas may be slightly higher than that of green teas the [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system), thought to protect adenosine has mostly inhibitory effects in the central nervous system, the effects of adenosine antagonism by caffeine are generally stimulatory. Tea plants accumulate [fluoride](../minerals/fluoride) in their leaves. In general, the oldest tea leaves contain the most fluoride [(19)](#reference19). Most high-quality teas are made from the bud or the first two to four leaves — the youngest leaves on the plant. Fluoride levels in green, oolong, and black teas are generally comparable to those recommended for the prevention of [dental caries](../glossary#dental-caries) (cavities). Thus, daily consumption of up to one liter of green, oolong, black, or pu-erh tea would be unlikely to result in fluoride intakes higher than those recommended for dental health [(20, 21)](#reference20). The fluoride content of white tea is likely to be less than other teas, since white teas are made from the buds and youngest leaves of the tea plant. A comparative study of green, oolong, and black teas from six provinces of China found that fluoride content was [inversely correlated](../glossary#inverse-association) with the quality level of tea sensory attributes (i.e., appearance, taste, flavor) [(22)](#reference22). The fluoride content of 17 brands of green, oolong, and black teas is presented in Table 3 [(20)](#reference20). These values do not include the fluoride content of the water used to make the tea.
