Eur J Clin Nutr. 2007;61(10):1174-1179. ] [(PubMed)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17299492) Contents While excessive alcohol consumption has been linked to a number of serious health and social problems, [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have associated moderate alcohol consumption with some important health benefits. The relationship between alcohol consumption and mortality is often described as J-shaped, meaning that when graphed from alcohol abstinence on the left to heavy drinking on the right, light-to-moderate alcohol consumption (2 drinks/day) is associated with lower rates of mortality — mostly from [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) — than abstention, while heavy alcohol consumption (>3-4 drinks/day) is associated with higher rates of mortality from a number of causes [(3-5)](#reference3). Because the consumption of alcohol can be viewed as a "double-edged sword," individual decisions regarding alcohol use should take into consideration scientific evidence regarding potential health benefits and [risks](../glossary#risk), as well as personal and family histories of health problems and addictions. It is important to note the data on alcohol-disease relationships come from only observational studies, not [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), and observational data cannot establish causation. In observational research, potential [confounding](../glossary#confounder) variables should be adequately adjusted for using statistical techniques. For instance, nondrinkers have been shown to differ from those who consume alcohol in ways that might affect the disease outcome of interest [(6)](#reference6). Even when controlling for many potential confounders, [residual confounding](../glossary#residual-confounding) may still occur. A standard alcoholic drink contains approximately 14 grams of alcohol, which is equivalent to 12 ounces of beer (~5% alcohol), 8.5 ounces of malt liquor (~9% alcohol), 5 ounces of wine (~12% alcohol), 3.5 ounces of fortified wine (e.g., sherry or port), or 1.5 ounces of liquor (distilled spirits; ~40% alcohol). *In addition to weighing less, on average, women absorb and metabolize alcohol differently than men. In general, women have less body water than men of similar body weight, so women achieve higher blood alcohol concentrations after drinking equivalent amounts of alcohol [(10)](#reference10). Women also appear to be more vulnerable to adverse health effects of heavy drinking than men. Thus, most definitions of "moderate" or "heavy" drinking offer a lower threshold for women. Data from [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have shown that light-to-moderate alcohol consumption (1 drink/day for women and 2 drinks/day for men) is protective against all-cause mortality [(4](#reference4), [11-15)](#reference11). As mentioned above, a J-shaped relationship is apparent when all-cause mortality is plotted against alcohol consumption (alcohol abstinence on the left and heavy drinking on the right of the x-axis) [(4](#reference4), [16)](#reference16). In other words, those who drink moderately have the lowest [risk](../glossary#risk) of total mortality when compared to nondrinkers and heavy drinkers, and heavy drinkers have the highest risk of mortality. The association of reduced mortality with moderate alcohol consumption is largely attributed to a decrease in cardiovascular mortality [(14](#reference14), [16-18)](#reference16), especially from coronary heart disease (see [Cardiovascular disease](#cardiovascular-disease-potential-benefits-moderate-consumption) below). However, concern has been raised that some earlier observational studies have misclassified former drinkers in the lifetime abstention group (i.e., the referent group), but most recent studies have not supported such a 'misclassification hypothesis' [(15, 16](#reference15), [19)](#reference19). Over the past four decades, the most consistent evidence of a health benefit associated with moderate alcohol consumption has been a significant reduction in the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [coronary heart disease](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease) (CHD) — a finding confirmed by a large number of [epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study). When the results of 28 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) were combined in a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis), adults who consumed an average of 25 grams/day of alcohol (the amount in two standard alcoholic drinks) had a risk of CHD that was 20% lower than adults who did not consume alcohol [(20)](#reference20). More recent data from two large prospective cohort studies conducted in the US suggest that the magnitude of CHD risk reduction associated with moderate alcohol consumption may be closer to 30%. In a 12-year study of more than 38,000 male health professionals, those who consumed alcohol at least 3-4 times weekly had a risk of [myocardial infarction](../glossary#myocardial-infarction) (heart attack) that was 32% lower than men who drank alcohol less than once weekly [(21)](#reference21). Similarly, in a 20-year study of more than 120,000 men and women, those who reported consuming 1-2 alcoholic drinks daily had a risk of death from CHD that was 30% lower than those who did not drink alcohol [(22)](#reference22). A 2011 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and meta-analysis of 29 studies found that alcohol consumption was associated with a 29% reduced risk of CHD compared to abstention; intakes of 2.5 to 60.0 grams/day of alcohol were associated with a lower risk of CHD [(16)](#reference16). [How does alcohol consumption reduce CHD risk? The development of ] [CHD](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease) is characterized by the formation of [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol)-laden plaque in the arteries ( [atherosclerosis](../glossary#atherosclerosis)), vascular [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation), and clot formation [(23)](#reference23). Numerous small, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) trials have examined the effect of daily alcohol consumption on markers of CHD [risk](../glossary#risk), consistently finding that moderate alcohol consumption significantly increases concentrations of [high-density lipoprotein](../glossary#HDL) (HDL)-cholesterol — the 'good cholesterol from tissues, including arterial walls, back to the liver for elimination or recycling. In addition to increasing HDL levels, moderate alcohol consumption has been shown to increase apolipoprotein A1, a major component of circulating HDL [(25)](#reference25). Higher levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL)-cholesterol have been associated with reductions in CHD risk [(26)](#reference26). Alcohol may also have anti-thrombotic properties. Clot formation is the result of complex interactions between factors that promote [coagulation](../glossary#coagulation) and factors that inhibit coagulation or promote the dissolution of clots. Several randomized trials have found that moderate alcohol consumption decreases [serum](../glossary#serum) levels of fibrinogen, a [protein](../glossary#protein) that promotes clot formation [(25)](#reference25) and increases serum levels of an [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) that helps dissolve clots (tissue type plasminogen activator) [(24)](#reference24). Further, moderate alcohol consumption may have an anti-inflammatory effect since serum levels of C-reactive protein (CRP), a marker of systemic inflammation and sensitive predictor of CHD risk, are lower in people who drink moderately than those who abstain from alcohol [(27-32)](#reference27). Moderate alcohol consumption has also been associated with improvements in adiponectin levels [(25)](#reference25), [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) (see [(33)](#reference33), and [endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) function [(34)](#reference34). Does the type of alcohol consumed (wine, beer, or liquor) affect CHD risk? Significant reductions in [CHD](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease) [risk](../glossary#risk) have been associated with moderate consumption of wine, beer, and liquor. However, the "French Paradox" — the observation that mortality from CHD is relatively low in France despite relatively high levels of dietary [saturated fat](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid) and cigarette smoking — led to the idea that regular consumption of red wine might provide additional protection from CHD [(35, 36)](#reference35). Red wine contains the phenolic compound resveratrol — although usually at variable and low concentrations (see the article on [Resveratrol](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/resveratrol#food-sources)) — as well as [flavonoids](../dietary-factors/phytochemicals/flavonoids) like procyanidins; these compounds could provide additional [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) benefits beyond those associated with ethanol. Beer also contains polyphenolic compounds that might confer some cardioprotection [(37)](#reference37). Some large [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have found wine drinkers to be at lower risk of CHD than beer or liquor drinkers [(22](#reference22), [38-40)](#reference38), but others have found no difference [(21](#reference21), [41, 42)](#reference41). Moreover, some studies have observed a decreased risk of [myocardial infarction](../glossary#myocardial-infarction) or CHD in predominantly beer-drinking populations in the Czech Republic [(43)](#reference43), in Germany [(44)](#reference44), and in Japanese men residing in Hawaii [(45)](#reference45). A 2011 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of prospective cohort and [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) found that moderate consumption of wine or beer was associated with a decreased risk of non-fatal vascular events [(46)](#reference46). This analysis did not associate drinking liquor with cardiovascular benefit, although the authors noted that binge drinking — which is known to increase CHD risk — was apparent in several of the included studies [(46)](#reference46). Socioeconomic status and lifestyle characteristics (e.g., tobacco use, exercise habits) may differ among people who prefer wine, beer, or liquor, and this may in part explain any additional benefit of one beverage type observed in some studies. For example, several early studies found that people who prefer wine tend to have higher incomes, have more formal education, smoke less, and eat more [fruit and vegetables](fruit-vegetables) and less [saturated fat](../glossary#saturated-fatty-acid) than people who prefer other alcoholic beverages [(47-49)](#reference47). These potential [confounders](../glossary#confounder) should be controlled or adjusted for in the analysis of [observational](../glossary#observational-study) data. Thus, although moderate alcohol consumption has been consistently associated with 20%-30% reductions in CHD risk, it is not yet clear whether drinking a specific type of alcoholic beverage might confer additional cardiovascular benefit. [Ischemic strokes](../glossary#ischemic-stroke), which represent 87% of all strokes, are the result of insufficient blood flow to an area of the brain, which may occur when an artery supplying the brain becomes blocked by a blood clot [(50)](#reference50). [Hemorrhagic strokes](../glossary#hemorrhagic-stroke) occur when a blood vessel ruptures and bleeds into the brain. Although they are less [prevalent](../glossary#prevalence) than ischemic strokes, hemorrhagic strokes are generally more severe and contribute disproportionately to overall stroke mortality [(51)](#reference51). Light or moderate alcohol consumption has been associated with a reduced [risk](../glossary#risk) of ischemic stroke, but not hemorrhagic stroke, in a number of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) [(52-58)](#reference52). When results of 19 [prospective cohort](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) and 16 [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) of alcohol consumption and the risk of stroke were combined in a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis), moderate alcohol consumption was associated with a significant reduction in the risk of ischemic stroke [(59)](#reference59). Overall, those who consumed one or two drinks daily had a 28% lower risk of ischemic stroke than those who did not consume alcohol. Another meta-analysis of more recent studies (1980-2009) confirmed that moderate alcohol consumption was protective against only ischemic stroke in both men and women [(60)](#reference60). A more recent meta-analysis of 27 prospective cohort studies found that light-to-moderate alcohol consumption (<15 grams/day) in women was associated with a reduced risk of ischemic ( [RR](../glossary#relative-risk), 0.72) but not hemorrhagic stroke; moderate alcohol consumption (15-30 grams/day) was not linked to either type of stroke in men in this analysis [(61)](#reference61). Thus, light-to-moderate alcohol consumption appears to decrease risk of ischemic stroke, but not hemorrhagic stroke, likely due to the anti-thrombotic effect of alcohol. Just as [atherosclerosis](../glossary#atherosclerosis) of the arteries supplying the heart muscle leads to [coronary heart disease](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease), atherosclerosis of the arteries of the extremities leads to [peripheral arterial disease](../glossary#peripheral-arterial-disease) (PAD). When atherosclerosis is severe enough to diminish blood flow to the legs, even walking may result in leg or hip pain known as [intermittent claudication](../glossary#intermittent-claudication) [(62)](#reference62). Impaired vascular endothelial function is also characteristic of the disease and may contribute to the clinical symptoms [(63)](#reference63). Although much less consistent than the evidence for heart disease and [stroke](../glossary#stroke), there is limited evidence that moderate alcohol consumption is associated with decreased risk of PAD. Four [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have found moderate alcohol consumption to be associated with significant decreases in several different indicators of PAD [(64-67)](#reference64). One of these studies found that the inverse association between alcohol intake and PAD risk was significant in nonsmokers but not smokers, suggesting that the adverse effects of cigarette smoking on PAD risk may outweigh any protective effects of alcohol consumption [(64)](#reference64). [Coronary heart disease](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease) is a major cause of heart failure. A prospective study in a cohort of 21,601 men and another in a cohort of 126,236 men and women found that moderate alcohol intake was [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with heart failure, especially heart disease related to CHD [(68, 69)](#reference68). More recently, in a cohort of 4,490 older adults (65 years or older at baseline) followed for more than 20 years (1,380 cases of heart failure), drinking one or more alcoholic drink per week was associated with a 26% lower risk of heart failure compared to abstainers [(70)](#reference70). While several studies have found that heavy alcohol consumption increases [risk](../glossary#risk) of sudden cardiac death (SCD; see [below](#arrhythmias-sudden-cardiac-death)), the association of light-to-moderate alcohol consumption and SCD is less clear. Studies on this association have reported mixed results, but the two largest prospective cohort studies to date have found a lower risk of SCD with light-to-moderate alcohol consumption [(71, 72)](#reference71). Three [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) have found a U-shaped relationship between alcohol consumption and incidence of type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), with greater protection being observed for women [(73-75)](#reference73). The most recent meta-analysis included 20 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) and associated moderate alcohol consumption (22-25 grams of alcohol daily or 1.6-1.8 drinks/day) with a 40% [risk](../glossary#risk) reduction for women and a 13% risk reduction for men compared to lifetime alcohol abstainers [(74)](#reference74). Heavy alcohol consumption (62 grams/day or 4.4. drinks/day for men and 51 grams/day or 3.6 drinks/day for women) was associated with an increased risk for type 2 diabetes [(74)](#reference74). Increased [insulin](../glossary#insulin) secretion by the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas) and decreased [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) are important factors leading to the development of type 2 diabetes. Research suggests that moderate alcohol intake may decrease [serum](../glossary#serum) insulin levels, increase adiponectin (an adipocyte hormone [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with type 2 diabetes) levels [(25)](#reference25), and improve insulin sensitivity [(76-79)](#reference76). On the other hand, heavy alcohol consumption may increase the risk of type 2 diabetes by contributing to obesity, especially abdominal obesity, disturbing [carbohydrate](../glossary#carbohydrate) [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), and/or impairing pancreatic or liver function [(80)](#reference80). [Osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis), a condition common among the elderly, results from progressive loss of [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) (BMD). Several [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have associated light or moderate alcohol consumption with higher BMD in older adults compared to abstainers [(81-91)](#reference81). Some studies have found stronger protective relationships among wine [(89)](#reference89) or beer drinkers [(89, 90)](#reference89) in comparison to those who consume liquor, suggesting that non-alcohol components (e.g., silicon in beer) might help explain the association. The effects of alcohol on bone health may also be dependent on age, gender, and hormonal status (reviewed in [92](#reference92)). It is important to note that the available data come from observational studies, and the observed associations may be [confounded](../glossary#confounder), e.g., individuals who consume alcohol in moderation may have an overall healthier lifestyle than those who drink heavily or abstain. However, a recent study in perimenopausal women found that moderate alcohol intake was associated with improved BMD independent of various lifestyle factors, including smoking status, [fruit and vegetable](fruit-vegetables) intake, and physical activity level [(90)](#reference90). Although alcoholism and heavy alcohol consumption (>3-4 drinks/day) is known to increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) impairment and [dementia](../glossary#dementia) [(93-95)](#reference93), recent [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) and reviews have reported that light-to-moderate alcohol consumption in older adults is associated with a decreased risk of dementia and [Alzheimer's disease](../glossary#alzheimer-disease) when compared to abstention [(93](#reference93), [96, 97)](#reference96). Some meta-analyses have not found a significant reduced risk for vascular type dementia [(96, 98)](#reference96) or for cognitive decline [(93](#reference93), [96](#reference96), [98, 99)](#reference98). A few studies have suggested that consumption of wine may be especially protective against dementia, although inconsistent findings have been observed, and many studies have not distinguished among the various types of alcohol. At least three [epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study) have used [magnetic resonance imaging](../glossary#magnetic-resonance-imaging) (MRI) to examine relationships between alcohol intake and [subclinical](../glossary#subclinical) abnormalities in the brains of healthy middle-aged or older adults. Two studies found that infarctions (areas of dead tissue) were less frequent in the brains of those reporting light or moderate alcohol intake compared to those who abstained from alcohol [(100, 101)](#reference100). However, another study found no relationship between alcohol intake and the presence of infarction [(102)](#reference102). Two of the studies measuring brain [atrophy](../glossary#atrophy), a characteristic of Alzheimer's disease and alcoholic dementia, found brain atrophy to be lower in those who abstained from alcohol compared to alcohol consumers [(100, 102)](#reference100). The other study found less brain atrophy with light-to-moderate alcohol consumption but only in carriers of the apolipoprotein E (APOE) 4 allele, who are at increased risk for Alzheimer's disease [(101)](#reference101). Because of the complex nature of alcohol's effects on the brain, further research is needed to determine the risks and benefits of alcohol consumption with respect to cognitive function and dementia. The majority of [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) [(103-107)](#reference103) and [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) [(108, 109)](#reference108) have found that men and women with moderate alcohol intakes have lower [risks](../glossary#risk) of [gallstones](../glossary#gallstones) or [gallbladder](../glossary#gallbladder) surgery (cholecystectomy) than those who do not consume alcohol. Although the reasons for the consistent [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between moderate alcohol consumption and gallstone incidence are not entirely clear, regular alcohol intake may result in [bile](../glossary#bile) that is less likely to crystallize into gallstones or stimulate gallbladder emptying [(106)](#reference106). Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) is a continuum of developmental abnormalities resulting from [gestational](../glossary#gestation) alcohol exposure; FASD may affect as many as 1%-2% of US children [(110, 111)](#reference110). Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) — a severe FASD — is a cluster of physical and mental birth defects associated with heavy alcohol consumption during pregnancy. Some characteristics of FAS include facial abnormalities, mental retardation, and growth impairment. More moderate alcohol consumption during pregnancy (7-14 drinks/week) has been associated with more subtle effects on [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) and behavioral development [(112, 113)](#reference112). Children of mothers who drank moderately during pregnancy have been found to have problems with memory, attention and learning, and behavior [(114)](#reference114). Overall, studies on the association of low-to-moderate drinking during pregnancy and mental health of offspring have reported mixed results (reviewed in [115](#reference115)). However, it is important to note that these studies are [observational](../glossary#observational-study) in nature and may have not adequately controlled for potential [confounding](../glossary#confounder) factors (e.g., lifestyle differences [in women who drank alcohol during pregnancy versus those who abstained] that influence mental development) [(115)](#reference115). Since no safe level of alcohol consumption has been established at any stage of pregnancy, pregnant women and women who are planning a pregnancy should abstain from alcohol [(116, 117)](#reference116). More than 100 [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have been completed on the association between alcohol consumption and female breast [cancer](../glossary#cancer), with most finding an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) [(118-121)](#reference118). Even though the available data come from observational studies, many consider the association to be causal. Regular alcohol consumption as low as one or two drinks per day has been associated with modest but significant increases in breast cancer risk. A threshold for harm, however, is difficult to define due to potential underreporting of alcohol intake by heavy drinkers, which could result in heavy drinkers being misclassified as 'moderate alcohol consumers' [(122)](#reference122). A linear dose-dependent relationship between alcohol consumption and breast cancer risk has been observed for premenopausal and postmenopausal breast cancer regardless of the type of alcoholic beverage consumed. Pooled and [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) have found that each 10-gram increase in daily alcohol consumption (slightly less than one drink) is associated with a 7%-10% increased risk of breast cancer in women [(123-125)](#reference123). Studies of alcohol consumption and breast cancer-specific mortality have reported mixed results, with a recent meta-analysis of 25 prospective cohort studies finding an increased risk only with alcohol consumption in excess of 20 grams (1.4 drinks)/day [(126)](#reference126). Moderate alcohol consumption has been consistently associated with reduced risk of all-cause mortality (see [Mortality](#mortality) above). Although the mechanisms for the consistent association between alcohol intake and breast cancer incidence have not been clearly identified, proposed mechanisms include acetaldehyde formation, induction of CYP2E1 metabolism and increased [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress), increased circulating [estrogen](../glossary#estrogen) or androgen levels, and enhanced invasiveness of breast cancer cells [(119](#reference119), [127)](#reference127). Current estimates are that about one in eight women (12.4%) in the US will develop breast cancer at some point in her lifetime [(128)](#reference128). Although there are many risk factors for breast cancer, alcohol consumption is one of only a few modifiable risk factors. Alcohol interferes with the absorption, transport, and [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) of folate, which is required for [DNA](../glossary#DNA) [methylation](../glossary#methylation) and DNA repair (see the article on [Folate](../vitamins/folate)). Alterations in these processes may result in [mutations](../glossary#mutation) or altered [gene expression](../glossary#gene-expression), which increase the risk of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [(118)](#reference118). Several [(129-134)](#reference129), but not all [(135-139)](#reference135), studies have found that sufficient folate intake may modify the association between alcohol intake and breast cancer risk. Although the interactions between folate, alcohol, and breast cancer risk remain to be clarified, it makes sense for women who drink alcohol to take a daily multivitamin containing 400 g of folic acid. Some people, such as recovering alcoholics and those with family histories of alcohol abuse or alcoholism, may not be able to maintain moderate drinking habits. Susceptibility to alcoholism is affected by genetic, psychosocial, and environmental factors. Children of an alcoholic parent have been found to be at significantly higher risk of developing alcoholism than those without an alcoholic parent [(140)](#reference140). This increase in risk is likely related to interactions between genetic factors and factors related to the family environment. The National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism recommends that people with a family history of alcoholism, especially in a parent, approach moderate drinking carefully [(141)](#reference141). In the liver, alcohol is metabolized by the same [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) as many medications. Therefore, alcohol consumption can affect the activation or breakdown of a number of medications. The consumption of alcohol may also increase sedation, drowsiness, and hypotensive effects caused by numerous prescription and over-the-counter medications. Although serious interactions between alcohol and medications are more common in the presence of heavy alcohol consumption, even moderate alcohol consumption may hypothetically increase the risk of some adverse reactions in susceptible people [(142)](#reference142). Women and older adults are particularly at [risk](../glossary#risk) for interactions between alcohol and medications [(143, 144)](#reference143). Many different classes of prescription medication may interact adversely with alcohol, including antibiotics, [anticonvulsants](../glossary#anticonvulsant), [anticoagulants](../glossary#anticoagulant) (e.g., Coumadin), antidepressants, antidiabetic pain relievers. Over-the-counter medications and herbal preparations may also interact with alcohol, including pain medications like aspirin, acetaminophen (Tylenol), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), and medications like cimetidine and herbal preparations like chamomile, valerian, and kava. To help avoid potentially serious interactions between alcohol and medications, make sure your health care provider is aware of your alcohol intake. Before taking prescription or over-the-counter medications, read the product warning labels or consult a pharmacist or health care provider to determine whether alcohol consumption increases the risk of adverse effects. It may, in general, be advisable to separate taking any medication and drinking alcohol by two to three hours. For more information on potentially serious interactions between alcohol and medications, see the [National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism website](http://pubs.niaaa.nih.gov/publications/aa27.htm). None Heavy consumption of alcohol during pregnancy causes fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). See [above](#pregnancy). Heavy alcohol consumption has been consistently associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of high blood pressure ( [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension)) review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 12 prospective cohort studies found consuming 50 grams (3.6 drinks)/day of alcohol was associated with a 1.6-fold and 1.8-fold higher risk of hypertension in men and women, respectively; alcohol intake at twice that level (100 grams (~7 drinks)/day) was associated with a [relative risk](../glossary#relative-risk) of 2.5 for men and 2.8 for women [(148)](#reference148). The results of numerous [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) indicate that reducing alcohol intake lowers blood pressure in hypertensive and normotensive individuals. A meta-analysis that combined the results of 15 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found that reducing alcohol consumption resulted in significant decreases in both [systolic](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) and [diastolic blood pressure](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) [(149)](#reference149). [Ischemic strokes](../glossary#ischemic-stroke) are the result of insufficient blood flow to an area of the brain, which may occur when an artery supplying the brain becomes blocked by a blood clot. [Hemorrhagic strokes](../glossary#hemorrhagic-stroke) occur when a blood vessel ruptures and bleeds into the brain. Although regular, moderate alcohol consumption has been associated with decreased [risk](../glossary#risk) of ischemic stroke in some studies, heavy alcohol consumption has been associated with increased risk of both ischemic stroke and hemorrhagic stroke. A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) that combined the results of 19 [prospective cohort](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) and 16 [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) found that heavy drinking more than doubled the risk of hemorrhagic stroke and increased the risk of ischemic stroke by 70% [(59)](#reference59). A meta-analysis of recent studies (1980-2009) confirmed that heavy drinking is associated with increased risks of ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke in both men and women [(60)](#reference60). Heavy alcohol consumption may increase the risk of stroke by contributing to [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension), [cardiomyopathy](../glossary#cardiomyopathy) (heart muscle damage), cardiac rhythm disturbances, and [coagulation](../glossary#coagulation) (clotting) disorders and impaired [hemostasis](../glossary#hemostasis). The long-recognized association between bouts of heavy alcohol consumption and cardiac rhythm disturbances ( [arrhythmias](../glossary#arrhythmia)) was called "holiday heart syndrome" because it was first described in people who were admitted to hospitals after holidays or weekends [(150)](#reference150). [Atrial fibrillation](../glossary#atrial-fibrillation) is the cardiac arrhythmia most commonly associated with heavy alcohol use [(151, 152)](#reference151). A 2010 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) found a dose-dependent association between daily alcohol consumption and [risk](../glossary#risk) of this type of cardiac arrhythmia, with an increased risk being found with consumption greater than 24 grams/day (1.7 drinks/day) for women and 36 grams/day (2.6 drinks/day) for men [(153)](#reference153). A 2014 meta-analysis of seven [prospective studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) found that consumption of more than two drinks per day was associated with increased risk of atrial fibrillation in men and women, and the risk increased by 8% with each additional daily drink [(154, 155)](#reference154). Additionally, several studies have found that heavy alcohol consumption (>5 drinks per day) increases risk of sudden cardiac death (SCD) [(156, 157)](#reference156). The ways by which alcohol may trigger arrhythmias and SCD are not fully known. Alcohol may interfere with the contractility of heart muscle cells, change the shape and structure of heart muscle cells, contribute to [electrolyte](../glossary#electrolytes) imbalance, and/or induce [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) [(158)](#reference158). Alcoholic [cardiomyopathy](../glossary#cardiomyopathy) is a heart muscle disease caused by long-term, heavy alcohol consumption [(159)](#reference159); this disease likely occurs in only a small proportion (<10%) of heavy drinkers [(160)](#reference160). Alcoholic cardiomyopathy occurs in two stages: (1) an early asymptomatic stage, when the damage to the heart muscle has no obvious symptoms; and (2) a symptomatic stage, when the heart muscle is too weak to pump effectively. Although the level of alcohol consumption resulting in alcoholic cardiomyopathy has not been clearly established, people consuming at least seven alcoholic drinks daily for more than five years are thought to be at risk of developing asymptomatic alcoholic cardiomyopathy. Those who continue to drink heavily ultimately develop heart failure. Research suggests that women may be more susceptible to alcohol's toxic effects on the heart muscle than men [(161, 162)](#reference161). Chronic excessive alcohol use is a major cause of illness and death from liver disease [(163)](#reference163). Alcoholic liver disease is characterized by a spectrum of liver injury, including [steatosis](../glossary#steatosis) (fatty liver), [hepatitis](../glossary#hepatitis) (a potentially fatal [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) of the liver), fibrosis, and [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis) — the most advanced form of alcoholic liver disease. In cirrhosis, the formation of fibrotic scar tissue results in progressive deterioration of liver function. Complications of advanced liver disease include severe bleeding from distended veins in the [esophagus](../glossary#esophagus) (esophageal varices), brain damage (hepatic encephalopathy), fluid accumulation in the abdomen (ascites), and kidney failure. A 2004 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of nine studies found a dose-responsive increase in risk for liver cirrhosis with increasing amounts of alcohol consumed: [relative risks](../glossary#relative-risk) (RR) of 2.9 for 25 grams (1.8 drinks)/day, 7.1 for 50 grams (3.6 drinks)/day, 26.5 for 100 grams (7.1 drinks)/day [(164)](#reference164). Another meta-analysis found a higher RR for liver cirrhosis with increasing doses but also suggested a threshold response for morbidity from liver cirrhosis (higher risk in women with consumption >24 g (1.7 drinks)/day of alcohol, and higher risk in men with consumption >36 g (2.6 drinks)/day of alcohol) [(165)](#reference165). Risk of mortality from liver cirrhosis was increased with any alcohol consumption in women and with consumption of >12 g (0.9 drinks)/day in men; a stronger relationship between alcohol consumption and mortality from liver cirrhosis versus morbidity might be expected because alcohol consumption is known to exacerbate any existing liver disease [(165)](#reference165). Serious liver disease has been found to develop in approximately 10% of those who consume more than 60 grams per day of alcohol (4.3 drinks/day). Women are more susceptible to serious alcoholic liver disease than men [(165, 166)](#reference165), and individuals with hepatitis C infection have an increased risk of alcoholic liver disease [(167)](#reference167). Heavy alcohol consumption has been found to increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) at a number of sites [(168)](#reference168). Heavy alcohol consumption is consistently and dose-dependently associated with increases in risk of cancers of the mouth, pharynx, [larynx](../glossary#larynx), [esophagus](../glossary#esophagus), liver, [colon](../glossary#colon), [rectum](../glossary#rectum), and breast [(165)](#reference165). Moreover, the combination of smoking and alcohol results in even more dramatic increases in cancer risks [(169)](#reference169). Increased risk of liver cancer with long-term heavy alcohol consumption may be related to alcoholic [cirrhosis](../glossary#cirrhosis) of the liver or increased susceptibility to cancer caused by [viral](../glossary#virus) [hepatitis](../glossary#hepatitis). Chronic heavy alcohol use and alcohol dependence are associated with detrimental effects on the brain and its function, especially memory and [executive functions](../glossary#executive-function) [(170)](#reference170). Alcoholics have been observed to suffer from [cerebral](../glossary#cerebral) [atrophy](../glossary#atrophy) (shrinkage of brain tissue), which likely contributes to alcohol-associated [dementia](../glossary#dementia) and [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) impairment [(94)](#reference94). In contrast to the cerebral atrophy observed in [Alzheimer's disease](../glossary#alzheimer-disease), alcohol-related cerebral atrophy may decrease after a period of abstinence. Alcohol-related brain disorders may be associated with nutritional deficiencies like [thiamin](../vitamins/thiamin) [(171)](#reference171) or [niacin](../vitamins/niacin) [(172)](#reference172). Pancreatitis is a painful [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) of the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas). Acute pancreatitis is characterized by the sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting [(173)](#reference173). Although most attacks of acute pancreatitis require only supportive care, a small percentage of people may experience serious or life-threatening complications. Studies estimate that 19%-32% of acute pancreatitis cases have an alcoholic [etiology](../glossary#etiology) (reviewed in [174](#reference174)). Chronic pancreatitis results in progressive destruction of the pancreas, leading to loss of pancreatic function [(175)](#reference175). An estimated 60%-72% of chronic pancreatitis cases have an alcoholic etiology. The risk of developing chronic pancreatitis increases with the quantity and duration of alcohol consumed: an increased risk of chronic pancreatitis is observed with long-term consumption of five or more alcoholic drinks per day [(174)](#reference174). Only a small percentage (<10%) of alcoholics develop clinical pancreatitis; thus, hereditary and environmental factors are also thought to play a role. The disease is more common in men than in women, in Blacks compared to Whites, and in smokers versus nonsmokers [(176, 177)](#reference176). Chronic alcoholism has deleterious effects on [bone health](../micronutrients-health/bone-health), including decreased [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) and increased risk of [fracture](../glossary#fracture). Consumption of large quantities of alcohol (100-200 grams/day) directly impairs activity of [osteoblasts](../glossary#osteoblast) — the bone-forming cells. Negative effects on bone health are also indirectly caused by the malnutrition experienced by alcoholics [(92)](#reference92). Alcohol use is associated with an increased risk of injury in a number of circumstances, including motor vehicle accidents, falls, and fires [(178)](#reference178). Data from hospital emergency departments indicate that consuming as little as one or two alcoholic drinks in the previous six hours significantly increases the risk of injury [(179)](#reference179). Thirty-one percent of all traffic fatalities in the US are alcohol-related [(180)](#reference180). Although the legal blood alcohol concentration (BAC) limit for drivers is 0.08 (grams of alcohol/deciliter of blood) in the US, most scientific studies have found significant impairment of driving-related skills at a BAC of 0.05 [(181)](#reference181). For reference, a BAC of 0.05 might be achieved by a 175-pound male consuming three standard alcoholic drinks in one hour or a 120-pound female consuming two drinks in one hour [(182)](#reference182). Excessive alcohol use is associated with all forms of violence, including suicide, homicide, domestic violence, sexual assault, and gang violence. Although the reasons for alcohol-associated violence are complex, alcohol use appears to increase the risk of violent behavior in some populations [(183)](#reference183). Heavy alcohol consumption increases the [risk](../glossary#risk) of mortality [(4](#reference4), [16)](#reference16). As mentioned [above](#mortality), the relationship between alcohol consumption and mortality is often described as J-shaped, meaning those with high intakes of alcohol have a higher risk of mortality than nondrinkers. A 2011 meta-analysis of eight [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) found that consumption of >60 grams/day of alcohol was associated with a 30% increase in mortality from all causes [(16)](#reference16). Accessed 10/3/07. Select a topic from the list for more information. Nutritional needs change throughout the life cycle. Growth and development during infancy, childhood, and adolescence require special intakes of many micronutrients. Nutritional needs also change throughout the stages of adulthood. For example, micronutrient requirements during pregnancy and lactation are increased, and micronutrient needs of older adults reflect age-related changes in nutrient absorption and metabolism. This section of the site is under development; new articles will be added in the future. Contents The period of childhood between ages 4 and 13 years is characterized by continued physical growth and rapid [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive), emotional, and social development [(1, 2)](#references). Many children, especially girls, undergo their pubertal growth spurt between ages 4 and 13. This period of childhood precedes adolescence — the transitional stage of development between childhood and adulthood. Due to increased growth and metabolism, the nutritional requirements of children are higher in proportion to body weight compared with adults [(1, 3)](#references). Good nutrition throughout childhood is important not only to support normal growth and cognitive development but also to establish healthy eating patterns that are associated with decreased risk of chronic conditions and diseases in adulthood, including [obesity](../glossary#obesity), type 2 [diabetes](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease), [metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome), and [osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis). Inadequate intake of nutrients can impair growth and development in children. This article discusses [micronutrient](../glossary#micronutrient) ( [vitamins](../glossary#vitamin) and nutritionally essential [minerals](../glossary#mineral)) requirements of children ages 4 to 13 years. The Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the Institute of Medicine establishes dietary reference intakes (DRIs) for each micronutrient; these reference values should be used to plan and assess dietary intakes in healthy people [(4, 5)](#reference4). The DRIs include the estimated average requirement ( [EAR](../glossary#EAR)), the recommended dietary allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)), the adequate intake ( [AI](../glossary#AI)), and the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)). The RDA, which is the average daily dietary intake level of a nutrient sufficient to meet the requirements of almost all (97.5%) healthy individuals in a specific life stage and gender group, should be used in the planning of diets for individuals [(6)](#reference6). An AI recommendation is set when an RDA cannot be determined. In children, these intake recommendations are based on data regarding average micronutrient intakes of children and also on certain criteria for micronutrient adequacy. However, because of limited data, many of the micronutrient intake recommendations for children are extrapolated from recommendations for adults using a formula that accounts for metabolic body weight and growth [(3)](#reference3). Metabolic body weight is determined by calculating the 0.75 power of body mass (body mass^0.75) [(7)](#reference7). To account for growth, the equation used to derive an RDA or AI involves an age group-specific growth factor [(3)](#reference3). The FNB establishes separate dietary intake recommendations for children between the ages of 4 to 8 years and those between the ages of 9 and 13 years (see [Ages 4 to 8 Years](#ages-4-to-8-years) and [Ages 9 to 13 Years](#ages-9-to-13-years)). For each [micronutrient](../glossary#micronutrient), the FNB sets an [RDA](../glossary#RDA) or [AI](../glossary#AI) for children ages 4 to 8 years; these micronutrient intake recommendations do not differ with gender for this age group. Table 1 lists the RDA for each micronutrient. As mentioned above, the RDA should be used in the planning of diets for individuals.
